site_title: Juncker pledges to boost auto tariffs if Trump reneges on agreement
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker pledged to boost auto tariffs if US President Donald Trump reneges on his agreement not to impose car tariffs. Juncker stated that the EU would respond in kind if the US imposes tariffs, and that the EU is willing to reduce its car tariffs to zero if the US does the same. The EU and US are at odds over various trade issues, including tariffs and the appointment of judges at the World Trade Organization.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, was named OCBC's incoming CEO after Helen Wong's retirement. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2. Singapore's affluents reported needing S$1.39 million to retire comfortably, and Tan Teck Long's salary is not specified in the article.

site_title: China's latest step to curb games and play wallops Tencent, Netease
summary: China's regulators plan to limit online game play and curb the number of games, part of a broader effort to address device addiction and myopia among children. The new regulations, which include discouraging outdoor activities and electronics usage, come as a freeze on game approvals has already muddied the industry. Tencent Holdings Ltd. and Netease Inc., China's two largest gaming companies, fell over 5% as investors reacted to the news. The regulations are part of a wider campaign against online content, casting doubt on the relationship between gaming companies and the government.

site_title: China banks managing US$16t can't stop talking about risk
summary: China's six largest banks, managing $16 trillion in assets, highlighted risk management in their first-half earnings announcements, with the word "risk" mentioned 1,900 times, a 9% increase from 2017. Despite slowing economic growth and corporate defaults, the banks reported lower bad-debt ratios and increased recovery rates, as they cut exposure to struggling industries. This shift in focus on risk management is attributed to the government's priority on controlling financial risk, with lenders aiming to prevent a record buildup of corporate debt from tipping the economy into a crisis.

site_title: Non-landed DC rates up 9.8% for fifth straight increase
summary: Singapore's development charge (DC) rate for non-landed private homes has increased by 9.8% for the fifth consecutive time, with rates also rising for commercial and industrial sites. The rate hike, effective until February 28, 2019, is attributed to property-cooling measures and reflects a cautious approach to land prices. Areas with significant increases include Tanglin Road, Cuscaden Road, and Bukit Merah, with rates rising by up to 33.3% and 27.9% respectively.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall on renewed fear of trade conflict
summary: European shares fell on Friday, with the Stoxx 600 down 0.8% and Germany's DAX down 1% due to renewed fears of a US-China trade conflict. Car stocks were particularly affected, falling 1.6% and marking their worst performance since the sector began tracking in 2001. The decline followed US President Donald Trump's plans to impose more tariffs on China.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit's CEO delays departure to Sept 2
summary: Cromwell European Reit's CEO, Philip Levinson, has delayed his departure to September 2, originally set for August 31. A new executive director and CEO will be appointed in early September. Levinson will remain in Singapore, pursuing advisory services and other business interests. The Reit's counter closed 1.74% up to 58.5 Singapore cents on Friday.

site_title: Keeping an eye on cash flow
summary: Improving cash flow management is crucial for a business's health. A healthy cash flow demonstrates that money is coming in and being used to settle expenses. To forecast cash flow better, small businesses can rely on their CEO and sales/ supplies buyers, while bigger businesses can use more complex forecasting methods. Poor cash flow management can lead to bankruptcy, even in profitable businesses. Effective cash flow management is vital for the success of any enterprise, and it's essential to identify potential problems before they arise.

site_title: India pushes back against tech 'colonisation' by internet giants
summary: India is pushing back against the dominance of US tech giants, such as Facebook and Google, in the country's internet landscape. Indian politicians view this as a form of "colonization," echoing the historical experience of being ruled by Britain. They are determined to reduce dependence on foreign tech companies and promote local alternatives. The Indian government is taking steps to encourage local app development and reduce the reliance on foreign platforms.

site_title: Flights suspended from Libyan capital Tripoli's only working airport: source
summary: Flights from Libya's Tripoli airport have been suspended due to intense fighting between rival militias, leaving at least 39 dead. The airport, Mitiga, was closed for at least 48 hours for security reasons after rockets landed near the facility. The Libyan capital has been at the center of a battle for influence since 2011. The internationally recognized Government of National Accord has charged forces with enforcing a ceasefire, but a commander has declared he must wait for a pause in fighting to intervene. The UN strongly condemns the loss of civilian lives and calls for a ceasefire.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corporation's subsidiary, DC Reit Holdings, has signed a sale and purchase agreement to sell approximately 55.1 million units of Keppel DC Reit for S$74.96 million, representing a 4.08% stake. The units were sold at a minimum price of S$1.36 per unit. The completion of the sale is expected on September 5, reducing Keppel's indirect interest in Keppel DC Reit from 29.27% to 25.2%.

site_title: China's August manufacturing outperforms expectations
summary: China's manufacturing PMI improved to 51.3 in August, beating expectations, driven by a pick-up in production and total new orders. Analysts attribute the slight improvement to recent government measures to support economic activity, including tax cuts and expedited bond sales. The slight uptick in the manufacturing PMI comes despite ongoing trade tensions with the US and a softening domestic economy. However, major sub-indexes underperformed, with new export orders and the import sub-index falling to 11-month lows.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as trade concerns weigh
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday for a second consecutive day, weighed down by concerns over ongoing trade talks between the US and other major economies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.08% to 25,964.85, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the Nasdaq falling 0.11% to 8,079.31. The decline followed a record rally for the major indexes earlier in the week, as investors remain uncertain about the impact of US trade policies on the global economy.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda: no rate hike "for an extended time": paper
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that interest rates are unlikely to be raised for an extended time, contradicting recent policy adjustments. The BOJ has pledged to keep interest rates "extremely low" while allowing the 10-year government bond yield to move in a slightly wider band around zero per cent, indicating a flexible policy approach. Economists believe this move is not preparation for policy normalization, suggesting the central bank is laying groundwork for eventual exit from its massive stimulus, but not expecting it soon.

site_title: Singapore bank lending cools in July
summary: Singapore bank lending declined 0.8% month-on-month in July, marking the first decline since January, according to preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Despite this, lending maintained a strong year-on-year growth of 6.9% from S$632.60 billion in July last year. The total domestic banking lending stood at S$667.53 billion in July.

site_title: Fintech and the disruption of financial services
summary: Fintech refers to the intersection of finance and technology, encompassing various technologies such as AI, big data, blockchain, and cloud computing. This evolution has the potential to disrupt financial services, forcing institutions and individuals to adapt for survival. The author's book, Fintech: The New DNA of Financial Services, provides a comprehensive view of fintech and its impact on the industry. Understanding fintech is crucial for its future development and its effects on the financial sector. The industry's ability to adapt will determine its success in the new world.

site_title: Electric vehicles: the next big investment opportunity?
summary: Global warming's devastating consequences, largely due to carbon dioxide emissions from cars, make Electric Vehicles a significant investment opportunity. Rising global sea levels, natural catastrophes, and governments' climate agreements, such as the Paris Climate Agreement, underscore the urgent need for change. With targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve energy efficiency, and increase renewable energy, Electric Vehicles are poised to drive growth and investment in the coming years.

site_title: Brazil electoral court bars Lula from presidential race
summary: Brazil's top electoral court ruled that jailed former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva cannot run in this year's presidential election due to a corruption conviction, with a 4-1 majority decision. Lula's lawyers have announced plans to appeal to the Supreme Court.

images.alt_text: Brazil's top electoral court ruled on Friday that jailed former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva cannot run in this year's presidential election due to a corruption conviction.

site_title: Silicon Valley exec pays SEC insider trading fine for tip-off to brothers
summary: A former senior executive at Qualys Inc, Amer Deeba, has agreed to pay a US$581,170 fine for insider trading. Deeba helped his two brothers sell their shares in the Silicon Valley company after learning it would report disappointing revenue, avoiding US$581,170 of losses. Deeba resigned as Qualys' chief commercial officer this month after the accusations. The SEC accused Deeba of providing his brothers with inside information in April 2015, just before the company's revenue forecast was cut and its share price plummeted 33%.

site_title: Price-quality evaluation to be default approach for govt procurement tenders
summary: The Singapore government will shift its procurement regime to use a price-and-quality evaluation approach as the default method for public tenders, aiming to promote innovation. This change maintains the guiding principles of value-for-money purchases and transparent processes. Minister for Education Ong Ye Kung stated that this upgrade will allow more capable agencies to experiment with different approaches.

site_title: Beijing's massive new airport 'on time' for 2019 launch
summary: Beijing's Daxing International Airport, set to become operational in June 2019, is a massive new mega airport aimed at easing passenger load from the city's other two airports. The airport, costing 63.9 billion yuan, will operate at full capacity by 2025 with eight runways expected to transport 72 million passengers annually, making it the world's busiest airport. Built with international standards and a workforce equivalent to one 18-storey building per day, the airport's construction is on schedule.

site_title: The long and short of it
summary: US investors should not rely solely on current market performance to predict future trends, as the impact of the China trade war may not be immediately apparent. While the Shanghai Index has seen a boost, Chinese businesses are not concerned about the tariffs, and major US companies like General Motors rely heavily on China for profits. Investors should look for signals of trend change, such as the successful testing of support levels on the Shanghai Index, before taking long or short positions. The S&P 500 remains strong, but investors should be cautious of potential trend reversals, such as head-and-shoulder patterns.

site_title: Market value of S'pore stocks shrinks as funds take cover from poor earnings visibility
summary: The combined value of Singapore stocks declined in August, marking the 10th consecutive year the market ends lower by an average of 4.2%. Funds are taking cover from poor earnings visibility and trade-war jitters, leading to a surge in defensive stocks. Oversold counters and yield plays also gained favor, but overall, the market experienced a weak performance.

images.alt_text: Cold Storage supermarkets (above) are a part of the Dairy Farm Group, whose shares have swung wildly but ultimately snapped back to their early-July highs.

site_title: Former Australian PM resigns from parliament, govt loses majority
summary: Former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull resigned from parliament, stripping the government of its one-seat majority. Turnbull's resignation follows a bitter party-room contest that ousted him from office, ushering in Scott Morrison as the country's sixth leader in a decade. Morrison now relies on independent lawmakers' support to pass legislation, hindering the government's agenda ahead of the 2019 election. The government faces a heavy defeat, with opinion polls showing the ruling Liberal-National coalition struggling to be re-elected.

images.alt_text: Australia's former prime minister Malcolm Turnbull on Friday resigned from parliament, a source familiar with the matter said, stripping the government of its one-seat parliamentary majority.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks head into weekend with hefty loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on Friday, closing 0.98% lower at 27,888.55, amid fears of US tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods set to be imposed early next month. The Hang Seng Index dropped 275.50 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell. The losses come as investors remain uncertain about the impact of trade tensions on global markets.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks up; won falls on Trump's trade threats
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.67% on Friday, driven by a decline in Asian shares due to US President Donald Trump's trade threats against Beijing. The won fell 0.39% against the dollar, while bond yields dropped. Despite a 6.5% decline in the year-to-date, Kospi analysts see potential for outperformance against other emerging markets.

site_title: From Sept 1, 2019, collecting NRIC numbers and making copies of identity cards will be illegal in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission has announced that as of September 1, 2019, it will be illegal for organizations to collect, use, or disclose NRIC numbers or make copies of identity cards. This rule change aims to protect individuals' personal data and prevent misuse.

images.alt_text: From Sept 1 next year, it will be illegal for organisations to collect, use or disclose NRIC numbers or make copies of the identity card, under stricter rules spelt out on Friday by the Personal Data Protection Commission.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% down on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 12.24 points to 3,213.48, finishing 0.4% lower on Friday, August 31, 2018. Losers outnumbered gainers 221 to 192, with 2.35 billion shares traded worth S$1.44 billion. Golden Agri-Resources was the most active, rising 3.64% to 28.5 Singapore cents. This marked the last trading day in August, with the index ending the month on a mixed note.

site_title: US: Stocks hold onto gains amid tense US-Canada talks
summary: US stocks maintained their gains on Friday, with the Nasdaq Composite rising 0.26% to 8,109.54, while the Dow Jones shed 0.09% to 25,964.82. The S&P 500 rose 0.01% to 2,901.52. Investors remained cautious ahead of a long weekend amid tense US-Canada trade talks, which have been ongoing. Despite the uncertainty, US stocks extended their rally, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 reaching fresh records.

site_title: UK house price rise slips back to five-year low: Nationwide
summary: British house prices grew 2.0% in August, the weakest pace in five years, according to Nationwide. This slowdown is the latest sign of a housing market decline since the 2016 Brexit vote. Economists had expected a 2.7% increase, with a 0.1% monthly rise forecast by a Reuters poll. Despite this, Nationwide still expects house prices to rise by 1% in 2018. The market slowdown reflects a broader economic slowdown since the Brexit vote, with economists predicting a 2% national increase in house prices this year and next.

site_title: Reits
summary: US mortgage rates have climbed after five straight weeks of declines, with no specific information on the rate increase provided in the article. In the real estate market, a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Manhattan rents have hit another record, with more increases anticipated. Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won worth of hotel and retail assets in Seoul. UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, according to an index. New World is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) announced a 9.8% increase in development charge rates for non-landed residential land use. This marks a decrease from the 22.8% hike in March. Meanwhile, Singapore bank lending eased in July, with a 0.8% decline from the previous month. Stricter rules on collecting and using NRIC numbers will take effect from September 1, 2019. The US and Vietnam are bracing for potential economic impacts from US tariffs, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Global funds raise stock allocations to four-month high
summary: Global investors raised their equity holdings to a four-month high in August, favoring Japan and emerging markets. Equity allocations rose to 48.3%, bonds fell to 38.8%, and cash decreased to 5.2%. Emerging-market equities fell 3% in August and 9% this year, but 63% of investors said it's time to buy emerging-market assets. Japanese equity holdings rose to 21.8% and bond allocations increased to 16.7%, with investors citing favorable valuations and business cycles.

site_title: Development charge rates raised by an average of 9.8% for non-landed residential land use
summary: Singapore's development charge (DC) rates for non-landed residential land use increased by an average of 9.8% from March, marking the fifth consecutive rise. The rates are based on land value assessments and are paid by developers for enhanced land use or larger projects. The largest increase was seen in sector 43, where the DC rate jumped by 33.3% to S$18,200 per square meter of gross floor area. The new rates will apply from September 1, 2018 to February 28, 2019, in an effort to cool the property market.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices hit another record but seen cooling as rates rise
summary: Hong Kong private home prices reached a record in July, rising 0.82% from June, with prices surging 11.6% this year and 16.6% year-on-year. However, rising interest rates, a slowing economy, and a depreciating yuan may cool the market, with some analysts predicting a 15% price drop over the next 12 months. Experts attribute the slowdown to the worst combination of fundamentals in 15 years, including rising interest rates and economic concerns.

site_title: Nets appoints OCBC COO Ching Wei Hong as next chairman
summary: OCBC Bank's COO Ching Wei Hong will become the next chairman of electronic funds transfer group Nets on September 1, replacing Tan Su Shan. Ching, who has been COO of OCBC since 2012, brings experience in the banking industry and innovative payment solutions. Nets CEO Jeffrey Goh praised Ching's credentials, while thanking Tan for her contributions to the company. Tan will remain a board director.

site_title: China's Meituan Dianping sets Hong Kong IPO valuation at up to US$55b: sources
summary: China's Meituan Dianping has set an indicative price range of HK$60 to HK$72 per share for its Hong Kong IPO, valuing itself at up to US$55 billion. The company, a food delivery-to-ticketing services platform, is discussing a valuation of US$46 billion to US$55 billion and plans to raise up to US$4 billion. Meituan's IPO includes a total of US$1.5 billion from five cornerstone investors, including Tencent Holdings and OppenheimerFunds.

site_title: Saudi Arabia hints at plan to turn Qatar into an island
summary: Saudi Arabia is reportedly moving forward with a plan to dig a 60km canal, potentially turning Qatar into an island, amid a 14-month-old diplomatic feud between the two Gulf nations. The project, estimated to cost up to 2.8 billion riyals, would physically separate the Qatari peninsula from the Saudi mainland. The plan has sparked concerns and no immediate reaction has been seen from Qatar. The dispute between Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt and Qatar began in June 2017, with Qatar accused of supporting terrorism and being too close to Iran.

site_title: How to build a sustainable bond portfolio
summary: Investors are increasingly seeking to align their bond portfolios with their social mission, but the fixed-income market has limited opportunities for sustainable investments. To address this gap, asset managers are tapping into overlooked asset classes such as affordable housing and development bank debt. Sustainable bond portfolios are emerging, with development bank debt and green bonds showing promising returns. Municipal bonds and ESG-rated bond portfolios are also gaining traction, with some funds focusing on impact investing in areas like affordable housing and environmentally-friendly buildings. As investors demand more ESG-friendly options, asset managers are working to create more sustainable fixed-income products.

site_title: South Korea's August export rise for second month but miss forecasts
summary: South Korea's exports rose 8.7% in August, driven by stronger demand for memory chips and petrochemicals, but missed forecasted growth of 10.1%. Exports reached $51.2 billion, while imports increased 9.2% to $44.3 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of $6.9 billion. Economists attribute the growth to a weaker won and robust US economy, but warn of potential risks if trade tensions between the US and China widen, potentially leading to a decline in exports.

site_title: Singapore bank lending eases in July with first m-o-m decline since January
summary: Singapore bank lending declined month-on-month in July for the first time since January, with a 0.8% drop to S$667.53 billion. This followed a record S$673.25 billion in June, and a 6.9% year-on-year increase. The decline was attributed to a 1.4% drop in business lending, while consumer lending remained steady. The drop in business lending was partly due to the impact of property cooling measures, which may lead to a slowdown in home loans.

site_title: Hong Kong private home prices hit another record in July
summary: Hong Kong private home prices reached a record high in July, with a 0.82% increase from June, extending a 28-month price surge. The 11.6% year-to-date growth and 16.6% year-over-year increase have raised concerns about the market's sustainability. Rising interest rates, a slowing economy, and depreciating yuan are expected to cool the market, with some analysts predicting a 15% price drop over the next 12 months.

site_title: ESR-Reit unitholders approve Viva Industrial Trust merger
summary: ESR-Reit unit holders approved a merger with Viva Industrial Trust, creating Singapore's fourth-largest industrial property trust. The merger received 94.2% approval, with 90% approval on related resolutions. Under the deal, ESR-Reit will acquire Viva's stapled securities for S$9.60 in cash and 160 new ESR-Reit units for every 100 stapled Viva securities.

site_title: China says will prevent haphazard investment in auto industry
summary: China's state planning agency has announced plans to prevent haphazard investment and low-level development in the automobile industry. According to Nian Yong, head of the National Development and Reform Commission's Department of Industrial Coordination, the goal is to promote sustainable development and prevent redundant investment. This move aims to maintain industry stability and support the development of the sector.

site_title: Never cook at home. Or, why I cook
summary: A home cook in New York City argues that there are many good reasons to never cook at home, citing the high cost of ingredients, unpredictability of farming, and exhaustion from work and family obligations. Despite the challenges, the author enjoys cooking for its focus, concentration, and reward of a delicious meal. They acknowledge the benefits of cooking, but prioritize convenience and the avoidance of stress and responsibility, instead opting for restaurant delivery or takeout.

site_title: Double stabbing at Amsterdam station in possible terror attack
summary: A 19-year-old Afghan man with a German residency permit stabbed two people at Amsterdam's Central Station before being shot by police in a suspected terror attack. The assailant, who is in custody, has been questioned about his motive. Witnesses described scenes of panic as gunshots rang out, and thousands of commuters and tourists were evacuated. The incident has raised concerns about the threat level in the Netherlands, which has been spared from recent terror attacks in neighboring countries.

images.alt_text: A knife attacker on Friday stabbed two people at Amsterdam's Central Station before being shot by police in a suspected terror attack, Dutch police said.

site_title: Apple expected to unveil new phone models, including rumoured iPhone XS, on Sept 12
summary: Apple is set to unveil new iPhone models, including a rumored iPhone XS, on September 12 at the Steve Jobs Theater. Analysts expect three new smartphones to be released this year, including one with a larger display and another with an edge-to-edge display using LCD screen technology. The event is expected to include a gold-colored iPhone model, similar to the iPhone X, which was previously only available in silver and gray. Apple shares reached an all-time high of $227.97 after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Apple's event invitation made heavy use of the colour gold, fuelling speculation on social media that the company plans to launch a gold-coloured successor to the iPhone X (above).

site_title: Asian markets end week lower after rollercoaster ride
summary: Asian markets ended a rollercoaster week lower, despite initial optimism from US-Mexico Nafta talks. US President Donald Trump threatened to withdraw the US from the World Trade Organization and impose additional tariffs on China, dampening market sentiment. The US$200 billion tariff increase on Chinese goods, set to end on September 5, fueled concerns about a trade war escalation. Global trade worries overshadowed the initial market lift, resulting in lower Asian equities.

site_title: Woody Allen's latest film release in doubt
summary: Woody Allen's latest film, "A Rainy Day in New York," starring Timothee Chalamet, Rebecca Hall, and Jude Law, is in doubt for release due to Amazon Studios' lack of a set date. The film, which finished filming in 2017, is Allen's latest project, and the director traditionally releases a new movie every year. Amazon Studios' decision casts uncertainty over the film's release, marking a rare pause in Allen's annual release schedule.

images.alt_text: The release of Woody Allen's latest film was cast into doubt on Thursday after distributor Amazon Studios said it had not decided on a release date.

site_title: Stars celebrate Queen Aretha at marathon funeral
summary: Former presidents, celebrities, and musical icons paid tribute to Aretha Franklin at her marathon funeral in Detroit, celebrating her life and legacy. The 76-year-old singer, known as the "Queen of Soul," died of cancer on August 16 after a six-decade career spanning multiple genres. The nearly eight-hour service featured gospel, eulogies, music, and sermons, marking the end of an era for America's beloved music icon.

images.alt_text: Bishop Charles Ellis (centre) delivers the final prayer over the casket containing the body of US recording artist Aretha Franklin during her funeral service at the Greater Grace Temple in Detroit, Michigan, August 31, 2018.

site_title: New high-rises spark land battle in Paris
summary: A group of 12 tenants in Paris refuse to leave their homes to make way for the construction of the Hermitage towers, a 320-meter high-rise building proposed by a Russian developer. The tenants, who have lived in the building for over 20 years, are fighting against the demolition of their homes, which will be replaced by the skyscrapers. The French government is pushing for expansion of office space and residential sites in the La Defense business district, but the tenants' struggle highlights the tension between development and community interests.

site_title: Argentine peso recovering after record low against US dollar
summary: Argentina's peso recovered 4.8% on Friday to reach 37.98 to the dollar after the Central Bank sold $250 million of its reserves to stabilize the currency. The peso had plummeted 20% over the previous two days, following President Mauricio Macri's efforts to secure accelerated IMF funding. This move put the brakes on the peso's decline, bringing its value closer to pre-record-low levels.

site_title: It feels like the world is ending - but I can't stop reading about it
summary: A person's addiction to depressing news stems from a desire to stay informed about the world's problems, but excessive exposure can lead to feelings of hopelessness and desensitization. Reading only positive news or avoiding news altogether can be seen as a form of escapism, but ultimately fails to address the underlying issues. Historians like Thucydides and Gibbon remind us that tribal hysteria and resistance to human decency are ancient and predictable phenomena. The question remains: what good does being informed do if it only reinforces a corrosive worldview?

site_title: Americans bid McCain solemn farewell with US Capitol honour
summary: US Capitol honors late Senator John McCain with a solemn farewell ceremony, with President Donald Trump absent despite a tradition of presidential attendance. McCain's widow and children attended, along with dignitaries, as a military honor guard carried the senator's casket through the Capitol Rotunda. Vice President Mike Pence delivered a tribute, acknowledging McCain's service and a final rebuke to Trump's absence. McCain will be buried on Sunday at the US Naval Academy, following a memorial service at the National Cathedral on Saturday, where former presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama will eulogize him.

site_title: China's banks see jump in fines under chief regulator Guo - UBS
summary: China's banking regulator, Guo Shuqing, has led to a significant increase in fines, nearly six-fold since his appointment in 2017. Fines have mainly been issued for hiding non-performing loans, with 65% of recent cases related to this issue. The surge in fines is part of Beijing's efforts to curb systematic financial risks and has led to a significant spike in bad loans, with 183 billion yuan in the April-June period. The stricter enforcement is expected to deter future underreporting of non-performing loans.

site_title: FLT acquires two prime Australian properties for A$62.6m
summary: FLT acquires two prime Australian properties for A$62.6 million, expanding its portfolio to 82 properties with a total GLA of 1.9 million sq m. The properties, both with 100% occupancy rates, are located in NSW and Queensland, with weighted average lease expiry (WALE) of 7 years and 4.2 years respectively. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to FLT's distribution per unit, with the company's counter ending up 0.92% to S$1.10.

site_title: London's new train line delayed for nearly a year
summary: London's new Crossrail train line, the Elizabeth Line, has been delayed until late 2019, nearly a year after its initial planned December 2018 opening. The £15.4 billion project, which aims to add 10% to central London's rail capacity, will now open in the third quarter of 2019. The delay is due to further testing and infrastructure work required to ensure the line is safe and reliable. The revised schedule has sparked concerns and criticism from London Mayor Sadiq Khan and opposition politicians.

site_title: Kremlin says Putin, Trump could hold talks 3 times this year, including in Singapore: Izvestiya
summary: The Kremlin announced that Russian President Vladimir Putin could hold talks with US President Donald Trump at three summits in 2018, including in Singapore, France, and Argentina. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov stated that Moscow is open to talks but emphasized the need for reciprocity. This potential meeting was first reported by Izvestiya newspaper.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,218.85, down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% on Friday, closing at 3,218.85, after a lunch break. Losers outnumbered gainers 168 to 138, with 1.26 billion shares worth S$675.3 million changing hands. Key movers included Golden Agri-Resources, BlackGold Natural Resources, and Rex International. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 6.87 points lower.

site_title: Precious as silver, vanilla brings cash and crime to Madagascar
summary: Vanilla farmers in Madagascar face a lucrative yet perilous crop due to poverty and corruption. Ninot Oclin, a 33-year-old farmer, patrols his land in the foothills of a volcano, protecting his valuable vanilla crop from thieves. The crop has become a target for violent criminal networks, with the windfall bringing both cash and crime to the region. The corrupt and weak state of Madagascar exacerbates the issue, leaving farmers vulnerable to exploitation.

Left: Ripe vanilla pods stamped with the owner's initials in Antsahalalina, Madagascar. Right: Pruning a vanilla vine at a plantation.

site_title: Trump to back US$200b China tariffs as early as next week
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to impose US$200 billion tariffs on Chinese imports as early as next week, following a public-comment period. Analysts predict this move will cause market jitters. Trump also criticized China's devalued yuan, citing the country's economic slowdown. The move is expected to affect the Asian garment industry, with Vietnam seeking a lower tariff rate. China's GDP growth is forecast to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Former Enron CEO released from prison into halfway house
summary: Former Enron CEO Jeffrey Skilling has been released from an Alabama prison camp and is now residing in a halfway house in Houston. He was released after serving 14 years of a 24-year prison sentence for his role in Enron's 2001 collapse. Skilling's release comes after a deal was struck between prosecutors and his lawyers, allowing him to regain a portion of his frozen fortune. The release marks the end of a long appeals process for Skilling, who was convicted of 19 counts of conspiracy and securities fraud in 2006.

site_title: New network provides members with co-working spaces, business opportunities across Asia
summary: A new regional network, the Millet World Trading Post (MWTP), offers co-working spaces and business opportunities to small enterprises in Asia. The network, operated on a subscription basis, provides access to digital matching platforms, physical co-working spaces, and events. MWTP aims to facilitate regional cross-ventures and has signed agreements with property developers to set up venues in Melbourne and other cities. The network plans to have 10,000 nodes by 2020, offering workshops, talks, and conferences on innovations and trends in the arts, culture, and creative industry.

site_title: Game on, Las Vegas
summary: Las Vegas is rapidly adopting cutting-edge technology, transforming it into a vibrant tech haven. The city's casinos generated a record $26.2 billion in revenue last year. The city's residents have also become accustomed to using innovative technologies, such as self-service kiosks at car rental centers and interactive video conferencing for remote assistance. The city's emergency alert system, the Integrated Public Alert and Warning System, allows for wireless emergency alerts sent by state and local officials, and tech firms like Google, Facebook, and Twitter are working to issue emergency alerts. Rideshare services, popularized by Uber, are also becoming an integral part of daily life in the city.

site_title: EDBI's Chu Swee Yeok appointed non-executive director at SingPost
summary: Chu Swee Yeok, CEO of EDBI, has been appointed as a non-executive director at SingPost, effective September 1. He will serve on the audit, board risk and technology committees. This move comes after the market closed on Friday, with SingPost's counter closing up 0.88% to S$1.15. The appointment aims to leverage EDBI's expertise in technology and risk management to support SingPost's growth and operations.

site_title: Vonovia to pause on acquisitions after M&A spree
summary: Vonovia, Germany's largest residential property company, will pause on acquisitions after raising its outlook for the second time in less than four months. CEO Rolf Buch cited steep price rises in German cities as a reason for the pause, stating that the company will focus on making its business model work in Austria and Sweden, where 90% of its flats are located. The company's shares fell 1.9% after the announcement, despite a 25% gain over the past year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Two brokerages, CGS-CIMB and RHB Research, have issued analysis on Dyna-Mac Holdings Limited. CGS-CIMB lowers its target price to S$0.13 due to a wider discount to its target price of 2.2x price to book value. RHB Research maintains a "buy" rating with a target price of S$0.77, citing APAC Realty's entry into the Hainan market as a potential catalyst for long-term earnings sustainability.

site_title: Asian stocks bruised by Trump's trade war threats
summary: Asian stocks fell on Friday, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index dropping 0.8% for a monthly loss of 1.6%, amid US President Donald Trump's renewed threats to step up a trade war with China. Chinese stocks declined, and emerging market currencies, including the Argentine peso and Turkish lira, also fell. The US S&P500 e-mini futures dropped 0.05%, following a week of volatility sparked by Trump's comments. The trade tensions have raised concerns about a global economic slowdown.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip on Trump trade talk
summary: European stocks fell 0.3% as US President Donald Trump stepped up trade talks, casting doubt on a US-Europe trade deal and hinting at further tariffs on Chinese goods. Emerging-market shares declined, with the Indian rupee and South Africa's rand reaching record lows. Global stocks have been on a solid rally since mid-August, but caution is returning as US-China relations sour. The US plans to impose tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports as soon as next week.

site_title: The rise of corporate governance in Asia - what's next?
summary: Asia's corporate governance has plateaued, with companies focusing on risk assessment and compliance rather than incorporating governance throughout their structure. To progress, companies must redefine their corporate purpose and connect it to behavior that strengthens governance mechanisms. This involves breathing life into policies and processes, ensuring transparency and structured approaches, and fostering stakeholder confidence. By doing so, Asian companies can improve on global best practices and lead the way in corporate governance.

images.alt_text: Ms Chow says though much progress has been made in Asia, a gap still exists between governance standards in Asia and global best practices.

site_title: Duterte says Philippines better off run by dictator if he were not around
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte stated that the country would be better off run by a dictator like late Ferdinand Marcos if he were not around, citing entrenched graft and illicit drugs. Duterte expressed reluctance to hand over power to Vice-President Leni Robredo, citing concerns about disorder and a need for authoritarian leadership. Duterte's admiration for Marcos has sparked controversy, with many Filipinos still tormented by his brutal rule.

site_title: Collecting NRIC numbers, making copies to be illegal from Sept 1, 2019
summary: Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) has announced that from September 1, 2019, organisations will be prohibited from collecting, using, or disclosing National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers or making copies of the identity card. Organisations that have collected NRIC numbers must dispose of them by then, and will need to implement adequate protection measures to safeguard the personal data. Exceptions include situations where NRIC numbers are required by law, such as for healthcare or financial transactions. Organisations that fail to comply can be fined up to S$1 million.

images.alt_text: From Sept 1 next year, it will be illegal for organisations to collect, use or disclose NRIC numbers or make copies of the identity card, under stricter rules spelt out on Friday by the Personal Data Protection Commission.

site_title: Australian shares fall on fear US-China trade fight to worsen; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 6,319.5, as investors feared an escalation in US-China trade tensions. Telecom stocks suffered heavy losses after a merger deal between TPG and Vodafone's Australian unit. The sector index fell 1.7% amid rising US tariffs on Chinese imports. Global miners BHP and Rio Tinto also declined. The only sector to gain was healthcare, led by shares in Primary Health Care and Ramsay Health Care.

site_title: Bankrupt Titanic exhibitor sets biggest sale ever of ship relics
summary: The bankrupt exhibitor Premier Exhibitions Inc. is set to auction off the largest collection of Titanic relics, valued at $189 million. The collection, which includes over 5,500 artifacts, is being sold to the highest bidder to cover debts and generate funds. US hedge funds, Chinese investors, British museums, and James Cameron's production company are among the interested parties. The auction could raise questions about foreign ownership and a review by the US government. The collection will be kept intact and displayed in museums in the UK, including the National Maritime Museum in Belfast and the National Maritime Museum in London.

site_title: Oil slips as trade war worries outweigh Iran sanctions
summary: Oil prices slipped on Friday, falling 35 cents to $77.42 a barrel for benchmark Brent crude, and 45 cents to $69.80 a barrel for US crude. The decline was driven by renewed concerns about a global trade war, which could dent energy demand, despite limited declines in Iranian and Venezuelan output. Oil has been boosted by declining Iranian shipments ahead of US sanctions in November. Speculators raised bullish bets on crude for the first time in over a month, but analysts cut price forecasts for 2018 due to growing trade concerns.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slipped on Friday, pressured by renewed concerns that a global trade war could dent energy demand, although impending US sanctions on Iran and falling Venezuelan output limited the decline.

site_title: What ails Manchester United?
summary: Manchester United is struggling after dismantling Alex Ferguson's legacy, evident in their 3-0 home defeat to Tottenham Hotspur. The club's winning culture and staff, deeply embedded in Ferguson's approach, have largely left, with key personnel such as coaches and goalkeeping staff departing or joining other clubs. This exodus has weakened the connection to Ferguson's success, making it harder for the team to regain its former glory, despite being a successful business.

site_title: Indian rupee hits record low as emerging market currencies sink in Asia
summary: The Indian rupee hit a record low against the US dollar, falling to 71 against the dollar for the first time, as emerging market currencies in Asia sank in response to financial crises in Argentina and Turkey. The decline was triggered by US President Donald Trump's plan to impose tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports, which added to fears of contagion. Other emerging market currencies, including the Indonesian rupiah and South Korean won, also plummeted. The decline was attributed to ballooning current account deficits and interest rate hikes failing to stem the selling in these currencies.

site_title: Argentina hikes interest rates to 60% as peso plummets
summary: Argentina's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate to 60%, the highest in the world, in a bid to stabilize the peso, which plummeted to a record low against the US dollar. Despite the rate hike, the currency lost 13.5% and 53% of its value since the start of the year. The government has committed to reducing its budget deficit and will announce new economic measures. Analysts say the government needs to provide more details on its plans to achieve IMF fiscal targets. The country faces a major obstacle in November with a $7 billion foreign exchange debt repayment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat retrieving some losses
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on Friday, recovering from earlier losses as traders reacted to strong China data. The Nikkei 225 index ended down 0.02% at 22,865.15, while the Topix index closed 0.22% lower at 1,735.35. The slight gains were attributed to positive sentiment from the China data, which offset concerns about US-China trade tensions and the ongoing Fed decision-making process.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds off tightening policy on jobs, inflation worries
summary: The Bank of Korea maintained its monetary policy unchanged, keeping interest rates at 1.50% due to concerns over a jobs crisis and weak inflationary pressure. Governor Lee Ju Yeol expressed doubts about job market recovery and downplayed expectations of further policy tightening this year. The decision came as the economy showed signs of weakness, with a small annual job gain and declining average disposable household incomes. The Bank of Korea's decision was seen as a relief for markets, with government bond prices rallying across the board.

site_title: Coca-Cola moves into coffee with £3.9b deal for UK's Costa chain
summary: Coca-Cola has agreed to purchase the UK's Costa coffee chain from Whitbread Plc for £3.9 billion, expanding its presence in the hot beverages market. The deal gives Coke nearly 4,000 coffee outlets in the UK and Europe, allowing it to move away from traditional sodas. Whitbread plans to reduce debt and expand its hotel chain, while Coca-Cola aims to capitalize on the growing demand for healthier beverages. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to increase Coke's presence in the global coffee market.

site_title: Coca-Cola expands into coffee with £3.9b deal for Britain's Costa
summary: Coca-Cola has agreed to buy Costa, Britain's second-largest coffee chain, for £3.9 billion, expanding its presence in the coffee market. The deal, which will give Coke nearly 4,000 coffee outlets in the UK and Europe, is part of the company's efforts to move away from traditional sodas and towards healthier options. The acquisition will also reduce debt and contribute to Whitbread's pension fund. The deal is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the growing demand for hot beverages.

site_title: Private vehicle journeys in Singapore see first drop since 1997: LTA
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) survey found that private vehicle journeys in Singapore dropped for the first time in nearly 20 years in 2016, with a 5% increase in overall travel demand to 15.4 million journeys. Bus and train journeys increased to a record high of 6.1 million, while private vehicle trips declined to 10.3 million, marking a decline of 1.2 million journeys. This represents a first decline since 1997.

site_title: Chinese airlines' profit hit by fuel costs, weak yuan
summary: China's major airlines, including China Eastern Airlines, China Southern Airlines, and Air China, saw their earnings decline in the first half of the year due to a weaker Chinese yuan and higher fuel prices. China Eastern's net profit dropped 48% to 2.3 billion yuan, while China Southern's profit fell 24% to 2.1 billion yuan. However, Air China's profit rose 4.05% to 3.5 billion yuan. The decline in earnings is attributed to the challenges faced by the industry, including sharp fuel price rises and large exchange rate fluctuations, amidst a growing domestic market.

site_title: Minor clogging of heart arteries: cause for concern?
summary: A recent study using coronary CT angiograms (CCTA) found that minor narrowing of heart arteries, previously considered non-significant, can still pose a risk of heart attack. Researchers analyzed data from over 86,000 patients and found that those with non-obstructive coronary artery disease (CAD) who had high plaque burdens and rapid plaque progression had the worst outcomes. The study suggests that CCTA is a more accurate test than invasive coronary angiography for detecting CAD and predicting progression. As a result, doctors are now recommending CCTA as the first-line test for evaluating patients with suspected CAD, and patients with non-obstructive CAD should take preventive measures to reduce their risk of heart disease.

images.alt_text: The CCTA allows doctors to not only obtain visualisation of the heart artery lumen but also the wall of the heart artery. CCTA is now the first-line test for the evaluation of patients with suspected CAD in the UK and it is likely that this will soon be the case in the US as well.

site_title: Nets appoints OCBC COO Ching Wei Hong as next chairman
summary: OCBC Bank's COO Ching Wei Hong will become the next chairman of electronic funds transfer group Nets, starting September 1. He replaces Tan Su Shan, who will remain a board director. Ching Wei Hong's appointment follows his role as OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: US dollar edges up on latest round of US-China trade tensions
summary: The US dollar rose against its peers on Friday, supported by heightened US-China trade tensions and investor risk aversion. The US dollar index edged up 0.15% to 94.748, driven by concerns over the next round of trade conflict. Emerging market currencies, such as the euro, Turkish lira, and Argentine peso, weakened, while the Chinese yuan remained stable. The dollar's rise was attributed to investors seeking safe-haven assets amidst market turmoil, with the euro and other currencies also experiencing declines.

site_title: Remembering Michael Jackson: Children mark King of Pop's 60th birthday
summary: Michael Jackson's children and family members marked his 60th birthday with an auction and award ceremony in Las Vegas. Paris and Prince Jackson accepted the Elizabeth Taylor Aids Foundation Legacy Award, while a new pair of ruby and diamond-studded sneakers were auctioned off to benefit the foundation. The event took place nine years after Jackson's accidental overdose death in 2009.

site_title: Warriors West retires from NBA after 15 seasons
summary: Golden State Warriors forward David West announced his retirement from basketball after 15 seasons in the NBA. The 38-year-old West played for the Warriors in their 2017 and 2018 NBA Finals-winning seasons. Warriors coach Steve Kerr praised West as a "true champion" and "consummate professional" who provided invaluable leadership and mentoring to the team. West averaged 13.6 points and 6.4 rebounds throughout his career, playing for the Warriors, New Orleans, Indiana, and San Antonio.

site_title: Inconvenience main reason for Singapore's low plastic recycling rate
summary: A new report by the Singapore Environment Council found that 20% of surveyed Singaporeans are unaware of recycling bin locations, leading to a low plastic recycling rate of 6%. The main reasons for not recycling are lack of knowledge (70%) and inconvenience (40%). To improve the recycling rate, the council recommends partnering with companies, building a market for recycled plastic, and implementing Extended Producer Responsibility policies. The government has also launched a research grant call for sustainable plastic design and plans to extend its policy to plastic and packaging waste by 2021.

site_title: Singapore and Malaysia rail projects decision out soon: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore and Malaysia are set to announce their joint decisions on the RTS and HSR rail projects soon, according to Coordinating Minister Khaw Boon Wan. A meeting between Khaw and Malaysia's Economic Affairs Minister Mohamed Azmin Ali has been productive, with both sides expressing optimism about a "win-win deal" on the High Speed Rail. Officials from both countries have been working together to strengthen bilateral relations.

site_title: Mega-trade deals can pave way for bigger projects: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of embracing mega-trade deals like the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) to pave the way for bigger projects. He called for a rules-based, multilateral trading system, citing the World Trade Organisation (WTO) as the right solution to trade friction. Heng also highlighted the significance of China's Belt and Road Initiative, stating that the region should welcome investments from all over the world, including traditional sources and new emerging markets. He reiterated Singapore's commitment to regional integration and settling disagreements through a broader forum.

site_title: AirAsia's China ambitions suffer a blow after deal collapses
summary: AirAsia's planned venture in China with China Everbright Group and the Henan government has collapsed after a preliminary agreement lapsed. The deal, signed last year, aimed to tap the world's second-largest aviation market. The move is a setback for AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes, who had been expanding the airline's presence in the region. The collapse comes amid increased scrutiny of Chinese investment in Malaysia, following the suspension of the East Coast Rail Link project. The deal's collapse leaves China as a crucial missing piece for AirAsia's regional expansion plans.

site_title: Apple self-driving car rear ended during road testing
summary: Apple's self-driving car was rear-ended while merging onto an expressway in California, sustaining damage but no injuries. The incident occurred on August 24, with the Apple vehicle traveling at 1 mph in autonomous mode and the other vehicle traveling at 15 mph. Both vehicles were damaged, and a human driver must be able to take control of Apple's self-driving test cars, as per a safety plan filed with California regulators. This incident comes as Apple continues to test its autonomous vehicles, with over 60 permits for vehicles on the road.

site_title: China's central bank faces a tough task in guarding nervous yuan
summary: China's central bank faces a challenging task in September to add liquidity to its money markets without weakening the yuan. Funding costs are expected to spike due to quarter-end checks and a surge in local government bond issuances. The People's Bank of China needs to provide around 980 billion yuan in funding, which could impact the currency. Policymakers must balance meeting liquidity needs without giving traders a reason to sell the yuan, which has recently bounced off its 19-month low.

images.alt_text: September is set to be a hard month for China's money markets, handing the nation's central bank the tricky task of adding just enough liquidity without prompting renewed weakness in the yuan.

site_title: Google, Mastercard cut a secret ad deal to track retail sales
summary: Google and Mastercard have a secret ad deal to track retail sales in the US, with Google paying Mastercard millions of dollars for the data. The partnership gives Google access to 70% of US credit and debit card transactions, allowing it to anonymously match existing user profiles to purchases made in physical stores. Advertisers can use this data to gauge the effectiveness of their ads and connect them to offline sales. However, this deal raises concerns about consumer data privacy, with critics arguing that people are not aware of the tracking and that companies are placing too much burden on consumers.

site_title: Huawei's hang-ups open 5G line for Samsung
summary: Samsung Electronics has gained a foothold in the 5G market after Huawei's mounting political problems overseas. Following Australian and Japanese government decisions to ban Huawei and ZTE from supplying wireless components for ultrafast 5G service, Samsung is poised to capitalize on the market, which is forecast to reach $25 billion by 2022. With its expertise, deep pockets, and essential 5G technology patents, Samsung is well-positioned to offer attractive prices and convince customers to switch, potentially tripling its market share in contract chip manufacturing within five years.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars on slippery slope as trade tensions flare
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined on Friday amid escalating US-China tariff tensions, with the Australian dollar falling to its lowest level since August 24 at US$0.7258. The currencies are set to end the week lower, with the Aussie down 0.9% and the kiwi down 0.7%. Analysts expect a full-blown Sino-US tariff war to weigh on the antipodean currencies, which have fallen over 7% and 6% respectively in 2018. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to leave interest rates at record lows, awaiting a revival in inflation.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars extended losses on Friday and were poised to end the week in the red amid worries about escalating tariff tensions between the United States and China.

site_title: Singapore makes collecting NRIC numbers, making copies of identity card illegal from Sept 1, 2019
summary: Singapore will make it illegal for organizations to collect, use, or disclose NRIC numbers or make copies of identity cards from September 1, 2019. Organisations must dispose of existing NRIC numbers by the end of the year. The Personal Data Protection Commission warns that indiscriminate collection or handling of NRIC numbers can increase the risk of identity theft or fraud. Exceptions include collecting NRIC numbers for law-requiring purposes, such as verifying identity for healthcare, financial, or real estate transactions. Organizations found flouting the Act can be fined up to $1 million.

images.alt_text: From Sept 1 next year, it will be illegal for organisations to collect, use or disclose NRIC numbers or make copies of the identity card, under stricter rules spelt out on Friday by the Personal Data Protection Commission.

site_title: KinderWorld readies for push into Asean
summary: KinderWorld International Group, a private-school operator, is expanding its operations in Vietnam after a 18-year presence in the country. The company's chairman and CEO, Ricky Tan, aims to increase organic growth and acquisitions, and is exploring fundraising options, including an initial public offering (IPO). KinderWorld has invested over $100 million in Vietnam and has 15 campuses, including 10 Singapore International Schools. The company is also re-entering China, where it plans to open preschools in the south-west corridor and establish a kindergarten franchise business model.

site_title: President Trump had a lot to say on Thursday. But not about John McCain.
summary: President Donald Trump diverted attention away from Senator John McCain's funeral, failing to acknowledge the late Republican war hero's contributions. Trump tweeted "Throwback Thursday" while McCain's coffin was being transported to Washington, and later spoke about his own economic accomplishments. In a Bloomberg interview, Trump denied missing a chance to unite the country after McCain's death and mocked his press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, over her perceived nervous breakdown. Trump also skipped a tribute to McCain, instead focusing on his own rallies and criticizing the media and Democrats.

site_title: DBS prices Ascendas' 7-year senior debt at 3.265%
summary: DBS priced S$200 million in 7-year senior debt for Ascendas at 3.265% per cent. The unsecured notes mature on Sept 6, 2025, and will be listed on the Singapore Exchange. Proceeds will be used for refinancing existing debts, financing potential acquisitions, and general corporate purposes. The joint lead managers and bookrunners are DBS Bank, HSBC, and OCBC Bank.

site_title: Fresh round of mega-deal trade talks at AEM meeting
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing initiated fresh ministerial talks for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade deal at the Asean Economic Ministers (AEM) meeting. He expressed hopes for a clear plan by November, aiming to conclude the substantial RCEP by the end of 2018. This move aims to reaffirm the region's support for free trade amidst rising protectionist sentiments.

images.alt_text: Fresh ministerial talks for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade deal began on Thursday afternoon, with Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing hoping for a clear plan by November.

site_title: Malaysia floats plan for third link to Singapore
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has hinted at a plan to build a third link between Malaysia and Singapore, potentially through a bridge in Johor state. The link would be in addition to the existing causeway and bridge. However, Singapore's Ministry of Transport has not received any official proposal, and Johor's chief minister Osman Sapian confirmed talks with a company about the project, which could be completed in three to four years.

site_title: Chinese property developers opt to 'wait and see' as failed land auctions climb
summary: Chinese property developers are adopting a "wait and see" approach due to failed land auctions and macro-economic uncertainties. The number of failed land auctions more than doubled to 796 in the first seven months of 2018, with major cities recording the highest number since 2015. Despite this, property investment growth accelerated in July at its quickest pace in nearly two years. Developers face reduced liquidity and thinning margins due to government policy tightening and a weaker macroeconomic environment, with some opting to buy land at lower premiums to maintain cash flow and margins.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower extending loss in US
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, extending losses in New York due to concerns over imminent US tariffs on China. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.53% and the Topix index 0.49%, with the benchmark index at 22,748.05 and 1,730.64, respectively. This follows a decline in New York, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Russia tries more precise technology to block Telegram messenger
summary: Russia is testing more precise technology to block Telegram, a messaging service banned in the country, after a previous attempt inadvertently blocked other online services. The new technology, Deep Packet Inspection, aims to target individual services without affecting unrelated traffic. However, initial tests have been unsuccessful, with companies involved reporting that other services were still being blocked. The testing is ongoing, with a goal of refining the technology and installing it on Russian telecoms operators.

site_title: Malaysia: Market closed for National Day holiday
summary: Malaysia's stock market is closed on Friday due to a National Day holiday, resuming trading on Monday.

site_title: Boeing to develop refuelling drones for Pentagon
summary: The US Pentagon has awarded Boeing a $805 million contract to develop the first unmanned refuelling drones, the MQ-25A Stingray, for the US Navy. The drones, set to enter service in 2024, will expand aircraft range and mission capability, launching from aircraft carriers. Boeing beat out General Atomics and Lockheed Martin for the contract, with potential expansion to a $13 billion deal for 72 drones if requirements are met. The project marks a significant shift in the Navy's warfighting capabilities, integrating unmanned and manned aircraft.

site_title: China unveils plans to curb new games and play, hitting Tencent
summary: China's regulators plan to limit the number of new online games and total titles to curb gaming addiction among children, with a freeze on game approvals nationwide. The move aims to prevent and control myopia in children and teenagers, with controls exerted over game publishers. Tencent Holdings Ltd and Netease Inc fell 5% and 7.2% respectively, while game makers in Japan also declined. The new rules may impact the gaming industry's growth outlook, but major companies with existing measures may not be significantly affected in the long term.

site_title: Precious as silver, vanilla brings cash and crime to Madagascar
summary: Madagascar's vanilla crop, worth over $600 per kilogram, has driven an economic boom in the Sava region, but at a cost. Thieves target farmers, and the high price has led to a black market. Farmers like Ninot Oclin patrol their land, paying guards to protect their crops. Middlemen, such as Pascale Rasafindakoto, profit from the sale of vanilla, but are accused of swindling growers and lowering quality. Exporters, like Michel Lomone, face theft and corruption, with the justice system often failing to protect them. The boom has also led to social poverty, with people competing to make fast money.

site_title: China lowers yuan mid-point less than expected to 6.8246 per US dollar
summary: China's central bank lowered the yuan's midpoint to 6.8246 per US dollar, weaker than expected, amid a report that US President Donald Trump plans to impose additional tariffs on Chinese goods. This move follows a 0.19% drop in the previous fix. The weaker yuan reflects growing concerns about a potential trade war between the US and China.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won drop on concerns over Trump's trade threat
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and the won dropped on Friday due to concerns over US President Donald Trump's trade threat with Beijing. The Kospi fell 1.51 points or 0.07% to 2,305.84, while the won was quoted at 1,113.4 per US dollar, 0.43% weaker than its previous close. The news led to mild losses in US stocks and weakened Japanese stocks. The won has risen 4.32% against South Korea this year, while the Kospi has fallen 6.5% so far this year.

site_title: Growth worries rise as Japan's July factory output falls
summary: Japan's factory output fell 0.1% in July, its third straight decline, due to slowing exports and disruptions from flooding and global trade tensions. The slowdown is attributed to declining car and steel shipments, as well as effects from US tariffs and a slowdown in demand for semiconductor production equipment. Economists expect a slight rise in output in August and September, but the outlook remains uncertain, with fragile domestic demand and trade tensions between the US and Japan's trading partners.

site_title: BlackRock voted to replace Tesla's Musk with independent board chair
summary: BlackRock funds voted in favor of a shareholder proposal requiring Tesla to replace Elon Musk with an independent board chairman, despite Musk's opposition. The proposal, initially defeated in June, was backed by BlackRock, a top-10 Tesla shareholder, citing concerns about Musk's pay and board independence. BlackRock's approach is driven by its fiduciary duties to clients, aiming to drive long-term shareholder value. This move comes amid public pressure on Musk following his attempts to take Tesla private.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Keppel DC Reit, Singapore Exchange, Wheelock Properties
summary: Keppel Corp and Keppel DC Reit saw developments on Friday. Keppel DC Reit's wholly owned subsidiary, DC Reit Holdings, signed a sale and purchase agreement to sell about 55.1 million units for S$74.96 million, resulting in a gain of about S$17 million. Singapore Exchange increased its investment in Asian Gateway Investments by S$73.7 million. Wheelock Properties' independent financial adviser clarified its advice on the offer to take the company private as fair and reasonable, despite "market feedback" that may have caused concerns.

site_title: Gold dips on stronger US dollar, palladium hits 10-week peak
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.6% to $1,198.84 an ounce, reaching a six-day low, due to a stronger US dollar following strong US economic data. Despite concerns over global trade tensions, analysts see a medium- and long-term bullish outlook for gold. Meanwhile, palladium reached a 10-week peak at $965 an ounce, driven by a global deficit and ample supply of platinum.

site_title: Argentina hikes interest rates to 60% - world's highest - as peso plummets
summary: Argentina's central bank raised interest rates to 60%, the world's highest, in a bid to stabilize the peso, which plummeted 13.5% against the US dollar. Despite the rate hike, the currency lost 53% of its value since the start of the year, trading at 39.87 to the dollar. Treasury Minister Nicolas Dujovne pledged new economic measures, while President Mauricio Macri denied facing an economic disaster. The move was seen as insufficient by ratings agency Moody's, which described it as a signal that economic policy approaches have not contained financial pressures.

site_title: China factory gauge unexpectedly rises in August amid trade war, but export orders fall again
summary: China's manufacturing sector unexpectedly expanded in August, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 51.3, marking a 25th consecutive month above the 50-point mark. However, export orders shrank for a third straight month, and imports also contracted. The growth is seen as a temporary respite, with analysts warning that US trade tariffs are starting to bite. China's economy was already slowing, with investment growth at a record low and consumers becoming more cautious, prompting policymakers to speed up infrastructure spending and offer support to smaller companies.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Friday's open; STI down 0.75% to 3,201.49
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.75% on Friday, closing at 3,201.49, amid reports of potential US tariffs on Chinese imports. Losers outpaced gainers 70-35, with Keppel DC Reit and Golden Agri-Resources leading the decline. Active index stocks, including DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank, also fell. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors taking a cautious stance amidst trade uncertainty.

site_title: The bugs are coming, and they'll want more of our food
summary: A study published in Science found that global warming will increase insect pests' consumption of crops, leading to a 10-25% loss of wheat, corn, and rice worldwide. As temperatures rise, insects' metabolisms speed up, causing them to eat more and reproduce faster, resulting in reduced crop yields. The study suggests that pesticides may not be an effective solution, as they can harm other organisms and contribute to global warming. Instead, drastically reducing greenhouse gas emissions is the key to mitigating crop losses and ensuring global food security.

site_title: Trump to back US$200b China tariffs as early as next week, sources say
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to impose tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports as soon as a public-comment period concludes next week, according to sources. The proposed duties cover various goods, including electronics and machinery, and come after the US has already imposed $50 billion in levies. China has threatened to retaliate with duties on $60 billion of US goods, further escalating tensions in the trade war between the two nations. The move is expected to unnerve financial markets, with US stocks falling on the news.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump wants to move ahead with a plan to impose tariffs on US$200 billion in Chinese imports as soon as a public-comment period concludes next week, according to six people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Crude rises to highest since July on sanction concerns
summary: Oil prices rose to the highest in more than a month, driven by growing concerns over disruptions to crude supply from Iran and Venezuela, as well as a decline in US inventories. Brent crude oil rose 63 US cents to $77.77 a barrel, while US crude settled 74 US cents higher at $70.25 a barrel. The rally is attributed to a tightening global oil market, with Iranian oil exports expected to drop to 2 million barrels per day in August and Venezuela's exports halved to 1 million barrels per day.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks plunge at open
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted over 1% at the open on Friday, following a report that US President Donald Trump plans to impose fresh tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports next month. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.3% to 27,798.21, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.28% and 0.41%, respectively. The decline was attributed to trade frictions returning to the fore, despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US.

site_title: Hyundai to ship cars made in China to S-E Asia amid erratic sales recovery
summary: Hyundai plans to ship cars made in China to South-east Asia amid erratic sales recovery in China. The company's China joint venture has idled most of its massive local manufacturing capacity due to a 40% drop in Chinese sales in July. Hyundai aims to sell 900,000 cars in China this year, but the target is nearly half of its 1.65 million vehicle capacity. Exporting China-made vehicles to South-east Asia could help Hyundai avoid tariffs and improve its market share, with the government supporting firms expanding in Indonesia.

site_title: The Sound Of Silent Movies
summary: Silent movie screenings are gaining popularity among cinephiles, offering a unique experience of watching black-and-white films without the aid of modern sound technology. The National Museum Singapore will screen the 1928 Indian romance film "Shiraz: A Tale of Romance" on September 2, featuring a newly scored soundtrack by sitar player Anoushka Shankar. The film is based on the true story of Shah Jahan and his wife Mumtaz Mahal, and has been beautifully restored for the screening.

site_title: Keppel pares stake in Keppel DC Reit by 4.08% for S$74.96m, recognises S$17m gain
summary: Keppel Corporation sold about 55.1 million units of Keppel DC Reit for S$74.96m, representing a 4.08% stake, at a price of at least S$1.36 per unit. The sale is expected to reduce Keppel's indirect interest in Keppel DC Reit from 29.27% to 25.2%. The group expects to recognize a gain of about S$17 million from the sale, which will be completed on Sept 5, 2018.

site_title: US, Canada make late-night push for Nafta deal
summary: US and Canadian top negotiators worked late into the night Thursday to resolve final differences on the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) ahead of a Friday deadline. Despite contentious issues, the talks have a positive tone, with US President Donald Trump expressing hope for a trilateral deal. Mexico's Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo is expected to rejoin talks soon, and the US and Canada have agreed on a bilateral deal on autos content rules, paving the way for a modernized Nafta deal. A deal by Friday would allow Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto to sign it before he leaves office at the end of November.

images.alt_text: Top Nafta negotiators from Canada and the United States worked late into the night Thursday to resolve final differences to meet a Friday deadline, with their Mexican counterpart on standby to rejoin the talks soon.

site_title: Maybank Q2 profit rises 18% on drop in provisions
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest lender, reported a 18% increase in Q2 profit to 1.96 billion ringgit, driven by lower expenses and loan loss allowances. This beats analyst estimates of 1.9 billion ringgit. The bank's net profit for April-June was 1.96 billion ringgit, up from 1.66 billion ringgit in the same period last year.

site_title: China trade fears end European shares' recovery
summary: European shares fell 0.3-0.5% on Thursday as Chinese markets weakened and trade tensions between the US and China dominated. The Stoxx 600 ended down 0.3%, while Germany's DAX dropped 0.5% due to concerns over Chinese exports. Earnings reports also led to sharp moves in individual stocks, with Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield falling 4.3% despite a profit boost. The real estate sector was among the worst performers, down 1.2%, as investors awaited a potential Nafta deal.

site_title: Dream Makers
summary: Sleeper, an ethical sleepwear brand co-founded by former fashion editors Kate Zubarieva and Asya Varetsa in 2014, has gained significant success despite the Ukrainian Revolution of Dignity. The brand, which started with a $2,000 investment, has grown 500% in sales and is stocked in top American retailers. Sleeper's focus on artisan-manufacturing traditions, natural eco-friendly fabrics, and "made-to-order" garments has earned praise from influential fashion personalities and industry leaders. The brand's transitional sleepwear wardrobe, designed to be versatile and timeless, has become a staple in many closets.

site_title: Checking In
summary: Swissotel The Stamford is nearing completion of its extensive hotel makeover, with new features including automated check-in and check-out counters with biometric facial recognition. Guests can now zip in and out painlessly, and pay for their room key with the system. All 1,252 guest rooms and the executive lounge will be ready by the end of the year.

site_title: Include corporate governance awareness in investor education
summary: Investor education has grown in importance since the US sub-prime crash of 2008, with a focus on traditional finance. However, incorporating corporate governance awareness is crucial to minimize risk of loss. Good corporate governance involves understanding company norms, practices, and information sources. Investors should familiarize themselves with the Singapore Code of Corporate Governance and ask questions about a company's governance structure, diversity, and independence. This education aims to make people responsible investors, enhance market discipline, and complement traditional finance knowledge, ultimately reducing loss from corporate misbehaviour.

site_title: Two initiatives to equip 12,000 over 3 years with AI knowledge
