summary: Singapore has launched two initiatives to equip 12,000 citizens with AI knowledge over three years. AI for Industry (AI4I) will provide a subsidized three-month course to 2,000 executives and those with technical AI skills, while AI for Everyone (AI4E) will offer a free introductory workshop to 10,000 people. The initiatives aim to address the global shortage of AI talent and boost Singapore's AI ecosystem.

site_title: IFA clarifies recommendation for Wheelock offer
summary: The independent financial adviser (IFA) to the recommending directors of Wheelock Properties (Singapore) has clarified its recommendation to take the company private as "fair and reasonable." The IFA previously stated that the offer price of S$2.10 per share is a 19.2% discount to the company's net asset value (NAV), but noted that the shares have not traded above the offer price since July 2017. The IFA advises shareholders to accept the offer unless they can obtain a higher price on the open market.

site_title: Former Enron CEO released from prison to halfway house
summary: Jeffrey Skilling, the former Enron CEO, has been released from an Alabama prison camp and transferred to a halfway house in Houston, Texas, according to US Bureau of Prisons records. Skilling served a 24-year prison sentence for his role in the company's collapse. No further information was immediately available from his lawyers.

images.alt_text: Jeffrey Skilling, the former chief executive officer of Enron who received a 24-year prison sentence for his role in the company's spectacular collapse, has been released from an Alabama prison camp and moved to a halfway house, records from the US Bureau of Prisons showed on Thursday.

site_title: Changing tastes whipsaw fashion fortunes
summary: Luxury goods market is expected to grow 8% this year, driven by demand from China, while fast-fashion retailers face increased competition from online rivals. Bernard Arnault's LVMH surpassed Amancio Ortega's Inditex as Europe's richest person, with Arnault's net worth increasing by 25% to $79.3 billion. Meanwhile, Ortega's net worth dropped 7% to $69.7 billion, with Inditex shares tumbling 5.7% after Morgan Stanley analysts downgraded the stock. Changing consumer tastes favor luxury brands over fast fashion.

site_title: ACE inks MOU to give leg-up to Austria and S'pore startups
summary: ACTION Community for Entrepreneurship (ACE) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Advantage Austria and the Global Incubator Network (GIN) to promote international business opportunities for Singapore and Austrian startups. The signing was attended by Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz and Senior Minister of State Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman during his three-day official visit to Singapore. The partnership aims to provide leg-up to startups in both countries, fostering collaboration and innovation in the tech sector.

site_title: US: Wall Street rally ends as investors sell risk
summary: US stocks ended a four-day winning streak on Thursday as investors sold risk ahead of the long holiday weekend, amid ongoing trade talks and China's insistence on "equality" in negotiations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.44% and the S&P 500 lost 0.33%, while Apple shares hit a record high. Tesla and Campbell Soup Co. shares declined, while Amazon.com edged closer to reaching $1 trillion in market value. The core PCE price index rose 2% year-over-year, boosting the likelihood of additional rate hikes this year.

site_title: Top trends at Berlin's IFA tech fair
summary: Berlin's IFA tech fair has kicked off with new product launches, featuring top trends. TV sets now boast higher resolution and bigger screens, with 8K sets offering four times the pixels of 4K UHD screens. Voice commands are the preferred control scheme, replacing traditional remotes. The first compatible 8K content won't be available until the 2020 Japan Winter Olympics.

site_title: Apple announces event on Sept 12 for revamped iPhone lineup
summary: Apple has announced a September 12 event to unveil its revamped iPhone lineup, featuring three new models with facial recognition, edge-to-edge screens, and OLED or LCD displays. The event will be held at the Steve Jobs Theater in Cupertino, California. The new iPhones will include a refreshed flagship device, a larger premium model, and a cheaper model with LCD technology. The event marks the second year in a row that details about new products have leaked, and comes as the iPhone accounts for about two-thirds of Apple's revenue, with estimated sales of over $30 billion in the last quarter.

site_title: Dollar slips for a fifth day as Nafta concerns ease
summary: The US dollar slipped for a fifth consecutive day due to easing concerns over trade conflicts between the US and Canada. Investors are betting that a likely trade deal would reduce dollar demand, leading to a decline in its value. The pound recaptured $1.30, while the euro rose against the dollar, and New Zealand's dollar fell as business confidence sank. The offshore Chinese yuan also declined, extending its losses into a third session.

site_title: A suitcase with cult status for millennials
summary: A suitcase brand called Away has gained cult status among millennials, with its sleek, colorful, and feature-rich hard-shell rolling suitcases. Founded by Jen Rubio and Steph Korey, Away has attracted celebrities such as Rashida Jones and Dwyane Wade, and has sold about 500,000 pieces since 2016. The brand's innovative approach to luggage design, including built-in chargers and lithium-ion batteries, has disrupted the market and made travel easier for its users. With its affordable prices, ranging from $190 to $595, Away is positioning itself as a leader in the luggage industry.

site_title: Frankenscience or fearless medicine?
summary: Modern medicine is advancing with 3D printing technology, allowing bioprinters to create living tissue from cells, raising concerns about the ethics of "Frankenstein-like" creations. An interview with a 3D biomedical printer in Singapore discusses the challenges and potential of this technology. Meanwhile, other sections cover topics such as investing, fintech, and a road trip to Las Vegas, as well as articles on lifestyle, sustainability, and corporate purpose. The goal of these advancements is to improve healthcare, but the path forward is complex and requires careful consideration.

site_title: Corporate ICOs - how to succeed in a brave new world
summary: In 2018, blockchain startups raised over $18 billion through Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs), five times the 2017 total. Traditional companies are increasingly entering the cryptocurrency space, emphasizing the need for rigorous governance, compliance, and audit controls. A successful ICO requires a well-thought-out business case with a sustainable value proposition, proper communication, and thorough vetting of white papers and contracts by legal professionals. Companies must also establish robust Know-Your-Customer and Anti-Money Laundering policies, develop internal accounting policies for crypto-assets, and implement effective internal controls to mitigate risks.

site_title: Singapore's plastic recycling rate only 6%; inconvenience one of reasons for not recycling
summary: Singapore's plastic recycling rate is only 6%, largely due to lack of knowledge about recyclable plastics and inconvenience of recycling. A survey of over 1,000 Singaporeans found that 70% did not fully understand what plastics to recycle, and 20% were unaware of recycling bin locations. To improve the rate, the Singapore Environment Council has proposed six recommendations, including partnering with companies and industries to reduce plastic packaging and building a market for recycled plastic. The government is also studying the feasibility of extending an Extended Producer Responsibility policy to plastic and packaging waste by 2021.

site_title: A Night With A Legend
summary: Brazilian saxophonist Leo Gandelman, a renowned musician with over 800 recordings, will perform at PianoBotanica 2018 on September 9 at Singapore Botanic Gardens. Accompanied by pianist Eduardo Farias, Gandelman will blend Samba Jazz, Bossa Nova, and pop into an effervescent new sound. This free concert marks a rousing end to the week, featuring a range of music from classic to popular tunes.

site_title: For Fuji Xerox, it's all about the kids
summary: Fuji Xerox prioritizes its corporate social responsibility (CSR) projects focusing on children and young people, believing they are stewards of the country's future. The company will pair volunteers with at-risk youth for a photography workshop and neighborhood walk in November, aligning with its 2012 goal of involving and helping young people. This initiative aims to empower the next generation and contribute to the company's CSR efforts.

site_title: Petronas boosts payout to KL after Q2 profit doubles
summary: Malaysia's state-owned energy firm Petronas has reported a near doubling of its profit in the second quarter, totaling RM13.63 billion, up from RM7 billion a year ago. The company plans to expand its core business portfolio and pay the Malaysian government a higher dividend of RM24 billion this year, up from RM16 billion last year. Petronas' CEO Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin stated that the company will maintain a "prudent view on the outlook" and expects its full-year performance to be "satisfactory".

images.alt_text: Petronas will pay the Malaysian government, its sole shareholder, a dividend of RM24 billion this year, up from RM16 billion last year.

site_title: S&P pays A$215m to settle Australian lawsuit
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has agreed to pay A$215 million to settle a lawsuit in Australia, where it was accused of overlooking risks in awarding high ratings to opaque investments that imploded during the global financial crisis. The settlement resolves the last crisis-era case against the firm. S&P had faced lawsuits from two local governments and two pension funds, which lost money on synthetic collateralised debt obligations. The Federal Court approved the terms, describing the settlement as a "positive outcome" for the affected parties.

site_title: Nafta is dead - long live Nafta
summary: US President Donald Trump has unveiled a new trade agreement with Mexico, replacing the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). The agreement aims to promote US jobs by requiring a higher local content of vehicles and imposing conditions on vehicle manufacturers. The deal includes a 2.5% tariff on vehicles that meet certain production requirements, such as having 75% of content made in North America by workers earning at least $16 an hour. Critics argue that the agreement will raise car prices and harm consumers, while Trump claims it will promote good US jobs.

site_title: How firms can kickstart their journey of AI adoption
summary: Organisations are increasingly adopting artificial intelligence (AI) to supplement their business, but many struggle to implement sound AI strategies due to a lack of know-how. To kickstart their journey of AI adoption, firms should identify specific areas where AI can add value, understand the challenges of adopting AI, and consider short- and long-term goals. This can be achieved by working with trusted partners who can provide expertise in AI implementation. Successful adoption of AI can lead to increased labour productivity by up to 40%, making it a crucial strategy for innovative leaders.

images.alt_text: An autonomous parcel delivery robot featured at the AI Congress in London earlier this year. The flexibility of AI provides organisations with the freedom of choice to best address their most pressing needs.

site_title: Rustic Retreat
summary: Liguria, a northwest Italian region, is often overlooked by travelers, but it offers a unique blend of rugged beauty, authentic charm, and rich history. Genoa, its capital, boasts a sheltered bay and a history as a great maritime republic, earning it the nickname "La Superba." The city's Centro Storico features a medieval-era historical center, narrow alleyways, and stunning architecture. The region's coastline is dotted with picturesque villages, including Portofino and Cinque Terre, and offers breathtaking views of the Mediterranean. With its unique blend of history, culture, and natural beauty, Liguria is a hidden gem waiting to be discovered.

images.alt_text: View of the city from the re-developed harbour area.
Novel decorative element adds charm to this Old Town walkway.
Neo-classical buildings around Piazza de Ferrari in the financial and business district of Genoa.
Spectacular Baroque church interiors are the norm in Genoa.
A popular restaurant just off the narrow road between Santa Margherita and Portofino.

site_title: CPFIS funds deliver average returns of 0.62% in Q2
summary: CPFIS funds delivered an average return of 0.62% in Q2, with unit trusts averaging 0.64% and investment-linked insurance products averaging 0.60%. Equity funds rose 0.88%, while bond funds fell 0.41%. The overall one-year performance of CPFIS funds was 5.29%, with unit trusts rising 5.86% and ILPs rising 4.96%. Experts warn of potential volatility risk due to ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Working Buddies
summary: A new co-working app, Workbuddy, has been launched in Singapore, offering users access to over 20 co-working spaces across the city. The app, priced at $129 for a 5-day pass or $299 for an unlimited monthly pass, allows users to book a desk instantly without contracts. Co-founder Gaurav Joshi aims to provide professionals with "new levels of freedom" to access workspaces anytime. The app is available on Google Play and App Store, targeting freelancers, start-ups, and multinational enterprises.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket chain, is well-positioned to capture sales during the Hungry Ghost Festival, a Buddhist and Taoist custom where devotees make food and paper offerings to the deceased. The chain has a wider range and availability of prayer items compared to its peers NTUC FairPrice and Dairy Farm, with some outlets dedicating entire sections or areas to festival stock. This is expected to boost sales during the 7-day festival.

site_title: Small Touches, Big Difference
summary: Pastor Jireh Ang downsized from a 1,700 sq ft townhouse in Seattle to a 785 sq ft two-bedroom apartment in Singapore, making the most of the smaller space. With the help of architect Tan Sok Tuan, the apartment's layout was transformed to maximize the limited floor area. The space features clever design elements, including foldable partitions, color blocks, and a bed with storage, making the apartment feel larger than it is. Despite the challenges of downsizing, Ang has turned the space into a cozy home, finding a sense of freedom and peace in his new space.

images.alt_text: Part of the living room can be transformed into a guest room, with the use of foldable partitions.
A custom designed black painted steel frame door with mesh inserts serves to create a sense of visual transparency.
The master bathroom shower space is finished in black mosaic tiles contrasting against the rest of the bathroom.
Pastor Jireh Ang downsized from a 1,700 sq ft townhouse to a 785 sq ft apartment.
Glass doors separate the dining area and the kitchen.
Escher inspired homogenous tiles are carefully aligned with the paneling of the kitchen cabinetry.

site_title: Will Powell bend to Trump's desire for lower US dollar?
summary: US dollar rallies despite twin deficits, due to emerging nation debt repayments and a strong American economy. However, investors are wary due to the Trump Administration's preference for a weak dollar to maintain US competitiveness. Fed Governor Jerome Powell's comments on gentle interest rate rises to curb inflation have disappointed markets, and economists warn that small rate hikes may not be enough to control inflation. The US dollar index has fallen 2.5% since mid-August, and investors are concerned about the impact of the upcoming US elections on the dollar's value.

site_title: Campbell Soup to sell units, leaves open option of complete sale
summary: Campbell Soup Co plans to sell its international and fresh refrigerated-foods units, leaving the possibility open for a complete sale. The move comes after months of pressure from hedge fund investors, including Dan Loeb's Third Point LLC, who wants the company to be sold to a competitor. Campbell forecast earnings per share for fiscal 2019 below Wall Street's average estimate, citing struggles to attract young consumers and increasing debt and costs. The company aims to use the proceeds of the unit sales to reduce debt and increase cost savings.

site_title: Longer practice stint, tougher Bar exams to secure industry's future
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law has accepted recommendations to strengthen the professional training regime for lawyers, including tougher Bar exams and a longer practice-training period. The changes aim to secure the industry's future and raise training standards in a rapidly changing profession. Law graduates will have greater flexibility in their career paths, with the option to be admitted to the Bar without practice training. Those who wish to practice law will still need to complete a practice training contract. The new regime will be implemented from the 2023 session of the Singapore Bar Examinations, with 17 other recommendations to be implemented over the next five years.

site_title: Nestle wants your DNA
summary: Nestle, the world's largest food company, has launched a personalized nutrition program in Japan, using artificial intelligence, DNA testing, and social media to provide tailored diet recommendations and supplements. The program, which costs $600 a year, aims to help customers improve their health and longevity. This move marks a shift in Nestle's direction, as the company invests in healthier options and nutraceuticals to address growing consumer interest in natural and less processed products.

images.alt_text: A glass of Nestle Japan Ltd nutrient-fortified green tea and a drink capsule.

Supplementary nutritional information, provided by Nestle Japan's Wellness Ambassador programme, delivered via the Line application to a user who has provided a photo of his meal, is displayed on a tablet.

site_title: Developer sentiment hit by new cooling measures: survey
summary: Developer sentiment in Singapore's prime residential and suburban sectors declined significantly following the government's new cooling measures, according to a survey. The Real Estate Sentiment Index (RESI) dropped from 6.6 to 3.9, indicating deteriorating market conditions. The prime residential sector's net balance percentage turned negative (-31%), while the suburban sector's dropped from 53% to -31%. Only office, business park/hi-tech space, and hotel/serviced apartment sectors showed positive sentiments, with 87.9% of developers expecting new launches to be higher before the measures.

site_title: A Fistful Of Rupiahs
summary: Buffalo Boys, an Indonesian Western directed by Mike Wiluan, is set in 19th-century Java and follows exiled brothers Ario Bayu and Tio Pakusadewo as they return to Indonesia to unravel their past and avenge their parents' brutal deaths. The film, which has an epic trailer, is compared to Quentin Tarantino and John Woo's works. Buffalo Boys is scheduled to open in theatres on September 6.

site_title: Ministers in fresh round of mega-deal trade talks
summary: Ministers from 10 Asean countries, along with Australia, China, India, Japan, South Korea, and New Zealand, are engaged in fresh trade talks for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) deal. The talks, which began in Singapore, aim to conclude the agreement by November. Minister Chan Chun Sing hopes for a clear plan by then, with negotiations set to progress in October and potentially lead to a deal by the end of the year. The RCEP, which involves significant trade-offs, aims to strengthen supply chains and reach a bilateral trade target of $200 billion with Korea by 2020.

site_title: Bloomberg moves business forum from Beijing to Singapore
summary: Billionaire media executive Michael Bloomberg has moved the planned business forum from Beijing to Singapore due to Chinese partner's request to postpone the event, citing President Xi Jinping's preference for a Shanghai import expo to boost international trade interest. The move highlights the difficulty of conducting business in China amid rising tensions with the US, with the Shanghai event taking on new significance due to the ongoing trade war. The forum, originally set for Beijing, will now take place in Singapore in November, with a reduced focus on China.

site_title: STI dips on rising trade friction
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended in the red for the second straight day, down 0.6% to 3,225.72, due to rising tensions between the US and China. Analysts attributed the decline to cooling economic growth in China and concerns over a protracted trade war. The tumbling Argentine peso may also trigger a renewed wave of emerging market currency rout, according to DBS Group Research analyst Yeo Kee Yan.

site_title: Mega-trade deals can pave way for bigger pacts: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of globalisation and defending it through international mechanisms like the World Trade Organization (WTO). He believes mega-trade deals, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), can pave the way for even bigger projects, but warned of the risk of trade friction escalating into a destabilizing global economy. Heng reiterated the need for a rules-based, multilateral trading system and called for countries to make full use of the WTO to resolve issues.

site_title: Barnier says no-deal Brexit is possible despite market optimism
summary: European Union chief negotiator Michel Barnier warned that a no-deal Brexit remains a possibility despite market optimism. He stated that the EU must be prepared for all options, including a no-deal scenario. German Economy Minister Peter Altmaier also expressed concerns about the time running out in negotiations. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab confirmed that the deal timeline is slipping beyond the October deadline, with a summit of EU leaders in Salzburg on September 20 likely to be more significant.

site_title: Economic optimism rides Malaysia's winds of change
summary: Malaysia celebrates its 61st Merdeka Day with a bold transformation and resilience in its economy, having diversified from natural rubber and palm oil exports to a vibrant regional hub for financial, infocomms, and logistics services. Despite concerns over international crises and sluggish GDP growth in Q2, investors remain optimistic, citing the government's accountability and transparency, as well as Malaysia's diversified economic structure, strong external position, and robust institutions. The World Bank's Malaysia Economic Monitor report sees an opportunity for structural reforms and convergence with high-income economies, with investors looking to the upcoming Budget and mid-term review for clarity on the government's economic policy direction.

site_title: Consumer spending, inflation up in July; incomes cool
summary: US consumer spending and inflation rose in July, with purchases increasing 0.4% and inflation reaching a six-year high of 2.3% annual gain. This supports the Federal Reserve's decision to gradually raise interest rates, with two more hikes expected this year. Despite a 0.3% increase in incomes, inflation-adjusted spending slowed to its lowest pace since February. The economy expanded at a 4.2% annualized rate in the second quarter, with consumption rebounding to a 3.8% pace.

site_title: Superstar CEOs of winner-takes-all economy may self-destruct
summary: Celebrity CEOs in the tech industry, such as Elon Musk, may ultimately self-destruct due to the pressures of a "winner-takes-all" economy. A recent study by MIT professor John Van Reenen suggests that structural factors, including globalization and new technology, contribute to the emergence of superstar companies with high sales margins and returns on capital. These companies often have impulsive leaders who prioritize global control over all else, leading to instability and potential downfall. While some companies, like Netflix and Tesla, have successfully navigated this landscape, others, like Uber, have seen their founders ousted due to excessive ambition.

site_title: KOP breaks ground on integrated Shanghai ski resort
summary: KOP, a Singapore-based property developer, has broken ground on a 227,000 sq m integrated ski resort in Shanghai, called Wintastar Shanghai. The $1.21 billion project, set to open in 2022, will feature an indoor ski and snow park, retail and food outlets, and a luxury hotel brand Montigo Resorts, with 1,000 room keys. The resort aims to attract 3.2 million visitors annually, primarily from the domestic market, and will be designed and run by Majid Al Futtaim.

site_title: Malaysia's property market buoyed by steady economic growth
summary: Malaysia's property market is expected to see a gentle recovery in the second half of 2018 and into 2019, driven by steady economic growth, favourable labour market conditions, and the conclusion of the 2018 General Election. The Kuala Lumpur residential segment is expected to see more enquiries and investment activities, with prices and rentals holding steady for high-end condominium and serviced apartment schemes. The office market remains challenging, but active enquiries and leasing activities from co-working operators and rising demand for flexible work space bode well for the short term.

site_title: Greenest Shophouse In Town
summary: The office of HKS Asia Pacific Design Consulting at 51 Duxton Road in Singapore has been awarded the Green Mark Gold Plus Certification by the Building and Construction Authority (BCA), marking the first time a shophouse has received this status. Designed to minimize energy usage, the office incorporates green features such as energy-efficient LED lights, a two-storey vertical green wall, and indoor plants, while also encouraging staff to adopt environmentally conscious habits. The award reflects the company's commitment to sustainability and its goal of designing the "greenest shophouse" in Singapore.

images.alt_text: A double storey vertical green wall adds to the ambience of HKS.
The original ceiling is kept and the carpet has green certification.

site_title: Decision on Singapore and Malaysia rail projects out soon
summary: Singapore and Malaysia are set to announce their joint decisions on the Johor Baru-Singapore Rapid Transit System and the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur High Speed Rail projects soon, according to Khaw Boon Wan, Singapore's Coordinating Minister for Infrastructure and Transport.

site_title: Born From Healing
summary: Two skincare and wellness brand founders, Cord Cohen and Kazumasa Kawasaki, have created products that benefit others after overcoming personal health crises. Cohen, who suffered a devastating car crash at 19, found healing through alternative therapy in India, which inspired his luxurious body care line Zents. Kawasaki, who suffered multiple organ failure in his early life, developed his eponymous skincare brand, The Kawasaki Way, featuring products that promote internal and external health. Both brands prioritize natural ingredients, sustainability, and customer well-being.

site_title: It's A Rich Man's World
summary: A new film, "Crazy Rich Asians," offers a glimpse into the lives of Asia's ultra-wealthy, but its portrayal is limited. Based on author Kevin Kwan's 2013 bestseller, the movie follows the romance between a Singaporean bachelor and his American girlfriend, amidst a backdrop of extravagant weddings and family drama. The film showcases the lavish lifestyles of Singapore's top one percent, including multi-million-dollar wedding gifts and A-list pop stars. While it explores universal themes of identity and empowerment, the movie also raises questions about the authenticity of its depiction of the super-rich, with some critics arguing it doesn't go far enough in its portrayal.

site_title: Lunch At Waku Ghin
summary: Waku Ghin, a two-Michelin-starred restaurant, introduces a five-course executive set lunch menu starting from September 7 for S$180. The lunch menu features four savory dishes and one dessert, with a signature dish available only for lunch, featuring Hokkaido uni, oscietra caviar, and raw shrimp lightly tossed with al dente pasta. The restaurant also offers casual bites at the bar, including grilled Ohmi wagyu rice set and marinated fried chicken.

images.alt_text: Tengumai Gorin sake with a bowl of marinated toro tuna on rice.

site_title: Moody's cuts CMT's outlook to 'negative'
summary: Moody's Investors Service downgraded CapitaLand Mall Trust's (CMT) outlook to 'negative' due to the proposed acquisition of Infinity Mall Trust's Westgate, which is expected to increase CMT's debt leverage. The acquisition, financed through debt, will likely weaken CMT's headroom within its A2 ratings. Moody's expects CMT's leverage to weaken to 6.9 times on a normalized basis, eroding any headroom under the downgrade trigger level of 7.0 times. The outlook could return to stable if CMT improves its debt leverage, but further downward pressure is possible if the retail environment deteriorates or CMT fails to maintain a well-managed debt maturity profile.

site_title: Magic Leap's augmented reality gear meets actual reality, and stumbles
summary: Magic Leap, a Florida start-up, has raised $2.3 billion from investors to develop augmented reality (AR) glasses that can mix computer-generated images into human sight. The company, which has been secretive for seven years, released demo videos and allowed a few to test its View Master under controlled conditions. However, its progress appears to be slow, with some questioning whether it can deliver on its promises, making its "next big thing" status uncertain.

site_title: SGX increases investment in subsidiary Asian Gateway Investments by S$73.7m
summary: SGX has increased its investment in Asian Gateway Investments by S$73.7 million through the issuance of 73.7 million ordinary shares. The capital injection will be used for additional working capital and is funded by internal resources, with no impact on earnings per share or net tangible asset value. Post-injection, SGX will retain 100% ownership of AGI. The move does not affect the company's current financial year.

site_title: Ready, Action
summary: Richard Mille has unveiled the RM 25-01 Tourbillon Adventure Chronograph, a high-end watch developed in collaboration with Sylvester Stallone. The timepiece features a tonneau-shaped case, interchangeable bezels, and a spirit level indicator. It also includes a special compartment for storing water purification tablets. The watch's movement, a grade 5 titanium tourbillon, has reduced energy consumption by 50% through months of development. Only 20 pieces of the RM 25-01 Tourbillon Adventure Chronograph are available, making it a unique and exclusive timepiece for urban warriors.

site_title: Ex-bank officer who misappropriated S$520,000 gets 12-year prohibition
summary: A former bank officer, Bentley Lee Chang Yeh, has been prohibited from carrying out regulated activities for 12 years due to his "fraudulent and dishonest conduct" in misappropriating S$520,000 from clients. He was previously jailed in 2017 for the same offense. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has banned him from performing financial advisory services under the Financial Advisers Act and from carrying out activities regulated under the Securities and Futures Act.

site_title: CapitaLand buys prime residential site in Ho Chi Minh City
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property developer, has acquired a prime residential site in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam for S$81.4 million. The company paid 62% of the purchase price in cash, with the remaining balance subject to post-completion adjustments. CapitaLand plans to build over 100 landed residential units by 2021 on the site, which is in the fast-growing District 2 region of the city. The acquisition marks the company's ninth residential development in the area, with 93% of its launched units in Vietnam sold as of June 30, 2018.

site_title: Australia's A$15b telco deal dials up high hopes
summary: TPG Telecom and Vodafone Hutchison's joint venture is merging to create a $15 billion competitor in Australia's telecom market. The deal is expected to reduce the likelihood of a price war and may lead to higher profits for the industry. TPG's David Teoh retains 49.9% of the merged operation, while Vodafone and Li Ka-shing's Hong Kong holding company each own 25%. The merger is expected to yield annual synergies of $350 million, or 6% of combined revenue, and may benefit Telstra, which saw its shares jump 10% on the deal possibility.

site_title: Beaded Beauties
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels has introduced new bracelets to its Perlee collection, featuring rows of small gold beads that add sparkle and create a multi-dimensional effect. The Perlee couleurs bracelets showcase contrasting effects with diamonds and hard stones, while the Perlee diamond bracelets are more subtle with rows of round diamonds flanked by gold beads. The new additions join existing designs, which have been popular since 2008, and demonstrate the maison's continued innovation in jewelry design.

site_title: ICBC flags trade war risks as profits rise
summary: China's largest commercial bank, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), reported higher first-half profits and steady bad loan ratios, but flagged trade tensions as a risk to the economy. The bank's net profit rose to 160.4 billion yuan, up 5.7% from the same period last year, despite analysts' expectations of a 5.2% rise. ICBC chairman Jiang Jianqing expressed concerns about trade friction bringing uncertainty to the global and Chinese economies.

site_title: R.E.S.P.E.C.T.
summary: Aretha Franklin, known as the Queen of Soul, died at 76. Her iconic 1968 album 'Lady Soul' stands out, crossing genres and breaking records. The album features 10 perfect or near-perfect songs, including 'Chain of Fools', 'People Get Ready', and '(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman'. Considered one of the finest songs in pop music history, 'Lady Soul' is available on iTunes.

site_title: Malaysia's consumption tax revenue to be half previous level
summary: Malaysia's new Sales and Services Tax (SST) is expected to collect less than half the revenue of the previous Goods and Services Tax (GST). The SST, which takes effect on Saturday, will impose a 5-10% tax on goods and 6% on services. Despite the higher tax rate, the government has declared 5,443 items exempt, compared to 544 under GST. The finance minister projects SST to raise RM21 billion in 2019, down from RM44 billion by GST last year, with RM23 billion returned to the people. Headline inflation is expected to moderate at 1.3%.

site_title: Mao's China, and its transformation in less than 4 decades
summary: China, the world's second-largest economy, is rapidly transforming under Mao's legacy, with significant investments in modern technologies. The US, however, is embroiled in a trade war with China, sparking concerns about a potential war between the two nations. A Harvard University professor's research found that 12 out of 16 historical encounters between a rising power and an established great power have led to war, fueling fears of an inevitable conflict. Experts warn that the US-China confrontation may lead to open war, echoing the Thucydides Trap theory.

site_title: IFA clarifies recommendation for Wheelock offer
summary: PrimePartners Corporate Finance, the IFA to Wheelock Properties' recommending directors, has clarified its advice on taking the company private as "fair and reasonable" following market feedback. The IFA reworded a paragraph in its original letter to address potential inconsistencies, advising the directors to recommend shareholders accept the offer unless they can obtain a higher price on the open market. The offer closes on September 7, 2018.

site_title: The jury's still out on the magic of mushroom tea
summary: Mushroom tea, promoted as a health enhancer, lacks concrete scientific evidence to support its claimed benefits, including boosting energy and easing depression. While some studies suggest potential benefits, such as improved mental functioning in lion's mane, more research is needed to confirm these findings. The three most popular and researched adaptogenic mushrooms - chaga, lion's mane, and reishi - may interact with medications or cause adverse effects, and their safety and effectiveness for certain health conditions remain unproven.

site_title: A promising start for Esora
summary: Esora, a new Japanese eatery in Singapore, has made a visually stunning debut with its modern Zen-inspired design. Chef Shigeru Koizumi's food, however, requires more time to evolve, with dishes that are pleasant but lack depth. The restaurant offers a unique blend of Japanese flavors and Western influences, with standout dishes like grilled ayu and sashimi platter. While the food is not yet on par with Tokyo standards, Esora is a promising start, and with further refinement, it could become a top dining destination.

site_title: Apple buys startup focused on lenses for AR glasses
summary: Apple has acquired Akonia Holographics, a startup focused on creating lenses for augmented reality glasses. The acquisition signals Apple's ambitions to develop wearable devices that can superimpose digital information on the real world. Akonia's display technology enables "thin, transparent smart glass lenses" that display vibrant, full-color images. The deal is Apple's first clear indication of how it will handle the challenge of producing crystal-clear optical displays for augmented reality glasses.

site_title: Chinese soya buyers leave US exporters show empty handed
summary: US soybean exporters attended their annual conference without securing any known sales to Chinese buyers, a stark contrast to previous years when billions of dollars' worth of soybeans were signed over to China. The US-China trade dispute has halted bilateral trade in soybeans, with US farmers concerned that export demand will fall short this autumn. Despite delegations from other countries, including Mexico, inking deals for US soybeans, Chinese soybean importers toured a Missouri farm and exchanged market views with US counterparts, but no deals were finalized.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as China trade worries linger
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, halting a four-day record run for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indexes, due to lingering concerns over the US-China trade dispute. The Dow Jones fell 0.10%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.18%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.19%. Optimism over US-Canada trade talks was overshadowed by worries about US tariffs on Chinese goods.

site_title: Canada economy grew 2.9% in Q2
summary: Canada's economy grew 2.9% in the second quarter, driven by a rise in export volumes, particularly in energy products, and consumer spending. Exports led the growth, with foreign sales of pharmaceutical products and business jets contributing to the increase. However, business investments slowed in the quarter. The growth was slightly less than expected, with analysts projecting 3% growth.

images.alt_text: Canada's economy grew at an annual rate of 2.9 per cent in the second quarter, lifted by a rise in exports and services, the national statistical agency said Thursday.

site_title: Jho Low's father cuts stake in Frencken
summary: Larry Low Hock Peng, father of fugitive financier Jho Low, has reduced his stake in Singapore-listed contract manufacturer Frencken Group from 8.14% to 4.74%, following the disposal of his shares in Meng Tak Corp. This comes amid speculation over his involvement in the 1MDB scandal. Frencken shares have fallen 25% since the start of the year, with the company facing money-laundering charges related to alleged embezzlement of funds from 1Malaysia Development Bhd.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks turn lower after three-day streak
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.89% on Thursday, ending a three-day winning streak, as investors cashed in gains. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 28,164.05, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also declined. Strong US growth data and a record close on Wall Street failed to spark further buying, with investors instead focusing on profit-taking.

site_title: Raising the bar
summary: Singaporean entrepreneurs are making a name for themselves in the global food and drink industry, with several individuals achieving prestigious awards and recognition. Joshua Kalinan, a 52-year-old Singapore Airlines' inflight auditor, became the first Singaporean to win the Sake Sommelier of the Year 2018 award in the UK. Sashi Cheliah, a 40-year-old former police officer, won MasterChef Australia in 2018, showcasing Singaporean flavors on the global stage. Teo Hong Han, a former accountant, opened Pink Blossoms Brewing, Singapore's newest craft beer scene, while Andrew Hodgson, Tim Whitefield, Chris Box, and Charlie van Eeden, expats from the UK, created the first locally made craft gin, Tanglin Gin. These individuals are elevating Singapore's presence in the global F&B industry, demonstrating the country's talent and entrepreneurial spirit.

site_title: Credit Suisse is seeking withdrawal from debt deal with owner of National Enquirer
summary: Credit Suisse is reconsidering its role in refinancing American Media Inc's $425 million debt, following negative publicity surrounding the publisher of the National Enquirer. The Swiss bank had been set to lead the deal, but now seeks to withdraw due to the company's association with hush-money payments to women who had affairs with Donald Trump in 2016. Representatives for both Credit Suisse and American Media declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Germany eyes European banking champion in fix for Deutsche woes
summary: Germany is considering European banking consolidation to address the struggles of Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, two of the country's largest banks. Finance Minister Olaf Scholz and Chancellor Angela Merkel's government have called for mergers or cross-border deals to create "national or European champions" that can compete globally. The move aims to support Germany's export-driven economy and address concerns about the country's fragmented financial landscape. However, regulatory hurdles and complexities of cross-border consolidation must be cleared before major consolidation can proceed.

site_title: Douglas Deboer
summary: Douglas DeBoer, CEO of Crystal Jade Culinary Concepts, shares his journey from Minnesota to becoming a leading figure in the Singapore food industry. DeBoer, who spent formative years in China, credits his experience for his deep understanding of Chinese culture and food. He plans to expand Crystal Jade into seven to 10 new markets in the next five years, including North America and the Middle East. DeBoer's strategy involves global expansion, tier expansion, and enhancing food quality. He emphasizes the importance of understanding consumer goals and building relationships in the business world, drawing parallels between Asia and the US.

site_title: Malaysia shares close flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 0.98 points down at 1,819.66 on Thursday, with 685 losers outnumbering 299 gainers. The stock market saw 26.5 million lots traded worth RM2.95 billion.

site_title: US airlines mull fare, fee hikes to stem falling profits
summary: US airlines are increasing fares and fees to combat declining profits, targeting ancillary revenue, baggage fees, and base fares. Fuel prices have risen 26% over the past year, and airlines are trimming expansion plans. Business fares have climbed 8% this week, while leisure travel ticket prices remain unchanged. Major carriers, including American, United, and Delta, are likely to follow JetBlue's lead in raising checked-bag fees, which generated $6 billion in revenue for the three largest US carriers last year. The industry's annual profit is headed for a third straight decline.

images.alt_text: JetBlue Airways Corp became the first major US carrier to raise fees on the first checked bag to US$30.

site_title: The Challenger
summary: Declan Ee, a partner at TLG Capital and co-founder of Castlery, shares his passions and inspirations. He grew up listening to Chinese music and electronic music in London, blending genres in his music group Trouze. Ee is driven by moments of perfection and aims to live out his passions, supporting marginalized communities through his private investment firm. In his free time, he journals and takes 30-minute walks to relax and reflect on his life. Ee finds inspiration in people, places, and things, particularly through music, which serves as a time capsule connecting him to his past.

site_title: Bad Apple business drags Epicentre into S$7.1m FY18 loss
summary: Epicentre Holdings, a Singapore-based company, reported a net loss of S$7.1 million in FY18 due to losses from its Apple-related businesses. Revenue from continuing operations fell 30.5% to S$18.35 million, largely from a decline in Malaysian operations. The company's board described the operating environment as "challenging" but sees an opportunity to venture into new business areas through a planned acquisition.

site_title: TFG to open retail brand in Australia, test appetite outside Africa
summary: The Foschini Group (TFG), a South African clothing and homeware retailer, plans to launch one of its African retail brands in Australia to test its market appeal. The move aims to gauge the success of TFG's local brands in more developed markets. Six stores are expected to open by the end of the year, with plans for up to 100 stores if the test is successful. TFG's expansion into Australia follows its 2017 acquisition of Retail Apparel Group, and the company views itself as a disruptor in the Australian market.

site_title: Britain to consider doubling charge on single-use plastic bags
summary: Britain is considering doubling the charge on single-use plastic bags from 5 pence to 10 pence and extending it to all shops. The move aims to reduce plastic bag sales, which have dropped by 86% since 2015. The government will launch a consultation later this year to set out the plans. Small-and-medium-sized businesses supply over three billion plastic bags annually, prompting the government to expand the charge to cover all shops.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lum Chang, a Singapore-based construction and property developer, invited holders of its S$50 million 5.5% notes due 2019 to exchange their notes for S$50 million 5.8% notes due 2021. The company aims to retain noteholders after the existing notes' redemption on March 28, 2019. As an incentive, it will pay 0.6% of the principal amount for early submissions. Meanwhile, Singapore Myanmar Investco terminated a joint venture with Jones The Grocer in Myanmar due to an unavailability of the initial development location. The Singapore Exchange Limited increased its investment in Asian Gateway Investments by S$73.7 million.

site_title: Fixing the US trade deficit comes at the cost of growth
summary: US President Donald Trump's goal of maximizing domestic economic growth and ending the country's trade deficit is contradictory. To balance the books, the US would need to reduce consumption, but this is unsustainable without a reserve currency. The US dollar's status as the global reserve currency means it can finance current account deficits through printing money. Ending the trade deficit would require the US dollar to lose its reserve currency status, but this is not a sovereign decision. Instead, it's determined by global economic actors. To address the underlying cause of the deficit, the US would need to focus on domestic savings and reduce spending, which Trump is unlikely to do due to his love of creating debt.

site_title: US consumer spending, inflation rose in July; incomes cooled
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.4% in July, matching economists' estimates, while inflation rose to a six-year high of 2.3% annual gain. This reflects economic strength, keeping the Federal Reserve on track to gradually raise interest rates. Consumer spending drove growth, with increases in outlays on prescription drugs, food services, and accommodations. Initial jobless claims rose to 213,000, and wages and salaries rose 0.4% for the second month.

site_title: Fund that made 10,000% return on Spotify seeks new winners
summary: A Swedish venture capital fund, Creandum, is seeking new investors for a fund that made a 10,000% return on Spotify, investing in startups like Kry, Neo Technology, and Epidemic Sound, which have "Spotify potential". Creandum's general partner, Johan Brenner, prioritizes companies with strong founding teams, unique business ideas, and large markets. The fund has previously invested in Spotify, Klarna, and Kahoot!, and has returned about 1,000% since its inception in 2007, with a 12-year perspective and a focus on early-stage investments.

site_title: Indian opposition raps Modi over "failed" ban on high-value notes
summary: India's main opposition Congress party criticizes Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 2016 demonetization policy, which aimed to curb black money, as a "failed" move. The policy withdrew 500 and 1,000 rupee notes from circulation, causing economic hardship and hurting the cash-dependent economy. Data shows the policy did not meet its key objective of bringing unaccounted wealth into the mainstream economy. The move has been widely criticized for its negative impact on the economy and ordinary people.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.6% down on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.6% to 3,225.72 on Thursday, with 229 losers outpacing 156 gainers. Total shares traded were 2.24 billion worth S$1.09 billion. Notable movers included Rex International (flat), Rich Capital (flat), and Singtel (up 1.88%). Active index stocks included DBS (down 0.24%) and OCBC Bank (up 0.09%).

site_title: London court approves S'pore extradition request of suspected StanChart robber; case sent to UK Secretary of State for decision
summary: A London court has approved Singapore's extradition request for Canadian national David James Roach, suspected of robbing a Standard Chartered Bank branch in 2016. The case has been sent to the UK Secretary of State for a decision on whether Roach should be extradited. The Singapore authorities are working closely with the UK authorities on the next steps, according to a statement from the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Attorney-General's Chambers.

site_title: China private equity industry faces turbulence after debt clampdown
summary: China's private equity industry is experiencing turbulence due to Beijing's debt clampdown and Sino-US trade tensions. Fundraising has slowed, with $19.7 billion raised in the first half of the year, down from an average of $46.5 billion since 2010. Yuan-denominated funds have been particularly affected, with a 90% drop in fundraising. The industry faces reduced liquidity, impacting deal-making and company funding plans, with some funds unable to achieve desired returns, and investors opting for funds with a proven performance track record.

site_title: Ex-bank officer who misappropriated S$520,000 gets 12-year prohibition orders
summary: A former bank officer, Bentley Lee Chang Yeh, has been slapped with multiple 12-year prohibition orders by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for misappropriating S$520,000 from clients while working at United Overseas Bank from 2005 to 2010. Lee was previously jailed for 4 years and 9 months and fined S$50,000 for the offense. The prohibition orders bar him from carrying out regulated activities, including financial advisory services and management roles. The move aims to protect consumers, deter similar misconduct, and preserve the integrity of the financial industry.

site_title: CPFIS funds deliver 0.62% returns in Q2
summary: CPFIS funds delivered average returns of 0.62% in Q2, with unit trusts averaging 0.64% and investment-linked insurance products averaging 0.60%. Equity funds rose 0.88%, while bond funds fell 0.41%. Over the past year, CPFIS funds posted a positive return of 5.29%, with unit trusts rising 5.86% and ILPs rising 4.96%. The MSCI All Country Asia ex-Japan index fell 1.54% in Q2, but rose 9.13% over the past year. Trade tensions pose a risk to global economic growth.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of regional deals like the RCEP and BRI, calling for careful execution. The country also launched initiatives to develop AI and data applications, and a joint Singapore-Malaysia decision on high-speed rail and road tunnel links is set to be announced soon. Meanwhile, KOP broke ground on an integrated indoor ski resort in Shanghai, and Moody's downgraded CMT's outlook to 'negative' due to increased debt leverage following its Westgate acquisition. Singapore shares closed 0.6% lower on Thursday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks flat, erase early gains on sluggish Chinese markets; won up
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index ended flat on Thursday, giving up early gains as Chinese markets declined. The Korean won rose, while US President Donald Trump permitted targeted relief from steel and aluminum quotas for countries including South Korea, boosting steel shares. Cosmetic and duty-free stocks also rose on expectations of increasing Chinese tourist arrivals. The won was quoted at 1,108.6 per dollar, up 0.14% from its previous close.
