site_title: Singapore's ACE signs pact with Austrian organisations to help startups internationalise
summary: ACTION Community for Entrepreneurship (ACE) has signed a memorandum of understanding with Advantage Austria and the Global Incubator Network (GIN) to promote international business opportunities for Singaporean and Austrian startups. The agreement aims to organize events and workshops to raise awareness of the two countries as entry points to their respective markets. The initiative also seeks to foster greater investor networks and increase market access, ultimately supporting the internationalization of startups in both countries.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,222.06, down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday at 3,222.06, down 0.7% after lunch, with the Straits Times Index retreating 21.86 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 189 to 106, with 1.08 billion shares worth S$534.7 million changing hands.

site_title: A broker just launched the world's cheapest global fund
summary: A Swedish online stockbroker, Avanza Bank AB, has launched the world's cheapest global fund with a management fee of 0.05% and a total annual cost of 0.1%. This is significantly lower than the average of 0.3% among seven other Nordic providers. The fund's ultra-low fees are expected to boost customer numbers and help Avanza reach its long-term financial targets, including having 10% of the Swedish savings market and 1 million customers by 2020.

site_title: Moody's cuts CMT's outlook to 'negative' from 'stable' on Westgate acquisition
summary: Moody's Investors Service has downgraded the outlook on CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) to "negative" from "stable" due to the proposed acquisition of Infinity Mall Trust's remaining 70% stake in Westgate. The acquisition is expected to increase CMT's debt leverage, potentially weakening its ratings. Moody's warns that if CMT fails to maintain a well-managed debt maturity profile or its financial metrics weaken, its rating could face further downward pressure.

site_title: Europe: Trade fears regain grip on shares, real estate stocks fall
summary: European shares fell 0.3-0.4% on Thursday, tracking a decline in Asian markets, as Chinese stocks plummeted due to factory sector slowdown amid trade uncertainty. Trade-sensitive mining and auto stocks tumbled 0.9-0.5%, while real estate stocks fell 1.3%. Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield shares rose despite reporting profits from its Westfield acquisition, but other UK commercial property firms Intu and Hammerson fell 4.2-3.9%. The decline was attributed to Morgan Stanley's downgrading of the European property sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end flat ahead of US data
summary: Tokyo stocks ended flat on Thursday, trimming earlier gains ahead of new US economic data. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.09%, while the Topix index declined 0.03%. Investors locked in profits, anticipating the release of US economic indicators. This move follows a recent rally in Asian markets, driven by positive sentiment despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: KOP breaks ground on integrated indoor ski resort Wintastar Shanghai
summary: KOP, a Catalist-listed property developer, broke ground on Wintastar Shanghai, a multibillion-renminbi integrated indoor ski resort in China. The project, set to open in 2022, will feature the world's largest indoor Ski & Snow Park, operated by Ski Dubai. The resort will have a total gross floor area of 227,000 sq m and offer 1,000 rooms across four themed hotels. It is expected to attract 3.2 million visitors annually, mainly from China.

site_title: BofA's Merrill lifts ban on commissions for retirement accounts
summary: Bank of America Corp's Merrill Lynch will allow commissions on retirement accounts, reversing a ban implemented in June due to the US Department of Labor's defunct fiduciary rule. The change aims to provide clients with more flexibility and choice. The ban was spurred by a US court's strike down of the fiduciary rule in March, which aimed to require brokers to prioritize clients' interests. The policy change is expected to be implemented by October 1, following a 60-day review period.

images.alt_text: Bank of America Corp's Merrill Lynch will allow commissions on retirement accounts, reversing an earlier ban that had been spurred by the US Department of Labor's now-defunct fiduciary rule.

site_title: Malaysia to impose 5-10% tax on goods, 6% on services
summary: Malaysia will impose a 5-10% tax on goods and a 6% tax on services starting September 1, as part of a new tax regime. The Sales and Services Tax (SST) replaces the previous goods and services tax (GST), which was repealed earlier this month. The SST is expected to take effect after the country's customs chief announced the new tax rates.

site_title: Asean service providers and exporters gain from two new agreements
summary: Asean service providers and exporters gained from two new agreements signed at the 50th Asean Economic Ministers Meeting. The agreements include a protocol to implement the 10th and final package of commitments for the Asean Framework Agreement on Services (AFAS), increasing market access and opening up new service sectors. The Asean Trade in Goods Agreement (ATIGA) was also amended to implement the Asean-Wide Self-Certification (AWSC) regime, allowing exporters to self-certify goods origin and enjoy preferential treatment.

site_title: Australian shares unmoved as financials offset gains from TPG-Vodafone deal; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Thursday following a merger between TPG Telecom and Hutchison Telecommunications, creating a heavyweight challenger to Telstra. The merger's implied value is A$15 billion, with TPG's shares rising 18%, Hutchison's 44%, and Telstra's 2.9%. Weaker financials from the "Big Four" banks offset gains, with Commonwealth Bank down 1.5% and Westpac up 2.7% after raising mortgage rates. New Zealand's benchmark index slipped 0.2% due to declining business confidence, with a survey showing a decade-low in August.

site_title: Asia: stocks slip, weakness in China outweighs Nafta trade optimism
summary: Asian stocks slipped on Thursday, weighed down by China's market weakness despite optimism over the US-Mexico trade deal and the potential for a NAFTA agreement. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.8% and the Hang Seng Index dropped 0.7%, while the US dollar index struggled near a four-week low. Despite this, US shares extended their rally, hitting record highs for a fourth straight session, and the pound surged as fears of a 'hard Brexit' eased.

site_title: Developer sentiment takes a hard hit after new cooling measures: survey
summary: Developer sentiment in Singapore has dropped significantly following the government's announcement of new cooling measures, according to a survey. The Real Estate Sentiment Index (RESI) fell from 6.6 to 3.9, indicating deteriorating market conditions. Out of 65% of developers who expected new launches to be higher post-measures, only 13.5% anticipated residential property prices to increase, while 48.6% expected prices to drop. The outlook for prime residential and suburban sectors were the hardest hit, while office, business park/hi-tech space, and hotel/serviced apartment sectors were relatively unaffected.

site_title: CapitaLand buys 60,732 sq m prime residential site in Ho Chi Minh City for 1.38t dong
summary: CapitaLand acquired a 60,732 sq m prime residential site in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam for 1.38 trillion Vietnamese dong (S$81.4 million) in cash. The site is owned by Doan Nguyen House Business & Investment, which is 100% owned by BCLand Joint Stock Co. CapitaLand's wholly owned subsidiaries acquired 100% of BCLand's charter capital, with 62% of the consideration paid upfront and the remaining balance subject to post-completion adjustments.

site_title: Australian shares rise on TPG-Vodafone deal; NZ edges lower
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Thursday following the merger of TPG Telecom and Vodafone Group's local unit, Hutchison Telecommunications (Australia), valued at A$15 billion. TPG shares surged 22%, while Vodafone's Hutchison rose 76%. The deal increases competition in the sector. Meanwhile, financial stocks fell, with Westpac Banking down 0.6%, and New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index slipped 0.2%.

site_title: China arrests private fund chief after 18b yuan goes missing
summary: China has arrested Zhu Yidong, 36, chairman of Shanghai Fuxing Group, on suspicion of manipulating stocks and economic crimes. The arrest follows the disappearance of the company after it missed 18 billion yuan (S$3.59 billion) in payments to clients through private equity products. Authorities plan to check Fuxing's private fund assets and investor list to defuse risks, amid a broader crackdown on financial wrongdoing in China. This case highlights the country's determination to cut risk from the economy and stabilize markets.

site_title: South Korea police raid BMW office over car fires
summary: South Korean police raided BMW's Seoul headquarters in connection with dozens of engine fires in BMW vehicles. The investigation is into whether the company covered up vehicle defects and the police seized documents and materials. The move follows reports of over 40 BMW vehicles bursting into flames this year, leading to a temporary ban on untested BMW cars in South Korea and several complaints filed against the company. BMW has recalled 106,000 vehicles with a faulty exhaust gas recirculation module and faces ongoing legal actions over the issue.

site_title: Suspected bank robber can be extradited to Singapore
summary: A British court has ruled that a Canadian citizen, David Roach, can be extradited to Singapore to face charges of robbery and money laundering. Roach is suspected of stealing $30,000 from a Standard Chartered bank branch in Singapore in 2016. Singapore agreed to waive corporal punishment, which includes caning, as a condition of the extradition. The British government will now make the final decision on Roach's extradition to Singapore.

images.alt_text: A British court has ruled a man suspected of carrying out a rare bank robbery in Singapore can be extradited after the city-state promised he will not be caned, officials said on Thursday.

site_title: NZ dollar skids as business confidence slumps; Aussie weakens on disappointing data
summary: The New Zealand dollar fell 0.7% to its weakest since August 24 after a business confidence gauge hit a decade low in August. The Australian dollar also eased due to disappointing capital expenditure data. The ANZ Bank survey found 50.3% of respondents expected economic conditions to deteriorate, with a decline from July's 44.9%. This slump in business sentiment is expected to impact economic growth, with New Zealand central bank governor Adrian Orr considering further easing of policy.

site_title: Malaysian fugitive Jho Low hires Chris Christie, Trump law firm for legal defence
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low has hired former US Governor Chris Christie and Trump law firm Kasowitz Benson Torres to defend himself in a Justice Department investigation. Low is accused of looting over $4 billion from 1MDB investment fund. He also retained Bobby Burchfield of King & Spalding to advise him on ongoing investigations. US federal officials are investigating whether Low used laundered money to pay his legal team, with no indication that anyone knew the funds were tainted. Low faces civil forfeiture charges in a Los Angeles case.

site_title: Jho Low's father cuts stake in Singapore-listed contract manufacturer Frencken
summary: Larry Low Hock Peng, father of fugitive financier Jho Low, has reduced his stake in Singapore-listed contract manufacturer Frencken Group from 8.14% to 4.74%. This follows a disposal of shares in the Low family vehicle, Meng Tak Corp. The move comes amid speculation about his involvement in the 1MDB scandal. Frencken's shares have lost 28% of their value since the start of the year. Larry Low and his son Jho are wanted by Malaysian police for money-laundering charges related to the alleged embezzlement of funds from 1MDB.

site_title: Monetary Authority of Singapore and Dubai authority sign fintech accord
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Dubai Financial Services Authority (DFSA) have signed a fintech accord, allowing each party to refer fintech companies to the other and facilitating information sharing on innovation in the financial sector. They will work on joint projects on key technologies, including digital payments, blockchain, and big data. The agreement aims to deliver new financial services, manage risks, reduce costs, and increase efficiency. This is the third pact between MAS and DFSA, following a 2008 Memorandum of Understanding and a 2022 collaboration with the Association of Supervisors of Banks of the Americas.

site_title: As Bali awaits financial elite, a volcano is still rumbling
summary: Indonesia prepares for the International Monetary Fund and World Bank Group annual meeting on Bali in October, amid safety concerns following a recent earthquake and ongoing volcanic activity. The island's Mount Agung volcano has been rumbling for a year, prompting mass evacuations and airport closures. Authorities have a contingency plan in place, including evacuation ships and navy vessels, in case of a volcanic eruption. The IMF-World Bank meeting will focus on infrastructure financing, digital economy, and the trade war between the US and China, with Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell attending.

site_title: Singapore to train 2,000 executives, workers in developing basic AI, data applications
summary: Singapore has launched two nationwide initiatives to boost its artificial intelligence (AI) talent pool. The initiatives, AI for Industry (AI4I) and AI for Everyone (AI4E), aim to equip 12,000 Singaporeans with AI knowledge over the next three years. AI4I will provide a subsidised three-month course to 2,000 executives and those with AI skills, while AI4E is a free three-hour workshop for 10,000 people. The initiatives are part of AI Singapore's efforts to grow the AI ecosystem and address the global shortage of AI talent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 1.21 points to 1821.54. The market saw 109.7 million lots traded worth RM43.6 million, with 130 gainers outpacing 111 losers.

site_title: South Korea's Moon pushes ahead on plan to meet North Korea's Kim
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in plans to meet North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in September despite US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's cancelled trip. Moon's office stated he will work as a mediator between Kim and US President Donald Trump, aiming to resolve problems and overcome obstacles. However, US analysts have raised concerns that Moon's eagerness to improve inter-Korean ties may undermine Washington's efforts to apply "maximum pressure" on North Korea to denuclearise.

site_title: Global investor confidence falls to 18-month low in August: State Street
summary: Global investor confidence fell to an 18-month low in August, according to State Street's Investor Confidence Index, with a reading of 94.3. This marked the lowest level since February 2017. North American confidence declined 7.4 points to 92.5, while Asian confidence fell 0.9 points to 102.6. European confidence improved, rising 8.1 points to 99.5. The decline in confidence was attributed to elevated trade uncertainty and geopolitical turmoil.

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco calls off Jones The Grocer franchise joint venture
summary: Singapore Myanmar Investco (SMI) has terminated a joint venture with Pinnacle Myanmar to launch the Jones The Grocer restaurant chain in Myanmar, citing an unavailability of the initial development location. The joint venture company will be dissolved, with no impact on SMI's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the year ending March 31, 2019.

site_title: Panasonic to move UK headquarters on Brexit fears
summary: Panasonic plans to relocate its European headquarters from the UK to the Netherlands due to concerns over potential tax issues related to Brexit. The move, expected to take place in October, will shift the headquarters from outside London to Amsterdam. The decision was made to minimize potential tax liabilities, according to a company spokeswoman.

images.alt_text: Panasonic plans to move its European headquarters from Britain to the Netherlands later this year over concerns about potential tax issues related to Brexit, a company spokeswoman said Thursday.

site_title: Joint Singapore-Malaysia decisions on HSR and RTS link to be announced soon: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore and Malaysia are expected to announce joint decisions on the high-speed rail (HSR) and Rapid Transit System (RTS) link soon. Coordinating Minister for Infrastructure and Transport Khaw Boon Wan and Malaysian Economic Affairs Minister Mohamed Azmin Ali had a meeting to discuss the projects. Malaysia has confirmed the delayed RTS link will proceed, but has requested a deferment of the HSR due to its national debt. The HSR project was originally slated for completion in 2026. A joint announcement is anticipated in the near future.

site_title: Emerging-market junk-bond market shaping up as key area to watch
summary: Emerging-market junk-bond debt, set to reach a record $24.2 billion in 2021, poses a key area of concern as global investors eye higher US interest rates. Risks vary across Asia, including heavy debt piles in China, South Korea, and Taiwan, as well as current account deficits in Indonesia, India, and the Philippines. Other vulnerabilities include under-water high-grade corporate notes, credit stress, household debt, sovereign debt, trade tensions, and foreign exposure, which could impact Asia's growth prospects and expose it to a broader selloff.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.41% at the open on Thursday, tracking a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 28,533.93. Asian markets followed, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.32% and the Shenzhen Composite Index down 0.14%. The rally comes amid optimism over a potential US-Canada trade deal, which could rewrite the North American Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: Capital World's full-year profit down 17.7% to RM57.7m
summary: Capital World's full-year profit dropped 17.7% to RM57.7 million, mainly due to lower revenue from Capital City Mall, which was 83.2% completed as of June 30, 2018. Higher general and administrative costs also weighed down results. The company remains committed to completing Project Capital City and exploring joint venture projects, despite the decline.

site_title: Pressures on Didi intensify after latest passenger slaying
summary: China's largest ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing has suspended its carpooling service after a passenger was killed, amid public and government backlash. The incident, similar to a May killing by a Didi driver, exposes a weakness in Didi's business model and creates an opening for rival services to chip away at its dominance in China. Industry analysts say tighter oversight will squeeze driver numbers and extend customer waiting times. Didi's aggressive expansion without adequate control of drivers on its platform is seen as a major issue.

images.alt_text: China's largest ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing has suspended its carpooling service after a passenger was killed, and is likely to face tighter oversight that will squeeze driver numbers and extend customer waiting times.

site_title: Trump unblocks more critics on Twitter as ordered by court
summary: A federal district court judge's ruling that US President Donald Trump's Twitter account blocking opposing viewpoints violates the First Amendment has led to the unblocking of more critics. The Knight First Amendment Institute at Columbia University successfully sued Trump, and a court order requires him to unblock Twitter users blocked for criticizing him. As of Wednesday, 41 more Twitter users were unblocked, with the institute expressing confidence in defending the ruling against the Justice Department's planned appeal.

site_title: Hong Kong unveils list of professionals it wants to lure
summary: Hong Kong has released a list of 11 professions it aims to attract, including waste treatment specialists, asset management professionals, and data scientists, to bolster its competitiveness in finance and technology. Those in these fields will receive 30 bonus points under the Quality Migrant Admission Scheme. The initiative also includes an achievement-based points test for those who excel in fields like innovation, technology, and creative industries. The goal is to enhance Hong Kong's position as an international maritime hub and catch up with Shenzhen.

site_title: Make full use of global trade system, with regional deals as 'building blocks' for broader pacts: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need to carefully execute regional trade agreements, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), to support a rules-based, multilateral trading system. He urged agreements and dispute resolutions to be done through established international channels, warning that bilateral trade disputes can lead to a fragmentation of the world into major trading blocs. Heng also stressed the importance of regional integration, citing the benefits of cooperation and settling disputes, and encouraged policymakers to work together to address common challenges.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending rallies in New York, as the yen remained lower against the US dollar. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.77% to 23,023.77, while the Topix index gained 0.53%. The rally follows a strong performance in New York, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US-China trade uncertainty.

site_title: US, Canada leaders upbeat on progress in Nafta talks
summary: US President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau expressed optimism about the progress made in renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). The two leaders said they were close to a deal, with Trudeau suggesting it could be completed by the end of the week. The sticking points, including Canada's managed dairy market and labor disputes, are being worked out. A high-level agreement has been reached, and the US will notify Congress of its intention to enter into a new trade pact in 90 days.

site_title: Lum Chang offers investors an exchange of notes due 2019 for higher-coupon notes
summary: Lum Chang, a Singaporean construction and property developer, is offering investors the chance to exchange their outstanding 5.5% notes due 2019 for higher-coupon 5.8% notes due 2021. This move aims to retain investors before the existing notes are redeemed in March 2019. The company will pay a one-time fee of 0.6% for early submissions, decreasing to 0.3% for later submissions. The new notes will be issued under Lum Chang's $300 million multicurrency medium-term note program.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.11% to 3,247.64
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.11% to 3,247.64. The index saw a positive start, following gains in Japan and Australia. Gainers outnumbered losers 65 to 50, with Ezion Holdings and Singtel leading the gains. Active index stocks included DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank, both up 0.1% and 0.2% respectively.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sakae Holdings, Epicentre, Kitchen Culture
summary: Sakae Holdings reported a net profit of S$1 million for its fourth quarter, reversing a net loss of S$12.6 million in the previous year. Epicentre Holdings posted a net deficit of S$7.1 million for the year ended June 30, while Kitchen Culture reported a net loss of S$3.8 million for its fiscal year ended June 30, 2018.

site_title: TPG Telecom, Vodafone Hutchison Australia in A$15b merger to take on Singtel's Optus, Telstra
summary: Vodafone Hutchison Australia and TPG Telecom announced a merger worth A$15 billion to create a telecommunications giant, rivaling Telstra and Optus. Vodafone Australia will hold 50.1% of the merged entity, TPG Telecom Limited, with TPG shareholders owning 49.9%. The deal aims to increase competitiveness, with combined strengths in innovative services and customer focus. Regulators have approved the deal, with completion expected next year.

site_title: Gold steady as US dollar dips; rate hike expectations cap gains
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$1,205.58 an ounce, following a nearly half-percent rise in the previous session, as the US dollar edged down but interest rate hike expectations limited gains. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates next month, which could impact gold prices. The US GDP grew 4.2% in the second quarter, supporting rate hike expectations. Asian stocks rose as US and Canada expressed optimism about a new North American Free Trade Agreement deal.

site_title: China Evergrande seeks to sustain profit margin
summary: China Evergrande Group, the country's second-largest property developer, reported the industry's highest-ever first-half profit of 55.01 billion yuan (S$11 billion). The company aims to sustain margins by focusing on core tier-one and tier-two cities and targeting large, cheap land. Evergrande plans to build its land bank and has slowed down land purchases to de-leverage, with a goal of reducing its net gearing ratio to 70% by June 2020.

site_title: Argentina says IMF loan disbursements to be accelerated
summary: Argentina's President Mauricio Macri announced the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will accelerate funding for the country's austerity program, aiming to provide all necessary funds to fulfill the financial program in 2019. The IMF agreed to extend a $50 billion standby loan, with the government committing to reduce its budget deficit to 2.7% this year and 1.3% of GDP next year. However, the Argentine peso continued to decline, plummeting 6.99% through Wednesday, and market analysts expressed doubts about the government's ability to deliver on its promises.

site_title: Apple buys startup focused on lenses for AR glasses
summary: Apple has acquired Akonia Holographics, a startup focused on developing lenses for augmented reality (AR) glasses. The deal marks a significant step towards Apple's ambition to create wearable devices that can superimpose digital information on the real world. Akonia's display technology allows for thin, transparent smart glass lenses that display vibrant images, and the company had previously raised $11.6 million in seed funding. The acquisition is seen as a crucial step towards Apple's AR plans, which have been rumored to be in development for several years.

site_title: Sakae back in the black with S$1m Q4 profit
summary: Sakae Holdings reported a net profit of S$1.0 million for its fourth quarter, reversing a net loss of S$12.6 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the improvement to reduced operating expenses, including a write-back of impairment losses and cost savings from its rationalisation exercise. Revenue fell 20.3% to S$68.9 million, while earnings per share rose to 3.51 Singapore cents, up from a loss of 9.06 Singapore cents in the previous year.

site_title: Despair for Australian farmers as drought kills livestock
summary: Australia's worst drought in living memory is devastating the country's main food bowl, particularly wheat and barley crops. Farmers are struggling to feed livestock due to lack of water and grazing land, with some forced to shoot starving cattle. The drought has resulted in significant financial losses, with forecasters predicting a wheat crop of just 2.4 million tonnes, less than a third of the average annual yield. The NSW state government has declared a drought, and the federal government has pledged billions of dollars in aid for affected farmers.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won gain on trade optimism
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and the won rose on Thursday, driven by gains on Wall Street and optimism over trade tensions easing. The Kospi gained 9.62 points, or 0.42%, at 2,318.65, while the won rose 0.19% to 1,108.1 per US dollar. Steelmakers and cosmetic firms, exposed to China, also saw gains. The won has risen 3.92% against the US dollar this year, following a US Commerce Department announcement that President Trump signed a proclamation permitting targeted relief from steel and aluminum quotas.

site_title: Bad Apple business drags Epicentre into S$7.1m FY18 loss
summary: Epicentre Holdings reported a net loss of S$7.1 million in FY18, driven by losses from its Apple-related businesses. Continuing operations contributed a net loss of S$3.1 million, while discontinued operations posted a net loss of S$4.0 million. Revenue fell 30.5% to S$18.35 million, largely due to a decline in revenue from its Malaysian operations. The company's board described the operating environment as "challenging" and sees opportunities for growth through new business areas, including a planned acquisition of property development and hotel management businesses.

site_title: Kitchen Culture incurs S$3.8m loss for fiscal 2018
summary: Kitchen Culture reported a net loss of S$3.8 million for fiscal 2018, with revenue of S$14.5 million, down from S$49.6 million in the prior 18-month period. The company attributed the decline to fewer residential projects and retail sales. The business outlook remains challenging, with plans to broaden the group's business through new product launches and expansions.

site_title: The future of procurement
summary: A KPMG report suggests that nearly 80% of chief procurement officers believe digital technologies won't disrupt legacy systems, despite significant changes in customer experiences and expectations. This contradicts the goal of procurement functions to achieve cost-savings while procuring goods and services. The report highlights the potential for digital technologies to transform procurement processes, but current attitudes among procurement officers indicate a need for adjustment to stay responsive to changing customer needs.

site_title: Ryan Gosling took flying lessons for new astronaut film First Man
summary: Hollywood star Ryan Gosling took flying lessons to prepare for his role as astronaut Neil Armstrong in the new biopic First Man. Gosling revealed that he learned to fly to get inside Armstrong's mind and test his skills, but had to stop taking lessons after a controlled stall. Director Damien Chazelle praised the film's attention to detail, saying the crew created authentic space capsules that made the actors claustrophobic. The film pays tribute to Armstrong's courage and the astronauts' experiences, with the cast crediting Armstrong's sons and widow for their involvement in the project.

site_title: US Q2 growth revised upwards to 4.2%
summary: The US economy experienced faster-than-expected growth in the second quarter, with the GDP advancing at an annual rate of 4.2%, a tenth of a point faster than initial estimates. The growth is attributed to a boost in corporate spending, particularly in the software sector, and increased exports ahead of China's retaliatory tariffs. However, economists view the uptick as a blip, citing one-off factors unlikely to be sustainable, and expect growth to cool in the third quarter.

site_title: Asean service providers, exporters to gain from new agreements
summary: ASEAN service providers and exporters will gain greater market access and convenience under two agreements signed at the 50th Asean Economic Ministers Meeting. The agreements include a protocol to implement the 10th and final package of commitments for the Asean Framework Agreement on Services, and a protocol to amend the Asean Trade in Goods Agreement to implement the Asean-Wide Self-Certification regime. The agreements aim to create a more open and facilitative business environment in Asean, with potential annual savings of S$500,000 for Singapore-based exporters.

site_title: Newcastle suffer early League Cup exit, Everton roll on
summary: Newcastle suffered a 3-1 defeat to Nottingham Forest in the League Cup, eliminating them from the competition. The Magpies' poor start to the season continued with this loss, following a 0-0 draw with Chelsea. Meanwhile, Everton and Watford advanced to the next round with victories over Rotherham and Reading, respectively. Newcastle manager Rafa Benitez was criticized for his negative approach in the loss, but expressed confidence in his team's abilities.

images.alt_text: Newcastle's miserable start to the season suffered another blow with a dramatic late 3-1 defeat to Championship side Nottingham Forest on Wednesday to crash out of the League Cup at the second round.

site_title: Bloomberg moves new forum for elites from China to Singapore amid fallout of trade war
summary: Michael Bloomberg has relocated a planned conference for global business and political leaders from Beijing to Singapore, amid the fallout of the US-China trade war. The event, initially set to take place in Beijing, was moved to Singapore due to a request from a Chinese partner to postpone it. Instead, China plans to spotlight an import expo in Shanghai to bolster international interest in trade. The Singapore conference is set to take place over two days in early November.

site_title: MAS and Dubai authority sign fintech accord
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Dubai Financial Services Authority (DFSA) have signed a fintech accord to facilitate the sharing of information on innovation in the financial sector. The agreement allows for the referral of fintech companies to each other and enables joint projects on key technologies, including digital payments, blockchain, and big data. The partnership aims to promote the development of fintech, enhance financial services, and increase efficiency. This is the third fintech cooperation between MAS and DFSA, following a Memorandum of Understanding signed in 2008.

site_title: Nestle wants your DNA
summary: Nestle, the world's largest food company, is launching a personalized nutrition program in Japan that uses DNA testing and artificial intelligence to provide tailored diet recommendations and supplements. The program, called "Nestle Wellness Ambassador," costs $600 a year and includes a home kit for blood and DNA testing to identify susceptibility to common ailments. The company aims to shift its focus towards healthier options and capitalize on the trend of personalized nutrition, with the goal of the wellness segment accounting for half of its sales in Japan.

site_title: Micron Technology plans US$3b expansion of Virginia plant
summary: Micron Technology plans a $3 billion expansion of its Virginia plant over the next 12 years, aiming to meet increasing demand for chips in automobiles. The expansion will help the company capitalize on the growing market for automotive computer chips, which is expected to double to $6 billion by 2021. According to CEO Sanjay Mehrotra, the future of automobiles will resemble "data centers on wheels." The investment will support the production of advanced chip features such as collision avoidance systems and lane departure warning systems.

site_title: Merkel begins West African tour in Senegal
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel began a West African tour in Senegal, aiming to promote economic development and combat migration and jihadism. Merkel met with Senegalese President Macky Sall, signaling Germany's commitment to the region. She emphasized the need to tackle human trafficking and create legal opportunities for African youth, rather than relying on illegal migration. Merkel's visit is part of a broader effort to strengthen economic ties with resource-rich African nations and offer opportunities for young people, in an effort to dissuade them from migrating to Europe.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Health Management International (HMI) reported a 51.5% year-on-year increase in Q4 FY2018 core Patmi to RM15.9 million, driven by 7% full-year growth and 2.4 percentage points of Ebitda margin expansion. The company expects a gestation period of up to 2-3 years for its StarMed outpatient facility, with forecasted Ebitda losses of RM3-7 million in its first three years of operations. Despite slower inpatient growth, HMI continues to invest in future growth and diversify marketing efforts.

site_title: Dollar strengthens as relief over US-Mexico trade deal dissipates
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Wednesday as investors shifted their focus away from relief over the US-Mexico trade deal and towards concerns about the ongoing US-China trade conflict. The dollar index rose 0.1% to 94.826, while the euro fell 0.2% to $1.1663. The Swedish kronor edged down to a nine-year low versus the euro due to uncertainty about the upcoming election and interest rate hikes. The Australian dollar also fell, amid concerns about the Reserve Bank of Australia's monetary policy.

site_title: Iran-based influence blitz morphs into bigger, more persistent, global threat
summary: An Iranian influence operation, known as the International Union of Virtual Media (IUVM), has been identified as a significant threat to global public opinion, with a sprawling network of anonymous websites and social media accounts in 11 languages. The operation, which pushes content from Iranian state media and other outlets, was previously thought to be smaller, but a Reuters analysis has found 10 additional sites and dozens of social media accounts. The network was taken down by Facebook, Twitter, and Alphabet, but remains active, highlighting the difficulty for tech companies to guard against political interference on their platforms.

site_title: Oil jumps to highest in a month as US reports stockpile drop
summary: Oil prices surged to their highest in a month as the US reported a 2.57 million-barrel decline in crude inventories, exceeding analysts' expectations. West Texas Intermediate futures rose 1.4% to $69.51 a barrel. The drop in US stockpiles, combined with a decline in Iranian crude exports and a rise in demand, contributed to the increase. Analysts attribute the rise to a "war between fears about the economy and demand, and concerns on the supply side about Venezuela and Iran."

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Wilton Resources Corp reported a net loss of 24.7 billion rupiah ($2.3 million) for its fourth quarter, with revenue at 4.3 billion rupiah. Synagie Corp partnered with United Overseas Bank to provide SME clients with preferential access to its e-commerce solutions. Green Build Technology signed an asset purchase agreement with Yea Eun Columbarium in South Korea. New Silkroutes reported a net loss of US$2.7 million for its fourth quarter, with revenue increasing 68.8% to US$193.4 million.

site_title: Venus eyes Serena clash as US Open sweats in sexism storm
summary: Venus Williams advanced to a potential US Open third-round match with sister Serena, winning 6-4, 7-5 against Camila Giorgi. The match took place amidst extreme heat and a sexism storm, with the US Open facing criticism for its handling of a code violation incident involving French player Alize Cornet. The US Open Tennis Association (USTA) initially penalized Cornet for changing her shirt on court, but later admitted the mistake and clarified its policy. Meanwhile, defending champion Sloane Stephens and two-time Australian Open champion Victoria Azarenka also made the third round, with Azarenka condemning the USTA's initial decision as "ridiculous."

site_title: Renault plots revival with launch of sporty SUV in Russia
summary: Renault unveiled the Arkana coupe-crossover in Moscow, targeting a wealthier set of buyers in Russia and worldwide. The vehicle is part of the company's efforts to grow sales outside of slowing European markets, aiming to boost deliveries by 40% to 5 million vehicles annually by 2022. Following Russia's return to car demand growth, Renault sees the country as a key market, with a goal to surpass China and become its biggest market by 2022, offsetting its struggling European market performance.

site_title: Aston Martin gears up for possible IPO on London Stock Exchange
summary: Aston Martin Holdings (UK) Ltd, the maker of James Bond's favorite car, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) on the London Stock Exchange. The company, led by CEO Andy Palmer, has seen a turnaround with 8% increase in first-half revenue to £445 million. Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation rose 14%. The IPO, if successful, would give the company 25% of its stock on the London Stock Exchange, with existing investors selling shares to realize value. A decision is expected by September 20.

site_title: Robot teachers invade Chinese kindergartens
summary: Chinese kindergartens have begun using autonomous robots, named Keeko, as teaching assistants. The robots, about 60 cm high, use screens for faces and can interact with children through storytelling and logic problems. Developed by Xiamen Technology, over 600 kindergartens have adopted Keeko, with the goal of expanding into Greater China and Southeast Asia. While some praise the robots for their stability and ability to provide a "human touch," others believe they cannot fully replace human educators, citing the importance of interaction, eye contact, and facial expressions in the classroom.

site_title: UK, EU to drop Oct deadline for Brexit
summary: The UK and EU have agreed to drop their October deadline for a Brexit deal, with senior officials now aiming to finalize divorce terms by mid-November at the latest. Negotiations have been slow since March, with the two sides remaining far apart on the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. The extended timeframe increases the risk of a deal not being reached before the UK's exit on March 29. The EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, reiterated that a deal cannot be much later than the end of the year.

site_title: Half-year results ended June 2018
summary: BT released half-year results ending June 2018, with revenue potentially below target and an operating loss similar to the first half of the year.

site_title: Rolls Royce in talks to lease London space from The Guardian
summary: Rolls Royce Holdings is in talks to sublease its London headquarters from The Guardian's owner, Alphabet, at the Kings Place building in King's Cross. The planned move would be to a smaller office space, less than 500 meters from Buckingham Palace. This change comes as the engineering company seeks a new location.

site_title: RCEP trade deal could be delivered by year-end: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong suggested that the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade deal could be finalized by the end of the year. This comes as talks on the mega free trade deal are at a critical stage. In contrast, Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing criticized "recent policy U-turns elsewhere."

site_title: Passengers also have role to play for better aviation safety
summary: A recent Aeromexico Flight 2341 crash highlights the importance of aviation safety, with 103 passengers and crew members on board, though some sustained serious injuries. Most airplane accidents are survivable, thanks to aircraft designers, safety regulators, and flight crews. Passengers also play a crucial role in keeping safe, by following safety procedures, such as locating emergency exits, turning off mobile devices, and evacuating quickly. Aviation safety efforts, including the International Air Transport Association's IOSA standard, have significantly reduced accidents, with an average person needing to travel for 6,033 years to experience a fatal accident.

site_title: At 106, Roberta McCain has outlived her son
summary: Roberta McCain, the mother of late Senator John McCain, has outlived him at 106 years old. She was a key figure in her son's upbringing, often traveling the world with him and instilling in him a love of adventure and learning. Roberta's own life was marked by travel and spontaneity, and she took the reins of her own life after her husband's death. She was known for her optimism and resilience, and her influence on her son's life was a significant factor in his later success.

site_title: Economics and politics at play in the wooing of Africa
summary: African leaders are meeting with top world leaders, including Donald Trump, Xi Jinping, Theresa May, and Angela Merkel, underlining the continent's growing economic importance. Africa is home to six of the world's top 12 fastest-growing countries and is expected to have among the best growth prospects globally over the next five years. China is increasing its interest in Africa, hosting a China-Africa Summit next week with at least 50 heads of state attending, while the US is also developing an ambitious Africa strategy, with President Trump meeting with Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta to boost bilateral trade.

site_title: SPH Magazines expands its complimentary digital library to Shangri-La Hotel
summary: SPH Magazines is expanding its complimentary digital library, The Wifi Library, to the Shangri-La Hotel in Singapore. The service, which offers 7,000 titles, will be available to hotel guests for free through the hotel's Wi-Fi. This marks the first time The Wifi Library will be offered at a luxury hotel. The service, which was previously available at OCBC bank branches, malls, and HomeTeamNS clubhouses, is a digital reading solution that allows users to access magazines through the MyNewsstand app.

images.alt_text: Visitors to the Shangri-La Hotel will now be able to tap the hotel's Wi-Fi service to enjoy free access to 7,000 titles from SPH's The Wifi Library.

site_title: India calls for halt to sales, import of e-cigarettes, smoking devices
summary: India's federal health ministry has called for a halt to the sale, import, and advertisement of electronic cigarettes and heat-not-burn tobacco devices, citing them as a "great health risk" to the public, particularly children and non-smokers. The move comes amid concerns about the devices' potential to lead to nicotine addiction and increase tobacco use. The ministry's advisory to state governments follows a public interest litigation filed last year, which led to the court's request for regulatory measures. The health ministry's stance is seen as a strong message against the devices, which are also being promoted by tobacco giant Philip Morris.

site_title: Indonesia, Australia hope to announce economic partnership on Aug 31
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo and Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison are set to announce on August 31 the completion of negotiations on an economic partnership pact, known as the Indonesia Australia Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (Cepa), aimed at boosting trade between the two countries. The pact, which covers goods, services, investment, and intellectual property, will allow for up to 67% foreign ownership in Indonesian universities and could revise rules on farm goods. The deal has been in talks since 2012 and is expected to be finalized later in 2018 after a legal review.

site_title: Why the US equity bull market could keep running into 2019
summary: The US equity bull market may continue into 2019, driven by a strong consumer and corporate earnings backdrop. Despite global growth moderating, US GDP growth accelerated to 4.1% in the second quarter, with consumer confidence and corporate earnings performing well. Tax cuts and increased federal spending may have contributed to this growth, but the US economy's foundation remains solid. The market's valuation is fair, with the S&P 500 trading at 16.5x next year's earnings, and investors should focus on sustainability and quality for long-term investments.

site_title: Revamped Tiffany flagship store at New York's Fifth Avenue to have more sales, VIP space
summary: Tiffany & Co. is revamping its flagship store on New York's Fifth Avenue, expanding sales floor space and VIP areas to improve customer experience. The 10-floor building, which accounts for 10% of the company's global sales, will see administrative offices reduced to make way for a more efficient sales process. The renovation, expected to cost up to $250 million, will prioritize faster checkout lines and easier access to high-end jewelry. The project is seen as key to the company's future, with CEO Alessandro Bogliolo citing the need to address long wait times and inadequate space.

site_title: Benchmarking, behavioural insights tapped to improve Singapore workplace safety
summary: Singapore's Manpower Ministry is piloting a new approach to workplace safety by informing firms with poorer records of their safety performance, rather than relying on surprise inspections. The pilot, based on design thinking and behavioural insights, aims to encourage companies to reassess their safety practices. The ministry plans to expand the pilot and implement recommendations to improve workplace safety, including making safety performance more transparent, training safety experts to manage risks, and leveraging technological advancements such as data analytics and virtual reality.

site_title: Record 3.9t yen selloff so far this year weighing on Japan's bourse
summary: Foreigners have dumped a net 3.9 trillion yen ($47.8 billion) in Japanese equities so far this year, on track for the largest annual selloff since 1987. The yen's strength, coupled with concerns over trade wars and Japan's sales-tax increase, has led to a 5% decline in the benchmark Topix index. Analysts attribute the selloff to a combination of factors, including the Bank of Japan's reduced ETF purchases and global economic uncertainty. Despite this, some experts predict a return to the market before the end of the year, citing Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's likely election victory.

site_title: Koufu's Q2 net profit slips 2.6%
summary: Koufu Group's Q2 net profit dropped 2.6% to S$6.16 million, mainly due to a decrease in finance income. Revenue increased 1.2% to S$54.15 million, while earnings per share slipped to 1.27 cents. The company expects to remain profitable in FY2018, barring unforeseen circumstances, and will continue to look for new premises to increase its number of food and beverage outlets.

site_title: Vividthree lodges offer document for proposed spinoff, Catalist listing
summary: Vividthree Holdings (VVH) has lodged a preliminary offer document for a proposed spinoff and listing on the Catalist Board. The company, 51% owned by mm2 Asia, plans to use proceeds from the issuance of new shares to produce virtual reality content and expand through acquisitions. VVH made a net profit of S$2.71 million and S$7.06 million in its last financial year. The spinoff follows a restructuring agreement with mm2 Asia and four individual shareholders, who will transfer their stake in Vividthree Productions to VVH in exchange for S$50,000.

site_title: Toyota to invest US$500m in Uber for self-drive vehicles
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is investing $500 million in Uber Technologies Inc to jointly develop self-driving cars. The deal values Uber at $76 billion and aims to mass-produce self-driving cars for ride-hailing services. Toyota's Guardian technology will be combined with Uber's autonomous driving system, and the combined technology will be built into Toyota's Sienna minivans. The partnership is seen as a bid by both companies to catch up with rivals in the autonomous-driving business.

site_title: 800 Super falls a further 19% on weak results
summary: 800 Super Holdings, a Singapore-listed environmental services provider, plummeted 18.8% in Wednesday trading to 67 Singapore cents, its lowest in over a year. The company reported a net loss of S$1.65 million for its fiscal fourth quarter earnings, citing higher expenses. Revenue slipped 1.8% to S$37.9 million due to completed term contracts and renewed contracts at lower prices. The stock has dived 33% over the past two days, putting it among the top five losers in percentage terms due to the highly competitive waste management industry.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO warns of growing pressure to consolidate
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing warned that European banks must bulk up or risk dying due to increased regulatory pressure and declining revenue. The need for investment in IT and rising capital demands have eroded profits, prompting speculation about potential consolidation with rival Commerzbank. Sewing reaffirmed his bank's global ambition, despite cutting investment banking operations in the US, and stated that the pressure to consolidate will significantly rise in Europe.

site_title: ASL Marine narrows Q4 loss on higher gross profit
summary: ASL Marine reported a 15.7% decrease in its fourth-quarter net loss to S$52.62 million, driven by higher gross profit and other operating income. The Singapore-based shipbuilder and vessel owner-operator saw its net loss for the three months ended June 30 fall to S$52.62 million, from S$62.36 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Home prices in 20 US cities post smallest gain since 2016
summary: US home prices in 20 major cities rose in June at the slowest monthly pace in almost two years, according to S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller data. The growth, 0.3%, was driven by Las Vegas with a 13% annual increase. Despite a strong job market, mortgage rates near a seven-year high, and tight supply, home sales remain flat over the last six months. The data reinforces signs of a softening residential real estate market, with purchases of previously owned homes falling to a two-year low in July.

site_title: Aretha Franklin's fans say goodbye
summary: Aretha Franklin's fans gathered to pay their respects after her passing on August 16, 2018, at the age of 76. Thousands lined up outside the Charles H Wright Museum of African American History in Detroit for two 12-hour viewing periods, with some fans camping out overnight. The adoring public came to say goodbye to the Queen of Soul, who was laid to rest in a star-studded funeral at Detroit's Greater Grace Temple. Fans shared stories of how Franklin's music inspired them, including one who credited her with saving her life. Plans are underway to turn Franklin's house into a museum or raise a statue in her honor.

images.alt_text: The adoring public came from far and wide to glimpse Franklin and at one point in the morning, the line of visitors waiting to enter the first of two 12-hour viewing periods on Tuesday and Wednesday stretched for five blocks.

site_title: Google ties up with 4 Indian banks in bid to woo new users
summary: Google has partnered with four Indian banks - Federal Bank, HDFC Bank, ICICI Bank, and Kotak Mahindra Bank - to provide quick loans to users through its app. The move aims to woo tens of millions of new Internet users in India to its digital payments services, making banking services more accessible to them. Caesar Sengupta, Google's vice-president, emphasized that this partnership will help bridge the banking gap for millions of Indians.

images.alt_text: Caesar Sengupta, vice-president of Google's Next Billion Users initiative, said the move would make banking services accessible to tens of millions of Indians. He also said Google is open to collaborating with other Indian payments firms.

site_title: APAC Realty to enter Hainan property market with 40% stake in JV
summary: APAC Realty, a Singapore-based real estate brokerage, has entered a 40% stake in a joint venture with two Chinese firms, Hainan Zhong Zhi Sheng He Real Estate Investment and Bei Guo Tou (Shanghai) Equity Investment and Fund Management, to penetrate the Hainan property market. The JV, ERA Hainan Real Estate Marketing Co, will conduct brokerage services and establish training for property agents. Despite China's property cooling measures, APAC Realty believes the venture will ensure a sustainable transaction volume and price appreciation, with a planned free trade zone in Hainan by 2020.

site_title: The Fed should prepare for the unexpected
summary: US Federal Reserve officials are grappling with managing uncertainty in the economy, with multiple risks requiring different policy responses. The Fed's baseline models indicate a range of uncertainty, particularly regarding worker scarcity's impact on inflation. Analysts suggest a cautious approach to raising interest rates, as their effectiveness is uncertain. However, the most pressing concern is the risk of a recession in the next couple of years, which the Fed lacks tools to address, and keeping interest rates lower to prepare for such an event.

site_title: Tencent-backed EV maker guns for valuation above US$8b in IPO
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric-vehicle maker backed by Tencent, plans to raise up to $1.3 billion in its US initial public offering (IPO), aiming for a valuation of $8 billion. The company plans to use the funds for product development, sales and marketing, and manufacturing facility construction. Nio's IPO comes amid China's push to increase battery-powered car use and the company's goal to take on Tesla. The IPO, expected to price on September 11, will give Tencent a 21.5% voting power, with founder William Li retaining 48.3% voting power.

site_title: SIAS sets up steering committee for Hyflux noteholders
summary: SIAS establishes informal steering committees for Hyflux noteholders of Series 008, 009, and 010 notes, as well as S$400 million of 6% preference shares and S$500 million of 6% perpetual securities, to facilitate engagement during the company's reorganisation. Hyflux will not make any coupon or interest payments, distribution payments, or dividend payments until the reorganisation is complete. The company's shares have been suspended since May 18, and it will make its unaudited management accounts available on its website.

site_title: Clear skies for careers in the cloud
summary: Cloud computing companies in Singapore are expanding their workforce in response to the growing demand for cost-effective cloud services. The Asia Cloud Computing Association has named Singapore the most cloud-ready economy in the Asia-Pacific, driven by the digital transformation of businesses and the adoption of emerging technologies such as IoT, 5G, and AI. Companies like VMware, Alibaba Cloud, and Pure Storage are hiring employees to support their growth in the region, citing Singapore's strategic location and talent pool as key factors.

site_title: Raising the bar for brand Singapore
summary: Singaporean food and drink talents are gaining international recognition, with notable achievements including the first-ever Singaporean top sake sommelier and a hobby chef winning MasterChef Australia. A group of entrepreneurs, including a former accountant and architect, are contributing to Singapore's rise in the international food industry. The article also highlights Douglas DeBoer, CEO of Crystal Jade Culinary Concepts, who shares his expertise on Chinese food despite being an American.

site_title: Emerging-economy crisis cycle may have ended, but...
summary: Emerging economies have experienced boom-bust cycles in external financing for decades, but whether this pattern has finally been broken is uncertain. A recent crisis in Turkey, which saw the Turkish lira plummet and trigger currency depreciations across Latin America, may signal a new crisis. However, the limited contagion from the crisis suggests that emerging economies' resilience to sudden stops has increased, with investors now taking a more nuanced approach to country risk analysis. Despite this, rising protectionist sentiment and trade tensions remain significant concerns, highlighting the need for smart policies and an improved global financial safety net.

site_title: Dr M & Forest City: mixed views on investor impact
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's comments stating that foreigners will not be allowed to buy property in the China-led Forest City mega project have sparked mixed views on its impact on investors. Some economists fear it will dent confidence, while others argue that the comment is arbitrary and won't affect the country's longer-term outlook. Despite the uncertainty, many economists believe investors will take a wait-and-see approach, and the business relationship between Singapore and Malaysia remains strong, with no feedback from members of the Singapore Business Federation indicating a negative impact.

site_title: Noble survives but will it be able to thrive again?
summary: Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based commodities trader, has survived a US$3.5 billion debt rescue plan after a special general meeting of shareholders voted in favor of the plan. The plan, which includes a debt-for-equity swap, will leave equity investors with 20% of a new, revamped company owned by senior creditors. Noble's troubles began in 2015 with allegations of dodgy accounting and a commodity slump, leading to significant losses and a decline in its stock price. The company's future remains uncertain, with many questioning whether the new Noble can generate enough cash to recover.

site_title: Thai central bank in no rush to raise rates
summary: Thailand's central bank governor, Veerathai Santiprabhob, says the country has a strong external position and a relatively strong currency, making it less likely to raise interest rates. The Bank of Thailand is monitoring economic developments, particularly trade protectionism risks, but remains cautious due to its solid buffers. The central bank's benchmark rate has remained at 1.5% since 2015, differing from other emerging markets that have tightened policy. Thailand's foreign-exchange reserves and current-account surplus have shielded it from the worst of the emerging-market rout.

site_title: Korea Post looks to the West to buy riskier debt
summary: South Korea's state postal service, Korea Post, plans to invest $112 billion in riskier debt, infrastructure, and real estate in North America and Europe, aiming for better returns. The fund will focus on mezzanine and distressed debt, as well as infrastructure and real-estate assets abroad, and reduce investments in stocks. Korea Post's allocation to alternative assets is small but reflects a shift by conservative institutional investors in Asia to seek higher returns due to low interest rates and lacklustre equity returns. The move poses risks of lower liquidity and less publicly available information.

site_title: Fast-food chain Yum China rejects US$17.6b buyout offer
summary: Yum China Holdings Inc has rejected a US$17.6 billion buyout offer from a consortium led by Hillhouse Capital Group, citing that the proposed price of US$46 per share was below market value. The offer, which would have been one of Asia's biggest deals this year, was made nearly 24% above Tuesday's closing price. The decision quashes the potential acquisition of the largest fast-food chain in China.

site_title: In an AI-centric future, skill sets must change
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is poised to revolutionize various aspects of life, transforming the way we work and live. With its potential to deliver unprecedented economic and social benefits, non-adoption can have a critical impact on businesses and countries. AI will augment human capabilities and productivity, replacing low-level routine work and boosting productivity tools for advanced jobs. It will also impact social infrastructures such as healthcare, enabling early intervention and personalized diagnosis. As AI becomes more prevalent, job skills will need to evolve, and education systems will need to adapt to prepare future generations.

site_title: Medical tourism and ageing Thais help sustain US$13 billion hospital empire
summary: Bangkok Dusit Medical Services Pcl, a Thai hospital operator, has seen its shares surge 29% in 2018, reaching a market value of US$13 billion, making it the most-valuable business in an emerging market. The company's revenue from foreign patients, primarily from Asia, has grown 10% in the first half of 2018, driven by Thailand's ageing population and high-quality treatment at reasonable prices. The company's shares are expected to continue growing, despite being valued at 39 times estimated earnings, with investors anticipating further room for rise.

site_title: China to ensure sufficient gas supplies for this winter's fight against smog
summary: China aims to ensure sufficient natural gas supplies for this winter to avoid repeating last year's shortages, which left some residents without heating in northern China. The government has implemented measures to control coal use and industrial output, and cities must sign winter supply contracts and improve storage facilities. China's reliance on imported natural gas is expected to rise to 44% this year, putting pressure on supplies. Officials vow to learn from past mistakes and prioritize energy supplies over alternative heating methods.

site_title: Japan's Abe pushes for fast change to Constitution in election pamphlet
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is pushing to rapidly amend the country's post-World War II Constitution, aiming to have the Liberal Democratic Party submit the proposed amendment in the next Parliament session. The amendment, which includes a clear reference to Japan's Self-Defence Forces, would require a two-thirds majority in both houses and approval by voters in a national referendum. Abe's bid for a third consecutive term as party leader is expected to be successful, potentially allowing him to stay in power until late 2021.

site_title: FB employee group criticises 'intolerant' liberal monoculture
summary: A group of over 100 Facebook employees, led by senior engineer Brian Amerige, formed an internal group called FB'ers for Political Diversity to promote ideological diversity within the company. The group's post, titled "We Have a Problem With Political Diversity," criticized the company's liberal monoculture and intolerance of differing views. The group's aim is to create a space for diverse perspectives, but it has upset some employees who claim its posts are offensive to minorities. The move is a rare sign of organized dissent within Facebook, which has historically been loyal to its liberal workplace culture.

site_title: Building boom lures visitors to Morocco's 'Red City'
summary: Marrakech, Morocco, is experiencing a surge in luxury tourism, with over 11 million visitors in 2017, a 10% increase from the previous year. The city is reinventing itself to attract high-end tourists, with new hotels, resorts, and amenities such as M Avenue, a $100 million multi-use project featuring gardens, shops, and galleries. The government has eased visa regulations and modernized infrastructure to improve safety and accessibility. As a result, luxury hotels and real estate projects are sprouting up, including a W hotel, a Ritz-Carlton hotel, and a Park Hyatt hotel, with the goal of increasing the length of stay for tourists and boosting the local economy.

images.alt_text: The Four Seasons in Marrakech, Morocco. As more wealthy tourists flock to the country, Marrakesh is reinventing itself with luxury hotels and resorts and fashioning itself as a contemporary art destination to attract its share of visitors.

site_title: SIA rebranding needs to include cultivation of customer loyalty
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is rebranding and seeking a new strategy, content, website, and apps to modernize its iconic brand. The move comes after a business transformation program and strategic review, which includes consolidating its four brands into two: SIA and Scoot. SIA's customer loyalty is a key focus, as the airline faces increased competition and criticism about service quality and reliability. The airline's loyalty programs have been a point of contention, and SIA must rebuild customer loyalty to remain competitive, particularly among its premium travelers who account for 40% of the airline's income.

site_title: Asian stocks muted as tariff deadline looms
summary: Asian stocks were muted on Wednesday, despite a two-day rally, as a key deadline for US tariffs on Chinese goods loomed. The Dow and S&P 500 index remained near neutral, and Tokyo's Nikkei ended higher, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng fell 0.13% due to a cloudy outlook for China's trade and economic growth. Malaysian stocks retreated from a three-month high, and Singapore's Straits Times Index ended 0.1% lower. The US-China trade dispute continued to weigh on regional markets, with some analysts warning of potential losses if the US imposes tariffs on an additional $200 billion of Chinese goods.

site_title: Lian Beng bags S$65m construction contract
summary: Lian Beng Group secured a S$65 million construction contract for a building starting September 10 through its unit Deenn Engineering. This brings the group's order book to S$1.29 billion. The 24-month contract is expected to positively impact the group's net tangible asset per share and earning per share for the 2019 financial year.

site_title: California moves towards requiring 100% clean power by 2045
summary: California lawmakers approved a measure requiring 100% clean power by 2045, marking the state's biggest step against global warming. The state assembly voted in favor, with the state currently getting 44% of its power from renewables and hydropower. The bill must clear the state Senate before being signed into law by Governor Jerry Brown. This move would accelerate a shift away from fossil fuels, building on California's existing efforts to cut emissions and lead the fight against climate change.

site_title: UBS to sell digital SmartWealth platform to fintech startup
summary: UBS is selling its digital SmartWealth platform to fintech startup SigFig, citing limited short-term potential following a review. The platform, launched in Britain in 2017, will be discontinued. UBS executives confirmed the decision in an internal memo. The sale marks the end of UBS's digital wealth management efforts in Britain.

site_title: Australia's Westpac hikes mortgage rates
summary: Westpac, Australia's second-largest bank, has raised its variable standard home-loan rate for owner occupiers by 14 basis points to 5.38%, the first of the country's major banks to increase rates amid higher wholesale funding costs. The move aims to balance the interests of all stakeholders, despite potential squeezes on borrowers already struggling with stagnant wages growth and high household debt. The bank's shares rose 2.74% following the announcement, while other major banks also saw gains.

site_title: CIMB posts higher quarterly profit, on track to meet 2018 targets
summary: Malaysia's second-largest lender, CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, posted its highest quarterly profit on record, driven by one-off gains from stake sales in joint ventures. The bank's shares rose 1.8% to a two-month high, despite a weaker broader market. CEO Zafrul Aziz expressed optimism about the bank's performance in the second half, citing a positive consumer sector and pipeline of deals. CIMB is on track to meet its 6% loan growth target for 2018.

site_title: Wall Street expats angle for piece of China's biotech drug boom
summary: Former Wall Street bankers and pharmaceutical industry veterans are capitalizing on China's growing biotech market, which has become more accessible due to government reforms and a surge in funding for young biotech companies. New firms are acquiring Chinese sales rights to drugs previously de-emphasized or abandoned by big pharmaceutical companies. Startups like Everest Medicines are helping smaller drugmakers expand their reach in China, with one executive, Ian Woo, leaving his Wall Street job to become the company's finance chief and president. The Chinese healthcare market is expected to grow, with a potential value of $30-50 billion, attracting investors and companies from the US and elsewhere.

site_title: Pernod Ricard in high spirits as India, China sales drive growth
summary: Pernod Ricard, the world's second-largest spirits group, reported a 17% dividend hike as sales and profit growth accelerated in the 2017/18 year, driven by strong demand in China and India. The company forecast underlying profit growth of 5-7% for the 2018/19 year, with a "very strong" first quarter and a boost in the July-September period due to an earlier Mid-Autumn Festival in China. Sales growth accelerated to 6% in the 2017/18 year, spurred by a 17% jump in China and 14% in India.

site_title: Europe: Shares bounce as trade deal hopes lift risk appetite
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday as optimism over US-Canada trade talks lifted risk appetite, despite some market watchers expressing caution due to ongoing trade tensions with China. Britain's FTSE 100 fell 0.7% due to a rise in sterling, while individual stocks such as Germany's RTL and France's Ingenico were under pressure. The Stoxx 600 index ended the session up, with shares in micro Focus and Sinclair Pharma also gaining.

site_title: MAS and Dubai authority sign fintech accord
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Dubai Financial Services Authority (DFSA) have signed an agreement to facilitate fintech cooperation and innovation in the financial sector. The accord allows for the sharing of information on fintech developments and enables both authorities to refer fintech companies to each other. The partnership aims to support the growth of fintech, improve financial services, and manage risks more effectively. MAS and DFSA will work on joint projects, including digital payments, blockchain, and Big Data, to enhance the fintech landscape in the Middle East and beyond.

site_title: Cliff Richard to release first album of new material in 14 years
summary: Veteran British singer Cliff Richard is set to release his first album of new material in 14 years, titled "Rise Up", in November. The 77-year-old announced the release on the 60th anniversary of his debut single "Move It", referencing the "bad period" he endured after a 2014 police raid on his home, which led to a high court ruling in his favor with damages of US$272,475. The album features a duet with Olivia Newton-John and marks Richard's return to music after a 14-year hiatus.

images.alt_text: Veteran British singer Cliff Richard, who won substantial damages in a privacy case ruling against the BBC last month, said on Wednesday he would release his first album of new material in 14 years, called "Rise Up".

site_title: Blockchain enables supply-chain transparency and business growth
summary: Recent research by the Economist Intelligence Unit found that only 30% of multinational firms address supply chain issues such as ethical breaches or corruption. A lack of trust in manufacturers can lead to lost customer loyalty, with retailers with high trust generating 78% more sales. Supply chains bear a significant responsibility for a brand's reputation, as seen in recent recalls and costly challenges for aviation companies. Blockchain technology can improve supply chain transparency and business growth, but more needs to be done to address these critical issues.

site_title: US-Canada Nafta talks resume with focus on dairy
summary: US-Canada Nafta talks resumed in Washington with a focus on dairy, as the US pressures Canada to strike a deal by Friday to replace the trade accord. The US and Mexico announced a deal requiring 75% of car content to originate in the US and Mexico, which Canada must now match. The talks aim to reduce Canadian dairy tariffs and dismantle a system to avoid oversupply, with the US prepared to move forward with Mexico alone if Canada does not reach an agreement.

images.alt_text: Canada's foreign minister Chrystia Freeland said August 29, 2018 she was "optimistic" about having productive trade talks with the United States."Mexico has made some significant concessions, which will be really good for Canadian workers."

site_title: Argentina asks IMF for early release of standby funds
summary: Argentina is seeking early release of $50 billion IMF standby funds to calm turbulent markets and alleviate concerns over meeting dollar debt obligations in 2019. The country's currency has weakened 40.79% in 2018, with investors worried about high inflation, a weak economy, and a global selloff in emerging markets. President Mauricio Macri announced the move to advance funds, aiming to eliminate uncertainty and stabilize the currency. The government expects the economy to contract 1% in 2018 but grow by at least 1.5% next year.

site_title: Bees swarm Times Square hot dog stand
summary: Thousands of bees swarmed a Times Square hot dog stand on Tuesday, sending tourists and passers-by scrambling. The bees, estimated to be 15,000-20,000 in number, settled on the vendor's umbrella, weighing it down. The New York Police Department's beekeeping team responded quickly, using a vacuum cleaner to safely relocate the bees. The incident drew a large crowd and sparked some humorous reactions, but the vendor remained unharmed. The NYPD's beekeeping team is equipped to handle such incidents, which are not uncommon in the city.

images.alt_text: The mass of insects was so dense it weighed down sections of the stand's umbrella.

site_title: Sale of RHT's assets to Fortis 'on normal commercial terms': IFA
summary: RHT Health Trust has agreed to sell its assets to Fortis on "normal commercial terms" without prejudicing its minority unitholders, according to its independent financial adviser (IFA). The proposed sale, valued at S$913.5 million, represents a 58.1% return and an internal rate of return of 10.2% per annum. The IFA deemed the terms favorable, considering the premium of 6.5% of net asset value (NAV) and the estimated consideration per unit representing a discount of 11.3-22.6% to the per unit adjusted equity value.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly higher as tech stocks gain
summary: US stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, driven by gains in technology stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 18.51 points, or 0.07%, to 26,082.53. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the Nasdaq gaining 14.30 points, or 0.18%, to 8,044.34. Investors await progress on US-Canada trade talks and next week's deadline for China-US tariffs.

site_title: Cheap fares, costly fuel send India's airlines into tailspin
summary: India's airlines face financial struggles due to low fares, high fuel costs, and a depreciating rupee. Despite expected growth in the aviation sector, becoming the world's third-largest by 2025, airlines are struggling to maintain profits. To survive, they are forced to cut costs. The sector's growth is attributed to a growing middle class seeking better connectivity and affordable flights.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 6.26 points lower on Wednesday at 1,820.64, with 629 losers outnumbering 355 gainers. The market saw 2.62 billion lots worth RM2.6 billion.
