site_title: US: Wall Street extends rally, tech leads S&P, Nasdaq to record highs
summary: US stocks extended their rally on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching record highs for the fourth straight session. Technology companies led the advance, with Apple and Amazon reaching new highs, while promising trade negotiations boosted investor sentiment. The US economy grew at a 4.2% annual rate in the second quarter, according to the Commerce Department. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.23%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.57% and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.99%.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi won't be stripped of Nobel Peace Prize -committee
summary: The Norwegian Nobel Committee has ruled that Aung San Suu Kyi's Nobel Peace Prize will not be withdrawn due to a UN report detailing Myanmar's military's mass killings of Rohingya Muslims. Suu Kyi, who won the prize in 1991 for her fight for democracy, has been criticized for failing to speak out against the army crackdown in Rakhine State. Committee Secretary Olav Njoelstad stated that Nobel Prize rules do not allow for a prize to be withdrawn, citing her achievements up until 1991.

site_title: Myanmar dam overflow displaces thousands
summary: A dam in central Myanmar's Bago region overflowed due to heavy monsoon rain, displacing over 12,600 people and leaving thousands trapped in their homes. The Swar Chaung dam spillway collapsed, causing widespread flooding and damage to a bridge on the Yangon-Mandalay highway. No casualties have been reported, but authorities are working to evacuate residents. The incident comes after a UN report criticized Myanmar's handling of the Rohingya crisis, and the country's army chief, Min Aung Hlaing, has been under international pressure.

site_title: SIAS sets up informal steering committees for Hyflux noteholders
summary: The Securities Investors Association (SIAS) has established informal steering committees for Hyflux's noteholders, including Series 008, 009, and 010 notes, as well as S$400 million of 6% preference shares and S$500 million of 6% perpetual securities. The committees aim to facilitate Hyflux's engagement with noteholders during the reorganisation process. The company has suspended trading and will not make any coupon or interest payments, distribution payments, or dividend payments until the reorganisation is completed. Hyflux will also make its unaudited management accounts available on its website.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with more gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Wednesday, marking a third straight gain, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.23% to 28,416.44. This follows another record on Wall Street, despite caution from investors awaiting developments in the China-US trade row.

site_title: Trump says White House counsel McGahn soon leaving
summary: US President Donald Trump announced on Twitter that White House counsel Don McGahn will leave his position in the fall, shortly after Judge Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation to the US Supreme Court. McGahn had "cooperated extensively" with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team, including multiple interviews totaling 30 hours. Trump had authorized his team to cooperate with investigators, fueling speculation about what McGahn might have said about potential obstruction of justice. The departure comes as Mueller's team closes in on the president's inner circle.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump said Wednesday that White House counsel Don McGahn would soon be leaving his post, as Special Counsel Robert Mueller - who is leading the Russia election interference probe - closes in on the US president's inner circle.

site_title: UK to consider proposals to curb Big Four auditors - industry official
summary: Britain's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is expected to consider proposals to curb the market share of the "Big Four" auditors, EY, KPMG, Deloitte, and PwC, in a bid to increase auditor choice for companies. The proposals, presented by industry officials, include temporary curbs on Big Four audits among Britain's top 350 companies. The CMA's decision comes amid criticism of the Big Four's dominance and concerns over lack of choice for companies.

site_title: Barnier offers Britain close ties but no "single market a la carte"
summary: European Union chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said the bloc is prepared to offer Britain an unprecedentedly close relationship after it quits the EU, but will not permit anything that weakens the single market. Barnier stated that Britain's "red lines" will be respected, but in return, they must respect the EU's single market. He emphasized that the single market is a unified entity and cannot be "single market a la carte." This offer includes economic, foreign, and security policy ties.

site_title: Koufu's Q2 net profit falls 2.6% to S$6.16 million
summary: Koufu Group's Q2 net profit fell 2.6% to S$6.16 million, driven by a 83% decrease in finance income. Revenue increased 1.2% to S$54.15 million, mainly due to new food courts and coffee shops. Earnings per share slipped to 1.27 Singapore cents. For the half year, net profit decreased 1.4% to S$12.4 million, while revenue rose 2.1% to S$109.2 million. Koufu plans to expand F&B outlets and remain profitable in FY2018.

site_title: Japanese LPG firm Gyxis to open office in Singapore
summary: Japanese liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) importer Gyxis Corp plans to open an office in Singapore in September or October, according to sources. The move is part of the company's strategy to import LPG to Japan, likely through long-term purchase agreements with US and Middle Eastern exporters. Gyxis, one of Japan's four major LPG firms, imports about 2.8 million tonnes of LPG annually to its seven primary import terminals in Japan. The Singapore office will be Gyxis' first overseas presence, expanding the company's operations in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Deutsche bank CEO says global ambition isn't under debate
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing reaffirmed the bank's global ambitions despite recent restructuring efforts. He stated that the bank's corporate and investment bank will continue to operate, despite cuts to unprofitable areas. The bank has reduced staff by 1,700 and 80 billion euros of leverage exposure. Sewing emphasized that his leadership will not lead to a reevaluation of the bank's global ambitions, indicating a commitment to maintaining its international presence.

site_title: Asean services providers, exporters to gain from two accords signed at Asean Economic Ministers Meeting
summary: ASEAN services providers and exporters will benefit from two agreements signed at the 50th Asean Economic Ministers Meeting. The Asean Framework Agreement on Services (AFAS) protocol increases market access and opens up new services sectors, while the Asean Trade in Goods Agreement (ATIGA) protocol introduces the Asean-wide Self-Certification (AWSC) regime, allowing exporters to self-certify the origin of their goods and enjoy preferential treatment. These agreements are expected to contribute to a more open and facilitative business environment in Asean, with potential annual savings of up to $500,000 for Singapore-based exporters.

site_title: US Q2 GDP growth revised up to 4.2%
summary: US economic growth in Q2 was revised up to 4.2%, its best performance in nearly four years, driven by stronger business spending and lower imports. This is slightly higher than the initial 4.1% pace reported in July. The growth is partly due to a US$1.5 trillion tax cut package and a front-loading of soybean exports to China. However, the economy's robust growth is unlikely to be sustained due to one-off drivers and ongoing trade tensions with China and other countries.

site_title: ASL narrows Q4 loss to S$52.62m
summary: ASL Marine reported a narrowed fourth quarter loss of S$52.62 million, down 15.7% from the same period last year. The loss per share was 8.36 Singapore cents, lower than 9.92 Singapore cents in the previous year. This improvement was attributed to higher gross profit and other operating income.

site_title: Tokyo: Main stocks higher for 7th straight day
summary: Tokyo's main stocks rose for the 7th consecutive day, driven by renewed optimism over North American trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.15% to 22,848.22, while the Topix index rose 0.46% to 1,739.60. Market sentiment remains positive despite tariff uncertainty, with investors focusing on trade talks and US-EU relations.

site_title: Standard Chartered may face another fine for Iran sanctions breaches
summary: US authorities are considering a larger fine for Standard Chartered over its alleged breaches of Iran sanctions. The bank, which has already paid $667 million, is suspected of secretly moving billions of dollars through the US on behalf of Iranian clients. An investigation by a coalition of agencies, including the Justice Department and New York's Department of Financial Services, may announce a resolution by the end of the year, potentially imposing a larger fine than the previous penalty.

site_title: Raffles Education back in the black with S$10.7 million net profit for FY2018
summary: Raffles Education Corporation reported a net profit of S$10.7 million for FY2018, reversing a net loss of S$1.8 million in the previous year. The company benefited from a S$64.9 million gain from its investment properties, primarily due to the sale of OUCL and Oriental University of City Holdings (HK) in FY2017. Revenue edged up 0.6% to S$96.8 million, while earnings per share improved to 0.9 Singapore cent from a loss of 0.17 Singapore cent in the previous year. The company attributed its improved financials to cost management and restructuring efforts.

site_title: Bank of Thailand governor says rates hike not 'imminent'
summary: Thailand's central bank governor, Veerathai Santiprabhob, stated that interest rate hikes are not imminent due to the country's strong economic buffers and currency. The Bank of Thailand has kept its benchmark rate at 1.5% since 2015, and Governor Santiprabhob believes the need for a rate hike is not as pressing as for other emerging markets. The baht has appreciated 1.8% against the dollar in the past month, making it a safe haven for investors.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.1% down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.1% to 3,243.92 on Wednesday, with 189 losers outweighing 177 gainers. The market saw 1.28 billion shares worth S$817.1 million change hands. Nico Steel traded flat, while Rex International and DeClout Limited rose 16.39% and 7.32% respectively. DBS Bank declined 0.28%, while UOB increased 0.33%.

site_title: German consumers cautiously optimistic for September: poll
summary: German consumers remain cautiously optimistic about the economy, with a 0.1-point fall in consumer confidence barometer to 10.5 points in September, according to a poll by GfK. Strong economic growth and solid wage increases have lifted consumers' economic expectations, but higher energy prices and inflation are expected to dampen growth further. Unemployment remains low, allowing consumers to remain open to large purchases despite concerns about their own finances. Consumption spending is expected to continue rising this year, but inflation could hinder growth in the future.

site_title: Cheap fares, costly fuel send India's airlines into a tailspin
summary: India's airlines face financial struggles due to cheap fares, high fuel prices, and a depreciating rupee. The industry is expected to become the world's third-largest by 2025, but experts warn that the current unsustainable business model will lead to financial woes. Top airlines, including IndiGo, Jet Airways, and Air India, are cutting costs and seeking investment to survive. The industry's reliance on low fares and favorable fuel pricing is unsustainable, and analysts predict fare hikes to match rising costs, potentially leading to a passenger crunch.

site_title: Refining trade facilitation
summary: ASEAN is working to refine trade facilitation by eliminating non-tariff sources of trade costs, such as customs and documentation procedures. The region aims to become a single market and production base, with initiatives like the ASEAN Single Window and ASEAN-Wide Self-Certification regime. An ASEAN Mutual Recognition Agreement on Authorised Economic Operators (AEO) is also being explored to facilitate and simplify customs clearance and reduce regulatory burdens. ASEAN has eliminated 98.64% of all tariffs, but further reductions are needed to achieve deeper regional integration and economic growth.

site_title: European stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.1% to 7,624.80 points, and the DAX 30 in Frankfurt and CAC 40 in Paris also increasing 0.2% each. The rally was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares. US stocks also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said negotiations for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) are nearing completion. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Dubai's Dubai Financial Services Authority (DFSA) signed a fintech agreement. APAC Realty entered a 40% joint venture in China's Hainan property market. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by the US tariff announcement, and the Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong (9th from L) poses with the ASEAN economic and trade ministers at the opening of 50th ASEAN Economic Ministers (AEM) Meeting and Related Meetings in Singapore on August 29, 2018

site_title: Singapore and Africa continue to push for economic integration and co-operation
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of economic integration and cooperation between Singapore and Africa amid a challenging global economic environment. He encouraged African firms to explore business opportunities in South-east Asia, particularly in Singapore, and urged governments to forge partnerships to create conducive environments for interactions between businesses. Chan also signed an avoidance of double taxation agreement with Gabon's Minister of Foreign Affairs, marking the 13th such arrangement between Singapore and an African country.

images.alt_text: From left: Mamadou Lamine Gueye, chief executive of the Compagnie Sénégalaise de Transport Transatlantique Afrique de l'Ouest; Chan Chun Sing, Minister for Trade and Industry; and Raymond Wong, managing director of Well & Able Holdings.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on US-Mexico trade deal; won steady
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.26% on Wednesday, driven by positive sentiment on the US-Mexico trade deal, while concerns over the Sino-US tariff war capped gains. The won remained flat, and bond yields fell. Shares of Dongkuk Steel Mill and Woongjin jumped 15% and 14.4% respectively, while construction stocks lost 2.9% after US Defense Secretary's remarks.

site_title: Malaysia joins property clampdown around the world with foreign buyer ban
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has announced a ban on foreign buyers for the US$100 billion Forest City project, citing concerns over foreign investment and the risk of "colonialism." The move follows a trend of restrictions on foreign property purchases worldwide, driven by soaring home prices and populist politics. Other countries, including Australia, Canada, New Zealand, and Singapore, have implemented similar measures, with experts warning that foreign buyers are often unfairly blamed for driving up home costs, despite having a minimal impact.

site_title: Australian shares lifted by financials; reopened NZ closes at record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to a 6,352.2 index value, driven by gains in the financial sector. The sector surged 1.8% with major banks climbing 2.1-2.7% after optimism over easing global trade tensions. New Zealand's benchmark index reached a record high of 9,362.67, up 1.6% after system glitches halted trading the previous day. Despite a sharp fall in gold prices, investors remained positive, with Boral Ltd jumping 10% after reporting higher annual profit.

site_title: Aston Martin gears up for £5b IPO on London Stock Exchange
summary: Aston Martin plans to list a quarter of its shares on the London Stock Exchange in an initial public offering (IPO) valued up to £5.0 billion. The company, known for its luxury cars favored by James Bond, has reported strong financial results and increased demand. CEO Andy Palmer stated that a bad Brexit deal would not significantly impact the firm. The IPO will involve a secondary sell-down by existing shareholders and will allow employees and customers to purchase shares.

site_title: Thai exchange chief confident foreigners will return to stocks
summary: Thailand's stock exchange chief, Pakorn Peetathawatchai, is confident that foreigners will return to the nation's equities as the country's growing economy and strong corporate earnings attract investors. Thailand's benchmark stock index has surged 8% this quarter, driven by better-than-expected quarterly growth in exports, spending, and investments. Despite a 2% loss for the year, the exchange expects the right timing for the first Bank of Thailand interest-rate increase in seven years, potentially boosting growth and corporate earnings. The Stock Exchange of Thailand is promoting its equities to international investors through an investment conference.

site_title: UK, EU drop October deadline for Brexit deal
summary: The UK and EU have revised their Brexit deadline, shifting from October to November at the latest, according to senior officials familiar with the negotiations. The EU had previously set a deadline of October 18, but officials now expect the divorce terms to be finalized by the middle of November. The prolonged talks and lack of progress have raised concerns that the UK may leave the EU without an agreement, with the pound experiencing recent volatility.

site_title: Bank of Thailand governor says no 'imminent' need to hike rates
summary: Bank of Thailand Governor Veerathai Santiprabhob stated there's no imminent need to hike interest rates due to Thailand's solid economic buffers and strong currency. Despite inflation returning to the 1-4% target range, the central bank is monitoring developments closely, particularly trade protectionism risks. The Bank of Thailand is not under pressure to raise rates, and its benchmark rate remains at 1.5%, near a record low.

site_title: Westpac first big Australia lender to raise mortgage rates
summary: Westpac Banking Corp, Australia's largest lender, raised its key mortgage rate by 14 basis points to 5.38% for owner-occupiers, marking the first major bank to pass on higher funding costs. The move reflects sustained increases in wholesale funding costs and will add A$35 to the interest cost of an A$300,000 loan. The decision comes amid a backdrop of stagnant wages growth and high household debt, and may squeeze borrowers already struggling.

images.alt_text: Westpac Banking Corp raised its key mortgage rate, the first of the nation's biggest banks to decide passing on higher funding costs is worth the risk of further reputational damage.

site_title: APAC Realty to enter Hainan property market with 40% joint venture
summary: APAC Realty has entered into a 40% joint venture with two Chinese firms to penetrate the Hainan property market. The new venture, ERA Hainan Real Estate Marketing Co, will conduct brokerage services and train property agents. The joint venture will have a registered share capital of 20 million yuan and will be owned by APAC Realty, Zhong Zhi Sheng He Real Estate Investment, and Bei Guo Tou (Shanghai) Equity Investment and Fund Management Co. The move comes as the Chinese government imposes property cooling measures to rein in escalating prices, with APAC Realty CEO Jack Chua stating that the measures will ensure a sustainable transaction volume.

site_title: Tencent-backed China electric car maker NIO seeks US$1.3b in US IPO
summary: NIO, a Chinese electric car maker backed by Tencent Holdings, is seeking up to $1.3 billion in its US IPO, offering 160 million American depositary shares at $6.25 to $8.25 each. The company plans to use proceeds for research and development, sales and marketing, and expanding manufacturing facilities. Founder William Li will retain significant voting power, with 14.5% ownership and 48.3% voting power. NIO's first vehicle, the ES8, has been delivered to over 1,300 customers, with reservations for another 15,700.

site_title: UOB, Synagie tie up to help SMEs manage online sales channels
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with Synagie Corp to provide its small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) clients with preferential access to the e-commerce solutions of Synagie. The partnership aims to help SMEs manage their online sales channels more effectively, with solutions including Synagie.com, a cloud-based platform for integrating sales and distribution across multiple e-marketplaces and offline channels. The deal also offers on-demand warehousing and fulfilment services, real-time big data analytics tools, and enhanced financial management capabilities, with UOB clients eligible for up to S$2,500 in benefits.

site_title: Encouraging innovation and e-commerce
summary: Singapore aims to promote innovation, digital connectivity, and e-commerce in ASEAN to harness the region's potential in the digital economy. The ASEAN Agreement on e-Commerce is being finalized by the end of 2018, expected to streamline regional trade rules and lower barriers to entry for businesses. The agreement will facilitate freer movement of e-commerce goods and allow companies to market products regionally while making electronic payments easier. This move is expected to boost economic growth and provide businesses with opportunities to participate in the digital economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,251.6, up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading with a 0.1% gain, reaching 3,251.6, after a lunch break. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 4.05 points. Trading was relatively balanced, with 148 gainers and 150 losers. Key movers included Nico Steel, Rex International, and AusGroup, which saw significant price movements. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: The ASEAN Economic Community
summary: The ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) was established on December 31, 2015, with the AEC Blueprint 2025 aiming to deepen and broaden integration among the 10 member states. Key goals include eliminating non-tariff barriers, streamlining regulatory regimes, and increasing financial inclusion. The AEC also seeks to create a highly integrated and cohesive economy, promote innovation and productivity, and improve connectivity among member states. ASEAN aims to become a competitive, innovative, and dynamic region, with a focus on sustainable economic development and global integration.

site_title: Saudi women entrepreneurs grow their ventures at US incubator
summary: Saudi women entrepreneurs are participating in a US-based business incubator to develop their ventures, following reforms aimed at promoting gender equality. 14 women, including Reem Dad and Heba Zahid, attended an intensive programme at Halcyon in Washington, working on projects such as virtual reality tours, recycling initiatives, and community service games. The initiative aims to support Saudi women's participation in the workforce, with the goal of increasing their presence from 22% to 30% by 2030, in line with the government's Vision 2030.

site_title: ASEAN Economic Community: Challenges ahead
summary: ASEAN's Economic Community (AEC) 2025 faces challenges ahead, including rising trade protectionism, the US-China trade war, and Brexit's impact on globalisation. Despite progress since AEC's establishment in 2015, implementation remains uneven, and concerns over unequal benefits and conflicts of interest hinder governments from committing to bold measures. However, AEC will continue to focus on trade, digital commerce, and services sector cooperation to promote economic integration and address vulnerabilities in the future.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB posts higher Q2 profit, cautious on full-year growth
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings reported a higher second-quarter net profit of RM1.98 billion, driven by gains from recent deals. Excluding deal gains, profit was RM1.05 billion. Revenue rose 12% to RM4.86 billion, while net interest income fell 6%. The bank is cautious on 2018 growth prospects due to rising global trade tensions and market uncertainties. CIMB's CEO Zafrul Aziz stated this in a statement, indicating a relatively cautious outlook for the full year.

site_title: Myanmar rejects UN probe on Rohingya abuses
summary: Myanmar rejected a UN probe alleging genocide by its military against the Rohingya, citing the UN Fact-Finding Mission's inability to enter the country. The UN report found evidence of genocide and crimes against humanity "perpetrated on a massive scale" in last year's military crackdown. Myanmar's government responded by forming its own Independent Commission of Enquiry and criticized Facebook for removing the pages of top military brass, claiming it hampers national reconciliation efforts. The US and other countries called for Myanmar's military leaders to face international justice.

site_title: China faces difficulties in achieving stable economic development: state planner
summary: China is facing challenges in achieving stable economic development, according to the head of its state planning department, He Lifeng. China needs to boost efforts to hit consumption and social development targets in the second half, with a focus on boosting growth in these areas. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Hot stock: 800 Super falls more than 25%
summary: 800 Super, a Catalist-listed environmental services provider, has seen its stock fall 26.06% in trading, reaching its lowest point this year at 61 Singapore cents. The firm reported a net loss of S$1.65 million for its fiscal fourth quarter, attributed to higher expenses. Revenue fell 1.8% to S$37.9 million, mainly due to completed term contracts and competitive pricing. Despite near-term profit weakness, the company is expected to see higher earnings in FY2019 due to new projects, including a waste-to-energy plant and Integrated Waste Management Facility.

site_title: Seamless economic integration and connected ASEAN is good for all
summary: Singapore's ASEAN Chairmanship in 2018 aims to deepen economic integration and create a seamless business environment, benefiting all ASEAN countries. With a combined GDP of $2.55 trillion and 600 million consumers, ASEAN is a significant market with enormous potential for growth. The region's economic performance is built on the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) vision, which aims to reduce trade barriers and create opportunities for businesses and people. Key initiatives include the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and the ASEAN Single Window, which aim to boost free trade and facilitate trade within the region.

images.alt_text: "In the face of mounting pressures on the open and rules-based multilateral trading system, and the regional integration and economic cooperation that have underpinned ASEAN's growth, I am heartened that the ASEAN Member States have responded by reaffirming the importance of deepening economic integration." - Chan Chun Sing.

site_title: Toyota to target tripling China production over next decade: sources
summary: Toyota aims to triple car production in China by 2030, targeting 3.5 million vehicles annually, with plans to boost imports to 500,000 vehicles and expand capacity in Tianjin and Guangzhou. The move comes as the company seeks to adapt to China's growing demand for hybrid and electric vehicles, with the government aiming for 20% of car sales to be new-energy vehicles by 2025. Toyota plans to reinforce its organisation to accelerate its Chinese business, despite challenges including a cooling market and US tariffs.

site_title: China's bankers have one too many balls in the air
summary: China's commercial banks are facing pressure to balance conflicting policy goals, including funding infrastructure spending and cutting bad debt. To remain profitable, lenders must prioritize consumer lending, but this poses risks due to the high cost of assessing individual creditworthiness and the potential for consumer borrowing to cool. Despite this, joint-stock banks have increased mortgage and credit card lending, with some banks reporting yields of nearly 6%. The Chinese government is loosening fiscal purse strings to support infrastructure investment, but a shortage of viable projects and concerns over private company debt usage add to the complexity.

images.alt_text: Chinese loan officers are finding themselves torn between conflicting policy goals. Beijing wants the country's commercial banks to help fund infrastructure spending to support cooling growth, but isn't relaxing a campaign to cut a US$290 billion pile of bad debt.

site_title: Capturing ASEAN markets with knowledge and partnership
summary: ASEAN economies are expected to remain resilient despite global protectionist policies, with a 5.4% GDP growth forecast in 2018. 77% of Singapore businesses plan for overseas expansion, with 77% targeting ASEAN as the region for expansion. The ASEAN Economic Community is seen as a key factor in this positivity, with 70% of companies surveyed believing integration will bring opportunities. To succeed, businesses must adapt to unique opportunities and challenges, leveraging trade associations, international agreements, and free trade agreements to establish networks and lower market entry barriers.

site_title: Fung Group makes Singapore its bridge to S-E Asia
summary: Hong Kong's Fung Group has established its regional headquarters in Singapore to expand its presence in South Asia and Southeast Asia. The conglomerate, which includes Li & Fung and Global Brands Group, aims to capitalize on the region's growing consumer market. The move underscores the Fung Group's long-term commitment to developing the supply chain industry in Singapore, leveraging its strategic location and connectivity. The group's operations in Singapore include logistics, trade, and retail businesses, and it plans to develop a new built-to-suit facility to support future growth.

images.alt_text: Merchandisers working in Fung Group's new Singapore office.

site_title: 1MDB-linked banker disappears from US website
summary: A former Goldman Sachs banker, Roger Ng, linked to the 1MDB scandal, has disappeared from the website of his last-known employer, Celsius Holdings Inc, a US-based energy drinks company. Ng, who was managing director for Asia, was removed from the company's website in August 2018. Celsius has ties to other individuals connected to 1MDB, including Tim Leissner, a former Goldman Sachs banker who is a shareholder in the company. The company's losses have been incurred for at least a decade, and it has been sold in Target Corp stores and distributed in Asia by Li Ka-shing's AS Watson Group.

site_title: PayPal uniquely positioned to help ASEAN SMEs
summary: PayPal has identified three key business verticals in South-east Asia: travel, freelance workers, and micro, small and medium-sized enterprises. The company sees these sectors as engines of growth in emerging economies, and is uniquely positioned to help them access and connect to the global digital economy. With youthful demographics and improved technology, South-east Asia is expected to drive growth in e-commerce and the gig economy. PayPal is focusing on initiatives to empower freelancers and SMEs, with a goal of making payments disappear into platforms, giving them a competitive edge.

site_title: Facebook rolls out video service worldwide
summary: Facebook is rolling out its Watch video service worldwide, following a successful year-long launch in the US. The service aims to engage users through original shows, interactive content, and user-generated videos. Fidji Simo, Facebook's vice president for video, emphasized the importance of user-created content and monetization through ads, rather than relying solely on funded content. The move comes as Facebook continues to shift its focus towards online video platforms, following the rise of streaming services like Netflix and Hulu.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise but investors guarded over trade
summary: Asian markets rose for a third day, with Tokyo and Hong Kong gaining 0.7% and 0.3% respectively, as investors cautiously welcomed the US-Mexico free-trade deal and Canada's talks on joining. However, concerns over US-China tariffs and a potential US$200 billion levy remain, with Shanghai losing 0.4%. Analysts caution that the deal may not be fully ratified by the US Congress, and the Trump administration's trade policies continue to pose uncertainty.

site_title: Virgin Australia swings to annual underlying profit, forward bookings strong
summary: Virgin Australia reported an annual underlying profit of A$109.6 million, its highest in a decade, driven by a strong domestic business. Despite a statutory loss of A$653.3 million, the airline expects to post both underlying and statutory profits in the current half, driven by a 7% growth in group revenue. CEO John Borghetti stated the domestic business is in the best position ever, and forward bookings are strong, leading to a profitable current half.

site_title: Boosting energy security in ASEAN
summary: Singapore, as ASEAN chair, is pursuing initiatives to boost energy security in the region, focusing on energy efficiency, natural gas, and renewable energy. Planned initiatives include developing a regional green building code, enhancing LNG cooperation, and attracting energy investments. The country is also co-organising a clean energy investment and financing training programme with the International Energy Agency. Additionally, Singapore is hosting the 11th Singapore International Energy Week, which will bring together key stakeholders to discuss global energy issues and develop energy solutions for the region.

site_title: RCEP talks could be nearing finish line; integrated Asean a more attractive economic partner: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong says negotiations for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) are nearing completion, with the multilateral trading system under pressure amid global tensions. The proposed RCEP mega-deal involves 10 Asean member states and six free trade agreement partners, and is seen as a way to strengthen regional economic integration and counter unilateralism and protectionism. Lee urged countries involved to take a long-term view and engage constructively to deliver an agreement on the RCEP this year, emphasizing the importance of maintaining the multilateral trading system.

site_title: SPH Magazines expands its complimentary digital library to Shangri-La Hotel
summary: SPH Magazines has expanded its complimentary digital magazine service, The Wifi Library, to the Shangri-La Hotel in Singapore for the first time. The service offers free access to 7,000 titles, previously available at OCBC bank branches, Paragon, and other locations. Users can connect to the Wi-Fi network, download the MyNewsstand app, and access the digital library. The partnership aims to enhance the hotel's guest experience and provide easy access to Asia's top magazine titles.

site_title: Disposal of RHT's assets to Fortis 'on normal commercial terms': IFA
summary: RHT Health Trust's proposed disposal of assets to Fortis is on normal commercial terms and not prejudicial to the trust's interests or minority unitholders. The disposal, valued at S$669.6 million, represents a 58.1% return and an internal rate of return of 10.2% per annum. The trust's assets, including 12 clinical establishments and two operating hospitals in India, will be sold after negotiations with Fortis, which has an indirect control over the assets. Unitholders will vote on the proposed disposal and amendments to the trust deed at an extraordinary general meeting on Sept 26.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 4.89 points to 1,822.01. Losers outnumbered gainers 103 to 94, with 110.58 million lots traded worth RM44.75 million.

site_title: The key is to scale up, work collectively and reduce cost
summary: ASEAN's economic integration has made significant progress since the 1997-1998 Asian Financial Crisis. The region has scaled up, worked collectively, and reduced costs to attract foreign investors, leading to increased job opportunities and technology transfer. Tariffs on goods have been cut to a minimum, and competitively-priced goods from all ASEAN Member States are now available in all member states. ASEAN's economic integration has also led to increased cooperation in areas such as agriculture, civil aviation, tourism, education, environment, ICT, and migration. The ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) Blueprint 2025 aims to further integrate the economy, with predicted GDP growth of over 5% in the next three to four years.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks inch up, won steady awaiting China tariff deadline
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.53 points, or 0.07%, to 2,304.65, driven by optimism over the US-Mexico trade deal. However, caution remained ahead of the China tariff deadline. The Korean won remained steady, while bond yields rose. MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index also edged up 0.07%. The Kospi has fallen 6.7% this year, but the previous 30-day gain was 0.05%.

site_title: ASEAN takes the lead
summary: ASEAN has made significant progress in its economic integration efforts, with 98.7% of intra-ASEAN tariffs eliminated by 2018. Key milestones include the live operation of the ASEAN Single Window and the ASEAN Solutions for Investments, Services, and Trade platform. ASEAN is also negotiating an ASEAN Trade in Services Agreement and intensifying efforts to finalize the ASEAN Agreement on e-Commerce. To stay relevant, ASEAN must continue to voice support for an open, rules-based multilateral trading system and remain steadfast in its integration efforts. The region is also pursuing the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a potential game-changer for regional economic growth.

site_title: Paving the way to enhance ASEAN economic integration
summary: The ASEAN Business Advisory Council (ASEAN-BAC) aims to enhance ASEAN economic integration by providing private sector feedback and guidance to the grouping's leaders. Established in 2003, ASEAN-BAC drives vision and action through the theme "Building Tomorrow, Connecting Today." It advocates policy recommendations and shares business insights on key trends impacting businesses in ASEAN. This year, ASEAN-BAC rolls out the "SGConnect" legacy project to foster smart urbanization and support successful urbanization in ASEAN.

site_title: Regional markets guide
summary: Singapore firms can tap into growth opportunities in ASEAN markets, with Enterprise Singapore highlighting key sectors such as technology, healthcare, and finance. Meanwhile, Vietnam was surprised by the Trump tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. In Malaysia, a RM3 billion asset seizure was made against Daim Zainuddin, and the country's industrial production rose 0.3% in May. GoTo shares are expected to rebound after a US$2.2 billion sell-off, and foreign investors are returning to Vietnam's stocks. A rate cut in Malaysia was seen as a response to tariff threats, while Thailand's super-long bonds gained due to tariffs and a political crisis.

site_title: Leaders' views on an integrated ASEAN
summary: ASEAN leaders express their views on the ASEAN Economic Community, highlighting its contributions to the region's economic integration and development. The ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) has achieved significant progress, including expanding market access, promoting trade and investment, and fostering a resilient and inclusive economy. Leaders emphasize the importance of MSMEs and the private sector in driving economic growth and narrowing development gaps. They also stress the need for closer cooperation with dialogue partners to accelerate ASEAN integration. The AEC has led to increased economic connectivity, a more competitive and dynamic ASEAN, and a stronger voice for the region in global economic affairs.

site_title: China to start new anti-dumping probe on some bisphenol A imports
summary: China's commerce ministry announced it will launch a new anti-dumping investigation on imports of bisphenol A (BPA) from Japan, South Korea, Singapore, and Taiwan, effective August 30. Existing duties on these imports will continue during the investigation. This move follows existing anti-dumping measures on BPA imports from the same countries.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.1% to 3,251.36
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 3.81 points to 3,251.36. The STI gained 0.1% as 29.1 million shares worth S$34.8 million changed hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 65 to 48, with Nico Steel, Yanlord Land Group, and Singtel being the most active stocks.

site_title: Exploring economic relationships with external partners
summary: ASEAN has strengthened economic relationships with external partners, including Canada, the US, the EU, Russia, China, Japan, Hong Kong, South Korea, India, Australia, and New Zealand, while preserving ASEAN centrality. The region has implemented or is in the process of implementing free trade agreements (FTAs) with these partners, including the ASEAN-China Free Trade Agreement (ACFTA) and the ASEAN-ROK Free Trade Area (AKFTA) Agreement. ASEAN is also part of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) negotiations, which aim to create a comprehensive economic partnership among 16 countries. These agreements are expected to deepen economic cooperation and promote trade and investment among the participating countries.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday following a gain on Wall Street, driven by renewed optimism over North American trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.16% to 22,850.39, while the Topix index gained 0.23% to 1,735.59. This marked the sixth consecutive day of gains for the Nikkei 225.

site_title: Regional connectivity crucial to 'Sea'
summary: Regional connectivity is crucial for Sea, a Singapore-based internet firm, as it boosts growth in its core market of South-east Asia. The company's strategy involves tailoring products and services to each local market, with a focus on localisation. Dr. Santitarn, Sea's group chief economist, emphasizes the importance of regional investments in infrastructure and digital economy initiatives, such as e-payment methods and digital identity systems. He highlights the potential of ASEAN's digital economy, which he believes has the potential to surpass the overall economy, and calls for deeper public-private cooperation and transnational projects to develop the region's digital ecosystem.

site_title: Dozens at Facebook unite to challenge its 'intolerant' liberal culture
summary: A group of Facebook employees, led by senior engineer Brian Amerige, have formed an online group called FB'ers for Political Diversity to promote ideological diversity within the company. The group's aim is to create a space for diverse viewpoints, but its creation has been met with criticism from other employees who say its posts are offensive to minorities. The initiative is seen as a rare sign of organized dissent within Facebook, which has faced criticism for its liberal workplace culture and alleged anti-conservative bias. The group's formation comes amid a wave of employee activism over diversity in the tech industry.

site_title: VMware's hybrid cloud service to be available in Singapore in first quarter 2019
summary: VMware is set to launch its hybrid cloud service, VMware Cloud on AWS, in Singapore in the first quarter of 2019. The service, which enables enterprise customers to migrate applications to the cloud, will be available in Singapore after being launched in Sydney and Tokyo. The hybrid cloud solution allows customers to run production applications across VMware's hybrid cloud environments, providing optimised access to AWS services and robust disaster protection. VMware aims to help customers improve employee and customer experience through its cloud-based solutions.

images.alt_text: Digital infrastructure software company VMware announced this week that it will be launching in Singapore its hybrid cloud service, VMware Cloud on AWS (Amazon Web Services), in the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: Trump warns tech giants, stepping up attacks claiming 'bias'
summary: US President Donald Trump warned tech giants, including Facebook, Google, and Twitter, to be "careful" after criticizing "rigged" internet search results. Trump claimed Google was "taking advantage of a lot of people" and cited Facebook and Twitter as treading "troubled territory." Google denied any bias, stating that search results are not manipulated for political sentiment. The White House may consider regulation, but experts argue any government attempts to control search results would violate the Constitution's First Amendment speech guarantees.

site_title: China's Didi apologises, vows changes after passenger killing
summary: China's ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing has apologized and vowed to prioritize safety after a second passenger was allegedly killed by a driver using its services in three months. The company will suspend its Hitch car-pooling service indefinitely and redesign its emergency help button. Didi has also removed two executives and will re-evaluate its business model. The company stated that it had failed to protect its passengers and will take responsibility for the deaths. This comes after the company faced criticism from state media, regulators, and social media users.

site_title: One killed, dozens wounded in Philippines bombing
summary: A bomb blast at a festival in the southern Philippines killed one person and wounded dozens more, the second deadly attack in the region in under a month. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred near a petrol station in the town of Isulan. Authorities discovered two other bombs in the area and defused them. The attack comes as the government enacts a law to create greater autonomy for the Muslim minority in the south, aiming to help end the decades-long conflict.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open marginally lower
summary: Hong Kong shares opened marginally lower on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 12.67 points to 28,338.95. This followed two days of gains, despite another record close on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down, with the Shanghai Index losing 0.11% and the Shenzhen Index losing 0.16%. The decline was attributed to the ongoing US-China trade tensions, but investors remained optimistic due to the record close on Wall Street.

site_title: US Senate confirms Clarida as new Federal Reserve vice-chair
summary: The US Senate confirmed economist Richard Clarida as the new Federal Reserve vice-chairman, replacing Stanley Fischer, with a vote of 69-26. Clarida, a Columbia University economist, supports the Fed's interest rate policy and has served as assistant secretary of the US Treasury under former President George W. Bush. This is Trump's third nominee to the central bank, with six of the seven seats either filled or awaiting confirmation. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates again in December to keep inflation under control.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 rises as Nafta deal boosts miners, EM stocks
summary: The FTSE 100 rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by gains in mining stocks and emerging market exposure. Heavyweight miners such as BHP Billiton, Glencore, and Rio Tinto saw significant gains. The rally was also boosted by relief over global trade and anxiety over the NAFTA trade deal. Shares in South African-exposed companies and a healthcare provider in the UAE also rose. Despite the boost, the second-quarter earnings season has been weak for UK stocks, with commodity-related sectors driving growth and international stocks seeing upward revisions.

site_title: HMI's posts 43% increase in Q4 profit
summary: Health Management International (HMI) posted a 42.7% increase in net profit to RM15.2 million in its fourth quarter, driven by higher revenue from its healthcare business and better cost management. Revenue rose 6.7% to RM119.2 million, with earnings per share increasing to 1.82 sen. The company's full-year revenue rose 7.3% to RM467.6 million, with net earnings tripling to RM60.6 million.

site_title: Russia to hold biggest military drills since Cold War
summary: Russia will conduct the largest military drills since the Cold War era, Vostok-2018, from September 11-15, involving 300,000 troops and 1,000 aircraft. The exercises, similar in scale to the 1981 Zapad-81 drills, will also include troops from China and Mongolia. The Kremlin has described the exercises as "justified." NATO has warned of a "more assertive Russia," while Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu has stated that the exercises are a response to "new global challenges." The drills are seen as a demonstration of Russia's military capabilities.

site_title: Talent important in winning the ASEAN game
summary: Enterprise Singapore emphasizes the importance of nurturing talent in Singapore who can understand culture and market nuances to succeed in ASEAN. The agency identifies challenges in finding the right talent due to cost considerations and limited skillsets. To address this, Enterprise Singapore offers training programs, such as the Professional Conversion Programme and the ASEAN Leadership Programme, and provides financial incentives like the Double Tax Deduction scheme. The agency also highlights four growth areas in ASEAN: consumerism, technology and innovation, infrastructure, and manufacturing, where Singapore companies and talent can contribute.

site_title: Powering its way through to ASEAN markets and beyond
summary: Sunseap Group, a Singapore-based renewable energy company, has expanded its presence in 10 markets, including ASEAN countries and non-ASEAN markets such as Australia, India, and mainland China. The company credits the rise in demand for solar power due to lower costs and governments cutting fuel subsidies. Sunseap offers integrated energy solutions, including rooftop installations, floating photovoltaic systems, and solar farming technology. The company aims to consolidate its position in the markets it has recently entered and build new revenue streams through research and development of its proprietary technology.

images.alt_text: Mr Phuan says Sunseap's mission is to provide clean power and de-carbonising solutions for corporates, governments, and consumers, in a sustainable manner.

site_title: Gaining a foothold through economic links between ASEAN countries
summary: Golden Sunland, a Singapore-based rice company, has established a foothold in Myanmar's domestic rice market through economic links with ASEAN countries. Founded in 2016, the company leveraged emerging markets like Myanmar for long-term growth, bypassing more developed markets like Vietnam and Thailand. By utilizing ASEAN economic ties, Golden Sunland successfully conducted business in Myanmar, setting it apart from typical agriculture firms.

images.alt_text: Golden Sunland works with rice farms in Myanmar to grow high-yield hybrid rice and has been finding ways to add value throughout the supply chain.

site_title: Trudeau will only sign Nafta deal that's 'good for Canada'
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced he will sign a revamped North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) deal that is "good for Canada" but rejects US demands to dismantle Canada's dairy market. Trudeau stated that the agreement must prioritize middle-class Canadians and that he will defend Canada's supply-managed dairy market. US and Mexican leaders reached a tentative accord on a revised Nafta deal after months of negotiations, with President Donald Trump suggesting he could cut Canada out of the agreement. Trudeau's visit to Quebec came after Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland joined trilateral trade negotiations in Washington.

site_title: Italy looks to foreign support if speculators attack
summary: Italy is seeking foreign support in the event of speculative attacks on its markets, Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini said. Economy Minister Giovanni Tria visited China to deepen investment ties, amid volatile Italian sovereign bond yields reaching three-month highs. Salvini stated that Italy will count on support from non-EU countries like the US and Russia if its markets are targeted. This comes as Italy has the largest debt burden in the euro zone and has suffered recent speculative attacks on its bonds. Salvini's comments come as the new anti-establishment government seeks to strengthen economic ties with nations outside the EU.

site_title: Medical tourism, ageing Thais create US$13b hospital empire
summary: A Thai hospital operator, Bangkok Dusit Medical Services Pcl, has seen its shares surge 29% in 2018, driven by demand from Thailand's ageing population and medical tourism. The company's market value now exceeds $13 billion, surpassing Malaysia's IHH Healthcare Bhd. Despite the rally, investors believe the shares have further room to rise. This growth is attributed to the increasing need for healthcare services among Thailand's ageing population and the country's growing medical tourism industry.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq edge to fresh records, put trade fears aside
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher despite trade tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose less than a tenth of a percentage point. Investors are becoming increasingly optimistic about North American trade talks, with consumer confidence at its highest level since 2000. However, some companies like Best Buy and Tesla faced negative news, with Best Buy's shares sinking 5% and Tesla extending losses by 2.3%. Despite this, markets are putting trade fears aside and focusing on the economy's improving trends.

site_title: Malaysian committee to study Forest City project
summary: Malaysia's government has formed a committee to review the $100 billion Forest City real estate project, following Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's announcement that foreigners will not be granted visas to live there. The project, which aims to house 700,000 people on reclaimed land near Singapore, has faced uncertainty since Mahathir's coalition won the general election in May. Shares in Hong Kong-listed Country Garden, the project's developer, fell 3.5% following the announcement, which has been met with criticism from the company, citing compliance with regulations. A review of the project's terms will be conducted.

site_title: Buyers taking HDB loan can keep up to S$20k in CPF Ordinary Account
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has launched 5,101 flats for sale, including 4,375 Build-to-Order flats and 726 Re-Offer of Balance Flats. Buyers can now keep up to S$20,000 in their CPF Ordinary Accounts when taking a HDB loan, improving retirement adequacy. Prices range from S$75,000 to over S$411,000, with two new waterfront projects in Punggol and Yishun available. Applications close on September 3, with the next BTO launch scheduled for November.

site_title: Green Build buys columbarium niches in Seoul, raises S$2.4m in convertible bond issuance
summary: Green Build Technology signed an asset purchase agreement with Yea Eun Columbarium in Seoul, South Korea, to buy niches worth S$5.6 million, with a valuation pending. The company will issue 27.78 million new shares, making up about 10% of its enlarged share capital, in exchange for the acquisition. This move raises S$2.4 million in convertible bond issuance, following the issuance of S$5 million in new shares.

site_title: Oil dips on profit-taking, trade deal limits decline
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures declining 26 cents to $75.95 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling 34 cents to $68.53 a barrel. The decline was partly due to profit-taking after recent strong gains and partly due to a US-Mexico trade agreement easing tensions. However, losses were limited by news that the agreement could ease demand concerns for the energy industry. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' monitoring committee also reported that countries participating in an output-cut deal have been increasing production at a modest pace.

site_title: Texan begins selling 3D gun plans despite judge's order
summary: A Texas man, Cody Wilson, began selling 3D-printed gun plans, including for a plastic handgun, despite a federal judge's order to stop their distribution. The judge's ruling was made after a joint lawsuit from multiple states claimed Wilson's actions endangered public safety. Wilson interpreted the ruling as only prohibiting free online distribution, and instead started selling the plans for a fee, with visitors able to name their own price. Wilson claims the digital files were already available elsewhere online and argues that free speech rights are at stake.

images.alt_text: A Texas man on Tuesday began selling digital gun-making blueprints, including for a 3D-printed plastic handgun, despite a judge's order barring the distribution of the material.

site_title: US toughens stance as North Korea talks stumble
summary: The US is tightening its stance on North Korea amid stalled talks, with President Trump's administration suspending large-scale military drills and canceling a top-level summit in Pyongyang. Despite a historic summit between Trump and Kim Jong Un in June, North Korea has taken few concrete steps towards denuclearization, and signs of frustration abound. The US remains open to negotiations, but will only engage when North Korea shows readiness to deliver on its commitments, according to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

site_title: Lee Chee Koon to be CapLand's president, group CEO from Sept 15
summary: Lee Chee Koon will become CapitaLand's president and group CEO from September 15, succeeding Lim Ming Yan. Lim will remain as a board director until December 31 to provide guidance during the transition. Lee, 43, joined CapitaLand in 2007 and previously led its serviced-residence business. He has successfully grown revenues and expanded the business, and will build upon Lim's foundation to drive growth and achieve greater returns for shareholders.

site_title: Ghana, Britain sign £20m trade deal
summary: Ghana and the UK signed a £20 million trade and investment agreement, aiming to create 15,000 new jobs and promote economic development in Ghana. The agreement, tailored to Ghana's "Ghana Beyond Aid" vision, focuses on business facilitation, inward investment, and infrastructure development. Britain's Minister of State for Africa, Harriet Baldwin, stated that the programme will attract £15 million investments and improve trade relations with Ghana. The deal is part of UK Prime Minister Theresa May's campaign to promote Britain's global ambitions after Brexit.

site_title: Withdrawing CPF: Half put funds in savings accounts
summary: A CPF Trends study found that 51% of CPF members who withdraw funds use them for retirement savings, while 27% use them for household expenses. 13% use the funds to pay off loans. The majority of those who withdraw funds (4 in 10) do not use them, likely due to not needing the money. The median amount withdrawn was $9,000, and the most common purposes were retirement savings, household expenses, and loan payments.

site_title: Outlook for online hiring in Singapore extremely positive: report
summary: Singapore's online hiring outlook is "extremely positive" due to emerging technologies, with 17% of local employers expecting to increase staffing in the next quarter, according to Monster's Employment Index Q2 2018. The finance and insurance industry has the highest hiring intentions, and Singapore's banking and financial services sector remains the strongest in online hiring activity. The country's favorable regulatory environment and commitment to investing in infrastructure have contributed to its growth, with a projected 2.3% GDP growth for 2018-2022.

site_title: Talent crucial in winning the ASEAN game
summary: Enterprise Singapore's Ivan Tan emphasizes the importance of nurturing talent with a deep understanding of ASEAN culture and market nuances to help Singapore companies successfully venture into the region. Challenges include navigating regulations, finding suitable local partners, and differentiating products or services from stiff competition. With a huge population base, ASEAN attracts global investors, making it a key growth area for Singapore companies.

images.alt_text: Ivan Tan, Enterprise Singapore's Global Market Director for South-east Asia.

site_title: Gold miner Wilton Resources sinks deeper into the red with 24.7b rupiah Q4 loss
summary: Wilton Resources Corp, a gold miner, reported a net loss of 24.7 billion rupiah (S$2.3 million) in Q4 and 78.8 billion rupiah for the full year, with a loss per share of 10.12 rupiah and 32.35 rupiah respectively. Higher operating and finance expenses, mainly due to exploration and evaluation expenses, contributed to the losses. The company reported its maiden gold dore sale in Q4, but gold prices declined during the year due to a stronger US dollar. Despite this, Wilton Resources remains focused on gold production at its Ciemas Gold Project.

site_title: Stuck housing projects weighing down India realty
summary: India's residential property market is struggling due to 4.64 trillion rupees (S$90.2 billion) worth of stalled projects. As of 2013, 575,900 units are stranded in top cities, with developers facing liquidity crunches, environmental clearances, and labor shortages. The government may need to intervene to complete stalled projects, with buyers potentially spending more and lenders accepting losses to avoid further delays. The market's recovery is hindered by a slowdown this decade, despite government reforms.

site_title: Singapore can be African firms' launchpad to S-E Asia
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for economic integration and cooperation between Africa and South-east Asia. He encouraged African firms to use Singapore as a launchpad for business opportunities in the region. Chan also highlighted the importance of forging partnerships between governments and creating conducive environments for business interactions. The Minister signed an avoidance of double taxation agreement with Gabon's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Cooperation, Francophonie and Regional Integration. This move aims to promote economic collaboration between the two regions.

site_title: ASEAN Economic Community: Looking back to move forward
summary: ASEAN's economic community has evolved from a trade liberalisation initiative to a more comprehensive form of cooperation, with the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) 2025 aiming to bring economic coherence and establish a single market. The AEC's objective is to attract Foreign Direct Investment, support production activities at a lower cost, and remain competitive in a globalised world. The community's growth is crucial to address vulnerabilities, and a more integrated ASEAN is inevitable to address future challenges. ASEAN's economic integration is expected to drive regional growth and development.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Hatten Land, FJ Benjamin, Wing Tai, Civmec, IHH Healthcare
summary:

site_title: Completed condo prices slip 0.5% in July
summary: Singapore's completed non-landed private homes experienced a 0.5% monthly decline in July, following a 0.7% increase in June. Year-to-date, prices are up 3.7%, led by a 3.8% increase in the non-central region. Year-on-year, prices rose 8.0%, driven by a 9.4% increase in the central region and a 6.9% gain in the non-central region.

site_title: China's swine fever outbreak may spread in Asia: UN body
summary: China's African swine fever outbreak may spread to the Korean Peninsula and South-east Asia, according to the FAO. The disease, which has already affected four Chinese provinces, has raised fears of its transmission to neighboring countries due to high pork consumption and trade. China has culled 24,000 pigs and is conducting nationwide checks, while the FAO is communicating with authorities to raise preparedness. The disease is highly contagious and persistent, with no vaccine available, and its movement through pig products is likely to cause its spread.

site_title: Dancing in the moonlight
summary: Singapore Dance Theatre celebrates its 30th anniversary with a special edition of Ballet Under The Stars, a traditional annual event. The program features neo-classical works, including George Balanchine's "The Four Temperaments" and Edwaard Liang's "13th Heaven." The company will also pay tribute to late choreographer Goh Choo San with a showcase of three works. The event runs from August 31 to September 9 at Fort Canning Green, with tickets available.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BLACKGOLD Natural Resources denied being aware of any suspension of its Riau-1 Project and expects no impact from bribery allegations. The company's financials are not expected to be affected by the revocation of the project. Civmec posted a net profit of S$8.34 million in the fourth quarter, up from S$956,000 last year, driven by higher revenue from existing contracts. 800 Super Holdings reversed into the red for the fiscal fourth-quarter with a net loss of S$1.65 million.

site_title: Promoting innovation and e-commerce
summary: Singapore aims to promote innovation and e-commerce in ASEAN to boost digital connectivity and facilitate seamless movement of e-commerce goods. The ASEAN Agreement on e-Commerce is expected to streamline regional trade rules and lower operating barriers, while a digital integration framework will monitor progress and identify areas for improvement. The initiatives are expected to aid companies in harnessing their roles as business enablers, improve growth sectors, and benefit businesses, especially micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. The pay-offs for ASEAN are expected to be significant if the economies can harness digitalisation's potential.

site_title: A more economically integrated and connected ASEAN is good for all
summary: Singapore's 2018 ASEAN Chairmanship aimed to deepen economic integration and boost opportunities for the region. ASEAN, the sixth-largest economy in the world, has a combined GDP of US$2.55 trillion and a market of over 600 million consumers. The region's economic performance is built on the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) vision, which has created a seamless business environment by reducing trade barriers and improving market access. Key initiatives include the ASEAN Single Window and negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), which have the potential to bring about real and tangible benefits to businesses and citizens, positioning ASEAN for future growth.

site_title: Is there a doctor aboard the ship?
summary: The EU's European Regional Development Fund and a German shipowners' group have invested €1,860,616.54 in the e-healthy ship project, aiming to improve health management on ships without doctors on board. The project, funded by the Hamburg Authority for Health and Consumer Protection, utilizes modern communications technology to help the ship's master treat an emergency. This initiative seeks to enhance the health and well-being of seafarers, potentially saving lives and reducing healthcare costs.

site_title: Beyond the buzz for better business
summary: Emerging trends such as blockchain, AI, and sustainability are driving innovation in business, potentially delivering significant value beyond the bottom line. These innovations can lead to inclusive prosperity, strengthen developing markets, and address global challenges like corruption and climate change. A growing body of evidence supports the benefits of long-term value creation, with McKinsey and the Global Innovation Index reporting higher revenues and earnings growth for businesses prioritizing sustainability and social responsibility. Leaders have the opportunity to create value for both business and society, and the world's growing economies, particularly in Asia, are poised to benefit from these emerging trends.

site_title: Trump's Mexico trade deal looks like a lemon
summary: The US and Mexico have reached a trade deal on automotive imports, which could extend to Canada. The agreement includes lifting rules-of-origin requirements to 75% and a wage rule requiring 40-45% of content to come from factories paying more than $16 an hour. However, upon closer inspection, the impact is expected to be limited, with only three models made in Mexico that would attract tariffs under the new regime. The rules are likely to affect only a small percentage of Mexican-made cars sold in the US, and Mexico's domestic industry is unlikely to be significantly impacted.

site_title: Blow for Macron as star minister quits
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron suffered a major blow as environment minister Nicolas Hulot resigned live on radio, citing feeling "all alone" on environmental issues within the government. Hulot, a popular TV celebrity and environmental campaigner, announced his departure without informing Macron or Prime Minister Edouard Philippe beforehand. The resignation adds to Macron's mounting problems, including economic growth and EU reform challenges, and is likely to be received bitterly by the president.

site_title: Cars, houses, heroes: N Koreans win hearts at Asian Games
summary: North Korean athletes at the Asian Games are winning hearts with their unprecedented charm offensive, going off-piste to talk about their nerves, fears, and emotions. The team's attitude has been a stark contrast to previous competitions, where they would only thank leader Kim Jong-un before leaving. Athletes have mingled freely with spectators and reporters, sharing personal stories and thanking their South Korean counterparts for support. The thawing of global diplomatic relations appears to have encouraged this new open attitude, with rewards including new cars and houses for the medal-winning athletes.

site_title: Understanding comprehensive income, comprehensively
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Comprehensive income, introduced in 2012, aims to provide a more complete picture of a company's financial performance by including items not previously disclosed in the income statement. It consists of net income and "other comprehensive income" (OCI), which includes unrealised gains and losses on hedged instruments, foreign currency transactions, and pension plans. However, investors and stakeholders often struggle to understand the concept, with some considering it more confusing than informative. The introduction of comprehensive income has changed the nature of financial statements, but its effectiveness in providing a clearer picture of a company's performance is debated.

site_title: Wing Tai Holdings posts S$129.8m earnings for Q4
summary: Wing Tai Holdings, a Singaporean property and retail group, reported a net profit of S$129.8 million for Q4 2018, a 258% increase from the previous year. Revenue rose 80% to S$105.8 million, driven by higher contributions from development properties. For FY18, the group's bottomline soared to S$218.8 million, boosted by profits from associates and joint venture companies. Wing Tai expects the Singapore private residential property market to be subdued due to new cooling measures, and will focus on "yield-based investment" in countries like Japan.

site_title: Business efforts to help enhance ASEAN economic integration
summary: The ASEAN Business Advisory Council (ASEAN-BAC) provides private sector feedback to the ASEAN grouping's leaders, aiming to drive vision and action on economic integration. Established in 2003, the council shares business insights and discusses key trends impacting businesses in ASEAN through various activities, including the ASEAN Outlook Conference and Digitise ASEAN Conference. ASEAN-BAC also organizes the ASEAN Business and Investment Summit, which brings together policymakers and business leaders to discuss current issues. The council rolls out legacy projects, such as "SGConnect," to enhance ASEAN economic integration and promote business expansion into the region.

site_title: Singapore, African firms seal deals, eye new markets at business forum
summary: Singapore and African firms have sealed several business deals at the Africa Singapore Business Forum, with companies looking to tap into the continent's emerging market potential. A Singapore company, Well & Able Holdings, has signed a contract with a Senegalese firm to design and build a logistics hub, while another deal was inked with a Kenyan firm to work together on security and other services. The agreements aim to facilitate access to new markets and create employment opportunities in Africa, with experts noting the need for local partners to navigate the challenges of emerging markets.

site_title: US dollar pinned near 1-month low
summary: The US dollar fell to a near one-month low against a basket of its rivals, reaching 94.602 in London trading. The decline was attributed to a US-Mexico trade deal aimed at overhauling the North American Free Trade Agreement, which boosted appetite for riskier assets. The Chinese central bank strengthened the yuan against the dollar, and trade tensions may be receding. The euro edged 0.2% higher to US$1.1696, while sterling hit its weakest level in 2018 due to Brexit concerns.

site_title: Singapore a bridge to South-east Asia for Fung Group
summary: Fung Group, a major player in retail, trade, and logistics, has opened its 21,550 sq ft regional headquarters in Singapore, marking a critical base for expansion in South-east Asia and South Asia. The conglomerate sees strong potential for growth in the region, driven by affluent markets and predicted economic growth. Singapore's strategic location and connectivity make it an ideal hub for the group's operations, which include Li & Fung, Global Brands Group, and others, with plans to develop another built-to-suit facility to support future growth.

site_title: Positioning ASEAN for further economic growth
summary: Singapore aims to deepen ASEAN economic integration and promote growth through its 2018 chairmanship, focusing on five key areas: innovation and e-commerce, trade facilitation, services and investment integration, cultivating a conducive regulatory environment, and progressing ASEAN's external relations. The efforts include promoting digital connectivity, simplifying trade procedures, and deepening services and investment integration to boost intra-ASEAN trade and attract external partners, ultimately positioning ASEAN as a major economic force in Asia and a key driver of global growth.

site_title: China: Is Belt and Road a trap?
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative, a massive development strategy, has sparked concerns about its impact on participating countries. Since 2013, China has invested over $60 billion in countries along the Belt and Road, with more than 100 countries and organizations signing cooperation agreements. However, some countries, such as Sri Lanka, are struggling with massive debt and risk being "trapped" in debt. China's recent examples of "early harvest" projects, such as the railway tunnel in Uzbekistan and the railway line in Kenya, have raised questions about the initiative's long-term viability. China needs to reassess the viability of its projects to avoid a "debt trap" and ensure that recipient countries can pay back loans.

site_title: ASEAN SMEs yield big business for PayPal
summary: PayPal has identified South-east Asia as a key region for growth, focusing on small, medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and freelance workers. The payments firm has seen significant revenue from these groups, with South-east Asia being one of its fastest-growing regions. PayPal's regional managing director, Rahul Shinghal, notes that the region's youthful demographics and increasing online consumption will drive e-commerce and the gig economy, making freelancers a key driver of growth. The company is working to promote digital payments and support SMEs and freelancers in the region through initiatives and programs.

site_title: New fund, innovation centre to take Chongqing-Singapore cooperation to new levels
summary: Singapore and Chongqing have signed 11 Memoranda of Understanding to boost cooperation under the China-Singapore Connectivity Initiative. A new fund, the China-Singapore ICM Joint Innovation Development Fund, will support collaborations in areas like artificial intelligence, blockchain, and virtual reality. The fund will also help Singaporean ICM firms break into Chongqing and develop smart districts. Other collaborations include setting up an innovation centre for ICM small and medium-sized enterprises and sharing expertise in healthcare. The initiative aims to create an open platform for development and reduce costs.

site_title: AXA launches suite of services for high net worth clients
summary: AXA Insurance has launched the AXA Imperial Collection, a suite of legacy, wealth, lifestyle, and global medical solutions for high net worth (HNW) individuals. The offering includes variable universal life (VUL) products, insurance for lifestyle assets such as art and yachts, and concierge services. AXA aims to fill the gap in the HNW market, where insurance penetration is estimated at 3-5%, and targets a 20% share of the universal life market by 2020. The suite of services is designed to provide a full range of solutions for a diverse range of HNWIs.

site_title: Nestle seals US$7b deal to market Starbucks coffee globally
summary: Nestle has sealed a $7.15 billion deal to market Starbucks coffee globally outside of its cafes. The Swiss food giant will pay for the rights to market Starbucks coffee globally, significantly boosting Nestle's portfolio in North America. The deal also involves the transfer of around 500 Starbucks employees to Nestle. This marks a major boost for both companies, with Nestle CEO Mark Schneider citing the deal as a key priority in his growth strategy, particularly in the US. The deal is expected to amplify the Starbucks brand worldwide while delivering long-term value for shareholders.

site_title: CW Group explains delay in giving details on 69m-euro payment for German firm
