Bids are expected, with estimates ranging from six to eight offers, at a price tag likely reflecting market conditions. The winning bidder could offer between S$800 and S$830 per sq ft per plot ratio, according to experts.

site_title: Building a landmark business
summary: Singapore's Expand Construction, a construction group, rose from a family signage business in 1998 to become a viable business after the financial crisis. Founder Von Lee Yong Miang quit his job to revive the business, which eventually led to the creation of Expand Construction in 2000. The company's success factors include effective leadership, a family-centric culture, and a focus on human capital. Expand Construction has attracted top talents and is open to joint ventures to handle infrastructure projects. The company prioritizes being "asset-lite" and generating passive income to sustain itself during economic downturns.

images.alt_text: Founder and chairman Von Lee Yong Miang, of Expand Construction, snagged the third prize at the E50 awards last year.
(Above) The Supertree Grove at Gardens by the Bay and the Marina Bay Promenade, two significant milestones for Expand Construction.
The Supertree Grove at Gardens by the Bay and (above) The Marina Bay Promenade, two significant milestones for Expand Construction.

site_title: Bank of Singapore hires Rajeev De Mello as chief investment officer
summary: Bank of Singapore has appointed Rajeev De Mello as its chief investment officer, pending regulatory approval. De Mello, a Swiss national with 30 years of experience in global financial markets, will oversee research and investment strategy teams producing views across all financial asset classes. He will also chair the investment committee and manage discretionary portfolio services for clients. This appointment comes as the bank is growing, with assets under management at $102 billion, 14% higher than in the same period last year.

site_title: Noble shareholders back crucial rescue plan but challenges still abound
summary: Noble Group, a struggling commodity trader, has received overwhelming support from shareholders for its US$3.5 billion debt restructuring plan, with 99.96% of present shareholders voting in favor. The plan, which would transform the company into an asset-light, Asian-centric business model, is expected to be approved, offering a "clean start" for the new entity, New Noble. The plan's success is seen as a relief, but challenges still lie ahead, including securing competitive trade finance facilities and navigating potential legal risks.

images.alt_text: Noble's market value has dwindled from some US$6 billion in February 2015 to US$150 million at its last traded price before it was halted on Monday pending the outcome of the meetings.

site_title: New green building to help SMU students with hands-on learning and connect better
summary: Singapore Management University (SMU) is building a new, environmentally-friendly green building called the Tahir Foundation Connexion along Stamford Road. The S$70 million development, set to be completed by 2019, will feature a makerspace, classrooms, student lounges, and incubation spaces for start-ups, accommodating up to 80 start-ups per year. The building, designed to meet Green Mark Platinum certification, is the first on-site net-zero energy building in the city centre, and will support SMU's SMU-X programme, which enables students to tackle real-world challenges through hands-on learning and networking.

site_title: Singapore firms ranked 2nd in Asean for transparency on anti-corruption policy
summary: Singapore firms ranked 2nd in Asean for transparency on anti-corruption policy, scoring 55% overall, up from 47% in 2016. The country improved in public commitments and confidential reporting channels, but lagged in applying codes of conduct to directors and employees, and disclosing political contributions. Thailand topped the list with a 67% disclosure level, while the region's lowest scores were found in applying anti-corruption policies to third parties and suppliers. Experts called for urgent action to address these gaps and promote business integrity.

site_title: CIMB is first Asean bank to join UN's initiative for responsible banking
summary: CIMB Group Holdings has become the first Asean bank to join the United Nations' Environment Programme Finance Initiative Principles for Responsible Banking (UNEP-FI), making it a founding member of the sustainable initiative. This move aims to redefine the global banking industry's role in shaping a more sustainable future. CIMB's membership is part of the core UNEP-FI group, which consists of 27 member banks.

images.alt_text: Zafrul Aziz, group chief executive officer of CIMB Group, said the company is "fully committed" to achieving UNEP-FI's objectives to help transform global banking practices.

site_title: Finance elite among privileged circle at closed Riksbank events
summary: Sweden's Riksbank Governor Stefan Ingves is set to meet with investors and bankers in London, sharing his views on the economy, two days after the country's Sept 9 election. The event, at the Official Monetary and Financial Institutions Forum and Goldman Sachs Group Inc, is billed as private, but the Riksbank claims it was always planned as an open event. This private meeting highlights the bank's close ties with the financial community, despite its reputation as a transparent monetary institution.

site_title: Nanyang Business School to be housed in Asia's biggest wooden building
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) has unveiled a five-year plan to build Asia's largest wooden building, the Nanyang Business School, valued at S$180 million, on its campus. The six-storey, 40,000-gross-square-meter building will be completed in 2021 and will be the greenest university campus in the world, with a focus on sustainable construction and reducing energy, water, and waste intensity. The university also plans to hire hundreds of staff, double its solar energy, and invest in new schemes to attract talent and support PhD scholarships and undergraduate internships.

images.alt_text: University president Subra Suresh also said NTU will fill hundreds of positions to fuel its growth as a leading global research university.

site_title: Mahathir bans foreigners from buying Forest City project
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has banned foreigners from buying property at the $100 billion Forest City project, citing that it was built for foreigners, not Malaysians. The ban applies to buyers from China, Indonesia, Thailand, and Dubai, and also prohibits foreigners from being granted visas to live there. This move comes as Mahathir has taken a firm stance against foreign investments that he says don't benefit Malaysians, following a series of diplomatic incidents with China.

site_title: HR should view 'talent' in all its dimensions
summary: Singapore's economy is shifting from industrialisation to innovation, requiring a mix of entrepreneurial talent alongside professional and managerial skills. Traditional organisations can identify and nurture intrapreneurs, corporate innovators who behave like entrepreneurs within the company. Research found that intrapreneurial motivation can be measured distinctly from entrepreneurial, professional, and leadership career motivations. Organisations should define the space for "talent" in all three dimensions of EPL excellence and invest in identifying and developing employees with diverse skill sets.

site_title: Russia calls Britain's air force interceptions over Black Sea dangerous
summary: Russia has accused Britain's Royal Air Force (RAF) of intercepting its military aircraft over the Black Sea in a provocative manner, amid rising tensions between the two countries. The RAF made two intercepts in a single week, with Russia claiming it was designed to provoke Moscow. Russia's embassy in London stated that the intercepts were "dangerous" and "not strengthening anyone's security." The incident comes as relations between London and Moscow remain strained, following the poisoning of former Russian double agent Sergei Skripal in March.

site_title: Australia's far right should get the message: it's not all right, mate
summary: Australia's far-right movement has gained momentum, with politicians like Fraser Anning demanding a return to the White Australia policy and criticizing large-scale immigration. This sentiment is echoed in media outlets, with some claiming a "tidal wave" of migrants is changing Australia's culture. However, the country's preferential and compulsory voting systems, as well as its well-organized labor movement and social safety nets, have limited the far-right's influence. If left unchecked, these undercurrents could harm Australia's reputation as a destination for investments and visitors.

site_title: Seoul unveils proposed changes to chaebol conglomerate rules
summary: South Korea's anti-trust watchdog has proposed new rules to limit the power of family-run conglomerates, known as chaebols, to prioritize minority shareholders' interests. The proposed changes would require a holding company to own at least 30% in a listed subsidiary and 50% in an unlisted unit before making changes, such as mergers or spin-offs. The steps aim to reform chaebols, which account for over 50% of the country's market value, in line with President Moon Jae-in's campaign promises.

site_title: Building a united and shared vision beyond the bottom line
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can build a united and shared vision beyond the bottom line by prioritizing culture and values. SMEs must cultivate core values such as meritocracy and transparency, nurture staff's capacity to care about the firm, and establish avenues for initiative and creativity. A culture that encourages idea generation, innovation, and trust can help SMEs attract and retain top talent, drive growth, and ensure long-term survival. By prioritizing culture, SMEs can develop a distinctive identity that resonates with staff and sets them apart from competitors.

site_title: China's industrial profit growth cools for 3rd straight month
summary: China's industrial profit growth cooled for a third consecutive month in July, driven by weakening consumption, rising credit defaults, high financing costs, and escalating Sino-US trade tensions. Analysts at Nomura predict further pressure on China Inc's profit growth in coming months. This slowdown in industrial profit growth is a further indication that China's economy is cooling, raising concerns for policymakers.

site_title: 3.6t rupees of India loans under scrutiny on bankruptcy deadline
summary: India's central bank has set a 180-day deadline for banks to restructure an estimated 3.6 trillion rupees (S$70.1 billion) of stressed loans, potentially pushing dozens of companies into bankruptcy. The deadline, introduced in February, follows the nation's worst bad-loan ratios, with the central bank predicting an increase to 12.2% by March 2019. Over 70 large companies risk being taken to bankruptcy court, with power companies and non-power firms impacted, and some deals expected in the power sector soon.

site_title: Dollar steady after Powell says Fed may raise rates
summary: The US dollar steadied on Monday after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments on raising interest rates despite President Trump's criticism. The dollar's safe-haven appeal was reduced, and risk sentiment improved as US and Mexican trade negotiators appeared close to reaching a common position on NAFTA. The euro and Chinese yuan also strengthened, with the yuan reaching its strongest level since August 8. Market expectations for rate hikes in September and December remained unchanged, and Powell's comments were seen as a gradual approach rather than a shift towards an "auto-pilot mode".

site_title: Technology harnessed for solutions to caring for seniors
summary: A Singaporean competition, LeapForGood, awarded grants to five teams that designed technology-based solutions to address the needs of seniors and their caregivers. The teams, out of 11 finalists, developed innovative solutions such as motorized attachments, digital ecosystems, and IoT-enabled health monitoring systems. The competition aims to tackle the growing healthcare and daily-living needs of Singapore's aging population, with one in four citizens expected to be 65 and above by 2030. The winning teams will use the grants to kick-start their social enterprises, providing practical and targeted solutions to improve seniors' and caregivers' quality of life.

images.alt_text: The prototype of a chair which uses Internet of Things (IoT) technology and analytics to provide the caregiver with information on the patient.
Above: The chief executive of raiSE Alfie Othman (extreme left) presenting the award to Team Xiohoo's Allan Tay, Adrian Teo and Jean Tan.

site_title: Trump's full-spectrum corruption: there's more to come
summary: The article highlights the full-spectrum corruption of US President Donald Trump, a phenomenon that has fundamentally changed the Republican Party's attitude toward ethics and political leadership. Trump's character defects, including pathological lying, cruelty, and conspiracy-mongering, have been evident in his private and public life, and have led to widespread complicity among Republicans. The party's attachment to him has come at a great cost, including rank hypocrisy, damage to the white Evangelical movement, and a potential electoral price in November. The author warns that the worst is yet to come, as deeper layers of Trump's corruption will be uncovered, leading to further erratic and disordered behavior.

site_title: US blocks WTO judge reappointment as dispute settlement crisis looms
summary: The US has announced it will block the reappointment of a World Trade Organization (WTO) appeals judge, Shree Baboo Chekitan Servansing, due to expire on September 30, leaving only three judges. This move has raised concerns about a potential crisis in the WTO's dispute settlement system, which has been plagued by delays and disputes. The US has previously blocked all appointments to the appeals chamber, citing concerns about the judges' decisions, and the veto could paralyze the system, ending 23 years of WTO enforcement at a time of heightened global trade tensions.

site_title: Big Oil's exit helps revival of Norway's ageing North Sea fields
summary: Big Oil's exit from Norway's ageing North Sea fields is reviving production, with smaller, local companies taking over assets like Draugen and Valhall. The recovery in oil prices is helping, but the shift also shows how new companies are investing billions in projects discarded by the majors. According to Rystad Energy, oil and gas fields with new operators since 2010 have seen higher reserve growth compared to the average in Norway. This trend is expected to continue, with spending in Norway's oil industry set to rise this year and next, driven by new entrants like OKEA AS and Var Energi AS.

images.alt_text: Spending in Norway's oil industry is expected to rise this year for the first time since 2014, and will get a further boost next year, according to the latest figures from the country's statistics office.

site_title: SGX, Third500 to build emerging-growth pre-IPO, IPO market
summary: Singapore-based affiliate Third500 is partnering the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to build a pre-IPO and IPO market for emerging growth companies. The move aims to create a pipeline of companies that could eventually list on the SGX. Third500 focuses on companies with US$60 million in private investments, and Singapore was chosen for its trusted regulatory system and Asian commercial market access. The SGX and Third500 plan to explore a Singapore Financing Pathway with 5,700 emerging growth companies, which have attracted US$350 billion in investment.

site_title: China's soybean, soymeal futures fall on African swine fever worries
summary: China's soybean and soymeal futures plummeted on Monday, falling 1.8% and 2.8% respectively, amid concerns over African swine fever outbreaks and forecasts of a record US crop. High inventories and the impact of a depreciating currency also weighed on the market. The African swine fever, which has culled over 25,000 pigs, may further reduce demand for feed, exacerbating the downward trend.

site_title: Startup Travelstop lands US$1.2m in seed funding, will use funds to drive growth
summary: Singapore-based startup Travelstop has secured US$1.2 million in seed funding led by SeedPlus and a US-based travel-focused venture capital firm. The funds will be used to drive growth, product development, and hiring in Singapore. Travelstop aims to simplify business travel in Asia by automating booking and expense reporting. The Asia-Pacific region is the largest business travel market, expected to grow at 10.4% annually. The startup plans to focus on priority markets in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, Hong Kong, and Taiwan, with a goal of providing a modern business travel platform for young millennials and business travelers.

site_title: Lum Chang JV to sell part of stake in UK freehold land
summary: Lum Chang Holdings' joint venture company Kelaty Propco has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to sell a portion of its interest in a UK freehold site for £28.14m. The sale pertains to the student accommodation component, with Lum Chang retaining interest in the serviced residence component. The deal will provide a significant portion of the company's investment in the land, with proceeds to partly fund future investments.

site_title: New moves linking Singapore firms to China, Asean
summary: Singapore has launched initiatives to increase collaboration with China and ASEAN firms, including a platform connecting corporates with technology startups and a private-sector committee to tap infrastructure opportunities. The two-day FutureChina Global Forum and Singapore Regional Business Forum combined the flagship events of Business China and the Singapore Business Federation, marking a significant step in enhancing bilateral ties. These moves aim to boost economic cooperation and help Singaporean firms tap into China's vast market and infrastructure opportunities.

site_title: Asian markets buoyed by Fed reassurance
summary: Asian markets ended Monday on a high note, driven by the Federal Reserve's reassurance that the US economy is strong and inflation is near the 2-per cent objective. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole symposium, in which he advocated for gradual rate hikes, boosted confidence. Trade war fears also eased as US and Mexican negotiators reached a common position on the North American Free Trade Agreement. Asian markets rose, with China's Shanghai Composite Index ending 2.2 per cent higher and Singapore's Straits Times Index up 0.39 per cent.

site_title: China Taiping to boost Singapore-China business links
summary: China Taiping Insurance Group (CTIG) announced a partnership with Enterprise Singapore to promote regional infrastructure projects under the Belt and Road Initiative. The insurer plans to designate its Singapore office as the regional headquarters and will work together on fintech and innovation opportunities. CTIG signed memorandums of understanding with Enterprise Singapore, the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and Raffles Medical Group. The partnership aims to drive CTIG's growth in the region, leveraging Singapore's stable economy and favorable business environment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.01 points to 1,811.60 on Monday, driven by gains in the market. Volume reached 2.754 billion lots worth RM2.021 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 572 to 376.

site_title: Pacific Star Development posts S$8.43m profit for 18 months ended June 30
summary: Pacific Star Development reported a net profit of S$8.43 million for the 18 months ended June 30, 2018, with revenue reaching S$121.43 million. The company attributed revenue growth to its Puteri Cove Residences & Quayside project in Puteri Harbour, Malaysia. Total expenses increased due to higher staff and marketing costs. The company's shares ended trading at S$0.15, down 20.2% from the previous close.

site_title: New spins on classic ingredients
summary: Tee Yih Jia, a Singapore-based food manufacturing company, has expanded its product line and adopted automation to stay competitive. Since its founding in 1969, the company has evolved from a small semi-mechanised factory producing popiah skins to a global player producing a wide range of foodstuffs. Tee Yih Jia has received several awards for its innovation and productivity, including the National Productivity Award in 1986 and Enterprise 50 Awards from 1995 to 2000. The company's future plans include moving to a larger facility, introducing new products, and exploring new markets, such as China and the US. Tee Yih Jia aims to differentiate itself from competitors by selling ideas and applications, rather than just products.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Guocoland has hired Lim Yoke Tuan as its new CFO, replacing Lai Tak Loi who left to pursue other opportunities. Rex International has confirmed sustainable commercial flow from an oil discovery off Norway, with a test well producing 7,000 barrels of oil. Landing International Development's shares slid 8% after its chairman Yang Zhihui went missing, with the company citing normal operations and finances.

site_title: Crazy Rich Asians: Scoring big-time for brand Singapore
summary: The Hollywood film "Crazy Rich Asians" is boosting Singapore's international profile, particularly in terms of tourism, trade, and talent. The movie showcases the country's attractions, such as Marina Bay and the Newton Hawker Centre, and its modern infrastructure. However, the film stops short of reflecting Singapore's unique multiculturalism, which is a key aspect of its country brand. Despite this, the movie is expected to inspire curiosity and interest in Singapore among viewers, leading to increased tourism and trade opportunities. The film's portrayal of Singapore's diversity and inclusiveness is also seen as a positive representation of the country's societal milieu.

site_title: Why every big firm needs a foreign minister
summary: Microsoft's claim of thwarting Russian cyber attacks and data hacking against US political organisations and Senate offices highlights the growing potential for businesses to become intertwined with foreign relations. This incident is part of a trend of firms caught in political controversy, including telecommunications companies during the Egyptian revolution and Google's diplomatic row with Israel over its "Palestine" homepage change. As globalisation and new technology grow, firms are increasingly under the political spotlight, with some recognising the need for strategic corporate foreign policy to mitigate risks and seize opportunities.

site_title: New framework to professionalise career practitioners industry
summary: The Workforce Singapore (WSG) Career Development Framework (CDF) was launched to professionalise the career practitioners industry in Singapore. The framework establishes a roadmap for the development and certification of competencies for career practitioners, aiming to provide jobseekers with assurance of high professional standards and ethics. Four programmes will be rolled out over the next two years, with the first window for application opening on October 1. The framework aims to enhance the role of career practitioners in helping individuals navigate career crossroads and make informed career decisions.

site_title: Chinese bitcoin mining rig makers 'seeking billions from HK IPOs'
summary: Three Chinese bitcoin mining equipment makers, Bitmain, Canaan, and Ebang, plan to raise billions of dollars through initial public offerings (IPOs) in Hong Kong, despite a decline in bitcoin's price and regulatory scrutiny. The companies, which design high-end computer chips for mining cryptocurrencies, are seeking to diversify their business and explore non-bitcoin applications, such as blockchain, artificial intelligence, and 5G telecoms networks. However, concerns about the companies' profitability and the potential for a decline in demand for their chips due to the bitcoin price slump have raised questions about the success of their IPOs.

site_title: Lehman 10 years on: Let's draw the right lessons from it
summary: The 10th anniversary of Lehman Brothers' bankruptcy raises questions about whether the event could have been prevented. Economist Laurence Ball argues that the Federal Reserve could have rescued Lehman with emergency loans, but former Treasury Secretary Hank Paulson and others claim that doing so would have been too expensive and that Lehman was too far gone. Ball's analysis has been criticized for being overly harsh, and experts disagree on whether rescuing Lehman would have mitigated the financial crisis. The key takeaway is that policymakers must draw the right lessons from the disaster to avoid future economic chaos.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada by President Trump. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen green and transition finance cooperation.

site_title: New academy to help hospital workers tackle future redundancy
summary: The NTUC and HSEU have established a Healthcare Academy to prepare Singapore's hospital workers for the shift towards digitized medical records and automated services. The 600 public healthcare workers managing paperwork and 4,000 patient service associates who handle registration and payments may face redundancy. The academy aims to equip workers with new skills to remain employable in the changing healthcare landscape.

site_title: Bulls regrouping for China's sovereign debt
summary: China's sovereign debt has become more attractive due to a recent selloff in government bonds, making them a good buy as the central bank is expected to inject more liquidity into the financial system. The benchmark 10-year yield rose to a two-month high in August, but halted its two-week rising streak last week. Analysts predict the yield could drop to as low as 3.4% as the US-China trade war escalates and the central bank takes proactive measures to boost the economy. Chinese bonds have bucked forecasts to advance for most of this year, becoming the best performing sovereign notes in Asia.

site_title: Floods in Kerala may hit wedding season gold demand
summary: Heavy rains and floods in Kerala, India, have caused over $3 billion in damage, with the state's gold-buying market expected to see a 50% drop in sales during the peak festival and wedding season. The floods have affected 60-70% of jewelry manufacturing, with many factories flooded and workers unable to work. Demand for gold is expected to remain dull for at least two weeks, with people prioritizing rebuilding their homes over jewelry purchases.

site_title: US will 'vigorously defend' against Iran court challenge: Pompeo
summary: The US will "vigorously defend" itself in the International Court of Justice against Iran's challenge to the reimposition of US sanctions, according to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Iran is set to make opening arguments in The Hague this week against the unilateral sanctions, which were slapped back on three weeks ago following the US withdrawal from a 2015 nuclear accord with Tehran.

images.alt_text: The United States will "vigorously defend" itself in the International Court of Justice against Iran's challenge to the reimposition of US sanctions, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said Monday.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on optimism around Nafta progress
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by optimism around a potential trade deal between the US and Mexico, which led to record highs on the S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 92.36 points, or 0.36%, to 25,882.71. Investors are hopeful that a trade agreement will boost economic growth and alleviate uncertainty, contributing to the record-breaking opening for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Shangri-La Asia Ltd reported solid H1 2018 results, with a 147.8% increase in profit after tax to US$152.9 million. Revenue rose 18.8% to US$1.2 billion, and Ebitda increased 22.2% to US$301.5 million. Analysts believe the share price weakness may have been overblown, as the company's results suggest a stronger-than-expected performance. Shangri-La is seen as a proxy to a multi-year recovery in the mainland Chinese luxury hotel industry.

site_title: Rex flags production upside off Norway
summary: Rex International, an oil and gas company, is seeing production upside from a discovery off Norway. A test well drilled in the Rolvsnes oil discovery produced up to 7,000 barrels of oil during a production test. The well is 30% owned by Rex's subsidiary Lime Petroleum, which will be tied back to the Edvard Grieg platform for production. The company's CEO and executive chairman expressed confidence in the discovery's commercialization and potential value increase.

site_title: DBS or UOB, why not both?
summary: DBS Group Holdings has seen its share price rise, surpassing its rival UOB's stock price, which had been lagging for five years. The bank's annual dividend was raised to S$1.20 per share from 2017, a 50% increase. This move came after DBS upped its dividend early this year, closing the gap between the two banks' dividend payouts. The share price difference had narrowed to S$2 at the beginning of 2018, down from over S$5 five years prior.

site_title: Advent to invest US$485m in Walmart operations in Brazil
summary: Advent International, a private equity firm, has agreed to invest US$485 million in Walmart's operations in Brazil. As part of the deal, Advent will invest 1.9 billion reais (S$632 million) in the existing stores, converting unprofitable hypermarkets into cash-and-carry wholesale stores. The investment will be made in three installments, with the first two capital raises totaling 750 million reais each, and the remaining amount invested by 2021. This move is part of Walmart's plan to partially exit its underperforming Brazilian business.

site_title: Hair-raising! Japan bullet train staff made to sit by tracks
summary: JR West, a Japanese rail company, has defended a safety exercise that requires employees to sit beside tracks in tunnels as bullet trains speed by at 300km/h. The training, introduced in 2016 after an accident, aims to teach staff the importance of their jobs. However, some employees have complained about the exercise, describing it as a "horrible experience" and "just like a public flogging." The company has stated that the training will continue, but with a focus on safety.

site_title: Saudi-Iran oil war can break up Opec
summary: A brewing oil price war between Saudi Arabia and Iran could destabilize OPEC, potentially breaking it up. The conflict began when Saudi Arabia cut its oil prices to undercut Iran's sales, with Iran responding by cutting prices to its clients. Slowing demand growth in Asia, coupled with economic sanctions on Iran, has further exacerbated the situation. Analysts predict that a price war could lead to OPEC's internal fractures, with Saudi Arabia and Iran unlikely to back down, even if it means cutting prices to record lows.

images.alt_text: Iran has already voiced its strong opposition to the reallocation of individual member quotas suggested by Saudi Oil Minister Khalid al-Falih.

site_title: Datapulse names new chairman
summary: Datapulse Technology's board of directors appointed Aw Cheok Huat as the new chairman, effective August 27, 2018. The move comes after a heated extraordinary general meeting in April, where existing board members successfully blocked the appointment of proposed new directors, including Ng Bie Tjin, the daughter of the company's co-founder and former finance director. The board expressed appreciation for the service of outgoing chairman Low Beng Tin.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won strengthen after Powell comments
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index and currency won rose on Monday following Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments on interest rate hikes, which boosted Wall Street to record highs. The KOSPI index gained 6.09 points, or 0.27%, to 2,299.30, while the won strengthened to 1,113.8 per dollar, up 0.46% from its previous close. However, South Korean firms with exposure to North Korea closed down due to U.S. President Donald Trump's cancellation of Mike Pompeo's trip.

site_title: Australia's Victoria state in A$2.86b land title register deal
summary: Victoria state in Australia has agreed to sell a 40-year concession to run its land and property registries to pension fund First State Super for A$2.86 billion. The deal will allow First State Super to levy fees for property ownership registrations in the state, while the government will use the proceeds for infrastructure projects, including schools, hospitals, and transport. The state will maintain control over essential services, and pricing for statutory services will be controlled, with non-statutory service price increases capped at inflation.

site_title: ISOTeam sinks into the red with Q4 loss of S$1.99m
summary: ISOTeam, a Singapore construction company, reported a fourth-quarter net loss of S$1.99 million, down from a net profit of S$1.38 million a year earlier. Revenue fell 6.8% to S$20.2 million, mainly due to lower contributions from certain business segments. The company has a strong order book of S$126.3 million, which will be delivered over the next two years. A final dividend of 0.18 Singapore cent per share has been proposed, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% up on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% to 3,225.62 on Monday, driven by gains from local banks DBS, OCBC Bank, and UOB. A total of 1.15 billion shares worth S$764.3 million changed hands, with Nico Steel being the most actively traded counter. The rally follows a 5-day streak and comes ahead of GDP data, with investors seemingly unaffected by US trade tensions.

site_title: US and Mexico agree to preliminary Nafta deal
summary: The US and Mexico have reached a preliminary agreement to revise key portions of the 24-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), with a deal expected to be announced on Monday. The agreement focuses on rules governing the automobile industry, resolving a major source of friction. However, Canada remains excluded from talks and a revised Nafta would require congressional approval, including votes by Republican lawmakers. A two-country deal between the US and Canada appears unlikely, with opposition from Mexico, lawmakers, and industries relying on all three countries.

images.alt_text: On Monday morning, Mr Trump tweeted, "A big deal looking good with Mexico!"

site_title: Riverfront Residences sales volume lower than previously announced: KSH Holdings
summary: KSH Holdings, a 35% stakeholder in Riverfront Residences, has corrected its filing on the Singapore Exchange, stating that the project has sold "more than 45% of its 1,472 homes" - approximately 662 units, rather than the previously announced 52%. The correction comes after a panic-buying frenzy in July 2018, when 628 apartments were sold amid surprise cooling measures for the property market. No explanation has been provided for the change.

site_title: Apple to embrace iphone x design with new colors, bigger screens
summary: Apple plans to launch three new iPhones that retain the edge-to-edge screen design of the iPhone X, but with varying prices and features. The new phones, set to be unveiled in September, include a high-end iPhone with a 6.5-inch OLED screen, an upgraded iPhone X with a 5.8-inch OLED screen, and a cheaper LCD model. The devices will feature gesture-based control, Face ID, and dual-SIM card slots in some regions. Apple aims to increase average prices and expand the total number of active devices to support sales of accessories and digital services.

site_title: CapitaLand sells 70% interest in Westgate to CMT for S$789.6m
summary: CapitaLand has agreed to sell a 70% stake in Westgate to CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) for S$789.6 million, valuing the property at S$1.128 billion per square foot. The sale will generate S$397.6 million in cash for CapitaLand and net a gain of S$99.2 million. CMT will increase its stake in Westgate to 100% after the transaction, which is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018. The sale enhances CapitaLand's financial flexibility and aligns with its capital recycling goal of S$3 billion in 2018.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Noble Group won shareholder approval for a debt-for-equity rescue plan, overcoming a do-or-die deadline. Singapore saw a 7.3% increase in visitors in the first quarter, with 4.6 million arrivals. The government launched initiatives to help firms access innovation networks and infrastructure opportunities. Malaysia barred foreigners from buying flats in the Forest City project, citing it was built for foreigners. Singapore's service industries reported a 7.8% year-on-year rise in Q2 takings, while the Straits Times Index rose 0.4% on Monday.

site_title: China may scrap two-child limit: report
summary: China may scrap its two-child policy, according to a state-run newspaper citing a draft civil code that would overhaul decades of family-planning rules. The policy, enforced through fines, has been notorious for cases of forced abortions and sterilization. The draft code omits any reference to "family planning," effectively ending the policy that limits couples to having no more than two children. This change would mark a significant shift in China's approach to population control.

site_title: LaSalle Hotel is reconsidering its planned takeover by Blackstone
summary: LaSalle Hotel Properties, a luxury-hotel owner, is reconsidering its planned takeover by Blackstone Group LP after Pebblebrook Hotel Trust submitted a new bid. LaSalle's board unanimously determined that Pebblebrook's proposal may be superior to the Blackstone deal, which was agreed upon in June for $33.50 a share. LaSalle can now engage in discussions with Pebblebrook under the terms of its Blackstone merger agreement. If a deal is reached with Pebblebrook, LaSalle investors could receive 0.92 common shares and $37.80 in cash per share, potentially surpassing the Blackstone offer.

site_title: New initiatives to help Singapore firms access innovation network, infrastructure opportunities across Asean, China
summary: Singapore Business Federation launches initiatives to connect corporates with technology startups and infrastructure opportunities across Asean and China. The Singapore-China Open Innovation Platform promotes collaboration among government agencies, corporates, and startups, while the SBF Infrastructure Committee focuses on projects in four sectors across Asean and South Asia. The FutureChina Global Forum also signed memoranda of understanding to provide internship opportunities for Singaporeans in China, highlighting the potential of Asean-China cooperation in areas like the Master Plan on Asean Connectivity 2025 and the Asean Smart Cities Network.

site_title: The star businessman who ignores his investors to make them rich
summary: Akira Matsumoto, a 71-year-old Japanese businessman, prioritizes customers, employees, and the community over shareholders, citing a philosophy similar to Johnson & Johnson's credo. Despite this, his company, Calbee, has seen significant growth under his leadership. Matsumoto believes prioritizing shareholders can lead to scandals and has never asked investors to buy shares, instead encouraging them to sell if they disagree. Many investors, including a senior executive, have praised Matsumoto's track record and results, despite his unconventional approach.

site_title: China warns investment may weaken further, to make "good use" of fiscal policy
summary: China's investment growth, already at record lows, may weaken further, according to the state planner. Fixed-asset investment in the first seven months of the year grew at the slowest pace on record since 1996, and initial investment approvals have dropped sharply. The National Development and Reform Commission attributed the decline to infrastructure construction barriers and stiff competition in manufacturing. To boost investment, Beijing is urging more infrastructure spending and has told local governments to speed up the sale of special bonds.

site_title: German business morale brightens much more than expected in August
summary: German business morale improved more than expected in August, with the Ifo economic institute's business climate index rising to 103.8 from 101.7. The increase was driven by a truce in the trade conflict with the US and a robust domestic economic situation, suggesting economic growth of 0.5% in the third quarter. Ifo chief Clemens Fuest attributed the improvement to both factors, stating the German economy is performing robustly.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,235.74, up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.7% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,235.74 points. A total of 613.3 million shares worth S$373.9 million changed hands, with ThaiBev being the most actively traded counter. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Malaysia bars foreigners from Forest City project that drew Chinese buyers
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has barred foreigners from buying residential units in the US$100-billion Forest City project in Johor state. The project, which aims to accommodate 700,000 people, has faced uncertainty since Mahathir's election victory. Mahathir stated that the city was built for foreigners, not Malaysians, and that he will not give visas for foreigners to live there. This decision comes amid opposition to the project, which has been criticized for environmental damage and a glut in the property market.

images.alt_text: Malaysia will not allow foreigners to buy residential units in the US$100-billion Forest City project in its southern state of Johor bordering Singapore, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said on Monday.

site_title: Nokia secures 500m euro EU loan for 5G development
summary: Nokia has secured a 500 million euro loan from the European Investment Bank to develop 5G technology, which is expected to offer faster speeds, wider coverage, and more stable connections. The loan will support Nokia's efforts to compete with China's Huawei and the US's Ericsson in the 5G market, where demand has been flagging since 2015. This deal comes after Nokia's recent $3.5 billion deal with US mobile carrier T-Mobile, and by 2025, 1.2 billion people worldwide are set to have access to 5G networks.

site_title: French 2018 budget deficit to be above 2.3% target: minister
summary: French Budget Minister Gerald Darmanin announced that France's 2018 budget deficit will exceed the target of 2.3% of national income, but will remain below 3%. The deficit is expected to be around 2.6% due to weaker-than-expected economic growth. The government plans to address social spending in its next reforms, aiming to meet its promise to cut the deficit below 3% by 2020.

site_title: Companies offer employees hope with stem cell storage benefits
summary: Companies such as MyCrypto and Forever Labs are offering employees the option to store their stem cells, which may potentially be used for future health maintenance and treatment of diseases like heart disease and Alzheimer's. The companies pay for the stem cell collection procedure and cover storage fees, providing a unique benefit that may help retain employees in a competitive labor market. While the science behind stem cell storage is still uncertain, the promise of hope and extended life may be a valuable perk for young, tech-savvy employees.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally along with global shares on Powell comments
summary: European stocks rose 0.3% on Monday, crossing above their 50-day moving average, as the UK market remained closed for a public holiday. The gains followed US stocks hitting all-time highs after Fed Chairman Jerome Powell signaled the central bank sees little need to tighten policy aggressively. Europe's benchmark index is still down 1.2% for 2018, attributed to better economic growth and earnings growth in the US, making it more vulnerable to external shocks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks jump more than two per cent
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 2% on Monday, driven by a record-breaking lead from Wall Street and dovish comments from the Federal Reserve head regarding interest rates. The Hang Seng Index jumped 2.17% to 28,271.27, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.89% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 2.49%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: China clamping down on transport sector after Didi passenger's murder
summary: China has pledged to tighten oversight of its transportation sector following a Didi passenger's murder, where a 20-year-old woman was raped and killed by her driver. Didi Chuxing, the world's largest ride-hailing firm, has suspended its carpooling service, Hitch, and removed two executives from their positions. The National Development and Reform Commission has announced plans to expand the use of China's social credit system across the transport sector. The incident is the second such incident since May, denting Didi's image and raising concerns about the company's safety measures.

site_title: Noble snags shareholders' nod on pivotal debt revamp at SGM
summary: Noble Group secured an overwhelming nod from shareholders at a special general meeting in Singapore, paving the way for a debt-for-equity rescue plan. The plan, which has already secured irrevocable undertakings from 86% of existing creditors, will see Noble hand over 70% of equity to senior creditors, 10% to management, and the rest to existing shareholders. The outcome is seen as a "day of reckoning" for the embattled commodity trader, but the future sustainability of the revamped company remains uncertain.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as Asian bourses rally
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.88% to 22,799.64, while the Topix index increased 1.16% to 1,728.95, driven by gains in Asian markets and a relatively cheaper yen. Shares of Toyota, Nintendo, and Sony also rose, with Toyota increasing 1.99% to 6,966 yen after announcing plans to build a new factory in China. Investors remain cautious due to ongoing US-China tensions and upcoming global economic data.

site_title: China's soybean, soymeal futures fall on African swine fever worries
summary: China's soybean and soymeal futures fell on Monday, August 27, 2018, due to concerns over African swine fever and forecasts of a record US crop. Soybean futures dropped 1.7% to 3,594 yuan per tonne, while soymeal futures fell 1.9% to 3,070 yuan per tonne. High inventories and weak demand from the food sector also contributed to the decline. Analysts expect further drops in prices due to a bumper US harvest and a depreciating Brazilian currency.

site_title: Cluster of 3 adjoining shophouses on Chinatown's Smith Street for sale with S$3,500 psf guide price
summary: A freehold cluster of three adjoining conservation shophouses on Smith Street in Singapore's Chinatown is up for sale with a guide price of S$3,500 per square foot (psf), or S$33.25 million. The property, zoned full commercial, features approved uses for a restaurant, hostel, and TCM clinic. The location is within walking distance to the Chinatown and Maxwell MRT stations, making it an attractive investment opportunity for astute buyers in the bustling F&B and tourist destination. The tender closes on September 25.

site_title: Metro AG faces shake-up of shareholder structure
summary: Metro AG faces a potential shake-up of its shareholder structure as Ceconomy may sell a significant stake in the German retailer to an investor group led by Czech billionaire Daniel Kretinsky. Ceconomy is in talks to sell most of its 10% stake in Metro to EP Investment, with shares in Metro rising 5.1% following the news. This development could impact the company's ownership structure and potentially influence its future strategy.

site_title: HDB launches tender of 3.8ha mixed-use site at Pasir Ris Central
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) launched a 3.8ha mixed-use site at Pasir Ris Central for a 99-year leasehold through a dual-envelope exercise. The site, near Pasir Ris MRT station, must integrate a bus interchange, polyclinic, and town plaza, and can yield up to 600 private homes with a maximum permissible gross floor area of 95,010 sq m. The tender, closing on Dec 14, will evaluate concept and price proposals. The site is part of the "Remaking Our Heartland" plan for Pasir Ris Town.

site_title: GuocoLand hires Lafarge Malaysia's Lim Yoke Tuan as new CFO
summary: GuocoLand has appointed Lim Yoke Tuan as its new CFO, replacing Lai Tak Loi who left to pursue other career opportunities. Lim, formerly CFO of Lafarge Malaysia, begins immediately. Before Lafarge, Lim held CFO positions at The Lion Group, CP Lotus Corp, and Sun Hung Kai Properties Group. GuocoLand shares rose 1.6% following the announcement.

site_title: Two firms that won initial tender snag S$2.26m LTA contract for 2nd phase of on-demand bus project
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a S$2.26 million contract to two firms, Via Transportation and Ministry of Movement, for the second phase of its on-demand public bus services project. This follows their initial tender win in February to develop a dynamic routing and matching algorithm. A six-month trial of on-demand services will begin in December, allowing commuters to request pick-ups and drop-offs through a mobile app. The trial aims to enhance public bus services in Singapore.

site_title: Bayer, J&J's blood-thinning drug Xarelto fails 'Mariner' trial
summary: Bayer AG and Johnson & Johnson's blood-thinning drug Xarelto failed to prevent clotting in high-risk patients after hospital release, according to the Mariner trial results. The trial involved 12,000 medically ill patients, and results showed no reduction in blood-clot related deaths, despite a significant reduction in clotting. The setback won't affect Xarelto's sales forecasts, and both companies remain confident in the drug's prospects. Xarelto was approved in 2008 to prevent blood clots in patients undergoing surgery, and its sales were reported at 3.3 billion euros last year.

site_title: Singapore youths have little confidence their parents have saved enough for retirement: survey
summary: A recent survey in Singapore found that only one in five youths believe their parents have enough savings for retirement, with 15% trusting they've planned for retirement. Parents set aside 35% of the amount they need, but 67% expect to outlive their savings. To support their retired parents, 70% of youths plan to downgrade their lifestyle, while 66% factor in the cost of caring for their parents. The survey highlights inadequate retirement planning, with 80% of parents starting to save but only 6% confident in maintaining their lifestyle in retirement.

site_title: Australian shares led higher by firm commodity prices; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Monday, led by gains in resource-related stocks due to higher gold and base metal prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,268.9. Relief over the appointment of Scott Morrison as prime minister also contributed to the gains. Gold stocks surged 2.7%, while material stocks rose due to rising commodity prices. Financial stocks edged higher after initial findings from a Royal Commission inquiry into the sector were released, criticizing two major banks.

site_title: Sinopec reports best quarter in years after oil prices rebound
summary: Sinopec, China's largest refiner, reported its best quarterly profit in years, with first-half net income reaching 41.6 billion yuan, a 54% increase from the same period last year. The company attributed the strong earnings to rising oil prices, OPEC-led output cuts, and lower Venezuelan and Libyan output. Despite this, Sinopec warned that fuel sales are expected to drop and processing rates for crude to stay flat in the second half of 2018 due to an oversupply of refined fuels.

site_title: New Australian PM gets to work; govt support plummets
summary: Australia's new Prime Minister Scott Morrison began work after a week of turmoil, touring drought-hit farms to reassure voters. However, a leading opinion poll showed the government faces an increased chance of electoral defeat, with the ruling Liberal-National coalition's primary vote dropping to 33% and the two-party-preferred split now in favor of Labor 56-44. This indicates a heavy election defeat for the coalition, which has been in power since 2013.

site_title: Kazakh port in decline bids for slice of China trade
summary: Kazakhstan's Caspian seaport Aktau is seeking to capitalize on China's trillion-dollar Belt and Road initiative, which aims to boost overland trade. Despite being a sleepy port hit by new oil routes, Aktau is vying for a slice of the Chinese trade with new technology and investments in domestic road and rail infrastructure. The port expects to process 1,500 containers from China in 2018, double last year's figure, but still only three percent of its overall turnover. Other Caspian ports, including Turkmenistan and Azerbaijan, are also competing for the Chinese trade.

site_title: Indonesia wants to halve the foreign ownership of its sovereign bonds in five years
summary: Indonesia aims to halve foreign ownership of its sovereign bonds in five years, seeking to shield assets from external shocks. The government wants to reduce foreign ownership to 20% from around 38% currently. This move comes amid a global emerging market sell-off and Indonesia's reliance on foreign inflows to finance its current account and budget deficits. The government plans to increase local currency debt in new bond issuances, with a target of 70-75% local currency debt by 2023.

site_title: Car-parts makers, fear not: KKR has arrived
summary: KKR is in talks to acquire Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV's parts unit, Magneti Marelli SpA, in a deal potentially worth 10 billion euros. This acquisition would combine Magneti with Calsonic Kansei Corp., a Japanese parts company KKR bought from Nissan Motor Co. in 2016. The combined entity would be a car-parts giant with a valuation of 2.3-7 billion euros. This move could alleviate fears in the auto-parts industry, which has been sputtering.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS downgrades Y Ventures to 'hold'
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded e-commerce firm Y Ventures Group to 'hold' due to potential short-term delays in generating sales from new third-party brands and lower-than-expected sales of private labels. The broker lowered Y Ventures' target price to S$0.48 from S$0.77 and will relook its recommendation once the firm tackles challenges. However, a successful Aora initial coin offering (ICO) could be a catalyst for the stock, showcasing investor confidence in the Aora platform. DBS revised Y Ventures' fiscal 2018 and 2019 revenue by 11 and 14% respectively due to these challenges.

site_title: Singapore's core inflation reaches four-year high
summary: Singapore's core inflation has reached a four-year high due to rising costs. However, headline inflation remains steady. Meanwhile, Vietnam is responding to US trade terms with a surge in stocks. In Malaysia, the central bank has cut interest rates to shield the economy from tariff threats. The move signals growth jitters. Thailand's super-long bonds are gaining value due to tariffs and a political crisis.

site_title: Electric future sets East Europe refiners after coffee dollars
summary: Central Europe's oil companies, such as Hungary's Mol Nyrt. and Poland's PKN Orlen SA, are diversifying their businesses to compete with electric vehicles gaining popularity. The companies are investing in retail operations, including fuel stations turned convenience stores, with plans to offer artisanal coffees, wholewheat wraps, and designer bottles of water. The strategy aims to increase consumer services Ebitda to 30% by 2030 and address long-term threats to the business. Meanwhile, smaller rivals are also expanding into non-fuel services, such as car- and bike-sharing services and power production.

site_title: Floods in India's top buyer may hit wedding season gold demand
summary: Heavy rains and floods in Kerala, India's top gold-buying state, have caused over $3 billion in damage, affecting the upcoming festival and wedding season. Sales of gold for weddings are expected to drop 50% due to the disaster. The state's industries, including tourism and rubber, are also expected to be impacted, while coffee production faces a 21-year low. The death toll has climbed to at least 370, with nearly 1 million people taking shelter in relief camps.

images.alt_text: Jewellers in India's biggest gold-buying state expect sales to drop during the peak festival and wedding season after heavy rains and floods caused more than US$3 billion of damage.

site_title: SGX, Third500 to build emerging growth IPO market in Singapore
summary: Third500, a Singapore-based affiliate of US investment bank Healthios Capital Markets LLC, has partnered the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to build a pre-IPO and IPO market for venture-backed emerging growth companies. The market, focusing on companies with US$60 million in private investments, aims to provide funding options for companies below US$300 million market cap. The partnership has already seen four clients raise nearly US$200 million in growth capital, with one successfully completing an IPO on the Nasdaq.

site_title: A cult New Zealand honey is causing legal problems in the US
summary: New Zealand's prized Manuka honey is causing legal issues in the US, with counterfeit products being sold at a fraction of the authentic price. A class-action lawsuit was filed against Trader Joe's, alleging the store sold 100% manuka honey that tested as low as 62.6% pure. The honey is produced from native New Zealand manuka trees and has antibacterial properties. Industry players, such as Comvita Ltd. and Pacific Resources International, are struggling to meet demand due to production limitations and are warning of more lawsuits.

site_title: ISOTeam swings into the red with S$1.99m Q4 loss
summary: Construction company ISOTeam reported a net loss of S$1.99 million for the 3 months ended June 30, down from a net profit of S$1.38 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 6.8% to S$20.2 million, mainly due to lower contributions from certain business segments. The company proposed a final dividend of 0.18 Singapore cent per share and has a strong order book of S$126.3 million.

site_title: Singapore's service industries report 7.8% year-on-year rise in Q2 takings
summary: Singapore's service industries saw a 7.8% year-on-year rise in Q2 takings, driven by the information and communications services industry, which jumped 13.5% on higher software publishing and data centre revenues. Financial and insurance industry revenue rose 10.1%, while business services expanded by 7.9%. In contrast, the recreation and personal services industry declined by 2.8%. The Business Receipts Index measures short-term changes in income from business operations, excluding wholesale and retail trade, and accommodation and food services.

images.alt_text: The recreation and personal services industry saw revenue decline by 2.8 per cent year on year, after growing by 10.5 per cent previously.

site_title: Workforce Singapore unveils development roadmap for career practitioners industry
summary: Workforce Singapore (WSG) unveiled a development roadmap for the career practitioners industry with the launch of the Career Development Framework (CDF). The framework aims to professionalise the industry by establishing a roadmap for the development and certification of career practitioner competencies. The CDF defines competencies for various roles and packages training courses to help career professionals begin their practice. Four programmes will be rolled out over the next two years, providing practitioners with the edge in assisting jobseekers make quality career decisions.

site_title: China targets rumours, religion in updated party rules
summary: China's Communist Party has issued updated regulations governing members' behavior, threatening punishment for spreading political rumors and recommending those who cling to religious beliefs be asked to leave the party. The rules, aimed at ensuring cadres are loyal and disciplined, include severe punishments such as expulsion for spreading rumors or engaging in "activities that use religion for incitement". President Xi Jinping's name is written into the revised rules, solidifying his central role in party life. The regulations also crack down on distortions of national history.

site_title: Startup Travelstop pulls in US$1.2m in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based startup Travelstop has secured US$1.2 million in seed funding, led by SeedPlus and a US-based travel-focused investor. The AI-powered software-as-a-service platform aims to simplify business travel in Asia by automating booking and expense reporting. The funding will be used to drive product development, build a team, and ramp up growth in priority markets such as Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Travelstop's goal is to provide a seamless travel experience for young millennials and business travelers in Asia.

site_title: Bank of Thailand's hawkish tilt adds to the currency's allure
summary: The Bank of Thailand's hawkish stance is adding to the baht's appeal, with the currency outperforming other emerging-market currencies. Thailand's strong current-account surplus and benign inflation have enabled it to maintain near-record low interest rates, making the baht an attractive option. Analysts expect a potential rate hike in September, and technical analysis suggests the dollar-baht pair may continue its downtrend, pushing the currency up 1.6% this month and 1.1% this quarter.

site_title: South Korea says Pompeo's cancelled visit impacts North Korea liaison office plans
summary: South Korea's liaison office with North Korea, planned to open by August, is facing uncertainty after US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's cancelled visit. The office, aimed at improving ties between the two Koreas, had raised concerns about violating UN and US sanctions. South Korea's Unification Ministry says the office's material is for operational purposes, not economic gain. The inter-Korean summit, set for September, remains on track, with President Moon Jae-in's role as mediator expanding after Pompeo's cancellation.

site_title: Australia's Victoria state in A$2.86b land title register deal with pension fund
summary: Victoria state in Australia has agreed to sell a 40-year concession to run its land and property registries to pension fund First State Super for A$2.86 billion. The deal will allow First State Super to levy fees for property ownership registrations in the state, with proceeds to be spent on schools, hospitals, and transport projects. The state will retain control of essential services, with pricing for statutory services controlled and capped at inflation. The sale is expected to boost Victoria's infrastructure investment, with an average A$10.2 billion per year to be invested over the next four years.

site_title: Myanmar court postpones verdict for Reuters journalists
summary: A Myanmar court postponed its ruling on Reuters journalists Wa Lone and Kyaw Soe Oo, who have been held in prison for eight months on charges of violating a state secrets law. The new date for the verdict is September 3. The journalists were reporting on the Rohingya crisis and were arrested in December after being invited to a police dinner. Reuters has denied the charges, and the case has sparked concerns about press freedoms in Myanmar under civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi.

site_title: Malaysia bars foreigners from Forest City project that drew thousands of China buyers
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has announced that foreigners will no longer be allowed to buy residential units in the $100-billion Forest City project in Johor, citing concerns that the project was built for foreigners and not Malaysians. The decision follows opposition to the project, which was a key factor in Mahathir's shock victory in the May general election. The project, developed by Chinese company Country Garden, had faced uncertainty and criticism from Malaysians over issues such as environmental damage and a glut in the property market.

site_title: In world's 'happiest' countries, signs of a happiness gap
summary: The Nordic countries, which consistently rank as the world's happiest nations, face a significant happiness gap. Despite their high taxes and social welfare systems, an average of 12.3% of the population in Finland, Norway, Denmark, and Iceland struggles or suffers, according to a report. Young people are driving this inequality, with a rise in depression and loneliness, particularly among young people and women. The report highlights the need to address these issues, as unhappiness has significant socioeconomic consequences, including absence from work and low productivity.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally after Wall St record, dollar eases
summary: Asian markets rallied after a record lead from Wall Street, while the dollar eased following Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments indicating a gradual pace of interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq closed at fresh records, with Asian markets such as Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai rising. The US dollar dropped against major peers, including the Mexican peso, which was boosted by news of a revised free-trade pact. The yuan also gained support from a policy tweak by the People's Bank of China to prevent a sharp decline.

site_title: To avoid extinction, fading Swiss village puts hope in tourism
summary: Switzerland's smallest village, Corippo, with a population of 12 full-time residents, is facing extinction due to demographic decline. To address this issue, the village has been transformed into a hotel, dubbed "albergo diffuso," which will offer 25 beds and a public space. The hotel is expected to cost 3.2 million Swiss francs, with 2.2 million secured through public funding and bank loans. While the hotel may attract tourists, concerns remain about its impact on the village's long-term sustainability and whether it will truly benefit the local community.

site_title: Furious voters deliver damning verdict on Australia political chaos
summary: Australia's support for the government has plummeted after the ousting of Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, with a poll showing Labor ahead by 12 points. Scott Morrison was sworn in as the country's 30th leader after a bitter Liberal Party revolt. The survey also showed a large swing towards Labor leader Bill Shorten as preferred prime minister, with voters considering Julie Bishop as the right person to head the Liberal Party. The poll puts the government on track for a devastating defeat at elections due next year.

site_title: Co-working space outlook 'robust' but mixed across Asean markets: Maybank Kim Eng report
summary: A report by Maybank Kim Eng analysts Lee Ju Ye and Chua Hak Bin describes the outlook for co-working spaces in Asean as "robust" but varies across markets. Co-working spaces could grow from less than 1% of Asean office stock in 2015 to 10-15% by 2030, driven by the gig economy and flexible leasing terms. Developers are partnering with co-working space operators, and mergers and acquisitions are on the rise. However, the analysts caution that a business downturn could lead to co-working players being the first option for firms to break leases, highlighting concerns over cyber security and intellectual property risks.

site_title: China's oil majors risk wasting a good trade war
summary: China's state-owned oil majors, including PetroChina, are experiencing a surge in earnings due to the US-China trade war, which has boosted crude prices and opened opportunities in Iran. Earnings for CNOOC and Sinopec have risen significantly, with PetroChina expected to report its best quarterly earnings since 2015. The companies are benefiting from higher oil prices and a clampdown on independent refiners at home. However, to sustain their growth, they need to reduce expenses and invest in more efficient operations, as the benefits of the trade war are temporary and may not last forever.

site_title: Rajeev De Mello joins OCBC's Bank of Singapore as chief investment officer
summary: OCBC Bank's private banking arm, Bank of Singapore, has appointed Rajeev De Mello as chief investment officer, pending regulatory approval. De Mello, a Swiss national with over 30 years of experience in global financial markets, will oversee research and investment strategy teams, chair the investment committee, and manage discretionary portfolios. His appointment comes as BOS expands, with assets under management reaching US$102 billion as of June 30. The move aims to provide timely and insightful research capabilities to investors amidst market uncertainties.

site_title: China's July industrial profit growth cools for third straight month
summary: China's industrial profit growth slowed for the third consecutive month in July, rising 16.2% from the previous year, down from a 20% increase in June. The slower growth is attributed to moderating producer price inflation and cautious consumer spending. Despite rising raw material prices benefiting producers, margin pressures persist, and smaller manufacturers continue to shed staff. The data follows weaker economic readings and US-China trade tensions, with officials pledging targeted measures to cope with trade friction impacts.

site_title: Rakuten details plan to fight back against Amazon, SoftBank
summary: Rakuten Inc., a Japanese e-commerce giant, plans to launch a cutting-edge wireless network to compete with SoftBank Group Corp. and Amazon.com Inc. The new mobile business, set to debut next year, will integrate Rakuten's 80 different services, offering a single ID for shopping, travel, and payments. The company aims to attract new customers and increase spending on the platform. Rakuten targets 10 trillion yen in lifetime value and plans to expand its mobile-payment business, improve logistics, and build a wireless carrier, with a goal of 15 million subscribers.

site_title: Gig economy taking off but labour observers flag insurance and CPF concerns
summary: The gig economy in Singapore is growing, with nearly three-fifths of own-account workers earning more than S$20,000 last year. However, labor and economy experts are concerned about traditional self-employed workers, such as private tutors and taxi drivers, due to patchy insurance coverage and lack of CPF retirement savings. The government has released recommendations, including mediation for payment disputes and a contribute-as-you-earn model for healthcare savings. Experts warn that the trend may not be sustainable, citing the need for better protection for these workers and the potential impact on housing affordability.

site_title: South-east Asia is ripe for a cashless revolution
summary: South-east Asia is poised for a cashless revolution, driven by the region's high internet and mobile penetration rates. The rise of financial technology and cashless solutions could address the region's unmet financing demands, but the adoption has been slow. Governments and banks are racing to develop cashless solutions to reduce infrastructure costs, but progress has been hindered. The cashless revolution could simplify commerce, reduce cash management costs, and increase financial inclusion, but its implementation is still pending.

site_title: Shares of casino operator Landing International slide; chairman still uncontactable
summary: Shares of Landing International Development Ltd slid 8% after the casino operator reported no update on its missing chairman, Yang Zhihui, who has been uncontactable since Thursday. Despite operations and finances being reported as normal, the company's market value has lost nearly half since last week. A company spokeswoman declined to provide further updates, citing no new information.

site_title: CIMB becomes member of United Nations initiative for responsible banking
summary: CIMB Group Holdings has become a founding member of the United Nations' Environment Programme Finance Initiative Principles for Responsible Banking, making it the only banking group in ASEAN to join. As a member, CIMB will contribute to the development of the principles, which aim to redefine the global banking industry's role in shaping a sustainable future. The group will align with the UN's Sustainable Development Goals, the Paris Agreement, and national frameworks, setting a global benchmark for sustainable banking and requiring signatory banks to report on their social, environmental, and economic targets.

site_title: Mexico, US closing in on Nafta deal, talks to resume Monday
summary: US and Mexican trade negotiators are close to reaching a common position on the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), with talks set to resume on Monday. Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo stated that progress has been made, and they are "hours" away from a deal. However, Guajardo also indicated that more work remains to be done, and talks will start again on Monday at 9am local time in Washington. The resumption of talks marks a significant development in the bilateral negotiations.

site_title: UK PM May travels to three African nations in post-Brexit trade push
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May travels to three African nations, South Africa, Nigeria, and Kenya, on a five-day visit to promote post-Brexit trade opportunities. The trip aims to strengthen ties with economies outside the EU and capitalize on Africa's growing population. May will meet with counterparts to discuss investment, stability, and security in the continent. The visit comes as the UK prepares to leave the EU in March, amid concerns about a potential no-deal Brexit and its economic implications.

site_title: Struggling Noble Group faces crucial vote for US$3.5b restructure
summary: Noble Group, a struggling commodities trader, faces a crucial shareholder meeting on Monday to vote on a US$3.5 billion debt restructuring deal. The proposal, which includes a debt-for-equity swap, aims to halve Noble's debt and provide access to trade finance. Shareholders will own 20% of the business, while creditors will hold 70%. Analysts warn that the company's turnaround is uncertain, and a failure to secure funding could lead to its demise.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged over 1% at the open on Monday, following a strong lead from Wall Street where the Nasdaq and S&P 500 ended at fresh records. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.25% to 28,016.66, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.25% to 2,736.32. The rally came despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: China to crack down on dishonesty in transport, including ride services
summary: China's state planner, the National Development and Reform Commission, plans to crack down on dishonesty in the transportation sector, including ride-hailing services like Didi Chuxing. This comes after a passenger was raped and killed by a driver in Wenzhou. The commission will improve governance across various transport sectors, including civil aviation and railways. Authorities aim to enhance oversight and accountability, following the recent criticism of Didi Chuxing. The crackdown is expected to increase regulation and safety measures in the industry.

site_title: Mahathir cancels China-backed projects worth US$22b to reduce national debt
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced the cancellation of three China-backed projects worth US$22 billion to reduce the country's national debt. The projects include a railway connecting Malaysia's east coast to southern Thailand and two gas pipelines. Mahathir made the announcement during a visit to Beijing, citing the need for his country to find a way to pay its debts. The decision comes as Malaysia faces economic challenges and tariff threats from the US.

images.alt_text: Dr Mahathir is trying to reduce Malaysia's national debt, which has ballooned to some US$250 billion.

site_title: China sets yuan fix stronger than expected, revives "X" factor
summary: China's central bank lifted its official yuan midpoint to 6.8508 per US dollar, stronger than expected, as part of its efforts to support the currency. The move, which is 202 pips or 0.3% firmer than the previous fix, aims to stabilize the currency market amid broad dollar strength and trade tensions. The central bank re-introduced a counter-cyclical factor to its daily fixing mechanism, a move seen as a response to the weakening yuan.

site_title: Tokyo stocks open higher following Wall Street advance
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, following a Wall Street advance last week, as the US Federal Reserve chief signaled no acceleration of interest rate increases. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.41% to 22,694.53, while the Topix index climbed 0.37% to 1,715.51. The gains come as investors remain optimistic despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won climb over Powell comment, bullish Wall Street
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.12% to 2,296.05 on Monday, tracking US stock gains. The won strengthened against the US dollar after Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's speech, with bond yields falling. Construction and steel stocks dropped 10% after US President Donald Trump cancelled Mike Pompeo's trip to North Korea. The KOSPI is down 7.1% this year, but foreign investors were net buyers of 62 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Australian shares flat as inquiry knocks financial sector; NZ up
summary: Australian shares were flat on Monday, as a rise in mining stocks offset a weaker financial sector following the initial findings of a market inquiry. The S&P/ASX 200 index remained steady at 6,247.2. Resource stocks, particularly gold and commodity prices, gained due to a weaker US dollar. Newcrest Mining and Evolution Mining rose 2.7% and 5%, respectively. The 'Big Four' banks eased following criticism from the Royal Commission inquiry into the financial sector. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.2% driven by gains from a2 Milk Company and Synlait Milk.
