site_title: Citi says its Asia equities business is booming
summary: Citigroup's Asia equities business is expected to post its best results since the financial crisis, with revenue increasing 33% in the first half of 2018. The division aims to meet its full-year forecast by boosting derivatives and prime finance offerings, driven by a rise in block trades and initial public offerings. Investments in technology and recent senior hires are expected to provide a boost, as the division aims to crack the top five in Asian equities. This growth is attributed to European banks' struggles and MiFID II regulations pushing clients toward large brokerages.

site_title: Asia stocks slip after US-China trade talks end without progress, Powell eyed
summary: Asian stocks fell on Friday after US-China trade talks ended without progress, with the US and China activating another round of duelling tariffs on $16 billion worth of each country's goods. The Dow lost 0.3% and shares of industrial giants Caterpillar and Boeing fell. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech on Friday is expected to provide insight into the direction of US monetary policy, with some analysts expecting rate hikes this year.

site_title: Australian dollar seen headed for over 2-year low of 70 US cents
summary: The Australian dollar is expected to reach a 2-year low of 70 US cents due to infighting in the ruling party, threatening policy paralysis and economic uncertainty. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is facing a challenge from his own party, and a leadership vote is likely to occur. The currency has already weakened 10% from its January high, and experts predict it will test 70 US cents by year's end, with some expecting a decline to 71.25 US cents.

site_title: World Bank says demand for blockchain bond tops expectations
summary: The World Bank successfully raised A$110 million in its first-ever blockchain bond offering, exceeding initial expectations of A$50 million. The two-year bond, valued at A$110.48 million, was oversubscribed by official institutions, fund managers, and banks. The World Bank has long seen blockchain as a valuable tool in its economic development mission, citing its potential to improve supply chains and product verification in various industries. The bond offering was facilitated by Microsoft and TD Securities, and was seen as a significant milestone for the adoption of blockchain technology in capital markets.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages to pay S$1.18m in costs to Promedia Directories for copyright infringement suit
summary: Global Yellow Pages has been ordered by the Singapore High Court to pay S$1.18 million in costs to Promedia Directories after losing a copyright infringement case in January 2017. The company will make further announcements on the case as necessary.

site_title: Japan July inflation stagnates, lacks demand-driven support
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.8% in July, unchanged from the previous month, as the country's inflation remains stagnant. The Bank of Japan's massive stimulus program continues to struggle to achieve its 2% inflation target, with wage growth remaining a key challenge. The central bank's efforts to make its policy framework more sustainable have been met with rising risks, including impacts on bank profits. Japan's economy rebounded in the second quarter, but real wages rose at their fastest pace in over 21 years, offering policymakers some hope for future price growth.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Friday's open; STI down 0.36% to 3,238.14
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Friday, declining 0.36% to 3,238.14, following two days of US-China trade talks without a major breakthrough. Losers outnumbered gainers 75 to 35, with Singtel and City Developments shedding 1.2% and 0.6%, respectively. Active index stocks, including United Overseas Bank and DBS Group Holdings, also fell 0.6% and 0.4%, respectively.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the open on Friday, extending losses from the previous day, following a negative lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.81% to 27,565.98, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.28% to 2,717.08. This follows a mixed performance in the US market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia faces increased blackout risks this summer as coal plants age
summary: Australia faces increased blackout risks this summer due to ageing coal-fired power plants becoming less reliable. The Australian Energy Market Operator (AEMO) warns that the southeastern states of Victoria and South Australia are most at risk of outages, with New South Wales also facing some risk. AEMO calls for more power investment to avert outages, citing the need for a new generation mix to replace retiring coal-fired plants. The risk of load-shedding has increased since last year's outlook, with temperatures expected to be warmer than average this summer.

site_title: Isolated tribe members in Brazil spotted in drone footage
summary: Brazil's National Indian Foundation (FUNAI) has released drone footage showing isolated tribe members in the Javari Valley, a hard-to-access area of the Amazon rainforest. The footage, recorded in 2017, reveals the existence of the tribe, which has made contact with FUNAI officials. The region is home to over 100 confirmed isolated tribes, with 11 more detected via signs. FUNAI aims to protect these tribes, which face threats from agricultural and mining industries. The footage is part of a larger project that also encountered poachers and released wild animals, highlighting the need for increased vigilance and control.

site_title: Australia's Westpac reports lower margins, warns delinquencies on rise
summary: Australia's Westpac Banking Corp reported a 11 basis point drop in its quarterly net interest margin (NIM) to 2.06%, citing higher funding costs and rising mortgage delinquencies. The lender's shares fell 3% as credit growth in the country fell to a four-year low of 5.6% in June. Despite this, Westpac's home loan book grew at 6% for the past year, and it noted lower impairments in its smaller portfolios. The bank warned of higher stressed exposures in its corporate property and retail portfolio.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher helped by cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by a cheaper yen against the US dollar. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.31% and the Topix index gained 0.51%. The US dollar strengthened against the yen, providing a tailwind for Japanese shares. Some blue-chip exporters, such as Sony and Panasonic, were higher, while steelmakers and automakers were lower. The Dow on Wall Street declined 0.3% despite the latest US-China tariffs.

site_title: Hong Kong intervenes again to defend peg as greenback strengthens
summary: Hong Kong's monetary authority intervened to defend its currency peg, buying HK$1.77 billion to stabilize the Hong Kong dollar at HK$7.85, as the greenback strengthened following US-China trade talks. The intervention came as the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index jumped six weeks high, and analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next month, potentially leading to Hong Kong's first prime rate hike in a decade. The aggregate balance of HK$91 billion will fall on August 27.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) bought HK$1.77 billion (S$309.7 million) during New York trading hours on Thursday, according to the de facto central bank's page on Bloomberg.

site_title: Music and Lee
summary: Singapore music pioneer Dick Lee is set to perform a two-night concert with Singapopera, celebrating his life in musicals. The concert features a nine-piece band and notable talents such as Sebastian Tan and Cheryl Tan. Lee's musicals, including Fried Rice Paradise and Forbidden City, have been revived multiple times, introducing new generations of fans. Singapopera runs at the Esplanade Concert Hall on Aug 25 and 26.

site_title: British Airways, Air France halting flights to Iran from next month
summary: British Airways and Air France will halt flights to Iran from September due to business reasons. British Airways will suspend its London to Tehran service on September 22 and 23, while Air France will stop flights from Paris to Tehran on September 18. The decision follows US President Donald Trump's re-imposition of sanctions on Iran and a decline in business customers. German airline Lufthansa has no plans to stop flying to Tehran.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso swings into the red with S$50.9m Q4 loss
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings reported a net loss of S$50.9 million for the fourth quarter, down 43.4% from the previous year. Revenue fell to S$24.2 million, and cost of sales increased to S$70.3 million. The company attributed the losses to difficult ground conditions, regulatory requirements, and unfavorable trade terms. For the full year, net loss was S$54.5 million, with loss per share of 17.01 Singapore cents. Shares have been suspended since June 27 due to a court-supervised reorganisation process for its liabilities.

site_title: Elon Musk hires Morgan Stanley to help take Tesla private
summary: Elon Musk has hired Morgan Stanley to advise him on a potential bid to take Tesla Inc. private, according to a person familiar with the matter. The bank suspended coverage of the stock without explanation after Musk tweeted on August 7 that he had "funding secured" for a private takeover. This move follows Musk's surprise announcement in August 2018 that he wanted to take Tesla private.

site_title: Fed policymakers see rate hikes, blurring dove-hawk divide
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers are increasingly united on raising interest rates to extend the economic expansion, despite falling unemployment. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell is expected to signal more rate hikes ahead, with Kansas City Fed President Esther George and Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan backing a three- to four-rate hike over the next nine to 12 months. The Fed aims to move interest rates to a neutral setting of 2.5% to 3% to balance promoting full employment and maintaining stable prices.

site_title: Lion Asiapac Q4 profit plunges 99% in absence of disposal gain
summary: Lion Asiapac reported a 99% fall in Q4 net profit to S$85,000, down from S$15.67 million, due to the absence of a gain from the disposal of a subsidiary. Fourth quarter turnover soared 89% to S$4.36 million, but margins remained depressed by high production costs. Full year net profit plunged 92% to S$1.28 million. The company declared a first and final dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share and plans to implement cost containment measures.

site_title: Fusion impossible
summary: Hublot's latest watch releases showcase the "Art of Fusion" concept, combining contrasting elements to create unique timepieces. The Big Bang Meca-10 Blue Ceramic and Big Bang Ferrari feature cutting-edge mechanics with ultra-resistant blue ceramic cases, while the Classic Fusion Aerofusion Chronograph Orlinski is a collaboration with French artist Richard Orlinski, blending vintage and neo-futurist styles. Limited-edition releases include the Big Bang Ferrari, Classic Fusion Aerofusion Chronograph, and the Spirit of Big Bang Blue, each showcasing the brand's innovative approach to watch-making.

site_title: Sales at Gap brand stores worsen, shares fall
summary: Gap Inc's namesake brand reported a 5% drop in same-store sales in the fiscal second quarter, beating profit expectations but sending shares down 6.6% due to inventory issues and a lack of newness in its assortment. Despite strong revenue growth and a focus on improving margins, Gap executives acknowledged the need to revive the brand, which struggles to compete with fast-fashion rivals and Amazon. Other brands, such as Old Navy, performed well, with same-store sales rising 5%.

site_title: Former Lynyrd Skynyrd guitarist Ed King dies at 68
summary: Ed King, former lead guitarist of Lynyrd Skynyrd and co-writer of the hit song "Sweet Home Alabama," has died at 68. King joined the band in 1972 and left in 1975, returning in 1987 and staying until 1996. He was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2006. The cause of death was not revealed, and King's bandmate Gary Rossington described him as "our brother" and a "great songwriter and guitar player."

site_title: Australia's AGL Energy says CEO Vesey steps down
summary: AGL Energy Ltd, Australia's biggest power producer, announced CEO Andy Vesey's resignation after nearly four years in the role. Vesey will remain with the company as an advisor until December 31, 2018. The company will begin a search for a new CEO and has named Chief Financial Officer Brett Redman as interim CEO. The move comes amid a feud between AGL and the federal government over the company's coal-fired power plant plans. AGL reported a 28% rise in underlying profit, but its FY19 forecast fell short of analyst expectations.

site_title: JPMorgan is planning to hire for its midsize banking push abroad
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co plans to expand its commercial banking operations abroad, particularly targeting midsize companies in Mexico, France, Spain, and the UK. The company aims to deepen relationships with non-US companies and help them expand globally. This move builds on Todd Maclin's international strategy, which has historically focused on US companies' local subsidiaries abroad. JPMorgan plans to hire bankers in these countries to build out teams and provide deal advice, treasury services, and lending to foreign firms.

site_title: Facebook suspends hundreds of apps over data concerns
summary: Facebook has suspended over 400 apps, including the myPersonality app, due to concerns over data sharing and misuse. The move follows the Cambridge Analytica data scandal, which affected up to 87 million users. The app was banned for not agreeing to an audit and for sharing user information with companies with limited data protection. Facebook plans to notify 4 million users who shared data with myPersonality and has modified its app data sharing policies. The move aims to protect users' information and prevent similar breaches in the future.

site_title: US existing home sales fall for fourth straight month
summary: US existing home sales fell 0.7% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.34 million units in July, marking the fourth straight monthly decline. The drop was attributed to a shortage of properties on the market, pushing up house prices and sidelining potential buyers. Existing home sales fell 1.5% from a year ago, with inventory stabilizing last month. The median house price rose 4.5% to $269,600, and at current sales pace, it would take around 4.3 months to exhaust the current inventory.

images.alt_text: Sales fell across the north-east, south and mid-west, but rose in the west. Existing home sales make up about 90 per cent of US home sales. There were 1.92 million homes on the market in July.

site_title: Nikon plays catch-up with mirrorless camera
summary: Nikon has unveiled its first full-frame mirrorless cameras, the Z7 and Z6, aiming to compete with Sony in the professional photography market. The new devices will feature new lenses and a lighter design, with prices starting at 440,000 yen (S$5,000) for the Z7 and 270,000 yen for the Z6. This move is seen as a response to Sony's dominance in the market and Canon's upcoming entry. Nikon aims to deliver new value to the mirrorless market and regain its position as a leader in the industry.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Global Yellow Pages, Lion Asiapac, Ryobi Kiso, Clearbridge Health, Lian Beng
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies in Singapore saw significant developments affecting their shares. Global Yellow Pages was ordered to pay S$1.18 million in costs to Promedia Directories after losing a copyright infringement case. Lion Asiapac reported a 99% fall in fourth-quarter net profit, while Ryobi Kiso Holdings posted a net loss of S$50.9 million. Clearbridge Health's subsidiary SAM Laboratory entered into an agreement to expand laboratory testing services to Indonesia. Lian Beng Group won a S$278.5 million contract for residential flats development, and Parkson Retail Asia's net loss narrowed to S$18.58 million.

site_title: Australia PM's party expected to force leadership vote on Friday
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's party is expected to force a leadership vote on Friday after a petition from challenger Peter Dutton has yet to be presented. Turnbull narrowly defeated Dutton on Tuesday but has faced pressure to call a second contest due to Cabinet resignations. Key player Mathias Cormann, a former Turnbull supporter, expressed confidence in a party room meeting, which would lead to a vote between Dutton, Treasurer Scott Morrison, and Foreign Minister Julie Bishop. The outcome could impact the Australian dollar and stock market.

site_title: Europe: Shares gradually abandon gains, trade angst dent autos
summary: European shares fell 0.16% on Thursday, as the latest US-China tariffs on $50 billion worth of goods hurt trade-sensitive autos stocks. The STOXX 600 edged down, with autos stocks losing 1.4% for the second day. Continental's profit warning sank the stock, while carmakers Daimler, BMW, and Volkswagen also fell. Despite this, shares in some sectors, like mining and healthcare, rose, and earnings growth helped preserve the market.

site_title: US-Mexico Nafta talks seen running into next week, autos unresolved
summary: US-Mexico talks on the revamped Nafta trade pact are set to continue into next week, despite unresolved issues, including rules of origin for autos and dispute resolution mechanisms. The talks aim to address US President Donald Trump's concerns that the current pact has undercut US manufacturing to Mexico's benefit. Mexico's economy minister Ildefonso Guajardo expressed caution, saying the two sides are "well advanced" but not yet agreed. Canada's re-entry into the negotiations depends on resolving these issues, with Canadian foreign minister Chrystia Freeland emphasizing the need for Canada's satisfaction with new rules of origin.

site_title: US: Wall St weighed by new round of US-China tariffs
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday due to a new round of US-China tariffs, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 76.62 points, or 0.3%, to 25,656.98. Trade-sensitive stocks like Caterpillar and Boeing fell, while the technology sector rose 0.2% despite the overall decline. The US-China trade dispute and potential political fallout from former Trump advisers weighed on investor sentiment. Despite jobless claims falling for the third straight week, investors are cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting in Jackson Hole, where Chair Jerome Powell will speak on Friday.

site_title: ABB weighs sale of power grid unit as value swells
summary: ABB Ltd is considering the sale of its power grid unit amid a surge in its value, estimated at around $10.2 billion. The division's productivity and margin gains have led to the increase in valuation, making it about one-fifth of ABB's overall market capitalization. ABB's board, including top shareholder Investor AB, is open to offers, but the company isn't running a formal sale process. The decision comes after CEO Ulrich Spiesshofer's initial plans for the business were questioned.

images.alt_text: ABB Ltd is considering the sale of its power grid unit amid a surge in the value of the asset, according to people with knowledge of the matter, signaling a potential reversal in chief executive officer Ulrich Spiesshofer's plans for the business.

site_title: US-China trade talks end with no breakthrough as tariffs kick in
summary: US and Chinese officials ended two days of talks on trade with no major breakthrough, despite activation of additional tariffs on $16 billion worth of goods. The talks, led by US Treasury Under Secretary David Malpass and Chinese Commerce Vice Minister Wang Shouwen, aimed to address structural issues in China, including intellectual property and technology transfer policies. China has filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization, and the conflict raises concerns about global economic growth, with economists estimating a 0.5% reduction in global trade for every $100 billion of imports hit by tariffs.

site_title: Australian dollar may be en route to 70 US cents
summary: Australia's dollar is expected to drop to a two-year low of 70 US cents amid infighting in the ruling party, threatening policy paralysis. The currency has weakened over 10% this year, and money managers are becoming increasingly bearish due to the trade dispute between Australia and China, and a widening interest-rate differential in favor of the US. Experts predict the Aussie will decline further to around 71.25 US cents, but some asset managers believe it will stay above 70 US cents.

site_title: Defying the present: watches of tomorrow
summary: Zenith's Defy collection marks the future of watch-making with its modern and complex designs. The brand's revolutionary timepieces, including the Defy El Primero 21 and Defy Lab, have set a new benchmark in mechanical watch-making. The Defy Classic, a gateway to Zenith's futuristic universe, features a three-hand watch with a date, a titanium case, and a blackened skeletal movement. The Defy Zero G, a limited-edition watch, nullifies gravity's effect on the watch's running rate using a patented "Gravity Control" module. Zenith's innovative designs showcase the brand's commitment to pushing the boundaries of watch-making.

site_title: Vast potential for Singapore and Chongqing tech firms to cooperate: ESM Goh
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong of Singapore emphasized the vast potential for tech companies to cooperate between Singapore and Chongqing, China, during the opening ceremony of the Smart China Expo. The Chongqing Connectivity Initiative aims to spur growth in China's western region by enhancing transport and trade links, with a focus on the ICT arena. Goh highlighted the benefits of increased ICT connectivity, including boosted physical and digital trade between Singapore and China, and the growth of China's ICT market to US$880 billion by 2025.

site_title: Belmont Rd GCB fetches S$33.8m or S$2,243 psf
summary: A newly completed bungalow in Singapore's Belmont Road has been sold for S$33.8 million, or S$2,243 per square foot, on a 15,069.46 sq ft freehold land area. The buyer is Kady Leyau, a former model and VJ, who is married to billionaire Richard Chandler. The sale, which is one of the highest prices paid for a Sentosa Cove bungalow since 2013, follows a similar S$33.3 million deal for a bungalow in Sentosa Cove.

site_title: Versatility is key here
summary: Panerai has introduced the Luminor Due 3 Days Automatic, a slim and versatile watch line with cases as small as 38mm in diameter, making it the smallest in the brand. The watches, available in stainless steel or red gold, feature cases as thin as 10.5mm and come in various colors for the dials and straps. This new collection is part of the Luminor Due line, which was introduced in 2016 and was also slim. The watches are designed to be versatile, appealing to a wide range of customers.

site_title: China's soy sauce king Haitian sees profitable 2018
summary: China's largest soy sauce maker, Haitian Flavouring & Food Co, saw a profitable 2018 with a 66% surge in its Shanghai-listed shares over the past 12 months. The company's growth is attributed to the booming catering industry in China, with its sales from the domestic market accounting for 60% of its revenue. Haitian's strong rally is justified by its stable cash flow and growth potential, with analysts assigning a valuation premium of 43 times earnings forecast for this year.

site_title: Insurer AIA posts 17% rise in 1st-half new business value
summary: AIA Group Ltd reported a 17% rise in new business value for the first half of the year, reaching US$1.95 billion. This surge is attributed to the sale of high-margin insurance products in Hong Kong and China, where AIA has a significant presence. The company's business in Asia-Pacific, with a focus on Hong Kong and China, has contributed to the growth. AIA's value of new business has increased from US$1.61 billion in the same period last year.

site_title: It's still unclear how Trump's Terrible Tuesday will end
summary: President Donald Trump's former lawyer Michael Cohen pleaded guilty to eight criminal charges, including tax evasion and campaign finance violations, admitting Trump directed him to arrange payments to women who had affairs with Trump during the 2016 campaign. Meanwhile, a jury in Virginia convicted former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort of eight charges related to bank and tax fraud, after four days of deliberations. The guilty verdicts raise concerns about Trump's involvement in campaign finance and potential wrongdoing, but the exact implications and consequences of these events remain unclear.

site_title: For sale: Welsh castle, comes with its own 'fire-breathing dragon'
summary: A Welsh castle, Castell Gyrn, is up for sale for £2.25 million, featuring 6 bedrooms, 3 reception rooms, and a 5,800 sq ft residence with panoramic views. The castle, renovated by owner Jeff Thompson, comes with a fire-breathing dragon sculpture that can be turned off, as well as a grotto and wildlife pond. Located 32 km from Chester, the property has been Thompson's permanent residence since 2005 and is now being sold due to downsizing in retirement.

site_title: Hall Of Beauty
summary: Takashimaya's beauty hall has undergone a significant makeover, featuring revamped counters, wider walkways, and new brands such as MDNA Skin and Chantecaille. Luxury skincare brands like Fresh, Shiseido, and Clé de Peau Beauté also have new spaces. The updated hall offers a more luxurious shopping experience, with a focus on high-end products and innovative retail concepts. The makeover aims to provide a more enjoyable and engaging shopping experience for customers, with a variety of products and services on offer.

site_title: Mid~Autumn Splendour
summary: TungLok Group has launched its 2018 range of healthier mooncakes, including the Lower Sugar Mooncake, which contains 30% less sugar than the original. The move is in line with the Health Promotion Board's Healthier Dining Programme guidelines. This initiative aims to cater to the growing number of health-conscious Singaporeans who are watching their sugar intake during the Mid-Autumn Festival.

site_title: HG Metal commits to majority stake in joint venture in Myanmar
summary: HG Metal Manufacturing has agreed to take a majority stake in a joint venture in Myanmar, acquiring a 51.04% stake in First Fortune International Co for US$95,700. The venture will provide cut and bend, and fabrication services in the growing Myanmar market. HG Metal will pay US$1.95 million of the initial additional subscription, with the remaining US$9.3 million to be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings. The joint venture aims to capitalize on Myanmar's growing demand for steel products, with the facility expected to be a modern base for HG Metal's services in the country.

site_title: Palm oil watchdog needs to take giant leap to save forests
summary: A global watchdog for the palm oil industry, the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO), faces pressure to strengthen its standards to require all members to commit to ending deforestation by 2023. The organization aims to publish new guidelines in November, but critics argue that the current standards are not tough enough. Industry leaders and investors are urging the RSPO to adopt a "total commitment" to zero deforestation to maintain credibility and relevance in the industry.

site_title: Japaneses students go wild for botaoshi
summary: In Japan's Kaisei secondary school, the century-old game of botaoshi, a combination of American football, rugby, sumo, and martial arts, continues to be a rite of passage despite rising injury rates. The game, which involves pulling down a four-meter wooden pole, promotes teamwork, toughness, and sportsmanship. With over 50% increase in injuries from 2005 to 2016, the school has taken measures to improve safety, but the game remains a cherished tradition among students and alumni. Despite concerns, many parents trust the school's detailed rules and safety measures, allowing the game to endure.

site_title: A more affordable way to maintain your Lamborghini
summary: MR Tuning Asia, a new venture by luxury car workshops Exquisite Marques and Eurohaus, and Australian racing outfit McElrea Racing, aims to offer more affordable maintenance services for high-performance cars like Lamborghinis. The team, with combined decades of experience, believes its racing know-how can benefit the average customer, repairing cars quickly and efficiently, even faster than authorized dealers. MR Tuning Asia plans to differentiate itself with driver development programs and lower prices, offering personalized service and transparency.

site_title: Past 12 months have been sweet for China's soy sauce maker
summary: China's soy sauce maker, FOSHAN Haitian Flavouring & Food Co, has seen a 66% surge in shares over the past 12 months, making it one of the top performers among global consumer stocks. The company's strong rally is attributed to booming growth in China's catering industry, with Haitian's profits growing over 20% for seven consecutive quarters. Analysts justify the valuation premium, citing the growth potential of China's catering industry and Haitian's stable cash flow.

images.alt_text: Haitian's profits grow as Chinese consumers dine out more often.

site_title: Reviving a legendary dive watch with an alarm
summary: Jaeger-LeCoultre marks the 50th anniversary of the Polaris Memovox with a new sports collection, featuring six Polaris timepieces, including a limited edition model with an alarm function. The iconic watch, launched in 1968, was the world's first diving watch with an alarm feature. The new collection includes the Polaris Memovox, Polaris Automatic, Polaris Chronograph, Polaris Date, Polaris Geographic WT, and Polaris Chronograph WT, with prices ranging from S$10,300 to S$36,000. The watches blend vintage elegance with modern sporty design, paying tribute to the original Polaris Memovox's innovative alarm feature.

site_title: Greek Odyssey still has some way to go
summary: Greece has officially exited its third bailout, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras celebrating the end of a "modern-day Odyssey". However, the economic reality is more complicated, with growth of around 2% per year insufficient to achieve normality, and significant structural weaknesses persisting, including high unemployment and a lack of foreign investment. To sustain its debt burden, Greece must run high primary budget surpluses until 2060, and policymakers must reform to address these issues, rather than simply celebrating the bailout exit.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Construction firm Lian Beng Group's subsidiary, United Tec Construction, has secured a S$278.5 million contract to develop 955 residential units in Silat Avenue. The project includes landscaping, carparks, and communal facilities. This contract marks a significant win for United Tec Construction, with the development expected to be completed in the near future.

site_title: Swiss watch exports post best half-yearly showing in six years
summary: Swiss watch exports posted their strongest first-half growth in six years, with global shipments increasing 10.5% to 10.5 billion Swiss francs in January-June. Asia drove the growth, accounting for 90% of the global rise, with Singapore being the eighth-largest market for Swiss watches. Hong Kong remained the largest market, with exports surging 29.5%. The Swiss watch industry's growth was tempered by a decline in European markets, with exports to the UK and Italy falling 10.9% and 13.3% respectively. The Swatch group reported record half-year sales, with net sales rising 14.7% to 4.3 billion Swiss francs.

site_title: Indonesia wants foreigners to own less of its bonds in long run
summary: Indonesia aims to halve foreign ownership of its sovereign bonds in five years, aiming for 20% local ownership, to shield assets from external shocks. The move comes as the country seeks to reduce reliance on foreign inflows to finance its current account and budget deficits. The government plans to keep 70-75% of new bond issuance in local currency debt, with the earliest switch to rupiah-denominated bonds set for 2023. Experts warn it will be challenging to achieve due to the lack of depth in the local market.

site_title: Deutsche Bank threatens to end business with Russia
summary: Deutsche Bank has threatened to end its business with the Russian government unless it submits documents to refresh its Know-Your-Customer information. The bank's London branch sent a letter to Moscow in June stating that it would terminate its business relationship if necessary documents are not received within 30 days. This move follows previous fines from UK and US authorities for compliance failures, including helping wealthy Russians move $10 billion out of the country. The bank's CEO, Christian Sewing, has recently appointed a new COO, Frank Kuhnke, to improve KYC procedures.

site_title: When all you want is sleep...
summary: Singaporeans are among the world's most sleep-deprived people, averaging 6 hours and 32 minutes of sleep per night, significantly below the recommended 8-9 hours. A 2014 survey ranked Singapore as the third most sleep-deprived city, while a 2018 survey placed it second. ENT specialist Dr. Kenny Pang attributes the issue to stress and increasing work demands, with sleep disorder cases doubling in the past decade. This sleep deprivation has severe consequences, including irritability and decreased productivity, affecting millions of Singaporeans.

site_title: Forward earnings estimates pared as Q2 figures underwhelm
summary: Singapore's listed companies reported combined earnings of S$21.1 billion in Q2, down 8.8% from a year ago. Banks drove the earnings performance, with a 19% year-on-year increase, but growth is expected to taper due to a slowdown in mortgage and trade loans. Offshore and marine earnings remained weak, and technology firms saw a 30% year-on-year improvement in net profit. The market expects earnings growth to slow in late 2018 and 2019 due to weaker economic growth and trade war concerns, with analysts cutting forward earnings estimates.

site_title: Singapore fuel oil inventories at 9-year low
summary: Singapore's fuel oil inventories plummeted to a 9-year low in the week ended Aug 22, dropping 7% to 14.233 million barrels, or 2.124 million tonnes. This is the lowest level since July 30, 2009. The decline was attributed to reduced net imports of fuel oil, averaging 748,000 tonnes per week in 2018. Industry participants expect arbitrage supplies to gradually recover in the coming weeks as demand from the Middle East starts to wind down.

site_title: Asian Sensations
summary: The US$30 million film "Crazy Rich Asians" is the first major American studio release in 25 years to feature a predominantly Asian cast. Directed by Jon M Chu, the rom-com adaptation of Kevin Kwan's novel stars Constance Wu and Henry Golding as an economics professor and her boyfriend who attend a wedding in Singapore, where she faces cultural shock from the wealthy Asian community. The film's cast includes Pierre Png, Koh Chieng Mun, and Fiona Xie, marking a milestone in representation in Hollywood.

site_title: Investors dump Qantas even after record profit as fuel bill, wages rise
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd dropped 2.8% in Sydney after reporting a record annual profit despite concerns over rising fuel prices and costs. The airline's fuel bill is expected to jump 21% this financial year, and wages and aircraft leases will become more onerous. CEO Alan Joyce assured investors that Qantas can "substantially recover" the higher fuel costs, particularly in the domestic market. The airline will also redirect international capacity to Asia and explore non-stop flights to London. Despite the concerns, Qantas remains the best-performing airline in 2018, with a 30% gain this year.

site_title: Bell and Good
summary: Violin virtuoso Joshua Bell returns to the Singapore Chinese Orchestra (SCO) on August 30 at the Esplanade Concert Hall, playing the classic Chinese work "The Butterfly Lovers' Violin Concerto". Conducted by Yeh Tsung, the performance will be recorded live by Sony Classics. This marks Bell's second performance with SCO, following his debut in 2016. The concert features a Western-style orchestra and solo violin, and tickets are available from Sistic.

site_title: COE prices lower in 2nd bidding for August
summary: COE premiums in Singapore closed lower across the board in the second round of bidding for August. The COE price for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp dropped 5.6% to S$32,429, while cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp saw a 5.3% decrease to S$31,997. Motorcycle premiums fell 11% to S$4,889, the lowest since August last year. The removal of motorcycle COEs from the open category and increased quotas for motorcycles may be contributing factors.

site_title: The new Santos gets a modern makeover
summary: The Cartier Santos, a modern wristwatch designed specifically for outdoor adventurous purposes, has undergone a modern makeover. Introduced in 1904, the watch features a square case and was created to address Alberto Santos-Dumont's difficulty in checking the time while flying. The latest reincarnation boasts sleeker lines, a straightened bezel, and a water-resistant design up to 100 meters. The watch now comes with interchangeable straps and bracelets, a new in-house movement, and various metal options, with prices ranging from $6,250 to $43,200.

site_title: Some like it hot
summary: Michael Chiang's gender-bending comedy "Private Parts" is set to return to the stage in Singapore, 26 years after its initial production. Directed by Ong Keng Sen, the play tells a non-sexual romance between a male TV presenter and a transgender man undergoing a sex-change operation. The revival is seen as a reflection of how sexuality was viewed in the early 1990s, with the producers intentionally capturing the zeitgeist of the era. The new production aims to spark discussions on the topic of sexuality, now charged with conversations in the developed world.

site_title: Khazanah not currently in talks to sell stake in joint ventures with Temasek
summary: Khazanah Nasional Bhd, a Malaysian state-linked fund, is not currently in talks to sell its stake in joint ventures with Temasek Holdings. The speculation resurfaced in a report by a Malaysian newspaper, but both parties have denied any discussions. Khazanah may consider selling its stake in M+S Pte Ltd and Pulau Indah Ventures in the future, but not now, as it awaits the stabilization of yields from office assets. Market sources believe Khazanah will hold out until it books sales of residential and commercial space.

site_title: Meat vending machines may be the next cool thing
summary: New York - Meat vending machines may become the next innovative food option, providing a convenient way to access raw steak. Unlike traditional vending machines, these machines would deliver edible meat, catering to those following specific diets or seeking a unique eating experience. The concept is seen as a game-changer in the food industry, offering a ready-to-eat option that was previously considered unsuitable for vending machines.

site_title: Singtel, DBS lead Singapore stocks rally
summary: Singapore stocks rallied 1.6% to a 3,249.89-point close, led by Singtel's 6.5% surge and DBS's 2.2% gain. The Straits Times Index advanced 50 points, with about 1.47 billion shares changing hands. Investors are cautious due to a lack of fresh ideas and unclear implications from TPG Telecom's proposed merger with Vodafone Hutchison in Australia.

site_title: Going beyond 100% ethical gold
summary: CHOPARD has committed to using only ethical gold in its products, sourced from responsible mines that meet global best practice environmental and social standards. The luxury watch and jewelry company will source gold from the Swiss Better Gold Association, Fairmined, and Fairtrade schemes, or RJC-certified refineries. This move aims to promote environmental and social responsibility among gold-mine operators, following Chopard's recent decision to prioritize ethical sourcing.

site_title: Singtel shares surge 6.5% on potential union of Australia telecom rivals
summary: Singtel shares surged 6.5% after Vodafone Hutchison Australia Pty and TPG Telecom Ltd announced exploratory discussions for a potential merger. This could reduce competition in Australia, where Singtel generates over half of its revenues. Analysts believe a deal would be positive for Singtel's Australian business, Optus, and upgrade Singtel to outperform. Meanwhile, Singtel is examining a possible bid for Amaysim Australia Ltd to gain access to its 1.1 million mobile subscribers.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental hits South America amid push to open new hotels
summary: Mandarin Oriental is opening its first hotel in Santiago, Chile, in early 2019, bypassing Sao Paulo due to lower crime rates. The 310-room hotel will be refurbished and rebranded as a Mandarin Oriental. The company plans to open its second location in Vina del Mar in 2020, part of a strategy to double global locations. Chile's growing luxury market, low crime levels, and high occupancy rates in the hotel industry have made it an attractive location, with 22 new hotels under construction in Santiago by 2022.

site_title: Timely showcase
summary: Baselworld watch fair in Switzerland saw the launch of new timepieces with modern high-precision movements, including Rolex's Pepsi GMT-Master II and Omega's Seamaster, powered by new Master Chronometer movements. Patek Philippe's Nautilus and Aquanaut models received updates with perpetual calendars and flyback chronographs. Cartier introduced a new Santos model with easily detachable strap and bracelet mechanisms. The trend towards affordable luxury in the watch world continued, with Vacheron Constantin's new FiftySix line and Zenith's Defy Classic line. Smart watches also gained popularity, with Hublot's connected timepiece and TAG Heuer's digital watch. Women's watches saw significant growth, with Bulgari and other brands unveiling new models.

site_title: Who needs a car showroom? Public spaces are the way to go now
summary: BMW is hosting its "BMW World Of Passion And Joy" event in Singapore, featuring 34 BMW and Mini cars, including historical models and future releases, at the Suntec Singapore Convention and Exhibition Centre. The event, priced at S$20 per ticket, aims to showcase the brand's heritage and upcoming models, while also allowing potential buyers to interact with the brand. Similar events are being planned by rival brands Audi and Kia to reach consumers in public spaces, highlighting the shift in marketing strategies for luxury car brands.

site_title: Fun fare at Kinou
summary: Kinou, a small plates restaurant in Singapore, has gained popularity with its carnival vibe and easy-going food. The restaurant offers a variety of dishes, including ceviches, tartares, and burgers, in small portions meant to be shared. Chef-owner Benjamin Tilatti's menu features creative names and descriptions, such as "Taste of Brine" and "Prawning Spot." Despite some dishes being underseasoned, the food is generally fresh and flavorful. Kinou is not a fine dining spot, but rather a fun dining experience where customers can enjoy cocktails and casual eats in a lively atmosphere. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: More personal information up for sale in China
summary: In China, private data is being sold to insurance companies, banks, and loan sharks, despite penalties. William Zhang received multiple calls from his insurance company, Ping An Insurance Group, to renew his car insurance before it expired. This practice is common, with Zhang receiving calls almost daily. The sale of private data is a concern, as it raises questions about data protection and security.

site_title: Euro falls as US dollar snaps losing streak
summary: The US dollar snapped a five-day losing streak, rising 0.3% to 95.415, driven by political uncertainty, new trade tariffs, and the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes signaling a September rate rise. The euro fell 0.3% to US$1.1559, while the Australian dollar dropped 0.8% and the yen fell 0.3% on safe-haven demand for the US dollar. The Fed's minutes showed officials discussed raising rates soon and examined the impact of global trade disputes on businesses and households.

site_title: Saudis kill Aramco IPO; oil giant disbands advisers
summary: Saudi Arabia has canceled plans for the domestic and international listing of state oil giant Aramco, a move that was expected to be the biggest stock flotation in history. The decision comes after financial advisers working on the planned listing were disbanded, and the kingdom shifts its attention to a proposed acquisition of a strategic stake in Saudi Basic Industries Corp. The listing was a key part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's reform drive, but the valuation of Aramco at $2 trillion or more was questioned by industry experts, hindering the process.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia has called off plans for the domestic and international listing of state oil giant Aramco, billed as the biggest stock flotation in history, four senior industry sources said on Wednesday.

site_title: BMW i3s review: Let the sparks fly
summary: The BMW i3s is a sportier variant of the i3 electric city car, featuring a carbon-fibre chassis, wacky doors, and enhanced acceleration. The i3s boasts a 184hp electric motor, wider tyres, and a lower suspension, making it more confident in corners. It excels in urban driving with strong acceleration and smooth steering, but requires extra concentration at high speeds. The i3s offers more cabin space and storage options, with a price tag of S$201,000, expected to launch in Q4 2018 with a S$20,000 premium.

site_title: Scene stealers
summary: Watch brands unveil new, feminine designs for 2018, focusing on horological icons such as the Daytona, Reverso, Santos, Royal Oak, and Nautilus. Patek Philippe releases the Ladies Chronograph Ref 7150/250R and Calatrava Pilot Travel Time Ref 7234R, featuring elegant designs and in-house movements. Rolex introduces the Daytona Ref 116595RBOW and Datejust 31 Ref 278288RBR, showcasing luxury and style. Audemars Piguet releases a stunning yellow gold Royal Oak Selfwinding watch with a blue dial, while Chopard's Happy Sport watch features glittering diamonds moving freely around its dial. Bulgari's Octo Finissimo Automatic Sandblasted and Omega's Seamaster Aqua Terra Jewellery are also introduced, offering unique designs and precision movements. Cartier's Revelation d'Une Panthère is a one-of-a-kind masterpiece combining art and watchmaking.

site_title: Tough cookies
summary: Luminox has released its Navy SEAL 3580 series, a collection of five timepieces inspired by the US Navy SEALs. The new series features a chronograph function and Carbonox casing, designed to withstand tough obstacles. The collection's name, "The Only Easy Day Was Yesterday," reflects the SEALs' mantra of working harder each day. The updated timepieces aim to provide a durable and reliable companion for those who face challenging situations.

site_title: Eunice Olsen
summary: Eunice Olsen, a Singaporean politician and media executive, has published a book titled "I'm A Girl, See What I Can Be" that celebrates the stories of high-achieving women through poetry. The book features interviews with women like Paralympic bronze medallist swimmer Theresa Goh and features illustrations by differently-abled artists. Olsen aims to empower young readers and promote gender equality, citing the need for meaningful change in society. She has also expressed her desire to direct a film centered around empowering women and has been involved in various initiatives, including Space For Humanity, a US non-profit organization aiming to democratize space.

site_title: Fed poised to keep raising rates to historically normal levels
summary: The Federal Reserve is set to continue gradually raising interest rates to return them to historically normal levels, despite President Donald Trump's calls to pause rate hikes. Fed officials are monitoring for signs of economic fallout from Trump's trade policies, particularly the impact on the residential construction market. The Fed has left interest rates unchanged, but plans to raise them again in September, the third time this year. Officials expressed concerns over the potential effects of trade disputes on business sentiment, investment spending, and employment, but are waiting to see evidence of damage in the data.

site_title: Remaining in perfect shape, 50 years on
summary: Patek Philippe is celebrating the 50th anniversary of its Golden Ellipse watch, launched in 1968 as the brand's second oldest line after the Calatrava. The thinnest watch in Patek's collections, the Golden Ellipse boasts a slim elegance and quirky style that has made it an attractive dress watch. Despite initial reservations, the timepiece has maintained its perfect shape over five decades, solidifying its place in Patek Philippe's iconic collections.

site_title: Novartis trial win lifts profile of new breast cancer drug
summary: Novartis announced a trial win for its breast cancer drug BYL719, which, when combined with hormone therapy, improved survival chances for patients. The Swiss drugmaker said the investigational medicine slowed disease progression. Analysts predict BYL719 will play a leading role in advanced breast cancer treatment. The success of BYL719 is a significant development for Novartis, elevating the profile of the new breast cancer drug.

site_title: US, China impose new tariffs on each other as talks resume
summary: The US and China have imposed new tariffs on each other's goods, with the US collecting 25% duties on Chinese imports worth $16 billion and China retaliating with a similarly sized tax on US imports. Trade talks resumed in Washington, with US Treasury Undersecretary David Malpass and Chinese Vice-Commerce Minister Wang Shouwen meeting for the first face-to-face discussions since June. The talks are expected to result in a joint statement, but the outcome is uncertain amid ongoing divisions within the Trump administration.

images.alt_text: A restaurant in Guangzhou has a poster depicting the US president and stating that all US customers will be charged 25 per cent more than other customers starting from the day that Mr Trump started the trade war with China.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: StarHub's new CEO, Peter Kaliaropoulos, has outlined strategic priorities to leverage the group's consumer and enterprise businesses. Management will defend its high-value mobile subscribers and expects data consumption to increase in Singapore. The company aims to adopt a variable cost model for pay-TV content. Despite competition from TPG Telecom, StarHub remains optimistic about its prospects, with a target price of S$1.82.

site_title: Favourites and key creations
summary: Wihelm Schmid, CEO of A Lange & Sohne, reveals his affinity for chronographs, citing their interactivity and hands-on nature. His favorite watch, the Datograph Up/Down, was launched in 2011 and features improved power reserve and a power reserve indicator. The original Datograph, launched in 1999, remains a significant model, while the Lange 1, the brand's signature model, is considered an icon and continues to drive success. The Lange Zeitwerk, introduced in 2009, is another key creation under Schmid's watch.

site_title: Skoda Octavia review: Five doors for the price of four
summary: The Skoda Octavia is a roomy and feature-packed saloon that offers five doors at a price comparable to its rivals, despite being a hatchback. With a 590-litre boot and ample space for rear passengers, the Octavia is a comfortable and practical choice. Although it may not be the most premium in its class, its soft suspension and refinement make for a smooth driving experience. Priced at S$108,400, the Octavia is a bargain for its features, making it an attractive option for Singaporeans who value value for money.

site_title: Alibaba's revenue surges as Jack Ma's free spending bears fruit
summary: Alibaba reported its fastest revenue growth in over four years, with a 61% increase to 80.9 billion yuan (S$16.1 billion) in the three months ended June. The company's growth was driven by its expansion into cloud computing and entertainment, avoiding the disappointments of rival tech giants. This growth was in line with the average estimate, solidifying Alibaba's position as China's largest e-commerce company.

site_title: Philippines' San Miguel plans US$2.7b share sale in food unit, shares soar
summary: San Miguel Corp, a Philippine conglomerate, plans to sell a US$2.7 billion stake in its food and beverage unit, San Miguel Food and Beverage Inc, through a share sale. The share sale is part of the parent firm's asset restructuring plan to inject its food and beverage assets into the unit. Shares of San Miguel Corp and San Miguel Food and Beverage rose 7.5% and 13% respectively, reaching multi-year highs, with the sale expected to increase the company's public float.

site_title: BYO Music
summary: Royal Caribbean International has launched SoundSeeker, a tool that transforms travellers' photos into original, shareable soundtracks with matching videos. Users can upload three photos and AI will analyze them to create a unique track inspired by 90s hip-hop, rock, and electronic dance music. The tool can generate over one million unique tracks, allowing users to share multisensory holiday memories. This is part of Royal Caribbean's effort to provide a unique spin on sharing memories.

site_title: Stealing the spotlight
summary: Rolex has introduced its latest GMT-Master II collection, featuring a new steel case, red and blue ceramic bezel, and powered by a new automatic movement (calibre 3285). The watch is available in 40mm stainless steel, with a recommended retail price of US$9,250, and is certified a Superlative Chronometer. The new GMT-Master II has a distinctive Jubilee-style bracelet, similar to the one used on past GMT-Master models, and is lighter and more affordable than its white gold counterpart.

site_title: Citic Securities H1 profit rises 13%
summary: Citic Securities Co Ltd, China's largest brokerage, reported a 13% increase in first-half net profit to 5.57 billion yuan (S$1.1 billion) due to steady growth in its securities investment and asset management businesses. Despite a turbulent stock market and depressed trading, Citic maintained its market share of brokerage services through its strong service culture. The company's net profit rose 10.3% in 2017, and its performance contrasts with a 40.5% decline in the total net profit of China's securities firms to 32.9 billion yuan in the first half of 2018.

site_title: Horological jellyfish
summary: MB&F's latest timepiece, the Horological Machine No. 7 (HM7) "Aquapod," has been released with a titanium case and green sapphire crystal bezel. Inspired by a jellyfish, the watch features a flying tourbillon and unidirectional rotating bezel, and is water-resistant to 150 feet. The 53.8mm case houses a three-dimensional movement with 72 hours of power reserve, priced at $108,000. Limited to 50 pieces, the HM7 Aquapod is a unique aquatic timepiece that combines innovative design with technical expertise.

site_title: A brief history of Rolex's GMT-Master
summary: The Rolex GMT-Master watch was launched in 1955 for airline pilots, featuring a two-time-zone design with a rotating bezel and 24-hour graduated insert. The iconic watch was adopted by Pan Am as its official timepiece and was used on the first non-stop Pan Am Jet Clipper flight from New York to Moscow in 1959. Over the years, the GMT-Master has undergone several design changes, including the introduction of new materials and technologies, such as ceramic and PVD coatings, and has become a defining feature of Rolex watches.

images.alt_text: Left: The original Pepsi Oyster Perpetual GMT-Master, 1955. Right: Oyster Perpetual GMT-Master II, 2005.
The Coke in steel Oyster Perpetual GMT-Master II, 1982.
A Rolex advertising booklet from the 1950s.

site_title: Still crazy after all these years
summary: Franck Muller celebrates the 15th anniversary of its iconic "Crazy Hours" watch, which features a unique jumping hour mechanism. The brand also showcases its Skafander dive watch with a tonneau-shaped case and innovative features, as well as the Vanguard S6 Yachting, a pre-eminent horological masterpiece with a skeletonised dial and tourbillon. Meanwhile, Franck Muller's Vanguard Lady Gravity watch features a delicate tourbillon cage and a half-open work design. The brand offers various versions of the watches in different materials and sizes.

images.alt_text: Franck Muller's Crazy Hours in 40 variations marking its 15th anniversary.

site_title: Lunar wonder
summary: Omega celebrates the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 8 mission with a new "Dark Side of the Moon" watch, marking a significant milestone in the brand's history. The Speedmaster Professional was the first watch to land on the moon in 1969 and has since become iconic. A limited-edition "Dark Side of the Moon" watch was released in 2013, followed by variations in 2015 and 2017, including a 50th-anniversary edition with a hand-wound movement and a unique dial design. The new watch features a 44.25mm all-ceramic case and a skeletonised open-worked dial, paying tribute to the Apollo 8 mission and the moon's far side.

site_title: Wasting some time is good for you
summary: Researchers found that spending time idly can have benefits for mental health, creativity, and productivity. A study suggests that allowing for brief periods of downtime can help reduce stress, increase focus, and improve overall well-being. This concept challenges the traditional notion that every spare moment must be used productively, encouraging individuals to adopt a more balanced approach to time management. By embracing the value of "wasting time," people can potentially improve their quality of life and increase their efficiency in the long run.

site_title: Contingency plans announced if Britain crashes out with no Brexit deal
summary: The UK government has announced contingency plans for a no-deal Brexit, with 80% of the Withdrawal Agreement settled, according to Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab. Raab stated that the plans are to inform businesses and people about potential disruptions, but EU negotiators see this as a ploy to secure a better deal. The plans include 25 no-deal Brexit notices covering 80 contingencies, aiming to facilitate the smooth functioning of business and services despite a potential no-deal. Despite Raab's assurances, concerns persist about the impact on businesses and the public.

site_title: Integrated Shield Plans: sustainability and affordability are big issues
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield Plans face sustainability concerns due to rising medical costs and underwriting losses. The country's out-of-pocket healthcare expenditure is the second highest among 11 countries at 54.8%. Insurers are grappling with losses, and policyholders worry about premium affordability, particularly at older ages. To address these issues, policyholders can consider downgrading plans, comparing premiums, and switching insurers. The Health Ministry must also monitor premium increases and moderate them if needed, while a long-awaited medical fee benchmark is expected to help dampen costs.

site_title: Thrill Factor
summary: The Nevis Catapult, a bungee jump operated by AJ Hackett Bungy New Zealand, offers a unique experience in the remote Nevis Valley near Queenstown, New Zealand. The Catapult jump propels participants 150m out across a ravine at speeds of almost 100 km/h in 1.5 seconds, generating forces of up to 3G. Developed to international safety standards and regulated in New Zealand, the Catapult is priced at NZ$255 and available for booking on bungy.co.nz.

site_title: Trump plan prolongs life of coal plants
summary: The Trump administration's plan to ease carbon dioxide limits allows coal power plants to upgrade without installing pollution control systems, potentially prolonging their lives. This change could extend the lives of over 30% of ageing coal power plants, but also increases nitrogen oxide emissions by tens of thousands of tons annually. The proposal aligns with the New Source Review programme, making it harder to trigger requirements for better pollution-control systems, and has been met with criticism from environmental groups.

site_title: Ho Bee Land to buy London property with HSBC green loan
summary: Ho Bee Land, a Singaporean property investment and development firm, has secured a £200 million (S$352.9 million) green loan from HSBC to acquire a commercial development in London. This is Singapore's first green loan and will be used for the acquisition.

site_title: SMG's prospects worth a premium, says Spackman
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group raised its equity stake in Spackman Media Group (SMG) by acquiring shares at a significant premium, citing valuation reports and valuation of SMG's shares. SMG's value per share was estimated between US$4.70 to US$8, and the group plans to capitalize on SMG's platform to participate in top-quality entertainment content projects. Spackman also intends to continue expanding its equity stake in SMG, with its interim CEO and CFO sitting on the board of SMG.

site_title: Singaporeans spent US$4.6b in cross-border real estate transactions
summary: Singaporean investors spent US$4.6 billion on cross-border real estate transactions from the second quarter of 2018, with US$3.3 billion invested in Australian real estate, a 32% year-over-year increase. This ranks Singaporean investors as the second-most active in the Asia-Pacific region. The majority of their investments were in Chinese and Australian real estate.

site_title: The All-Bling Rolex Daytona
summary: The Rolex Daytona "Rainbow" is an extremely luxurious and expensive timepiece, featuring 56 brilliant-cut diamonds, 11 baguette-cut sapphires on the dial, and 36 baguette-cut sapphires on the bezel. Made of Everose gold, this model is the most expensive in the Daytona collection, showcasing a unique rainbow gradation on the bezel. The chronograph counters are set in pink gold crystals, adding to the watch's exceptional bling.

site_title: US-China trade war: Beijing has three options
summary: US-China trade tensions escalate with the imposition of $50 billion worth of US tariffs on Chinese goods by the end of the month. Beijing has three options to retaliate: restricting US business activity in China, devaluing the yuan, or selling US Treasuries. Analysts predict the yuan may be devalued, but a currency war is unlikely due to China's deleveraging efforts. The trade dispute is expected to have a broader impact on Asian economies, with South Korea's GDP slowing due to exports and private consumption.

site_title: China's robot industry dampened by US-China tariff war
summary: China's robot industry is being impacted by the US-China tariff war, with annualized growth rates dropping from 35.1% in May to 6.3% in July. Analysts attribute the slowdown to the tariffs on industrial machinery and robot parts, as well as domestic manufacturers deferring production during trade talks. The US has imposed $16 billion in tariffs on Chinese goods, including electronics and auto parts, which require automated manufacturing and robots. Chinese robotics manufacturers are concerned about further US tariffs on consumer goods, which could worsen their situation.

images.alt_text: An AvatarMind iPal humanoid robot on display at the World Robot Conference in Beijing last week. The robots are built to be futuristic retail workers, teacher's assistants and household helpers.

site_title: Rest And Relax
summary: A range of sleep retreats and programs are available globally, focusing on improving sleep quality and addressing underlying issues. These retreats, developed in collaboration with sleep experts, offer customized treatments, meals, and activities to enhance sleep. Some notable programs include Six Senses' "Sleep with Six Senses," Kamalaya's Sleep Enhancement Wellness Programme, Revivo Resorts' Sleep Well Retreat, and Four Seasons Resort Bali's Sacred Nap. These retreats cater to various needs, from insomnia to stress and digital addiction, and aim to provide sustainable sleep solutions for guests.

site_title: Thai Food Trail
summary: The Chang Sensory Trails food festival, now in its third edition, will take place on August 31 and September 1 at The Lawn at Marina Bay. Eight Thai restaurants in Singapore have collaborated to serve family recipes, featuring 24 dishes such as Thai-style prime ribs, fried shrimp and pork paste toast, and watermelon fried rice. Local bands 53A and O.K Ready! will also perform during the event. The festival is organized by the Thai beer brand and can be found on Facebook.

site_title: Galaxy of Features
summary: Samsung has unveiled the Galaxy Note9, a new phone designed for power users. The device features a 4,000mAh battery, up to 512GB of internal memory, and a Bluetooth-enabled S Pen for enhanced functionality. The camera also boasts an intelligent AI system for optimal settings and a flaw detection feature. The phone will be available starting August 25 at various retailers, priced at S$1398 for the 128GB version and S$1728 for the 512GB version.

site_title: Striking figures
summary: Bulgari has introduced two new models, Lvcea Tubogas and Lvcea Skeleton, to its Lvcea collection for ladies, which was first introduced in 2014. The Lvcea Tubogas features the iconic Tubogas bracelet and comes in five versions, including a 28mm stainless steel case with a black lacquer dial, a 33mm steel case with a white mother-of-pearl dial, and a rose gold piece with diamonds on the bezel and bracelet. The new models pay homage to Bulgari's heritage as a jeweller.

site_title: Northern Exposure
summary: Nami, a Japanese restaurant at the Shangri-La Hotel in Singapore, presents a seasonal Hokkaido omakase menu from August 23 to September 3, featuring the freshest ingredients from various prefectures in Japan's northern island. The eight-course menu, priced at $200 per person, showcases authentic omakase experiences with high-quality seafood from Hokkaido, including dobinmushi, sweet snow crab, and Bafun sea urchin. The menu is available daily, with seafood flown in four times a week from Tokyo's Tsukiji market.

site_title: Goldman in sell-and-leaseback deal for its London office
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to sell and lease back its new London headquarters to Korea's National Pension Service for £1.16 billion. The 10-storey building, valued at £1.16 billion, will be leased back for at least two decades, solidifying Goldman's presence in London despite Brexit uncertainty. The deal is the second-largest in London this year, following the sale of the Walkie Talkie tower for £1.28 billion. The sale is part of Goldman's efforts to raise funds and cash in on demand from Asian investors for UK property.

site_title: New A*Star facility enables firms to test advanced manufacturing technologies
summary: A*Star in Singapore has launched the Model Factory, a facility allowing companies to test advanced manufacturing technologies. The facility houses over 10 technologies, including virtual manufacturing and digitized assembly lines. Multinational firms such as Nestle, Procter & Gamble, and Shell have signed up to join the Advanced Remanufacturing and Technology Centre (ARTC) as industry members, aiming to improve productivity and meet fast-changing consumer needs. The Model Factory is expected to attract companies from various sectors, including retail and services, and will offer services to companies that need to test-bed advanced manufacturing methods.

site_title: Move over, sushi and sashimi
summary: Kappo cuisine, a traditional Japanese fine dining style, is gaining popularity in Singapore, with several new restaurants opening their doors. Esora, Yoshi, and Takayama are among the latest ventures, offering intimate kappo-style dining experiences with modern twists. Chef Shigeru Koizumi's Esora combines traditional techniques with modern tools and ingredients, while Yoshi and Takayama focus on casual, omakase-style dining with seasonal produce. Kappo Shunsui, a 19-seater restaurant, aims to introduce authentic Japanese cuisine to a wider audience at a reasonable price. These restaurants are set to add a new dimension to Singapore's Japanese dining scene.

site_title: Yesterday Once More
summary: Photographer Darren Soh's exhibition "Before It All Goes: Architecture from Singapore's Early Independence Years" showcases iconic buildings set for demolition, including People's Park Complex, Golden Mile Complex, and others. The 50-image exhibition runs from Aug 24 to Sept 29 at Objectifs, Chapel Gallery, highlighting the disappearing Singaporean landscape and the evolving role of development. Soh aims to spark a conversation about shared social memories of these structures.

site_title: Suzuki Swift review: Delivering a swift kick
summary: The Suzuki Swift has made a successful return to the market, offering a fun and zesty driving experience despite some compromises. Powered by a turbocharged three-cylinder engine, the Swift accelerates quickly to 100km/h in 10 seconds. Its handling is agile, but the ride can be jittery and the engine buzzes at idle. The car offers a habitable space in the back and a decent boot, but its price has been pushed up by a S$10,000 pollution surcharge, making it less competitive. Despite this, the Swift remains a great option for first-time car buyers or those seeking a fun, uncomplicated driving experience.

site_title: A new sporty model
summary: FP Journe has unveiled the Chronographe Monopoussoir Rattrapante, the third model in the lineSport collection, a sports line introduced in 2011. The watch features a new hand-wound movement, calibre 1518, with a split-second chronograph and rattrapante function. Available in platinum, red gold, and titanium, the watch boasts a 44mm case and 80-hour power reserve. The design updates the traditional leather-strapped FP Journe watch with a metal bracelet, reflecting the sports line's focus on lightweight materials.

site_title: A collection which does Minerva proud
summary: Montblanc celebrates the 160th birthday of Swiss watch manufacturer Minerva, known for its chronographers and professional timepieces. To mark the occasion, Montblanc released 13 new timepieces, including two new in-house movements, as part of the Montblanc 1858 Collection. Inspired by Minerva's 1920s-1930s military and mountain exploration watches, the collection features vintage designs, innovative complications, and robust materials. The standout piece is the Montblanc 1858 Geosphere, a world-time complication powered by a new automatic movement, paying homage to the Seven Summits Challenge.

site_title: Time to impeach Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump's longtime fixer Michael Cohen has pleaded guilty to violating campaign finance laws, allegedly conspiring with Trump to commit crimes to influence the 2016 election. Cohen admitted to paying hush money to two women "in coordination with and at the direction of a candidate for federal office," meeting the Constitution's standard for impeachment. This development changes the author's previous skepticism about impeaching Trump, who remains popular with tens of millions of Americans. Cohen's sentencing is set for December, and his lies under oath raise questions about his credibility.

site_title: Brexit-bound London beats global rivals to lure real estate cash
summary: London has regained its status as the top destination for international investors in commercial property, with foreign buyers spending £5.6 billion on the city's offices in the first half of 2018. The weak pound makes London a bargain compared to European cities, which have experienced their own property booms. This is a rare bright spot in Britain's Brexit process, which has seen investment dry up and economic growth slow. Strong demand for office space and a relative scarcity of supply have contributed to London's appeal.

site_title: eSports levels up as gaming goes pro
summary: E-Sports is rapidly becoming a professional sport, with viewership numbers and prize money rising. Games like League of Legends, Counterstrike, and Overwatch have massive followings, leading to huge growth in the industry. Singapore is poised to play a significant role in this growth, with the city hosting pro-gaming events. The Asian high-yield space is also under scrutiny, and investors are taking note of the potential for growth in the e-Sports industry.

site_title: Get robo-invest advice with just S$3,500 investment
summary: OCBC Bank has launched its robo-investment service, OCBC RoboInvest, requiring a minimum initial investment of S$3,500. The service charges a 1.5% annual fee for AUM up to S$50,000 and 1% for amounts above. Investors can choose from 28 portfolios across six markets, with algorithms re-balancing assets quarterly or half-yearly. This launch follows a pilot run with accredited investors last year, and competitors such as StashAway and AutoWealth already offer low-cost robo-advising services in Singapore.

site_title: Grab to launch 200 EVs under SP Group partnership from next year
summary: Grab will introduce 200 new electric vehicles through its rental arm, GrabRentals, as part of a partnership with SP Group starting next year. The move aims to increase the availability of eco-friendly transportation options in Singapore.

site_title: Bayer's Monsanto sued by 8,000 plaintiffs on glyphosate
summary: Bayer's Monsanto faces nearly 8,000 US lawsuits over glyphosate-based weedkillers, with damages totaling $289 million awarded in the first case. Bayer shares have lost 10% since the verdict. The company plans to "vigorously defend" the cases and will provision for legal defense costs in its second-quarter results. Bayer CEO Werner Baumann stated that the number of plaintiffs is not indicative of the merits of the cases and demand for glyphosate-based products remains strong.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia narrows losses in Q4FY18
summary: Parkson Retail Asia narrowed its net loss in Q4FY18 to S$18.58 million from S$41.71 million, mainly due to lower expenses. Revenue dipped 3.1% to S$106.2 million, with negative same-store sales growth in Malaysia, Vietnam, and Myanmar. Despite this, the company expects improved performance in FY19 after closing underperforming stores and growing its topline. Net loss for FY18 reduced to S$42.39 million, and revenue remained nearly flat at S$413.89 million. Parkson aims to rebuild topline growth and monitor expenditure in FY19.

site_title: Fed debate on risks intensifies around post-September rate hikes
summary: US central bankers are intensifying their discussion on raising interest rates next month, with forecasts indicating strong labor markets and robust growth despite slightly above-target inflation. Chairman Jerome Powell plans to lift the benchmark lending rate, potentially putting it in a range of 2-2.25%, amid potential headwinds from trade disputes, waning fiscal stimulus, and financial instability. Despite scrutiny from President Trump, Fed officials view trade disputes as a significant source of uncertainty and risks, but see little tangible growth effect from trade tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 12.76 points to 1,810.87. The index saw a significant volume of 2.2 billion lots worth RM2.4 billion. Gainers narrowly outnumbered losers, 485 to 418.

site_title: Upgrades for two stars
summary: Patek Philippe has unveiled two new timepieces: the Nautilus Perpetual Calendar and the Aquanaut Flyback Chronograph. The Nautilus Perpetual Calendar features Patek Philippe's iconic perpetual calendar mechanism, while the Aquanaut Flyback Chronograph is the first chronograph in the Aquanaut family. Both watches boast sleek designs and advanced complications, with the Nautilus Perpetual Calendar priced at S$156,800 and the Aquanaut Flyback Chronograph retailing at S$57,700.

images.alt_text: Ref 5740 - Nautilus Perpetual Calendar from Patek Philippe.
Above, left: Patek's Ref 5968 - Aquanaut Chronograph in carrot orange strap. Above, right: Patek's Ref 5968 - Aquanaut Chronograph in Black Strap.

site_title: British Airways to suspend flights between London and Tehran
summary: British Airways is suspending flights between London and Tehran due to non-commercial viability. The route was reinstated in 2015 after a nuclear deal between western powers and Iran was reached. However, with US President Trump withdrawing from the deal and reimposing sanctions, the airline has deemed the operation unsustainable. The last outbound flight will be on September 22, and the last inbound flight on September 23.

site_title: OCBC launches robo-investment service for account holders
summary: OCBC Bank has launched OCBC RoboInvest, a robo-investment service for its account holders. The service uses WeInvest's technology and offers 28 investment portfolios across six markets, with fees ranging from 1.5% to 1% per annum. Investors can choose from defensive to high-risk portfolios and have access to a dashboard to monitor their investments. OCBC RoboInvest charges a minimum initial investment of S$3,500 and offers automatic rebalancing with customer consent. The service aims to provide low-cost investment options for OCBC account holders.

site_title: US banking profits hit record US$60b in Q2 - FDIC
summary: US banking profits reached a record $60.2 billion in Q2, a 25.1% increase from the same period last year. The majority of the gains came from lower effective tax rates and higher net interest income. Only 3.8% of banks reported net losses, while over 70% reported year-over-year growth. The FDIC attributed the increase to the new tax law, which boosted profits by 11.7% without its effect. FDIC Chairman Jelena McWilliams warned that intense competition could drive banks to take on more risk, while regulators reported a decline in problem banks to 82.

site_title: Want to be healthier? Pick up the pace
summary: A recent study found that walking at an "average" speed, below 20 minutes per mile, is associated with a 20% lower risk of death from heart disease and cancer compared to walking at a slow pace. Participants who walked briskly (below 18 minutes per mile) had an additional 4% lower mortality rate. The study, published in the British Journal of Sports Medicine, suggests that walking at a moderate pace is the most beneficial for health, with no effect on cancer rates. Experts recommend aiming for a pace that leaves you slightly out of breath.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
