summary: Singapore's inflation remained steady at 0.6% in July, with core inflation reaching its highest level in four years due to increased electricity and gas costs. Grab partnered with SP Group to power its new electric vehicle fleet, while Singaporean investors spent US$4.6 billion on cross-border real estate. CorpPass will become the single login method for businesses to transact with public sector services from September 1. Singapore shares rose 1.6% on Thursday, driven by a potential merger between Australian telecom rivals.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia narrows Q4 losses
summary: Parkson Retail Asia narrowed its Q4 net loss to S$18.58 million, down from S$41.71 million, due to lower expenses. Revenue decreased 3.1% to S$106.2 million, while loss per share fell to 2.76 Singapore cents from 6.19 Singapore cents last year. The company attributed the improvement to cost-cutting measures, including reduced impairment charges and store closures. Parkson expects its performance to improve in the coming financial year.

site_title: Alibaba revenue jumps 61% but one-time expense hits profit
summary: Alibaba reported a 61% revenue increase to 80.92 billion yuan in the latest quarter, driven by its core e-commerce segment. However, net profit declined 41% to 8.69 billion yuan due to a one-time compensation award. Despite concerns over China's slowing economy and the US-China trade war, Alibaba's revenue met analyst forecasts and CEO Daniel Zhang expressed confidence in the company's growth, citing significant user expansion and robust engagement across its ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Chinese retail giant Alibaba said on Thursday that its revenue jumped 61 per cent in the latest quarter as its core e-commerce segment chugged along, but profit for the period was dragged down by a one-off expense.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat, with Jackson Hole meet in focus
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday, with markets awaiting the outcome of the Jackson Hole economic symposium. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.07% to 25,714.86, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The US-China trade war continues to weigh on markets, with new tariffs taking effect. Investors are watching the Federal Reserve's stance on interest rate hikes, with some speculating about a potential rate cut.

site_title: ESR-Reit can be sponsor's platform for S-E Asian logistics assets
summary: ESR-Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (REIT), could serve as a platform for sponsor ESR to invest in South-east Asian logistics assets, according to ESR Director Jeffrey Perlman. Perlman emphasized the importance of building up ESR-Reit's scale to enjoy economies of scale, as larger REITs benefit from better cost of capital and trading prices. This strategy aligns with Warburg Pincus, a key shareholder of ESR, which is also ESR-Reit's sponsor.

site_title: Trump declares emergency as hurricane menaces Hawaii
summary: US President Donald Trump declared a state of emergency in Hawaii on August 23, 2018, as powerful Hurricane Lane threatened the Big Island. The Category 4-storm had maximum sustained winds of 215 km/h, posing torrential rains, high winds, and dangerous surf. Residents stockpiled water and emergency supplies as the storm approached, with forecasters warning of "excessive rainfall," flash flooding, and landslides. The storm's slow movement and strong winds were expected to cause significant coastal erosion and damage.

images.alt_text: Waves crash on the coast as Hurricane Lane approaches Hawaii. US President Donald Trump on Thursday declared a state of emergency in Hawaii, releasing disaster funds.

site_title: Clearbridge unit enters into MOU to expand lab testing services to Indonesia
summary: Clearbridge Health's subsidiary, SAM Laboratory, has entered into a non-binding MOU with PT Indo Genesis Medika and PT Kreasi Putra Nusantara to expand lab testing services to Indonesia. The agreement includes a proposed subscription of a controlling stake in Indo Genesis for S$3.8 million and an interest-bearing loan of up to S$9.5 million. The move aims to leverage Indo Genesis' existing hospital network for Clearbridge's precision medicine products and services, expected to be earnings accretive and generate revenue synergies.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.6% higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 50 points, or 1.6%, to 3,249.89 on Thursday, with 1.47 billion shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 210 to 181, led by Singtel's 6.5% gain to S$3.28, and DBS' 2.2% rise to S$25.55. The rally followed a 0.4% gain on Wednesday and marked a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Three secret sauces to designing green cities
summary: A global heat wave has sparked renewed debate on climate change, with industrialisation and fossil fuel consumption linked to global warming. As an architect and sustainability consultant, experts are seeking ways to design green cities and buildings that consume less energy. Three secret sauces for designing sustainable cities include: (1) using passive design principles, (2) integrating renewable energy systems, and (3) implementing green infrastructure. By adopting these strategies, buildings and cities can reduce their environmental impact and contribute to a more sustainable future.

site_title: China's Xi says ideology work 'absolutely correct' amid trade row criticism
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has stated that the country's propaganda efforts are "absolutely correct" and those who work in the field should be trusted, amid criticism over the government's messaging on the trade dispute with the US. Xi praised the success of propaganda efforts since the 2012 Communist Party Congress, promoting traditional culture and enhancing China's cultural influence. The government has tightened controls over the internet and state media, restricting freedom of speech and criticism of the party, with Xi calling for a "clean" internet and rejecting "vulgar" content.

site_title: Lian Beng unit bags S$278.5m deal for construction in Silat Avenue
summary: Lian Beng Group's subsidiary, United Tec Construction, has secured a S$278.5 million contract for a residential development in Silat Avenue. The project involves building two 56-storey blocks with 955 units, as well as landscaping and communal facilities. The contract period is 42 months, set to commence in August. The deal brings Lian Beng's order book to approximately S$1.2 billion, providing a sustainable flow of activity until FY2022. The company's shares rose 2% to close at 51 Singapore cents.

site_title: Asian Games: Joseph Schooling wins men's 50m fly in 23.61 seconds
summary: Joseph Schooling of Singapore won the men's 50m butterfly at the 2018 Asian Games with a time of 23.61 seconds. China's Wang Peng took second place at 23.65 seconds, while Kazakhstan's Adilbek Mussin finished third in 23.73 seconds. Schooling successfully defended his men's 100m fly title earlier in the meet and has now won two gold medals, surpassing his performance at the 2014 Asian Games.

site_title: Draghi succession wide open as Merkel loses interest in ECB
summary: Germany is no longer pushing for Jens Weidmann to become the next European Central Bank (ECB) president, making the succession of Mario Draghi more open. Despite this, the ECB's planned policy course remains unchanged, with Draghi aiming to exit extraordinary stimulus and implement gradual interest-rate increases starting in the second half of next year. The ECB's course is unlikely to change, leaving the door open for other candidates, but no clear favorite to succeed Draghi has emerged.

site_title: Britain outlines plans for 'unlikely' no-deal Brexit
summary: Britain has outlined plans for managing a potential no-deal Brexit, warning of increased customs red tape and higher card payment charges for consumers. Brexit Minister Dominic Raab said the government would adopt EU rules and stockpile medicines in case of a no-deal, but remains "still confident" of reaching an agreement with the EU. The government will publish technical notices to advise different sectors of the economy on how to handle negotiations collapsing, including increased costs for euro transactions and potential surcharges for online shopping.

images.alt_text: Brexit Minister Dominic Raab said Britain would adopt a series of EU rules in case of a no-deal to allow EU imports in and urged Brussels to do the same for British goods.

site_title: Women face uphill battle for employment in Hong Kong, study shows
summary: A new study by the Equal Opportunities Commission and Chinese University of Hong Kong reveals that women in Hong Kong face significant barriers in the job market, with only 37.4% of employers willing to recruit a woman "without family status" and 47.2% willing to hire women with children. In contrast, 70% of men with children are favored as job candidates. The research suggests that women who are not caring for children or elderly relatives are perceived as not being sufficiently committed to their job.

site_title: A good year for complications
summary: Complications in watches have seen a resurgence this year, particularly in the affordable segment. The Tudor Black Bay GMT stands out as a highlight, offering a dual time zone function, in-house movement, and robust quality at a modest budget. Another notable mention is the FP Journe lineSport Chronograph Monopoussoir Rattrapante, a single-button, split-seconds chronograph with a traditionally laid out mechanism, priced in the high five figures. Both watches showcase value for money and offer a unique blend of style and complication, appealing to those seeking a premium timepiece experience.

site_title: Drones offer high-tech help to Japan's ageing farmers
summary: Japanese farmers are testing a high-tech drone to ease the physical burden of rice farming, which is often performed by elderly farmers. The drone, called Nile-T18, can apply pesticides and fertilizer to a rice field in 15 minutes, reducing the time and effort required by hand. Developed by drone start-up Nileworks Inc, the drone aims to improve productivity and farmers' income in rural areas facing a shortage of labor. With a price tag of 4 million yen, the drone is smaller and cheaper than larger radio-controlled mini-helicopters, and can be controlled with an iPad.

site_title: Grab taps SP Group to power up new electric vehicle fleet
summary: Grab has partnered with SP Group to power its new fleet of 200 electric vehicles (EVs) with fast-charging capabilities. The EVs will be rolled out in Singapore from early 2019, offering drivers preferential EV charging rates and potentially earning up to 25% more in daily income. This partnership marks SP Group's first fleet partnership and is part of its plan to build Singapore's largest and fastest public EV charging network, with 500 charging points by 2020.

site_title: Time to get started
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several value-for-money watches were showcased at Baselworld 2018, offering respectable prestige and heritage at affordable prices. Brands like Hamilton, Tissot, Bell & Ross, and Oris offer mechanical timepieces under $5,000. The Hamilton Khaki Field Mechanical starts at $635, while Tissot's Ballade models range from $1,380 to $1,660. Limited-edition options include the Bell & Ross BR V1-92 Racing Bird ($3,600) and Oris' Clipperton ($2,950). The article concludes that these watches offer great value, with the Tudor Black Bay GMT being a standout option at $4,896, providing a unique blend of style, functionality, and affordability.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down, snapping rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended down 0.49% on Thursday, snapping a four-day rally, as investors took profits amid ongoing US-China trade talks. The Hang Seng Index closed at 27,790.46, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.37%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 0.63%. The losses follow a strong rally in Asian markets, with Singapore and US stocks reaching fresh records.

site_title: Craig Zadan, 69, dies; produced musicals for stage, screen and TV
summary: Craig Zadan, 69, a renowned showman and producer, died on Tuesday after complications from shoulder replacement surgery. He co-produced numerous Broadway and TV musicals, including live NBC broadcasts of The Sound of Music, Peter Pan, Hairspray, and The Wiz, and won six Oscars, 17 Emmys, and five Golden Globes. Zadan's last major show was a live version of Jesus Christ Superstar, which aired on Easter Sunday. He is survived by his partner, Elwood Hopkins, and was known for his vision and enthusiasm in bringing classic musicals to life.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index closes higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed up 0.22% at 22,410.82, driven by a cheaper yen against the dollar, despite tit-for-tat tariffs between the US and China. The broader Topix index ended down 0.01%. The Nikkei's gains were largely unaffected by the ongoing trade tensions, which have seen US President Trump make new threats.

site_title: ECB must not delay rolling back stimulus: Weidmann
summary: European Central Bank President Jens Weidmann urged the ECB to roll back its stimulus program now that inflation is consistent with its target, despite warnings against delaying the process. Weidmann believes the normalization of monetary policy will take place gradually over the next few years. His comments come after Chancellor Angela Merkel was reported to be giving up on promoting him to succeed ECB chief Mario Draghi, who has set a timeline for an interest rate hike after next summer. Weidmann's views contradict Draghi's take on inflation, citing a 1.7% projection for 2020 as "broadly consistent" with the bank's mandate.

site_title: Russia will not stop rocket engine exports to US
summary: Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov stated that the country will not halt exports of rocket engines to the US despite new sanctions. This comes after a Russian lawmaker suggested restricting RD-180 engine exports if US sanctions were imposed. Ryabkov also confirmed that Russia will continue to export titanium to the US for its aviation industry. The decision appears to be a response to US sanctions, but Russia has chosen not to reciprocate with its own restrictions.

images.alt_text: Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov said on Thursday Moscow did not plan to halt supplies of rocket engines to the United States in response to a new round of US sanctions against Russia

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon trading at 3,249.69, up 1.6% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 49.8 points or 1.6% to 3,249.69. Gainers outnumbered losers 196 to 140, with shares of Singtel and Noble Group leading the gainers. The rally follows a 5-day streak of gains ahead of GDP data, with investors maintaining a positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Singtel shares surge 7.5% on potential union of Australia telecom rivals
summary: Singtel shares surged 7.5% on a potential merger between Australia telecom rivals Vodafone Hutchison Australia and TPG Telecom. This could reduce competition in Australia, where Singtel generates over half its revenues. Analysts expect a positive impact on Singtel's Australian business, Optus, and a possible bid for Amaysim Australia to gain access to its subscribers. A deal would also influence the Singapore mobile market, but its implications are unclear.

site_title: China reports fourth African swine fever outbreak: ministry
summary: China reported its fourth African swine fever outbreak, with over 400 pigs infected on three farms in Zhejiang province, killing 340 hogs in Wenzhou city. Authorities have culled over 20,000 animals and banned live hog movement to contain the spread. This is the fourth region to detect the highly contagious disease, with previous outbreaks in Liaoning, Henan, and Jiangsu provinces.

site_title: World Bank launches world-first blockchain bond
summary: The World Bank has launched the world's first public blockchain bond, priced at A$100 million, to test the use of blockchain technology in bond sales. The two-year bonds have a yield of 2.251% and will settle on August 28. This prototype deal aims to move bond sales away from manual processes towards faster and cheaper automation, marking an initial step in adopting blockchain technology in the industry.

site_title: Australia shares finish lower under political cloud; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares fell on Thursday as uncertainty over the country's next prime minister rattled investor confidence. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's tenure looked doomed after senior ministers resigned and supported a second leadership ballot. Financials were hit, while resources stocks gained. The country's future will be decided in a leadership vote on Friday if Turnbull receives a letter signed by a majority of Liberal party legislators.

site_title: Saudi energy minister denies Aramco IPO will be called off
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Khalid al-Falih, denied reports that the state oil giant Aramco's initial public offering (IPO) will be called off, citing the government's commitment to the deal. The IPO, aimed at restructuring the kingdom's economy and reducing dependence on oil revenue, was set to value the company at $2 trillion or more. Disagreements over valuations and listing venues had slowed down preparations, but al-Falih's statement suggests the IPO may still proceed. The listing was central to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's reform drive.

site_title: Gold falls as US tariff fears, rate hike views buoy US dollar
summary: Gold prices fell 0.4% to $1,191.18 an ounce due to US dollar gains, driven by fears of additional tariffs on China and expectations of higher interest rates. The US dollar index rose 0.3% as the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates again. The Fed's minutes suggested a possible rate hike next month, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold and boosting the dollar.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady as rallying techs offset drop in miners
summary: European stocks remained steady on Thursday, driven by a rally in tech shares, which offset a decline in mining stocks. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index gained 0.1%, while the tech sector index rose 0.6% and the basic resources sector index fell 0.5%. The dollar rebounded after the Federal Reserve signaled interest rate hikes, while copper prices slipped below $6,000. Despite a summer slump, investors remain optimistic, awaiting PMI figures for direction, and assessing the implications of Continental's revenue forecast warning.

site_title: PODCAST: What are equities and how to best put together an investment portfolio (Money Hacks, Ep 18)
summary: In the podcast "Money Hacks" episode 18, Kelvin Goh, head of investments and wealth advisory at OCBC Bank, provides tips for creating an investment portfolio. He explains that a portfolio is a collection of investments, and equities are a key component. Goh recommends reviewing portfolios every 6-12 months for long-term investments and quarterly for short-term investments. He also advises considering risk tolerance, time horizon, and diversification when building a portfolio. The podcast aims to offer guidance for newcomers to the financial investment scene in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers can test latest technologies at new model factory
summary: Singapore has launched a new 15,000 sq ft facility, the Model Factory, to allow companies to test and co-develop advanced manufacturing technologies. The facility, operated by the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star), features 10 areas showcasing technologies such as collaborative robots, autonomous guided vehicles, and virtual manufacturing labs. The initiative aims to sustain Singapore's competitiveness in the industry and technology innovation, with senior Minister Koh Poh Koon stating that the world's economic centre of gravity is shifting towards Asia, driven by the rising middle class and urbanization.

site_title: Singapore inflation steady at 0.6% in July; core inflation highest in four years
summary: Singapore's headline inflation remained steady in July at 0.6% year-on-year, matching economists' expectations. Core inflation rose 1.9% due to higher electricity and gas costs, the fastest pace since August 2014. Despite this, private road transport costs fell, and food and services inflation were stable. The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects core inflation to rise gradually and headline inflation to stay moderate due to subdued retail rents and constrained pricing power.

images.alt_text: Food inflation came in at 1.5 per cent in July, unchanged from June. Services inflation was lower at 1.5 per cent, compared to 1.7 per cent the month before.

site_title: CorpPass to be only login method for businesses to transact with public sector from Sept 1
summary: From Sept 1, CorpPass will be the single login method for businesses to transact with over 140 government digital services, replacing SingPass and EASY. CorpPass, a corporate digital identity, has been adopted by more than 90% of businesses since its launch in 2016. The move aims to simplify transactions and enhance security for businesses interacting with government agencies.

site_title: Qantas eyes larger Airbus A350 jet for Sydney-London flights: CEO
summary: Qantas is considering the Airbus A350-1000 for its proposed non-stop 20-hour Sydney-London flights by 2022. The airline has advanced to the request for proposal stage, with a purchase decision due next year. Qantas had initially eyed the A350-900ULR, but is now also considering the Boeing 777-8. The airline aims for 300 passenger seats on London flights, including an economy class offering, and is seeking more details from Boeing on the 777-8's weight. Qantas is confident both manufacturers can meet the range challenges, but the new service will still require regulatory and pilot union approvals.

site_title: Arun Jaitley to resume charge as India's finance minister
summary: Arun Jaitley, India's finance minister, will resume his duties after a three-month gap due to a kidney transplant surgery. Jaitley, 65, had undergone the surgery in April and was temporarily replaced by Railway Minister Piyush Goyal. President Ram Nath Kovind has re-assigned the portfolios, following advice from Prime Minister Narendra Modi. This marks Jaitley's return to office after a gastric bypass operation in 2014 to manage his diabetes.

site_title: Philippines' San Miguel plans US$2.7b share sale in food unit; shares soar
summary: Philippine conglomerate San Miguel Corp plans to sell a $2.7 billion stake in its food unit San Miguel Food and Beverage Inc, part of its asset restructuring plan. The share sale, which will sell up to 1.02 billion shares at 140 pesos each, is expected to increase the company's public float. Shares of San Miguel Corp and San Miguel Food and Beverage rose 7.5% and 13% respectively, outpacing the broader index's 1.8% gain. The sale is aimed at injecting value into the food unit and solidifying San Miguel's position as the leading food and beverage company in the Philippines.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysian shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.45 points to 1,801.56. Volume reached 101.71 million lots worth RM55.7 million, with 169 gainers outnumbering 81 losers.

site_title: Asian markets mixed as China, US hold talks but prepare tariffs
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as investors took a breather after a recent run-up, awaiting China and US talks on their long-running trade dispute. China and the US are set to impose tit-for-tat sanctions, despite officials holding talks to ease the row. The dollar rose after the Federal Reserve indicated it will hike borrowing costs next month, while Singapore surged 1.3% on a one-day holiday. Markets await developments in Washington and the outcome of this week's annual central bankers' symposium at Jackson Hole.

site_title: As Macron extends his dominance, French politicians abandon ship
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's dominance in politics continues, with many establishment party politicians abandoning ship. Former industry minister Arnaud Montebourg has left politics to sell honey, while others, such as Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet and Francois Fillon, have resigned from elected positions to pursue new careers. This shift reflects a changing French political landscape, where voters are increasingly demanding new ideas and solutions, and politicians are no longer able to rely on their party affiliations. Macron's newly created party has disrupted traditional party politics, with many politicians seeking fresh challenges outside the system.

site_title: Ho Bee gets its first green loan from HSBC to buy London commercial property
summary: Ho Bee Land, a Singapore-based property investment firm, has secured its first green loan from HSBC to acquire a commercial development in London. The £200 million loan, valued at S$352.9 million, is one of Singapore's first green loans and was executed under Ho Bee's green finance framework certified by Sustainalytics. The loan will fund the acquisition of Ropemaker Place, a 21-storey commercial development with LEED and BREEAM green building certifications. This deal is seen as a step forward for Singapore's green financing credentials and sets a template for other corporates seeking similar transactions.

site_title: Facebook suspends 400 apps in data leak probe
summary: Facebook has suspended 400 apps in a data leak probe following a developer data leak scandal in March. The move is part of the company's efforts to ramp up privacy standards, particularly with regards to developer relationships. The suspension includes an app called myPersonality, which was banned after failing to cooperate with an audit and sharing user information with researchers and companies with limited protections. The incident led to increased scrutiny of Facebook and its handling of user data, following revelations of Cambridge Analytica's data misuse.

images.alt_text: Facebook Inc said it has investigated thousands of apps and suspended 400 of them since a developer data leak scandal broke in March.

site_title: Australia shares dip as political uncertainty knocks sentiment; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.2% to 6,256.1 on Thursday, weighed down by uncertainty over the country's next prime minister and losses in financials. The Aussie dollar fell 0.8% against the greenback amid elevated sovereign risk. Gains in the materials and energy sectors limited the decline. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index slipped 0.1% as stocks such as Air New Zealand weighed on the index.

site_title: Lockheed poised to get US$11b F-35 contract despite delays
summary: The US Pentagon is poised to award Lockheed Martin a potential $11 billion contract for 141 F-35 aircraft, the 11th production batch, despite the company's production delays and defects. Lockheed has been "late to contract requirements" in delivering 209 of 308 F-35s to US and international customers through June 30, with seven expected to miss the deadline. The Defense Contract Management Agency has expressed concerns about the production line's assembly floor issues, but Lockheed says it is making steady progress in eliminating defects and expects to deliver all 91 F-35s due this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Thursday, driven by investor optimism over trade talks between China and the US. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.28% to 28,005.33, while the Shanghai Composite Index barely moved. Despite uncertainty surrounding US tariffs, investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday's open; STI up 1.32% to 3,242.02
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.32% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,242.02. The gains followed Asian markets, with 130 gainers outnumbering 54 losers. Key movers included Singtel (up 5.5%), Noble Group (up 9.0%), and DBS Group Holdings (up 1.4%). The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady as trade talks, US politics fuel uncertainty
summary: European stock markets ended flat on Wednesday, amid uncertainty over US-China trade talks and US President Donald Trump's legal woes. Despite a rise in oil prices and gains in mining and healthcare stocks, autos underperformed, with Continental AG dropping 14% on a profit warning. The US and China's trade conflict dominated headlines, while limited effects from Trump's legal developments were noted.

site_title: Singapore investors spend US$4.6b on cross-border real estate: report
summary: Singaporean investors spent US$4.6 billion on cross-border real estate transactions in the second quarter of 2018, with a focus on Chinese and Australian markets. This ranks Singapore as the second most active investor in the Asia-Pacific region. Investment in Singapore itself fell 12% to US$7.6 billion, but saw a 100% increase in transactions, driven by a surge in en bloc sales, which accounted for 58% of land sales. Another US$1.7 billion in en bloc deals are in the pipeline.

site_title: US oil extends gains after crude inventories fall
summary: US oil prices rose on Thursday, extending gains from the previous session, due to a decline in US commercial crude inventories. US WTI crude futures increased 4 US cents to $67.90 per barrel, while Brent crude fell 13 US cents to $74.65 per barrel. The decline in US inventories, which fell by 5.8 million barrels, was attributed to a 3% jump in US crude oil production, now reaching 11 million barrels per day. The ongoing trade dispute between the US and China also weighed on international crude markets.

site_title: South Korea Q2 household disposable income falls for a 7th quarter
summary: South Korea's average disposable household income declined 0.1% in the April-June period for a seventh consecutive quarter, according to Statistics Korea. Real household income grew 2.7% in the second quarter, faster than the 2.4% gain in the first quarter. Unemployment increased in the lowest income bracket due to an ageing population and sluggish businesses. This marks a blow to the government's efforts to boost consumer spending, as income inequality improved slightly, with an index measuring income inequality at 5.23.

site_title: US, China resume trade talks as Trump imposes new tariffs
summary: US and China resume trade talks after a months-long standstill, with mid-level officials meeting to discuss intellectual property protections and trade rebalancing. The talks are seen as an attempt to avoid an all-out trade war, but expectations are low, with many analysts predicting a joint statement of productive discussions. The US has imposed new tariffs on $16 billion of Chinese exports, and the talks may focus on China's pledge not to let the yuan weaken further in exchange for continued negotiations. The outcome is uncertain, with the Trump administration divided on how to approach the talks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nam Cheong, HG Metal, iFast, Singtel
summary: Nam Cheong resumes trading after a year-long suspension following a debt restructuring exercise, reporting a net profit of RM34.74 million for the second quarter. HG Metal Manufacturing pays US$2 million for a majority stake in a joint venture in Myanmar. iFast Corp seeks investors to raise capital for its Greater China business, while Singtel hires Bank of America to assess options for a possible bid for Amaysim Australia.

site_title: Australian PM's leadership looks doomed after senior ministers back rival
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's leadership appears to be under threat after three senior ministers tendered their resignations and backed rival Peter Dutton. The ministers, who previously supported Turnbull in a leadership vote, changed their stance and now support Dutton, who won the previous contest by seven votes. Dutton has called for a second leadership vote, putting Turnbull's position in doubt.

site_title: Australia competition watchdog takes action against Trivago over hotel price advertisements
summary: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has taken action against Trivago, a hotel price comparison website, over its hotel price advertisements. The ACCC alleged that Trivago's ads could be misleading, as they often included additional fees not clearly disclosed. The commission ordered Trivago to stop making these claims and to provide clearer information about its services. This action aims to protect consumers from potentially deceptive advertising practices.

site_title: Palm oil watchdog urged to take 'giant leap' to save forests
summary: A global watchdog for the palm oil industry, the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO), is under pressure to strengthen its standards to require all members to commit to ending deforestation. The organization aims to publish new guidelines in November that will cover the next five years, with many growers, investors, and green experts calling for a "total commitment" to zero deforestation. The move comes as major buyers like Nestle and PepsiCo have committed to zero deforestation and as institutional investors have called on the RSPO to ban deforestation and clearings of peatlands.

site_title: US, China impose new tariffs on each other as talks resume
summary: The US and China imposed new tariffs on each other's goods, totaling $16 billion, as trade talks resumed. The US will collect 25% duties on Chinese imports, while China will impose a similar tax on US goods. Mid-level officials from both countries met for the first face-to-face discussions since June, with talks focusing on intellectual property and trade rebalancing. Analysts say the hawkish position of Trump's administration has been consolidated, and China is prepared to endure trade tensions. The outcome of talks is uncertain, with some officials pushing for a negotiated solution and others seeking increased pressure on Beijing.

images.alt_text: The US and China imposed fresh tariffs on each other's goods in the middle of trade talks aimed at averting the worsening conflict between the world's two biggest economies.

site_title: HG Metal commits US$2m to begin cut & bend, fabrication JV in Myanmar
summary: HG Metal Manufacturing has committed US$2 million to form a joint venture in Myanmar, acquiring a 51.04% stake in First Fortune International Co. for US$95,700. The venture will provide cut and bend, and fabrication services in the fast-growing Myanmar market. HG Metal will pay US$1.95 million of the initial additional subscription, while YNJ Engineering Co will provide a lease agreement for the factory. The joint venture aims to modernize HG Metal's services in Myanmar.

site_title: Facebook to pull VPN app from App Store over data worry
summary: Facebook will remove its VPN app, Onavo Protect, from the App Store due to concerns over data collection violating Apple's rules. The app, which routes internet activity through Facebook servers, was available for several years but has been deemed non-compliant. Facebook agreed to voluntarily remove the app rather than face removal by Apple. Versions of the app installed on iPhones will continue to work, but updates will no longer be available, while the app will remain available on Android devices.

site_title: This £2.25m Welsh castle comes complete with fire-breathing dragon
summary: A £2.25 million Welsh castle, Castell Gyrn, is on the market with panoramic views, a grotto, and a fire-breathing dragon sculpture. The 5,800 sq ft residence features six bedrooms, three reception rooms, and a library. Purchased in 2005, the castle was renovated by owner Jeff Thompson, who added features such as bronzed casement windows for effective climate control. Located 20 miles from Chester, the castle offers a unique blend of medieval charm and modern amenities, making it a rare find for those seeking a castle lifestyle.

site_title: Greek banks' new loans not enough for cratered economy
summary: Greece's banks are struggling to provide sufficient funding for the country's economy, despite injecting 11 billion euros into the economy this year. The banks' cautious approach is due to their high bad debt levels and need for more encouragement to support viable businesses and households. The economy has lost over a quarter of its output in the past decade and is struggling to recover, with real investment still below 40% of its pre-crisis level. The government expects growth of 2.5% in 2018, but experts say foreign direct investment is crucial to unlocking investments and lifting the country's growth potential.

site_title: Goldman is said to be shutting two hedge funds run out of Asia
summary: Goldman Sachs is shutting two hedge funds run by Ryan Thall and Hideki Kinuhata, based in Asia, due to fickle demand for hedge fund-like products. The funds, which manage about US$1.4 billion in assets, are part of the Goldman Sachs Investment Partners division. The closures are attributed to the struggling hedge fund industry and investors' shift to alternative options. Thall is expected to start his own fund, while Kinuhata is retiring.

site_title: SEC quashes more Bitcoin ETF pitches in another blow to crypto
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) rejected proposals for Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) from ProShares, GraniteShares, and Direxion, citing concerns over price manipulation. The SEC stated that the proposed exchanges failed to prove they could prevent fraudulent and manipulative acts. This decision is the second rejection of a Bitcoin ETF proposal this year, following a similar ruling in late July. The rejection has taken a toll on Bitcoin's price, which rose less than 1% in early trading to around $6,360.

site_title: China's new 'consumption downgrade' culture a worrying trend for its economy and the world
summary: China's economy is experiencing a "consumption downgrade" culture, where middle-class citizens are cutting back on spending due to economic slowdown, rising costs, and trade tensions. This shift is reflected in reduced shopping, slower wage growth, and declining stock market performance. As a result, Chinese consumers are opting for cheaper alternatives, such as buying second-hand goods, cooking at home, and using public transportation. The trend has significant implications for China's economy and the global market, potentially weakening China's role in global growth and emboldening US President Donald Trump in his trade fight with China.

site_title: Global wheat supply to crisis levels; big China stocks won't provide relief
summary: Global wheat supply is at crisis levels due to a scorching hot, dry summer affecting major exporters. China, which consumes 16% of the world's wheat, is holding 46% of its stocks, with 126.8 million tonnes, and is unlikely to release any onto global markets. This leaves the eight major exporters with 20% of world stocks, just 26 days of cover, down from one-third a decade ago. The US is expected to capitalize on the shortage, with higher stocks and rising production, while North African countries have higher stocks and are better placed.

site_title: Going cashless in Asean
summary: South-east Asia is poised for a cashless revolution due to its high internet and mobile penetration rates. However, the adoption of cashless solutions has been slow, despite the benefits of reduced cash management costs and increased convenience. E-wallets, such as Grab and Alipay, are already in use, but barriers to digitalization, including lack of familiarity and banking access, have hindered widespread adoption. The region's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) also face challenges in securing financing, with peer-to-peer lending offering a potential solution. The growth of electronic remittances can also improve the financial inclusion of migrant workers. To accelerate the transformation, concerted efforts by governments, financial incumbents, and populations are needed.

site_title: Spackman says it priced in growth premium for SMG stake purchase
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group plans to expand its equity stake in associate company Spackman Media Group (SMG), citing significant growth prospects. The group acquired 1.34 million SMG shares at a premium of US$3 per share, valuing the stake at US$4 million. Based on valuation reports, SMG's shares are estimated to be worth between US$4.70 to US$8 per share. Spackman aims to capitalize on SMG's platform to participate in high-quality entertainment content projects, and will continue to explore opportunities to expand its stake in the company.

site_title: Australia bans China's Huawei from participating in mobile network infrastructure build
summary: Australia has banned Huawei Technologies Co Ltd from participating in the country's 5G broadband network infrastructure build, citing national security concerns. This decision comes after Huawei promised complete oversight of 5G equipment by Canberra. The Australian arm of Huawei described the ban as "extremely disappointing" for consumers. The move follows similar bans in other countries, including the US, which has also restricted Huawei's access to its 5G network equipment.

site_title: US and China officials meet as Thursday tariff deadline looms
summary: US and Chinese officials met for a two-day discussion to address the deepening trade conflict, but no agreement was reached to halt the new round of US tariffs set to take effect on Thursday. US President Donald Trump has threatened to impose duties on $500 billion of Chinese goods unless Beijing agrees to changes in intellectual property practices, industrial subsidies, and tariffs. The talks, led by US Treasury Under Secretary David Malpass and Chinese Commerce Vice Minister Wang Shouwen, were seen as a positive step by business groups, but expectations for a deal were low.

site_title: China's Geely sees minimal impact from US-China trade row, 2018 sales jump
summary: China's Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd reported a 44% increase in June sales to 766,630 vehicles, beating expectations, despite intensifying China-US trade frictions. The company, which owns Volvo, said growing tensions had a minimal direct impact due to its domestic focus. Geely expects to meet or exceed its full-year sales target of 1.58 million units, driven by its global expansion plans, including new models and partnerships in South-east Asia and Europe.

site_title: American Airlines drops a second major China route
summary: American Airlines will drop a second major China route, ending direct service between Chicago and Shanghai in October, due to "colossal loss makers" flights. The airline is rearranging its overseas network to cope with higher fuel prices, which have made some flights unprofitable. The move coincides with declining passenger traffic from China to the US and intense competition from mainland Chinese carriers. American will retain routes connecting Shanghai with Dallas and Los Angeles, and is also reducing flights between Chicago and Tokyo.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday as the yen eased against the US dollar, following minutes of the US central bank's last meeting that suggested a rate hike soon. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.23% to 22,413.68, while the Topix index increased 0.10% to 1,700.02. The move was seen as a positive sign for the market, which had been influenced by uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: US: Wall St end mixed as S&P marks longest bull run
summary: US stocks were mixed on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq gaining on tech stocks while the S&P 500 remained little changed, marking its longest bull-market run of 3,453 days. The S&P 500 was influenced by the conviction of former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort and lawyer Michael Cohen, sparking uncertainty. Energy stocks rose 1.2% and retailers gained after Target and Lowe's announced quarterly results. Despite the mixed results, investors are considering the implications of the negative news on the Republican Party's election prospects and Trump's presidency.

site_title: Australia's Santos first-half profit soars, revives dividend
summary: Santos Ltd, Australia's second-largest independent gas producer, reported a near doubling in first-half underlying profit to US$217 million, beating forecasts. The company revived its dividend after slashing debt, declaring an interim dividend of US$0.035 per share. This move follows a two-year hiatus, with the company focusing on reducing its debt. The improved financial performance is seen as a positive step for Santos.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on hopes for US-China talks; won down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.20% on Thursday, driven by hopes for a positive outcome from US-China trade talks. The won edged lower, while bond yields fell. US officials met for the first time in two months to discuss trade, but no halt in new US tariffs was expected. South Korean firms with China exposure gained, with casino companies and cosmetic brands jumping. The Kospi is down 7.9% so far this year, and the won has risen 5% against the US dollar this year.

site_title: Aramco listing plan halted, oil giant disbands advisors: sources
summary: Saudi Arabia has halted the domestic and international stock listing of state oil giant Aramco, citing a shift in attention to a strategic stake acquisition in Saudi Basic Industries Corp. The decision to disband financial advisors working on the proposed listing was made some time ago, according to sources. The listing was a key part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's reform drive, with a predicted valuation of $2 trillion or more. The kingdom will now focus on a local petrochemicals maker, delaying the IPO indefinitely.

site_title: The new thing in Hong Kong's public schools: 'white students'
summary: In Hong Kong, the number of white students in public schools has increased by 44% since 2013, reaching a record high of 818 students last year. This shift is attributed to the rising costs of international schools, which have become more expensive due to a new market of wealthy mainland Chinese immigrants. As a result, many Western expatriates, including British and American families, are opting for public schools to afford education, with some even choosing to enroll their children in Cantonese-language schools to better integrate into the city.

site_title: If Fed follows Trump, US assets would be dented
summary: US President Donald Trump's persistent policy jawboning has investors factoring in the potential for the Federal Reserve to slow down monetary policy tightening, which could dent the US dollar and US assets' appeal as a global haven. Strategists warn that a step back by the Fed could lead to rising inflation expectations, boosting longer-term financing costs and hurting the perceived safety of US assets. On the other hand, emerging markets could benefit from the increased global liquidity and growth.

site_title: Air New Zealand posts 2.5% rise in annual profit, lowers guidance
summary: Air New Zealand reported a 2.5% rise in annual profit to NZ$540 million, beating expectations. The airline attributed the increase to strength in the domestic market and robust tourism. However, it lowered its fiscal 2019 earnings guidance due to higher fuel prices. The airline forecast a range of NZ$425-525 million in underlying pre-tax profit, assuming an average jet fuel price of US$85 per barrel. Revenue rose 7.4% to NZ$5.49 billion, with a final dividend of NZ$0.11 per share.

site_title: Australians take it slow with fast fashion, fearing for environment
summary: Australians are adopting a slower approach to fast fashion, driven by environmental concerns. Sarah Freeman's shop encourages customers to rent clothes instead of buying cheap garments, mirroring the concept of libraries. The shift aims to reduce waste and promote sustainability.

site_title: Former Julius Baer executive pleads guilty to money laundering
summary: A former Julius Baer executive, Matthias Krull, has pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering. Krull, a German citizen and Panama resident, admitted to participating in a $1.2 billion scheme to launder money embezzled from Venezuela's state-owned oil company PDVSA. Krull faces up to 10 years in prison and has agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. The scheme began in 2014 and involved a currency exchange scheme to divert $600 million from PDVSA, which doubled to $1.2 billion by 2015. Krull's sentencing is scheduled for October 29.

site_title: 'America First' risks making US assets a costly last resort
summary: The US has become a safe-haven destination for investors due to global economic uncertainty, with 62.6% of global bond-fund allocations now invested in the US, the highest since 2010. This has led to concerns about the potential risks of US assets, particularly with rising domestic political risks and the ongoing impact of US sanctions and tariff threats on emerging economies. Experts warn that the US may not be immune to the strains its policies are creating, and the dollar's current strength may expose weaknesses in US assets, particularly in the face of domestic political risks.

site_title: Success of 'Crazy Rich Asians' movie sparks plans for sequel
summary: Warner Bros is developing a sequel to the 2018 romantic comedy "Crazy Rich Asians," with director Jon M Chu set to return. The new film will be based on author Kevin Kwan's second book, "China Rich Girlfriend," and is expected to feature the main cast, including Constance Wu and Henry Golding. No script has been written or deals signed with screenwriters, and the film's release date is uncertain. The project marks a milestone for Hollywood, following the success of the original film, which became the first major studio film to feature an all-ethnic Asian ensemble cast in 25 years.

site_title: Next season of 'Big Bang Theory' to be its last
summary: The Big Bang Theory, a long-running CBS sitcom, will conclude with its 12th and final season premiering in September 2018 and concluding in May 2019. The show, which won 10 Emmys, will end after 279 episodes and a total of 19 million viewers per episode in its last season. The decision to end the show is a result of a deal that saw the lead cast members, including Jim Parsons and Kaley Cuoco, earning the same salary per episode. The show's creators and cast members expressed gratitude for the show's success and aim to deliver an epic creative close.

site_title: NP raises S$22k to help rebuild villages in Lombok
summary: Ngee Ann Polytechnic (NP) has raised S$22,000 to help rebuild villages in Lombok, Indonesia, after a recent earthquake. The fundraising effort, initiated by students after a previous YEP programme, aims to provide basic necessities like food, clean water, and blankets to affected locals. The group plans to use the funds to support rebuilding efforts and is seeking corporate sponsorship for materials and construction costs. With the study/exam week currently underway, NP is ramping up efforts once the exams are over to engage more Singaporeans in the cause.

site_title: China's soy sauce king steams ahead as catering industry booms
summary: China's largest soy sauce maker, Foshan Haitian Flavouring & Food Co, has seen its Shanghai-listed shares soar 62% in the past year, making it one of the top performers among global consumer stocks. The company's growth is attributed to China's booming catering industry, which has seen a 27% increase this year, contrasting with the 18% decline of the CSI 300 Index. This growth is partly due to US-China trade tensions, which have sparked demand for domestically focused sectors. Haitian's shares have outperformed major US food giants, such as Kellogg Co and General Mills Inc.

site_title: For Formwerkz , an easy decision to sponsor the event
summary: Formwerkz, an architectural practice, has decided to sponsor the Business Times Corporate Golf League, citing the event's potential for business collaborations. The company, passionate about improving the physical world, saw the sponsorship as an opportunity to connect with like-minded businesses.

site_title: Global trends bode well for SGX
summary: Singapore's stock exchange, SGX, is expected to benefit from global trends favoring alpha generation over beta tracking, according to SGX's head of equities, Chew Sutat. The shift away from "blind money" investments in US indices and towards more fundamental approaches is likely to lead to increased capital allocation to smaller value stocks in Singapore. Additionally, growing demand for liquidity and increased exits in the private market are expected to benefit the public markets. This, combined with Singapore's stable and consistent capital market, bodes well for the exchange's growth, with SGX reporting a five-year high net profit in 2018.

site_title: GIC acquires minority stake in Indian real estate developer
summary: Sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired a minority stake in Indian real estate developer Provenance Land, investing US$250 million in a mixed-use development in central Mumbai. The development, situated on four acres of prime freehold land, includes a luxury hotel, private residences, and a proposed office tower. Provenance Land aims to expand into new developments with GIC's international expertise and long-term investment approach. The investment marks a key milestone for Provenance Land, with Adarsh Jatia stating that it will help create additional value for all stakeholders.

site_title: Qantas extends investor splurge after record annual profit
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd reported a record annual profit driven by a recovering Australian resources industry and increased demand for leisure travel. The airline will return up to A$500 million to shareholders, including a higher-than-expected dividend and stock buyback, and will pay bonuses worth A$67 million to its 27,000 employees. CEO Alan Joyce expressed confidence in the company's ability to recover higher fuel costs this financial year, citing "healthy demand" and "improving levels of capacity discipline."

images.alt_text: Qantas Airways Ltd, this year's best-performing airline stock, kicked off another round of investor payouts as it reported record annual profit on the back of a recovering Australian resources industry and increased demand for leisure travel.

site_title: Business comes first, then tech
summary: Singaporean manufacturers have adopted digital manufacturing techniques at a higher rate than their regional counterparts, but companies must approach digitalization strategically to avoid "technology clutter." Siemens Singapore's head of digital factory manufacturing design, Surya Tumuluri, emphasizes the importance of identifying areas of focus, educating oneself on relevant technologies, and having a coordinated roadmap to drive sustainable goals. Companies should prioritize business objectives before adopting technology, and work with partners to create a tailored digitalization plan.

images.alt_text: "It helps them make a very educated and justifiable conversation with their different vendors and partners." - Surya Tumuluri, Siemens Singapore's head of digital factory manufacturing design. He says that customers who understand "digital levers" will be in a better position to decide what tech to prioritise

"It helps them make a very educated and justifiable conversation with their different vendors and partners." - Surya Tumuluri (above), Siemens Singapore's head of digital factory manufacturing design. He says that customers who understand "digital levers" will be in a better position to decide what tech to prioritise

site_title: Nam Cheong back in the black on absence of asset impairments, forex gain
summary: Nam Cheong, a Singapore-based offshore marine player, reported a net profit of RM34.74 million for the second quarter ended June 30, reversing a loss of RM2.02 billion from the same period last year. The company's revenue was 16% lower due to lower shipbuilding segment revenue, while earnings per share increased to 1.66 sen from a loss of 96.54 sen previously, driven by a foreign exchange gain and absence of asset impairments.

site_title: Europe questions safety of bridges after Genoa tragedy
summary: A highway bridge collapse in Genoa, Italy, on August 14, 2018, killed 43 people, highlighting concerns about ageing European infrastructure. Experts warn of inadequate maintenance and inspections, with many countries, including the US, underinvesting in bridge upkeep. A French study found 7% of bridges have damage that could lead to collapse, but the outcome may be decades away. Germany's transportation ministry has announced a new law to address the issue, despite some politicians downplaying the severity of the problem and pointing to its thorough inspection regimen.

site_title: Trump, a currency manipulator? Wall St isn't ruling it out
summary: US President Donald Trump's comments on weakening the US dollar have raised concerns among Wall Street observers that he may launch a sustained campaign to manipulate the currency. Some analysts, including former US Treasury official Charles Dallara, suggest that a weaker dollar could be a way to reduce the US trade deficit, but doing so would undermine the US dollar's status as the world's reserve currency. Trump's administration has been lukewarm towards the US dollar, and some experts warn that any direct intervention would require congressional approval, but a national emergency declaration could bypass this hurdle.

site_title: Chinese phone giant Xiaomi delivers growth in first results
summary: Xiaomi, China's largest smartphone manufacturer, reported a 68% revenue jump and a quarterly profit of 14.7 billion yuan in its maiden earnings report. The company booked a one-time gain of 22.5 billion yuan due to a revaluation of preferred stock. Revenue from its internet services business rose 64% to 4 billion yuan, driven by ad sales. Despite the positive results, analysts expressed concerns about Xiaomi's business model, citing a slowing smartphone market and local rivals' challenges overseas. The company's stock closed up 1.6% on the day, above its IPO price.

site_title: Bulls eyeing Thai stocks as country's economic recovery strengthens
summary: Thailand's stock market is one of the world's best performers this quarter, driven by strong economic growth. The country's GDP expanded 4.6% in the second quarter, beating expectations, and is expected to support earnings growth. SCB Asset Management and Morgan Stanley have turned bullish on the Thai market, predicting a potential rise in the benchmark SET Index to at least 1,800 this year. The main beneficiaries of the economic recovery are expected to be banks, property developers, and auto-part makers, although higher interest rates and inflation pose risks.

site_title: Indonesian billionaire gives up wine in pursuit of Asian gold
summary: Indonesian billionaire Michael Bambang Hartono, 78, is competing in the Asian Games with his bridge team, seeking to become the oldest Asian Games medal winner. A professional bridge player since childhood, Hartono credits the game for teaching him risk-taking and decision-making skills that contributed to his $11.5 billion fortune. He has vowed to stay sober during the competition after losing a gold medal in a previous tournament due to wine consumption. Hartono hopes to see bridge included in the Olympics, a goal he believes is achievable given the inclusion of esports in the 2024 Paris Olympics.

site_title: New York subpoenas ex-Trump attorney Cohen in Trump Foundation probe
summary: New York state issued a subpoena to Michael Cohen, former attorney to US President Donald Trump, in a probe of the Trump Foundation charity. The subpoena was issued by the New York state tax department after Cohen's lawyer mentioned Cohen had information about the charity. The agency will work with the New York attorney general and Manhattan district attorney as needed. This development comes amid investigations into the Trump Foundation's activities.

site_title: Tech giants dismantle global Iranian propaganda push
summary: Tech giants Facebook, Twitter, and Alphabet have removed hundreds of Iranian-linked social media accounts promoting Iran's geopolitical agenda worldwide. The campaign, which targeted users in the US, Britain, Latin America, and the Middle East, used fake news websites and personas to spread narratives aligned with Iran's interests. The move comes as concerns rise about foreign attempts to disrupt the US midterm election. FireEye, a cybersecurity firm, linked the activity to Iran, citing themes of anti-Saudi, anti-Israeli, and pro-Palestinian advocacy.

site_title: China could use a little US-style suburban sprawl
summary: China's rapid urbanization has boosted economic growth, but it may hinder the country's future by reducing birthrates. The one-child policy, implemented to address rural poverty and agricultural labor shortages, has led to a demographic crisis with an aging population and low household formation. To counter this, China could adopt a suburban model similar to the US, with detached single-family homes and lower-density communities, which may encourage higher birthrates and a more sustainable population. This could be a key factor in China's efforts to catch up with the US in areas like technology.

site_title: Sleep better, this Weekend
summary: Singaporeans are among the most sleep-deprived in the world, with schedules often disrupted by smartphones. However, the country also offers wellness resorts and tranquil surroundings for improving sleep habits. Meanwhile, Eunice Olsen, a former MP and Miss Universe Singapore, has published a book for young readers and continues to champion women's rights. The article also explores kappo cuisine and a unique house design, as well as a re-staging of veteran playwright Michael Chiang's iconic comedy Private Parts.

site_title: Sea's loss widens on investment in Shopee e-commerce platform
summary: Sea Ltd posted a quarterly loss of US$250.8 million, widening from a loss of US$92.1 million a year ago, as it invests in its e-commerce platform Shopee. Revenue rose to US$183.8 million, driven by growth in digital entertainment unit Garena. Sea has invested heavily in expanding beyond games into payments and e-commerce, where Shopee competes with Alibaba-backed companies. The company raised US$575 million in convertible notes to bolster its balance sheet and support Shopee's growth.

site_title: Euro continues to rise ahead of Fed minutes, trade talks
summary: The euro rose for a sixth consecutive day ahead of Federal Reserve minutes and US-China trade talks. The euro gained 0.2% to $1.1594, near a two-week high, while the dollar index fell 0.1% to 95.138. The conviction of Donald Trump's former campaign chairman and a guilty plea by his former personal lawyer dampened investor appetite for riskier investments. The Fed is expected to confirm it will raise interest rates twice more this year, and US-China trade talks are set to begin later on Wednesday.

site_title: Crypto trading firm rents world's priciest offices
summary: Crypto trading firm BitMEX, co-founded by Arthur Hayes, has leased the world's most expensive offices in Hong Kong, the Cheung Kong Center, for $225 per square foot. The 45th-floor space is a significant upgrade from their previous, sparsely-decorated offices, and may signal the industry's ability to prosper despite market volatility. The move comes as cryptocurrency firms seek to mainstream their operations, despite a 65% slump in bitcoin prices.

site_title: Let's retire the phrase 'privacy policy'
summary: A majority of Americans believe that a website's "privacy policy" means the site won't share their information without permission, but this is not true. In reality, these policies explain how companies use visitor data, often trading it with third parties. The label can be misleading, leading people to assume their information is private, and distracting from the need for effective privacy laws. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) should rule that only sites not sharing information without permission can use the phrase, and companies should use more accurate labels like "how we use your information."

site_title: Vodafone Hutchison jumps for bigger lifeboat
summary: Vodafone Hutchison Australia, a joint venture between Vodafone and CK Hutchison, is in talks to merge with TPG Telecom, a homegrown challenger, to resolve a prolonged stalemate. The move aims to alleviate Vodafone Hutchison's A$3 billion in net losses since 2012. A potential deal would see TPG acquire Vodafone Hutchison for an equity value of over A$1 billion, with the companies seeking to consolidate the Australian telecommunications sector amid a government-owned fixed-fibre network increasing competition.

site_title: Brexit's bewildering endgame
summary: The UK's Brexit negotiations are nearing its endgame, with the full range of potential outcomes still live possibilities, including no deal or no Brexit. A new paper from the Institute for Government outlines five scenarios, with only one envisioning a smooth withdrawal agreement and parliamentary approval. The risk of a no-deal Brexit is high, with Prime Minister Theresa May's deal facing rejection by Parliament, and the UK's economy facing a potential blow. The outcome is uncertain, with various factions within the Conservative Party and Labour Party holding opposing views on the best course of action.

site_title: Housing is back, but the American dream isn't
summary: The US housing market has partially recovered since the 2008 crisis, but it's largely excluding lower-earning and younger Americans. Despite efforts to save money through homeownership, many are being shut out due to stricter lending policies and rising housing prices. The government's failure to help keep people in their homes during the crisis has resulted in wealth inequality, as foreclosed homes are now being held by wealthier individuals. The concentration of ownership in the hands of the wealthy is partly due to Nimbyism, or anti-development interests, which restrict supply and drive up prices, making it difficult for new homeowners to enter the market.

images.alt_text: When few new homes are built, first-time homebuyers are forced to bid for the existing housing stock at ever-higher prices.

site_title: US isolationism casts cloud over dollar's reserve dominance
summary: The US dollar's dominance as the global reserve currency is under threat due to US isolationism and increasing tensions with allies. The share of central banks' FX reserves held in US dollars has fallen since Donald Trump's election, with some countries like Iran, Russia, and Turkey looking to reduce their dependence on the dollar. Analysts estimate a 30% reduction in the US dollar's share of reserves held by US-dependent states could occur if diplomatic and military ties with allies fray. The US dollar's long reign as global FX reserve king may be vulnerable, with China's yuan and other currencies gaining traction as alternatives.

site_title: Whisky infused with a sense of place
summary: A Pittsburgh craft distillery, Wigle Whiskey, is producing whisky with distinct flavor profiles based on the source of the grain, similar to wine's terroir concept. The distillery's Terroir Project features three rye whiskies made from grains sourced from Saskatchewan, Minnesota, and Pennsylvania, each with unique taste characteristics. Advocates argue that terroir can enhance the appeal of spirits like whisky, and some distillers are experimenting with regionally specific grains and farming techniques to create unique flavor profiles. This trend is part of a broader movement to return distilling to its agricultural roots.

site_title: Democratising healthcare with tech
summary: The medtech industry is rapidly evolving, with technological advancements in healthcare having a significant impact on patient care and healthcare systems. Digital solutions, such as AI, virtual reality, and mobile technologies, are being introduced to improve patient outcomes, reduce hospital expenditures, and democratize healthcare. Startups and established companies are collaborating to bring these innovations to scale, expanding access to healthcare services, particularly in remote communities. However, concerns around patient safety and regulatory frameworks must be addressed to ensure the reliable integration of technology into healthcare systems.

images.alt_text: Medical robotics system MiroSurge is presented at the German Aerospace Center in Wessling. The three-piece minimally invasive surgery system is commanded by a surgeon from a master console and operated by specialised robot arms. Digital technology is benefiting millions of patients and is helping to create a more inclusive system around the world.

site_title: Banks and consumers are top performers: SGX
summary: Banks and consumers in Singapore outperformed other stocks over the past 12 months, with DBS, Sheng Siong Group, UOB, Venture Corp, and Dairy Farm International ranking as top performers. The top five stocks collectively achieved an average one-year total return of 22.2%. Banks saw an average one-year total return of 15%, driven by higher net interest margins and loan growth, while consumer stocks recorded a 3.1% average return. However, high returns on equity (ROE) do not always translate to price performance, with some high-ROE stocks, such as StarHub, experiencing significant losses.

site_title: Global wheat supply hits crisis levels
summary: A global wheat shortage is expected due to a hot, dry summer in key wheat-producing countries, leading to low reserves and high prices. China, the world's largest wheat consumer, holds 46% of its wheat reserves at the start of the season, but is unlikely to release any onto global markets. The US is best placed to capitalize on the shortage, with higher stocks and rising production, potentially benefiting US farmers caught in a trade war with China.

site_title: Malaysia: Market closed for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's stock market, Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index, was closed on Wednesday due to a public holiday. Trading resumed on Thursday.

images.alt_text: chchefs04 - Whey Interior. Credit: ZS Hospitality Group

site_title: Europe: Shares open cautiously after Wall Street's record high
summary: European stock markets opened lower on Wednesday, following a record high on Wall Street. The STOXX 600 declined 0.1% as investors awaited updates on US-China trade talks. Despite this, shares in Argenx rose 6% after Abbvie exercised an option for a drug, while Jyske Bank fell 4.8% after publishing its Q2 results. US markets continued their bull run, with the S&P 500 reaching a record high.

site_title: Turnbull dumps unpopular tax plan in frantic bid to win favour
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has abandoned his centrepiece tax policy, cutting corporate tax rates to 25% from 30%, after facing opposition from his own party and growing speculation about his future. The move comes after a narrow victory in a party-room vote and a challenge from former home affairs minister Peter Dutton, who is already canvassing support for another leadership bid. The turmoil has led to financial market instability, with the main stock market down nearly 0.5% on Wednesday, and raises concerns about the country's political stability ahead of the next election due by May.

site_title: The new railway generation
summary: The rail industry in Singapore is experiencing a surge in investment and growth, driven by digitalization and technological advancements. The sector faces a significant skills shortage, with the Land Transport Authority and rail operators hiring over 9,300 staff, aiming to reach 15,000 by 2030. To address this, training academies like the Singapore Rail Academy and Alstom's training academy have been established to upskill and reskill the workforce. The industry is also focusing on diversity and inclusion, with initiatives to attract and retain women and young talent, and partnerships with tertiary institutions to develop digital engineering skills.

site_title: Geely beats Nissan, Honda and Toyota in China
summary: Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd reported a 54% jump in net income for the 6 months through June, surpassing its top three Japanese rivals in China. The company now trails only Volkswagen AG and General Motors Co, after overtaking Nissan Motor Co, Honda Motor Co, and Toyota Motor Corp. Geely's sales are expected to beat its target of 1.58 million units this year, thanks to models appealing to China's young consumers.

site_title: Singapore: SGX closed for public holiday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) was closed on Wednesday for a public holiday. Trading will resume on Thursday.

site_title: New technology trends drive continuous semiconductor life cycle for Singapore
summary: Singapore's semiconductor industry is driving the country's manufacturing sector growth, with electronics, biomedical, and transport engineering clusters contributing to the 10% expansion in the second quarter of 2018. The industry is poised to benefit from the growing Internet of Things (IoT) market, with billions of connected devices requiring semiconductors. However, supply is expected to remain tight due to increased demand from traditional and new manufacturers, leading to a need for a continuous semiconductor life-cycle strategy to ensure flawless execution and mitigate potential disruptions.

site_title: Allen & Gledhill launches regulatory and compliance consultancy
summary: Law firm Allen & Gledhill has launched a new consultancy arm, Allen & Gledhill Regulatory & Compliance (AGRC), to help organizations navigate local and international regulatory requirements. AGRC provides consultancy and advisory services on compliance, risk, and regulatory obligations, led by Lawrence Low, a seasoned expert with over 20 years of experience. The consultancy aims to provide seamless advice and solutions to clients, complementing Allen & Gledhill's existing regulatory and technology lawyers.

site_title: Lao Securities Exchange benefits from inflows of Asian capital
summary: The Lao Securities Exchange (LSX) has benefited from Asian capital inflows, with the government aiming to develop the exchange as a hub to attract investors to local companies and the Lao financial market. Two recent initial public offerings (IPOs) took place in August, with Lao Agrotech Co and Mahathuen Leasing Public Company raising funds to expand their businesses. The LSX has also seen growth in trading volume, with the value of stocks traded increasing to 343 billion kip in 2017. The exchange is expected to list more companies by 2025, with the government aiming to graduate the country from the list of least developed countries by 2024.

site_title: Japanese nuclear power firms in talks over alliance: source
summary: Japanese nuclear power firms Tepco, Hitachi, Toshiba, and Chubu have signed an initial agreement to form an alliance, focusing on decommissioning old reactors and potentially building and maintaining new nuclear plants. The move aims to reboot the sector after the Fukushima disaster seven years ago and is seen as a response to the industry's struggles with safety standards and public resistance. The partnership is supported by Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, which believes that private companies cannot operate the business alone.

site_title: A movie in an economy of narrative scarcity
summary: A movie, Crazy Rich Asians, starring Asian-Americans, has significant consequences for the Asian-American community due to narrative scarcity, a lack of diverse representation in media. This scarcity stems from a historical economy where Asian-Americans have been underrepresented in storytelling, often relegated to stereotypes or extras in non-Asian-centric films. The success of Crazy Rich Asians could mark a breakthrough in narrative plenitude, but it's just one step in creating a more inclusive economy of storytelling where Asian-Americans can tell their own stories without feeling the need to prove their worth or exceptionalism.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.64% on Wednesday, driven by a halt in the dollar's weakness and rallies on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 22,362.55, while the Topix index rose 0.77%. Investors remained cautious ahead of US-China trade talks.

site_title: Xiaomi's maiden results provide some redemption for founder Lei Jun
summary: Xiaomi, China's $65 billion handset maker, delivered better-than-expected maiden results after a bumpy initial public offering. The company's sales increased 68% to 45 billion yuan in the second quarter, driven by smartphone sales of 32 million units. International sales more than doubled and now account for over a third of total sales. Despite a lacklustre Hong Kong market debut and shares falling by almost a fifth, Xiaomi's growth provides some redemption for founder Lei Jun, who has been under pressure to deliver strong growth.

site_title: Two leading healthcare, medtech events set to be bigger and better this year
summary: Two leading healthcare and medtech events, Medical Fair Asia and Medical Manufacturing Asia, will take place at Marina Bay Sands from Aug 29 to 31. The events will feature 1,220 exhibitors from 62 countries and 23 national pavilions, with 20,000 visitors expected. This year's exhibitions will highlight innovations in areas like geriatrics, digital healthcare, 3D printing, and micro and nanotechnology. The events will also focus on key trends shaping the healthcare sector, including Asia's ageing population and rising middle class.

site_title: Scientists confirm ice exists at Moon's poles
summary: Scientists have confirmed the existence of ice on the Moon's surface for the first time, detected using instruments that flew on the Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft. The ice lies in the frigid shadows of craters at the lunar poles, and was identified using data from NASA's Moon Mineralogy Mapper instrument. The ice is found in areas that are "super cold," with temperatures never reaching above -157 deg C. The discovery could potentially provide a resource for future human expeditions to the Moon, with NASA aiming to return humans to the lunar surface in the coming years.

site_title: Asian Games: Joseph Schooling retains men's 100m butterfly title in Games record time of 51.04sec
summary: Joseph Schooling retained his Asian Games men's 100m butterfly title in a Games record time of 51.04 seconds. Schooling, the Olympic champion, also won silver in the 50m butterfly and bronze in the 200m butterfly, ending Singapore's 32-year wait for a men's individual swimming gold. Schooling's time beat China's Li Zhuhao's 51.46 seconds for the silver and Japan's Yuki Kobori's 51.77 seconds for the bronze.

site_title: Booming US economy has costs for global growth
