summary: The US economy is expected to experience accelerated growth this year due to President Trump's tax cuts, with the dollar rising and interest rates squeezing emerging economies. In contrast, China's momentum is stalling, European confidence is dipping, and emerging markets are slowing. The global economy is facing a slowdown, with China's GDP growth set to slow and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. Experts, including Citigroup, predict a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index, signaling a challenging period for global growth.

site_title: US commander in South Korea says he supports plan to reduce DMZ outposts
summary: US General Vincent Brooks expressed support for plans to withdraw some outposts along the DMZ border with North Korea, despite concerns about military defense capabilities. South Korea's defense ministry aims to reduce guard posts and equipment to reduce tension and build trust with North Korea. The move is part of efforts to promote peace and cooperation in the region.

site_title: Ping An Insurance posts best 6-month profit in decade on strong customer growth
summary: Ping An Insurance Group Co. of China reported its best 6-month profit in a decade, with a net profit of 58.10 billion yuan (S$11.5 billion), a 34% increase from last year. The insurer's gross written premiums grew 20% to 408.19 billion yuan, driven by strong customer growth, including a 25.2% rise in retail customers to 179 million. Ping An's life and health business saw a 43.3% profit increase, while its banking arm reported a 6.5% profit rise.

site_title: PepsiCo returns to soda's roots with its SodaStream deal
summary: PepsiCo has acquired SodaStream for $3.2 billion, marking a return to the mixable syrup model that its sugary business empire is built on. The soda industry originated as a medical remedy in the late 1700s, with carbonated water mixed with herbs and spices. However, the rise of vending machines led to a decline in popularity. With the resurgence of DIY sodas and a desire for variety and control, PepsiCo is gambling that consumers are ready for new alternatives. The acquisition aims to revive the mixable syrup model, which was previously used by Coca-Cola.

site_title: Linde-Praxair merger hits antitrust hurdle
summary: Linde and Praxair's planned $83 billion merger faces an antitrust hurdle, with regulators demanding significant divestments. The companies have agreed to sell businesses with 3.7 billion euros in sales or 1.1 billion euros in Ebitda, which would exceed the revenue threshold, potentially allowing either party to withdraw without penalty. Despite this, Linde remains in constructive talks with regulators and investors are optimistic the deal will be pushed through, with a deadline of October 24.

site_title: Typhoon forces Britain and Japan to cancel historic beach landing drill
summary: Britain and Japan cancelled a historic beach landing drill near Mount Fuji due to Typhoon Cimaron, which is expected to bring strong winds and rain to Japan. The drill, which would have been the first joint drill between their troops, was to involve a Royal Marine detachment and Japanese amphibious troops storming a beach from the HMS Albion. The cancellation was announced by Britain's embassy in Japan and the Ministry of Defence in Tokyo, with the exercise being part of efforts to bolster defence ties between the two countries amid China's growing military presence.

site_title: Hackers target smartphones to mine cryptocurrencies
summary: Hackers target smartphones to mine cryptocurrencies, a cyberattack known as "cryptojacking." This occurs when a smartphone's processing power is hijacked to solve complex mathematical equations, generating cryptocurrencies. The attack can cause a phone to slow down, overheat, and drain its battery. Experts warn that this type of attack is becoming increasingly common, highlighting the need for users to be vigilant and take precautions to protect their devices.

site_title: How might the Code be tweaked the next time?
summary: The Singapore Code of Corporate Governance (SCCG) underwent its third revision since 2002, focusing on enhancing the quality of the Board of Directors. The updates include a tighter definition of independence and a nine-year limit on director service. The revisions aim to adapt to best practices in other developed markets. Notably, a proposal to tighten the definition of independence from substantial shareholders in 2005 was not accepted. The changes are part of the SCCG's ongoing evolution to reflect changing circumstances and best practices.

images.alt_text: There is no harm in inserting the word "trust" into the Code to remind companies that without trust, no business can succeed, writes David Gerald.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks inch up, bond yields rebound from 10-month low
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.22% to 2,275.01 on Wednesday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street. Bond yields rebounded from a 10-month low, while the Korean won weakened marginally. Shares of STX Corp and affiliates gained, boosted by the company's debt restructuring program. The won was quoted at 1,119.6 per dollar, down 0.1% from its previous close.

site_title: US: Stocks open flat after convictions of ex-Trump aides
summary: US stocks opened flat in early trading on Wednesday, unaffected by the convictions of ex-Trump aides, as investors remained optimistic over trade talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average remained unchanged at 25,926.12, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.1% to 2,861.37, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.1% to 7,867.32. The market showed resilience despite the convictions, which were seen as a minor distraction from the ongoing trade negotiations.

site_title: Controlling shareholder of Chew's Group enters into conditional agreement to sell stake
summary: The controlling shareholder of Chew's Group, Fenghe Investment Holding, has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement with Goldhill Trust to sell its 68.14% stake in Chew's for S$12.13 million. Upon completion, Goldhill Trust will make a mandatory general offer for the rest of the group at S$0.2107 per share, a 27.3% discount to the last traded price. The pre-conditions must be fulfilled by Oct 8, or the SPA will be terminated. Goldhill Trust plans to review Chew's business to strengthen its financial position and optimize operations.

site_title: Australia cancels livestock shipper's live export licence after sheep deaths at sea
summary: Australia's government has cancelled the live export licence of Emanuel Exports Pty Ltd, the country's largest livestock shipper, after thousands of sheep died from heat stress during a shipment to the Middle East in 2017. The decision followed a thorough investigation and show cause process. Emanuel Exports has vowed to appeal the decision, citing a "proud history of complying with government regulation." The move comes after Australia introduced measures to improve animal welfare standards for live exports, including reducing the number of sheep carried during the northern hemisphere summer.

site_title: Nam Cheong returns to the black in Q2
summary: Nam Cheong, a marine player, reported a net profit of RM34.74 million for the second quarter, reversing a loss of RM2.02 billion a year ago. Revenue declined 16% due to lower shipbuilding segment revenue. The company's net profit for the half year rose to RM557.22 million due to debt restructuring. A proposed rights issue of up to 2.09 billion new shares has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange, with net proceeds mainly used for working capital and debt repayment.

site_title: More to saving the earth than singling out use of grocery plastic bags
summary: Singaporeans are calling for a ban on single-use plastic bags, joining over 60 countries in the effort to combat plastic pollution. However, a blanket ban may not be feasible due to unique factors in the city-state, where 90% of residents live in high-rise buildings and plastic bags have solved a waste-disposal problem. Instead, measures that make sense in other countries may be adapted to suit Singapore's specific needs. The call for a ban highlights the growing global awareness of the dangers of plastic pollution, driven by images of animals suffocated by plastics.

site_title: Chinese phone giant Xiaomi delivers growth in first results
summary: Xiaomi Corp reported a 68% revenue jump and quarterly profit of 14.7 billion yuan, exceeding expectations. The company's net income turned positive after booking a one-time gain from revaluing preferred stock. Xiaomi's internet services business grew 9% and accounted for a significant portion of revenue, helping the company price its IPO at higher multiples. However, challenges persist, including competition from local rivals and a saturated Chinese market. Xiaomi aims to grow services income and expand into emerging markets, with a focus on "honest prices" to acquire users.

site_title: US, China to resume trade talks in Washington amid low expectations
summary: US and Chinese officials are set to resume trade talks in Washington amid low expectations, with US President Donald Trump predicting little progress. The talks, led by mid-level officials, come ahead of scheduled tariff hikes on Thursday. China hopes for "quiet, steady talks" to resolve the trade dispute, while Trump believes resolving the issue will "take time" due to China's strong economy. The talks aim to address US demands for sweeping economic policy changes, including intellectual property protection and reduced industrial subsidies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks notch up four sessions of straight gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 0.63% to 27,927.58, amid planned trade talks between China and the US. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.70% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 1.14%. Investors reversed an early sell-off, likely due to optimism over the trade talks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen eases
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by a weakened yen and rallies on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.20%, while the Topix index gained 0.04%. The gains were attributed to hopes that the US is working towards defusing trade conflicts with China.

site_title: Japan probes claim ministries cheated on disabled hiring quota
summary: Japan is investigating claims that government ministries have overstated the number of disabled employees to meet a hiring quota. Local media reported that the land and internal affairs ministries had padded their data. The problem may be broader, with similar reports emerging at other ministries and local governments. The investigation aims to determine the extent of the alleged cheating and its impact on the country's disability hiring efforts.

site_title: China defence minister meets Indian PM as ties warm further
summary: Chinese Defence Minister Wei Fenghe praised India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi, describing their relationship as a long-standing friendship dating back to ancient times. During a meeting, Wei emphasized the importance of deepening security exchanges, strengthening mutual trust, and protecting peace on their border. The two countries agreed to open a new chapter in ties after a dispute over a Himalayan border stretch in April. Despite deep mistrust over their border dispute, the meeting aimed to further discuss the issue and strengthen their partnership.

site_title: Ministers offer to quit as Australia political crisis deepens
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull narrowly survived a challenge to his leadership after a 48-35 Liberal party ballot victory. The move came amid a leadership crisis fueled by poor opinion polls and a revolt against his plans to embed carbon emissions targets. At least 10 ministers have since offered their resignations, deepening the crisis. The situation appears to be heading towards another challenge against Turnbull, with the populist Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton likely to make another move. Turnbull's future as Prime Minister remains uncertain.

site_title: Sea loss widens on investment in Shopee e-commerce platform
summary: Sea Ltd., operator of Southeast Asia's biggest gaming platform, posted a wider quarterly loss of $250.8 million, despite a 71% increase in adjusted revenue to $219.6 million. The company is investing heavily in its e-commerce platform Shopee, which competes with Alibaba-backed Tokopedia and Lazada. Shopee's second-quarter gross merchandise value reached $2.2 billion, and Sea raised its 2018 forecast for e-commerce gross merchandise value to $8.2-8.7 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.30% at open on Wednesday, following a strong lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 27,836.68. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.07% and 0.20% respectively. The gains were attributed to hopes of a positive outcome from China-US trade talks this week.

site_title: US feud helps Erdogan deflect blame for Turkey's economic woes
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is diverting attention from Turkey's economic woes by blaming the US for the country's problems, analysts say. The US's sanctions on Turkey have led to a sharp decline in the lira's value, but Erdogan is using this as an excuse to shift blame to the US rather than addressing internal economic issues. This tactic plays on widespread anti-American sentiment in Turkey, allowing Erdogan to deflect criticism and maintain control. The US measures have exacerbated Turkey's economic troubles, but Erdogan is using them to his advantage.

site_title: Hackers target smartphones to mine cryptocurrencies
summary: Hackers are targeting smartphones to mine cryptocurrencies through a type of cyberattack called "cryptojacking." This involves installing malware to exploit the device's processing power, causing it to slow down, overheat, and drain battery life. Security experts warn that users may not notice the issue until it's too late. Gerome Billois, an expert, described cryptojacking as entrapping an internet server, personal computer, or smartphone to mine cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Uber hires CFO on the road to IPO
summary: Uber named Nelson Chai as its new CFO, bringing over a decade of experience from firms like CIT Group and Merrill Lynch. Uber's CEO Dara Khosrowshahi expressed excitement about Chai's addition, stating he will be a great partner in the company's journey towards becoming a public company. The ride-sharing service reported a $891 million loss in Q2, despite increased revenue, and is investing in new ventures like Uber Eats and environmentally friendly modes of transport. Chai's hire comes ahead of Uber's planned initial public offering (IPO) in late 2019.

site_title: Actress Asia Argento denies sexual relationship with underage teen
summary: Actress Asia Argento has denied allegations of a sexual relationship with 17-year-old actor Jimmy Bennett in 2013, calling them part of a "long-standing persecution". Argento, a prominent #MeToo movement figure, had paid Bennett $380,000 to keep quiet about the alleged incident. She claims the payment was made by her late boyfriend Anthony Bourdain to help Bennett financially and avoid further harassment. Police in California are not currently investigating, but an enquiry will be made.

site_title: Panic but no injuries as Venezuela hit by 7.3 magnitude earthquake
summary: A 7.3-magnitude earthquake struck Venezuela's northeastern coast, causing panic but no immediate injuries or damage. The quake was felt for several seconds, affecting several states, including the capital Caracas, with some buildings evacuated due to fears of aftershocks. Venezuela's Interior Minister Nestor Reverol called for calm, stating there were no reports of victims, and the US Pacific Tsunami Warning Center said there was no tsunami threat. The country is already struggling with an economic and political crisis.

site_title: Singapore real estate will endure as popular asset class
summary: Singapore's real estate market is expected to remain a popular choice for long-term wealth creation due to its regional hub status, solid growth prospects, and Asian investors' desire for property ownership. Cooling measures implemented in July have not deterred demand, with analysts attributing it to demographics, foreign buyers seeking yield, and the city-state's favorable tax environment. Experts predict the market will remain resilient, with Reits and property stocks offering alternative investment options, and property ownership remaining a cultural and psychological imperative for many Singaporeans.

site_title: GIC snapping up significant minority stake in Indian real estate developer
summary: Sovereign wealth fund GIC is acquiring a significant minority stake in Indian real estate developer Provenance Land, which owns a luxury hotel and private residences in Mumbai. The investment aims to expand Provenance Land's presence in high-end developments, with GIC bringing international expertise and long-term capital to the table. The partnership is seen as a key milestone for Provenance Land, with Adarsh Jatia stating that it will help deliver on the company's vision and create value for stakeholders. The investment is also expected to capitalize on Mumbai's growth potential.

site_title: Facebook cuts ad-target options to thwart discrimination
summary: Facebook is cutting over 5,000 ad-targeting options to prevent advertisers from discriminating based on traits such as religion or race. The move eliminates targeting options for ethnicity, beliefs, and other sensitive data. The decision comes after the US Department of Housing and Urban Development accused Facebook of allowing discriminatory ads. Facebook will require all US advertisers to certify that they accept its non-discrimination policy, and the company plans to expand the measure to more countries in the future.

site_title: Australian shares fall on political uncertainty, NZ hits record intraday high
summary: Australian shares fell on Wednesday, weighed down by materials and financials due to ongoing political uncertainty, with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull surviving a leadership vote against former Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index lost 0.5% to 6,253.4, with financials and materials sectors particularly affected. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index touched an all-time intraday high, driven by consumer discretionary stocks, including dairy giant a2 Milk Company Ltd, which reported a 12.8% jump in interim profit.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of trade talks, Trump woes return
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday, with Tokyo up 0.5% and Seoul 0.3% despite recent gains, while Hong Kong and Shanghai slipped. US President Donald Trump's legal troubles, including his lawyer Michael Cohen's admission to campaign finance violations, weighed on Wall Street futures. The pound rose against the dollar, breaking above US$1.29, after EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said officials would work non-stop on talks. Despite optimism for trade talks between China and the US, analysts say Asia was due a breather and investors remain cautious.

site_title: China expects Taiwan's last Africa ally will switch to Beijing soon
summary: China expects the Kingdom of eSwatini, Taiwan's last African ally, to switch diplomatic ties to Beijing soon. This comes after China won over the third Taipei ally in a year, with El Salvador becoming the third country to switch allegiances to China. China has been increasing pressure on eSwatini ahead of the Beijing summit with African leaders, with Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister Chen Xiaodong expressing hope that all African nations will join China's positive cooperation. Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen has vowed not to bow to Chinese pressure, citing her commitment to maintaining the status quo and defending democracy.

site_title: Trump says Manafort verdict doesn't change Mueller 'witch hunt'
summary: President Donald Trump called the conviction of former campaign chairman Paul Manafort a "very sad thing" but again claimed the investigation as a "witch hunt." Manafort was found guilty on eight counts, including bank and tax fraud, unrelated to Russian collusion. Trump also downplayed the guilty plea of former personal attorney Michael Cohen, calling his former fixer a "liar." Trump expressed concern about the potential impact on the midterm elections, with some aides and allies worried about the possibility of Democratic gains. Trump continues to dispute Mueller's investigation findings.

site_title: Facebook stops misinformation campaigns tied to Iran, Russia
summary: Facebook has stopped misinformation campaigns linked to Iran and Russia ahead of US elections. The social network removed over 650 pages, groups, and accounts deemed misleading, tracing content back to Iran and Russian intelligence operations. This move is part of Facebook's efforts to combat fake news. The investigation was ongoing, with US law enforcement notified, and CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the actions were taken to protect users.

site_title: Business groups urge Trump, Erdogan to meet as dispute hits investments
summary: US-Turkey business groups are urging President Donald Trump and President Tayyip Erdogan to meet to resolve a dispute affecting investor confidence and forcing firms to suspend investment plans. The dispute centers on the release of American pastor Andrew Brunson and US sanctions on Turkish state-owned Halkbank. The countries' relationship has been strained, causing a $300 million merger deal to be suspended and increasing trade and investment uncertainty. The Turkish currency has lost 40% of its value against the US dollar this year, and the lira's weakness has affected Turkish banks and corporates.

site_title: US ends goverment foray into Wall Street's rental home bonds
summary: The Federal Housing Finance Agency announced that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will no longer provide financing guarantees to Wall Street firms' single-family rental home bonds, effective immediately. This decision was made after the regulator's director, Melvin Watt, stated that the larger single-family rental investor market continues to perform successfully without the liquidity provided by the government-sponsored enterprises. The move is expected to limit large investors' ability to tap into the market.

site_title: American Airlines cuts second US-China flight on fuel cost, rivalry
summary: American Airlines is cutting its second US-China flight, a route between Chicago and Shanghai, due to high fuel costs and increased competition. The airline cited unsustainable costs and opportunities in other markets. This move follows a similar decision to cancel a Chicago-Beijing flight in May. Chinese aviation regulator easing long-haul international route policies has led to increased competition, giving Chinese carriers an advantage. US airlines face challenges with growing demand from China, expected to nearly triple to 12.8 million passengers by 2024.

site_title: Mexico's new government wants fintech, banks to help financial inclusion
summary: Mexico's new government aims to increase financial inclusion by partnering with fintech companies and large corporate banks. Despite only one-third of adults having a bank account, the country faces challenges in providing access to financial products and services, particularly in rural areas. The government plans to develop digital banking services and revisit Mexico's fintech law to improve financial inclusion. Deputy finance ministers Arturo Herrera and Gerardo Esquivel will work to create a basic infrastructure for transactions and combine welfare programs to fight poverty and inequality.

site_title: British pharmacy Superdrug says customers' information was compromised
summary: British pharmacy Superdrug announced that customers' personal information, including names, addresses, dates of birth, and telephone numbers, may have been compromised. The company confirmed that payment card information was not affected. Superdrug advised customers to change their online passwords and contacted the police and Action Fraud. The incident is believed to be the result of a hacker attempting to extort a ransom from the company.

site_title: Fed's Kaplan sees three or four more rate hikes, then a pause
summary: Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan expects 3-4 more interest rate hikes to reach a neutral level of 2.5-2.75%, at which point the Fed will reassess the economy and consider its next steps. Kaplan believes the US economy is in the late stages of an expansion, with growth expected to slow to 3% this year and potentially 2% next year. He sees the interest rate hikes as a means to manage imbalances and extend the current economic expansion.

site_title: Banks should not assume fraud victims are at fault: UK watchdog
summary: The UK's Financial Ombudsman Service has stated that banks should not assume fraud victims are negligent when they fall for scams. The service's chief, Caroline Wayman, says it's not fair to automatically label customers as grossly negligent due to a scam. This stance aims to prevent banks from denying liability for money lost to fraud, emphasizing the responsibility of the financial institution rather than the customer.

site_title: Trump's EPA unveils weaker alternative to Obama power plant rule
summary: The Trump administration's Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed a weaker alternative to the Obama-era Clean Power Plan, allowing states to write their own rules for coal-fired power plants. The new plan would reduce carbon emissions guidelines and allow power plant owners to sidestep costly permits. Critics warn of dire environmental and health consequences, including higher carbon dioxide emissions and increased pollution-related deaths. The proposal is part of the administration's efforts to roll back environmental rules and boost domestic fossil fuels production.

site_title: Israel bans Juul e-cigarettes citing 'grave' public health risk
summary: Israel has banned the import and sale of e-cigarettes made by Juul Labs due to a "grave" public health risk posed by their high nicotine content. The ban, signed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, goes into effect in 15 days. Juul Labs expressed disappointment and plans to appeal the decision, citing its devices as a "true alternative to combustible cigarettes." The move follows similar restrictions in Europe and comes amid scrutiny over the popularity of Juul products with teenagers.

site_title: US Commerce Dept says six countries dumped welded pipe in US market
summary: The US Commerce Department has made a preliminary determination that six countries - Canada, China, Greece, India, South Korea, and Turkey - are dumping large-diameter welded pipe in the US market. The pipe is being sold at rates ranging from 3.45% to 132.63% below fair value, with some countries facing up to 500% duties. The department previously found imports from four countries - China, India, South Korea, and Turkey - to be unfairly subsidized, imposing preliminary duties in some cases. Further action is pending.

site_title: India's small renewables firms fighting consolidation wave
summary: India's small renewable energy companies are facing a consolidation wave due to lenders and investors withholding funds, citing stiff competition, weak bond markets, and high debt. This trend could limit growth opportunities and threaten India's target of 175 gigawatts of renewables capacity by 2022. Many smaller operators are being gobbled up or offering themselves for sale, with some companies, like Greenko Group, buying assets from larger companies. The trend began in 2016, and experts predict that only a few big companies and regional firms will remain active in the sector.

site_title: Oscar-winning director Danny Boyle quits new Bond movie
summary: Danny Boyle, the Oscar-winning director of "Slumdog Millionaire," has quit the 25th James Bond movie, reportedly due to creative differences with producers Michael G. Wilson and Barbara Broccoli. Boyle was set to partner with screenwriter John Hodge on the film, which is expected to begin filming in December and release on October 25, 2024. Boyle's departure leaves the future of the project uncertain, with speculation surrounding Idris Elba as a potential replacement for Daniel Craig, who is set to make his fifth appearance as Bond.

site_title: World's biggest wealth fund struggles under weight of trade war
summary: Norway's $1 trillion Government Pension Fund Global reported a $20 billion gain in the second quarter, driven by a rally in US markets. However, the fund's longer-term prospects are threatened by a deepening global trade war, with rising protectionism expected to negatively impact its return model. The fund delivered a 1.8% return, with oil and gas stocks contributing to the gain, but lost 5.7% in emerging markets and 4% on Chinese equities. The fund's diversification strategy, which includes a 70% stock allocation, may struggle to navigate global turmoil.

site_title: Oil auction from Brazil transfer-of-rights area unlikely in 2018: minister
summary: Brazil's Deputy Mining and Energy Minister Marcio Felix said an oil auction in the country's transfer-of-rights region is unlikely in 2018. The government transferred rights to extract 5 billion barrels of oil and gas to state-run oil company Petrobras in 2010, but now estimates suggest the volumes are much larger. The government wants to sell the rights to extract extra oil, but a deal with Petrobras and Senate approval are needed first, with the latter required to approve legislation allowing Petrobras to cede up to 70% of the area to other oil companies.

site_title: Phoenix Heights sold en bloc for S$33.1m
summary: Phoenix Heights condominium in Bukit Panjang, Singapore, was sold en bloc for S$33.1 million, defying recent property cooling measures. The 32-unit leasehold property, built in 1969, will be redeveloped by USB Holdings, which plans to apply for a fresh 99-year lease. The sale was overseen by ERA Realty and was funded through internal resources and bank borrowings. The acquisition is not expected to impact OKP's earnings per share or net tangible assets. The sale price took into account prevailing market conditions and surrounding property prices.

site_title: Top shark movie since Jaws may solve the US-China film puzzle
summary: The movie "The Meg" has become the biggest shark film since 1975's "Jaws" and the most successful co-production between Hollywood and Chinese movie-making houses, grossing $314 million globally. Its success is attributed to its "culture-lite" formula, which avoids culturally specific references, making it appealing to both US and Chinese audiences. The film's executive producer, Jiang Wei, believes this approach will lead to more co-productions that can be successful internationally.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge higher ahead of US-China trade talks
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday ahead of US-China trade talks, which begin on Wednesday. Investors remain cautious despite President Trump's comments that he doesn't expect significant progress. Oil and gas stocks led gains, with John Wood Group and Saipem seeing significant increases. The US dollar weighed on companies with overseas revenue, such as British American Tobacco and Heineken. European stocks are down 1.3% for the year, with analysts at BlackRock expressing concerns over trade, economic momentum, and political risks.

site_title: Oil hits one-week high as Iran-driven rally gathers pace
summary: Oil prices rose to a one-week high on Tuesday, driven by US sanctions on Iran, which boosted crude stockpiles and refinery runs. Brent crude futures reached $72.95 a barrel, the highest level since August 14. The US crude stockpiles fell 5.2 million barrels last week, more than three times analysts' forecasts. Despite the rally, traders and analysts remained cautious due to the ongoing trade dispute between the US and China.

site_title: Singapore and Zhejiang will commit to open trade with bilateral deals: Sim Ann
summary: Singapore and Zhejiang province in China have committed to open trade with bilateral deals, focusing on five key areas: identifying projects, evaluating policies, and promoting dialogue. This move aims to boost global trade, aligning with the Belt and Road Initiative. The two sides have already seen significant investment and trade growth, with Singapore investing S$8 billion in Zhejiang and trade value increasing by 44% to S$3.5 billion in the first six months of the year.

site_title: Apple planning low-cost MacBook and pro-focused Mac mini upgrade
summary: Apple is set to release a new low-cost MacBook and an upgraded Mac mini desktop later this year, aiming to revitalize its stagnant Mac lineup. The new MacBook will feature a higher-resolution "Retina" display and thinner bezels, while the Mac mini will receive new storage and processor options. The moves are seen as an attempt to regain market share in the education sector, where Chromebooks have gained popularity. The upgrades are expected to be released in the fall, following the launch of new iPhones and other Apple products.

site_title: Trump's ex-campaign chief Manafort guilty of fraud
summary: Paul Manafort, Donald Trump's former campaign chief, was found guilty of eight counts of fraud, including five counts of making false income tax returns, two counts of bank fraud, and one count of failure to report foreign bank and financial accounts. The verdict came after a partial mistrial on 10 counts, with Manafort's lawyer stating his client is evaluating all options. The case is an important test for the Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian election interference and possible collusion between the Trump campaign team and Moscow.

site_title: US and Mexico postpone Nafta ministerial talks until Wednesday
summary: US and Mexican officials have postponed Nafta ministerial talks until Wednesday, despite meeting earlier on Tuesday. Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo from Mexico will meet US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer on Wednesday, while Jesus Seade, the designated chief negotiator of President-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, met Lighthizer earlier. The talks aim to break through in the renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: Jet Airways India says it's not aware of any inquiry by govt
summary: Jet Airways India Ltd denied receiving any government inquiry into alleged embezzlement of funds, despite a report suggesting the company is under scrutiny. The Registrar of Companies, under the Ministry of Corporate Affairs, has initiated a preliminary inquiry into potential wrongdoing, including diversion of cash and the role of auditors. Shares of the carrier fell 3.9% after the report, and the stock has plummeted 65% this year. Jet Airways will announce its delayed earnings on August 27.

site_title: Trump has yet to deliver promise to bring back coal
summary: US President Donald Trump's promise to revive the coal industry has yet to materialize 19 months into his term. Despite rhetoric, coal production, consumption, and exports are projected to decrease in 2019. Trump's plan to scale back Obama-era greenhouse gas emissions limits and grant states more leeway in regulating plants has been met with skepticism, and analysts expect little change in the industry's fortunes. The industry's decline is attributed to the increasing use of natural gas and renewable power, with utilities opting out of coal-fired plants.

site_title: Paul Allen's space firm details plans for rockets, cargo vehicle
summary: Stratolaunch Systems Corp, a space company founded by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, unveiled plans for medium-lift rockets and a reusable space cargo plane. The company aims to compete in the lucrative launch services market, targeting higher demand for satellite deployment. The rockets will drop from Stratolaunch's six-engine, twin-fuselage airplane, similar to Virgin Galactic's method, and are expected to launch as early as 2022. The company also plans to develop a reusable space plane and a variant with a payload capacity of 6,000 kg, with potential for human cargo transport.

site_title: Trade minister unveils plan to make UK export 'superpower'
summary: Trade Secretary Liam Fox unveiled the UK's future export strategy, aiming to increase exports as a proportion of GDP by 5 percentage points over the long term. This move is part of the country's bid to become an "exporting superpower" after Brexit. The strategy's goal is to boost the UK's global trade and economic influence.

site_title: Deutsche Bank raises bet on Noble's US$3.5b rescue plan
summary: Deutsche Bank is doubling down on its bet that Noble Group's US$3.5 billion restructuring plan will succeed. The German lender is offering to buy Noble's senior unsecured bonds for 45% of face value, with the goal of increasing its stake in the reorganized company. Creditors who back the debt-for-equity swap will receive a more valuable package of new securities, creating an opportunity for Deutsche Bank to acquire bonds from investors who are unwilling or unable to participate. The deal, which includes trade finance and a hedging facility, aims to hand creditors a 70% ownership stake in Noble.

site_title: PBOC says it won't resort to strong stimulus
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced it won't use strong stimulus to support the slowing economy but will maintain liquidity and offer help to companies struggling with financing. The bank reiterated it won't manipulate the yuan to deal with trade frictions. Policymakers will focus on reducing risks to growth, with measures including easing corporate taxes and fees, and providing loans to smaller businesses. Analysts expect further stimulus measures, but predict a measured response rather than large-scale stimulus.

site_title: US oil prices hold firm; fuel markets expected to tighten
summary: US oil prices held firm on Tuesday, with WTI crude futures rising 30 cents to $66.73 per barrel. Fuel markets are expected to tighten, driven by low US inventories of refined products such as diesel and heating oil. However, the release of 11 million barrels of crude from the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve may offset expected supply cuts due to Iran sanctions. Global demand is expected to grow by 1.4 million barrels per day in 2018 and 2019, according to BNP Paribas, suggesting that markets may remain supplied.

site_title: Detroit carmakers dream ahead while residents are stuck in traffic
summary: Detroit's residents face significant traffic congestion, ranking among the top 7% of US cities, with commuters spending an average of 35 hours in congested traffic last year. The city's lack of reliable public transportation, dating back to the 20th century, hinders the development of carmakers' mobility services. Despite efforts by Ford and GM to shift towards mobility services, progress is slow, and coordination on transit remains a challenge. The city's car-centric culture and limited public transit options lead to residents working from home or relying on ride-hailing services, exacerbating the issue.

images.alt_text: Detroit ranks in the top 7 per cent for traffic congestion out of 300 US cities, with the average commuter spending 35 hours in congested traffic last year.

site_title: Mahathir to scrap China-backed projects worth US$22b
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced the cancellation of three China-backed projects worth US$22 billion due to financial constraints. The projects include a railway and two gas pipelines. Mahathir aims to reduce Malaysia's national debt, which has reached US$250 billion. Despite the cancellation, he sought to strengthen business ties with Beijing, citing China's willingness to help resolve Malaysia's fiscal problems.

site_title: Daikin, thriving in Asia and India, sets its sights on Africa
summary: Daikin Industries, the world's largest air-conditioning equipment maker, is expanding into Africa, following its successful entry into Asia and India 10 years ago. Despite conventional wisdom that the company should focus on high-end markets, Daikin has prioritized low-cost production to boost its global presence. The company plans to set up a regional office in east Africa, led by Indian industry veteran Kanwal Jeet Jawa, who also oversaw Daikin's expansion in India.

site_title: Foreign marques oppose Trump Nafta plan as US-Mexico talks resume
summary: Foreign automakers, including Toyota, Volkswagen, and Hyundai, oppose the Trump administration's plan to increase local content in North American-made vehicles, citing concerns over increased costs and competitiveness. Talks between US and Mexico resumed in Washington, with Canadian participation expected to follow. The negotiations aim to resolve bilateral issues and finalize a deal before the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) expires. The outcome will impact the automotive industry and trade relations between the US, Mexico, and Canada.

site_title: Workplace software startup Slack valued at US$7.1b in new funding
summary: Slack, a workplace collaboration software startup, raised $427 million in funding, valuing it at $7.1 billion. The company has over 8 million daily active users and 70,000 paid teams. Slack aims to simplify and enhance work experience, competing with Microsoft, Facebook, and others offering similar tools. The funding makes Slack one of the most valuable "unicorns" with private funding worth over $1 billion.

site_title: Blue is the new green
summary: The oceans, covering 71% of the Earth's surface, are gaining global attention for their importance in the environment and commerce. Politicians and the public are slowly understanding the significance of ocean health, which is crucial for the Earth's water supply. The Hawaii Pacific University's Oceanic Institute notes that the oceans contain 97% of the Earth's water. As a result, the shipping industry is recognizing the environmental and commercial benefits of addressing ocean health, making it a pressing cause.

site_title: Artificial intelligence - The CFO's strategic ally
summary: CFOs face increasing stress due to economic uncertainty, regulation, and investor scrutiny. Advances in artificial intelligence (AI) are helping alleviate this burden by automating routine tasks, revealing predictive insights, and improving decision-making. CFOs can use AI to free up time for strategic work, prioritize payments, and make informed decisions. By leveraging cloud-based applications, CFOs can connect internal and external data, analyze patterns, and provide actionable recommendations. Implementing AI can help CFOs accelerate workflow, improve business outcomes, and future-proof their organization in an era of uncertainty.

site_title: HK family buys Club St shophouse for S$21.8m
summary: A 999-year leasehold shophouse at 64 Club Street in Singapore is being sold for S$21.8 million, working out to S$3,880 per square foot based on its estimated 5,618 sq ft built-up area.

images.alt_text: A 3D steel-rod wall mural mounted on the side facade of 64 Club Street depicts a series of caricatures featuring familiar characters from Singapore's past such as the coolie, the samsui woman and the rickshaw puller.

site_title: Ex-Trump lawyer Cohen, in guilty plea, says made payments at candidate's direction
summary: Michael Cohen, former personal lawyer to US President Donald Trump, pleaded guilty to campaign finance violations and other charges, admitting he made payments to influence the 2016 election at Trump's direction. Cohen pleaded guilty to one count of willfully causing an unlawful corporate campaign contribution and one count of making an excessive campaign contribution. He faces a possible prison sentence of up to five years and three months. The guilty plea came after a federal jury convicted former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort of eight charges of tax and bank fraud.

images.alt_text: Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump's former personal attorney and fixer, exits federal court, August 21, 2018 in New York City. Cohen reached an agreement with prosecutors, pleading guilty to charges involving bank fraud, tax fraud and campaign finance violations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Industries' unit Sembcorp Gayatri Power Limited won a tender to supply 250 megawatts of power to Bangladesh Power Development Board over 15 years. Analysts expect more exports due to Bangladesh's power shortage and potential imports from India. Uni-Asia Group's Q2 results were in line with expectations, with hotel operations set to benefit from the Tokyo Olympics and Rugby World Cup. Analysts maintain "buy" calls for both companies, citing growth potential and lower sector valuations.

site_title: Macau's gaming industry faces two disruptions
summary: Macau's gaming industry is facing two disruptions: licence expiry and competition from Japan and the Chinese province of Hainan. Licence renewal is due in March 2020 for two concessionaires, with potential scenarios including a one-time payment or entrance of a seventh concessionaire. Competition from Hainan could chip off 15% of Macau's gaming revenue by 2025, while Japan may impact 5%. The industry market capitalisation could decline by $60 billion if the worst-case scenario occurs, or trade at a 42% upside if licence renewal is successful.

site_title: US dollar weakens after Trump criticises Fed
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's interest rate hikes, stating he wants the US dollar to be weaker to boost the economy. The US dollar index fell 0.4% to 95.544 against a basket of six currencies, its lowest since August 9. Investors are cautious ahead of talks between the US and China over trade, which may ease tensions and reduce the dollar's appeal. Analysts say Trump's verbal attacks on the Fed are unlikely to have a significant impact on the dollar's value.

site_title: Microsoft links fake websites to Russian hackers
summary: Microsoft has linked five fake websites to Russian hackers, affiliated with the notorious APT28 group, which has been linked to a Russian intelligence agency. The fake sites, created over several months, were designed to trick US political players into visiting and hacking into their computers. Microsoft's Digital Crimes Unit discovered and disabled the sites, and the company is launching an initiative to provide expanded cybersecurity protections for campaigns and election agencies using Microsoft products. This effort comes ahead of the midterm congressional elections in the US, where officials have warned of Russian interference efforts.

site_title: Italy gives EU cause for concern even as Greece clears its debts
summary: Italy's economic woes, following an inconclusive general election, raise concerns for the eurozone's future. The country's debt load of over 130% of GDP and under-performing banking sector pose significant threats. Unlike Greece, which has made progress in paying off its bailout package, Italy's populist government may struggle to implement structural reforms, potentially leading to further economic paralysis. The new Italian government's budget plans, which include significant spending and potential breaches of EU budgetary rules, could further destabilize the eurozone.

site_title: When a US$1,000 gift is better than US$1m
summary: Bill Gates and other high-profile philanthropists are shifting focus to smaller, local gifts, rather than megaphilanthropy, to feel their donations truly matter. KentPresents, a highbrow ideas festival, is donating $1,000 to $10,000 to local social service agencies in Litchfield County, Connecticut, helping organizations like The Gathering Place and a volunteer fire department. This trend is part of a broader movement to make individual donations more impactful, as big gifts can feel like a drop in the bucket compared to what billionaires and foundations are giving.

site_title: STI inches lower; Noble sees new dawn
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trader, saw a 22.9% surge in its share price, making it the most actively traded counter by volume on the Singapore bourse for the day. The Straits Times Index (STI) eased 0.2% to close at 3,199.89. The jump follows media reports that Deutsche Bank is offering to buy Noble's senior unsecured bonds and founder Richard Elman's announcement that he won't take up the position of executive director at the new Noble.

site_title: Slowing Malaysian economy could be a challenge for new regime
summary: Malaysia's new government, led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, marked its 100th day in office, with mixed reviews. The regime has fulfilled some election pledges, such as scrapping the Goods and Services Tax, and has seen improved public trust in institutions. However, the economy is slowing down, with a negative second-quarter GDP growth rate of 4.5%, and macro headwinds from trade wars and tightening monetary policy. The government's approval ratings are high, but the country's fiscal stance and investment activities may not be enough to cushion the economy from a slowdown.

site_title: View, trade and settle in various currencies: SGX trials view-only prototype service
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is testing a new service that allows investors to view, trade, and settle in multiple currencies. In partnership with fintech firm M-Daq, the service enables investors to view real-time prices of Straits Times Index component stocks in selected currencies, increasing investment yield and risk management. The view-only prototype is available for investors to provide feedback, and a multi-currency trading service is expected to enhance risk management and access to the securities market.

site_title: Denis Tang to be new CPIB director from Oct 1
summary: Denis Tang Siew Taeng, current deputy commissioner of operations at the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority, will become the new director of the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) on October 1. He will replace Wong Hong Kuan, who served as CPIB director since 2013. Tang is credited with strengthening border security and intelligence capabilities during his time at ICA. The Prime Minister's Office praised outgoing CPIB chief Wong for his efforts to promote good governance and ethical business practices.

site_title: US: S&P touches record high, equals longest-ever bull run
summary: The S&P 500 index reached a record high, equaling its longest-ever bull-market run, on August 21, 2018, with a 0.6% rise. The benchmark index closed at 2,873.23 points, surpassing its previous record high of 2,872.87 on January 26. The longest bull-market run would become 3,452 days old on Wednesday. Industrial stocks rose 0.8%, driven by optimism over the US-China trade dispute resolution, while consumer discretionary stocks climbed 0.9% on strong earnings reports.

site_title: Tech boom, competition for talent to support Asia-Pacific's prime office rental growth
summary: The Asia-Pacific office market is expected to experience growth driven by the tech boom, with key cities such as Hong Kong, Melbourne, Seoul, and Sydney seeing prime rents rise 2-5% per year from 2018 to 2020. Singapore's prime office market is expected to outperform the region, while logistics markets are also expected to grow due to e-commerce expansion. However, labor shortages and rising construction costs may limit growth, and rental growth is expected to perform in line with inflation for most markets.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vibrant Group has appointed Ernst & Young Advisory as special auditor for its subsidiary Blackgold International Holdings, following irregularities and accounting issues. Midas Holdings received a writ of summons in a defamation suit filed by former executive chairman Chen Wei Ping. China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings agreed to sell loss-making subsidiaries for 204 million yuan, with shareholder approval required.

site_title: Why accountants should embrace Machine Learning
summary: Recent technology advancements have enabled Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) to transform the accounting industry. ML is being implemented to streamline operations, reduce time and costs, and increase productivity. Unlike analytics, which uses data to gain insights, ML uses mathematical algorithms to train computers to generate rules, recognize patterns, and make predictions. By automating repetitive tasks, accountants can focus on higher-level tasks that require professional judgment and interpretation, providing valuable insights to clients. This shift enables accountants to offer sought-after services that machines cannot replicate.

images.alt_text: ML is an analysis method which uses mathematical algorithms to train computers in the processing and analysing of large amounts of data, allowing them to generate rules, recognise patterns and make classification predictions.

site_title: SIA pushes on with reforms, ties up with Alibaba and works on brand overhaul
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is seeking a creative agency to help with its branding makeover and digital capabilities, partnering with e-commerce giant Alibaba to leverage its expertise. The airline is looking to modernize its iconic brand and cut through the changing marketing landscape with data-driven insights. SIA will also collaborate with Alibaba on areas such as flight ticket sales, loyalty programs, and logistics. The partnership aims to enhance the airline's digital capabilities and provide innovative travel solutions to customers.

images.alt_text: SIA has invited advertising agencies to come up with an impactful integrated solution to address the changing marketing and communications landscape and also to make the SIA brand stand out.

site_title: Some techies are ditching Silicon Valley for Japan's manga, anime and video games
summary: Techies are shifting from Silicon Valley to Japan, drawn by the country's vibrant pop culture and growing tech industry. Companies like Line Corp and Mercari Inc are actively recruiting global talent, offering competitive salaries and a welcoming work culture. Despite Japan's aging population and limited immigration policies, the government has introduced a point system to fast-track permanent residency for skilled workers. However, many companies remain monolingual and have a long way to go in terms of diversity, with some firms even requiring employees to learn Japanese to work effectively.

site_title: Govt to gather feedback on new housing initiatives: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's government plans to gather feedback on new housing initiatives, aiming to fine-tune policies before their implementation. National Development Minister Lawrence Wong announced the move, acknowledging concerns among Singaporeans about the future of public housing. Key policies include the Voluntary Early Redevelopment Scheme (Vers), lease buyback scheme expansion, and easing of rules for using CPF savings to buy older flats. The government aims to engage with Singaporeans over the next few months or years to gather feedback and ideas on these policies.

site_title: High-level visitors to Pyongyang may achieve peace
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is expected to visit Pyongyang, North Korea, amid concerns over the denuclearization agreement reached by US President Donald Trump and North Korean Chairman Kim Jong Un in Singapore. China, a key player in the Korean nuclear issue, is pushing for an end-of-war declaration involving South Korea, North Korea, the US, and China. The visit may provide an opportunity for clarity on North Korea's willingness to denuclearize and the timing of complete denuclearization. President Moon Jae In of South Korea and President Xi Jinping of China are also set to visit Pyongyang, further complicating the negotiations.

site_title: Shanghai steel retreats from gains, tight supply concerns remain
summary: Shanghai steel futures retreated 0.2% to 4,337 yuan (S$866) a tonne, despite concerns about tight supply due to strengthened production restrictions in China. Rebar prices rose nearly 5% since last Friday, driven by news of environmental measures in Tangshan and Jiangsu. However, steel mills and associations denied receiving further production curbs from the government, saying market frenzy may lead to unsustainable moves. Despite this, prices may start to slow as Jiangsu Shagang Group raised rebar prices by 150 yuan a tonne.

site_title: More than infrastructure and connectivity
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is a global development strategy aiming to promote cooperation and connectivity between Asian, European, and African countries. Launched by President Xi Jinping in 2013, BRI consists of overland and maritime routes, with China investing over $1 trillion in the project. The initiative is expected to create jobs, alleviate poverty, and improve living standards, with benefits extending to both developed and developing countries. China has already provided significant help in improving connectivity and developing infrastructure in many BRI countries, with the aim of promoting cost-effective projects and reducing resistance to the initiative.

site_title: India companies may find offshore loans more costly as easy money ends
summary: Indian companies may face more expensive foreign currency loans as banks become more selective, with spreads on investment-grade dollar loans expected to rise over the next six months. This comes as local lenders struggle with non-performing debt, and the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening pushes up dollar rates. After enjoying the cheapest loan costs in over a decade, Indian companies may be forced to rely more on international creditors, adding to forecasts of a market turn. Local lenders' growing pickiness and the government's plan to support state-owned lenders may not be enough to mitigate the impact.

site_title: Fed should do more to help boost the economy: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve under Chairman Jerome Powell, saying the central bank should do more to boost the economy. Trump expressed dissatisfaction with the Fed's interest rate hikes and accused China and Europe of manipulating their currencies. The Fed has raised interest rates twice this year, and Trump believes other countries are benefiting from their central banks' moves during trade talks. Trump's comments may affect the Fed's candidates for open seats on the seven-member board, with analysts doubting they will be swayed by his outbursts.

site_title: Singapore police recover over S$27m linked to Ezubao Ponzi scheme
summary: Singapore police have recovered over S$27 million in proceeds linked to China's Ezubao Ponzi scheme, a large-scale online peer-to-peer lender found to be a massive fraud. The recovered money was returned to China after a Beijing court convicted 26 individuals of fraud and other offenses.

site_title: Automation goes beyond tech to transform your business
summary: Automation is transforming businesses, but it's crucial to view it as a business-driven exercise rather than a technology project. Companies should define their objectives, select processes to change, and then decide on relevant technologies. Finance functions have the highest potential for automation, with 80% of tasks potentially automatable. CFOs should prioritize understanding automation possibilities, distinguish between robotic process automation (RPA) and artificial intelligence (AI), and consider cognitive automation for complex tasks. Organisational transformation is also essential, requiring stakeholder engagement, change management, and collaboration across the business.

site_title: Baodi in mandatory cash offer for Techcomp
summary: Baodi International Investment has made a mandatory unconditional cash offer for shares in Techcomp Holdings, a Singapore-listed scientific equipment supplier, after acquiring a 61.5% stake. The offer was triggered after Baodi completed the acquisition of shares held by Techcomp's president, executive director, and controlling shareholder Lo Yat Keung, and other executives. The acquisition is aimed at acquiring the remaining shares held by minority shareholders.

site_title: Tsukiji fish market to stop tourist tuna viewings
summary: Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo will stop admitting tourists to watch its pre-dawn tuna auctions on September 15, as it prepares to move to Toyosu on October 11. The market, which has been in operation for over 80 years, will no longer allow tourists to witness the auctions, which are considered a must-see for visitors. The market will instead open a deck for visitors and a special aisle for viewing the tuna auction through a glass wall at its new location.

site_title: Cambodia's first rum maker looks to expand overseas market
summary: Cambodia's first rum maker, Samai Distillery, aims to expand its overseas market by entering Malaysia, Japan, Hong Kong, and Spain by next year. Founded in 2014, the distillery currently produces 500 bottles of rum a month, with plans to export around 2,000 bottles per country annually. Despite high competition in India, the US, and the Philippines, premium brands are driving demand growth in the rum market, with Samai's Gold Rum and Kampot Pepper Rum winning gold medals at the Madrid International Rum Conference in 2017.

site_title: DBS launches B2B portal for SMEs
summary: DBS Bank has launched a business-to-business (B2B) portal for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), providing access to supply-chain connections, financing, and payment solutions. The platform is a partnership with Mediacorp, Mastercard, and Singtel, and is expected to be launched by the end of the year. The move aims to help SMEs expand their business by digitalizing their operations, with the goal of fostering innovation and collaboration among large corporates, SMEs, and the government.

site_title: Venturing to western China
summary: Singapore tech companies, including video analytics firm Vi Dimensions and smart tourism solutions provider Fooyo, are participating in the Smart China Expo in Chongqing, China, from August 23-25. This marks Singapore's participation as one of the two countries-of-honour at the expo, highlighting the country's close economic ties with Chongqing. The Chongqing Connectivity Initiative aims to boost economic growth, and Singapore companies see opportunities to enter the Chinese market, particularly in smart security and tourism.

site_title: Modi can't afford a weak rupee now
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi faces pressure to maintain a strong rupee due to past GDP data, which suggests growth averaged 8% from 2014 to 2014, compared to 7.4% since then. The data contradicts Modi's claims of a strong economy and could harm his re-election prospects. The opposition Congress Party has pounced on the report, citing India's better economic performance under the previous government. Modi's hands-off approach to the rupee's depreciation may be difficult to maintain, as a weak currency could be seen as a symbol of his failure to deliver economic growth.

site_title: Singtel said to tap Bank of America for pursuit of Australia's Amaysim
summary: Singtel, South-east Asia's largest telecom services provider, is exploring a possible bid for Australian wireless operator Amaysim, with Bank of America assisting in the process. The deal could give Singtel access to Amaysim's 1.1 million mobile subscribers. Amaysim's shares jumped 19% in Tuesday trading, and the company's market value is estimated at A$212 million. Deliberations are at an early stage, and there's no certainty a bid will be made, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: RWS staff show 'kampung' spirit for needy and elderly residents
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) staff spent their day volunteering at low-income rental flats in Singapore, as part of the annual 'aRWSome Volunteer Day'. Over 370 employees, including senior management, visited 45 flats and performed decluttering and cleaning, with the help of experts from the Facilities Management and Engineering department. The initiative, led by RWS Cares, aimed to show "kampung spirit" and support needy and elderly residents. The event was well-received, with 50% more staff volunteers than last year, and a National Day-inspired lunch party was held for 100 elderly beneficiaries.

site_title: Trade war takes its toll on Swiss watch sales
summary: Swiss watch exports cooled in July, with a 2% growth rate, down from 6.6% in June. The decline is attributed to trade tensions between the US and China, with shipments to both countries falling. Despite this, luxury brands such as Kering SA, Hermes International, and LVMH remain unaffected, but investors are cautious due to high valuations and a declining Chinese stock market. The industry's remarkable recovery over the past two years may be slowing down, with a potential impact on luxury brands.

images.alt_text: Trade war takes its toll on Swiss watch sales

site_title: Midas Holdings, directors receive writ of summons in defamation suit
summary: Midas Holdings and its directors have received a writ of summons from the State Courts over alleged defamation by former executive chairman Chen Wei Ping. Chen alleged that 16 Midas announcements between March 22 and July 4 contained defamatory words. The company is seeking legal advice and will issue further announcements as the matter develops. Trading in Midas shares has been suspended since February due to difficulties publishing audit results and preparing an annual report.

site_title: Airbnb, Niido to open 14 home-sharing complexes across US by 2020
summary: Airbnb and its partner Niido plan to open 14 home-sharing complexes across the US by 2020, with the first project in Nashville, Tennessee, transforming a 328-unit apartment building into a mix of long-term rentals and short-term Airbnb stays. The complexes will take 25% of the income generated by residents and rent out the remaining vacant units through Airbnb's platform. The partnership aims to offer a more hotel-like experience, but some residents have expressed concerns and surprise over the changes.

site_title: Farfetch plans to go public as luxury e-commerce grows
summary: Farfetch, a luxury e-commerce platform, plans to go public with an initial public offering (IPO) on the New York Stock Exchange, aiming to raise US$100 million. Founded in 2007, the company has seen significant growth, with a valuation of over US$1 billion and 500 independent luxury boutiques and 200 brands on its platform. Despite not turning a profit since its creation, Farfetch expects to generate revenue from high-end jewelry and watches, and is backed by Chinese e-commerce giant JD.com. The IPO is seen as a sign of growth in the global fashion e-commerce space.

images.alt_text: Farfetch now has almost a billion active consumers, can ship to 190 countries and has created an infrastructure platform that luxury brands can use to develop their own e-commerce businesses.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on earnings, trade optimism
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by encouraging earnings reports and optimism over planned trade talks between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 28.30 points, the S&P 500 gained 4.46 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 19.09 points, marking new highs. The positive start was attributed to anticipation that the trade talks could help resolve the trade spat between the world's two largest economies.

site_title: For as little as US$5,000, you can become a wine collector with Instant Cellars from Sotheby's
summary: Sotheby's has launched "instant cellars" in New York and Hong Kong, offering curated wine collections starting at US$5,000. The service, part of the auction house's goal to become a full-service wine business, includes a consultation with a wine advisor and storage solutions. Four levels of cellars are available, ranging from a starter collection to a US$25,000 "enjoyment cellar" with 168 bottles. The instant cellars feature a selection of classic Bordeaux, Burgundy, and Champagne from excellent vintages, and are suitable for beginners and experienced collectors alike.

site_title: After the bitcoin boom: Hard lessons for cryptocurrency investors
summary: Cryptocurrency investors have suffered significant losses, with the value of outstanding digital tokens falling 75% since January's peak, totaling a US$600 billion decline. Many ordinary investors, including those in South Korea and Japan, have seen their investments drop by 90% or more. The collapse is attributed to irrational exuberance, lack of expertise, and the failure of entrepreneurs to deliver on initial coin offerings. Bitcoin, however, has held up relatively better, with a 70% decline from its all-time highs. Some investors remain optimistic, but many are left financially ruined, with some even considering selling their coins to pay off debts.

images.alt_text: Tony Yoo, a financial analyst in Los Angeles, has invested more than US$100,000 of his savings last autumn. At their lowest point, his holdings have dropped almost 70 per cent in value.

site_title: World's biggest wealth fund struggles under weight of trade war
summary: Norway's $1 trillion wealth fund saw a $20 billion return in the second quarter, a 1.8% gain, despite trade tensions. The fund's stock holdings in emerging markets, including China, declined. The return missed the benchmark index by 0.2 percentage point, with oil and gas stocks contributing the most to the returns. The fund is set to increase its stock holdings to 70% in the coming years, while bonds and real estate make up the remaining 30% and 2% of its portfolio.

site_title: British tycoon killed in seaplane crash leaves £41m to Oxfam
summary: Richard Cousins, 58, a British tycoon, died in a seaplane crash in Australia with his family, leaving behind a £41m fortune to charity Oxfam. Cousins had drawn up a will with a "common tragedy clause" that left his money to Oxfam if he and his sons were killed together. The charity is struggling to cope with a sex abuse scandal and the bequest could help alleviate some of its financial woes. Cousins' family will receive £2 million, with £1 million going to each of his two sons.

site_title: Cambodia's first rum maker looking to export to new international markets
summary: Cambodia's first and only rum producer, Samai Distillery, aims to export to new international markets, including Malaysia, Japan, Hong Kong, and Spain, with initial shipments of 2,000 bottles per country per year. Founded in 2014, the boutique distillery currently produces 500 bottles of rum a month, with two of its brands winning gold medals at the Madrid International Rum Conference in 2017. Despite growing demand for rum in Cambodia, more advertising is needed to raise awareness of the drink among the local population.

site_title: China says won't resort to strong stimulus but will keep liquidity ample
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, stated it won't use strong stimulus to support the slowing economy, but will maintain liquidity and offer more financing help to companies. The bank aims to reduce risks to growth and address financing issues faced by smaller companies. Analysts expect potential cuts in corporate taxes and fees, as well as increased infrastructure spending to cushion the economy. China's economic growth rate slowed to 6.7% in the second quarter, with fixed-asset investment and non-performing loans weakening.

site_title: Malaysia shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.53 points to 1,798.11 on Tuesday, with a 25 million lots traded worth RM2.4 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 549 to 378.

site_title: iFast Corp looking for investors in its Greater China business
summary: iFast Corp, a wealth management firm, is seeking investors for its Hong Kong and mainland China operations. The proposed investment, expected to increase the business's value by 15%, will be used to grow the business, including a planned virtual banking business in Hong Kong. The company has applied for a virtual banking license in Hong Kong and plans to restructure its subsidiaries. The investment is expected to boost net profit, but there is no certainty it will be successful or completed.

site_title: Some techies are shunning Silicon Valley for the Japanese dream
summary: Tech-savvy individuals, particularly those from the US and India, are flocking to Japan to work for Japanese companies, attracted by the country's unique pop culture and growing tech industry. Despite Japan's reputation for long hours and low salaries, companies like Mercari and Ascent Robotics are offering competitive salaries and benefits to attract foreign talent. The government's efforts to attract skilled workers have also led to a rise in international recruitment, with some companies holding sensitivity training to ensure a welcoming work environment.

site_title: EU carbon hits fresh 10-year high on stronger energy, EU climate target talk
summary: The European Union's benchmark carbon price reached a 10-year high of 19.41 euros/tonne, rising almost 5% on Tuesday, driven by stronger energy prices and comments from the European Commission hinting at a potential increase in the bloc's climate target to 45% by 2030. The Commission's analysis suggests this could lead to higher auction volumes and increased demand for carbon permits. This news comes amid lower demand for EU carbon permits in August, with auctions at half their usual volume.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks continued their rally, extending a third consecutive day of gains, driven by anticipation of US-China trade talks resuming this week. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.56%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices jumped 1.31% and 1.39%, respectively. The global market advance contributed to the rally, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Airlines is seeking a creative partner to revamp its brand, with a 23-page Request for Information (RFI) released. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) partnered with fintech firm M-Daq to develop a prototype for multi-currency securities trading. The Singapore Police Force recovered over S$27m linked to China's Ezubao Ponzi scheme. Overseas news includes Vietnam's surprise at US tariff announcements, and China's GDP growth expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: IPS Securex halves its Q4 net loss
summary: IPS Securex Holdings, a Singapore-listed security company, reported a 50% reduction in its Q4 net loss to S$1.37 million, driven by a 76.6% surge in revenue to S$3.67 million. The company attributed the decline in losses to increased direct material costs and a higher cost base for its integrated security solutions business. For the full year, IPS Securex reported a net loss of S$1.29 million, narrowing from S$2.5 million the previous year. The company plans to adopt a more prudent approach to credit risk management and expand its security product range.

site_title: China-backed rail and pipeline projects cancelled for now: PM Mahathir
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced the cancellation of two major projects funded by China: the US$20 billion East Coast Rail Link (ECRL) project and a natural gas pipeline project in Sabah. The projects will be put on hold until Malaysia can afford them, according to Mahathir. The comments were made during a press conference in Beijing during his five-day trip to China. The decision is seen as a response to concerns over the economic implications of the projects, amid growing tensions between Malaysia and China.

site_title: Eagles overtake Michael Jackson with biggest selling album in US
summary: The Eagles' greatest hits box set has surpassed Michael Jackson's "Thriller" as the biggest selling album in the US, with 38 million units sold. The compilation, released in 1976, had previously held the top spot but was overtaken by "Thriller" in 2009. The Eagles' "Hotel California" is now ranked third with 26 million units sold. Don Henley, the group's lead singer, expressed gratitude to fans for sticking with the band over 46 years, following the death of co-founder Glenn Frey in 2016. The group has resumed touring and scheduled US concerts in September.

site_title: Swedish healthcare firm Capio to sell French business to Vivalto Sante
summary: Swedish healthcare firm Capio plans to sell its French business to Vivalto Sante for up to 455 million euros, focusing on its less capital-intensive Nordic operations. The deal, worth up to $710 million, will help Capio pay down debt and return cash to shareholders. The transaction is subject to due diligence, regulatory approval, and shareholder approval. This sale comes after Capio rejected a 661 million euro takeover offer from Ramsay Health Care in July.

site_title: China Gaoxian inks pact to sell loss-making subsidiaries in 204 million yuan deal
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings has inked a 204 million yuan deal to sell its loss-making subsidiaries to businessman Chen Jiarong's Kingwealth International Investments. The sale includes Huaxiang China Gaoxian International Holdings and its units, with 10 million yuan to be paid in cash and the remaining value assigned to payables, receivables, and a loan. The deal aims to rationalize financial and capital resources, reduce debt-to-equity gearing, and improve future operational performance. The transaction is subject to shareholder approval and will be implemented on July 1.

site_title: More refugees find jobs in Germany, integration going "pretty well"
summary: Germany's migrant integration is going "pretty well" according to data, with a growing number of refugees finding jobs and German companies attracting more apprentices from asylum seekers. Figures show 306,574 employed migrants from eight countries, with 197,000 registered as unemployed. The head of Germany's Labour Office said the numbers are better than expected and that the arrivals are not a burden on the country's welfare system. Despite concerns over skilled labor shortages, the data suggests a positive impact of Chancellor Merkel's 2015 decision to open German borders to hundreds of thousands of migrants.

images.alt_text: Figures last week also showed that German companies have managed to attract more apprentices to on-the-job training schemes due to a surge in applications from asylum seekers from Afghanistan and Syria.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on trade optimism; won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.99% to 2,270.06, driven by hopes of a thaw in the US-China trade war and criticism of Federal Reserve rate hikes by US President Donald Trump. The won strengthened 0.42% to 1,118.4 per dollar. Asian-Pacific shares outside Japan rose 0.64%, while Japanese stocks gained 0.09%.

site_title: Japan offers to boost Sri Lanka security as China makes inroads
