summary: Japan has pledged to boost Sri Lanka's maritime security, donating two coast guard patrol craft worth over $11 million. The donation was made during talks between Japanese Defence Minister Itsunori Onodera and Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena. This move aims to counter China's growing strategic influence in the Indian Ocean, where Sri Lanka is a key player. The cooperation is seen as a significant step in strengthening bilateral ties between Japan and Sri Lanka.

images.alt_text: Japanese Defense Minister Itsunori Onodera shakes hands with Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe during their meeting in Colombo, Sri Lanka August 21, 2018. Japan donated two coast guard patrol craft costing over US$11 million in total to boost Sri Lanka's maritime security.

site_title: Korea Exchange checking Merrill Lynch trades on public concerns
summary: The Korea Exchange (KRX) is monitoring Merrill Lynch's Seoul operations due to public concerns over high-speed trading, which could destabilize markets and disadvantage individual investors. Petitions have been filed calling for an investigation into Merrill Lynch's trading practices. The KRX declined to comment on whether other investment banks are being monitored. Merrill Lynch has not commented on the KRX's checks, and its Seoul branch is a subsidiary of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

site_title: Must do better: Japan eyes AI robots in class to boost English
summary: Japan plans a pilot project to introduce English-speaking AI robots in 500 classrooms to improve students' English skills, costing around $227,000. The move aims to address the country's weak oral and written English, with a national curriculum change requiring children to learn English from age 10. AI robots will help check pronunciation, and other measures such as tablet apps and online lessons will be implemented. This is part of efforts to address the shortage of qualified English teachers and lack of funds in schools.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady ahead of US-China trade talks
summary: European shares remained steady ahead of US-China trade talks, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index flat in percentage terms. Germany's DAX rose 0.2% and Britain's FTSE 100 was also steady. A weaker dollar boosted shares in international earners and commodities sectors, despite ongoing worries over a trade dispute between the US and China.

site_title: A Chinese billionaire is using his fortune to unlock the human brain
summary: Chinese billionaire Tianqiao Chen has dedicated $1 billion to brain research, aiming to unlock the human brain and potentially treat mental disorders and neurodegenerative diseases. Chen, who turned his fortune to brain research after struggling with mental health issues, plans to establish neuroscience institutes at the California Institute of Technology and Fudan University-affiliated Huashan Hospital. He believes that a better understanding of the brain could lead to breakthroughs in treating chronic pain, depression, anxiety, and other diseases, and predicts that unlimited possibilities may emerge in the next 10-20 years through technologies like brain-machine interfaces and brain-to-brain communication.

site_title: China says won't resort to strong stimulus but will keep liquidity ample
summary: China's central bank announced it won't use strong stimulus to support the slowing economy but will maintain liquidity and offer more financing help to companies struggling to secure loans. The move comes amid a weakening economy, trade frictions, and US tariffs. Officials reiterated that China won't manipulate its currency to deal with trade issues. The People's Bank of China will "effectively ease" financing problems and improve coordination with other agencies to ensure monetary policy measures are transmitted into the broader economy. Analysts expect further cuts in corporate taxes and fees to support smaller businesses.

site_title: Logitech unveils US$150 gamer mouse in bet on future of esports
summary: Logitech unveiled a US$150 gaming mouse, the G PRO Wireless Gaming Mouse, designed for esports. The mouse, developed over two years with professional gamers, weighs 80 grams and prioritizes speed. The company's gaming division saw a 57% increase in sales last year, with revenue more than tripling to US$492 million. Logitech's investment in esports has paid off, positioning the company to capitalize on the growing industry, which generated US$1.5 billion in revenue last year.

site_title: Australian shares slip on BHP profit miss, political uncertainty; NZ edges up
summary: Australian shares slipped 1% to 6,284.40 on Tuesday, amid failed attempts to topple Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and BHP missing annual earnings expectations. BHP's shares fell 1.9% despite a 32.7% profit increase, due to concerns over trade disputes. The Reserve Bank of Australia's minutes stated it aims to provide stability amidst political strife and drought. New Zealand's benchmark index edged up 0.1% on strength in utilities and consumer staples.

site_title: Phoenix Heights sold en bloc for S$33.1 million to OKP Holdings associate
summary: OKP Holdings' associate, USB Holdings, has won the tender for the collective sale of 32-unit Phoenix Heights in Bukit Panjang for S$33.1 million. The 99-year leasehold condominium has a site area of 3,971.9 sq m and will be redeveloped with a fresh 99-year lease. The acquisition is expected to have a minimal impact on OKP's earnings and net tangible assets per share. The deal was closed after the introduction of new property cooling measures, which may have influenced the tender price.

images.alt_text: AN associate of OKP Holdings has won the tender for the collective sale of 32-unit Phoenix Heights in Bukit Panjang, the mainboard-listed construction engineering company said on Tuesday.

site_title: Swiss cows get too fat for their own good
summary: A Swiss dairy association, New Swiss Cow, is advising farmers to consider smaller cows, weighing 500-600 kilograms, due to rising costs of feed and space. These cows produce proportionally more milk and require fewer vet visits, reducing costs. The association argues that the push for bigger cows in the 1960s was based on false assumptions about increased milk output. With Europe facing drought and heat, Switzerland and neighboring Germany are forced to import feed, increasing costs for farmers.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.2% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index retreating 4.82 points to 3,199.89. Losers outnumbered gainers 193 to 182, with about 1.08 billion shares changing hands. Noble Group rose 22.9% to 14.5 Singapore cents, while AEM Holdings fell 17.1% to 82 Singapore cents. The market declined despite a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US tariffs cast a cloud over Huawei's solar electronics launch
summary: Huawei's US launch of its solar-panel control device, FusionHome, is expected to be delayed due to US tariffs on Chinese electronics. Analysts predict a 25% tariff will undermine the product's pricing advantage, potentially benefiting rival producers. Huawei will need to either reduce margins or raise prices, which could harm profits and favor competitors like SolarEdge and Enphase Energy.

site_title: Wannabe wine connoisseurs can now buy instant cellars for US$5,000
summary: Sotheby's has launched "instant cellars" for wine enthusiasts, offering curated collections of 50-168 bottles for $5,000-$25,000. The service allows customers to purchase pre-assembled cellars with expertly selected wines from top vintages, catering to both beginners and experienced collectors. The cellars can be tailored to individual tastes and preferences, with options ranging from starter collections to investment-grade selections. Sotheby's aims to provide a convenient and hassle-free way for people to start or expand their wine collections.

site_title: Cambodia's first rum maker looks to expand overseas market
summary: Cambodia's first and only rum producer, Samai Distillery, plans to expand its overseas market. Founded in 2014 by three South Americans, the distillery currently exports to France and Singapore, aiming to enter markets in Malaysia, Japan, Hong Kong, and Spain by next year. With 16 employees, it produces 500 bottles of rum per month, and its brands have won gold medals at the Madrid International Rum Conference. Demand for rum is growing in Cambodia, but more advertising is needed to increase awareness of the drink among locals.

site_title: Malaysia PM Mahathir says China-backed rail, pipeline projects cancelled for now: reports
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad announced that the $20 billion East Coast Rail Link (ECRL) project and a natural gas pipeline project in Sabah, funded by China, will be cancelled for now due to Malaysia's financial constraints. Mahathir made the comments during his trip to China, stating that he relayed the matter to China and they understood Malaysia's problems. The projects were previously suspended due to pricing and graft accusations. Mahathir's decision aims to prevent Malaysia from becoming a bankrupt country.

site_title: Japan's Daikin, thriving in Asia and India, sets sights on Africa
summary: Japan's Daikin Industries, the world's largest air conditioning equipment maker, is expanding into Africa, 10 years after successfully partnering with a Chinese company. The company aims to replicate its success in India, where it has established itself as a top player, by leveraging its cost competitiveness and volume-zone strategy. Daikin's senior executive, Yoshihiro Mineno, said the company is prepared to silence critics and adapt to challenging markets, including the US, where it faces stiff competition from local rivals.

site_title: SIA brand set for makeover; Singapore carrier seeking creative partner
summary: Singapore Airlines is seeking a creative partner to modernize its iconic brand as part of its three-year transformation program. The airline released a 23-page Request for Information (RFI) to find an agency or agencies to help with strategy, branding, content, and digital presence. The goal is to "cut through the changing marketing and communications landscape with impact" and "elevate" the SIA brand. The tender is expected to conclude by December 13, with a final pitch presentation by shortlisted agencies.

site_title: Sweden calls for nuclear reactors to be shielded from hot weather
summary: Sweden's nuclear energy regulator has asked plant operators to develop plans to shield reactors from hot weather, following record-breaking temperatures in July that led to shutdowns and reduced output. The regulator, SSM, has asked operators to submit suggestions by autumn, with the cost of modifications estimated to be in the hundreds of millions of euros. This comes after a similar request in 2011 following the Fukushima disaster, and Sweden's largest reactor, Oskarshamn 3, is not expected to be affected by hot summers. The changes are due by 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares trim loss on solid China market
summary: Tokyo shares recovered from morning losses, ending 0.09% higher at 22,219.73 on the Nikkei 225 index, driven by gains on the Chinese market. The broader Topix index declined 0.40%. This rebound comes as regional investors were encouraged by the Chinese market's performance.

site_title: Snack chain CEC spurs M&A talk after founder's death
summary: CEC International Holdings Ltd., operator of 759 snack food chain, saw its shares surge 91% to HK$0.89 after Chairman Lam Wai Chun's death sparked takeover interest from rival Best Mart 360. Chairman Lin Tsz Fung expressed interest in acquiring CEC for under HK$1 billion, but clarified it's a personal evaluation. The company reported losses for the past three years due to weak retail demand. Tang Fung Kwan was appointed as the new chairman.

site_title: Singapore Airlines in new tie-ups with Alibaba to expand in China's fast growing travel market
summary: Singapore Airlines has partnered with Alibaba to expand its presence in China's growing travel market. The collaboration aims to tap into Alibaba's 600 million mobile users, cloud services, and logistics networks. SIA will leverage Alibaba Cloud for its IT ecosystem and join forces with Cainiao Network to build a global smart logistics network. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to capture China's fast-growing travel market, with 131 million Chinese tourists traveling abroad in 2017, and forecasts to reach 157 million by 2020.

site_title: SGX partners M-Daq to roll out prototype for multi-currency securities trading
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has partnered with fintech firm M-Daq to develop a prototype for a multi-currency securities trading service. This new service will allow investors to view, trade, and settle in multiple currencies, increasing investment yields and managing foreign exchange risks. The service will provide real-time prices of Straits Times Index component stocks in selected currencies, currently determined after trades are made. The partnership aims to enhance investor experience and increase market efficiency.

site_title: Taiwan 'won't bow to pressure', says President Tsai Ing-wen amid China tensions
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen stated that her country would not bow to pressure from China amid rising tensions. Following her high-profile trip to the US, Tsai emphasized Taiwan's determination for freedom and democracy, despite China's claims of sovereignty. The US has strengthened ties with Taiwan, and Tsai vowed to continue strengthening relations, while China has complained about her US stopovers, calling for a boycott of Taiwanese businesses.

site_title: Deutsche Bank raises bet on Noble pulling off US$3.5b rescue plan
summary: Deutsche Bank is doubling down on a bet that Noble Group Ltd will successfully restructure its debt, offering to buy senior unsecured bonds for 45% of face value. The German lender's move aims to increase support for the restructuring plan, which would hand creditors a 70% ownership stake. Noble Group's shares surged 21% after the announcement, and the company has received backing from key shareholders, including Abu Dhabi-based Goldilocks Investment Co. The restructuring plan is set to be voted on by Noble shareholders on August 27.

site_title: Singapore's architectural history under threat from redevelopment frenzy
summary: Singapore's architectural heritage is under threat due to a redevelopment frenzy, prompting calls to conserve ageing properties that symbolize the country's history and economic rise. The Singapore Heritage Society has urged preservation of brutalist blocks built in 1965, just after independence. Despite preserving some colonial-era buildings, more needs to be done to protect the nation's architectural identity. The island's focus on modern, sleek designs has led to the destruction of many historical buildings, sparking concerns about the country's cultural heritage.

site_title: Taiwan says breaks ties with El Salvador
summary: Taiwan has severed diplomatic ties with El Salvador, citing the Central American country's likely establishment of relations with Beijing. Foreign Minister Joseph Wu condemned China's "crude actions," leaving Taiwan with 17 international allies, as more countries switch recognition to China. This move follows a growing trend of countries recognizing China over Taiwan's status as a self-ruling democratic island.

site_title: Singtel tapping Bank of America for pursuit of Australia wireless operator Amaysim: sources
summary: Singtel, South-east Asia's largest telecom services provider, is exploring a possible bid for Australian wireless operator Amaysim, working with Bank of America to assess investment options. A deal would give Singtel access to Amaysim's 1.1 million mobile subscribers. The company hasn't decided on the size of its stake and the process is private. Amaysim's shares have slumped 54% this year, giving the company a market value of A$193 million. Deliberations are at an early stage, and there's no certainty a bid will result.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon trading at 3,208.05, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed afternoon trading on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 3.34 points, or 0.1%, to 3,208.05. Noble Group was the most actively traded counter, rising 20% to 14.2 Singapore cents. The market was relatively balanced, with 157 gainers and 151 losers, and 569.1 million shares worth S$456.3 million changing hands.

site_title: Foreign automakers oppose Trump NAFTA plan as US-Mexico talks resume
summary: Foreign automakers, including Toyota, Volkswagen, and Hyundai, oppose the Trump administration's plan to raise local content in North American-made vehicles, citing concerns about meeting stringent requirements. The US and Mexico are close to a bilateral deal on autos, which would lift the requirement to 70% from 62.5%. Talks with Canada are set to resume, and the automakers' opposition may raise resistance among lawmakers in southern states where foreign manufacturers have built auto plants.

site_title: Singapore police recover over S$27m linked to China's Ezubao Ponzi scheme
summary: Singapore police have recovered over S$27 million linked to China's Ezubao Ponzi scheme, which involved 1.15 million investors with an estimated loss of 38 billion Chinese yuan. The money was transferred to Singapore and alerted Chinese authorities, who subsequently convicted 26 individuals of fraud and sentenced them to between three years' jail and lifetime imprisonment. The seized funds have been returned to China to facilitate restitution, according to the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department. The case highlights Singapore's commitment to working with foreign counterparts to detect and deter transnational crime.

site_title: Brazil's Ambev plans to buy 1,600 electric trucks amid new freight fares
summary: Brazil's Ambev plans to purchase 1,600 Volkswagen electric trucks, the largest fleet of its kind in Brazil, and will be exempt from new fixed minimum freight fares for diesel truckers. The move comes after a truckers strike in May that severely impacted the flow of goods. Negotiations between Ambev and Volkswagen predated the new policy, which was implemented this month. The exemption may prompt clients to reassess their fleets.

images.alt_text: Brazilian beer maker Ambev plans to buy 1,600 Volkswagen electric trucks, they said on Monday, making it the largest fleet of its kind in Brazil, and which would be exempt from new fixed minimum freight fares for diesel truckers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of US-China trade talks
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, August 21, 2018, as investors awaited US-China trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.39% and the Topix index declined 0.37%. The lack of fresh market-moving events contributed to the wait-and-see attitude among investors.

site_title: Writedowns see mining giant BHP's annual net profit sink
summary: BHP, the world's largest miner, posted a 37% slump in annual net profit to $3.7 billion due to heavy impairment charges from the sale of its US shale assets and costs associated with the Samarco disaster in Brazil. Underlying profit rose 33% to $8.9 billion, driven by robust commodity prices and higher production. The company declared a record final dividend of 63 US cents and has a strong balance sheet, with net debt at the lower end of its target range. Despite a 1.1% drop in its share price, analysts expect further rises due to the underlying profit.

site_title: Taiwan loses another ally to China
summary: Taiwan lost diplomatic ties with El Salvador, leaving the island with formal relations with 17 countries, mostly in Central America and the Pacific. The move follows previous losses to China, which accuses Taiwan of luring its friends with aid packages. Taiwanese officials say they will not bow to pressure and will maintain the status quo, while China denies any wrongdoing. El Salvador's President Salvador Sanchez Ceren severed ties with Taiwan to establish new relations with China, citing "massive funding support" from Beijing as the reason.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby, China food giant sign deal to produce palm oil-based products
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation Berhad and China's state-owned food processing company, Cofco, signed a memorandum of understanding to produce palm oil-based products in Malaysia for the Chinese market. The joint venture aims to utilize Malaysia's palm oil supply and produce products for export to China and other countries. This cooperation is expected to attract more foreign investors to develop downstream industries in Malaysia, with Primary Industries Minister Teresa Kok stating that it will help stabilize palm oil pricing in the international market. The deal was signed during Malaysian Prime Minister Dr. Mahathir Mohamad's visit to China.

site_title: Venezuelan business leaders lambast Maduro's new banknotes
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro introduced new banknotes with five zeros, aiming to curb hyperinflation, but business leaders and opposition groups criticized the move as counterproductive, fearing it would increase economic instability. The new "sovereign bolivar" replaces the oil-rich "strong bolivar," which has become nearly worthless due to predicted inflation of one million percent. Maduro also announced a 3,400 percent hike in the minimum wage and other measures to tackle poverty, but the country remains plagued by economic crisis, with over two million people fleeing and widespread shortages of basic goods.

site_title: Jennifer Garner honored with Hollywood star
summary: Jennifer Garner received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, honoring her 24-year career in film and television. Garner, 46, has appeared in over 30 films and is known for her awards in the industry. She expressed gratitude, saying the honor is "amazing and special" to share with her family and friends.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 3.16 points to 1790.74. The index saw 121 gainers for every 52 losers, with volume reaching 55.95 million lots worth RM21.54 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with small gains on Tuesday, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.26% to 27,670.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The gains were driven by hopes for planned trade talks between China and the US.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.29% to 3,195.54
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.29% to 3,195.54. The decline came ahead of scheduled US-China trade talks this week. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 55, with Singtel staying flat and AEM Holdings advancing 3.0%. This marks the first decline in the 5-day rally, which was driven by positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: 'We cannot afford this': Malaysia pushes back on China's big projects
summary: Malaysia is pushing back against China's big projects, citing concerns over debt and strategic value. The country's new leader, Mahathir Mohamad, has suspended two major Chinese-linked projects amid accusations of inflated contracts and debt traps. Mahathir has stated that Malaysia cannot afford these projects and is seeking to free the country from its $250 billion debt, much of it owed to Chinese companies. Malaysia is following a growing trend of nations rebelling against China's Belt and Road Initiative, with many discovering that Chinese investment comes with less-savory accompaniments, including closed bidding processes and influxes of Chinese labor.

site_title: After the bitcoin boom: Hard lessons for cryptocurrency investors
summary: A bitcoin investor in the US lost 82% of his $23,000 investment in eight months due to excessive risk-taking and fear of missing out. Pete Roberts of Nottingham, England, attributes his financial ruin to getting caught up in the market's hype. This experience serves as a hard lesson for cryptocurrency investors, emphasizing the importance of caution and risk management.

images.alt_text: Tony Yoo, a financial analyst in Los Angeles, has invested more than US$100,000 of his savings into cryptocurrency. At their lowest point, his holdings dropped almost 70 per cent in value.

site_title: Britain to US, Europe: 'Go further' to counter Russia
summary: Britain's new Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt is urging the US and European countries to take tougher action against Russia, saying the country's "malign behaviour" must be countered. Hunt will ask allies to go further in implementing sanctions and standing shoulder to shoulder with the US in condemning Russia's actions. This comes after the poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and the UK's diplomatic crisis with Russia. Hunt will also warn that those who flout international rules will face a "serious price to pay."

site_title: Google sued for unwanted tracking of phone locations
summary: Google is being sued for allegedly tracking the locations of smartphone users despite having "location history" settings turned off. A California man filed a federal lawsuit seeking unspecified damages and class-action status for US iPhone and Android users who turned off location history. The lawsuit claims Google misrepresented its policies, stating that turning off location history would prevent tracking, when in fact location data may still be used for other services. The Electronic Privacy Information Center has sent a letter to the US Federal Trade Commission to investigate potential violations of a 2011 consent order.

site_title: Australia's Turnbull survives ballot to remain prime minister
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has survived a leadership vote by defeating Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton 48-35. The narrow victory has weakened Turnbull's position and widened rifts within the government, with another challenge likely. Turnbull has struggled to implement policies and maintain authority since the 2016 election, and his government's trailing behind the opposition in opinion polls has led to growing dissent.

site_title: Baodi offers HK$3.267 per Techcomp share after acquiring 61.5% stake
summary: Baodi International Investment has made a mandatory unconditional cash offer of HK$3.267 per Techcomp share after acquiring a 61.5% stake in the company. The offer includes a premium of 38.43% over Techcomp's net asset value. If accepted, Baodi will pay HK$379.7 million to minority shareholders and HK$33.72 million to cancel outstanding share options. The offer, which closes on Sept 11, was triggered by Baodi's acquisition of shares held by Techcomp's president and controlling shareholder.

site_title: Martial arts group ONE Championship taps CFO to double as head of China operations
summary: ONE Championship has appointed CFO Teh Hua Fung as chairman of its China operations, aiming to double the martial arts organization's presence in the country. Teh, a seasoned executive with experience in private equity and investment, will lead ONE Championship's growth in China while delivering an authentic martial arts experience to fans. This appointment follows a period of expansion for the organization, which includes martial arts fights in Jakarta, Singapore, and Shanghai. Teh brings his expertise to the role, citing his dedication to growing ONE Championship's footprint in China.

images.alt_text: The chief financial officer (CFO) of Temasek-invested martial arts organisation, ONE Championship, Teh Hua Fung has taken on a dual role as the chairman of its business unit in China.

site_title: Melania Trump to make solo Africa trip
summary: US First Lady Melania Trump plans a solo trip to Africa later this year, focusing on good-deed projects and education. The White House will release details in the coming weeks. This trip marks her first to the continent, following previous solo trips to Canada and with her husband. Melania Trump emphasized the importance of open dialogue and exchanging ideas to learn from each other, contrasting with her husband's alleged disparagement of African countries.

site_title: 'Dangerous' for Twitter, Facebook to ban accounts, says Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that it's "very dangerous" for social media companies like Twitter and Facebook to ban accounts, as it could silence voices. Trump made the comments amid scrutiny from Congress to police foreign propaganda. He previously criticized the industry for allegedly discriminating against Republican/Conservative voices, after some content from Infowars, a website run by conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, was removed from platforms. Trump's comments come as social media companies testified before Congress that their goal is to serve the conversation, not make value judgments on personal beliefs.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sheng Siong Group is upgraded to a "buy" call by RHB Research with a target price of S$1.30, citing the group's expansion plans and increased retail space, which is expected to boost earnings by 2-3% in 2019-2020. Meanwhile, Sembcorp Marine is maintained at a "hold" by OCBC Investment Research, despite a 40% drop in its share price, due to its established track record and potential for future growth.

site_title: Hot stock: 8Telecom's 10.5% surge prompts SGX query
summary: 8Telecom International Holdings saw its shares surge 10.5% in early morning trading on August 21, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for "unusual price movements". The company announced it received in-principle approval for a proposed acquisition and plans to issue new shares at 9 Singapore cents apiece, a 10% discount to its volume-weighted average price. The stock had previously reached a price of 20.3 Singapore cents on August 13.

site_title: Japan's Tsukiji fish market to stop tourist tuna viewings
summary: Tokyo's Tsukiji fish market will stop admitting tourists to watch its pre-dawn tuna auctions on September 15, as it prepares to move to Toyosu on October 11. The market, which has operated for over 80 years, will cap daily tourist numbers at 120 and end viewing wholesale markets for marine products and vegetables on September 29. The move aims to address concerns about earthquake resistance, sanitation, and fire safety at the antiquated facility, and will be replaced by a new facility in Toyosu with a deck for visitors and a special tuna auction viewing area.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vibrant, Techcomp, Sembcorp, Perennial, Sarine Tech
summary: Stocks to watch on August 21, 2018, include Vibrant Group, which appointed Ernst & Young as special auditor for its subsidiary Blackgold International Holdings, and Techcomp Holdings, which was acquired by Baodi International Investment. Sembcorp Industries won a tender to supply electricity to Bangladesh for over 15 years. Perennial Real Estate launched and priced S$170 million of 5.95% notes due 2020, while Sarine Technologies inked a deal to provide its stone mapping technology to a blockchain-based wholesale diamond retailer.

site_title: BHP annual profit jumps 33%, misses forecast
summary: BHP, the world's largest miner, reported a 33% increase in underlying profit to US$8.93 billion for the full year ended June 30, beating estimates of US$9.27 billion. The company's profit was driven by robust oil and base metals prices. BHP declared a final dividend of US$0.63 per share, up from US$0.43 per share last year. The company's market value is Australia's largest.

site_title: North Korea's Kim criticises his country's health sector
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un criticized his country's health sector, stating there is nothing to be proud of in the public health sector. He promised personal attention to updating the Myohyangsan Medical Appliances Factory in keeping with the goal to radically improve domestic production, automation, and modernization. Kim also criticized poor workmanship on a railway to the border with China, calling for improved roadbeds, accident-free construction, and increased electricity production. This is part of his campaign to jumpstart economic development after a June summit with US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Venezuela braces for currency devaluation storm
summary: Venezuela is bracing for a currency devaluation storm after President Nicolas Maduro unveiled a 95% devaluation of the currency, effective Tuesday. The move, which includes the introduction of a new sovereign bolivar currency, aims to address hyperinflation but faces skepticism from economists and opposition politicians, who warn of further suffering. The government has also announced a minimum wage increase and regulated prices for staples, but critics argue the plan lacks specifics and credibility. The move is seen as a desperate attempt to quell a rising sense of panic in the nation, which is already struggling with food and medicine shortages, and citizens fleeing to neighboring countries.

site_title: Vibrant Group names Ernst & Young as unit Blackgold's special auditor
summary: Vibrant Group has appointed Ernst & Young as special auditor for its Australian-listed coal producer subsidiary Blackgold International Holdings. The audit will investigate irregularities, assets, and accounting records related to a recent vehicle fire in China, which Blackgold reported as a suspected deliberate act to destroy records. The audit committee and Singapore Exchange will receive a written report of the findings. The board will provide further updates on material developments.

site_title: Singtel sells US$500m of 10-year bonds at 3.875% coupon; reoffered yield at 3.889%
summary: Singtel sold US$500 million 10-year senior unsecured bonds at a 3.875% coupon, with a reoffered yield of 3.889%. The offering received US$2.85 billion in interest and will be used for the ordinary course of business. The notes are rated A1 by Moody's and A+ by S&P Global Ratings, with Citigroup, DBS Bank, and HSbc serving as joint lead managers and bookrunners.

site_title: Weaving in a winning philosophy
summary: Benjamin Barker, a Singapore-based menswear brand, has been recognized for its success in the local retail scene, earning its first Enterprise 50 (E50) award in 2017. Founded by Nelson Yap after he took over his family's debt-ridden tailoring business, the brand has grown to twelve retail outlets in Singapore and Australia, with a focus on classic suits tailored to the Asian physique. Benjamin Barker aims to expand into South-east Asia, with plans to open franchises in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Cambodia, and is exploring a franchising model to reduce operational costs.

images.alt_text: Founder Nelson Yap (far left) with COO Damien Tan, who started off as college roommates to become entrepreneurs behind award-winning homegrown label Benjamin Barker.

site_title: Venezuela cuts five zeros from currency as economic plan sows confusion
summary: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro implemented a new economic plan, slashing five zeros from prices and pegging salaries, prices, and the exchange rate to the state-backed cryptocurrency "Petro." The plan aims to combat hyperinflation, but economists warn it will exacerbate the crisis, with many citizens already struggling due to product shortages and a mass exodus. The plan has been met with skepticism, and business organizations have criticized it as "improvised" and "incoherent," sparking concerns about the country's economic activity and potential social unrest.

site_title: China defies US pressure as EU parts ways with Iranian oil
summary: China is set to continue purchasing Iranian oil despite US sanctions, using tankers from National Iranian Tanker Co. This move comes as European companies, including France's Total, are halting imports due to fear of reprisals from Washington. China's oil imports from Iran have increased, with 23.8 million barrels loaded in July, worth around $1.5 billion per month. The US is trying to force Tehran to negotiate a new nuclear agreement by halting Iranian oil exports, but China's defiance throws a lifeline to Iran while Europe walks away.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets has redesignated Pauline Gately as executive chairman, recognizing her role in the proposed merger with Tawana Resources. The change took effect on August 17. This follows a significant shift in leadership, as Gately was previously the independent non-executive chairman.

site_title: Europe: Shares gain on optimism over US-China trade row
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Monday, driven by optimism over a potential US-China trade compromise, lifting hopes of a market rebound. The Stoxx 600 index, a pan-European benchmark, closed in positive territory. Analysts attributed the gains to investors tentatively returning to the market amid concerns about a potential escalation of the trade dispute.

site_title: Trump once again criticises Federal Reserve, rate hikes
summary: President Donald Trump criticized the US Federal Reserve for raising interest rates, accusing it of failing to support his economic policies. Trump declined to confirm his support for the central bank's independence, which has raised concerns among financial markets. The Fed has raised interest rates seven times since 2015, and Trump's criticism is seen as a departure from protocol. Despite the criticism, markets have been relatively unaffected, with the dollar index moving slightly lower after reports of Trump's comments.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher ahead of trade talks
summary: US stocks rose Monday ahead of US-China trade talks, lifting hopes for an agreement. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4% to 25,758.69, while the S&P 500 gained 0.2% to 2,857.05. Investors are optimistic despite President Trump's administration pushing forward on additional tariffs. Mid-level officials will resume talks later this week, seen as preferable to further escalation.

site_title: HDB value proposition improves as market awaits scheme details
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) is introducing a voluntary early redevelopment scheme (VERS) to upgrade ageing flats. The Home Improvement Programme II (HIP II) will upgrade flats aged 60-70 years, while residents in selected precincts will have the option to sell their flats back to the government before the lease runs out. Analysts expect no immediate impact on the resale market, but the new policies may stabilize prices and attract buyers of older flats, potentially slowing price depreciation.

site_title: Oil gains on easing trade war concerns, sanctions on Iran
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as investors became less concerned about a potential trade war between the US and China, and more concerned about US sanctions on Iran. Brent crude futures gained 0.5% to $72.21 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose 0.8% to $66.43 a barrel. The easing of trade war concerns and potential reduction in global GDP demand due to US sanctions on Iran supported oil prices.

site_title: Trump attorney Giuliani walks back 'truth isn't truth' remark
summary: Rudy Giuliani, Donald Trump's personal attorney, clarified his previous statement that "truth isn't truth" by explaining it was meant to describe the contradictions in testimonies, likening it to the "he said, she said" puzzle. His comment on NBC's "Meet the Press" initially sparked mockery and scorn. Giuliani clarified on Twitter that his statement was not a moral theology, but rather an attempt to convey the complexities of conflicting accounts.

site_title: China said to start fresh round of checks on P2P lenders
summary: China has begun a new round of checks on thousands of peer-to-peer (P2P) lending sites, aiming to resolve risks and guide some firms to exit the business. The move is part of efforts to clean up the industry, according to a document issued by the Internet Lending Financial Risk Management Working Leadership Group and co-signed by the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission.

site_title: Noble's founder won't be executive director in restructured firm
summary: NOBLE Group's founder, Richard Elman, will not take the post of executive director after the company's restructuring. Elman cited personal reasons for his decision. Existing shareholders will hold a combined 20% stake in the new Noble post-restructuring, with Elman holding 17.9%. The company is set to seek approval for its $3.5 billion debt restructuring plan at a special general meeting on August 27, and has secured irrevocable undertakings from several shareholders to vote in favor of the plan.

site_title: Some Venezuelans, alarmed by Maduro's measures, speed up plans to flee
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro's economic plan, including a 96% devaluation and pegging the currency to a cryptocurrency called the "petro", has alarmed many Venezuelans, prompting some to accelerate their plans to flee the country. Hundreds of thousands have already left, and the International Monetary Fund forecasts inflation could reach 1 million percent by the end of the year. Many Venezuelans fear the measures could render the country even more anarchic, and some are considering emigrating to neighboring countries like Aruba or Mexico.

site_title: Labour standards shouldn't be supply chains' weakest link
summary: A growing number of companies are recognizing the importance of ensuring good labour standards in their supply chains. Following a devastating garment factory collapse in Bangladesh five years ago, trade unions, brands, and retailers signed a five-year framework for factory inspections to improve safety. Regulations such as the Modern Slavery Act in the UK and the Transparency in Supply Chains Act in California mandate transparency on sourcing and labour practices. Investors are also scrutinizing companies' labour practices, with some joining forces to set expectations for addressing forced labour in global supply chains.

site_title: Chinese national kidnapped in US, held for US$2m ransom
summary: A Chinese national, Ruochen "Tony" Liao, 28, was kidnapped in California on July 16 by three men demanding a US$2 million ransom. Liao, who worked at a luxury car dealership, may have been targeted due to a business deal gone sour. The FBI is investigating the abduction, which occurred in the city of San Gabriel. Liao has been missing for five weeks, and his whereabouts are currently unknown.

site_title: Solutions for staff and clients
summary: Precursor, a client services firm, has implemented its new Smartcursors Marketplace software suite to improve staff productivity and client management. The integrated system logs client engagements and provides data analytics on performance statistics, allowing staff to track productivity and client losses. The cloud-based system also enables seamless access to client information, regardless of the time of day or location. This streamlined approach is expected to enhance the firm's "solution as a service" offerings to clients, providing a more efficient and effective way to manage customer relationships.

site_title: Will Turkey turmoil turn into contagion?
summary: Turkey's economic turmoil raises concerns of contagion, with some experts predicting a global economic convulsion. The country's slowdown, combined with rising US interest rates, President Trump's trade wars, and emerging market economies' challenges, could hinder global expansion. Economists are divided on the issue, with some foreseeing a larger economic impact and others considering it a one-country event. The global economy already faces obstacles to growth, making the outcome of Turkey's economic situation crucial.

site_title: China will sympathise with Malaysia's fiscal problems: Mahathir
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad expressed optimism that China will sympathize with his country's fiscal problems, particularly regarding over $20 billion in Chinese-funded projects. Mahathir, seeking to renegotiate or cancel the projects, believes China will understand Malaysia's internal fiscal issues and potentially offer assistance. China's Premier Li Keqiang agreed to increase trade ties, including imports of palm oil, and signed memoranda of understanding on bilateral currency swaps and trade.

site_title: Japan and Russia plan freight route via Trans-Siberian Railway
summary: Japan and Russia plan to develop a freight transport route via the Trans-Siberian Railway, aiming to boost mutual economic cooperation and build confidence between the two countries. The project will start with a test in September, focusing on transportation costs, time, and customs procedures. The overland route could reduce transport time to 20-27 days, cutting costs by up to 40%. The goal is to increase exports of auto parts and industrial products, and potentially expand the route to Europe.

site_title: Chinese police nab suspects after US$87m cryptocurrency theft
summary: Chinese police have arrested three suspects allegedly responsible for hacking into computers to steal 600 million yuan (approximately $87 million) in cryptocurrencies, including bitcoin and ether. The investigation began in March after a victim reported his computer was hacked, leading police to a suspect in Hunan, who was eventually arrested along with two others. The arrests are part of a broader crackdown on cryptocurrency trading in China, which was banned in February by blocking overseas websites and removing related apps.

site_title: Precursor to progress and digital solutions
summary: Precursor, a professional services firm, has developed a software suite called Smartcursors Marketplace, a comprehensive platform offering various applications for client and workflow management. The platform, set to launch in October, aims to provide a fully cloud-based solution for clients to access a range of services, including tax, audit, and HR management. The firm's managing director, Tan Khoon Guan, believes the platform will enable clients to work smarter and more efficiently, with the goal of helping them undergo a digital transformation. The Smartcursors Marketplace is designed to be affordable and purpose-built for Singapore's accounting rules and corporate regulations.

site_title: Eagles overtake Michael Jackson with biggest selling album
summary: The Eagles' compilation album "Their Greatest Hits 1971-75" has surpassed Michael Jackson's "Thriller" as the biggest selling album of all time, according to the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA). The album has sold 38 million units, surpassing Jackson's 33 million. "Hotel California" is ranked third with 26 million units sold. The new ranking includes sales from discs and streaming, which was previously uncalculated for the Eagles. Don Henley expressed gratitude to fans for sticking with the group through 46 years, following the death of co-founder Glenn Frey in 2016.

site_title: Credit Suisse sees Asia wealth race shift from offshore hubs
summary: Credit Suisse is shifting its focus from accumulating wealth in offshore hubs like Singapore and Hong Kong to onshore markets in Asia, such as Manila, Jakarta, and Shanghai. The bank aims to reach a minimum of $10 billion in assets in each of its 11 key Asian markets. This shift is driven by growing wealth creation in Asia, with total wealth assets expected to grow 10% annually from 2025, while offshore wealth is expected to grow 6-7% over the same period.

site_title: Enticed by Game of Thrones, throngs threaten a magical Croatian city
summary: Dubrovnik, Croatia, is struggling with over-tourism, with crowds growing so bad that the city has become synonymous with the issue. The city's mayor, Mato Frankovic, has implemented measures to limit cruise ship arrivals and restrict outdoor seating to control the influx of tourists. This summer, the city cracked down on street vendors and limited the number of people who can disembark from cruise ships. The goal is to find a balance between welcoming tourists and preserving the city's beauty and charm.

site_title: Lifting productivity in Singapore's retail, F&B
summary: Singapore's retail and F&B sectors are struggling with productivity, but recent research by the Singapore Productivity Centre (SGPC) has identified key areas for improvement. The 8M framework, which considers management, manpower, material, method, money, make, market, and message, can help businesses overcome productivity challenges. SMEs are increasingly adopting new technologies and customer-centric strategies, but face challenges such as lack of awareness, workforce issues, and technology anxiety. Policymakers can refine their policies to support productivity growth in these sectors, and businesses can learn from case studies of successful SMEs, such as Paul Frank Singapore and Cold Storage, which have implemented RFID systems to improve inventory management.

site_title: STI dips slightly ahead of US-China talks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.73 points or 0.15% to close at 3,204.71, mainly dragged by Jardine Matheson's 1.4% drop to US$64.03. Despite opening higher after a strong Wall Street finish, the index ended slightly lower on Monday. Gainers outnumbered losers 208 to 191, with 1.28 billion shares changing hands.

site_title: Siemens, ST Engg Electronics consortium bags S$18.8m LTA contract
summary: Siemens and ST Engineering Electronics have won an S$18.8 million contract from the Land Transport Authority (LTA) to develop a software system, Reams, that integrates asset information across all MRT lines. The system will enable better monitoring of rail assets and allow for proactive maintenance, improving reliability and costs. The project will be first introduced on the Downtown Line (DTL) and is expected to be operational by mid-2020, with other rail lines to be added in phases. The consortium will provide long-term system support.

site_title: Euro drops ahead of planned US-China trade talks
summary: The euro dropped ahead of planned US-China trade talks, with investors hoping for a resolution to tensions between the world's two biggest economies. The US dollar gained in anticipation of the talks. Concerns about the Turkish currency crisis and Italy's budget also impacted the euro. Analysts attribute the decline to uncertainty and potential risks to eurozone banks.

site_title: Sembcorp's India power arm wins 250MW tender
summary: Sembcorp Industries' India arm, Sembcorp Energy India Ltd, has won a 250MW power tender in Bangladesh, with a 15-year power supply contract. The deal is expected to start once procedural requirements and government approvals are met. The contract is seen as a strategic move to provide cost-competitive and reliable power to the neighboring country. The outcome is not expected to significantly impact Sembcorp's earnings per share and net assets per share for the year.

site_title: US firms warn next China tariffs to cost Americans from cradle to grave
summary: The US Chamber of Commerce and other major US businesses warn that proposed $200 billion tariffs on Chinese imports, set to be implemented by late September, will increase costs for everyday consumer products, affecting Americans from birth to death. The tariffs target a wide range of products, including seafood, furniture, tires, and car seats, potentially leading to price spikes and higher costs for Americans.

site_title: UOB marks groundbreaking of new Thailand HQ
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) held a groundbreaking ceremony for its new Thailand headquarters in Bangkok, with the bank's deputy chairman and CEO Wee Ee Cheong and UOB (Thai) president and CEO Tan Choon Hin laying the foundation stone for the 30-storey building.

site_title: America's top brands sweat next step in Trump's trade war with China
summary: US brands, including Nike, Starbucks, McDonald's, and Michael Kors, may face significant losses if China retaliates against US tariffs. China has vowed to retaliate against all US tariffs, which could lead to a state-nudged boycott and shutdown of factories. The Asian nation is a crucial supplier and growth market for many US companies, making a severe response potentially devastating. Brands with high exposure to China include Nike, Starbucks, and McDonald's, which could see sales decline and revenue growth impacted.

site_title: Speed up efforts to save nuclear deal, Iran urges EU
summary: Iran urged Europe to accelerate efforts to salvage the 2015 nuclear deal, amid the US pulling out and French oil group Total pulling out of a major gas project. The European powers, China, and Russia are trying to persuade Iran to stay in the deal, but the threat of US sanctions has prompted many major companies to pull out. Iran relies on its own capabilities to overcome the sanctions, and the country's economy is suffering due to the weak rial currency and financial difficulties.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Apple wipes thousands of gambling apps after China media attacks
summary: Apple has removed thousands of gambling apps from its Chinese store after China's state-run broadcaster accused the company of hosting banned content. The move follows a report by China Central Television that Apple pulled 4,000 apps tagged with the keyword "gambling" on August 9. Apple confirmed the action, stating that it was complying with regulations and has been vigilant in removing illegal apps. The move highlights the challenges faced by foreign companies operating in China, particularly in policing content, and underscores the country's resurgent crackdown on online content.

site_title: Africa's a growth market, but it's a long-term play
summary: Singapore is exploring investment opportunities in Africa, with Enterprise Singapore identifying technology, food manufacturing, and traditional sectors like oil and gas engineering as growth areas. The agency has proactively allocated resources, partnered with private sectors, and engaged governments to establish a treaty network in the continent. Experts note that investing in Africa is a long-term play, with the digital economy and manufacturing sectors showing promise. Businesses such as Tolaram Group and Asiatic Agricultural Industries have already reaped rewards from investing in Africa, with revenue growth expected to rise to 35% in five years.

images.alt_text: Asiatic Agricultural Industries has sold products such as fungicides in Africa since the early 2000s. Its chairman Chan Chek Chee expects the continent's contribution to the company's revenue to hit 35 per cent in five years.

site_title: Lease buyback now open to all HDB flats; liquidity boost for older resale flats
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) has opened its Lease Buyback Scheme to all HDB flats, including five-room units and executive maisonettes. This change aims to provide a liquidity boost for older resale flats and enable seniors to fund their retirement years. The scheme, previously restricted to four-room or smaller flats, will allow owners to sell a part of their lease to the government and receive an average of S$146,000. The move is part of the government's efforts to upgrade and rebuild older HDB towns, with the goal of preparing for the future responsibly.

site_title: China Gaoxian appoints new CFO
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings has appointed Daniel Wong Kai Yin, a 37-year-old Hong Kong resident, as its new CFO, more than three years after his predecessor's resignation in March 2015. Wong, who previously held internal control manager and assistant audit manager positions, was selected by the nominating committee for his qualifications and experience. The company reported a second-quarter net loss of 60.9 million yuan, citing missing accounting books and records from before 2011. Wong's appointment aims to address the company's financial management and reporting issues.

site_title: SGX firms' Aug buybacks exceed S$100m
summary: Singapore Stocks Report Buybacks Exceed S$100m in August. The five largest buyback considerations in August have been made by DBS, UOB, CapitaLand, City Developments, and OCBC Bank, totaling S$116.5 million. This is the seventh consecutive month the S$100 million threshold has been crossed, with buyback consideration exceeding S$1 billion in the year to date. Seven new buyback mandates were initiated in the first 12 sessions of August.

site_title: Doors slam shut for China deals around the world
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an updated CFIUS bill, expanding its scope to include minority and passive investments in critical technology, infrastructure, and data-handling businesses. This move tightens rules on Chinese investments, with potential implications for smart home devices, robotics, and other tech-related acquisitions. China's "Made in China 2025" ambitions face challenges, but joint ventures and opening its financial sector to foreign investment may provide alternatives. The world's doors are shutting to Chinese investments, with European and UK governments also increasing scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Ant Financial's bid for MoneyGram  was abandoned amid US fears of data on its military personnel - who use the payments service - falling into the wrong hands.
Broadcom's bid for Qualcomm was rejected by US President Donald Trump over concerns that it would give Huawei an advantage.

site_title: Turkey's attempt to stem lira rout may come back to haunt it
summary: Turkey's attempt to stabilize the lira by limiting offshore currency swaps has backfired, causing debt and equity markets to suffer. The move, intended to curb speculators betting against the lira, has instead made it difficult for foreign investors to hedge their currency risk, leading to a surge in yields and a decline in the benchmark stock index. This has created uncertainty, prompting investors to sell local bonds and stocks, and potentially accelerating outflows from the Turkish market.

site_title: Australian 'bag rage' slows sales at Woolworths
summary: Woolworths, Australia's largest grocer, reported a loss of sales momentum after introducing a levy on plastic bags, despite standing by the charge. The company's shares fell 3.5% in early trading, erasing most losses to close down 0.6%. Comparable sales growth slumped to 1.3% over the first seven weeks of the 2019 financial year, down from 3.1% in the prior quarter. Despite the backlash, Woolworths' CEO believes the issue will be short-lived and customers will adapt to the new policy.

site_title: Investors hold on to German debt as questions about Turkey linger
summary: German government bond yields hovered near one-month lows as investors held on to safe assets amid uncertainty over Turkey's currency crisis and potential contagion to emerging markets. The dollar fell ahead of US-China trade talks, while investors remained optimistic about a resolution. Despite concerns about emerging markets, German 10-year bond yields remained flat at 0.305%, and French 10-year bond yields were near a four-week low. The Turkish lira fell 0.6% against the dollar, keeping investors cautious about potential market volatility.

site_title: Reverse mortgages make sense to help China's retirees
summary: China is considering introducing reverse mortgages to help its aging population, with safeguards in place to mitigate financial risk. The country has a significant untapped wealth in housing and low debt ratios, with 88% of urban home value being owner-equity. The pension system faces large shortfalls, with estimated losses of nearly $100 billion. Reverse mortgages could provide retirees with a way to tap into their home equity, improving their quality of life. However, financial institutions must be required to act as fee-only providers and the amount of equity that can be tapped should be limited.

site_title: Boon Tat Street conservation shophouse put up for sale
summary: A 999-year leasehold conservation shophouse at 21 Boon Tat Street in Singapore's Telok Ayer Conservation Area has been put up for sale via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise. The shophouse, home to Michelin-starred restaurant Cheek by Jowl, has permanent food and beverage approvals and a land area of 1,759 square feet. The indicative guide price is S$17 million, with a unit land rate of about S$4,388 per square foot. The site is well-located near major expressways and MRT stations, offering a rare opportunity for a trophy asset with strong rental income.

site_title: One-off retirement payouts eat into Ellipsiz FY2018 results
summary: Ellipsiz posted a net profit of S$9.1 million for FY2018, a 7% increase from the previous year, driven by 18% revenue growth. The company attributed the growth to stronger distribution and services solutions in Singapore, mainland China, and Taiwan. Despite a global semiconductor and contract manufacturing industry growth, Ellipsiz expressed cautious optimism due to the ongoing trade spat between the US and China.

site_title: Can China and Trump find exit from trade war?
summary: US and Chinese negotiators are set to meet this week in an attempt to avoid a trade war. The talks come after US President Donald Trump signed legislation requiring a review of Chinese investment in the US, citing national security concerns. The bill singles out China's "Made in China 2025" plan and gives the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (CFIUS) more authority to scrutinize foreign investments. China has reacted furiously to the legislation, which some see as part of a broader strategy to thwart China's rise as a global superpower. A breakthrough in the talks is uncertain, but both sides have incentives to resolve the escalating economic disputes.

site_title: Prepare for the future, nurture a maker culture
summary: A growing maker culture, fueled by DIY hobbyists and inventors, is transforming industries and creating new opportunities for entrepreneurs and small businesses. With the democratization of emerging technologies, makers can create innovative products and solutions, from 3D-printing and IoT innovations to smart cities and embedded vision devices. Technology firms can support makers by offering resources, workshops, and one-stop centers to help them overcome technical challenges and turn prototypes into mass-producible products. This collaborative ecosystem has the potential to drive resilience and sustainability, and is expected to have a significant impact on the global economy, with an estimated global economic impact of up to $6.2 trillion by 2025.

site_title: Trump lawyer Giuliani tries to explain what he meant by 'truth isn't truth'
summary: Rudy Giuliani attempted to clarify his statement that "truth isn't truth," saying it referred to contradictory statements rather than a moral stance. He claimed this in response to his appearance on NBC's "Meet the Press" where he argued that President Trump should not testify in the Mueller investigation due to the risk of perjury. Giuliani's assertion drew comparisons to Kellyanne Conway's earlier statement that presented "alternative facts."

site_title: Tesla slashes spending, but this may add to its woes
summary: Tesla slashes spending, aiming to achieve profitability by reducing capital expenditures by 25% to $2.5 billion, but this may delay the introduction of new models that could boost revenues. The company's near-term cash position is precarious, with $2.2 billion in cash at the end of the second quarter, down from $3.3 billion at the beginning of the year. Investors will closely monitor Tesla's financial health as it considers a potential take-private deal, and analysts warn that the spending cuts may be costly in the long term.

site_title: VW to recall 700,000 cars over roof lighting - trade magazine
summary: Volkswagen is recalling approximately 700,000 Tiguan and Touran cars worldwide due to a possible lighting defect in the panoramic roof's light strip. The issue may cause a short circuit, resulting in scorching damage and potentially leading to a fire. In Germany, about 52,500 cars are affected. The company is currently working on a solution, but no immediate comment was available.

site_title: HK bears go short on Chinese auto-makers
summary: Several Chinese automakers, including BYD Co, Brilliance China Automotive Holdings Ltd, and Great Wall Motor Co, are experiencing a slump in Hong Kong's equity markets due to bets on a persistent fall in China car sales. The slump is attributed to a slowing economy, trimmed government subsidies, and rising competition from foreign brands. Analysts predict a bearish outlook for the auto sector in the second half, with some companies facing concerns over sustainability of joint ventures and potential profit slowdowns.

site_title: Russian wheat prices fell last week due to weak rouble
summary: Russian wheat export prices fell due to a weaker rouble, which is near its lowest level since April 2016. Prices dropped US$4 to US$230 per tonne for 12.5% protein content wheat, while barley prices rose US$1 to US$231 per tonne. Speculation about potential export limits may limit the decline in prices. Russia has exported 6.8 million tonnes of grain since the start of the 2018/19 season, a 46% increase from the previous year.

site_title: Turkey's attempt to stem the lira rout may come back to haunt it
summary: Turkey's attempt to stem the lira rout by restricting offshore currency swap market liquidity has had unintended consequences, including a sharp increase in local currency bond yields and a decline in the benchmark stock index. The lira's impressive recovery may be short-lived as foreign investors are bailing out of local bonds and stocks due to increased currency risk. The measures may ultimately cost Turkey's debt and equity markets, highlighting the need for more sustainable solutions to address the currency crisis.

site_title: OrangeTee & Tie unveils app for agents to manage multiple property listings
summary: OrangeTee & Tie has launched an app, Agent App, allowing its agents to manage multiple property listings across various portals, including 99.co, Carousell, and EdgeProp. The app, called Listing Hub, aims to increase productivity and collaboration among agents, and also integrates UOB's home-loan solution. The platform provides access to research reports, data analytics, and a client proposal-generation function, as well as monthly property auctions. OrangeTee & Tie plans to expand the feature to more portals and has not ruled out partnering with SoReal Prop, a competitor platform.

site_title: Malaysia's China reset imagines Byte and Road
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has proposed a "Byte and Road" initiative, which includes exchanging technology for infrastructure with China. This move counters his predecessor Najib Razak's Belt and Road plans, which prioritized infrastructure development over technology exchange. Mahathir's new-energy deal with Geely and focus on technology extraction suggest a shift in Malaysia's trade policies. The initiative aims to reduce reliance on US infrastructure projects and promote a more balanced trade relationship with China.

site_title: Healthier Greece exits bailouts after years of biting austerity measures
summary: Greece exits its third and last bailout, having received a total of 289 billion euros in loans from the EU, ECB, and IMF. After years of austerity measures, the country has returned to growth, achieved a budget surplus, and reduced unemployment to below 20%. However, officials warn that Greece still has a long way to go, and households continue to feel the effects of austerity. The country is now expected to finance itself on the financial markets until 2022.

site_title: Netball charity game raises S$15,000 for 2nd AWWA school
summary: A netball charity game in Singapore raised S$15,000 to fund the development of AWWA's second special education school, serving 300 students with autism aged 7-18. The event, held at Kallang Netball Centre, featured prominent personalities from various industries, including NTUC FairPrice, Deloitte, and Sport Singapore. The teams were captained by Deloitte employees Charmaine Soh and Kimberly Lim, with students from AWWA School watching and participating in a clinic. The funds will support the new school's special education programs.

site_title: JPMorgan finds 'sharp' downturn in credit investors' outlook
summary: JPMorgan's August survey of fund managers reveals a sharp downturn in credit investors' outlook, with bullish sentiment shrinking to 20% from 63% in July. Bears now outnumber bulls, and nearly half of respondents have turned neutral on corporate bond spreads. The survey comes ahead of a busy September debt sales period, as investors seek to shorten portfolio duration and manage interest-rate risk, with risk premiums see-sawing this year.

site_title: Singapore-based startup AirTrunk raises A$850m to expand data centres
summary: Singapore-based startup AirTrunk has raised A$850 million to expand its two Australian data centers and enter the Asia market, taking advantage of the growing cloud computing market. The funding will be used to expand its current facilities in Sydney and Melbourne, and to establish new facilities in Singapore, Tokyo, and Hong Kong. AirTrunk, backed by Goldman Sachs, plans to increase its power capacity to 174 megawatts within 12 months, with 100MW ready for customers by the end of 2019. The company expects to make an additional A$3-5 billion in investments over the next three years.

site_title: OrangeTee & Tie launches one-stop platform to manage multiple property listings by agents
summary: OrangeTee & Tie launches an app, Agent App, to manage multiple property listings across various portals, including 99.co, Carousell, and EdgeProp. The "one-stop platform" aims to increase agent productivity and collaboration with industry stakeholders. The app features a listing hub, home-loan solution, research reports, and data analytics charts. Agents can also generate client proposals and list properties on monthly auctions. Currently, the app is only available for OrangeTee & Tie and Edmund Tie & Co agents, with plans to expand to a separate consumer-facing platform by next year.

site_title: China rating firm banned from assessing bonds for a year
summary: China's regulatory commission banned Dagong Global Credit Rating Co, the country's second-largest credit rating firm, from assessing bonds for a year due to "chaotic" management and providing fake information. The National Association of Financial Market Institutional Investors also imposed a ban, citing high fees charged to borrowers. Dagong apologized and committed to implementing changes. The punishment is the most severe ever for a ratings company, aimed at improving transparency and independence in China's domestic credit market.

site_title: Turkey lodges complaint against US tariffs: WTO
summary: Turkey has lodged a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against the US tariffs on steel and aluminium, imposed amid a dispute over the detention of an American pastor. The US tariffs were announced by President Donald Trump, causing the Turkish lira to crash nearly 20% and prompting Turkey to hike tariffs on US imports. The WTO will attempt to resolve the dispute through bilateral consultations, a process that can take years. The dispute revolves around Turkey's detention of American pastor Andrew Brunson.

site_title: Melania Trump laments cyber bullying
summary: Melania Trump renewed her campaign to tackle cyberbullying, urging tech companies to listen to children's concerns about online harassment. The first lady emphasized the importance of social media in children's daily lives, highlighting both its positive and destructive uses. Her husband, President Trump, sparked controversy with his recent insults and public criticisms, overshadowing the first lady's efforts. Despite criticism, Melania Trump remains committed to the issue, elevating awareness and encouraging families to address cyberbullying.

site_title: Sarine Tech inks deal to supply its services to blockchain-based diamond retailer
summary: Sarine Technologies, a mainboard-listed gem company, has signed a deal with Clara Diamond Solutions Corp, a subsidiary of Lucara Diamond Corp, to supply its stone mapping technology. The agreement, on a per-stone per-carat basis, aims to create recurring revenue for Sarine Tech. Clara plans to use blockchain to track diamond mine origin, starting with stones from its parent company. The deal broadens Sarine Tech's addressable market into the upstream mining segment of the diamond industry.

site_title: 50 schools to keep a grand piano each from Sing50 fund
summary: DBS is donating S$60,000 to the Sing50 Fund to support the Adopt-a-Piano programme, which will give 50 schools grand pianos previously on long-term loan. The programme, launched in 2015, aims to promote Singapore music within school curriculum and activities. This gift coincides with the third anniversary celebration of Singapore Rhapsodies, a music series that has showcased over 2,000 students from 70 schools and arts groups. The donation will further empower schools to continue their work in promoting music education.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare takes 25% stake in Singapore medical aesthetics clinic for S$250,000
summary: ISEC Healthcare has invested S$250,000 for a 25% stake in I Medical & Aesthetics Pte Ltd, a Singapore medical aesthetics clinic, through a share subscription. The deal was funded from ISEC's initial public offering proceeds and leaves the company with S$1.27 million. The investment aims to diversify revenue streams and offers potential synergies with ISEC's existing medical eye care services. The deal was reached with existing shareholders and is not expected to impact consolidated net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Malaysia shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.11 points to 1,787.58 on Monday, with a total trading volume of 22.8 million lots worth RM2.04 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 497 to 383.

site_title: Will Singapore stay ahead of the IP game?
summary: Singapore has been ranked highly in the global intellectual property index, coming in 9th place globally and second to Japan in the Asia-Pacific region. The country has consistently aimed to set the gold standard in intellectual property, alongside its other top-ranked achievements such as having the world's best airport and most powerful passport. However, the article does not provide any conclusions or further information on the challenges and threats related to intellectual property rights in Singapore.

site_title: Swissco inks letter of intent to transfer mainboard listing to solar energy company
summary: Swissco Holdings, a suspended marine company, has entered into a letter of intent to transfer its mainboard listing to solar energy company Plus Renewable Technologies. The 60-day non-binding agreement would facilitate a scheme of arrangement. Swissco's judicial managers emphasized the uncertainty of the transactions and advised shareholders to exercise caution. The transfer is subject to various conditions and potential implementation agreements, with no guarantee of completion.

site_title: Linde, Praxair get EU approval for US$82b deal, await US decision
summary: Linde and Praxair, two industrial gas companies, received conditional EU antitrust approval for their $82 billion merger. The European Commission required the companies to sell assets, including their gas business in 28 countries and additional helium sourcing contracts, to address concerns about price hikes and competition. The companies also agreed to reinforce a Japanese rival in Europe. However, the US Federal Trade Commission has imposed more stringent demands, including possible asset sales exceeding the agreed threshold. The US decision is pending.

images.alt_text: German industrial gases group Linde and US rival Praxair secured conditional EU antitrust approval on Monday for their US$82 billion merger but still have to clear a major hurdle with US enforcers.

site_title: To quell uncertainty, explain public housing policies clearly and promptly
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced several public housing policies in a 30-minute speech, focusing on upgrading HDB flats and redeveloping precincts. The policies include a new voluntary early redevelopment scheme called Vers, which will allow the government to redevelop flats around 70 years old if residents vote for it. The scheme will also extend the Home Improvement Programme to include older flats. Additionally, elderly owners in HDB flats will be able to sell part of their lease back to HDB for retirement. The policies aim to keep flats safe and liveable while retaining their value, but concerns have been raised about compensation and impact on residents.

site_title: Perennial launches and prices S$170m of 5.95% notes due 2020
summary: Perennial Real Estate has launched and priced S$170 million of 5.95% notes due 2020, with net proceeds to refinance borrowings. The notes will be issued on August 28 and listed on the next market day. Associates of chairman Kuok Khoon Hong and vice-chairman Ron Sim have subscribed for 23.5% of the issue, while Perennial's CEO Pua Seck Guan has subscribed for 2.9%. DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank are joint lead managers and bookrunners for the notes.

site_title: Malaysia's 'eminent' council to present findings to PM this week
summary: Malaysia's Council of Eminent Persons, formed by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, will present its 100-day review findings to him this week. The council, led by Daim Zainuddin, focused on three themes: improving governance, public well-being, and sustainable growth. Recommendations were made on issues such as management shake-ups, institutional reforms, and a multi-billion dollar scandal at state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad. The council's report will inform the government's policies and management of public agencies and firms.

site_title: Pope vows no more cover ups on sexual abuse in letter to Catholics
summary: Pope Francis wrote an unprecedented letter to all 1.2 billion Catholics, vowing to root out "this culture of death" and promising no more cover-ups of sexual abuse. The letter comes amid crises in the US, Chile, Australia, and Ireland, where numerous surveys show plummeting confidence in the Church. The pope acknowledged the suffering of minors due to abuse by clerics and consecrated persons, calling for a zero-tolerance policy and increased accountability for bishops who covered up abuse. He urged Catholics to join forces to uproot the culture of death and condemn atrocities.
