The government's Vision 2030 program seeks to reduce reliance on oil, with the Public Investment Fund aiming to become the world's biggest sovereign-wealth fund, controlling over $2 trillion.

site_title: Political risk creeps into China's very bad bank
summary: China's state-owned bad bank, Huarong Asset Management, is facing a sharp decline in earnings due to the exit of its chairman, Lai Xiaomin, who was under a graft probe. The company, which is owned by the Ministry of Finance, is struggling with a cash crunch and has been forced to sell stakes, recall loans, and cut salaries. The government's handling of the crisis has raised concerns about the reliability of state backing and the blurring of lines between state and private enterprise.

site_title: Europe: Equities slide at open on Turkey crisis
summary: European stocks slid on Monday due to fears over Turkey's currency crisis, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index dropping 0.6% to 12,346.75 points. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.2% to 7,648.90 points. Bayer plummeted 10% after a US ruling against Monsanto, which merged with the German firm. The Paris CAC 40 lost 0.2% to 5,402.41 points. The concerns stem from Turkey's limited ties with the world and potential bank exposure.

site_title: Australia shares fall as Turkish rout hits; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% to a five-week low, weighed down by materials and banks, as a renewed selloff in the Turkish lira pushed Asian assets lower. The ASX mining index fell to its lowest in over three months, and commodity prices were pressured by global trade tensions. BHP and Rio Tinto were the biggest drags on the benchmark, and Australian banks fell 0.5-0.6% amid concerns over their reputations and mortgage growth. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also fell 0.7% amid healthcare stocks' losses.

site_title: Vietnam's Vinfast in deal with Siemens for technology to make electric buses
summary: VinFast, a Vietnamese private conglomerate, has signed two contracts with Siemens to supply technology and components for electric bus production. The deal enables VinFast to launch its first electric bus by the end of 2019. Additionally, VinFast plans to produce electric motorcycles, electric cars, and gasoline cars at its US$1.5-billion factory in Haiphong City.

site_title: Singapore startup UrbanZoom launches API access to property auto valuation tool
summary: Singapore startup UrbanZoom has launched API access to its auto-valuation tool, Zoom Value, which predicts HDB and condominium valuations with a median error of less than 3%. The tool has been used by Singapore government agencies and companies, including UrbanZoom's own users, such as SoReal Prop and Ohmyhome. By opening up API access, UrbanZoom aims to enable businesses to tap into its AI-enabled insights and enrich their services, with over S$100 billion worth of Zoom Value searches since its launch in March 2018.

site_title: Life on the edge: Scottish rapper probes UK wealth gap at Fringe
summary: Scottish rapper Darren McGarvey's Edinburgh Fringe show, "Poverty Safari Live," tackles the UK's wealth gap through rap and comedy. McGarvey, 33, shares his violent and addictive past, using it as a platform to dissect class attitudes and address inequality. His show has been successful in sparking conversations, and he won the prestigious Orwell prize for political writing. Research by NatCen Social Research found that those who backed Brexit were often economically deprived and had no educational qualifications, highlighting the need for a more inclusive discussion on class and inequality.

site_title: Oil falls on trade dispute; Iran sanctions tighten outlook
summary: Oil prices fell 30 US cents a barrel to $71.77 due to concerns over global trade disputes slowing economic growth and demand for fuel. US sanctions against Iran are expected to tighten supply, limiting losses. Escalating trade tensions are pushing up the dollar, making oil more expensive for consumers.

site_title: Russia's richest lose US$3.1b as tax plan hits shares
summary: Russia's richest individuals lost over US$3.1 billion in one day after a proposal to raise taxes on giant metal and mining companies was made. The plan, proposed by President Putin's top economic aide, could raise 500 billion roubles (S$10.1 billion) a year. The affected companies include MMC Norilsk Nickel PJSC, Severstal PJSC, and Sibur Holding PJSC, owned by tycoons Vladimir Potanin, Alexey Mordashov, and Leonid Mikhelson. The proposal was met with criticism, with one billionaire calling it a "promotion of inefficiency".

site_title: Australia's Capilano Honey gets US$138m bid from consortium
summary: Australia's Capilano Honey Ltd has accepted a US$138m bid from a consortium of China-focused Wattle Hill RHC Fund and Roc Partners. The deal offers shareholders A$20.06 per share, a 28.2% premium. This comes amid China's growing interest in Australian food and healthcare companies, driven by food and health scares in China. This is part of a larger trend of Chinese investment in Australian sectors, including wine and healthcare.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall back on double whammy of Turkey crisis, Q2 GDP miss
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.2% on Monday, down 39.47 points, amid concerns over the Turkey crisis and a weaker-than-expected Q2 GDP growth of 3.9%. The lira's plunge and spillover fears affected emerging currencies, including the Indonesian rupiah. Despite this, experts believe the impact on Asian assets will be limited due to negligible exposure to Turkey and a stronger US dollar. The market reaction is seen as a worst-case scenario rather than a simple response to current implications.

site_title: Iran's problems "internal, not just sanctions": Khamenei
summary: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei attributed the country's economic problems to internal mismanagement, not just US sanctions. The currency has lost nearly half its value since April due to poor management. Khamenei stated that if Iran's government improves its performance, sanctions would have less impact and could be resisted. This comes as protests and strikes continue over high prices, unemployment, and economic management, with analysts saying US hostility has exacerbated long-standing issues within Iran.

site_title: Algeria's state oil firm gets new management, targets brain drain
summary: Algeria's state oil firm Sonatrach has appointed a new leadership team, led by Abdelmoumen Ould Kaddour, to address a brain drain and improve the company's management. The move follows years of short-lived CEOs, fraud scandals, and red tape that deterred foreign investors. As the country seeks to reduce its dependence on Russia for energy, Sonatrach is crucial for Algeria's economic security and budget. The overhaul aims to reverse talent loss and boost the firm's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The head of Algerian state oil firm Sonatrach has assembled a new leadership team, a senior company source said, aiming to reverse a flow of talent from an unwieldy state enterprise that keeps the country afloat.

site_title: Samsung may suspend operations at China mobile phone plant: report
summary: Samsung is considering suspending operations at its Tianjin mobile phone plant in China due to slumping sales and rising labor costs, according to a report. The move comes as the company faces declining smartphone sales in China, with the market share falling from 20% to less than 1% in five years. Samsung has focused its investments on production facilities in Vietnam and India, and the Tianjin plant produces 36 million mobile phones annually. The company has yet to confirm any decision on the fate of the plant.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei plunges nearly 2% on Turkey crisis
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted nearly 2% on Monday due to Turkey's lira crisis, with investors fearing wider financial instability. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.98% or 440.65 points to close at 21,857.43, marking its fourth consecutive decline. The broader Topix index also dropped 2.13% or 36.66 points to 1,683.50. The decline was attributed to tensions between Turkey and the US, sparking concerns about global economic stability.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes afternoon trading at 3,242.26, down 1.3%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed afternoon trading at 3,242.26, down 1.3% from the previous close. The Straits Times Index fell 42.52 points, with 1.2 billion shares worth S$575 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 224 to 116, and active index stocks included DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank, both down 1.6% and 2.2%, respectively.

site_title: In Thailand, obese monks are urged to trim down and get healthy
summary: Thailand's Public Health Department has urged obese monks to trim down and adopt healthier lifestyles. According to a study, nearly half of Thai monks are obese, with high cholesterol, blood pressure, and diabetes rates also on the rise. Health officials suggest that monks consume fewer calories but more sugary drinks, which contribute to their weight gain. To combat this, the government and Buddhist authorities are launching initiatives such as the Healthy Monk-Healthy Nutrition Project, which aims to educate monks on nutrition and physical fitness, and provides recipe booklets and measuring tapes to track their progress.

site_title: Nikki Beach wants to remake itself as a chill resort brand
summary: Nikki Beach, a 20-year-old nightlife company, plans to expand its business by doubling down on its Zen-inspired hotel and resort concept, with 20 locations in the next five years. The company aims to create a more chill resort brand, offering amenities like a massage pagoda, serene pool, and library-like lounge, rather than its traditional beach club experience. The brand's "celebration of life" ethos emphasizes comfort and relaxation, and its expansion plans are seen as a unique entry in the hotel market, combining a pool-party experience with a spa and retreat.

site_title: Singapore insurance industry sees strong 20% rise in new business in H1 2018
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 20% increase in new business premiums to S$2.02 billion in the first half of 2018, driven by strong sales of investment-linked plans and a positive attitude towards protection and retirement needs. The industry also recorded a 19% increase in total sum assured for new business to S$66.28 billion. A total of 14,505 retirement insurance policies were sold, generating S$131 million in premiums. The industry aims to help Singaporeans prepare for retirement and narrow protection gaps, with plans to announce key actions later this year.

site_title: The Chinese street's view of the trade war: some say they won't buy US products
summary: Chinese citizens in Beijing and Shanghai express mixed views on the US trade war, with some expressing concern and others confusion. A survey of 50 individuals found that there is no widespread panic or sense of crisis, with some advocating for retaliation against American products. However, many are uncertain about how to respond to US President Donald Trump's actions, with some arguing that China should strike back at American interests. The mood on the streets is divided, with no clear consensus on whether Chinese people should boycott American products in retaliation.

site_title: Prominent Chinese videos sites vow to cap actors' pay amid tax evasion probe
summary: China's three largest video sites, iQiyi Inc, Youku, and Tencent Video, have pledged to cap actors' pay amid a tax evasion probe into the country's $8.6 billion film industry. The pledge comes after accusations of "yin-yang" contracts, where actors sign a higher payment contract and a lower one for tax authorities. China's tax authorities launched investigations in June, and the video sites' move is seen as a response to the probe. The cap on actors' pay is expected to reduce the industry's tax evasion.

images.alt_text: China's three largest video sites iQiyi Inc, Youku and Tencent Video have pledged to cap actors' pay, as authorities ramp up their tax-evasion investigation into the country's $8.6 billion film industry. The country's top earning celebrity was actress Fan Bingbing (above), who earned 300 million yuan (US$43.64 million) in 2017.

site_title: PayNow Corporate now available to businesses and government agencies
summary: Singapore's PayNow Corporate e-payment service is now available to businesses and government agencies, allowing for instant transfers using Unique Entity Numbers. The service, launched on August 13, 2018, builds on the existing peer-to-peer PayNow service, which has seen over 1.6 million registrations and $1.2 billion in transfers. The new service is available to customers of seven participating banks, with a new QR code option also available for businesses to receive customer payments. The Association of Banks in Singapore sees PayNow as a convenient and secure means for seamless fund transfers.

site_title: Battery technology may be next stranded assets in green revolution
summary: Battery technology may become the next "stranded asset" in the green revolution, as rapid advancements in the industry render some existing technologies obsolete before they reach the market. Despite significant investment in startups and carmakers, not all new technologies are likely to succeed, with lithium-ion cells remaining dominant for the next decade. As demand for battery capacity rises to 1,784 gigawatt-hours by 2030, investors are worried about the potential for stranded assets, with some warning that investments in batteries may become unprofitable due to the need for new manufacturing processes.

site_title: Chinese tech-obsessed insurer may cast a long shadow over Asia
summary: China's Ping An Insurance, the country's largest insurer by market value, is evaluating a potential acquisition of Prudential Plc's Asia business, which would expand its reach to Singapore to Indonesia and increase competition with international brands. With 23,000 research staff and $billions spent annually on R&D, Ping An has attracted 46 million new customers last year, equivalent to Spain's population, mainly in its home market. A successful deal would solidify Ping An's position in Asia's insurance market.

site_title: Brokers' take: ComfortDelGro upgraded to 'add' by CGS-CIMB
summary: Brokers have upgraded ComfortDelGro to 'add' from 'hold' following the company's second-quarter profit decline, citing higher revenue from bus and rail businesses and new acquisitions. Analysts raised target prices, with CGS-CIMB increasing its target to S$2.75, citing an impending earning recovery in the taxi business. Analysts expect ComfortDelGro to maintain a similar 75% dividend payout level and yield a 4.4-4.9% dividend yield for 2018-2020.

site_title: Japan's Don Quijote would be interested in buying Walmart's Seiyu
summary: Japan's discount retailer Don Quijote Holdings Co Ltd expressed interest in buying Walmart's Japanese supermarket chain Seiyu, citing it as an attractive opportunity. Don Quijote Chief Executive Koji Ohara stated that if Seiyu were to be sold, the company would be interested in acquiring it. However, Walmart has not confirmed plans to sell and continues to develop the business. The US retail giant reported last month that it would consider selling the unit.

images.alt_text: Japanese discount retailer Don Quijote Holdings Co Ltd said it would be interested in buying Walmart Inc's Japanese supermarket chain Seiyu.

site_title: Fish fry: Japan heatwave threatens famed tuna auction
summary: Japan's heatwave threatens the famed Tsukiji tuna auction, with air conditioners struggling to keep up. The market is due to close later this year and relocate to a new site. To keep tuna cool, wholesalers are using makeshift measures such as sealed shutters, cool trucks, and tarps, and the auction space is being kept at 15 degrees Celsius instead of the usual 15 degrees. The heatwave, which has killed 119 people, has also led to the discovery of soil contamination at the new site, delaying the relocation. The auction is set to close on October 11.

site_title: Dubai Bank's Turkey bet just got US$1b cheaper. And riskier
summary: Dubai Bank's Emirates NBD has reduced its acquisition price for Turkey's Denizbank AS by approximately US$1 billion, from US$3.2 billion to US$2.27 billion, following a 28% decline in the Turkish lira. The deal, expected to close later this year, has raised concerns about the risk and potential renegotiation of the terms. Analysts believe the lira's plunge may trigger a clause benefiting Emirates NBD, making the deal "more manageable from a capital perspective." The acquisition is seen as a growth opportunity for Emirates NBD, but also poses challenges due to Turkey's financial crisis and potential non-performing loans.

site_title: UK house prices are on the longest losing streak since crisis
summary: UK house prices fell for a fifth consecutive month in July, the longest losing streak since the 2008 financial crisis. The average price dropped 0.2% to £302,251, with London experiencing a "mixed picture" due to declining sales and prices in many boroughs. Slower economic growth, Brexit uncertainty, and inflation outpacing wage growth have contributed to the market's weakening trend.

site_title: Australia's Wesfarmers to sell Kmart Tyre and Auto Service business for US$254.9m
summary: Australian retailer Wesfarmers plans to sell its Kmart Tyre and Auto Service business to Continental AG for US$254.9 million. The sale is part of Wesfarmers' largest portfolio reshuffle in a decade, following the recent sale of its coal mining business for A$860 million. The conglomerate is also set to spin off its supermarket chain, Coles, estimated to be worth A$16 billion. The sale is expected to result in a pre-tax profit of A$270-275 million for Wesfarmers.

site_title: BOJ should ditch negative rates, yield cap: ex-BOJ executive
summary: A former Bank of Japan executive, Kazuo Momma, suggests the central bank should abandon negative interest rates and a yield cap on long-term bonds, as these measures are unnecessary for an economy experiencing steady growth. He argues that the BOJ should focus on the rising cost of prolonged easing and consider the impact on households and firms. The BOJ's current policies, including yield curve control, are seen as steps needed only in response to a crisis, rather than a sustainable solution.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.34 points to 1804.41. Losers outnumbered gainers 115 to 76, with a total volume of 37.5 million lots worth RM14.39 million.

site_title: China evacuates 200,000 as typhoon hits east coast
summary: China evacuated over 200,000 people as Typhoon Yagi made landfall on its eastern coast, bringing winds of up to 102kmh. The typhoon, which hit Zhejiang province, also forced the evacuation of almost 21,000 fishing boats and caused heavy rain. The storm's slow movement inland has minimized casualties, thanks to early government planning and evacuations.

site_title: US investigators find black box of crashed Seattle plane
summary: US investigators found the black box of a crashed Seattle plane, a Bombardier Q400, on Ketron Island in Puget Sound. The plane was hijacked by a baggage handler, Richard Russell, who crashed it into the island. Russell, nicknamed "Beebo," was described as "suicidal" and a "warm, compassionate man" by his family. Two F-15 fighter jets chased the plane, but did not shoot it down. The incident was ruled out as a terror attack, and no one was hurt besides Russell. The flight data recorder was found intact but burned, and will be analyzed for clues.

site_title: Koreas hold high-level talks on third leaders' summit
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un held high-level talks on August 13, 2018, to prepare for a third summit. The talks aimed to review progress on the Panmunjom Declaration and discuss next steps, including the autumn summit meeting in Pyongyang. The two sides agreed to informally schedule the summit for late August or early September. Despite progress in diplomacy, the key issue of North Korea's denuclearization remains unresolved. The talks also focused on officially ending the 1950-53 Korean War.

site_title: No Signboard Q3 profit falls 79.1% on slower sales, higher costs
summary: No Signboard Holdings' Q3 profit plummeted 79.1% to S$761,142 due to slower sales and higher costs, with revenue down 4% to S$6.8 million. The decline was attributed to lower average spending per customer and increased costs related to its new beer business. Pre-tax profit fell 79.7% to S$901,393, and the company will pay an interim cash dividend of 0.26 Singapore cent per share. No Signboard plans to expand its beer business and work on new casual dining concept restaurants.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble at open on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted at the open on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.44% to 27,956.78. The decline was attributed to investor concerns about a global contagion sparked by a Turkish lira rout. The Shanghai Composite Index also dropped 0.94% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.15%. The losses were part of a broader market trend, with US stocks reaching new records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: 'Crazy Rich Asians' to break ground, if not box-office records
summary: "Crazy Rich Asians" is set to debut in North America, generating around $18 million in its opening weekend. The film, featuring a mostly Asian cast, marks a 25-year gap since a Hollywood movie with Asian themes was produced. Its success may signal a new era in Hollywood films with Asian themes, with executive producer Janet Yang expressing hope that it could be the start of a broader trend.

site_title: Australian dollar at 1-1/2 year lows on risk off trade, kiwi soft
summary: The Australian dollar fell to 1-1/2 year lows, trading at US$0.7251, amid a "risk-off" trade following a slump in the Turkish lira. The currency has already dropped 2.1% this month. Analysts attribute the decline to investors seeking safe-haven currencies, particularly the Japanese yen. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar hit a 2-1/2 year trough, falling to US$0.6558, amid concerns over the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's potential rate cut.

site_title: Memtech reports 57% fall in Q2 profit on lower margins, one-off items
summary: Memtech International reported a 56.9% drop in Q2 net profit to US$2.1 million, due to margin compression and one-off items. Revenue rose 19.1% to US$45 million, driven by a 32.6% increase in the automotive segment. However, gross profit margin fell to 14.7% from 17.3% due to higher raw material and staff costs.

site_title: Asia: Shares, euro extend slide as Turkish lira plunges to new low
summary: Asia's shares slid, with the euro hitting one-year lows, as the Turkish lira plunged to new depths, driving demand for safe-havens like the US dollar, Swiss franc, and yen. Japan's Nikkei fell 1.3% and MSCI's Asia-Pacific index dropped 1.1%. The euro touched its lowest since July 2017 at US$1.13700, while the US dollar eased against the yen to 110.40. The Turkish lira's slide is expected to push the Turkish economy into recession and trigger a banking crisis, with wider economic spillovers for the euro zone.

site_title: Magnitude 6.4 earthquake hits Alaska's oil-producing North Slope
summary: A magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck near Alaska's oil-producing North Slope, the most powerful on record in the region, on August 12, 2018. The quake, centered 40 miles southwest of Kaktovik, had no impact on oil operations or generated a tsunami alert. No injuries or damage were reported. The earthquake occurred near an area the US Interior Department plans to lease for petroleum exploration, sparking concerns about environmental impact.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit beats forecast with 7-month DPU of 0.0253 euro on light-industrial strength
summary: Cromwell E-Reit exceeded its forecast with a 7-month distributable profit of 0.0253 euro per unit, 3% higher than expected. The pan-European industrial Reit posted revenue of 72.8 million euros, 2.2% higher than forecast, driven by income from its light-industrial portfolio. Net property income rose 3.1% from projections. Cromwell E-Reit has committed to paying out 100% of distributable income until December 2019.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday's open; STI down 0.63% to 3,263.94
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index declining 0.63% to 3,263.94, amid concerns of slowing economic growth in the second half of the year. The decline was led by CapitaLand and Genting Singapore, with 82 stocks losing value for every 40 that gained. The trade ministry's warning of slower growth outweighed the positive sentiment from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: Malaysia seeks US$35m private jet linked to 1MDB scandal
summary: Malaysia is seeking to repossess a US$35 million private jet owned by financier Low Taek Jho, linked to the 1MDB scandal. The jet was bought in 2010 using allegedly stolen funds from 1MDB. Authorities in Malaysia and the US are investigating billions of dollars in missing funds from the state fund. The DOJ has stated over US$4.5 billion was misappropriated, with some funds used to purchase luxury items including the private jet.

site_title: Trump endorses call for Harley-Davidson boycott
summary: US President Donald Trump endorsed calls for a boycott of Harley-Davidson due to the company's plans to move some production out of the US. Trump tweeted that many Harley-Davidson owners will boycott the company, calling it a "bad move" after the company was targeted with EU tariffs. The company had announced plans to build a plant in Thailand to boost foreign markets. Trump has taken the move personally, treating it as a loyalty test, and has previously criticized Harley-Davidson for building a plant in Thailand.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Federal International, Ace Achieve, ESR Reit, No Signboard, ComfortDelGro
summary: Several Singapore companies reported new developments that may impact their shares on Monday. Federal International fell into a second-quarter net loss of S$228,000 due to lower sales. Ace Achieve Infocom's two independent directors quit citing delays in the annual audit and lack of information. ESR Reit reported a 4.7% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit. No Signboard Holdings' net profit fell 79.1% due to higher costs and expenses. ComfortDelGro Corp's net earnings dipped 5.5% despite a 5.4% increase in revenue.

site_title: At new Raffles Hotel, two of the world's best chefs come to Singapore
summary: The Raffles Hotel in Singapore has reopened after a nearly 30-year renovation, boasting a lineup of world-renowned chefs, including Anne-Sophie Pic, Alain Ducasse, and Jereme Leung. The hotel's emphasis on food and drink has resulted in 10 food and beverage spaces, with over 1,100 seats for just 115 suites. The renovation aims to cater to modern travelers while preserving the hotel's historic charm, with bold new color schemes and Peranakan-style bathrooms. French cuisine is once again a focus, with Pic's La Dame de Pic restaurant set to open, offering a unique culinary experience.

site_title: China's co-working space start-up MyDreamPlus secures US$120m funding
summary: MyDreamPlus, a Chinese co-working space start-up, secured US$120 million in Series C funding led by Hillhouse Capital and General Atlantic. The funding will support expansion in major Chinese cities and enhance R&D and smart office spaces. This investment is part of the company's efforts to increase its presence and upgrade its offerings.

site_title: Tesla killers are arriving from Jaguar, Porsche, Audi and more
summary: Tesla faces increased competition from luxury electric vehicles from Jaguar, Porsche, Audi, and others, with comparable prices to the Model S and Model X. The I-Pace from Jaguar has been praised for its quality and driving experience, while Tesla's Model S and Model X have variable quality issues. Sales of Tesla's Model S and Model X have slowed, with a 30% decline in Europe, and the company forecasts 100,000 sales for the two models this year. Tesla's response is the Model Y, an electric crossover, and Elon Musk's consideration of taking the company private may ease cash concerns and help the company grow.

site_title: Kingsley Mansion in Balestier to launch en bloc tender with S$45.5m reserve price
summary: The owners of Kingsley Mansion in Balestier are launching an en bloc tender with a reserve price of S$45.5 million. The 18-unit condominium has a 14,350 sq ft freehold site, allowing for a 36-storey development with 53 apartments. The tender will close on Sept 13, with each unit potentially receiving S$2.36 million to S$2.57 million if successful.

site_title: Geopolitical issues to dictate trading mood
summary: US-China trade tensions and geopolitical concerns continued to dominate markets last week, with investors adopting a cautious approach towards riskier assets. The Turkish lira and Russian rouble were hit hard by US President Trump's tariffs and sanctions, respectively, while the US dollar strengthened. Wall Street declined on Friday, with major US banks closing lower, and key economic data due for release this week is expected to be closely watched.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust DPS up 2.2% for Q2
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) reported a 2.2% increase in second-quarter distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.902 Singapore cents. Gross revenue rose 3.9% to S$28.7 million, and net property income increased 3.3% to S$20.9 million. The Reit's overall portfolio occupancy reached a new high of 92%. VIT will hold an extraordinary general meeting on August 31 to seek approval for a proposed merger with ESR Reit.

site_title: China Jinjiang Q2 earnings dip 11.2%
summary: China Jinjiang Environment posted a net profit of 149 million yuan (S$30 million) for Q2 2018, down 11.2% from the same period last year, due to higher finance costs and other losses. Revenue declined 5.3% to 680 million yuan, while gross profit rose 15.4% to 337 million yuan. The company reversed an other income gain last year to a loss of 10 million yuan, primarily due to a foreign exchange loss and reduced income from sludge treatment.

site_title: Trump trade rows are 'destroying' growth, says German minister
summary: Germany's economy minister Peter Altmaier criticized US President Donald Trump's global trade rows, warning they're "destroying" economic growth. Altmaier expressed concern over Trump's metal tariffs on Turkey and China's retaliatory measures, which could lead to a full-blown US-China trade war. He emphasized the need for lower tariffs, less protectionism, and open markets. Altmaier also stressed the importance of maintaining European business deals with Iran despite US sanctions, saying "we will not let Washington dictate our trade relations with other countries."

site_title: Australia's APA recommends Hong Kong firm CKI's buyout deal
summary: Australia's APA Group recommended a $12.98 billion buyout offer from a consortium led by Hong Kong's CK Infrastructure, which would see APA shareholders receive $11.00 cash per share. The deal would make CK Infrastructure the major player in Australia's east coast gas pipeline network, pending regulatory approval.

site_title: British lawmakers 'disappointed' over regulator's inaction on RBS
summary: British lawmakers have criticized the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) for not taking further action against Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc after an investigation into the bank's treatment of business customers. The FCA took no enforcement action against RBS or its staff in the Global Restructuring Group (GRG) unit, despite accusations of stripping assets from small firms between 2008 and 2013. Lawmakers have called for a public inquiry and more powers for the FCA to regulate business loans.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Turkey crisis
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on August 13, 2018, amid US-Turkey tensions that drove down the lira, sparking fears of financial instability. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.83% to 22,112.2, while the Topix index dropped 0.83% to 1,705.94. Investors closely watched the situation, causing a decline in Tokyo shares.

site_title: Singapore's economy grows 3.9% in Q2; expected to slow down in H2 2018
summary: Singapore's economy grew 3.9% in Q2 2018, above market consensus forecasts, but is expected to slow down in the second half of the year to 2.5-3.5% due to trade tensions and global uncertainties. The Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the growth to outward-oriented sectors such as manufacturing and finance. Economists maintain their full-year forecast of 3% growth, despite downside risks from the US-China trade spat and tightening liquidity conditions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's monetary policy stance remains appropriate, according to its deputy managing director.

site_title: Two of three Ace Achieve independent directors quit over audit delay
summary: Two independent directors, Soh Yeow Hwa and Roy Ling Chung Yee, quit Ace Achieve Infocom's board due to delays in the annual audit and lack of information from management. The resignations follow the company's rejection of its application for more time to announce its fiscal 2018 results and hold the shareholders' meeting. The company is now left with one independent director, Kang Junen, and is making efforts to replace the departing directors.

site_title: Turkey taking action to ease market concerns: finance minister
summary: Turkey's finance minister, Berat Albayrak, announced an action plan to ease market concerns amid the lira's plunge. The plan, set to be implemented on Monday, targets banks and small to mid-sized businesses most affected by foreign exchange fluctuations. Albayrak stated that institutions will take necessary steps and share announcements with the market. This move aims to stabilize the financial markets and alleviate concerns following the recent decline of the Turkish lira.

site_title: Indian Oil's quarterly profit jumps as refining margin doubles
summary: Indian Oil Corp posted a 50% jump in quarterly profit to 68.3 billion rupees (S$1.36 billion) due to a doubling of refining margin and rising domestic oil consumption. Sales rose 16% to 1.5 trillion rupees, driven by vehicle sales and economic activity. The company earned $10.21 per barrel of crude converted into fuel, up from $4.32 a year earlier. Indian Oil signed a term tender to purchase American oil, amid US President Donald Trump's efforts to squeeze Iran exports.

site_title: France to set penalties on non-recycled plastic
summary: France plans to introduce a penalty system next year, increasing the costs of consumer goods with non-recycled plastic packaging, as part of its goal to use only recycled plastic nationwide by 2025. The system would make non-recycled plastic products more expensive, reducing excessive packaging. Products with recycled plastic packaging could cost up to 10% less. The measure aims to eliminate excessive packaging and reduce plastic waste, but critics argue it is only part of the solution and that more stringent measures are needed.

site_title: Investor relations professionals evolve to satisfy savvier investors
summary: Investor relations professionals are adapting to a new era of financially savvy retail investors who are asking sharper questions. With the rise of online financial education programs, retail investors are empowered to ask better questions, and companies must provide the right information in return. To address this, companies are engaging non-traditional research teams, providing individual videos of properties, and holding retail investor days. Experts emphasize the importance of honesty, transparency, and relationship-building in establishing trust between shareholders and companies, and IR professionals are updating their skills to meet the evolving demands of the industry.

site_title: Lira extends retreat as Turkey heads toward a financial crisis
summary: Turkey's lira continued its decline, weakening to 7.23 per US dollar, as President Erdogan showed no signs of backing down in a standoff with the US. The nation's Banking Regulation and Supervision Agency limited swap transactions, but analysts say measures to calm markets are needed to restore confidence. The lira's plunge has sparked global market concerns, weighing on the euro and Australian dollar, and has raised fears of a contagion. Turkey's economic crisis, fueled by a growth-at-all-costs policy and worsening relations with the US, continues to mount.

images.alt_text: Turkey's lira extended its precipitous slide on Monday after the nation's president showed no signs of backing down in a standoff with the US.

site_title: Indian PM Modi is confident of bigger win in 2019 elections
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed confidence of a bigger win in the 2019 elections, stating his Bharatiya Janata Party will break all records of seats won by the National Democratic Alliance. Despite opposition attempts to target his government's handling of promises, Modi said his administration is committed to improving lives regardless of faith. He attributed the party's success to voters seeking a strong central government to drive India's economic growth.

site_title: ESR Reit DPU up 4.7% for Q2
summary: ESR Reit reported a 4.7% increase in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.001 Singapore cents, driven by higher net property income and distributions from past divestments. Net property income rose 22% to S$23.4 million, mainly from new acquisitions completed in December 2017. Gross revenue was up 17.6% to S$32.5 million, and portfolio occupancy reached 91.4%. The Reit manager expects the leasing market to remain competitive despite improving demand and supply dynamics. Unitholders will vote on a proposed merger with Viva Industrial Trust on August 31.

site_title: Avoid Russian assets: Wall St banks
summary: Wall Street's largest banks are advising investors to avoid Russian assets due to mounting risks of crippling US sanctions. Morgan Stanley turned bearish on the ruble, while UBS Group AG closed its buy recommendation. Analysts at JPMorgan Asset Management estimate a 50% likelihood of curbs on Russian sovereign debt. The ruble retreated 6% last week amid US sanctions and tensions with Turkey. A bill punishing Russian sovereign debt for election meddling remains uncertain, but analysts expect selective sanctions to avoid global market instability.

site_title: Euro on defensive as Turkish crisis sparks rush to safety
summary: The euro is under pressure due to concerns over European banks' exposure to crisis-hit Turkey, with investors seeking safe havens like the US dollar, Swiss franc, and yen. The Turkish lira has slid to all-time lows, triggering fears of a Turkish banking crisis and recession. This has tainted emerging markets and boosted highly rated sovereign bonds. The euro has fallen to a one-year low against the Swiss franc and a 10-week low against the yen, with the dollar also easing against the yen.

images.alt_text: The euro was under pressure in Asia on Monday as fears about the exposure of European banks to crisis-hit Turkey sent investors scurrying to safe havens including the US dollar, Swiss franc and yen.

site_title: Singapore Q2 non-oil exports jump 9.4%; full-year forecast raised to 2.5-3.5%
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) jumped 9.4% year-on-year in Q2, exceeding expectations, with full-year forecast raised to 2.5-3.5%. Total trade expanded 10.2% in Q2, with growth forecast upgraded to 5-6% for 2018. Non-electronic exports drove growth, while electronics declined. The IMF maintains its 2018 global economic growth forecast at 3.9%, but notes downward risks such as trade tensions and rising interest rates may impact global growth and trade.

site_title: US tells China's HNA to sell stake in NYC building near Trump Tower
summary: The US government has ordered Chinese conglomerate HNA Group to sell its majority stake in a Manhattan building near Trump Tower, citing national security concerns. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (CFIUS) informed HNA several months ago that it had to divest itself of the property, which houses the NYPD's 17th precinct tasked with protecting Trump Tower. HNA set up a blind trust and transferred its stake to the trust, which is now in talks with potential buyers to abide by the CFIUS order.

site_title: Sanctions on Iran give China lead in gas project
summary: China National Petroleum Corp (CNPC) is set to take the lead on a $5 billion US project to develop Iran's share of the world's largest gas deposit, after France's Total SA halted operations following US sanctions. CNPC will increase its stake from 30% to 60%, becoming the lead operating partner. The project was halted after US President Donald Trump reimposed sanctions on Iran in May 2018, forcing Total to withdraw. The move comes as European companies, including Total, have withdrawn operations from Iran since the US reversal.

site_title: Erdogan stays defiant as Turkey slips toward financial crisis
summary: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan remains defiant amid a financial crisis triggered by US sanctions, with the lira plummeting 17% against the dollar. Investors worry about the country's exposure to interest- and exchange-rate shocks, and the risk of a full-blown financial crisis. Erdogan has called US sanctions a "financial attack" and urged citizens to exchange dollars and euros for liras, while policymakers consider measures to stabilize the currency, including interest-rate hikes and potential capital controls.

site_title: Caspian Sea nations to sign landmark deal
summary: Leaders of five Caspian Sea nations, including Iran, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Turkmenistan, are set to sign a landmark deal in Kazakhstan. The agreement settles a long-standing dispute over the Caspian's status as a sea or lake, allowing for shared use and division of underwater resources. The deal also bars third countries from establishing military bases on the Caspian and could pave the way for lucrative projects, including the construction of underwater pipelines and the export of Turkmen gas to Europe.

site_title: Ex-White House staffer releases tape of her firing, calls Trump "racist"
summary: A former White House staffer, Omarosa Manigault Newman, released a secret tape of her firing by Chief of Staff John Kelly, claiming Kelly pointed to "significant integrity issues" that led to her termination. The tape, made in 2017, was recorded in the Situation Room, a top-security room. Manigault Newman called President Donald Trump "racist" and accused the White House of deception. The White House dismissed her as a "disgruntled former White House employee" and expressed concerns about national security.

site_title: Euro tumbles as investors fear bank exposure to Turkey
summary: The euro plummeted to its lowest in over a year, falling 1.15% to $1.1393, amid concerns about European banks' exposure to Turkey's struggling lira. US President Trump's authorization of doubled tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Turkey and President Erdogan's combative stance fueled risk aversion. Investors fear a contagion effect, with the dollar index edging higher, and commodity-linked currencies like the Australian dollar also falling.

site_title: Carmakers are choking on blue-sky emission rules
summary: Mazda joins a growing list of carmakers that have failed to meet emissions requirements in Japan, with the company's fuel-economy tests falling short of the country's stringent standards. This scandal raises questions about whether global emissions standards are too high, with a study showing a significant gap between official and real-world carbon dioxide values. The issue highlights the need for a more nuanced approach to reducing emissions, with some experts suggesting that standard-setters should have more realistic expectations for the industry, and that incentives such as electric car subsidies could be more effective in driving change.

site_title: Beijing snuffs out planned protest over P2P failures
summary: China's authorities cracked down on planned protests over the failure of peer-to-peer (P2P) lending platforms, detaining dozens and forcing would-be demonstrators onto buses to a holding center. The P2P industry, which offers high returns to investors, has seen 243 online lending platforms shut down since June, with outstanding loans totaling 1.49 trillion yuan. Authorities are seeking to reassure the public that the economy is healthy despite a trade war and declining stock prices. The crackdown has been met with criticism, with experts warning that larger companies may benefit from firmer regulation, but smaller ones may struggle to survive.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp needs new strategy, says investor
summary: Thyssenkrupp, a German conglomerate, needs a new external chief executive to shift its strategy, according to investor Union Investment. The group's 2020/21 targets were met but failed to impress investors, who are calling for a more active management of its portfolio. The company has been in turmoil since its CEO and chairman resigned in July, with interim CEO Guido Kerkhoff facing pressure to revive the group's share price, which has fallen a third since 2011. A new external CEO could bring a fresh perspective and signal a stronger commitment to capital markets.

site_title: Putting sex in sexagenarian: Madonna still rocks at 60
summary: Madonna is turning 60 and continues to defy age norms with her provocative performances and unapologetic attitude. The pop superstar openly dates men decades younger, maintains a svelte figure, and has never gone more than four years without an album since her debut in 1983. Music scholar Freya Jarman says Madonna's legacy is evident in younger artists like Lady Gaga, but she's now demonstrating a new kind of relevance as an ageing, female musician still in the public eye.

site_title: Manufacturing sector drives Singapore GDP growth at 'robust' clip in Q2 2018
summary: Singapore's GDP grew at a 'robust' 10.2% in Q2 2018, driven mainly by the manufacturing sector, which expanded by 10.2% year-on-year. The electronics cluster, particularly semiconductors, contributed to the growth. The services sector grew 2.8% year-on-year, led by finance and insurance. However, the construction sector remained a drag, with a 4.6% year-on-year decline. The government maintains its GDP growth forecast for 2018 at 2.5-3.5%.

site_title: Novena Global Lifecare defers listing after MOU with Yozma BioScience
summary: Novena Global Lifecare, a Singapore-based healthcare chain, has deferred its initial public offering (IPO) plans following a recent fund injection. Instead, it is considering listing its subsidiary Novena Life Sciences, which has received US$5 million in investment from Yozma BioScience Holdings. The partnership will give Novena exclusive rights to Yozma's technologies in Asia, and in return, Novena will provide a 25% equity stake. The move is seen as a strategic partnership to drive innovation and commercialization of life sciences technologies in the region.

images.alt_text: Cousins Terence and Nelson Loh, co-founders of the Novena Global Lifecare Group.

site_title: High-tech Tokyo tops list of world's most innovative cities
summary: Tokyo has been named the world's most innovative city, surpassing London and New York due to its adoption of robotics and 3D manufacturing. The Japanese capital has rapidly risen in the Innovation Cities Index, joining other Asian cities such as Singapore and Seoul. The top 10 list was released on Friday, with Tokyo's innovative spirit attributed to its embracing of cutting-edge trends.

site_title: Tapping the differently abled
summary: Business leaders from various organizations in Singapore share their experiences of hiring people with disabilities and the impact it has on workplace culture. Many emphasize the importance of inclusiveness, valuing diversity, and creating a culture that supports employees with disabilities. They highlight the benefits of hiring differently-abled talent, including increased loyalty, valuable traits, and work ethics that contribute to the organization's success. The leaders also discuss the need to adapt the workplace to accommodate employees with disabilities and provide support and resources to help them thrive.

site_title: OCBC joins AWWA in battle against dementia
summary: OCBC Bank has partnered AWWA to launch the OCBC Glowing Years Programme, a holistic initiative to tackle dementia among seniors in Singapore. The programme provides incentives for seniors to improve their motor and cognitive skills through a points-based system, with rewards such as massages and outings. A pilot roll-out in January showed marked improvement in mental alertness and social interaction among 80 seniors. The programme aims to benefit 2,000 seniors over the next two years, and OCBC Bank hopes it sets a model for corporate sectors to engage with the community and prevent depression and dementia.

images.alt_text: Soh Kim Huay, 75, trying her hand at a shooting game, with Dr Koh and Mr Ooi cheering her on.

site_title: Trump embraces market pain with little concern of contagion
summary: US President Donald Trump is embracing market pain in foreign economies, doubling steel and aluminum tariffs on Turkey amid a currency crisis, and imposing new sanctions on Russia. Despite concerns about contagion, Trump shows little concern for the impact on US markets, instead celebrating the economic losses suffered by the targets of American tariffs and sanctions. Turkish President Recep Tayip Erdogan vows to take care of his country's business, while economists question the strategy's durability and potential for economically driven instability.

site_title: Turkish crisis, US retail earnings to set direction
summary: US stocks may be impacted by the Turkish currency crisis and the upcoming earnings report from Walmart, potentially revealing whether the "blue-collar" whites that form President Trump's base are feeling the effects of his economic policies. The crisis in Turkey could lead to a short-lived fallout in global markets, with economists predicting a quick recovery. Meanwhile, Trump's economic war with China and the ongoing UK exit from the European Union could also have significant effects on global markets, with a Chinese economic slowdown potentially having greater reverberations.

images.alt_text: US stocks fell slightly last week as excitement about the strongest quarters for earnings in the last decade gave way to fears about a currency crisis in Turkey.

site_title: Seeking its day in the sun
summary: Singapore startup SolarHome taps into record demand in Myanmar for internet connectivity through solar power, capitalizing on the country's 90% smartphone penetration since 2016. New cell towers have been built in rural areas, driven by investments from Japan, Qatar, and Norway. SolarHome's initiative aims to expand internet access to Myanmar's underserved regions, providing a sustainable solution to the country's growing demand for internet connectivity.

site_title: Fortnite ploy highlights Google's Android weakness versus Apple
summary: Fortnite's decision to bypass Google's Play app store and distribute its game directly through its website highlights weaknesses in Android's operating system compared to Apple's iOS. The move, which could be a precursor to a shift away from the current 30% revenue-sharing model, threatens Google's revenue from in-app purchases and game downloads. Analysts predict this could lead to a shift in the mobile gaming market, potentially favoring Apple's iOS, which doesn't allow external app downloads. This could have significant implications for Google's Android revenue, estimated to be around $10 billion this year.

site_title: Concerns raised over recalled heart drug a year ago
summary: A US inspector raised concerns with the Chinese manufacturer of valsartan, a widely used heart drug, in May 2017, over a probable cancer-causing chemical. The FDA found that the company ignored quality testing and recorded false results instead. The drug was recalled in August 2018 for containing NDMA, a chemical considered a probable human carcinogen. The FDA is testing samples to determine the extent of contamination. The company, Zhejiang Huahai, didn't respond to requests for comment.

site_title: PayNow Corporate launched today
summary: Singapore's PayNow Corporate e-payment service launched on August 12, 2018, allowing businesses and the government to instantly make and receive payments using Unique Entity Numbers. This extension of the peer-to-peer PayNow service, which has over 1.6 million registrations and $1.2 billion in transfers, is available to seven participating banks and their corporate customers. The launch aims to promote a convenient and secure funds transfer system between businesses and government agencies, according to the Association of Banks in Singapore.

site_title: US federal agency halts all work on Atlantic Coast Pipeline after judges revoke permits
summary: A US federal agency, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), has halted all work on the Atlantic Coast Pipeline after a panel of judges revoked two key permits for the project. The permits, issued by the National Park Service and the US Fish and Wildlife Service, were found to be flawed, with the court ruling that the agencies had not properly explained the pipeline's impact on public lands and endangered wildlife. The halt comes after similar setbacks for another pipeline project in Virginia, and environmental activists are calling for a reevaluation of the project's approval.

site_title: US Navy searching for overboard marine off Philippines
summary: The US Navy launched a search and rescue operation after a US marine may have fallen overboard from the USS Essex while it sailed through Philippine waters. The ship was conducting routine operations in the Sulu Sea when the incident occurred on Thursday morning. Aircraft and multiple searches are underway, both inside and outside the ship, covering approximately 3,000 square nautical miles. The Philippine coastguard is also participating in the expanded search. The US Navy remains committed to finding the missing marine.

site_title: MoneySmart plans 2020 IPO, acquisition also on the cards
summary: MoneySmart, a Singapore-based personal finance portal, plans to go public through an initial public offering (IPO) in 2020, with a target exit price of over S$200 million. The startup, founded in 2009, has received a Series B funding of S$14 million and has raised US$12.6 million in venture capital. MoneySmart aims to create a better product after an exit, and is open to acquisitions by larger financial aggregators or Chinese Internet giants. The company's vision is to disrupt the financial advisory industry and render financial advisory redundant.

site_title: Lower fund expenses a trend in US, Europe
summary: US and European fund investors are benefiting from lower average expense ratios, with a 2018 study by Morningstar finding an 8% decline in the US to 0.52% in 2017, and a 1% decline in Europe to 1% in 2016. This decline, driven by $4 billion in saved investor fees, is attributed to lower-cost share classes and the launch of no-fee exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in the US. The trend suggests that past low-cost funds are more likely to remain low-cost, and the creation of clean-fee share classes is driving down fees in Europe and the US.

site_title: Germany says Trump's tariffs, sanctions destroying jobs and growth
summary: Germany's Economy Minister Peter Altmaier has criticized US President Donald Trump's tariffs and sanctions, saying they are destroying jobs and growth, and that Europe will not bow to US pressure on Iran. The US has triggered a trade dispute with import tariffs targeting American jobs and European companies. Germany and the EU reached an agreement with the US last month, saving hundreds of thousands of jobs, but Altmaier warns that the trade war creates new uncertainties. Despite this, Germany expects strong growth this year due to domestic demand and rising wages.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's August 12, 2018, shipping market report reveals a mixed week for tanker and dry bulk markets. Tanker rates softened, with VLCC rates slipping to WS 52, while USG rates fell to WS 24.25. Suezmax rates in the Mediterranean dropped to WS 82.5/85. In contrast, Capesize rates remained steady, with some charters securing rates above $10.00. The market was affected by a Singapore holiday and a lack of fresh enquiry from certain regions.

site_title: Luxury flats rise on NY's industrial backyard
summary: New York City's north side of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is undergoing a luxury transformation, with the latest development being One Blue Slip, a 30-story rental building from Brookfield Property Partners. Part of the US$1 billion Greenpoint Landing project, the building features 359 apartments with water views and a range of amenities, including a co-working lounge and waterfront public park. The area, once industrial, is being redeveloped with sleek high-rises and public spaces, aiming to appeal to renters seeking a unique blend of grit and charm.

site_title: Oracle accused of defrauding investors on cloud sales growth
summary: Oracle is accused of defrauding investors by allegedly lying to shareholders about its cloud sales growth. A lawsuit filed by the City of Sunrise Firefighters' Pension Fund claims the company used coercion and threats to sell its cloud-computing products, creating an unsustainable model. The lawsuit claims Oracle's executives made false forward-looking statements, and the company used software license audits and weakened maintenance programs to compel customers to buy cloud products. Oracle has denied the claims, stating the lawsuit has "no merit" and will vigorously defend against the allegations.

site_title: Hedge fund giant sees trade war fuelling US dollar rally
summary: Morgan Stanley's Man Group predicts the US dollar rally may continue due to the escalating trade war between the US and China, which could fuel dollar strength rather than stymie it. According to Guillermo Osses, head of emerging markets debt strategies, the US may impose significant tariffs on China, leading to a transmission effect on other countries, including Europe, resulting in dollar appreciation. This view contradicts other financial giants, including Wells Fargo and JPMorgan, who believe the dollar is nearing its peak.

site_title: Chinese banks top ranking by assets - a cause for concern
summary: Chinese banks have surpassed US and European lenders in ranking by assets, a sign of rapid credit expansion. This growth mirrors Japan's 1988 financial crisis, where nine of the top 10 banks collapsed. Today, only one Japanese successor remains in the top ranks. The US and European economies have struggled with low growth since the 2007 sub-prime mortgage meltdown and sovereign debt crisis. China's rapid expansion raises concerns about the country's economic stability and potential policy pressures.

site_title: Investors sue Tesla's Musk over go-private tweets
summary: Two investors filed a lawsuit against Tesla CEO Elon Musk and the company over tweets that led to a significant increase in the share price. Musk tweeted he could finance a $420-per-share buyout, causing shares to jump 11%. The investors claimed Musk's tweets artificially inflated the price, resulting in millions of dollars in losses for short sellers. The US Securities and Exchange Commission also contacted Tesla to inquire about the accuracy of Musk's statements and the use of Twitter to disclose the information.

site_title: Facebook's David Marcus resigns from Coinbase board in blockchain push
summary: Facebook executive David Marcus has resigned from Coinbase's board, citing a new group he oversees exploring blockchain uses. This move suggests Facebook is pushing ahead with its own blockchain work, potentially leading to the issuance of its own cryptocurrency or token. Analysts believe a board seat at Coinbase could be a conflict of interest, as Marcus could lobby the exchange to list a Facebook token. This comes after Kik and Telegram issued their own tokens, and smaller social networks plan to distribute tokens in the near future.

site_title: Airplane without passengers taken from Seattle airport, crashes: official
summary: A Horizon Air turboprop Q400 airplane took off from Seattle-Tacoma airport without passengers, crashing in south Puget Sound. The incident occurred late Friday, and airport officials stated that normal operations had resumed. The incident was described as an "unauthorised takeoff" by airport officials, but no further information was provided. The cause of the crash remains unknown at this time.

site_title: Nobel-winning writer VS Naipaul dies at 85
summary: British author VS Naipaul, a Nobel laureate and post-colonial writer, has died at 85. Naipaul, born in Trinidad, was known for works like 'A House for Mr Biswas' and 'In A Free State', which explored the traumas of post-colonial change. He was a symbol of modern rootlessness and stirred controversy with his views on post-colonial countries and Islam. Naipaul was awarded the 2001 Nobel Prize for literature for his 'literary circumnavigation' and 'annalist of empires'. He was knighted in 1990 and wrote over 30 books.

site_title: Industrial Production data points to more upside for US equities
summary: The US general equity market continues to edge higher despite ongoing trade tensions, driven by strong economic data. The S&P 500 index is just 1% away from its January record high, while the Nasdaq 100 index has broken another record high. Industrial Production year-on-year growth rate remains above 0%, supporting the bullish narrative. Historically, a contraction in Industrial Production y-o-y data signals the end of the equity bull market, but the current trend suggests further upside for the S&P 500 index, with the next big hurdle being the 3,000 psychological round number.

site_title: Higher costs, losses from associates hit KSH's Q1 profit
summary: KSH Holdings' first quarter net profit decreased 3.8% to S$6 million due to higher expenses and deeper losses from associates. This marks a significant decline from the previous year. The construction and property development group attributes the decline to increased costs and losses. Despite the decline, the company remains committed to its operations and future growth.

site_title: Cheniere signs 25-year LNG sales deal with Taiwan's CPC
summary: US liquefied natural gas company Cheniere Energy Inc signed a 25-year deal with Taiwan's CPC Corp to supply 2 million tonnes of LNG per year starting in 2021, valued at approximately US$25 billion. The deal includes a price pegged to the Henry Hub monthly average plus a fee. The purchase will start in 2021, with deliveries to be made on a delivered basis.

site_title: Microsoft CEO sells US$36m in stock; starts trading plan
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella sold 328,000 shares valued at $35.9 million for financial planning reasons, starting a regularly scheduled trading plan for some of his equity awards. This is the second time he has sold Microsoft stock since becoming CEO in 2014. The sale is part of a plan to divest shares, with fewer than half of his Microsoft shares to be sold through the plan. Nadella remains committed to the company's success.

site_title: High fund expense ratios put Singapore retail investors in a bind
summary: Singapore retail investors face a dilemma due to high fund expense ratios (TERs) in the country's actively managed funds, exceeding 1.8% on average. These high costs dilute returns at a time when expectations are muted, with a TER of 2% eating into an investment of S$100,000 over 30 years, resulting in a loss of over S$82,000. Some fund houses, like Lion Global, offer lower TERs, but the majority of funds remain under pressure to meet retail investors' expectations. The CPFIS (Central Provident Fund Investment Scheme) is also seeking to reduce TERs, but retail investors are left with limited lower-cost alternatives.

site_title: Land Rover on charity drive to support animal welfare needs
summary: Land Rover Singapore organized a National Day Charity Drive in partnership with Causes for Animals, Singapore (CAS) and Land Rover Owners Singapore. A fleet of 50 Land Rover cars embarked on a 50km journey through Singapore, passing by notable landmarks. The drive aimed to raise funds and awareness for animal welfare needs in Singapore. The event marked a unique way for Land Rover to celebrate National Day while giving back to the community.

site_title: Walmart in unofficial coalition to tackle Amazon
summary: Walmart has formed an unofficial coalition with several powerful tech companies, including Google, Microsoft, and JD.com, to counter Amazon's dominance in the e-commerce market. The alliance aims to prevent Amazon from ruling the digital galaxy by investing in e-commerce, building automated distribution centers, and developing curbside pickup services. Walmart has also partnered with Google to create a voice-activated shopping experience, and with Microsoft to provide cloud-based services and leverage artificial intelligence and machine learning capabilities. The move reflects a strategic shift for Walmart, which acknowledges that it cannot compete with Amazon alone.

images.alt_text: Each member of the resistance provides something Walmart can't do well alone but one danger is a potential clash of cultures between the heavyweights.

site_title: Comply or Explain 2.0 casts a wider net
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore has issued a revised Code of Corporate Governance, known as Comply or Explain 2.0, which takes a more stringent approach to corporate governance. The revised code replaces the traditional "Comply or Explain" approach with a more nuanced system, where companies must explicitly state their compliance or explanations for deviations from mandatory principles. The new code also shifts practices that have become mainstream into the Listing Rules, making them compulsory. This revised approach aims to promote thoughtful compliance and growth, and will come into effect for annual reports starting from January 1, 2019.

site_title: At Carrier, the factory Trump saved, morale is through the floor
summary: Carrier factory workers, who were saved by President Donald Trump's intervention in 2016, are now struggling with low morale and rising absenteeism. Despite the factory staying open and investing in new equipment, workers feel uncertain about their jobs and are frustrated with the company's management. Many attribute the absenteeism to a lack of trust in the company, citing instances of supervisors pointing out workers in Mexico who miss fewer days. The workers, who earn relatively high wages, feel that the company is not doing enough to improve morale and are worried about the factory's future.

site_title: Sarine Q2 net profit up 27.9% to US$4.1m
summary: Sarine Technologies reported a 27.9% increase in Q2 net profit to US$4.1 million, driven by lower operational expenses and a more normalized tax rate. Revenue edged down 1.1% to US$18 million. Earnings per share rose to 1.18 US cents, or 1.61 Singapore cents.

site_title: Federal International (2000) posts Q2 net loss of S$228,000
summary: Federal International (2000) reported a Q2 net loss of S$228,000, down 83.1% from the previous year, due to lower sales from its trading business. Revenue declined to S$7.4 million, down 67.4% year-over-year. The company's net loss for the first half was S$1.2 million, primarily attributed to the near completion of its Zawtika Development Project Phase 1C.

site_title: Trump says he will have dinner with Apple CEO Cook on Friday
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to have dinner with Apple CEO Tim Cook on Friday, amid a trade war with China. Cook had previously expressed concerns over the tariffs imposed by Trump, which could affect Apple's purchases in China. The dinner comes after Trump reportedly assured Cook that the US government would not levy tariffs on Apple iPhones assembled in China. This follows Apple's recent milestone of becoming the first US$1 trillion publicly listed US company.

site_title: Earnings in focus; Synagie Corporation debuts on Catalist
summary: Synagie Corporation debuted on Catalist with an IPO that raised approximately S$11.6 million in gross proceeds. The company, which provides e-commerce solutions in the body, beauty and baby sector, works with SMEs and large MNCs, and its cloud-based platform was launched in August 2016. Synagie's CEO, Clement Lee, likens the company's business to Baozun in China, albeit on a smaller scale. The company's shareholder base includes pre-IPO investors such as Agate Investments Limited, Harmony Treasure Holdings Ltd, and Island Asset Management Pte Ltd.

site_title: Sensors to smartphones bring patent wars to diabetes monitoring
summary: A patent war is escalating in the diabetes monitoring industry, driven by the growing number of diabetics and increasing insurance coverage for new devices. The market for continuous glucose monitors is projected to reach $2 billion by 2026, with companies like DexCom and Abbott Laboratories vying for market share. The competition is fueled by emerging technologies such as wireless communication, signal processing, and increased sensitivity of glucose levels. The financial stakes are rising, with companies embroiled in lawsuits over patents, and the number of patent applications related to glucose monitoring increasing steadily.

images.alt_text: Most of today's devices are designed to help people with type-1 diabetes, who need daily doses of insulin, and insulin-dependent type-2 diabetes.

site_title: China says business ties with Iran no harm to any other country
summary: China's Foreign Ministry stated that its business ties with Iran do not harm the interests of any other country, opposing unilateral sanctions and "long-armed jurisdiction". China defends its commercial relations with Iran as open and transparent, despite US President Donald Trump's threat to bar companies from the US. China buys 7% of its crude oil from Iran and has invested billions in Iranian oil fields, citing dialogue and negotiations as the path to resolving the issue. China's relations with Iran remain unaffected by US sanctions.

site_title: Former Battle of Britain command post now £2.4m penthouse
summary: The Bentley Priory, a 600-year-old British estate, is now for sale as a £2.4m penthouse. The luxury apartment, named the Dowding Suite, was the command headquarters of the Royal Air Force during World War II and features three bedrooms, terraces with city views, and a 24-hour concierge. The property has a rich history, having been a royal residence, hotel, and girls' school, and is listed by Savills Plc. The sale comes as UK house prices fell in July for the first time in seven months.

site_title: Gold puts up a fight as selloff slows near key US$1,200 level
summary: Gold shows resistance near $1,200 an ounce, stalling declines after reaching a one-year low. Despite a stronger US dollar and economic growth, concerns over Turkey's financial crisis may be preventing a further selloff. Gold futures slipped 0.1% to $1,211.24 an ounce, with investors losing faith, as holdings in exchange-traded funds reach a six-month low. A technical rebound to $1,230 or $1,235 is possible, but gold bears remain in control.

site_title: Turkey's lira crisis: How bad can it get?
summary: Turkey's lira has plummeted to a record low of over six against the US dollar, wiping out a quarter of its value in a single day. The currency's depreciation is attributed to strained ties with the US and concerns over Turkish policymakers' unorthodox economic strategies. Economists warn that the lira's fall poses significant dangers to the economy, particularly the banking system. President Recep Tayip Erdogan's efforts to boost growth through unconventional monetary policies have put him at odds with markets, and the central bank's decision to keep interest rates on hold has further eroded investor confidence.

site_title: European pilots hit Ryanair with biggest strike yet
summary: Ryanair pilots across Europe staged the largest strike yet, with 55,000 passengers affected by the stoppages of 400 out of 2,400 scheduled flights. The strike, involving pilots in Ireland, Germany, Belgium, Sweden, and the Netherlands, was over better pay and conditions, with Ryanair offering customers refunds or rebooking options. The strike was the biggest escalation in Ryanair's long-simmering dispute with cockpit and cabin crews, with unions demanding improved pay, work conditions, and benefits for contractors.

site_title: World Bank to issue world's first blockchain bond
summary: The World Bank is issuing the world's first blockchain bond, a two-year Australian dollar-denominated bond aimed at raising around $50 million. The bond, which will be finalized the week of August 20, will utilize blockchain technology to improve transparency and reduce transaction time. The World Bank's innovation lab, in partnership with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Microsoft, is working to ensure the platform and software are secure and reliable. The move is seen as a step towards leveraging digital finance to support financial services for developing nations and gain experience with blockchain technology.

site_title: Monsanto ordered to pay US$289m in world's first Roundup cancer trial
summary: A California jury ordered Monsanto to pay $289 million in damages to a school groundskeeper who alleged the company's glyphosate-based weed-killers, including Roundup, caused his cancer. The jury found Monsanto liable and awarded $39 million in compensatory damages and $250 million in punitive damages. Monsanto denies the chemical causes cancer and plans to appeal the verdict. This is the first lawsuit to go to trial alleging glyphosate causes cancer, with over 5,000 similar lawsuits pending across the US.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SingTel's operating revenue dipped 0.5% to S$4.1 billion in Q2, driven by a 3% decline in group enterprise revenue. The Singapore consumer business saw a 1.7% year-on-year growth, mainly due to better home service revenue. The company's fair value is estimated at S$4.08.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends lower as Turkey woes hit banks
summary: US stocks declined on Friday as a worsening economic crisis in Turkey led to a drop in bank shares and triggered a risk-off move. The Dow and S&P 500 fell, with the S&P technology index down 0.8% and Intel shares down 2.6%. Investors fled to safe-haven assets, pushing the US dollar higher and weighing on US bond yields. The S&P 500 remains 1.4% below its record high, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 196.09 points, or 0.77%.

site_title: As Turkey crisis mounts, contagion jitters hit global banks
summary: Turkey's financial crisis is causing global bank contagion fears, with investors worried about the potential for loan defaults and weakening currencies. European lenders, including Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, UniCredit, and ING, saw their shares plummet due to Turkey's crisis and Russia's turmoil, alongside US firms like Citigroup. The US has also raised sanctions, further exacerbating the situation. Investors remain sensitive to risks in the sector, which lost billions in Greece and struggled to recover after the 2008 financial crisis. Global banks are experiencing a ripple effect, with shares falling even for those with minimal exposure to Turkey.

site_title: No artists outshine others in this egalitarian collection
summary: Patric McCoy, a Chicago art collector, boasts an impressive collection of 1,300 works, including paintings, sculptures, and drawings, which he praises equally. His apartment, located on the South Side of Chicago, houses this extensive collection. With a deep commitment to art, McCoy's collection rivals that of top-tier collectors, solidifying his position as a fully committed art enthusiast.

site_title: A supply chain of tools - making the right investment moves with logistics service providers
summary: The logistics industry is a complex and evolving sector that plays a crucial role in today's supply-chain ecosystem. To invest in logistics service providers, it's essential to establish a complete picture of a company's portfolio of services, including its demand drivers, pricing model, and operational performance. Key factors to consider include demand, volume, macroeconomic conditions, and the use of technology. Researching a company's transport planning, environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices, and operational metrics can help investors make informed decisions and identify top-performing logistics players.

site_title: Oil up on Iran sanctions but set for weekly decline
summary: Crude oil prices rose over 1% on Friday due to tightening US sanctions on Iran, but fell 0.5% to 1.2% for the week. Benchmark Brent crude settled at $72.96 a barrel, while US light crude rose 82 cents to $67.63 a barrel. Investors worry about slowing global trade growth and demand for energy, with hedge funds cutting bullish positions on US crude. US energy companies added 10 oil rigs, while the International Energy Agency warns of potential supply disruptions due to the sanctions.

site_title: Two more Chinese drug developers seeking to list in HK: sources
summary: Two Chinese drug developers, Kintor Pharmaceuticals and Frontier Biotechnologies, are planning initial public offerings in Hong Kong, which could each raise around $300 million. The companies are seeking to take advantage of the city's new listing rules, allowing unprofitable biotech firms to list. Kintor focuses on cancer and cardiovascular treatments, while Frontier develops HIV treatments. Listing preparations are at an early stage, and details of the potential offerings could change. This follows the recent listing of Ascletis Pharma and BeiGene Ltd in Hong Kong.

site_title: It's America First in markets as S&P thrives in Trump trade haze
summary: US stocks are thriving in a market downturn globally, with the S&P 500 up 6% in 2018, while the rest of the world is down 5.8%. This divergence is attributed to the US earnings fortress and the Trump administration's trade policies, which have torpedoed progress in emerging markets. Investors are preferring US assets, with $70 billion added to US equities since the start of the year, and a strengthening US dollar has boosted the allure of American assets. However, experts warn that the US market may not be shielded from global peers in the future, and a slowdown in growth from China to Europe will send ripple effects to US markets.

site_title: Tesla killers are arriving from Jaguar, Porsche, Audi and more
summary: Tesla faces increasing competition from luxury electric vehicles from Jaguar, Porsche, Audi, and others.
