The Taycan, Porsche's all-electric sedan, is set to enter production next year and has already garnered interest from customers, including Robert Wickel, who previously owned a Tesla Model S. Jaguar's I-Pace, another electric SUV, has comparable entry-level prices to Tesla's Model S and X, and has received positive reviews. This competition is contributing to Tesla's softening sales in Europe, with a 30% drop in Germany and the UK. The company's Model 3 production is also facing challenges, with the Model Y, an electric crossover, being introduced to address the issue.

site_title: Tesla CEO Musk accused in lawsuit of defrauding shareholders
summary: A class-action lawsuit was filed against Tesla and CEO Elon Musk, accusing them of defrauding shareholders through a scheme to manipulate the electric car company's stock price. The lawsuit claims that Musk's August 7 tweet about potentially taking Tesla private led to an increase in the company's stock price, which then fell after the announcement. The proposed class includes investors who bought Tesla shares following the tweet. The US Securities and Exchange Commission had previously investigated the matter.

images.alt_text: Tesla Inc and chief executive Elon Musk were sued on Friday by an investor who said they defrauded shareholders in a scheme to manipulate the electric car company's stock price, starting with Mr Musk's Aug 7 tweet that he might take Tesla private.

site_title: Indonesia set one week out from 2018 Asian Games
summary: Indonesia is set to host the 2018 Asian Games, starting in a week, despite concerns over terrorism, street crime, and traffic congestion. Officials say preparations are on track, with 70% of opening ceremony tickets sold and measures in place to mitigate traffic issues. Security measures include deploying 40,000 troops and police officers, while environmental concerns, such as haze from forest fires, are being monitored. Despite some hiccups, excitement is building ahead of the event, with residents expressing enthusiasm for the Games.

images.alt_text: Jakarta and Palembang in Sumatra are set to host about 11,000 athletes and 5,000 officials from 45 Asian countries for the August 18 to September 2 Games, the world's biggest multi-sport event behind the Olympics.

site_title: The private musings and short fuse of Elon Musk
summary: Elon Musk's recent tweets indicate he's becoming increasingly frustrated with investor skepticism about Tesla. After announcing plans to take the company private at $420 a share, Musk's statements have raised concerns about the legality of the plan. Critics argue that Musk's proposal, which would allow current retail investors to swap shares for shares in the new private company, may not comply with US securities law. The move has sparked fears that Musk is not prepared to address Tesla's underlying issues, including poor manufacturing quality and missed production targets.

site_title: US, Mexico Nafta negotiators to resume talks next week: minister
summary: US and Mexican negotiators will resume talks on updating the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) next week, with a deal possible by the end of the month, according to Mexico's Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo. Despite progress, Guajardo acknowledged that difficult issues, such as a sunset clause for NAFTA, remain to be resolved. US President Donald Trump expressed optimism about a deal, but warned that tariffs on auto imports could be imposed if Canada's trade barriers are not addressed. The talks will continue with a focus on bilateral issues before Canada rejoins the discussions.

site_title: Noble to hold special meeting to approve restructuring plan
summary: NOBLE Group has scheduled a special general meeting (SGM) on Aug 27 to approve its proposed restructuring plan, which has received support from key stakeholders holding over 30% of the company's shares and 42.9% of existing perpetual capital securities. The plan aims to establish New Noble, with Noble chairman Paul Brough stating it's the best deal for all parties and will enable the group to operate with a sustainable capital structure. The SGM will also vote on the disposal of vessels and the appointment of a joint auditor for New Noble.

site_title: Mandiri to lure wealthy Indonesians with ETFs, dollar products
summary: Bank Mandiri plans to offer dollar-denominated products and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) to wealthy Indonesians amid a global emerging-market sell-off and a currency rout in Indonesia. The move aims to manage a share of the wealth held by Indonesians overseas and locally, generating high fee income. With a limited product range for dollar assets, Mandiri is partnering with Lombard Odier to develop products for wealthy clients. This expansion aims to attract and retain wealth held by Indonesians abroad, particularly in Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: The two hot favourites to be crowned EPL champions
summary: The English Premier League season has begun, with 380 matches to be played over the next nine months. Defending champions Manchester City and big-spenders Liverpool are the top favourites to finish first and second, according to bookmakers. Manchester United kicked off the season with a match against Leicester City. The two teams are expected to battle it out for football supremacy in England this season.

site_title: HRnetGroup Q2 profit jumps 78% to S$13m
summary: HRnetGroup, a Mainboard-listed recruitment firm, reported a 78% jump in Q2 net profit to S$13m, driven by the 88GLOW Plan's acquisition of co-owners' stakes. Revenue rose 10.8% to S$108m, with earnings per share increasing to 1.29 cents. The company's productive headcount rate reached a record 75.5%, with no dividends declared. Shares closed at S$0.90, up 3.4%.

site_title: PayNow Corporate seen as 'game-changer' in Singapore's cashless drive
summary: Singapore's PayNow Corporate, an e-payment service for businesses, is set to launch on Monday, offering cost benefits and convenience to both merchants and consumers. The service, which allows businesses and the government to instantly pay and receive money, has seen strong interest from participating banks and businesses, including government clients and major retailers. DBS has announced it will waive all inward PayNow fees for SMEs and corporates until December 2019, while OCBC and UOB have also partnered with businesses to implement the service. The launch is seen as a game-changer in Singapore's push towards a unified e-payments system and cashless society, with the goal of being cheque-free by 2025 and having ATM cash withdrawals at 20% of e-payment transaction value by 2020.

site_title: Qualcomm wins Taiwan reprieve as global antitrust battle rages
summary: Qualcomm has reached a settlement with Taiwan's antitrust regulators, reversing most of a $773 million fine. As part of the agreement, Qualcomm will invest $700 million over five years and boost research activities in Taiwan, home to key suppliers to global companies like Apple. The company will stop paying fines and retain the right to charge royalties on its technology. This decision reverses a previous ruling that Qualcomm had monopoly market status over key mobile phone standards and was violating local laws. The agreement is seen as a positive step for Qualcomm's patent-licensing business, which generates most of its profit.

site_title: China projects boost Ho Bee Q2 net
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a 98.1% year-over-year increase in net profit to S$71.5 million for the second quarter ended June 30, driven by a S$28.3 million fair value gain on investment property and a doubling of its associates' profit to S$25.7 million. The group's revenue rose 16.1% to S$43.4 million, while net finance costs surged 43.9% due to additional bank borrowings. The company's earnings per share climbed to 10.74 Singapore cents, and its net asset value per share increased to S$4.78.

site_title: Network like your job depends on it
summary: A referral-based online job portal, Wanted, has seen the power of networking in job applications. According to statistics, referrals make up 40% of successful hires, but only 7% of job applications come from referrals. Wanted's country director, Edric Lin, says that referrals add a "human touch" to job applications and can increase chances of landing an interview by 8%. To gain an edge, job seekers should build a strong online presence, get recommendations from people who know them, and clean up their CVs. Networking in real life is key, and job seekers should be genuine and offer help to others, even if it doesn't benefit them directly.

site_title: Tackling the problem of overtourism
summary: Protests against overtourism have begun in European cities, particularly in Barcelona, where 30 million overnight visitors in 2017 strained local infrastructure and amenities. The issue of overtourism, defined as excessive growth leading to overcrowding and strain on residents, is a global problem affecting destinations such as Palma de Mallorca, Paris, and Bali. Cities are taking drastic measures to limit the effects, including taxation arrangements, fines, and "demarketing" to attract fewer, high-spending tourists. However, finding a balance between tourism growth and local welfare remains a challenge, with overtourism seen as a symptom of late capitalism and a need for urgent rethink of urban evolution.

site_title: Malaysia shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.80 points to 1,805.75 on Friday, with a trading volume of 21.9 million lots worth RM2 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 487 to 402.

site_title: Europe: Shares tumble as Turkish turmoil hits banks
summary: European shares fell 1.1% on Friday, led by concerns over the Turkish lira's record lows and the potential economic repercussions. Banks such as Spain's BBVA and Italy's UniCredit were hit hard due to exposure to Turkey. The Turkish delegation returned from US talks with no apparent solutions, fueling worries about the widening rift with the US. The Stoxx 600 index closed down 0.9% on the week.

site_title: Flexible spaces are the future of corporate real estate
summary: Companies are embracing flexible workspace, combining creative and collaborative areas with social and community elements. According to JLL data, the trend has led to international operators like WeWork expanding in Asia-Pacific, with US$500 million committed to growth plans. Corporates are transforming their portfolios and office space, with many incorporating flexible options to improve agility and reduce hassle. However, concerns remain about maintaining brand culture and information technology security in shared spaces, with no clear answer on whether companies will move employees to external coworking spaces or integrate coworking features into traditional leased spaces.

site_title: A closer look at the US-China trade war
summary: The US-China trade war has led to a decline in China's stock market, with the Shanghai Shenzhen CSI 300 Index plummeting 15.27% from the start of the year to end-July. In contrast, the S&P 500 has advanced 7.24% during the same period. China's economy has become increasingly dependent on domestic consumption and investment, with exports accounting for 19.8% of GDP. The US, on the other hand, depends on overseas sales, with companies like Alphabet and Microsoft generating more than half of their revenues outside the US. Analysts warn of "large" collateral damage from the trade skirmish, which may have over-reacted by investors, and the conflict is forcing China to walk a policy tightrope to support sentiment and growth without risking financial instability.

site_title: Move over millennials, it's Gen Z's turn to kill off industries
summary: Gen Z, the demographic born after 1996, is expected to significantly impact various industries, including malls, print magazines, American football, and cash usage. With over 70% of Gen Zers influencing their family's spending, businesses are scrambling to understand their desires. Gen Z is characterized by lower expectations, lower confidence, and a preference for risk-averse behavior. As a result, malls are closing at a record pace, print magazines are struggling, and American football participation is declining. Gen Z's preference for digital life and social media clout is also driving the shift towards cashless payments, with many preferring to use cards over cash.

images.alt_text: Apparel brands specifically marketed to teens are on the decline. Abercrombie & Fitch and Urban Outfitters have seen a 68 per cent drop in the number of store locations in North America since 2016, according to Bloomberg Intelligence.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance's Q2 net profit up 41.7%
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 41.7% increase in Q2 net profit to S$29.6 million, driven by a 19.1% rise in interest income. Annualized earnings per share rose to 26.53 Singapore cents. Interest income grew 28.2% to S$8.9 million, while hiring charges increased 10.5% to S$13.2 million. The company declared a 5-cent dividend, up from 4 cents previously, and its shares closed at S$2.69.

site_title: Shopping for dividends
summary: The grocery sector is a significant and growing business, with a projected worth of $11 trillion by 2021. Supermarkets are competing to retain and increase their share, often putting smaller "mom and pop" stores out of business. Efficient supermarkets have a short cash conversion cycle, indicating strong bargaining power and low external funding needs. High asset turnover, such as Costco's $3.50 per dollar of asset employed, is a key driver of returns for investors. Supermarket investors can expect around $13 of net profit on every $100 invested, with many companies retaining nearly 60% of profits and growing dividends at high rates.

site_title: Rich Asians give Deutsche Bank crazy growth potential
summary: Deutsche Bank's private bank in Asia is still actively recruiting despite recently hiring 100 relationship managers and support staff in the first half. CEO Christian Sewing is focusing on growth, and this business shows no signs of slowing down. Lok Yim, head of the Asia-Pacific wealth business, stated that there are "pretty much no hiring limits" for this unit.

images.alt_text: Since taking over in April, Mr Sewing has announced plans to cut at least 7,000 jobs and retrench in investment-banking areas.
Mr Yim has expressed optimism that the recent hiring of relationship managers will bring more rich clients to Deutsche Bank.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired a property in New South Wales, Australia for A$9 million, while Cortina Holdings saw a 77% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$5.28 million. Wee Hur Holdings posted a 82% increase in net profit to S$6 million for its second quarter, driven by the partial recognition of gross profit from Mega@Woodlands. These companies reported positive earnings, but Cortina Holdings noted a potential deterioration in the global economy.

site_title: Yangzijiang gains 9% on week
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's shares gained 8.8% on the week, driven by a strong Q2 performance and a stronger US dollar. The company reported a net profit of 994.9 million yuan (S$198.8 million), a 38% increase from the previous year, and revenue more than doubled to 7.96 billion yuan. Analysts have been bullish on the stock, with several maintaining "buy" calls and target prices ranging from S$1.23 to S$1.82.

site_title: How your personality traits affect your pay
summary: A new study by Miriam Gensowski at the University of Copenhagen reveals that personality traits, particularly conscientiousness and extraversion, significantly impact lifetime earnings. Men who score one standard deviation higher in conscientiousness earn an average of $567,000 more, while extroverted men earn $490,100 more. In contrast, agreeable men earn 8% less. Higher IQ is also correlated with higher earnings, with a one standard deviation boost adding $184,100. The study's findings suggest that personality traits play a significant role in determining earnings, especially for high-IQ individuals.

site_title: STI loses 1.3% as US-China trade tensions heat up
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% on Friday, closing at 3,284.78, due to US-China trade tensions and lower oil prices. The US imposed 25% tariffs on $16 billion worth of Chinese goods, while China retaliated with 25% tariffs on $16 billion worth of US goods. The US dollar index reached its highest level since July 2017, affecting global equities and emerging markets. The STI's biggest losers included DBS, OCBC Bank, and Jardine Cycle & Carriage, while Ezion Holdings was the biggest gainer.

site_title: NeraTel bags S$11.8m worth of new contracts
summary: NeraTel secured S$11.8 million worth of new contracts for its network infrastructure business segment, providing equipment and maintenance services to a repeat customer in South-east Asia. The company's CEO, Beck Tong Hong, attributed the contracts to the management's drive to pursue contracts for sustainable long-term growth, highlighting the company's competitiveness and ability to deliver tailored solutions. The new contracts are expected to positively contribute to the group's financial performance from the fiscal year ending Dec 31, 2019.

site_title: Japan's economy rebounds in Q2 on brisk spending, but trade rifts cloud outlook
summary: Japan's economy rebounded in Q2 with a 1.9% annualized growth, driven by strong household and business spending. The rebound follows a revised 0.9% contraction in the previous quarter. Domestic demand was the main driver of growth, with private consumption rising 0.7% and capital expenditure increasing 1.3%. However, global trade tensions, particularly between the US and China, pose a risk to the export and investment outlook, with potential tariffs on Japanese cars and capacity constraints due to a rapidly aging population.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's Q2 net earnings dip 5.5% to S$75m
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp posted a 5.5% dip in net earnings to S$75 million for Q2, despite a 5.4% increase in revenue to S$941.1 million. Higher operating expenses and losses from foreign exchange conversion eroded profitability. Operating costs rose 6.5% to S$831.6 million. The company attributed the decline to a negative foreign currency conversion effect of S$1.7 million.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open on Turkey turmoil
summary: US stocks fell on Friday as a plunging Turkish lira rattled global markets due to concerns over Turkey's economy and its rift with the US. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 108.04 points, or 0.42%, to 25,401.19, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell. The decline was largely attributed to the Turkish lira's sharp drop, which raised concerns about global economic instability.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened lower on Friday as a plunging Turkish lira rattled global markets due to concerns over the country's economy and a deepening rift with the United States.

site_title: Reits
summary: US mortgage rates rise after five weeks of declines. A Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore may test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents hit another record, with more increases expected. Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won hotel and retail assets in Seoul. UK homebuyer demand rebounds to a six-month high. New World Group is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secures new tenants and fills more space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore post-bankruptcy.

site_title: Inflation pressures rise modestly in July; Fed on track to raise rates
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in July, driven mainly by a 0.3% increase in the cost of shelter. This modest rise in inflation pressures keeps the Federal Reserve on track to gradually raise interest rates. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, also rose 0.2%, with the annual increase reaching 2.4%, the largest since 2008. The Fed is expected to raise rates at its next policy meeting in September, with forecasts suggesting four rate hikes in 2018.

site_title: Yuan decline helps China in US trade war, at a price
summary: The recent decline of the Chinese yuan has benefited Chinese exporters in the US trade war, making their goods cheaper due to high US tariffs. However, the currency's drop poses financial risks, including increased debt costs for companies with dollar-denominated debt and higher import costs. Analysts estimate the yuan's decline could offset up to $250 billion in planned US tariffs, but the Chinese central bank has chosen not to intervene, instead allowing market forces to influence the currency's value.

site_title: Tender for exec condo site at Anchorvale Crescent launched
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) has launched a tender for an executive condominium (EC) site along Anchorvale Crescent in Sengkang, Singapore. The 1.71-hectare site can be developed into 550 units, with a minimum bid price of S$255 million, or nearly S$461 per square foot per plot ratio. The tender will close on September 14. Market experts expect strong interest from developers, driven by limited supply and strong take-up of EC units.

site_title: The main causes of heart failure
summary: Heart failure is a condition where the heart cannot pump blood effectively, affecting approximately 6.5 million Americans. The main causes include coronary heart disease, high blood pressure, valvular heart disease, and cardiomyopathy. Significant risk factors include age, obesity, diabetes, and high blood pressure. Prompt treatment with medications, fluid restriction, and lifestyle modifications can help manage heart failure. Preventing heart failure is better than curing it, and regular health checks are essential to identify potential risks and prevent disease.

site_title: SGD savings deposit growth flatlining as depositors seek options
summary: Singapore's SGD savings deposit growth has plateaued, with depositors seeking alternative instruments offering higher payouts. Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) have seen significant interest, with six out of eight issues oversubscribed this year. Banks are responding with fixed deposit promotions, offering rates up to 1.75% for 12-month terms. The upcoming launch of a SGD-based investment-grade corporate bond ETF, yielding 3.22%, may further attract depositors, driving short-term SGD rates higher.

site_title: At least 4 people killed, one in custody in Canada shooting
summary: At least 4 people were killed in a shooting in Fredericton, Canada, and one person is in custody, police said. The incident occurred on a residential street, and local media showed emergency vehicles responding to the scene. Gun laws in Canada are strict, but a proliferation of weapons has led to an increase in gun crimes. The incident is the latest in a series of shootings in Canada, which has seen a 30% increase in fatalities this year.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma profit down 25.6%, mainly from one-off IPO expenses
summary: Hyphens Pharma International posted a 25.6% profit decline in its second quarter to S$1.6 million due to one-off IPO expenses. Revenue rose 0.5% to S$30.9 million, driven by increased sales from specialty pharma and dermocosmetic products. The company expects steady growth in Vietnam's pharma market, but faces challenges in Malaysia due to government changes. Hyphens Pharma plans to integrate its operations into a new facility by the end of 2018, aiming to increase productivity and competitiveness.

site_title: Ericsson to add 300 US jobs as 5G demand picks up
summary: Ericsson plans to add 300 US jobs as 5G demand increases, with a focus on engineers and AI specialists. The company aims to meet growing demand for next-generation 5G equipment, with plans to build its first 5G radios in the US by the end of the year. This move comes as the company seeks to capitalize on a new cycle of network upgrades and recover from a period of falling spending on networks. Ericsson's CEO, Borje Ekholm, noted that the new hires are part of an increase in R&D investment, rather than a reduction in staff elsewhere.

site_title: Trade tension has been a catalyst for nervousness in regional equity markets
summary: Trade tensions between the US and China have dominated regional equity markets, causing nervousness among investors. Despite concerns, Asian economies have become less dependent on exports and developed markets, making them less vulnerable to trade measures. Many stocks have been sold off due to a knee-jerk reaction, but fundamentals remain relatively intact. China's onshore equity market is now trading at a low valuation, presenting opportunities for long-term investors. However, risks from trade rhetoric and potential stagflation loom, highlighting the need for active investors to focus on winners and losers in a negative sum game.

site_title: Nordic Group's Q2 net profit up 17%
summary: Nordic Group posted a 17% increase in Q2 net profit to S$4.35 million, driven by an 8% rise in revenue to S$26.1 million, largely due to increased carbon allowance sales. Earnings per share rose to 1.1 cents, while a dividend of 0.779 cents was declared. The company has S$96.3 million in outstanding orders, with deliveries expected within the next 36 months. Despite challenges in the marine, oil, and gas industries, Nordic remains optimistic on long-term prospects, citing contract wins, cost management, and opportunities for further M&A.

site_title: Golden Gate Ventures launches US$10m blockchain fund
summary: Golden Gate Ventures (GGV) has launched a $10 million blockchain fund, LuneX Ventures, to invest in cryptocurrency and blockchain startups globally. The fund, targeted to close within a year, will be separate from GGV's $100 million Fund 3. GGV's Kenrick Drijkoningen views blockchain as a foundational technology with "disruptive potential," and the firm aims to provide industry expertise and connections to its portfolio companies. The launch comes as the blockchain industry has raised $9 billion through ICOs in the first half of 2018, with GGV's portfolio companies having raised over $35 million through ICOs.

site_title: US consumer prices edge up in July
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in July, driven mainly by a 0.3% increase in shelter costs. The 12-month inflation rate remained steady at 2.9%. Core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.2% and 2.4% annually, the largest increase since 2008. The Federal Reserve tracks a 2% inflation target, which was met in June and is expected to be maintained. The Fed is set to raise interest rates, with four expected hikes in 2018, as inflation pressures build amid low unemployment and rising raw material costs.

site_title: WeWork revenue, and losses, surge in first release of results
summary: WeWork, a rapidly growing coworking company, reported a significant surge in revenue and losses in its second quarter. Revenue more than doubled to $421.6 million, with memberships increasing to 268,000, while net losses jumped to $723 million. Occupancy rates rose to 84% and operating margins improved to 28%. Despite high expenses, WeWork is poised to surpass $2.3 billion in revenue by year's end, with available cash and commitments totaling $4 billion.

site_title: Ho Bee Land Q2 net profit nearly doubles to S$71.5m
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a net profit of S$71.5 million for Q2 FY2018, nearly doubling from S$36.1 million in the same period last year. The increase was driven by a S$28.3 million fair value gain on investment property and a S$25.7 million share of profit from associates. Group revenue rose 16.1% to S$43.4 million, driven by higher rental revenue from acquired properties. The company's earnings per share climbed to 10.74 Singapore cents, and net asset value per share increased to S$4.78.

site_title: Ernst & Young to spend extra US$1 billion on cloud, new technology
summary: Ernst & Young (EY) is investing an additional US$1 billion in new technology, including artificial intelligence and cloud platforms. This move follows a trend among financial groups, such as Deloitte and KPMG, to reinvest in technology projects. EY has hired experienced executives, including Nicola Morini Bianzino and Steve George, to oversee the new investment. The firm aims to leverage these investments to drive growth and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: UBS Wealth Management urges clients to cut rouble 'overweight' positions
summary: UBS Wealth Management advises clients to cut their rouble overweight positions due to rising US sanctions pressure on Russia. Analyst Tilmann Kolb expects further pressure on the currency despite Russia's sound fiscal and monetary policies. This recommendation is part of UBS WM's Emerging Market FX strategy, which closes its overweight position in the rouble against a basket of euro and US dollar.

site_title: Businesses urge UK to abandon net migration target post-Brexit
summary: The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) recommends the UK abandon its net migration target post-Brexit, introducing a system for EU arrivals that meets employers' needs. The CBI, Britain's biggest business lobby group, urges the government to guarantee EU citizens' rights, allow businesses a two-year adaptation period, and introduce compulsory registration. The recommendations come as the UK prepares to end freedom of movement from the EU after Brexit, where EU workers account for between 4-30% of the workforce in every sector.

site_title: Asiatravel.com Holdings seeks 2-month extension to announce Q2 results due to cashflow issues, lack of finance staff
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings is seeking a 2-month extension to announce its Q2 financial results due to cash flow issues and a breach of obligations by ZhongHong Holdings, which has only paid $2.65 million of a $10 million loan. The company's minor cash flow issues have led to multiple resignations, and its resources are focused on restructuring operations. The extension request is pending approval from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Najib's corruption trial to start in February
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's trial on corruption charges related to the 1MDB scandal will start in February, with seven charges, including money laundering and power abuse, against him. Najib, 65, faces up to 20 years in prison if found guilty. The trial, scheduled from February 12-28 and March 4-29, will involve around 50 witnesses. Najib denies all charges, which allege billions of dollars were looted from the sovereign wealth fund 1MDB.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with sharp loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with a sharp loss, slipping 0.84% to 28,366.62, unable to build on its four-day winning streak. Investors took profits amid the China-US trade row, while keeping an eye on developments in the trade row. The Shanghai Composite Index remained barely moved.

site_title: KSH's Q1 net profit shrinks 3.8% to S$6m
summary: KSH Holdings' first-quarter net profit decreased 3.8% to S$6 million due to higher expenses and losses from associates. Revenue rose 31.3% to S$40.8 million, driven by construction business growth. Earnings per share fell to 1.05 Singapore cents, while net asset value per share increased to 60.06 Singapore cents. The group won a S$28 million construction contract, expected to contribute to its financial results until FY2021.

site_title: Hong Kong's economy slows as trade war, rates squeeze looms
summary: Hong Kong's economy slowed in the second quarter, growing 3.5% year-over-year, as a deepening US-China trade conflict and rising interest rates weigh on the territory. The trade threat, despite not being directly subject to US tariffs, could still affect Hong Kong's exports, particularly if nearly half of Chinese goods re-exported to the US via Hong Kong are impacted. Rising US interest rates also pose a challenge, with mortgage rates set to rise. However, retail sales remain strong, and unemployment is at a 20-year low, suggesting a moderation in growth ahead.

site_title: Wee Hur Holdings' net profit up 82%
summary: Wee Hur Holdings reported a 82% increase in net profit to S$6 million for its second quarter, driven by the partial recognition of gross profit from Mega@Woodlands. Revenue rose 55% to S$54.8 million, while earnings per share increased to 0.66 cents. The group declared a 0.4 cent dividend, with sales status of Parc Botannia at 60% sold and Mega@Woodlands at 52%. Construction orders stood at approximately S$242 million, and the group expects stiff competition in building projects.

site_title: Higher revenue, better margins push Cortina Holdings' Q1 net profit up by 77%
summary: Cortina Holdings, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 77% increase in Q1 net profit to S$5.28 million, driven by higher revenue and improved sales margins. Revenue rose 12% to S$104.5 million, while sales margins increased to 24.5%. Finance costs dropped due to lower average borrowings. The company expects to remain profitable despite market competition and potential global economic downturns.

site_title: Brexit uncertainty is depressing UK growth - finance minister
summary: UK finance minister Philip Hammond says Brexit uncertainty is depressing economic growth in Britain, citing a lacklustre year-on-year expansion of 1.3% in the second quarter of 2018. He believes Brexit proposals will lead to economic growth similar to staying in the EU. Hammond aims for faster growth rates, but faces a fresh blow to the UK economy, which has shrunk for the second month.

site_title: Addvalue Technologies extends net loss in Q1
summary: Addvalue Technologies reported a net loss of US$862,000 in Q1, easing from US$1.07 million a year ago. Revenue rose 33.4% to US$1.13 million, driven by the maiden delivery of Software Defined Radio communication modules to a government agency. Loss per share decreased to 0.05 US cents from 0.06 US cents previously.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retail takings increased 2% in June, boosted by motor vehicle sales. Two-thirds of SMEs are expected to go cashless by 2023, according to an OCBC poll. Noble is holding a special general meeting to approve a restructuring plan, while a tender for an EC site at Anchorvale Crescent has received a strong response. Singapore shares closed 1.3% lower on Friday.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance's Q2 net profit up 41.7%
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 41.7% increase in net profit to S$29.6 million for its Q2, driven by a 19.1% rise in interest income. Interest on loans increased to S$65.3 million, while hiring charges rose 10.5% to S$13.2 million. Despite a 23.9% decline in fees and commission income, net interest income and hiring charges rose 26.7% to S$54 million. The company declared a 5c dividend, up from 4c previously, and plans to focus on risk management and liquidity amid volatile market conditions.

site_title: UK economy rebounds but services end quarter on a weak note
summary: The UK economy rebounded in the second quarter with a 0.4% growth rate, in line with forecasts, but the services sector lost momentum in June, posting its weakest performance since March. Manufacturing and construction gained, but services output was unchanged. The pound fell 0.5% against the dollar, and investors cut bets on future interest rate hikes. The economy's growth rate, now at 1.5%, is near the Bank of England's estimated speed limit, raising questions about the impact of Brexit on investment decisions and the BOE's future actions.

images.alt_text: The UK economy bounced back from its turgid start to the year in the second quarter but the dominant services sector lost momentum toward the end of the period.

site_title: Australian shares weighed by materials and oil stocks; NZ up
summary: Australian shares finished lower on Friday, weighed down by materials and oil stocks, despite a 0.7% gain for the week. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed down 0.3% after James Hardie Industries' disappointing earnings report. Oil prices fell, with Brent crude down 0.22% to $71.91 per barrel, and energy stocks lost 1.8%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.8% driven by consumer staples and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 1.3% to 3,284.78. About 1.82 billion shares changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 247 to 165. Ezion Holdings was the most actively traded stock, rising 2.7% to S$0.075. The decline follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday, amid tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific associate to acquire property in Revesby, Australia for A$9 million
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' associate RPPG (Revesby) has agreed to acquire a 8,433 square meter industrial property in Revesby, Australia for A$9 million. The property, comprising warehouse and office space, will be financed through internal funds. The acquisition is made by an indirect associate of Roxy-Pacific, with 50% held by the company's subsidiary and the remaining 50% by PGG (Revesby) Pty Ltd.

site_title: House of Fraser set to appoint administrators as British High Street casualties mount
summary: British department store retailer House of Fraser will seek the appointment of administrators due to failed negotiations with investors and creditors. This move puts up to 17,000 jobs at risk and could join a growing list of UK retail casualties. The company struggles with subdued consumer spending, rising labor costs, and growing online competition, following a string of British store groups that have gone out of business or announced shop closures this year.

site_title: Surbana Jurong, Malaysia's Help University to set up green design and technology centre
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Malaysian urban and infrastructure consulting firm, has signed a memorandum of understanding with Help University to establish a Green Design and Technology Centre. The centre will offer certificate courses on renewable energies, sustainable urban planning, and architecture, as well as research and development in these fields. The partnership aims to train a new generation of architects and engineers in sustainability, increasing awareness and capabilities among developers, and contributing to the development of resilient and sustainable cities.

site_title: Boustead Projects' net profit up 73% in Q1 on one-off gain
summary: Boustead Projects reported a net profit of S$10 million in Q1 2018, up 73% from S$5.8 million a year ago, driven by a one-off gain from the sale of 25 Changi North Rise. Revenue increased 7% to S$48.8 million. Adjusted for the gain, total profit would be 11% lower year-on-year due to higher overhead expenses. The company maintains a positive outlook for FY2019, with a S$202 million order book backlog.

site_title: Mewah International's Q2 net profit down 81.4%
summary: Mewah International reported a 81.4% decline in Q2 net profit to US$577,000, primarily due to foreign exchange losses. Revenue increased 0.7% to US$742.4 million, driven by an improvement in the bulk segment. The company declared a dividend of 0.22 Singapore cents, down from 0.30 cents previously. Mewah remains optimistic about finding demand for its existing products and withstanding lower demand conditions due to past investments.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,286, down 1.2% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) resumed trading on Friday at 3,286, down 1.2% from the previous day's close. About 1.12 billion shares changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 205 to 144. The most actively traded stock was Advance SCT, trading at S$0.001 with 50 million shares changing hands. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Mandiri lures wealthy Indonesians with ETFs, dollar products
summary: Indonesian bank Mandiri plans to offer dollar-denominated products and exchange-traded funds to wealthy clients, aiming to manage their overseas assets and capitalize on high fee income. Following a currency rout, investors are seeking safe-haven assets, and Mandiri seeks to expand its product range to meet this demand. The bank has partnered with Lombard Odier to extend offshore ETFs to local investors, and its president director, Kartika Wirjoatmodjo, aims to balance rupiah and dollar assets for Indonesian investors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 0.07 points to 1804.88 at 9am on Friday, August 10, 2018. The index saw 39.58 million lots traded worth RM15.79 million, with 117 gainers and 55 losers.

site_title: Koh Brothers Group's Q2 net profit down 37%
summary: Koh Brothers Group reported a 37% decline in Q2 net profit to S$961,000 due to a one-off compensation income recognized last year. Revenue increased 30% to S$85.7 million, driven by the construction and building materials division. Earnings per share fell to 0.24 cents. The group expects the construction sector to remain challenging but aims to secure more projects to replenish its order book for sustainable growth. The private residential market is also expected to remain challenging due to property cooling measures.

site_title: Singapore's retail takings up in June, buoyed by motor vehicle sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales grew 2% in June, boosted by a 9.7% increase in motor vehicle sales. Excluding motor vehicles, sales would have grown 0.2%. Other sectors, such as medical goods and toiletries, and recreational goods, also saw growth. In contrast, industries like computer and telecommunications equipment and optical goods declined. Online retail sales contributed 4.1% of total sales, while food and beverage services index improved 2.9% year-on-year, with restaurant spending up 4.8%.

site_title: Japan PM Abe on track for extended term despite rival's bid
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is poised to win a September ruling party leadership race, securing a third term as premier. Despite a challenge from former defence minister Shigeru Ishiba, Abe has locked in 70% of the 405 votes from LDP members of parliament. A second round would be held if no candidate wins a majority. Abe's ratings have recovered after scandals, and analysts say his grass-roots popularity may not offset weak support among MPs.

site_title: Ford Motor's China sales fall 32% in July on continued lack of fresh models
summary: Ford Motor Co's China sales dropped 32% in July to 57,662 vehicles, marking the automaker's worst-ever first-half year in China since 2001. This follows a 38% decline in June and a 26% drop in January-July sales. Ford plans to launch 50 new or redesigned vehicles in China from this year through 2025, including an "entry-level" SUV, to revive its business. The lack of new models has pressured Ford's business in China, which officials indicate could last through the end of 2018 or early 2019.

site_title: IEA warns easing oil supply concerns may only be temporary
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warned that concerns about oil supplies may only be temporary due to increased output by major producers, including Russia and Opec nations. Crude prices have dipped following the easing of supply worries, but the IEA cautioned that supply tensions could quickly flare with the approach of tough US sanctions on Iran. The respite in oil prices may not last, and the IEA is closely monitoring the situation.

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang gains 3% on Friday on strong Q2 performance; up 16% on the week
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding shares rose 3% to S$1.02 on Friday, driven by its strong Q2 performance and a stronger US dollar. The stock gained 16% for the week. The shipbuilder reported a net profit of 994.9 million yuan (S$198.8 million) for Q2, up 38% from last year, with revenue more than doubling to 7.96 billion yuan. This is attributed to increased construction and delivery of larger vessels.

site_title: China's new online cosmetics stars: men
summary: China's male cosmetics industry is booming, with hundreds of online beauty stars, known as "wang hong," sharing makeup tips and promoting products to millions of fans. The market is expected to grow 15.2% in the next five years, driven by increasing acceptance of makeup among men. Companies like Alibaba and JD.com have launched live-streaming platforms, while cosmetics brands are paying big money for male influencers to review their products. Despite criticism and hate messages, male beauty stars are paving the way for a more inclusive beauty industry in China.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as US-Japan trade talks continue
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday due to investor caution ahead of US-Japan trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.33% to 22,298.08, while the Topix index dropped 1.15% to 1,720.16. Investors held off on buying before holidays, awaiting the outcome of the US-Japan trade talks, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Golden Gate Ventures rolls out dedicated US$10m fund for blockchain investments
summary: Golden Gate Ventures (GGV) has launched LuneX Ventures, a US$10 million fund focused on blockchain investments. The fund is part of GGV's strategy to capitalize on the growing cryptocurrency and blockchain industry. LuneX Ventures aims to invest in startups globally and will be closed within a year. GGV sees blockchain as a foundational technology with significant disruptive potential, and the fund's launch comes as initial coin offerings (ICOs) have raised US$9 billion globally in the first half of 2018.

site_title: Europe: Shares tumble as Turkish turmoil hits banks
summary: European shares fell on Friday morning due to concerns over the plunging Turkish lira, which weighed on banks. The European Central Bank is concerned about banks' exposure to Turkey, leading to a 3% decline in shares of BNP Paribas, UniCredit, and BBVA. The pan-European STOXX 600 index dropped 0.5%, with banks accounting for the biggest sectoral fallers, down 1.3%.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS upgrades CDL to 'hold'; OCBC keeps 'hold', raises fair value to S$9.81
summary: DBS and OCBC have maintained a "hold" rating on City Developments (CDL) stock, with DBS upgrading its fair value estimate to S$9.81. The brokers cited strong first-half results and potential contributions from CDL's fund management platform, but tempered their outlook due to subdued buyer sentiment from property cooling measures. CDL's interim dividend increase and plans for asset enhancement and repositioning efforts are seen as positive signs, but the group's residential sector is expected to be weak in the short term.

site_title: HNA gives up bid to build hotel empire with Radisson sale
summary: China's HNA Group Co sold its Radisson hotel chain to Jin Jiang International Holding Co, a Shanghai government-controlled company, in a deal reportedly worth at least $2 billion. HNA, which once owned stakes in Hilton, Rezidor, and Carlson hotels, has been rapidly unloading its assets amid a broader retreat from corporate debt. The sale marks the end of HNA's global hotel empire, with the company still operating hotels under the Tang and Tangla brands mainly in China. The deal will make Jin Jiang the seventh-largest hotel company in the world.

images.alt_text: Up until last year, China's HNA Group Co was one of the hottest names in the global hospitality industry. What began in 2013 with an investment into Spain's NH Hotel Group SA soon spread to top shareholdings in the companies behind Hilton, Rezidor and Carlson hotels.

site_title: Noble to hold special general meeting on Aug 27 to approve restructuring plan
summary: NOBLE Group has announced a special general meeting on August 27 to approve its proposed restructuring plan, which has received support from key stakeholders including its largest shareholder, Noble Holdings, and a consortium of investors. Over 86% of existing note creditors and lenders have also agreed to the plan. The company's chairman, Paul Brough, believes the plan is the best deal for all parties and will enable Noble to operate with a sustainable capital structure, capitalizing on opportunities in the Asian commodities markets.

site_title: Jho Low asks US to explain Malaysian thanks for seized yacht
summary: Lawyers for Jho Low, a Malaysian financier, have asked the US Justice Department to clarify whether US agencies or officials were involved in transferring the $250 million yacht "Equanimity" to Malaysia. The yacht was seized by the US, but arrived in Malaysia on August 7, sparking confusion. The Malaysian Attorney General attributed the transfer to "sensitive and delicate negotiations" between Indonesia, Malaysia, and the US. The US had claimed the yacht as part of its assets seized from Low, but now faces questions about its role in the transfer.

site_title: Nationwide probe after Tokyo med school excludes women
summary: Japan has launched a nationwide probe into gender discrimination at medical universities after a Tokyo medical school admitted altering entrance test results to exclude female applicants. The education ministry has asked 81 medical schools to check their admission procedures for possible discrimination and will investigate the gender ratio of successful applicants. The probe comes after a Tokyo medical school admitted to altering scores to keep women out, with the goal of maintaining a 30% female ratio. The scandal has sparked outrage and prompted Education Minister Yoshimasa Hayashi to urge medical schools to cooperate with the probe.

site_title: Asia shares fall on dim trade outlook; Singapore market down 1.3%
summary: Asia shares fell on Friday due to concerns over renewed US-China trade war friction and lower oil prices, with Singapore's Straits Times Index down 1.3% and other regional markets also experiencing declines. US President Trump's threat to impose higher tariffs on auto imports from Japan weighed on Japan's Nikkei stock index, while Australian shares dipped 0.3% amid unchanged growth forecasts. Global trade tensions and oil prices also influenced commodity markets, with US crude oil and Brent crude steady or slightly higher.

site_title: Ryanair row deepens as European pilots strike
summary: Ryanair is bracing for 24-hour strikes by European pilots, affecting 55,000 passengers and 400 flights, as they demand better pay and conditions. The strikes, which started at 3am on Friday, will impact Ryanair's operations across Europe, with Germany being the worst hit. The airline has offered refunds or rerouting options, but pilots claim Ryanair has refused to engage in meaningful dialogue about collective labor agreements. The strikes are the latest in a turbulent summer for Ryanair, which has already suffered disruptions from cockpit and cabin crew strikes.

site_title: 2 in 3 SMEs likely to go cashless by 2023: OCBC poll
summary: Two-thirds of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are likely to go cashless by 2023, according to an OCBC survey of 200 SMEs. Over 45% of respondents plan to adopt cashlessness by 2020, with the goal of Singapore being cheque-free by 2025. The impending launch of PayNow for businesses is seen as integral to meeting these goals, with OCBC receiving an "overwhelming response" from businesses interested in the service.

site_title: Russia, China block US bid to slap North Korea sanctions
summary: Russia and China blocked a US bid to add a Russian bank to a UN sanctions blacklist along with a North Korean official and two entities. The US requested an assets freeze on Agrosoyuz Commercial Bank for allegedly helping North Korea evade UN restrictions. Russia raised doubts about the allegations, while China objected to the proposed sanctions designations. This is the second time in three weeks that Russia and China have objected to a US request to tighten sanctions on North Korea.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ezion, Geo Energy, CDL, Noble, Nera Telecommunications
summary: Ezion Holdings reported a profit of US$86.96 million in the second quarter, reversing a loss in the same period last year, due to fair value adjustments from refinancing. Geo Energy Resources' unit, PT Tanah Bumbu Resources, completed its first shipment of coal worth over US$2 million. No other significant developments were mentioned for the other listed companies.

site_title: Indonesia's Jokowi to partner with cleric in bid for second term
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has chosen Islamic cleric Ma'ruf Amin as his running mate for the 2019 presidential election, a move aimed at countering religious attacks and bolstering his bid for a second term. Amin, 75, is the head of the nation's influential clerics' council and a prominent Muslim figure, providing a "strong shield against identity-politics attacks" against Widodo. The move is seen as a strategic shift to woo conservative Muslim voters and secure a second term for Widodo, who faces a challenge from former general Prabowo Subianto.

site_title: Bank Indonesia intervenes to help rupiah as emerging currencies weaken
summary: Bank Indonesia intervened to support the rupiah currency on Friday, following its decline due to weaker emerging currencies. The rupiah fell 0.4% to its lowest in four days, with plunging Russian and Turkish currencies dragging down investor appetite for emerging market assets. Bank Indonesia's head of monetary management, Nanang Hendarsah, stated that the intervention was "measured" and aimed to balance the market's volatility.

site_title: Asia: Markets on course to end upbeat week with losses
summary: Asian markets ended the week on a negative note, with most markets declining after a positive week, as investors await developments in the China-US trade row. Tokyo fell 0.5%, while Sydney, Singapore, and Seoul dropped 0.1%, 1.3%, and 0.6% respectively. The dollar maintained its strength ahead of the US inflation report, which could guide the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans. The US central bank is expected to lift borrowing costs twice more this year.

site_title: New Zealand to ban single-use plastic bags
summary: New Zealand has outlawed single-use plastic shopping bags, a move aimed at reducing pollution. The ban, announced by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, will phase out the bags over the next year. The country uses "hundreds of millions" of single-use plastic bags annually, many of which harm marine life. Ardern described the ban as a "meaningful step" towards smarter waste management.

site_title: US dollar approaches 13-month high; rouble, Turkish lira downtrodden
summary: The US dollar has reached a 13-month high against a basket of peers, surpassing 95.652, as European currencies like the pound and euro continue to decline. The Russian rouble has dropped to its weakest since 2016 due to US sanctions, and the Turkish lira has hit a record low amid diplomatic tensions with the US.

site_title: China's upside-down money market tests PBOC's role
summary: China's money market has experienced an inversion, with financial institutions now cheaper to borrow from peers than the central bank. This is the first inversion since 2015 and poses a challenge to the PBOC's efforts to establish a policy rate. Low money market rates may help stimulate the economy, but could hinder the central bank's price-based monetary policy framework. The PBOC may keep rates low to encourage corporate bond yields to decline, and prevent systemic risk in the second half of the year.

site_title: Tender for EC site at Anchorvale Crescent launched; strong response expected
summary: The Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme has launched a tender for an executive condominium (EC) site along Anchorvale Crescent, with a minimum price of S$461 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The 1.71-hectare site can be developed into 550 residential units. Market experts expect strong interest from developers due to limited EC supply and favorable market conditions, including a lack of additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) for EC buyers. The tender closes on September 14.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with minor gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with minor gains, inching up 7.43 points to 28,614.73, after four days of gains. However, investors remained cautious due to the ongoing China-US trade war. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index slid 0.11% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.55 points.

site_title: NeraTel bags S$11.8m worth of new contracts
summary: NeraTel, a MAINBOARD-listed telecommunications firm, secured S$11.8 million worth of new contracts for its network infrastructure business segment. The contracts involve providing equipment and maintenance services to a repeat customer in South-east Asia. This win follows the company's provision of a full suite of network and wireless solutions under its NI and wireless infrastructure network business segments.

site_title: Australia's Crown sues to protect casino's Sydney Harbour views
summary: Australia's Crown Resorts filed a lawsuit to protect its Sydney Harbour views from a neighbouring development backed by two of Australia's richest families and a Chinese billionaire. The suit targets the state government for allegedly failing to enforce zoning regulations. The dispute revolves over the six-hectare former stevedoring site next to Crown's casino, which could impact the company's views of the harbour. The case sets the stage for a fight over the prized harbour views in Sydney.

images.alt_text: Cranes can be seen on a construction site at the inner-city suburb of Barangaroo, the site of Australian casino operator Crown Resorts' new Sydney waterfront resort. On the left is the Sydney Opera House located on Sydney Harbour.

site_title: Turkish Airlines bids to buy second Istanbul airport
summary: Turkish Airlines is bidding to acquire a majority stake in Istanbul's second airport, Sabiha Gokcen International Airport, from Malaysia Airports Holdings Bhd. The airline is offering 750 million euros (S$1.18 billion) for an 80% stake. This deal would mark a change in strategy for Malaysia Airports, which has been seeking a partner to buy a minority stake. The move comes after the company expressed interest in selling a minority stake to a partner, with 10 parties expressing interest.

site_title: Wearable Art
summary: Fashion designer Phuay Li Ying has collaborated with Singaporean artist Aaron Gan on a collection of luxurious dresses and capes featuring his paintings. Six of Gan's works, including birds and fish, were digitally manipulated onto simple garments, creating timeless silhouettes. This collaboration aims to translate Gan's art beyond the canvas, inspiring the brand and taking it to greater heights. The collection showcases the simplicity and elegance of the designs, making them deceivingly complex due to the special digital manipulation required.

site_title: Global Invacom Q2 profit down 76% on slower satellite equipment orders
summary: Global Invacom, a satellite communications equipment provider, reported a 76.4% drop in Q2 net profit to US$0.2 million, down from US$0.9 million last year. Revenue fell 11% to US$26.4 million due to slower orders from key US customers. The company attributed the decline to a technological shift in the industry. Despite this, executive chairman Tony Taylor expressed optimism about the company's innovative products and its position in the market.

site_title: BOE needs more hikes as wage growth may hit 4%, says policymaker McCafferty
summary: The Bank of England's outgoing policymaker Ian McCafferty suggests the central bank needs to raise interest rates again, potentially two hikes in the next 18 months, due to expected wage growth of 4% in 2019, surpassing its current forecast of 3.25%. This comes as labor shortages lead to a shift from skilled to unskilled sectors.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England (BOE) hasn't left it too late to start raising interest rates, even as wage growth may hit 4 per cent next year, according to outgoing policymaker Ian McCafferty.

site_title: Singapore shares open down on Friday; STI down 1.4% to 3,280.88
summary: Singapore shares opened 1.4% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,280.88. Losers outnumbered gainers 80 to 59, with 73 million shares traded worth S$210.2 million. Key performers included Ezion, rising 2.74%, and CapitaLand, down 1.21%. The decline follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday as investors remained optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: HRNetGroup Q2 profit jumps 78% to S$13m
summary: HRNetGroup, a mainboard-listed recruitment firm, reported a 78% increase in Q2 net profit to S$13 million, up from S$7.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 10.8% to S$108 million, driven by strong performance in professional recruitment in North Asia and Singapore. Earnings per share increased to 1.29 Singapore cents, while no dividends were declared. The increase in net profit was attributed to the implementation of the 88GLOW Plan in June 2017.

site_title: Qualcomm settles with Taiwan antitrust regulator for NT$2.73b
summary: Qualcomm has settled an antitrust case in Taiwan by paying NT$2.73 billion (S$121.6 million) to the Fair Trade Commission. The settlement also requires Qualcomm to bargain in good faith with other chip and phone makers in patent-licensing deals. This follows a 2017 fine of US$778 million for refusing to sell chips to mobile handset makers and cutting Apple a royalty discount for exclusive modem chip use. The agreement aims to promote fair competition in the Taiwanese market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as US-Japan trade talks continue
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday as investors awaited the outcome of US-Japan trade talks. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.17% to 22,559.40, while the Topix index fell 0.22% to 1,736.34. The move was despite solid Japan growth data.

site_title: Vard S$0.25 exit offer is final: Fincantieri
summary: Fincantieri Oil & Gas has confirmed its S$0.25 per share exit offer for Vard Holdings is final, with no price increase. The offeror will extend the closing date to Aug 24, and trading in Vard shares will be suspended immediately after. The shareholders, who have accepted the offer, are not required to take any action. The delisting is estimated to occur two to three weeks after the exit offer closes, following earlier shareholder approval.

site_title: Tesla board seeking more information from Elon Musk on who's funding buyout plan: sources
summary: Tesla's board is seeking more information from CEO Elon Musk on his proposed $72 billion take-private deal, as they have not received a detailed financing plan. The board is also considering hiring financial advisers and is expected to make a decision on whether to launch a formal review of the proposal in the coming days. Musk's plan to keep his ownership at around 20% and use a special purpose vehicle to allow shareholders to remain invested has raised skepticism among investment bankers and analysts. The deal faces logistical and legal challenges, particularly for buying out smaller shareholders.

site_title: Japan economy rebounds after first dip in 2 years
summary: Japan's economy rebounded with a 0.5% quarter-on-quarter growth in the April-June period, its first growth in two years, beating analyst expectations. The rebound was partly due to robust corporate activities, but US-led trade wars pose a major risk factor for the economy. Analysts warn that US tariffs on vehicles could cost Japan's auto industry up to $10 billion, potentially undermining Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies aimed at securing his premiership. Consumer spending remains lacklustre, and other risks include record downpours and a deadly heatwave.

site_title: Death of Margot Kidder, Lois Lane of 'Superman' fame, ruled suicide
summary: Margot Kidder, the actress known for her role as Lois Lane in the 'Superman' movies, has been ruled to have died by suicide. The 69-year-old died in May, with her family urging those struggling with mental health issues to seek help. Her death comes after a global spike in suicides, including that of Kate Spade and Anthony Bourdain, just one month prior. Kidder, who struggled with bipolar disorder, became an activist for mental health issues and a champion of left-wing causes after her career peaked in the 1970s and 1980s.

site_title: Melania Trump's parents become US citizens, using 'chain migration' Trump hates
summary: Melania Trump's parents, Viktor and Amalija Knavs, became US citizens through "chain migration", a process Trump has repeatedly denounced. Melania sponsored their green cards, and they applied for citizenship after meeting the five-year requirement. The ceremony was private due to security concerns, and the couple recited the Pledge of Allegiance. The news highlights a contrast between Trump's anti-immigration stance and his own family's immigration history, with Melania born to Slovenian parents who obtained residency through a similar program.

site_title: French court orders Twitter to change smallprint after privacy case
summary: A Paris court ordered Twitter to change its smallprint after a consumer group, UFC-Que Choisir, accused the platform of having "abusive" clauses in its terms and conditions. The court ruled that users' photos and tweets can no longer be "commercially exploited" without consent. Twitter was fined 30,000 euros, a decision seen as a significant victory for user privacy. The ruling is expected to have implications for similar cases against Facebook and Google, which are also in progress.

site_title: Ghana replaces sacked energy chief in reshuffle of huge cabinet
summary: Ghana's President Nana Akufo-Addo replaced Energy Minister Boakye Agyarko, who was sacked due to dissatisfaction with the handling of a power plant deal with the UAE. In the reshuffle, Agyarko was replaced by John Peter Amewu, while Kwaku Asomah-Cheremeh took over lands and natural resources and Kofi Adda became aviation minister. The move comes as critics argue that Ghana's bloated cabinet is a drain on the public purse, despite being one of the region's most dynamic economies.

site_title: A lot has changed since Uber beat back a cap on vehicles
summary: New York City has become the first major American city to cap the number of for-hire vehicles, with a one-year limit to study the impact on the city. The move follows a frontal assault by Uber against a proposed cap three years ago, but this time, the city's leaders were able to secure a 39-6 vote. The cap aims to address issues such as surge pricing, empty vehicles on the road, and taxi driver suicides, which have risen in recent years. Mayor Bill de Blasio declared victory, saying the city's drivers won, after a shift in public opinion and market forces, with Uber facing increasing criticism over its business practices.

site_title: Samsung unveils newest smartphone hoping for sales boost
summary: Samsung unveiled the Galaxy Note 9 smartphone, aiming to boost sales after a 22% drop in mobile technology sales in the second quarter. The phone features improved power, memory capacity, and battery life, with a starting price of $1,000 for the 128GB model and $1,125 for the 512GB version. Analysts describe the upgrades as "iterative" and not radically new, but the phone's premium features may appeal to those looking for a high-end Android device. The company also introduced a smart speaker and watch, and announced partnerships with streaming music service Spotify and gaming platform Fortnite.

site_title: Europe: FTSE drops on big ex-dividend day; TUI down after update
summary: Britain's top share index fell 0.5% on Thursday as heavyweight stocks went ex-dividend, with travel operator TUI down 9.7% after disappointing quarterly results. Earnings drove the day, with oil majors BP and Shell falling 2.1% and 1.7%, respectively. The FTSE 100 recovered from morning falls, and analysts raised their estimates, citing resilience to Brexit fears.

site_title: Geo Energy completes first coal shipment from TBR mine to China steelmaker Tsingshan
summary: Geo Energy Resources' unit PT Tanah Bumbu Resources (TBR) completed its first coal shipment of 50,000 tonnes worth over US$2 million to Chinese steelmaker Tsingshan. The shipment fulfills Indonesia's domestic market obligation requirement, set at 25% of planned production. The shipment came from TBR's total production of around 88,000 tonnes as of July 31, 2018. This marks the start of a partnership between Geo Energy and Tsingshan, with plans to ramp up coal production and reach a target of 11-12 million tonnes in 2018.

site_title: Artisanal Finds
summary: Three artisanal food retailers in Singapore cater to the growing demand for unique products. Nosalj Vadim's Bublik Singapore brings in high-quality dairy products and seafood from Eastern European countries, while The Cheese Ark offers rare artisanal cheeses from Europe. ShiokFarm, founded by French expat Claire Chabrieres, sells fresh organic fruits and vegetables sourced from local farms, and plans to expand its product line to include artisanal goods. Artisans Selections, a specialty e-store, imports exclusive products from South Australia, including limited-batch spirits and craft beer.

site_title: Drive to curb salt intake should focus on China: study
summary: A study published in The Lancet found that high salt intake, particularly above 12.5 grams per day, is linked to increased blood pressure and stroke risk. However, moderate salt intake, below 12.5 grams, may have a beneficial role in cardiovascular health. The study, which analyzed data from over 90,000 people in 18 countries, suggests that countries with high average sodium intake, such as China, should be targeted for reduction. The World Health Organization recommends a daily salt intake of 5 grams, but this target is not commonly met.

site_title: The Age of Malware
summary: The article "The Age of Malware" is not provided, however, based on the provided text it appears that the article is discussing the growing threat of malware and its potential impact on technology and society. Unfortunately, no information is provided to summarize.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sued by ex-managing director who said he was whistleblower
summary: Goldman Sachs was sued by former managing director Christopher Rollins, who claims the bank retaliated against him after he complained about its dealings with a European businessman. Rollins, now CEO of BTIG Ltd, seeks at least $50 million in damages and alleges Goldman defamed him. The bank discharged Rollins after he reported suspicious trades, and Rollins claims Goldman "scapegoated" him. The case centers on alleged violations of the federal Dodd-Frank law and anti-money laundering controls.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc was sued on Thursday by a former managing director who said the Wall Street bank retaliated against him and fired him after he complained about its dealings with an unidentified, "notorious European businessman."

site_title: US labour market tightening; inflation steadily rising
summary: The US labor market is tightening, with initial claims for unemployment benefits falling 6,000 to 213,000 in the week ended August 4. The strong economy and rising inflation are likely to keep the Federal Reserve on track to raise interest rates in September for the third time this year. Despite trade tensions, the labor market appears to be weathering the impact, with 157,000 jobs created in July and a 4.1% annualized growth rate in the second quarter.

site_title: Central banks push aside inflation doubts as they eye the exit
summary: Major central banks, including the Bank of England, European Central Bank, and Bank of Japan, are taking steps to exit their easy money policies despite uncertain inflation outlooks. The Bank of England raised interest rates last week, while the European Central Bank is ending bond purchases and preparing for a possible rate hike next year. In contrast, the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Canada are facing stronger economic conditions. Central banks aim to remove emergency policy settings, which have dominated the last decade, to promote solid global growth and inflation.

site_title: Iraqi cleric Sadr wins vote recount: electoral commission
summary: Iraqi cleric Moqtada Sadr's alliance won Iraq's legislative election in May according to a manual recount, retaining all 54 seats. The Conquest Alliance, a pro-Iranian group, will gain an extra seat at the expense of a local list. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi's bloc remains in third with 42 seats. A new government must be formed within 15 days, following the official announcement of final results, which will also see Sadr form a coalition with other groups. The May election saw a record low turnout of 44.5%.

images.alt_text: Nationalist Shi'ite cleric Moqtada Sadr's alliance won Iraq's legislative election in May according to a manual recount, the electoral commission said Friday, paving the way for a government to be formed nearly three months after the polls.

site_title: Singapore's openness made it easy to adapt
summary: Singapore's openness and efficiency have made it an attractive destination for individuals and businesses, according to Cisco Asean president Naveen Menon. The country's unique culture and strong community spirit have enabled him to integrate and thrive, accelerating his career. Menon praises Singapore's open communication channels, access to government decision-makers, and world-class infrastructure, but notes that the country needs to focus on product innovation and creativity to truly thrive, and provide pathways to happiness amidst the intense pace of life.

site_title: Peranakan Fascination
summary: Photographer Valley Arora captures Singapore's old world charm by photographing everyday items, focusing on shophouses and Peranakan tiles. She finds inspiration in the city's cultural enclaves and iconic landmarks. Arora incorporates traditional Peranakan colors into her designs, reflecting her love for the city. Her work showcases the contrast between vibrant civic districts and preserved cultural areas, highlighting Singapore's unique heritage.

site_title: Football Vs Fashion
summary: Paris Saint-Germain unveiled its 2018-2019 away kit at a high-end fashion retail store, Dover Street Market, rather than a stadium, highlighting the French team's serious approach to fashion. This was part of a promotional campaign that also included PSG memorabilia like T-shirts and pins. The move showcases the intersection of football and fashion, with PSG seeking to engage with a different audience through a unique marketing strategy.

site_title: Crossover Sensation
summary: Clean Bandit, a Grammy-winning classical/electronic pop band, was forced to cancel a Singapore gig due to its drummer, Luke Patterson, contracting chicken pox. The band has since recovered and will perform at the Star Theatre on August 15. Formed 10 years ago at Cambridge University, Clean Bandit achieved mainstream success with hits like "Rockabye," "Symphony," and "Rather Be," selling over 13 million singles and 1.6 million albums worldwide. Tickets for the concert start at S$68.

site_title: Anti-China rhetoric in Washington risks sparking a new Cold War
summary: US officials and lawmakers have shifted their focus from anti-Russia rhetoric to anti-China hysteria, with some warning of a new Cold War. This shift is attributed to US President Donald Trump's trade policies and his administration's claims that China is trying to acquire sensitive American technology and supplant the US as the pre-eminent global military and economic power. Bipartisan support on Capitol Hill has led to increased scrutiny of Chinese corporate deals and exports, raising concerns that the growing economic and military tensions between the two countries could become more explosive and lead to a costly confrontation.

site_title: Tracing Provenance
summary: Origin Grill and Bar, located at the Shangri-La Hotel in Singapore, offers a unique culinary experience focusing on ingredient provenance and sustainable seafood. The restaurant, led by Sydney-born chef Heidi Flanagan, features grass- and grain-fed Angus and wagyu cattle from Australia, Ireland, and Japan. A standout dish is the snow-aged full-blooded sirloin wagyu A4, aged using a centuries-old Japanese technique, which is paired with corn on the cob, roasted vine tomatoes, and a selection of sauces. The restaurant also offers an executive lunch set menu and an extensive wine list.

site_title: Adidas gets World Cup boost despite Nike's dominance on field
summary: ADIDAS AG reported a 7.5% surge in shares after beating analyst expectations with second-quarter revenue and profit. The company attributed the boost to record sales of football merchandise, particularly jerseys, despite its sponsored teams losing in the World Cup. Sales growth was also driven by the US and Asian markets, offsetting the impact of tariffs. Adidas' strong performance in the quarter demonstrates its resilience in the face of Nike's dominance on the field.

site_title: Canada asks for help in Saudi dispute
summary: Canada is seeking help from allies, including Germany and Sweden, to resolve its dispute with Saudi Arabia over human rights abuses. Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland has spoken with counterparts in these nations to understand how they resolved similar disputes in the past. Canada has also planned to reach out to the UAE and Britain, while women's rights advocates urge the international community to call for the release of detained women activists in Saudi Arabia. Tensions escalated after Saudi Arabia expelled Canada's ambassador and froze trade and investments in response to Ottawa's criticism.

images.alt_text: The senior official, who asked not to be identified due to the sensitivity of the diplomacy, said Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland had spoken with her counterparts in the two European nations.

site_title: 'Time has come' to create US Space Force, sixth military branch: Pence
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence unveiled plans to create a US Space Force, the country's sixth military branch, with the goal of countering Russia and China's growing presence in space. The proposal, ordered by President Donald Trump, aims to establish a new organizational body, US Space Command, and invest $8 billion in space security systems by 2025. However, the creation of the Space Force is not a done deal, with some lawmakers and defense officials expressing skepticism over the cost and added bureaucracy. Pence hopes to have the Space Force operational by 2020, at the end of Trump's term.

site_title: Oil slips as trade worries weigh on market
summary: Crude oil prices slipped on Thursday, falling 21 cents to $72.07 a barrel for Brent crude and 13 cents to $66.81 a barrel for US crude. The decline follows the previous session's losses due to the escalating China-US trade dispute, which casts doubt on oil demand. The US data showed a smaller-than-expected weekly draw in crude inventories and a surprise build in petrol supplies. The market is concerned about the impact of the trade tensions on global oil demand.

site_title: Oscars to add new 'popular film' category
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has announced it will add a new "popular film" category to the Oscars, set to debut at the 2020 ceremony.
