These programmes, which have been a feature of the private banking landscape for over a decade, offer a range of sessions on entrepreneurship, portfolio management, philanthropy, and sustainable investing, among others. With Asia-Pacific poised for the largest wealth transfer between generations, banks are recognizing the importance of these programmes, which have seen an increase in frequency and diversity of events in recent years.

site_title: Turkish delight off the table but this shouldn't ruffle Sats' feathers
summary: Sats has cancelled a memorandum of agreement with Turkish Airlines to provide in-flight catering at Istanbul New Airport, set to open in October. The move does not appear to affect the airline's plans, as analysts consider it a minor setback. Istanbul New Airport is expected to handle over 200 million passengers annually and is touted as the world's largest. The cancellation is seen as a business decision rather than a significant development.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q2 profit up 0.8% at S$16.9m
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 0.8% increase in net profit to S$16.9 million for its second quarter, driven by a 5.4% revenue growth from its healthcare services division. Revenue from its hospital services division decreased 2.3%. The company also successfully implemented its e-Commerce service and began refurbishment works for outpatient clinics and inpatient wards. RafflesHealthlnsurance obtained regulatory approvals to enter the Integrated Shield market and plans to open its hospitals in Chongqing and Shanghai.

site_title: MindChamps posts 83% jump in Q2 profit
summary: MindChamps PreSchool reported an 83% year-on-year jump in net profit to S$1.26 million for the second quarter, driven by growing student numbers and global franchises. Revenue rose 60% to S$7.65 million, with higher franchise income and the acquisition of seven preschool centres in Australia and Singapore. The group now has 13 company-owned and 51 franchisee-owned centres.

site_title: SingHealth attack was by APT group typically linked to foreign governments: Iswaran
summary: A cyber attack on SingHealth in Singapore, resulting in the leak of 1.5 million patients' personal data, was attributed to an "advanced persistent threat" group typically linked to foreign governments, according to Parliament. The attack was described as a "stealthy and continuous computer-hacking process" aimed at gaining intelligence or stealing information.

site_title: The promise of liberal identity politics
summary: Identity politics has become a central aspect of liberal politics in the US, with many arguing it contributed to Donald Trump's 2016 election. However, critics claim it can lead to fragmentation and polarisation, while also diverting attention from economic injustices. Research suggests that identity can improve representativeness in democracy, but it can also be manipulated for political gain by populists. To counter this, liberal democrats are promoting a broader common identity based on liberal values, which can foster economic prosperity and pluralism.

site_title: Progress in corporate governance, but challenges lie ahead
summary: The Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) has reported remarkable progress in corporate governance, with the average overall score for companies reaching an all-time high of 56.3. However, challenges lie ahead, particularly in stakeholder engagement, which scored only 38% in the general category. Director tenure and board independence are critical concerns, with companies tending to have longer-serving directors when an independence definition is not made. Notably, companies with independent chairmen have a higher proportion of independent directors, and stakeholder engagement scores increase with higher independent director proportions. To address these challenges, companies must prioritize director tenure and board independence to improve stakeholder engagement.

site_title: China's stocks and yuan slide as US-China trade war heats up
summary: China's stocks and yuan slid 1.3% on Monday as tensions with the US intensified in the trade war. The Shanghai Composite index and CSI300 index closed lower, while the yuan weakened despite efforts by the central bank to stabilize it. The yuan's longest weekly losing streak on record continued, with a 150-pip drop to 6.8438 per US dollar. The US proposed tariffs on $60 billion worth of Chinese imports, prompting Chinese state media to criticize US President Donald Trump. Analysts warn of heavy pressure on China's economic growth amid the trade frictions.

site_title: Making watches pretty with rare handcrafts
summary: Patek Philippe has released a collection of 50 rare handcrafts timepieces, showcasing traditional watch-making techniques such as manual engraving, grand-feu enameling, and gem setting. The collection features intricate designs, including low-relief hand-engraving, miniature painting on enamel, and cloisonne enamelling. Each piece took hundreds of hours to complete, with some requiring up to 230 hours of hand-engraving work. The collection includes pocket watches, wristwatches, and dome table clocks, highlighting the brand's commitment to preserving artisanal skills and traditional watch-making artistry.

site_title: Subaru books worst quarterly profit in five years on US sales slump
summary: Subaru reported its lowest quarterly profit in over five years, with operating profit falling 51.8% to 57.6 billion yen (S$707 million) in April-June due to a 13.9% slump in US sales. The decline was attributed to a delay in the launch of a revamped Forester SUV model. Subaru's global sales dropped 12.3% to 237,900 vehicles, with the US accounting for over 60% of its total sales. The company maintains its forecast for a 21% decline in full-year profit to 300 billion yen.

site_title: UOB celebrates opening of fully-owned subsidiary in Vietnam
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has incorporated its fully-owned subsidiary in Vietnam, marking the first time a Singapore bank has opened a foreign-owned subsidiary bank in the country. The move aims to deepen UOB's presence in Vietnam and support its regional clients and Vietnamese consumers and companies. The subsidiary's opening was celebrated with a gala dinner in Ho Chi Minh City, attended by government officials and UOB representatives. The move is seen as a significant milestone for UOB in Vietnam, with the bank committing to support the country's economic growth.

site_title: Court rules in favour of PACC Offshore
summary: A Singapore court has ruled in favor of PACC Offshore Services, ordering Kensteel Engineering Pte Ltd to return a S$3.8 million deposit made for a failed property purchase. Kensteel had also claimed S$3.3 million in damages and later reduced the claim to S$2.219 million. The ruling also discontinues Kensteel's action against PACC Offshore, with an undertaking not to bring future claims. PACC Offshore will take steps to enforce the judgment, including obtaining a court order against Kensteel, which is in liquidation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Noble Group has agreed to increase the issuance of new trading holding company bonds from $280 million to $300 million after further engagement with creditors. This move is part of the company's financial restructuring, with a circular to shareholders and a special general meeting notice to be sent out shortly.

site_title: US dollar extends two-week winning streak
summary: The US dollar extended its two-week winning streak, rising a third of a percent to 95.451 against a broad basket of currencies. This move puts the dollar within striking distance of its one-year peak of 95.652 reached on July 19. Investors are betting that trade war rhetoric and a strong US economy will continue to drive the currency higher.

site_title: Developer China Evergrande expects H1 core profit to more than double
summary: China Evergrande Group expects its first-half core profit to more than double from last year due to lower expenses and increased property deliveries. The company anticipates a 125% rise in after-tax net profit during the period. This growth is attributed to the reduction of costs and the expansion of its property portfolio.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower amid new tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to the first half. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks have rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Bringing local flavours to potato chips
summary: A Singaporean couple, Lee Yue Jer and Kee Vern Cheng, founded F.East, a potato chip brand that brings Asian flavors to the market. The company launched with laksa and chicken rice flavors, which received strong media attention and consumer demand. Despite limited marketing budget, the company scaled up quickly, with its products now available in local retailers and online. F.East aims to celebrate Singapore's culinary delights and offer a taste of home to Singaporeans overseas. The company plans to expand its repertoire of flavors soon, but no specific timeline was announced.

site_title: A finger on the pulse for biometric security solutions
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are considering biometric security solutions to stay ahead of modern threats. Biometric systems offer superior accuracy, accountability, and convenience. However, SMEs must consider factors such as population size, system placement, and accuracy levels when choosing a biometric security system. The Singaporean government has also implemented 2-Factor Authentication for all banks, highlighting the growing adoption of biometric solutions in the country. As technology advances, biometric solutions are expected to become increasingly integrated with IoT technology, enhancing everyday lives and personalization of services.

site_title: The triumph of downward mobility
summary: A conventional axiom in America is that future generations will live better than their predecessors due to technological advancements and economic growth. However, this idea is being challenged by the increasing downward mobility of the upper-middle class. Companies are getting worse at laying off employees, leading to stagnant job security and reduced living standards for those with advantages. This shift challenges the traditional notion that children of today's upper-middle class will enjoy a better future, instead suggesting a decline in economic opportunities.

site_title: Freehold St Thomas Ville targets bids of more than S$58m in collective sale
summary: The owners of St Thomas Ville, a freehold 12-storey site in District 9, Singapore, are seeking bids over S$58 million in a collective sale. Over 80% of the owners have consented to the sale, with an asking price of S$1,816 per sq ft per plot ratio. The site, zoned "residential" under the URA's 2014 master plan, is within walking distance of Great World City and the Orchard Road shopping district, and has excellent locational attributes that will appeal to small and mid-sized developers.

site_title: Singapore economy and exports expected to grow with CPTPP trade deal: Chan
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 0.2% by 2035 due to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) trade deal. Total exports are also expected to increase by the same percentage. The deal is expected to come into force in 2019, and Singapore companies will have better access to opportunities in CPTPP markets, including Mexico and Canada. The agreement is expected to generate an additional $147 billion in global income and establish a common set of enforceable rules for trade and investment in the 21st century.

site_title: Mission Impossible clings to top spot
summary: Mission Impossible - Fallout held the top spot in North American theatres for a second week, earning an estimated $35 million for the three-day weekend. Disney's Christopher Robin placed second with $25 million, while Lionsgate's The Spy Who Dumped Me took third with $12.4 million. Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again remained in fourth place with $9.1 million, and Sony's The Equalizer 2 rounded out the top five with $8.8 million. Disney's Black Panther has surpassed $700 million in North America since its release in February.

site_title: MOF proposes changes to Stamp Duties Act; amendments provide for stamp duty to be levied on electronic records
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) introduced the Stamp Duties (Amendment) Bill 2018, proposing changes to the Stamp Duties Act, including levying stamp duty on electronic records for transfers of interest in properties and shares. The move aims to safeguard revenue and keep pace with digitalization, while ensuring no change to tax rates or rules for property buyers and sellers. Technical amendments also improve tax policy and administration, including updating provisions for stamp duty relief and corporate restructuring.

site_title: ComfortDelGro launches seat booking app for its private buses
summary: ComfortDelGro Bus has launched an on-demand booking app, "CDGBus OnDemand", allowing commuters to guarantee a seat on private charter buses. The app will first be rolled out for its Tanjong Rhu to Shenton Way premium service, with 50% off fares for the first ride and a refund for every 16th ride booked. The app offers features such as multiple bookings, favourite pickup points, and real-time bus tracking. The move aims to increase convenience and affordability for commuters, following recent acquisitions by ComfortDelGro Bus.

site_title: Finding a real market for VR
summary: Sora Media, a Singapore-based production house, has successfully ventured into virtual reality (VR) content creation, producing one of Asia's first VR mini-series, "Dangerous Jobs". The company, founded by Kelly Lin and Ericson Gangoso, initially explored VR after seeing its potential from big companies like Google, Facebook, and Hulu. Sora Media experimented with VR cameras, creating immersive experiences that allow viewers to focus on specific objects or scenes. The company is now collaborating with educational institutions to develop interactive VR content for children and plans to expand its reach through partnerships with other organizations.

site_title: IWG plummets after abandoning talks with takeover firms
summary: IWG Plc, owner of serviced-office provider Regus, has abandoned talks with private equity firms Starwood Capital Group, TDR Capital, and Terra Firma, citing that none of the interested parties can deliver a transaction at a recommendable price. The company's shares plummeted 25% following the news, which also coincides with a 29% drop in operating profit in the first half of the year. The board remains confident in IWG's long-term value and opportunities.

site_title: Force for good
summary: Wealth transfer is expected to reach $2.4 trillion over the next decade, with the Asia-Pacific region facing the largest challenge. A group of young, successful individuals, including Grace Forrest and Helen Hai, are using their wealth to drive positive change. Forrest's Walk Free Foundation aims to combat modern slavery, while Hai's Made In Africa Initiative promotes industrialization in Africa. Both women emphasize the importance of collaboration, research, and empowering marginalized communities. They argue that traditional development models, which rely on aid and handouts, are ineffective and instead advocate for a more entrepreneurial approach, focusing on job creation and innovation.

site_title: STI up amid mixed trade in Asian market
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 19.61 points to 3,285.34, gaining 0.6% amidst mixed Asian markets. The gains were tempered by concerns over China-US trade tensions, which led to a 1.3% decline in the Shanghai Composite. The Hang Seng and ASX 200 ended in positive territory, while the Kuala Lumpur Composite closed flat. Gaming stalwart Genting Singapore was the biggest loser, falling 8.1%, while electronics firm Venture Corp gained 10.4% on its surprise interim dividend announcement.

site_title: Malaysia shares close flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 0.34 point lower at 1,779.75 on Monday, with 514 losers outnumbering 333 gainers. The index saw 2.1 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion.

site_title: Corporate governance: More bouquets, but also more brickbats
summary: The Singapore Governance & Transparency Index (SGTI) 2018 report shows a mixed picture of corporate governance practices in Singapore. The average overall score for listed companies rose four points to 56.3, but penalty points awarded for poor governance practices also increased. Top-ranked companies, such as SingTel and DBS Group, demonstrated significant improvement in areas like stakeholder engagement and board processes. However, companies still need to improve in areas like CEO remuneration disclosure and investor relations. The report highlights the need for companies to evolve their governance structures to remain relevant in the future economy.

site_title: Alternative forms of giving and investing
summary: Venture philanthropy, a form of giving and investing, is gaining traction among private wealth owners in Asia, particularly among millennials. This approach, initially coined by John D Rockefeller III in 1969, involves investing in social and environmental issues with the potential for financial returns. Unlike traditional philanthropy, venture philanthropy takes calculated risks and aims to generate both social and financial returns. As private wealth in Asia continues to rise, venture philanthropy is becoming a viable alternative to traditional philanthropy, offering a new way for individuals to create positive social and environmental impact.

site_title: OCBC to re-price mortgages for gradual margin lift
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 16% increase in net profit for the second quarter, reaching S$1.21 billion, beating forecasts. The bank's net interest income rose 8% to S$1.45 billion, with a 2 basis point expansion in net interest margin (NIM) to 1.67%. OCBC plans to re-price mortgages in the second half of the year to lift its NIM gradually, focusing on loans with all-in rates below Sibor. The bank's shares rose 2.03% to close at S$11.58.

site_title: OKP's Q2 net profit falls on lower revenue
summary: OKP Holdings' Q2 net profit fell to S$107,000, down from S$4.95 million a year ago, due to a 21% decline in revenue to S$27.35 million. The six-month net profit also dropped 70.5% to S$2.95 million. Despite challenging operating conditions, the company will focus on its core civil engineering business and seek opportunities in property through strategic partnerships. The group's net order book stands at S$208.3 million, with projects extending till 2021.

site_title: BHP boosts nickel mining, exploration investment amid electric vehicle boom
summary: BHP, a global miner, is increasing investment in nickel mining and exploration in Western Australia to secure its own supply of the key material for electric vehicle batteries. The company is building the world's largest battery-grade nickel sulphate plant and boosting output to be "as self-sufficient as possible." BHP's move comes as demand for nickel increases in new battery technologies, reducing the need for expensive cobalt. The company aims to double its nickel sulphate capacity with a potential second-stage expansion and is also developing resources at its Leinster mine and Venus deposit.

site_title: Two warehouse buildings at Gul Crescent put on market for over S$13m
summary: Two warehouse buildings at Gul Crescent in Singapore's Gul Industrial Estate are up for sale by expression of interest for over S$13 million. The 64,495 sq ft property, zoned "Business 2", has a leasehold site of 117,499 sq ft and a balance lease of 22.5 years. The sellers, an import and distribution business, are relocating to optimize their operations.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares ended 0.6% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 19.61 points to 3,285.34. The market saw an average unit price of S$0.63 per share, with 1.87 billion shares changing hands. The field was evenly matched, with 179 gainers and losers each. Notable stocks included Genting Singapore, ThaiBev, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding.

site_title: UK's Theresa May fails to form French connection with Emmanuel Macron
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May met French President Emmanuel Macron for a dinner on Brexit, but no significant progress was made in negotiations. Macron, who wants to avoid a messy Brexit divorce, has taken a hardline stance on the UK's exit from the EU. France's position reflects the complex interests of EU states, including trade, migration, and domestic politics, which vary widely among countries. Spain, another EU country with a strong stance against Brexit, may veto a final deal over Gibraltar, a UK overseas territory. The meeting highlighted the challenges in shaping unified EU stances and negotiating with individual countries.

site_title: An integral piece of the puzzle
summary: The LGT Group, a private bank and asset management firm owned by the Princely House of Liechtenstein, has set sustainability as a core value. The family has been an early adopter of sustainability and has managed roughly $6.2 billion in dedicated sustainable investment solutions. The firm uses a proprietary tool to assess securities' key performance indicators and has introduced a sustainability rating for equities, bonds, and ETFs. LGT also engages in private market efforts, supporting organizations and enterprises to create a long-term positive impact, with over $150 million invested to improve the lives of 5.5 million people.

site_title: Farming impact of Australia's worst drought in living memory
summary: Australia is experiencing its worst drought in living memory, affecting eastern regions with record-low rainfall and above-average temperatures. The drought has left farmers struggling, with some planting seeds in dry soil and others culling cattle and sheep due to unaffordable feed costs. Winter rain has been absent across much of the country, prompting farmers to pray for relief. The impact is expected to continue for several years, with the country's grazing and crop lands severely affected.

site_title: Singapore banks brace for chill from mortgage slowdown
summary: Singapore banks are bracing for a slowdown in the home loan space due to recent property cooling measures, but expect minimal impact on their mortgage books for the rest of 2018. OCBC, DBS, and UOB have reported higher earnings for the second quarter, with DBS citing a 6-7% loan growth forecast, while UOB expects low to mid single-digit percentage growth. The banks also express concerns over macroeconomic tensions and trade conflicts, with OCBC's Samuel Tsien warning of a potential shrinkage in the global economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has amended its listing rules after the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) accepted recommendations to promote corporate governance and director independence. OCBC is exploring a digital bank in Indonesia, while Singtel and CapitaLand Mall Trust topped the Singapore Governance and Transparency Index for the fourth consecutive year. Noble Group increased its new trading holding company bond issuance to US$300m following creditor engagement. The Singapore shares closed 0.6% higher, and the court ruled in favor of PACC Offshore in a failed property purchase case.

site_title: Shophouses in Little India, Chinatown conservation areas launched for sale
summary: Knight Frank is offering three prime conservation shophouses in Little India and Chinatown for sale by expression of interest. The properties include a block of four shophouses in Little India and two shophouses in Chinatown, with guide prices ranging from S$16 million to S$18 million and S$7 to S$7.5 million respectively. The sale is seen as an opportunity for investors and food operators to capitalize on the area's high footfall and demand for well-located businesses.

site_title: US committed to Asean centrality and broadening its partnership with the region
summary: The US reaffirmed its commitment to Asean centrality under its Indo-Pacific strategy, with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo meeting with Asean counterparts to deepen the strategic partnership. US President Donald Trump attended Asean-led summits in Manila last year, and Vice-President Mike Pence also visited the region. Pompeo's comments come as the US navigates trade tensions with Asean nations, with some countries expressing surprise at recent tariff announcements.

site_title: Moratoria over EMAS Offshore, subsidiaries expire
summary: Moratoria over EMAS Offshore and its subsidiaries have expired, following discussions with potential investors and lenders failing to secure a restructuring proposal. The group had sought to withdraw an earlier extension application, which was granted by the High Court of Singapore, and trading of shares has been suspended since March 2018. The moratorium's expiration marks the end of a restructuring process that was initiated to address financial difficulties. No new restructuring proposal has been accepted by investors and lenders.

site_title: Vietnam coffee growers expecting record crop next season
summary: Vietnamese coffee growers are expecting a record crop next season, with production forecasted to reach 1.8 million metric tons, according to a survey of 15 traders and analysts. Favorable weather and replanting of high-yielding varieties in the "coffee capital" of Dak Lak are credited for the expected increase. Local prices remain low, with Le Tien Hung, general director of Simexco Dak Lak, stating that 1.8 million tons is a record high for a Vietnamese coffee crop.

site_title: Nancy Tuckerman, 89, trusted aide of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, dies
summary: Nancy Tuckerman, 89, a longtime friend and trusted aide of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, has died in Salisbury, Connecticut, due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Tuckerman served as the first lady's social secretary for a few months in 1963, helping Kennedy deal with the aftermath of her son's death and the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. She remained a loyal and private spokeswoman for Onassis until her death in 1994, protecting her friend's privacy and reputation. Tuckerman was also a book editor and helped update "The Amy Vanderbilt Complete Book of Etiquette."

images.alt_text: Nancy Tuckerman, a lifelong friend of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis(above) who became her social secretary when she was the first lady and continued to be her spokeswoman until her death in 1994, died Wednesday in Salisbury, Connecticut. She was 89.

site_title: Vietnam's Nghi Son refinery seeks approval for oil product exports:sources
summary: Vietnam's Nghi Son oil refinery is seeking approval to export oil products due to high inventories and limited domestic fuel demand. The refinery, which produces over 50% of its capacity, has contributed to high fuel inventories, and local traders and consumers are unable to absorb all of its products. If approved, this would be the first time Vietnam allows domestic oil product exports, which could weigh on regional margins amid new projects in Malaysia and China.

site_title: Billionaires are sensing the call of the seven seas
summary: French billionaire Francois Pinault's wife, Maryvonne, has joined a growing group of billionaires investing in the luxury cruise industry. The Pinaults acquired Compagnie du Ponant in 2015, and the company now operates six upscale expedition yachts. Billionaires like Richard Branson and Lim Kok Thay, chairman of Genting Group, are also investing in the industry, which has a vast potential market of $126 billion. Despite risks such as fuel price fluctuations and geopolitical events, luxury cruise operators are attracting wealthy entrepreneurs, driven by the industry's favourable economics and the potential for repeat business.

images.alt_text: Mr Branson (left) is spending US$2.55 billion to build three adults-only ships for so-called "rebels with a cause and under Mr Lim, Crystal has undergone a lightning-fast expansion.

site_title: Malaysia tables Bills to reintroduce SST and repeal GST
summary: Malaysia's new government has tabled Bills to repeal the Goods and Services Tax (GST) and re-introduce the Sales and Services Tax (SST), fulfilling its election promise. The GST will be abolished at a date to be determined by the Finance Minister, while the SST rates will be fixed by the Minister, subject to approval by lawmakers. The move aims to reduce the burden on the people, with economists forecasting a dip in inflation but a reduction in tax collection to RM21 billion. The new tax system will be less regressive and have fewer exemptions than the GST.

site_title: SoftBank profit jumps 49% on boost from ARM, Vision Fund gains
summary: SoftBank Group reported a 49% increase in first-quarter profit to 715 billion yen, driven by a 245 billion yen gain from its Vision Fund and a 161 billion yen gain from the sale of ARM's Chinese unit. Revenue rose 4.6% to 880.5 billion yen. The company is shifting focus to investments in overseas technology companies, including the planned initial public offering of its domestic wireless business, which could raise over 2 trillion yen.

site_title: PACC Offshore Services narrows losses in Q2
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings' (POSH) net loss narrowed to US$5.8 million in the second quarter, compared to a year-ago loss of US$11 million. Revenue nearly doubled to US$83.14 million, driven by improved average daily charter rates and utilisation. However, increased general and administrative expenses, as well as higher finance costs, weighed down the bottom line. Loss per share decreased to 0.32 US cents, down from 0.6 US cents previously.

site_title: UOB incorporates fully-owned subsidiary in Vietnam
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has incorporated its fully-owned subsidiary in Vietnam, becoming the first Singapore bank to establish a foreign-owned subsidiary bank in the country. The subsidiary, United Overseas Bank (Vietnam), was incorporated to mark the expansion, with a gala dinner held in Ho Chi Minh City for over 300 guests.

images.alt_text: To mark the launch of the subsidiary, UOB held a gala dinner in Ho Chi Minh City for over 300 guests, including representatives from the State Bank of Vietnam and the Ministry of Planning and Investment, and Singapore's Ambassador to Vietnam.

site_title: Pom-pom girls and kiss cams: badminton gets edgy to win fans
summary: The Badminton World Federation (BWF) is attempting to attract new fans, particularly younger audiences, by incorporating entertainment elements into the sport. This includes using loud music, flashy spotlights, and a "kiss cam" to increase tension and excitement. The BWF aims to present players as stars, rather than just focusing on the court, and has seen growth in popularity, with new sponsors and increased prize money. The organization also has a schools program in 132 countries to get children interested in the sport.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on August 5, 2018 shows dancers performing during the badminton World Championships in Nanjing, Jiangsu province.

site_title: ComfortDelGro launches seat booking app for its private bus charter services
summary: ComfortDelGro's private bus charter service, CDG Bus, has launched a seat booking app called "CDGBus OnDemand". The app guarantees a seat on charter buses and allows for booking up to 24 hours in advance. Commuters can track the bus's status and make multiple bookings. To celebrate the launch, CDG Bus is offering 50% off fares for the first ride and a refund for every 16th ride booked. The app will initially be rolled out for a premium service from Tanjong Rhu to Shenton Way.

site_title: Japan's Subaru books worst quarterly profit in five years on US sales slump
summary: Subaru reported its lowest quarterly profit in over five years, with an 51.8% decline in operating profit to 57.6 billion yen in April-June. The slump was driven by a 13.9% fall in US sales, particularly for its Forester SUV, as customers waited for an updated model. Subaru expects a 21% decline in full-year profit due to a strong domestic currency and higher marketing expenses. The automaker has also been increasing buying incentives in the US to boost sales.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,294.3, up 0.9% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,294.3, up 0.9% on Monday, with 1.08 billion shares worth S$650.3 million changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 165 to 132, led by OCBC Bank's 2.91% gain to S$11.68. Genting Singapore fell 7.32% to S$1.14, while DBS rose 1.23% to S$26.45. The Straits Times Index moved up 28.57 points.

site_title: MindChamps Q2 net profit up 83%
summary: MindChamps PreSchool reported a 83% year-on-year jump in net profit to S$1.26 million for Q2 2018, driven by a 60% increase in revenue to S$7.65 million. The acquisition of seven preschool centres in Australia and Singapore contributed to the growth. Net profit for the six-month period increased 16% to S$1.6 million. MindChamps CEO David Chiem attributed the success to its proprietary curriculum and pedagogy, aiming to prepare children for an unpredictable future.

site_title: Malaysia braces for trade war fallout, cuts 2018 growth projection to 5%
summary: Malaysia's Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng has cut the country's 2018 growth projection to 5% due to potential fallout from a brewing trade war. The nation, heavily reliant on exports, is bracing for global economic slowdown impacts. Lim's forecast is more bearish than most economists' estimates and lower than the central bank's 5.5-6% projection. The government aims to reduce debt and curb spending to meet a fiscal deficit target of 2.8% of GDP, with a balanced budget not expected this year.

site_title: Climate change in Champagne has winemakers prepping for future
summary: Winemakers in Champagne are preparing for climate change, which has altered the region's cool climate and is affecting the acidity and flavor of their famous bubbly. Rising temperatures have caused buds to appear earlier, resulting in spring frosts and warmer nights that encourage new pests and diseases. To combat this, winemakers are experimenting with techniques such as conserving reserve wines, using straw to prevent sunlight from destroying microbial life, and blocking malolactic fermentation. Some are also working on creating new hybrid grape varieties that ripen more slowly in warmer conditions.

site_title: 900 tourists being evacuated from Indonesia quake islands: disaster agency
summary: A powerful quake struck Indonesia's Lombok, killing 91 people and injuring hundreds. National disaster agency officials reported that 900 tourists were being evacuated from the Gili Islands, with 200 already taken off. An additional 700 tourists remain waiting to be evacuated.

site_title: Freehold St Thomas Ville eyes S$58m in collective sale bid
summary: The owners of St Thomas Ville in District 9 are seeking bids of over S$58 million for the collective sale of their freehold 12-storey site, with over 80% of owners consenting to the sale. The 11,407 sq ft site is zoned "residential" with a gross plot ratio of 2.8 and is within walking distance to Great World City and Orchard Road shopping district. The site's excellent locational attributes are expected to appeal to small and mid-sized developers looking for smaller development plots in prime areas.

site_title: Taiwan to hit back at airlines that say island belongs to China
summary: Taiwan is considering retaliatory measures against foreign airlines that have caved to pressure from Beijing to refer to the island as part of China. The transportation ministry is studying options, including banning offending airlines from using boarding bridges and changing takeoff and landing slots. Authorities may also offer incentives to carriers that switch to a more neutral wording for Taiwan. This comes after 44 international airlines have been ordered by Beijing to use the term "China Taiwan" or "China Taiwan region" on their websites. The move is Taiwan's first official response to the pressure.

site_title: For these billionaires, it's all about cruise fleets
summary: French billionaire Francois Pinault's wife, Maryvonne Pinault, has joined the luxury cruise industry with her husband's Marseilles-based cruise line Compagnie du Ponant. The company, which reports annual revenues of $182 million, is part of the Pinault luxury portfolio. Billionaires like Richard Branson and Torstein Hagen are also investing in the industry, with Branson's Virgin Voyages and Hagen's Viking River Cruises expanding their offerings. The market is expanding, with the US cruise industry valued at $126 billion, but risks include swings in consumer demand and fuel prices.

site_title: Carrefour, Tesco alliance to become operational in October
summary: Carrefour and Tesco have announced their global purchasing alliance to become operational in October. The partnership aims to secure better terms from major suppliers, such as Nestle and Unilever, to drive down costs and compete on price. With combined annual sales of $170 billion, the alliance is designed to strengthen the French and British groups' market presence. The move is part of the industry's efforts to reduce costs and improve competitiveness.

site_title: Billionaire clothes makers trade barbs over how to measure customers
summary: Two Japanese clothing giants, Yusaku Maezawa's Start Today Co. and Tadashi Yanai's Fast Retailing Co., are debating the effectiveness of the Zozosuit, a skin-tight bodysuit used to measure clothing size. Maezawa views the Zozosuit as a game-changer, while Yanai calls it a "toy." Start Today Co. has started its own clothing business centered around the Zozosuit, which can be made-to-order. The debate highlights the companies' differing approaches to sizing and fit in the retail industry.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's tariff increase on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Sime Darby Plantations' Salleh named chairman of Malaysia Palm Oil Board
summary: Mohd Bakke Salleh, managing director of Sime Darby Plantations, has been appointed chairman of the Malaysian Palm Oil Board (MPOB) for a two-year term, effective July 31. He replaces Ahmad Hamzah and brings experience as chief executive of Felda Global Ventures Holdings Berhad and Lembaga Tabung Haji. Sime Darby Plantations is the world's largest palm oil company by land size, while FGV is the world's top crude palm oil producer.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian Palm Oil Board (MPOB) said on Monday Sime Darby Plantations' managing director, Mohd Bakke Salleh, has been appointed as chairman of the industry regulator and research body for a two-year term effective July 31.

site_title: Hot Stock: Venture shares up 11% in early session
summary: Venture Corp shares rose 11% in the early session, trading at S$18.70 after announcing a net profit of S$97.9 million for the second quarter, a 40.2% increase from the same period last year. The company also declared a surprise interim dividend of 20 Singapore cents a share. Analysts maintain a "buy" call, with OCBC Investment Research lowering its fair value to S$23.23. Despite strong results, UOB Kay Hian notes that Venture has not addressed key issues, such as production slowdowns.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Monday, following healthy gains across Europe and the US, despite ongoing concerns over the China-US trade row. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.76%, while the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.14%. This contrast suggests investors are focusing on regional economic trends.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday due to fears of a US-China trade war, with investors remaining cautious. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.08% to 22,507.32. The yen's slight appreciation also contributed to the decline. Major Japanese companies such as Toyota, Panasonic, and Sony lost value, with Toyota dropping 1.20% and Panasonic falling 1.36%. The decline was attributed to concerns over US tariffs on Chinese goods and the yen's impact on Japanese exporters' competitiveness.

site_title: London's vast wealth hides struggles of Brexit Britain in limbo
summary: London, a city known for its wealth and glamour, struggles with homelessness and poverty. Despite a record number of employment opportunities and a healthy economy, many individuals, like courier Sean Gibson, are unable to afford basic necessities due to low wages. The UK's Brexit policy has drained the government's focus from addressing pressing issues, including homelessness. The number of people in temporary accommodation has increased by 73% since 2013, and the government's plans to reduce homelessness have been overshadowed by Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Court rules in favour of PACC Offshore in claims over failed property purchase
summary: The Singapore court has ruled in favour of PACC Offshore Services, ordering Kensteel Engineering Pte Ltd to return a S$3.8 million deposit made for a failed property purchase. Kensteel had initially sought to keep the deposit and claimed an additional S$2.219 million in damages. The court also discontinued Kensteel's action against PACC Offshore. PACC Offshore will seek to enforce the judgment, with costs to be determined later, and will take steps to recover the deposit and interest.

site_title: Patten hits back at Beijing over Hong Kong press club row
summary: Former British governor of Hong Kong Chris Patten criticized Beijing for urging the Foreign Correspondents' Club to cancel a speech by independence activist Andy Chan, calling it "quite simply wrong." Patten defended Hong Kong's freedom of speech, protected by the 1997 handover agreement, and criticized Beijing's interference in the city's internal affairs. The club has refused to cancel the event, which is part of a traditional "club lunch" tradition, amid growing concerns that Beijing is eroding Hong Kong's liberties and local autonomy.

site_title: Jokowi's growth goal for Indonesia elusive as GDP rises 5.3 per cent
summary: Indonesia's GDP rose 5.3% in the second quarter, beating the 5.1% median estimate, but still short of President Joko Widodo's 7% goal. The economy's growth is seen as unlikely to take off, with economists citing a weakened currency, interest-rate hikes, and a widening current-account gap as drag factors. With presidential and parliamentary elections approaching, Widodo faces pressure to stimulate the economy and counter charges of economic mismanagement. The central bank has increased its benchmark rate to stabilize the currency, but its effects on growth are uncertain.

images.alt_text: The Indonesian economy is offering little cheer for President Joko Widodo as he gears up to run for a second term.

site_title: Gold may hit US$1,300 by end of year, ICBC says
summary: ICBC Standard Bank Plc predicts gold prices will rise to US$1,300 by December, driven by interest rate hikes and increasing physical demand. Gold averaged US$1,260 an ounce in the third quarter and is expected to continue climbing. The bank attributes the forecast to two potential US interest rate hikes this year, which are already partially priced into the market. This follows a recent decline in gold prices, partly due to a strong US economy and a strengthened dollar.

site_title: Australia's Fortescue Metals cuts stake in Atlas Iron
summary: Fortescue Metals Group reduced its stake in Atlas Iron by 8.53% or A$33.2 million, following Atlas's endorsement of a A$390 million offer from Hancock Prospecting. Fortescue aims to access capacity at Port Headland in Pilbara, while Hancock seeks Atlas's rights at the port. The company's CEO stated that Fortescue will participate in an industry consultation regarding berth access at Port Hedland. Shares of both companies rose following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore firms urged to see innovation and internationalisation as a single process
summary: Singapore firms are encouraged to view innovation and internationalization as a single process, according to ESG chairman Peter Ong. He emphasizes that innovation and internationalization are mutually reinforcing pillars, suggesting that firms should consider them as part of a single conversation. This approach is seen as beneficial for local companies, especially following the merger of two government agencies into Enterprise Singapore in April.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.29 points to 1,781.38 on Monday, with 73 million lots traded worth RM27.75 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 121 to 61.

site_title: 'Too little too late': bankruptcy booms among older Americans
summary: A growing number of older Americans are filing for bankruptcy, with the rate tripling since 1991. The shift in financial risk from government and employers to individuals is driving the surge, as traditional pension plans are replaced with 401(k) savings plans and medical expenses increase. Many older Americans struggle to make ends meet, with limited access to adequate resources, leading them to seek bankruptcy protection. The study found that older people are more likely to file for bankruptcy, with 12.2% of filers now 65 or older, and the average age of filers rising.

site_title: North Korean state media urges US to drop sanctions
summary: North Korean state media is urging the US to drop sanctions, citing Pyongyang's goodwill gestures such as ending nuclear testing and returning US soldier remains. Despite these moves, the US has maintained tough sanctions, prompting Pyongyang to accuse Washington of "acting opposite" its plan to improve ties. The US has insisted on denuclearization before easing sanctions, fueling Pyongyang's frustration over the slow-moving nuclear negotiations. North Korean propaganda outlets have called the sanctions "anachronistic" and a hurdle for better relations, while a South Korean spokesman urged North Korea to speed up denuclearization and the US to show a sincere attitude.

site_title: Why Prada can charge US$1,700 for bananas on your shirt
summary: Prada's bowling shirt, featuring a garish flame motif and banana print, costs $1,200 and has gained popularity among fashion enthusiasts. The brand's return to growth is attributed to its efforts to reinforce its unique brand identity, including reissuing iconic products and increasing spending on social media. The Prada banana motif, first introduced in 2011, has become a legendary symbol of the brand, and its recent relaunch has contributed to the brand's resurgence, with shares rising nearly 40% over the past 12 months.

site_title: OCBC mulls 'digital bank' in Indonesia
summary: OCBC is exploring the concept of a "digital bank" in Indonesia, following UOB's announcement of a similar digital bank in the Asean region. The digital bank is expected to be operated at a cost-to-income ratio of 35% and target three to five million customers in the next five years. OCBC's CEO, Samuel Tsien, declined to share more details, but noted that the digital bank may not be a standalone unit. This move comes after DBS launched a successful digital bank in India and Indonesia.

site_title: Hong Kong defies market slump with biggest-ever summer IPO haul
summary: Hong Kong's summer IPO season is its largest on record, defying a market slump. Since June, companies have raised $19.2 billion in initial public offerings, surpassing the 2010 record of $13.4 billion. The surge is attributed to changes in Hong Kong's IPO rules, which have allowed tech companies with weighted voting rights and unprofitable biotech firms to list. Despite a 16% decline in the Hang Seng Index, companies are still pursuing stock sales, with Meituan Dianping and several biotech firms planning listings later this year.

site_title: Singapore to release final Q2 GDP data on Aug 13
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) in Singapore will release the Q2 2018 economic survey on August 13, providing the final growth figures for the April to June quarter. The report will include sectoral performance, inflation, employment, and productivity. Advance estimates showed Singapore's economic growth slowed to 3.8% in Q2, the lowest in a year, due to trade risks and a cooling manufacturing sector. This is lower than the 4.3% growth in Q1 2018 and weaker than market forecasts.

site_title: Japan marks 73rd anniversary of atomic attack on Hiroshima
summary: Japan marked the 73rd anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima on August 6, 2018, with a ceremony at the Peace Memorial Park. Hiroshima Mayor Kazumi Matsui warned of rising nationalism threatening peace, urging the abolition of nuclear weapons. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe emphasized Japan's role as a bridge between nuclear and non-nuclear nations, while maintaining its non-nuclear principles. The event highlighted Japan's contradictory relationship with nuclear weapons, with the country relying on the US nuclear umbrella despite opposing atomic weapons.

site_title: Singtel, CapitaLand Mall Trust top corporate governance rankings again
summary: Singtel and CapitaLand Mall Trust topped the Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) rankings for the second and fourth consecutive years, respectively. Singtel secured 129 points, while CapitaLand Mall Trust achieved 128 points. The top 10 companies included DBS Group, CapitaLand, and Singapore Exchange. In the real estate investment trust (Reit) and business trust category, CapitaLand Mall Trust and CapitaLand Commercial Trust took the top two positions. The rankings aim to promote transparency and good corporate governance in Singapore's listed companies.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.45% to 3,280.4
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.45% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index advancing to 3,280.4, driven by gains from local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC. Genting Singapore was the most actively traded counter, down 5.69% to S$1.16. The market followed a similar trend in Tokyo, where stocks opened flat amid US-China trade war fears. The gains mark the fifth consecutive day of rally ahead of GDP data scheduled for release later in the week.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally after US gains, yuan edges up
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday following a strong lead from US stocks, despite fresh trade war threats. The US jobs data showed a slowdown in job creation in July, but a strong pace over the past three months. The yuan edged up after the Chinese central bank supported the currency. Hong Kong led gains, with the week starting on an upbeat note after recent losses.

site_title: APTT posts flat Q2 DPU of 1.625 S cents; warns of lower 2019 DPU
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) reported flat Q2 DPU of 1.625 S cents, unchanged from the year-ago period. Revenue declined 6.6% to S$77.57 million, and Ebitda fell 7.4% to S$46.27 million due to challenging operating conditions in Taiwan. The company expects 2019 DPU to be lower, citing competition in the wireless broadband market. Despite this, the broadband segment showed "reasonable progress" with growing revenue.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise as steelmakers jump
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.37% on Monday, supported by gains in steel stocks amid expectations of higher steel prices due to China's industrial production curbs. Shares of POSCO, Hyundai Steel, and Dongkuk Steel climbed over 3%, 2.25%, and 4.88% respectively. The Korean won gained 0.26% against the dollar, while the US dollar rose 5.48% against the won this year. Foreigners were net buyers of 15.656 million won worth of shares, and the KOSPI index is up 2.95% in the past 30 days.

site_title: UK's House of Fraser settles CVA challenge from landlords
summary: House of Fraser has settled a challenge from landlords regarding its restructuring plan, which includes closing 31 stores. The retailer had filed for a Company Voluntary Arrangement (CVA) to restructure its debt. A group of landlords had filed petitions to Scottish courts against the plan, but the parties have now settled the litigation, removing any risk to ongoing discussions with investors.

site_title: Australian shares start results-heavy week up, materials gain; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to 6,282, driven by iron ore prices and material stocks, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index gained 0.5% to 8,906.08. Mining stocks, including Galaxy Resources and BHP, rose 1.7% and 2.3%, respectively. Australia's largest lender, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, is set to report full-year results on Wednesday, while New Zealand's Synlait Milk Ltd shares fell 1.3% after a2 Milk Company raised its stake.

site_title: Gold extends recovery as dollar steadies
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,214.76 an ounce, extending a rally from a 17-month low, as the US dollar traded steady. The move comes despite a slowdown in US job growth and a proposal by China for $60 billion in retaliatory tariffs. The dollar index also remained steady at 95.243.

site_title: London mansion values start to climb on more realistic prices
summary: London's luxury homes market is showing signs of recovery, with values in top districts rising 1.2% in the second quarter from a year earlier, the fastest annual rate in almost three years. This growth is attributed to buyers taking advantage of price cuts after higher sales taxes and a glut of new houses. Cuts to asking prices of over 30% for period houses in the city center are also contributing to the increase. However, Brexit uncertainty remains a significant barrier to increasing sales activity, with agents expecting a slow market over the next 12 months.

site_title: Oil prices edge up after Saudi output dips, US drilling stalls
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as Saudi crude production dropped in July, reaching 10.29 million barrels per day, and US shale drilling plateaued. US energy companies cut oil rigs for a second time in three weeks, with 859 rigs operating. Markets anticipate US sanctions on Iran, which may impact global oil demand. Brent crude futures rose 5 cents to $73.26 per barrel, while WTI crude futures rose 12 cents to $68.61 per barrel.

site_title: Earnings season slows share buyback momentum
summary: Earnings season is underway, with 70 stocks reporting financials through Aug 2. The Straits Times Index declined 1.3% for the year, matching the regional benchmarks, while the Dow Jones gained 6% in SGD terms. Share buybacks are slowing, and this trend is expected to continue.

site_title: Demi Lovato thankful to be alive after overdose
summary: Pop star Demi Lovato expressed gratitude for being alive after a near-fatal overdose on July 24. In her first remarks since hospitalization, Lovato wrote on Instagram that she has been open about her addiction struggles and acknowledged that the illness doesn't disappear over time. She didn't provide further details, but stated she needed time to recover.

site_title: SGX amends listing rules after MAS accepts corporate governance council's recommendations
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has amended its listing rules to strengthen board independence and diversity, following the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) acceptance of recommendations from the Corporate Governance Council. Key changes include rationalizing tests of independence, lowering the shareholding threshold to 5% and limiting independent director tenure to nine years. The rules also require at least one-third of boards to comprise independent directors and disclose board diversity policies. The changes will come into effect on January 1, 2022, with a two-year transition period for companies to adapt.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Keppel, Raffles Medical, Manulife US Reit, Sasseur Reit
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 16% increase in net profit to S$1.21 billion for the second quarter of 2018, driven by strong loan growth and higher net interest margin. Keppel Corporation entered into a memorandum of understanding with Vicinity Centres to establish a new private fund and acquired a 3.35 hectare plot of land in Chengdu, China. Raffles Medical Group reported nearly flat growth in net profit and revenue, while Manulife US Reit's distribution per unit declined 9.7% due to the enlarged unit base. Sasseur Reit announced a 4.6% higher-than-forecast distribution per unit.

site_title: Sasseur Reit records DPU of 1.587 S cents in maiden earnings
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, announced its maiden earnings, recording a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.587 Singapore cents, 4.6% higher than forecast. The Reit's distributable income to unitholders was S$18.74 million, exceeding expectations. Total sales jumped 40.6% to S$193.3 million, driven by strong sales at its Chongqing Outlet mall. The Reit's manager plans to distribute 100% of distributable income to unitholders until December 2019, subject to regular review.

site_title: Huawei in British spotlight over use of US firm's software
summary: Huawei Technologies is facing increased scrutiny in Britain due to its use of an ageing software component from US firm Wind River Systems. The software, VxWorks, will stop receiving security patches and updates in 2020, leaving British telecoms networks vulnerable to attack. Despite Huawei's denial of security risks, British lawmakers and cybersecurity experts express legitimate concerns over the use of foreign software in critical national infrastructure. The issue highlights the challenges of securing international supply chains and the need for a balance between leveraging foreign technology and ensuring national security.

images.alt_text: Huawei Technologies is facing increased scrutiny in Britain because it is using an ageing software component sold by a firm based in the United States, one of the countries where lawmakers allege its equipment could facilitate Chinese spying, sources told Reuters.

site_title: iPhone chipmaker races to recover after crippling computer virus
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) is recovering from a debilitating computer virus that affected 80% of its fabrication tools, causing delayed shipments and reduced revenue. The incident, which occurred during software installation, spread through the company's network and is estimated to cut third-quarter revenue by 3% and gross margin by 1 percentage point. TSMC's largest customer, Apple, may be affected, potentially slowing the production of new devices, but the company expects to recover by Monday and maintain its 2018 forecast of boosting revenue by high single digits.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q2 profit up 0.8% to S$16.9m
summary: RAFFLES Medical Group reported a 0.8% increase in net profit to S$16.9 million for its second quarter, driven by a 5.4% increase in revenue from its healthcare services division. Revenue from the hospital services division decreased 2.3% due to softer demand from foreign patients. Earnings per share dropped to 0.95 Singapore cent, while the net asset value per share rose to 42.42 Singapore cents. The group declared an interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent, unchanged from the previous year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat as trade war fears weigh
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Monday as investors waited on US-China trade war fears, despite the yen appreciating. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.03% to 22,532.06, while the Topix index gained 0.02% to 1,742.93. The flat opening followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: OCBC's profit climbs 16% for Q2 to S$1.21b, beating estimates
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 16% increase in net profit for Q2 2018 to S$1.21 billion, beating estimates. This surpasses the S$1.12 billion consensus forecast. CEO Samuel Tsien warned of a challenging operating environment due to escalating trade and political tensions. OCBC is the last of Singapore's Big Three banks to report results, with DBS Group Holdings missing market expectations and United Overseas Bank beating estimates.

site_title: Noble to boost new trading holding company bond issuance from US$280m to US$300m
summary: Noble Group has agreed to increase the total issuance of its new trading holding company bonds from US$280 million to US$300 million following further engagement with creditors. The company continues to engage in discussions with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on its restructuring. A circular to shareholders containing further information on the restructuring is expected to be dispatched shortly.

site_title: Saudi Arabia freezes new trade with Canada for urging activists' release
summary: Saudi Arabia has frozen new trade and investment with Canada after the Canadian foreign ministry urged the release of arrested civil rights activists. The Saudi foreign ministry gave the Canadian ambassador 24 hours to leave the country and recalled its own ambassador. The move was in response to Canada's calls for the immediate release of the activists, which Saudi authorities deemed unacceptable. Saudi Arabia will retain its rights to take further action and freeze all new trade and investment transactions with Canada.

site_title: US will 'enforce the sanctions' against Iran: Pompeo
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced that the US will enforce sanctions against Iran, reiterating the country's commitment to "maximum pressure" measures. The sanctions, which began on August 6, target most sectors, including energy, and were prompted by President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the 2015 nuclear pact. Pompeo stated that the sanctions aim to push back against Iranian "malign activity" and expressed support for the Iranian people's desire for a stronger voice in their leadership. The move is seen as a significant escalation in US-Iran tensions.

site_title: Iran eases currency rules, hoping to buoy rial ahead of sanctions
summary: Iran has eased foreign exchange rules in an effort to stabilize the rial currency ahead of US sanctions. The currency has lost half its value since April due to fears of sanctions imposed by President Donald Trump. The move aims to halt a collapse of the rial and address soaring inflation, which has sparked demonstrations against profiteering and corruption.

site_title: Trump admits son met with Russian to get information on opponent
summary: US President Donald Trump admitted that his son met with a Russian lawyer in 2016 "to get information on an opponent," specifically Hillary Clinton, in a meeting at Trump Tower. Trump defended the meeting as "totally legal" and claimed he didn't know about it at the time. The meeting has been scrutinized by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who is investigating potential coordination between the Trump campaign and Russian efforts to sway the 2016 election.

site_title: Strong US earnings buoy stocks, but will optimism last?
summary: US stocks rose slightly last week, driven by strong earnings from Apple, which became the first US company to surpass a $1 trillion market value. The company's premium-priced phones and watches saw strong sales growth, validating expectations from brokerages. However, investors remain cautious about the impact of trade tensions with China on the US economy, with some strategists warning that tariffs could knock as much as 3% off 2019 revenues. Despite this, the bulls are holding down the fort, with annual wage growth holding steady at 2.7%, reducing fears of an economic downturn.

site_title: At least 82 killed by 7.0 quake in Indonesia's Lombok, Bali islands
summary: At least 82 people were killed when a magnitude 7.0 earthquake struck Indonesia's resort island of Lombok, triggering panic among tourists and residents. The quake, which occurred at a depth of 10 km, was felt in neighboring Bali, causing power cuts and minor damage. Aftershocks continued to hit the area, and thousands fled to emergency shelters. The earthquake occurred days after a 6.4 tremor killed 14 people and injured 162 on July 29. The National Disaster Mitigation Agency initially reported 32 deaths, but the toll has since been revised.

site_title: How Apple's posse fared on its rise to a US$1 trillion company
summary: Apple's rise to a $1 trillion company is attributed to its innovative products and partnerships. Hon Hai Precision Industry Co (Foxconn), a key supplier, has been the chief assembler of iPhones and manufactures components, yet its upside from Apple's success has been minimal. Other significant partners include companies connecting iPhones to their networks, but their roles are not as prominent. Apple's success is largely driven by its iconic product, with Hon Hai playing a crucial but relatively underappreciated role in its supply chain.

site_title: The Tre Ver sells over 140 of 200 units in first 3 hours of launch
summary: In Singapore, over 140 units of The Tre Ver condominium were sold in the first three hours of its launch, representing over 70% of the 200 units released in Phase 1.

site_title: Keppel unit to set up A$1b wholesale Australian property fund with Vicinity
summary: Keppel Corporation has entered into a memorandum of understanding with Vicinity Centres to establish a new A$1 billion wholesale Australian property fund. Vicinity will initially inject A$1 billion of retail assets into the fund and provide property and development services. The fund will target stable yields and long-term capital growth, and Keppel Capital Ventures and Vicinity Centres will manage it via a 50-50 joint venture. The proposed fund is Keppel Capital's first retail-focused real estate fund and will expand its track record in Australian real estate investments.

site_title: Edible oil traders use free-trade pact to get around India's import tax hike
summary: Edible oil traders are exploiting India's import tax hike by sourcing palm oil and other cooking oils from neighboring countries under a regional free-trade pact, SAFTA. Traders are designating these supplies as duty-free, disrupting India's trade and undermining efforts to raise local oilseed prices. India raised taxes on refined palm oil to 54% and other oils to 45% to support local farmers. The move has led to a surge in imports from Bangladesh and Sri Lanka, with exports increasing by a third from Malaysia to Bangladesh in July.

site_title: Tesla faces battery of complaints in Norway
summary: Tesla faces criticism in Norway over its after-sales support, with over 26,000 Tesla models registered in the country, but owners experiencing long waits for repairs and difficulty reaching customer services. The company has struggled to match soaring demand, with 38% of owners dissatisfied with after-sales support. Tesla CEO Elon Musk acknowledged the issues and promised to resolve them "quickly" with mobile repair vans, but recruiting and training new employees is a time-consuming process.

site_title: Manulife US Reit posts 9.7% drop in Q2 DPU on enlarged unit base
summary: MANULIFE US Reit reported a 9.7% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.30 US cents for its Q2 2023, largely due to the enlarged unit base from a preferential offering and limited income contribution from recent acquisitions. Normalizing the impact, adjusted DPU rose 5.5% to 1.53 US cents. Net property income increased 59.3% to US$20.4 million, and gross revenue surged 63.4% to US$32.5 million. Distributions will be paid on September 27.

site_title: Navigating the future
summary: Singaporeans share differing opinions on the trait that society should cultivate more of as the country turns 53. Some emphasize the importance of kindness, inclusiveness, and empathy, while others highlight confidence, openness, and adaptability. Others stress the need for honour, gratitude, and a sense of continuity. Many agree that a more gracious and respectful society would lead to a better quality of life for all. Ultimately, a balanced approach that incorporates these traits is seen as crucial for Singapore's continued prosperity and success in the future.

site_title: Brookfield gains lease on Kushner's landmark New York tower
summary: Canada's Brookfield Asset Management acquired a 99-year lease on 666 Fifth Avenue, a New York office tower controlled by the Kushner family, for a reported $600-700 million. The lease allows Brookfield to operate and redevelop the 1.5 million square foot building, which was previously sold to Kushner Companies in 2006 for $1.8 billion. The Kushner family will use the proceeds to pay off debt and buy out its partner, Vornado Realty Trust. The redevelopment plans are expected to capitalize on the building's potential as one of New York's best-known office properties.

site_title: Prada's back to profit, thanks to its ugly chic
summary: Prada has returned to profit after three years of declining sales, thanks to its "ugly chic" aesthetic and reissued iconic products. The brand has increased spending on social media to educate new customers about its unique style, and has seen a significant rise in shares, nearly 40% over the past 12 months. The relaunch of its sports-inspired collection Linea Rossa and the reissue of its most iconic products, including the infamous banana print, have contributed to the turnaround.

images.alt_text: Prada shares have risen nearly 40 per cent over the past 12 months. Growth is expected to accelerate later this year, supported by the relaunch of another iconic line, the sports-inspired Linea Rossa.

site_title: SGD bond issues jump 147% in July, but YTD figure still weak
summary: Singapore's SGD bond market has seen a significant surge in July, with a 147% increase in volume to S$2.8 billion, driven largely by government-linked issuers. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) sold a rare 40-year bond, its fourth this year, while the Housing and Development Board (HDB) also issued a S$700 million five-year bond. Despite this, the year-to-date figure remains weak, with issuance totaling S$11.1 billion, down 23.1% from last year. Market analysts predict continued interest in government-linked bonds, but warn investors to remain cautious in the rising interest rate environment.

site_title: Tariffs working in trade war with China, says Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump defended his use of tariffs in the trade war with China, stating that they are "working far better than anyone ever anticipated" and are making the US "much richer than it is today." He claimed that Chinese stocks are down, weakening their bargaining power, and that European countries are "dying to make a deal." However, experts have predicted that the escalating trade tensions could damage both economies, and the White House and Beijing remain locked in a rapid escalation of trade threats.

site_title: Petrobras posts biggest profit since 2011 as oil rebounds
summary: Petrobras posted its largest profit since 2011, reaching 10.07 billion reais (S$3.7 billion) in the first quarterly results under new CEO Ivan Monteiro. Rising crude prices compensated for sales disruptions during a trucker strike and lower margins on refined products. The company also announced a payment of 0.05 real per share in interest on equity, citing progress in cutting debt, which fell to US$91.7 billion. Petrobras expects to benefit from the exodus of rival importers and has regained dominance in fuel imports in Brazil.
