The group expects a challenging market environment this year, but remains confident in its strategies and capabilities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell in early trade on Friday, August 3, 2018, as traders worried about the brewing China-US trade war. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.22%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.17% and 0.21%, respectively. This marks a negative end to a tough week for Hong Kong shares.

site_title: BMW beats Q2 forecasts as new anti-pollution rules dent rivals
summary: BMW reported a 6% decline in Q2 operating profit to 2.74 billion euros, beating analyst expectations. The company attributed the decline to higher spending on electric and autonomous cars, as well as currency headwinds. Despite new anti-pollution rules and trade tensions affecting rivals, BMW affirmed its 2018 targets and expects capital expenditure to reach an all-time high. CEO Harald Krueger stated the company will continue to offer most of its cars, and BMW sees advantages in its ability to adapt to new regulations, potentially gaining market share.

site_title: Far East Orchard Q2 profit up 44%
summary: Far East Orchard reported a 44% increase in net profit to S$1.55 million for Q2 FY2018, driven by higher earnings from associated companies. Earnings per share rose to 0.37 Singapore cents from 0.26 cents last year. Sales decreased marginally to S$35.8 million due to weak market conditions in Perth and Melbourne, affecting Far East Orchard's hospitality business.

site_title: Paris's Eiffel Tower to reopen Friday after strike: officials
summary: The Eiffel Tower in Paris is set to reopen on Friday after a one-day strike due to a dispute over a new access policy that had caused long queues. The closure was prompted by workers who claimed the policy was unfair and led to increased wait times. No further information about the reopening is available in the provided articles.

site_title: Heineken agrees to sell China operation to CR Beer in US$3.1b deal
summary: Heineken agrees to sell its China operations to CR Beer for US$3.1 billion, injecting its operating assets and taking a 40% stake in the country's largest beer maker. The deal aims to help the Dutch brewer compete with global rivals in emerging markets. Heineken will receive 464 million euros for its 0.9% stake, while CR Beer will acquire three Chinese breweries for HK$2.4 billion. The transactions result in a combined net investment of 1.9 billion euros for Heineken.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge up despite nagging US-China trade worries; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 6,247.3 on Friday, driven by positive sentiment from US technology gains, despite concerns over a potential US-China trade war that could hurt the Australian economy. The heavy materials sector weighed on the advance due to its reliance on China as the country's largest market. Defensive sectors, such as healthcare and mining, contributed to the index's modest gain.

site_title: Perennial Q2 profit halves to S$8.6m with Capitol fully consolidated
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' Q2 net profit halves to S$8.6m, down from S$17.1m a year ago, due to debt and cost consolidation, lower fair value gains, and a one-off gain absence. Revenue grew 1.6% to S$18.1m, while finance costs increased 42.1% to S$20.7m. The company plans to rejuvenate Capitol Singapore, pursue asset sales, and focus on Chinese developments. Net debt to equity ratio rose to 0.74 times, while net asset value per share grew to S$1.704.

site_title: SingPost Q1 profit falls 40.4% on exceptional losses, higher taxes
summary: SingPost's Q1 net profit fell 40.4% to S$18.7 million due to an exceptional S$6 million loss and higher taxes. Revenue rose 3.3% to S$372.6 million, driven by growth in international mail and eCommerce. Operating profit rose 1.2% to S$39.2 million, but underlying net profit declined 9.8% to S$24.7 million. The company declared an interim dividend of 0.5 cent per share. Despite a 2.9% decline in shares, SingPost remains focused on executing well to keep up operational momentum as it transforms for the future.

site_title: UOB sees housing prices falling 5-10% over time; keeps 2018 home loan growth forecast
summary: UOB chief Wee Ee Cheong predicts Singapore housing prices will fall 5-10% over time following recent property cooling measures. Despite this, UOB maintains its 2018 home loan growth forecast of 6-7%. The bank reported a 28% rise in net profit for the second quarter, driven by stronger operating income and loan growth. UOB also announced plans to launch a digital bank in key Southeast Asian markets, aiming to grow a base of 3-5 million customers over five years.

site_title: UOB to launch digital bank in Asean
summary: UOB plans to launch a digital bank in five ASEAN markets, including Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, aiming to have 3-5 million customers in the next five years. The digital bank will operate at a 35% cost-to-income ratio, leveraging in-house technology and fintech partnerships. This follows DBS' successful launches of digibank India and Indonesia, which have attracted over 2 million and 250,000 customers respectively. UOB's CEO, Wee Ee Cheong, sees the digital bank as a key strategy to deepen customer engagement and scale up its customer franchise across Southeast Asia.

site_title: Venezuela loosens grip on currency in bid to ease crisis
summary: Venezuela's government has loosened its grip on currency controls, allowing citizens to make exchange operations in a legal and safe way, as part of a bid to attract foreign investment and ease a four-year recession. The move comes after President Nicolas Maduro admitted his economic model had "failed" and urged his loyalists to find solutions. The decision follows a series of economic crises, including hyperinflation and food shortages, and is seen as a response to the International Monetary Fund's forecast of a one million percent inflation rate this year.

site_title: Europe: Tariff threats and earnings disappointments dent shares
summary: European shares fell 0.8% on Thursday, with Germany's DAX index dropping 1.5% due to concerns over US tariffs on Chinese imports. Industrial group Siemens disappointed with lower-than-expected revenues, but asset manager Amundi impressed with higher profits. The autos sector fell 1%, but BMW outperformed after reporting a smaller-than-expected decline in operating profit. Other companies, including Altice Europe and Hugo Boss, also saw significant declines due to disappointing earnings reports.

site_title: Japan plans sovereign wealth fund to finance US infrastructure: Nikkei
summary: Japan plans to create a sovereign wealth fund to invest in US infrastructure projects, aiming to improve economic relations with the US and utilize excess capital. The fund's size has yet to be determined, with plans to raise money through zero-yield long-term debt. A committee will be formed to discuss the proposal, which also includes converting raised funds into foreign currency once the yen strengthens. The proposal is set to be presented at trade talks between Japan and the US starting August 9.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Sembcorp, Perennial, A-HTrust, OUE C-Reit, Vard
summary: Singapore stocks saw significant developments on Friday, August 3, 2018. United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 28% rise in net profit to S$1.08 billion, exceeding estimates. Sembcorp Industries posted a 46.8% increase in net profit to S$81.9 million, while Perennial Real Estate Holdings' net profit halved to S$8.6 million. Ascendas Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security rose 3.1% to 1.35 Singapore cents, and OUE C-Reit's distribution per unit fell to 1.06 Singapore cents. Vard Holdings' shares are expected to be suspended on August 10 due to an exit offer.

site_title: Dockless bike-sharing startup set to brave Sao Paulo streets
summary: A Sao Paulo startup called Yellow has launched a dockless bike-sharing service, allowing users to rent bikes and leave them anywhere on the street. The startup, owned by the founders of 99, received 50 million reais in initial investment and aims to expand to other Brazilian cities. Yellow plans to have 20,000 bikes by November and 100,000 by next year, with the goal of complementing traditional public transportation, not replacing it. This marks the entry of dockless biking into Brazil's traffic-clogged financial capital, following its success in China and other cities worldwide.

site_title: Ivanka Trump: Family separations a 'low point,' media not the enemy
summary: Ivanka Trump stated that family separations are a "low point" and she is "vehemently against" the policy, aligning with public opinion. She also distanced herself from her father's criticism of the media, saying it's misplaced. The Trump administration's "zero tolerance" policy led to thousands of children being separated from their parents, with 711 still not reunited as of the deadline. Ivanka, a senior advisor to President Trump, expressed her anxiety over the immigration crisis, calling it an "incredibly difficult issue."

site_title: Japan tourists are swapping their guide books for Instagram
summary: Japan is seeing a shift in tourism, with visitors increasingly relying on Instagram to plan their trips. The social media platform has become a key source of inspiration for travelers seeking unique experiences, with many flocking to off-the-beaten-track destinations like Nagato. The town's shrine saw a 36-fold increase in visitors in 2017 after being featured on CNN, and foreign tourists are now using Instagram to discover Japan's hidden gems. This trend is expected to continue with the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, with the number of foreign visitors projected to increase.

site_title: Oil rallies on expectation inventories will drop
summary: Oil prices surged on Thursday, with US crude gaining nearly 2% after a report showed domestic crude stockpiles declining. Industry information provider Genscape reported a 1.1 million-barrel drop in crude inventories at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub. Analysts expect this decline to continue, driven by lower US monthly production figures. Brent crude futures rose 1.5% to $73.45 a barrel, while US crude rose 1.9% to $68.96 a barrel, as traders weighed concerns about oversupply against the potential loss of Iranian crude supplies.

site_title: With spotlight fading, Detroit auto show moves to summer
summary: The Detroit auto show, a long-standing event, will shift from its winter date to a summer date in June starting in 2020. The move breaks a 30-year tradition and comes as major manufacturers have been favoring the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. European auto groups, including Ferrari and Volvo, were absent from this year's Detroit show, while companies like Ford and Mercedes-Benz showcased autonomous technologies at CES. The change aims to capitalize on emerging technologies and increasing competition, with organizers citing "exciting new opportunities" in the warmer summer months.

site_title: China junk bonds' longest winning streak unnerves investors
summary: China's dollar-denominated junk bonds experienced their 13th consecutive day of declines, but yields rebounded over two days to 9.5% on August 2, according to ICE Bank of America Merrill Lynch indices. The rally is under strain as Dongxing Securities warns that China could restart its deleveraging drive, potentially spoiling the market's recovery. Market sentiment has improved, but its sustainability is uncertain, according to Chak Lau, a credit investment manager. The prolonged rally is a concern for investors.

images.alt_text: The return of China's dollar-denominated junk bonds from the brink with the longest rally on record is showing signs of strain.

site_title: US says Russia still carrying out 'pervasive' election meddling
summary: The US government has accused Russia of carrying out a "pervasive" campaign to influence US elections, with Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats stating that Russia is trying to weaken and divide the country. Top officials, including FBI Director Christopher Wray and Homeland Security chief Kirstjen Nielsen, have vowed to investigate and prosecute those involved in the alleged meddling. The comments come despite President Donald Trump's denial of Russia's involvement and his calls for easing sanctions against Moscow.

site_title: Double Happiness
summary: Singapore's "Keeper's Playground of Infinite Happiness" opened at the National Design Centre, featuring over 100 local designers, artists, and craftsmen. The event showcases art installations across five floors and offers workshops, shopping, and food. The exhibition runs until August 5.

site_title: Work And Play
summary: Jabra's Elite 65e headphones and earbuds combine professional-grade Active Noise Cancellation with digital assistant capabilities, making them suitable for both work and play. The three-microphone call technology and soft, lightweight neckband provide optimal voice clarity and comfort. Although the design may resemble a workout accessory, the material makes it barely noticeable. The Elite 65e offers a reliable Bluetooth solution for those seeking a reliable audio experience.

site_title: Factory orders rise for second straight month
summary: US factory orders rose 0.7% in June for the second consecutive month, driven by strong demand for transportation equipment, electrical equipment, and computers. However, business spending plans on equipment were weaker than expected, suggesting a potential slowdown in the third quarter. The increase in factory orders was in line with economists' expectations, with orders rising 8% year-over-year. Rising shortages of workers and import tariffs are putting pressure on the supply chain, with the Trump administration's trade policies contributing to a decline in production in July, according to an Institute for Supply Management survey.

site_title: Singapore-Style Speakers' Corner
summary: Hong Lim Park in Singapore, originally named after Thomas Dunman, has a long history of hosting various activities. It was re-named Hong Lim Green in 1876 and later Hong Lim Park in 1960, featuring a children's playground, fountain, and open-air theatre. In 2000, the government designated it as the only venue for legally-staged public protests, honoring its past as a venue for storytelling and political speeches. The park's history dates back to World War II, with performances of wayang and cricket matches in the past.

site_title: Hi-P is the next tech play to tumble on sliding earnings
summary: Hi-P International's stock dropped 9.45% to S$1.15 on Thursday, following the announcement of lower earnings for its second fiscal quarter. This marks the latest tech stock to fall after AEM Holdings' significant drop. The company's stock hit a low of S$1 as investors rushed for the exits, raising concerns about the tech sector's performance.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit Q2 DPU falls 7.8% to 1.06 cents
summary: OUE Commercial Reit reported a 7.8% drop in second-quarter distribution per unit to 1.06 Singapore cents due to lower gross revenue and higher net finance costs. Gross revenue decreased 2.6% to S$43.1 million, while net property income fell 2.4% to S$33.9 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy remained stable at 95.2%. Higher interest costs from increased borrowings and lower retail revenue from One Raffles Place Shopping Mall contributed to the decline.

site_title: Adopt a framework approach to ensure auditor independence
summary: Auditors in Singapore are shifting towards a framework approach to ensure auditor independence, rather than relying on a rules-based approach. This method uses fundamental principles as a compass to meet various circumstances, providing a more effective way to maintain independence. The upcoming revisions to Singapore's Code of Corporate Governance emphasize the importance of internal audit independence and criticality. By adopting a framework approach, auditors can better address complex independence issues and maintain the quality of audits in capital markets.

site_title: Bettye Does Dylan
summary: Singer-songwriter Bettye LaVette releases a new album of Bob Dylan covers titled Things Have Changed. LaVette's deep, brassy voice transforms Dylan's gritty lyrics into soulful R&B interpretations, bringing new life to both classic and lesser-known songs. The album showcases LaVette's vocal prowess, offering a fresh perspective on Dylan's iconic music.

site_title: A-HTrust's 1Q DPS up 3.1%, lifted by divestment
summary: A-HTrust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) for the first quarter rose 3.1% to 1.35 Singapore cents, driven by divestment proceeds and lower net finance costs. Gross revenue and net property income declined 9.8% and 9.3% respectively, mainly due to reduced contributions from its Australian portfolio. The trust has used divestment proceeds to pare bank borrowings and fund the acquisition of a hotel in South Korea. Despite challenges in some markets, the trust remains confident in Australia's long-term hospitality market prospects.

site_title: US: Tesla gains, US$1t Apple lift Nasdaq
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index up 1.2% to 7,802.69, driven by huge gains in Tesla shares following its earnings report and Apple's market value surpassing $1 trillion. Apple rallied 2.9% and Tesla rose 16.2%. The S&P 500 rose 0.5% to 2,827.22, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped less than 0.1%. Investors are also watching the US employment report on Friday, which is projected to show a gain of 190,000 jobs.

site_title: N Korea warns of natural disaster brought by heat wave
summary: North Korea has warned of a "natural disaster" brought by a record-breaking heat wave, calling for an "all-out battle" to protect crops. Temperatures have topped 40°C in some regions, causing damage to crops like rice and maize. The country's economy, already battered by international sanctions, is at risk of further strain due to the heat wave. The warning comes after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has shifted focus to the economy and held a summit with US President Donald Trump, highlighting the need for institutions to respond to natural disasters.

site_title: Bank of England's Carney warns of rates ending up higher depending on Brexit outcomes
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned that interest rates could end up higher depending on the outcome of Brexit, stating there are many possible outcomes that could lead to higher rates. The BOE raised rates to 0.75% in a post-crisis high, citing uncertainty over Brexit outcomes. Carney emphasized that waiting for perfect certainty is not advisable, as the timing of higher interest rates is uncertain.

site_title: Doll treasures revived in tiny Rome workshop
summary: The Squatriti family in Rome has been running a workshop specializing in antique doll restoration since 1953. The shop, tucked away in a fashionable shopping district, has become a renowned destination for collectors seeking to repair and restore treasured dolls. The workshop is filled with over 100-year-old dolls, puppets, and toy soldiers, with some dolls having eyes pushed inside due to children's tampering. With only a handful of restorers like them left in Italy, the family is aware that their era may come to an end, but they continue to work on extending their business to its maximum potential.

images.alt_text: Federico Squatriti and his mother Gesolmina (above) work at restoring treasured objects.
Antique doll parts piling up in the tiny shopfront of the Squatriti family boutique (above).

site_title: Asean must stay the course on economic integration, innovation: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore emphasized the importance of Asean staying the course on economic integration and innovation, particularly in the face of global trade tensions. He called for the region to utilize technology to deepen cooperation and prepare for the future. Singapore will enhance its support for Asean's less-developed members through upgraded cooperation centers and increased technical assistance. Lee also expressed optimism about the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and the Asean-EU Comprehensive Air Transport Agreement, which he believes will demonstrate Asean's commitment to trade liberalization and economic integration.

site_title: BOJ surprises with offer to buy 400b yen of bonds
summary: The Bank of Japan surprised investors by offering to buy 400 billion yen of five-to-10-year bonds to stem a selloff that saw the 10-year yield reach an 18-month high of 0.145%. The move marks a shift away from the central bank's usual fixed-rate unlimited bond-buying operation, and analysts expect the market to test the 0.2% yield mark, potentially leading to a fixed-rate operation by the BOJ. This has repercussions beyond Japan, with yields in the US and Germany rising.

site_title: Owning a piece of Hollywood
summary: Movie memorabilia from iconic films like Indiana Jones, Back to the Future, and Star Wars will be auctioned off on September 20 in London, with over 600 items valued at more than $4.6 million. The auction features rare items such as Harrison Ford's fedora from The Empire Strikes Back, estimated to fetch up to $1.3 million, and the first-ever auction of the gray jacket worn by Ford in The Empire Strikes Back. The auction will be preceded by a preview exhibition and will be livestreamed, with proceeds from the sale going to the UK charity, the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

site_title: Tesla plans to fund new Chinese car factory with local debt
summary: Tesla plans to fund its new Chinese factory, Gigafactory 3, using mostly local debt. The facility, expected to produce 250,000 vehicles and battery packs per year, will double capacity over time. Construction is expected to start in the next few quarters, with investment not beginning "in any significant way" until next year. The estimated cost of the factory is around $2 billion, which is lower than initial estimates of $5 billion. Despite this, Tesla's cash burn has slowed in the second quarter as Model 3 production picked up, with the company expecting to become sustainably profitable for the first time in its 15-year history.

site_title: Singapore retailers share tales of digitisation battles on the ground
summary: Singapore retailers are struggling to get staff on board with digital initiatives, citing the need for adequate re-training and convincing employees that changes will make their jobs easier. Despite the introduction of digital initiatives such as self-checkout counters and automated systems, many retailers face resistance from staff who are accustomed to traditional methods. To overcome this, retailers are turning to training programs and workshops to empower staff and increase their value proposition, recognizing that a digitally savvy workforce is essential for future growth.

site_title: CCCS's anti-competitive ruling on Grab-Uber merger fair: lawyers
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has ruled that Grab's takeover of Uber's South-east Asian business threatens competition, citing a substantial lessening of competition in the ridehailing sector. Lawyers argue that the CCCS's role is to ensure a level playing field, preventing monopolies and near-monopolies from holding consumers hostage. The ruling may lead to measures to address potential monopoly, including removing exclusivity obligations for drivers and encouraging new players to enter the market. This could lead to increased competition and options for commuters.

site_title: HDB resale prices dip 0.3% in July, volume up 28%: SRX flash data
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore fell 0.3% in July, with a 1.6% decrease from last year and a 13.6% drop since April 2013. Resale volume increased 28% to 2,548 units, with a 42.7% year-on-year increase. Median Transaction Over X-Value (TOX) was zero, indicating buyers were underpaying. Experts attribute the rise in resale volume to increased supply, but predict a 1-3% year-on-year contraction in HDB resale prices for 2018 due to government cooling measures.

site_title: Google working on censor-friendly search engine for China market
summary: Google is developing a search engine for China, codenamed "Dragonfly", that will filter out certain topics to meet the country's censorship rules. The project was announced after Google withdrew its search engine from China eight years ago due to censorship and hacking. The project's employee described it as a "filter" that sorts out sensitive topics. The move has been criticized by human rights activists, who express concern about Google's involvement in China's censorship regime.

site_title: Venturing into strata office, retail properties? Beware the pitfalls
summary: Investors considering strata office, retail, and industrial properties in Singapore should be aware of the potential pitfalls. The latest curbs on private residential property purchases may channel investors towards non-residential sectors, but they still face TDSR rules limiting financing. The office market is showing promising prospects with rising prices and increasing rents, but low liquidity and shrinking net yields pose challenges. The retail market faces competition, high labour costs, and decreased demand, leading to declining rentals and prices. Investors must take a long-term approach, exercise prudence, and consider alternative options like real estate investment trusts (Reits).

site_title: Singapore market sees widespread losses
summary: The Singapore market experienced widespread losses on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) ending lower due to lower-than-expected earnings from DBS Group Holdings. Local bank stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, tumbled following the bank's disappointing results. The losses outweighed gains, with the local banks' stocks losing 2-to-1 compared to the overall market. The losses were largely driven by DBS's lower-than-expected earnings, which sent the bank's shares plummeting.

site_title: DBS trims property loans growth by S$1b; Q2 net up 18%
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest mortgage provider, has reduced its full-year loan growth forecast to between 6-7% due to cooling measures affecting the property market. The bank posted a 18% net profit gain to S$1.33 billion in Q2, missing analyst expectations. DBS also trimmed its trade loans forecast, citing fine pricing. The bank's treasury markets income dropped 59% due to trade tensions, flattened yield curve, and equity market sell-off. DBS expects a slowdown in consumer mortgage bookings and potential shortfall of S$1 billion in loans due to property measures.

site_title: Green energy producers just installed their first trillion watts
summary: Global wind and solar developers have installed their first trillion watts of power generation capacity, a milestone reached in the first half of 2018. This achievement marks substantial growth for the renewable energy industry, which has drawn $2.3 trillion in investment. The next trillion watts of capacity is expected to be installed within the next five years, with the cost expected to decrease by half, reaching $1.23 trillion. Solar energy is expected to overtake wind energy in early 2020, with China leading the world in solar power installations.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia indexes face temporary disruption
summary: Technical glitches at index provider FTSE Russell temporarily disrupted Singapore and Malaysia's market benchmarks, causing a delay in price updates. The issue affected the Straits Times Index and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index, with prices not reflecting until around 10 am. The disruptions were resolved, with the Straits Times Index closing 1.4% lower and DBS Group Holdings Ltd. down 2.4%. FTSE confirmed that all real-time values are now updating accurately, and the matter has been resolved.

site_title: Oil tanker owners are scrapping the most ships in decades
summary: Oil tanker owners are scrapping the most ships in decades due to a 19-month Opec cargo curtailment and environmental regulations. The demolition surge reflects the lowest charter rates for owners in decades, but scrapping can accelerate market recovery. Global fleet capacity could lack 100 million barrels by 2020. Average earnings for VLCCs have fallen by 65% to $6,159 a day, with owners opting for scrapping due to high costs and increasing regulations, including sulfur emissions limits and mandatory surveys.

site_title: US Congress passes bill forcing tech firms to disclose software probes
summary: The US Congress has passed a bill requiring technology companies to disclose if they allowed foreign countries, such as China and Russia, to examine the inner workings of software sold to the US military. The legislation, part of the Pentagon's spending bill, was drafted after a Reuters investigation found that software makers allowed Russian authorities to hunt for vulnerabilities in US government software. The bill would force companies to address any security risks posed by foreign source code reviews to the Pentagon's satisfaction, or risk losing the contract.

site_title: Gems For Generations
summary: Six Singapore-based jewelers, The Jewel Box, Choo Yilin Fine Jewellery, Marilyn Tan Jewellery, Caratell, Foundation Jewellers, and others, offer bespoke jewelry services to create family heirlooms. These jewelers cater to clients seeking unique pieces that reflect their personality, heritage, and milestones. Key takeaways include the importance of quality gemstones, attention to detail, and timeless designs that can be passed down to future generations. Notable projects include a 9-carat spessartite garnet cat ring, a ruby and diamond elephant bangle, and a Peranakan-style gold and diamond brooch gifted to Queen Elizabeth II.

site_title: Starbucks partners Alibaba to revive China sales
summary: Starbucks is partnering with Alibaba to deliver its coffee in Chinese cities starting this fall. The move aims to revive sales growth in China, where the company experienced a slowdown due to a crackdown on third-party delivery firms. The partnership will help Starbucks compete with aggressive local competition.

site_title: Punk Pioneers
summary: Opposition Party, Singapore's first-ever punk band, is celebrating its 30th anniversary with a show at The Substation on August 4. The band, which has undergone several line-up changes, will feature six opening acts and tickets are available for S$15 at the door. The show is a belated tribute to the band's DIY ethos and its contributions to the Singapore underground music scene in the 1980s. The band's music is now available to stream digitally on Bandcamp.

site_title: RHT Health Trust DPU tumbles 18%
summary: RHT Health Trust reported a 18% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1 Singapore cent for Q1 2019, down from 1.22 Singapore cents in the same period last year. Revenue fell 8.8% to S$22 million, mainly due to the depreciation of the Indian rupee. Occupancy levels dropped to 62% from 72% last year, contributing to lower operator revenue and variable fees. Total distributable income decreased 18.1% to S$8.6 million. The trust's manager is progressing with the disposal of assets to Fortis Healthcare, with a proposed investment by IHH.

site_title: Keppel takes 50% stake in US senior housing firm
summary: Keppel Corporation has acquired a 50% stake in US senior housing firm Watermark Retirement Communities for up to US$77.3 million. The acquisition, funded by Keppel's internal resources, will expand Keppel's presence in the senior housing sector. Watermark manages 52 senior housing communities in 21 US states, with a pipeline for 60 communities by 2020. The existing management team will continue to run the business post-acquisition, and Keppel aims to offer customized solutions to Singapore and Asian markets.

images.alt_text: The Hacienda at the River in Tucson, Arizona, one of the 52 senior housing communities managed by Watermark Retirement Communities.

site_title: The thin green line, in BT Weekend
summary: Banks face a delicate balancing act as they transition to a low-carbon economy, financing environmentally sound businesses while supporting unsustainable ones in poverty-stricken areas. British environmentalist Jonathon Porritt argues that sustainability is good economics and a celebration of innovation. Meanwhile, experts discuss sustainable investing, the potential impact of machine learning on jobs, and new products in the market, including a cryptocurrency for real estate investing. The article also explores various other topics, including a new BMW model, misheard song lyrics, and the International Champions Cup football tournament.

site_title: A Fairy-Tale Gem
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels has launched a new high jewellery collection inspired by four fairy tales - The Twelve Dancing Princesses, The Golden Bird, The Three Feathers, and Town Musicians of Bremen. The collection features over 20 pieces, including bejewelled "dancing princesses" clips and symbolic representations of the fairy tales using diamonds, emeralds, and sapphires. The maison's gemologists carefully select each stone to create unique designs that reflect the stories, showcasing the brand's whimsical and fantastical side. The collection marks the 112-year-old French luxury jewellery house's latest creative endeavor.

site_title: Is Trump team awry with Asia-Pacific ambitions?
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is visiting Singapore, marking the first time since the June summit with Kim Jong Un, to promote a "new era" of US economic commitment to the Indo-Pacific region. Pompeo's trip includes plans for $113 million in regional investments and $50 billion to expand US technology exports, but faces criticism that it will have less impact than the Obama administration's Trans-Pacific Partnership. China's Belt and Road initiative and alternative trade vision, FTAAP and RCEP, pose significant competition to the US strategy, with concerns about future US influence in the region.

site_title: Aviva Singapore's operating profit up 10%
summary: Aviva Singapore reported a 10% increase in operating profit for its first half of 2018, reaching £46 million (S$82 million), driven by sales from its expanded financial adviser network.

site_title: Heritage Eats
summary: Chef Damian D'Silva's Folklore restaurant in Singapore is celebrating National Day with a special set lunch menu featuring ethnic traditional recipes. The menu, priced at S$30 for two, includes dishes such as Braised Pork Trotters and Nasi Minyak with Lamb Rendang. The menu is available on weekdays and changes weekly, with a focus on family recipes and local ingredients. Reservations can be made by calling 6679 2900 or 9021 9700.

site_title: Hong Kong insurance market lures well-educated mainland Chinese
summary: A growing number of well-educated mainland Chinese individuals are moving to Hong Kong to sell insurance, drawn by lucrative pay and seeking refuge from a falling yuan and healthcare safety fears at home. These individuals, like 28-year-old May Zhang, hold master's degrees from prestigious universities and are selling policies to buyers in mainland China. This trend is expected to continue as the Chinese economy slows, putting pressure on policymakers. The influx of Chinese insurance professionals is expected to further transform Hong Kong's insurance market.

site_title: Indie chef makes his mark at IL Den
summary: IL Den, a hole-in-the-wall restaurant, is gaining cult appeal with its well-executed cuisine. The restaurant, located at Orchard Plaza, offers dinner services on Tuesdays to Saturdays from 6pm to 11pm. The chef has received attention for his dish "Javier," but no further information is provided.

site_title: Four hotels may have infringed Competition Act
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has issued a Proposed Infringement Decision against four hotels for exchanging commercially-sensitive information, potentially infringing the Competition Act. The hotels, including Capri by Fraser Changi City Singapore and Crowne Plaza Changi Airport Hotel, allegedly discussed and exchanged confidential customer-specific information regarding corporate customers' requests. The CCCS proposes that the hotels have infringed section 34 of the Competition Act, giving them six weeks to make representations on the issue. The decision aims to reduce competitive pressure on prices and contract terms.

site_title: Things still hunky-dory for co-working operators, but test will come during a business downturn
summary: Co-working space operators in Singapore continue to thrive, with a 27.1% share of office space leasing deals in the year to date, up from 0.9% in 2014. The sector's growth is driven by corporations seeking flexible workspaces, with hot-desking arrangements and shared facilities becoming increasingly popular. Envisaged expansion plans are backed by venture capitalists, and office landlords are warming up to co-working operators, with some even granting exclusivity to operators. However, experts caution that during a business downturn, flexible spaces may be vulnerable to cost-cutting measures, potentially disrupting the sector's growth trajectory.

site_title: Suzuki posts record profit on strong global car sales
summary: Suzuki Motor Corp posted a record-high operating profit of 116.5 billion yen (S$1.43 billion) in the first quarter, exceeding analyst estimates by 37%. The result is attributed to strong global vehicle sales, particularly in Asia, where overall sales rose 21% in April-June. This represents a significant growth in the company's biggest market, India, where sales surged. Suzuki's strong performance is expected to continue, driven by its expanding presence in key markets.

site_title: From Sydney to New York, cracks showing in property markets
summary: House prices in sought-after cities worldwide, including London, Sydney, Beijing, and New York, are experiencing declines due to tax changes, tougher lending standards, and affordability issues. In London, central properties have fallen 18% since 2014, while in China, Beijing's property market is in a downtrend. Similar trends are seen in Sydney, where credit curbs and stretched affordability have contributed to slumping prices. The International Monetary Fund warns that a downturn in one country could have wider implications for global markets, as wealthy buyers have been purchasing homes across continents.

images.alt_text: Sales prices in London are starting to fall as fears about the impact of Brexit, a slowing economy and high prices dampen demand.

site_title: Ascendas Reit buys Brisbane business park for A$33.5m
summary: Ascendas Reit has acquired the Cargo Business Park in Brisbane, Australia for A$33.5 million. The property, located near the Brisbane Airport and CBD, offers a combination of warehousing, showroom, and office space. The acquisition marks a significant move by the Singaporean real estate investment trust (REIT) into the Australian market. The deal is expected to enhance Ascendas Reit's presence in the logistics sector and provide investors with exposure to the growing demand for industrial properties in Australia.

site_title: New tax rules eat into Lippo Mall Trust DPU
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) cut its quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.59 Singapore cents, a 34.4% drop from the previous year, due to higher expenses and a 10% tax on outsourced service charges. Net property income declined 7.8% to S$43.2 million, while income tax costs surged to S$7.6 million. Despite this, the trust reported fresh turnover from three acquired properties last year and maintained an average portfolio occupancy of 93.6%.

site_title: Global gold demand falls 6% in H1 on drop in ETF buying
summary: Global gold demand fell 6% in the first half of 2018 to 1,959.9 tonnes, the lowest since 2009, due to a 9% decline in investment purchases, mainly driven by a 46% drop in exchange-traded fund (ETF) buying. Central bank purchases dipped 7% and jewellery demand fell 2% due to a weak Indian market. However, European demand was boosted by uncertainty over European Central Bank policy, while China's investment demand rose due to a trade dispute with the US.

site_title: Grab cashes up for a bigger taxi fight
summary: Grab, the Singapore-based ride-hailing firm, has secured a record-breaking $2 billion in funding, surpassing its previous round of $1 billion. The majority of the funds will be allocated to Indonesia, where Grab is competing with local rival Go-Jek. This move is seen as a strategic move to solidify Grab's position in the region and further its expansion. With its previous success in pushing Uber out of South-east Asia, Grab is positioning itself for a long fight in the region's tech landgrab.

images.alt_text: Grab is arming itself for a long fight. The ride-hailing firm won one big battle earlier this year when it pushed US giant Uber out of South-east Asia. Much of its latest US$1 billion funding round will be spent in Indonesia, where the Singapore-based group is up against homegrown rival Go-Jek.

site_title: Fed leaves key rate intact; says US economy rising at a 'strong rate'
summary: The Federal Reserve left US interest rates unchanged at 1.75-2% amid a "strong" economic growth, with unemployment at 4% and inflation near the 2% goal. The decision was unanimous, aligning with expectations for a September hike. Despite President Trump's criticism, Fed officials said they're not swayed by politics and will continue to gradually lift rates to nurture the second-longest US expansion on record.

site_title: Scoot to raise fares by 5% as fuel costs bite
summary: Budget airline Scoot will raise fares by 5% starting Sept 1 due to rising fuel costs, which have surged nearly 40% year-over-year to $90 per barrel. Singapore Airlines, Scoot's parent, has no plans to raise ticket prices. Other budget carriers, such as Jetstar Asia and AirAsia, are closely monitoring their own fares amid the fuel price increase.

site_title: Artificial Intelligence in Singapore: pervasive, powerful and present
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become pervasive in Singapore, with at least 60% of organizations having implemented AI in various areas such as information technology, supply chain, and customer support. Despite this, 76% of businesses struggle to know where to start with AI and 46% believe they have not invested sufficient man-hours and budgets in AI development. The financial services industry has been at the forefront of AI adoption, with AI-based automated chat systems improving service delivery and decision-making. To fully leverage AI, organizations must have a clear strategy, right talent, and right tech support, with robust infrastructure to handle growing data streams.

images.alt_text: An autonomous parcel delivery robot (centre), developed by Starship Technologies Ltd, on display at the AI Congress in London in January. If the right factors are into place, there are tremendous opportunities to be leveraged with the adoption of AI.

site_title: UK construction expands at fastest rate in 14 months
summary: The UK construction industry experienced its fastest growth in 14 months, with the IHS Markit/CIPS Construction PMI reaching 55.8 in July, surpassing forecasts. This uptick in construction follows a weak start to 2018 due to icy weather, and new orders have increased at the fastest rate since May 2017. The sector's positive tone is despite Brexit concerns and higher steel costs. House-building and employment have also seen significant growth, with year-on-year increases in housing starts reported by the National House-Building Council.

site_title: A Home For All
summary: A Singaporean family, including the son Joshua Oh and his wife Nana Yu, have rebuilt their home to accommodate multiple generations. The 950 sq m home, designed by architect Tan Sok Tuan, features a basement with sheltered parking, a private space for Joshua and Nana Yu, and a multi-level living area. The home maximizes land use, incorporating a courtyard with a skylight and indoor garden. Each family member has their own private space, while common areas are designed for family gatherings. The project prioritizes functionality and flexibility for a harmonious multi-generational living environment.

site_title: Temasek extends US$200m credit facility to Rent the Runway
summary: Temasek Holdings has extended a US$200 million credit facility to US clothing rental firm Rent the Runway to drive subscription growth, expand reverse logistics operations, and refinance existing debt. Rent the Runway will use the funds to accelerate its growth plans, with Temasek receiving warrants and an observer seat on the board of directors. The company has seen 150% year-on-year growth in its two-year-old subscription business, now representing over half of total revenue, with over nine million members.

site_title: FundedX platform for 'trading startups' stalls at start line over licensing issue
summary: FundedX, a platform for trading startups, has halted operations due to a licensing issue with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). FundedHere, the platform's parent company, initially claimed FundedX was a private stock exchange but later clarified it was not. MAS requires platforms for secondary trading of securities to be approved exchanges or recognised market operators, not capital markets services licences. FundedX will not operate until it receives the necessary authorisation, which it has not yet applied for.

site_title: Ryde to offer 'dynamic fixed fares' for taxis by Sept
summary: Ryde, a ride-hailing platform, has been granted a Class 1 third-party taxi-booking service by Singapore's Land Transport Authority. The move allows commuters to book taxis with upfront dynamic pricing, which can adjust based on demand. Ryde plans to onboard 7,000 taxi drivers, reducing waiting times from 5 minutes to 4. The platform expects to roll out its RydeX service to all taxi drivers by September, pending approval from the Public Transport Council. This move aims to increase efficiency in Singapore's point-to-point transport sector.

site_title: China property investors spend less abroad
summary: China's real estate outbound investment in the first half of 2018 fell to its lowest level since 2015, with Chinese institutional investors spending US$9.9 billion, a 37% decline from the previous year. The decline was mainly due to tighter controls on lending. Cushman & Wakefield downgraded its forecast for the full-year investment volume to 40-50% lower than 2017. The firm expects geopolitical issues to negatively impact investment, particularly in the US market, with investments in office space increasing by 44% to US$3.6 billion.

site_title: Euro, yuan slide amid flare-up in trade tensions
summary: The euro and Chinese yuan slid amid rising US-China trade tensions, with the euro falling 0.4% to a two-week low of $1.1608 and the yuan hitting a 14-month low of 6.868 yuan. Investors sought safe-haven US dollars, driving the dollar index up 0.3% to 94.944. The US Treasury yields also rose, bolstering the dollar's safety bid. The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged but expressed a more upbeat view of the US economy.

site_title: Kueh Goes Swee
summary: Sinpopo, a heritage dessert brand, has opened a concept store at Paragon in Singapore, offering modern twists on traditional local desserts such as Kueh Dada, Kueh Sarlat, and Ondeh Ondeh. To celebrate Singapore's 53rd birthday, customers who spend at least S$53 will receive a spin at the Gachapon Machine, which offers free cake slices, dine-in vouchers, and online delivery. The store also features freshly baked salted egg yolk cookies. This marks Sinpopo's third concept store in Singapore, following its success with modern desserts.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Y Ventures Group and China Aviation Oil (CAO) are expected to see growth in their respective industries. Y Ventures' value-added data analytics capabilities are seen as a key differentiator, while its cryptocurrency and Aora coin plans hold potential. CAO's core business of jet fuel supply to the Chinese aviation industry showed 13% year-on-year volume growth in Q2 2018, with profit exceeding estimates. Both companies are recommended to be bought with target prices of S$0.77 and S$1.80, respectively.

site_title: The Heavenly Art of Tea
summary: TWG Tea is celebrating its 10th anniversary with a retrospective of its iconic tea blends and accessories. Founded by Taha Bouqdib and Maranda Barnes, the company has grown into a global brand with a distribution network of 42 countries and a presence in 19 cities. To commemorate the milestone, TWG Tea has released a limited-edition Grand Tour Tea Set, featuring 12 of its most popular teas, including the Singapore Breakfast Tea and the Grand Golden Yin Zhen. The company has also expanded its physical presence globally, with locations in London, Tokyo, and other major cities, and plans to continue its mission of making high-quality tea accessible to tea lovers around the world.

site_title: Deep in the birthplace of Cuban rum and the daiquiri
summary: In Santiago, Cuba, a small rum bar called El Traguito is gaining recognition for its expertly crafted cocktails. The bar, located in the basement of a museum, is run by cantinero Eduardo Corona, who advocates for the city's underappreciated rum culture. Cuban rum is believed to have originated in Santiago in the mid-19th century, with Facundo Bacardi perfecting the refined, delicate style. Today, bartenders in Santiago still prefer the Bacardi brands produced at the original distillery, prized for their rich, complex flavors. El Traguito's expertly made daiquiris are a testament to the city's legacy as the birthplace of the popular cocktail.

site_title: Think there's been a productivity boom? Think again
summary: A 1995 Senate commission found that inflation was overstated by 1.1 percentage points, with the largest issue being the undercounting of price cuts due to quality improvements in products. Two decades later, a new study by the Brookings Institution estimates the bias at 0.85 percentage points, down from the initial 1.1 points, due to improvements in data collection. This suggests that the economy's output, productivity, and living standards may be underestimated if price increases are overestimated.

site_title: FundedX to refrain from operating until authorisation obtained
summary: FundedX, a crowdfunding platform launched by FundedHere, will suspend operations until it obtains relevant authorization. The platform's business model was initially described as licensed under FundedHere's capital markets services license, but it was later found to be incorrect. FundedHere clarified that FundedX must be an approved exchange or recognized market operator to operate, and it will refrain from operating until authorization is received. This decision comes after FundedHere retracted its initial clarification on the platform's business model.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.28% down on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks declined 1.3% on Thursday, closing at 3,286.32, with losers outnumbering gainers 265 to 124. The Straits Times Index fell 42.69 points. Key movers included Ezion, Genting Singapore, and Singtel, all of which fell in value.

site_title: Sicilian wines come into their own in the world's big wine buffet
summary: Sicilian wines, particularly frappato, are gaining popularity globally. Historically, Sicily's internationally recognized wines were sweet, but dry reds like frappato and nero d'Avola are now being discovered. Frappato, a grape grown in Sicily for centuries, has a floral freshness and high acidity, making it a great summer red. When blended with nero d'Avola, frappato produces Cerasuolo di Vittoria, one of the island's best red wines. Recent releases of varietal frappato wines, such as COS Frappato Terre Siciliane 2015 and Valle dell'Acate Il Frappato Vittoria 2016, showcase the grape's stylistic range, offering a refreshing and complex drinking experience.

site_title: Han Keen Juan
summary: Han Keen Juan, founder of Old Chang Kee, discusses the brand's expansion into Europe, particularly London, which is the first city in the region the brand plans to enter. Despite previous failures in countries like Japan and South Africa, Han attributes his optimism to London's cosmopolitan and accepting nature. The brand has entrusted the UK business to 37-year-old Sandra Leong, who shares Han's passion and drive. Han plans to open at least five outlets in London before expanding further into European cities, with the goal of establishing a strong logistics chain.

site_title: National Workout Day
summary: The Sports Hub National Day Fiesta will take place on August 9 from 12 to 9 pm at OCBC Square, Singapore Sports Hub. The event offers a variety of activities, including workout sessions, e-sports, and ethnic craft workshops. For those who prefer a more relaxed experience, there will be guided tours, music performances, and children's activities. Alternatively, the live telecast of the National Day Parade will be available from 5 pm to 9 pm.

site_title: European stock markets down at open
summary: European stock markets opened in the red on August 2, 2018, amid fears over the global impact of an escalating trade war between the US and China. The FTSE 100, CAC 40, and DAX indices declined 0.3%, 0.4%, and 0.9% respectively. The downturn was attributed to concerns over the global trade tensions, with investors seeking safe-haven assets.

site_title: 98 Paintings For 98 Years
summary: At 98, Lim Tze Peng, a Cultural Medallion recipient, is exhibiting a solo show at Ode To Art Gallery featuring 98 works from his career. Despite physical limitations, his mind remains sharp, and he continues to paint, reflecting on past scenes and creating new abstract calligraphy. Lim's artistic journey spans 98 years, from early landscapes to modern abstract works, showcasing his passion for constant improvement and artistic expression.

site_title: US jobless claims rise modestly, labor market firming
summary: US jobless claims rose 1,000 to 218,000 for the week ended July 28, exceeding economists' forecast of 220,000. This marks the highest reading since December 1969. Despite this, the labor market remains strong, indicating sustained resilience. Trade tensions, including those with China, Canada, and the European Union, have not significantly impacted the labor market, suggesting the economy's resilience.

site_title: Suspension of trading of Vard Holdings shares expected on Aug 10
summary: Vard Holdings' shares are expected to be suspended from trading on Aug 10, immediately after the close of Fincantieri Oil & Gas's exit offer on Aug 8. Shareholders approved the delisting in July, with the delisting estimated to occur two to three weeks after the exit offer closes. The suspension will affect scripless shares purchased close to or on the closing date, which may not be credited in time for the exit offer. The delisting date remains uncertain, but the suspension will take place after the close of the exit offer.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower weighed by tech stocks
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, weighed down by falling technology stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.31% to 25,256.45, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The decline came after President Donald Trump proposed 25% tariffs on US$200 billion worth of Chinese imports, sparking fears of a trade war.

site_title: Heatwave ravages European fields, sending wheat prices soaring
summary: A severe heatwave has ravaged European wheat fields, leading to soaring prices and reduced output estimates. The European Union's top wheat producers, including France and Germany, are experiencing extreme weather conditions, with harvesting progressing northward due to lack of rain. The heatwave has prompted the European Commission to speed up payments to farmers and allow them to use fallow land to feed livestock. Wheat prices have surged over 20% in the past three weeks, with prices reaching a five-year high of 214.50 euros per tonne.

site_title: Possible new US tariffs not 'cataclysmic', says Ross
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross downplays the impact of potential new tariffs on nearly half of China's imported goods, stating they would amount to less than 1% of China's economy. The proposed 25% tariff on $200 billion of goods is expected to cost China $50 billion annually. Despite this, China's top diplomat Wang Yi says US efforts to pressure China will be in vain, and China remains committed to its stance on the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Trump receives new letter from Kim
summary: President Donald Trump received a new letter from North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un, following up on their June 12 summit. The White House confirmed the letter was received on August 1 but did not disclose its contents. This development comes with little public sign of progress toward Trump's goal of Korean denuclearization, raising questions about the status of the talks.

images.alt_text: The White House said Thursday that President Donald Trump had received a new letter from North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un, without disclosing its contents.

site_title: Recipe For Success
summary: Several Singaporean eateries are expanding their businesses, creating their own unique identities and niches. One restaurant sells Singapore-style ramen in a hawker centre and plans to open in Hong Kong, while another modern Asian-Peranakan restaurant will have a spin-off in Singapore and Beijing. Two modern tze char joints are also expanding, with one opening its second outlet and the other introducing a localised burger joint. These successes demonstrate that Singaporean chefs can navigate the fine line between street food and heritage fare, finding a balance that allows them to sustain and grow their businesses.

site_title: Saudi Arabia cuts oil pricing as it boosts supply to meet demand
summary: Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil company, Saudi Aramco, cut oil pricing for September shipments to Asia, Europe, and the Mediterranean, reducing the premium for Arab Light crude by 70 cents per barrel. This is the second consecutive monthly cut and follows a boost in supply to meet customer demand. The move is seen as a signal that Saudi Arabia wants to supply more crude, and other producers in the region are likely to follow the kingdom's lead. The cuts were made in response to a surge in OPEC production, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia.

site_title: Musk's apology, relief over cash helps Tesla recover
summary: Elon Musk's apology to analysts and the company's improved cash management helped Tesla recover in the second quarter. The electric vehicle manufacturer burned through less cash than expected, sending shares higher. Musk's apology, which came after he scorned the analysts three months earlier, appeared to ease investor concerns. This development demonstrates Musk's growing maturity as a CEO and a sign of the company's resilience. As a result, Tesla's stock price rose following the close of regular trading.

site_title: Possible new US tariffs on Chinese goods not 'cataclysmic' - Commerce Secretary
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross downplays potential economic impact of new tariffs on China, stating they would only amount to less than 1% of China's economy, equivalent to $50 billion annually. The tariffs, directed by President Donald Trump, target nearly half of China's imported goods in response to China's refusal to meet US demands. Despite weighing on China's financial markets, Ross believes the move will not lead to disaster, with Chinese diplomat Wang Yi dismissing US efforts as in vain.

site_title: Souvenirs Of Singapore
summary: Singaporeans can show their love for the country through various items, including the One Singapore plate by Supermama, priced from S$42, and a postcard collection by SingPost, S$4.80. Onlewo's faux suede notebooks feature Singaporean illustrations, priced at S$36 each. The 1872 Clipper Tea Co. offers a National Day tea collection, S$15 each, celebrating Peranakan culture. YOKU MOKU's Singapore Heritage Tin, S$44, and the HDB Shoe Rack, S$290, are also available. Additionally, EZ-Link's National Day 2018 commemorative cards, priced at S$12 each, support Community Chest, while The LampPost Project sells tote bags and T-shirts, S$28 each, supporting the Singapore Association for Mental Health.

site_title: US factory orders rise for second straight month
summary: US factory orders rose 0.7% in June for the second straight month, driven by strong demand for transportation equipment, electrical equipment, and computers. This follows a 0.4% increase in May. However, business spending plans on equipment are expected to slow in the third quarter due to rising worker shortages and import tariffs. The Commerce Department also reported a 0.2% increase in non-defense capital goods orders, lower than initially reported, and a 0.7% increase in core capital goods shipments. This suggests a further slowdown in manufacturing.

site_title: How China's economy has spillover effects on Asean: AMRO report
summary: China's economy has significant spillover effects on ASEAN countries through various channels, including goods trade, investments, and financial markets. ASEAN's goods exports to China have increased, with consumer goods and electronics driving growth. China's outward direct investments (ODIs) in ASEAN have also risen, with a focus on manufacturing and wholesale trade. The report suggests that growth shocks in China can impact ASEAN's exports and GDP, with potential losses of 0.1-0.6% in GDP for ASEAN-5 countries.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: UnUsUaL Ltd, a media company, plans to develop and produce Apollo, a live entertainment show marking the 50th anniversary of the moon landing. The company has entered into a binding agreement with Nick Grace Management to develop and produce the show, forming a joint venture company.

site_title: BMW builds X5 in Thailand to counteract US China tariffs -CEO
summary: BMW is producing between 10,000 and 20,000 X5 sports utility vehicles in Thailand to supply Chinese customers, as imported vehicles from the US face a 40% tariff. This move counters the tariff impact, with the Thai plant now capable of making a "significant portion" of vehicles that would have been exported from the US plant in Spartanburg, South Carolina. BMW's CEO, Harald Krueger, stated this as a response to the tariffs.

site_title: Jaitley is set to resume work as India Minister in August
summary: Indian Finance Minister Arun Jaitley is set to resume work in mid-August after a three-month hiatus due to a renal transplant. His office is being renovated and sanitized to prevent infection, and he has been active on social media, addressing issues and holding video conferences. Jaitley's absence was marked by questions about who India's finance minister was, with Railway Minister Piyush Goyal holding the charge in his absence.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest bank, warned of heightened macroeconomic uncertainty due to US-China trade tensions. Grab raised $1 billion to finance its ride-hailing battle. Singapore's Big Data HR startup Pulsifi secured $1.1 million from angel investors. The Straits Times Index fell 42.69 points to 3,286.32, with Singapore shares closing 1.3% lower. Vietnam was surprised by the Trump tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate.

site_title: New Silkroutes Group unit acquires six clinics for S$11.4m
summary: New Silkroutes Group has acquired six clinics in Singapore through its subsidiary HSI Medical for S$11.4 million, expanding its healthcare offerings. The acquisition brings the group's total clinics to 17, including dental and traditional Chinese medicine clinics. The deal is expected to contribute positively to the group's earnings for the financial year ending June 30, 2019, and aligns with the group's strategy to focus on healthcare. The acquisition is financed by internal funds and bank borrowings.

site_title: Manufacturing activity eases a touch in July as trade tensions simmer
summary: Manufacturing activity in Singapore eased for the fourth consecutive month in July, with the PMI dipping 0.2 points to 52.3. Despite this, manufacturing remained in positive territory, with the electronics sector PMI recording a positive reading of 51.6. The slowdown is attributed to trade tensions and high base effects, with economists expecting a further slowdown in the second half of the year. The uncertainty surrounding the US-China trade dispute is also a factor, with Singapore's small and open economy making it vulnerable to any escalation of trade tensions.

site_title: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust cuts Q2 DPU by 34% to 0.59 S cent
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) has reported a 34% decline in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.59 Singapore cents, due to swelling property operating expenses and higher income tax. Net property income fell 7.8% to S$43.2 million, while income distributable to unit holders dropped 33.8% to S$16.8 million. The trust's portfolio occupancy remained at 93.6%. Despite a 1.3% increase in Indonesian currency terms, the rupiah's slide against the Sing dollar and new tax regulations impacted earnings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares suffer further sharp losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.21% on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 27,714.56, amid US warnings of tariffs on Chinese imports. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 2.00% and 2.40%, respectively. The US trade tensions have fueled fears of an all-out trade war between the world's top two economies, causing market volatility and investor uncertainty.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit Q2 DPU down to 1.06 Singapore cents from 1.15 Singapore cents
summary: OUE Commercial Reit's second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) declined to 1.06 Singapore cents from 1.15 Singapore cents in the previous year. The DPU drop came as Q2 income available for distribution fell 7.5% to S$16.5 million, with gross revenue shrinking 2.6% to S$43.1 million and net property income down 2.4% to S$33.9 million.

site_title: Aviva Singapore posts 10% rise in H1 operating profit on financial advisory boost
summary: Aviva Singapore reported a 10% increase in H1 operating profit to £46 million, driven by a 55% rise in financial advisory (FA) channel sales. The company's network now has 772 financial advisers, up from 673 last year. Life operating profit rose 22%, more than offsetting losses from general insurance and health. The FA channel is the biggest contributor to growth, according to CEO Nishit Majmudar.

site_title: Temasek Holdings extends US$200m credit facility to US clothes rental firm Rent the Runway
summary: Temasek Holdings has extended a US$200 million credit facility to US clothing rental firm Rent the Runway, allowing the company to drive subscription growth, expand logistics, and refinance existing debt. Rent the Runway, with over 9 million members and 150% year-on-year growth, plans to use the funds to fuel its business. In return, Temasek received warrants and an observer seat on Rent the Runway's board of directors.

site_title: Britain delivers second interest rate hike in over a decade
summary: The Bank of England raised interest rates by a quarter-point to 0.75% to combat high inflation, marking its second rate hike in over a decade. The decision was made despite investor concerns over a chaotic Brexit, and the central bank upgraded its 2019 economic growth forecast to 1.8%. The move aims to sustainably return inflation to the 2% target, and Governor Mark Carney cautioned that the bank is prepared for various Brexit outcomes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 10.18 points to 1,778.13. Volume reached RM2 billion, with 658 losers outnumbering 246 gainers. This marks the second day of losses for the index.

site_title: RHT Health Trust Q1 DPU down 18% to one Singapore cent
summary: RHT Health Trust reported a Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) of one Singapore cent, down 18% from the previous year. Revenue fell 8.8% to S$22 million, mainly due to the depreciation of the Indian rupee against the Singapore dollar. Occupancy levels dropped to 62% in Q1 2019, leading to lower operator revenue and variable fees. Total distributable income decreased 18.1% to S$8.6 million. The trust is in the process of disposing of assets to Fortis Healthcare and awaits unitholder approval for the disposal.

site_title: Japan's MUFG posts best Q1 in 7 years, helped by stock holdings sale
summary: Japan's MUFG reported its best first-quarter profit in seven years, reaching 315 billion yen, driven by sales of equity holdings and gains from clawing back provisions for potential bad loans. The bank's core banking operations remained weak due to a weak yen-bond market and low interest rates. MUFG maintained its full-year net profit forecast of 850 billion yen, down 14% from the previous year. The bank aims to boost its headcount for a securitization business in the US.

site_title: China's stock slump deepens on tariff concern; Tencent tumbles
summary: China's stock market slumped 2.9% on Thursday, with the CSI 300 Index falling to its lowest close since February 2015. Tencent Holdings Ltd plummeted 3.2% for a six-day loss of 9.5%, weighing on the Hang Seng Index. Analysts attribute the decline to concerns over a trade dispute with the US, which may lead to increased tariffs. The yuan remained stable at 6.8168 per dollar, while measures of consumer and tech shares were among the worst performers.

site_title: Hong Kong insurance market lures well-educated mainland Chinese
summary: A growing number of well-educated young Chinese are selling insurance in Hong Kong, attracted by lucrative pay and seeking refuge from a falling yuan and healthcare safety fears at home. These agents, often holding master's degrees, have an edge in winning business from upper and middle-class clients due to their similar educational and social backgrounds. This trend is driven by Hong Kong's insurance market, which offers higher pay than mainland China, drawing in Chinese buyers seeking financial security.

site_title: London Stock Exchange Group plans for a no-deal Brexit
summary: London Stock Exchange Group has activated contingency plans in case of a no-deal Brexit, including incorporating new entities in the EU and applying for EU authorization. The bourse operator reported a 21% rise in first-half adjusted operating profit to £480 million. The plans aim to mitigate the impact of a hard Brexit, but the complexity and lack of clarity on the application of the plan may decrease its effectiveness.

site_title: French insurer AXA reports H1 profit in line with forecast
summary: AXA, Europe's second-largest insurer, reported a 14.4% decrease in first-half net profits to 2.8 billion euros, meeting market forecasts. The decline was attributed to charges related to the initial public offering of its US unit and adjustments to asset values. AXA updated its debt reduction target to a debt gearing ratio of 25-28% by 2020, down from below 28%. Despite the lower profits, the insurer's earnings were in line with average analyst forecasts.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust Q1 FY2018/19 DPS up 3.1%
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) for Q1 FY2018/19 increased 3.1% to 1.35 Singapore cents. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) declined 9.8% and 9.3% respectively due to lower contributions from Australian hotels and foreign exchange translations. The trust benefited from a divestment of two hotels in Beijing, which reduced bank borrowings and funded a hotel acquisition in South Korea. Average occupancy and daily rate fell, but the trust still reported a 3.8% increase in income available for distribution.

site_title: Let's get fiscal
summary: HSBC Research reports that most Asean countries are on track to meet their fiscal targets in 2018. Indonesia, Vietnam, and Malaysia aim to consolidate deficits, but face hurdles. Fiscal policy is expected to drive growth in Singapore, the Philippines, and Thailand over the medium term. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacts to the Trump tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. In Malaysia, a rate cut is made to shield the economy from tariff threats, while Thailand's super-long bonds gain due to tariff concerns and a political crisis.

site_title: Ascendas Reit buys Brisbane business park for A$33.5m
summary: Ascendas Reit acquired Cargo Business Park in Brisbane, Australia for A$33.5 million, with a 12-month rental guarantee for vacant spaces. The 87.4% occupied property has tenants including the Australian Bureau of Meteorology, Asics, and Nike, with a retention rate of 78%. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to Ascendas Reit's distribution per unit and funded through internal resources and existing debt facilities, with completion expected in the September quarter. This acquisition brings Ascendas Reit's total properties to 99 in Singapore and 34 in Australia.

site_title: Ryde plans to offer dynamic pricing for taxi bookings by September after getting LTA nod
summary: Ryde, a ride-hailing platform, has received approval from Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) to offer dynamic pricing for taxi bookings. The feature, which was previously introduced by Grab, will allow users to pay upfront for their rides, reducing waiting times for commuters. Ryde aims to bring 7,000 taxi drivers on board its RydeX service by September, aiming to reduce average waiting times to four minutes. The move is part of Ryde's effort to transform Singapore's point-to-point transportation sector and make it more efficient by incentivizing supply to match demand.

site_title: Hotels may have infringed Competition Act by exchanging commercially-sensitive information
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has issued a Proposed Infringement Decision against four hotels for exchanging commercially-sensitive information, potentially infringing the Competition Act. The hotels, including Capri by Fraser, Village Hotel, Crowne Plaza, and OUE Airport Hotel, allegedly discussed and exchanged confidential customer information to secure corporate bookings. The CCCS proposes that these agreements constitute concerted practice and has given the hotels six weeks to make representations on the issue.

site_title: Australian shares fall as BHP and Rio Tinto take hits; NZ edges lower
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Thursday, led by declines in BHP and Rio Tinto, with BHP's stock dropping 3.3% and Rio Tinto's falling 4.9%. The slump was driven by lower commodity prices, a potential hit to demand from escalating trade tensions between the US and China, and concerns about higher inflation. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,240.9, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also fell 0.1%.

site_title: Keppel acquires 50% stake in US senior housing operator Watermark
summary: Keppel Corporation's subsidiary, Keppel Capital Senior Living, has acquired a 50% stake in US senior housing operator Watermark Retirement Communities for up to $77.3 million. The acquisition aims to expand Keppel's presence in the senior housing sector, leveraging Watermark's expertise and business model. Watermark currently manages 52 senior housing communities across 21 US states, with plans to expand to over 60 communities by 2020. The deal is expected to be completed in tranches, with minimal impact on Keppel's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares slip on US-China trade war worries
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 1.03% on August 2, 2018, following Wall Street's drop amid US-China trade war concerns. The Nikkei 225 index fell 234.17 points to 22,512.53, while the Topix index lost 17.67 points to 1,752.09. The US threatened to raise tariffs on Chinese goods, leading to investor worries.

site_title: KSH Holdings unit wins S$53.8 million construction contract
summary: KSH Holdings unit Kim Seng Heng Engineering Construction has secured a S$53.8 million construction contract, set to start in August 2018 and finish in 2020. The award lifts the group's Singapore construction order book to S$560 million, expected to contribute to financial results until FY2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,282.38, down 1.4%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading at 3,282.38, down 1.4% from the previous close, after a lunch break. Losers outpaced gainers 238 to 94, with Ezion falling 7.6% and local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC Bank also declining. The Straits Times Index shed 46.63 points, with 990.7 million shares worth S$649.6 million changing hands.

site_title: Thailand wants Britain to extradite former PM Yingluck
summary: Thailand's junta has requested Britain to extradite former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, who fled the country in 2017 after being charged with failing to stop graft in her government's rice policy. Yingluck, a key figure in Thai politics, is believed to reside in the UK. The request, made on July 5, has been met with skepticism by Yingluck's party, who claim it is a "political" move. Thailand's junta has promised elections next year, but democracy will be limited by a charter that curbs politician power.

site_title: FundedHere issues clarification, says FundedX not a 'private stock exchange' as initially claimed
summary: FundedHere clarified that its platform FundedX, initially described as a "private stock exchange," is actually a "matching platform" or "secondary broker platform" where buyers and sellers can register to buy or sell company stocks at pre-determined prices. FundedX does not have a license as a market operator and does not facilitate price discovery or continuous trading. The platform is backed by CapBridge and the Singapore Exchange, and has not yet launched with high-growth startups or privately held companies on board.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on Rio profit miss, weaker commodity prices; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 6,261.5 on Thursday, led by Rio Tinto's 3% decline after the global miner reported first-half earnings that fell short of market expectations. The materials sector was also impacted by escalating trade war worries, with copper and iron ore prices declining. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.2% on the day.

site_title: Rolls-Royce sees 2018 results at upper end of guidance
summary: Rolls-Royce reported its 2018 results will be at the upper end of its guidance range, driven by better-than-expected performance in its civil aerospace and power systems businesses. Despite issues with the Trent 1000 engine, which has grounded planes, the company upgraded its estimates of costs to fix the problem and compensate airlines to £450 million. Rolls also recognized an exceptional charge of £554 million for the Trent 1000 issues for the period to 2022.
