site_title: Tencent's stock price just keeps on tumbling
summary: Tencent's stock price has plummeted 8% this week, its lowest in 10 months, amid concerns over earnings and a global tech sector downturn. Despite 51 analysts maintaining a "buy" recommendation, the stock's current price of HK$342.80 is 50% below the average price target of HK$511.62. Tencent's market value has declined by about US$160 billion since its record high in January, with analysts citing shrinking margins and potential weakness in gaming revenue as key concerns. The company reports earnings on August 15.

site_title: Bank of Japan says no fixed timeframe for keeping rates low
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has stated that there is no fixed timeframe for keeping interest rates low, despite a pledge to maintain them "very low" for an "extended period of time." The decision comes after a policy meeting, where the BOJ allowed bond yields to move more flexibly around its zero per cent target. Disagreements among the nine-member board on the extent of yield flexibility have been revealed, but a broad agreement was reached on the new range of minus 0.2 per cent to 0.2 per cent for 10-year yields. The BOJ's goal of achieving a 2 per cent inflation target remains elusive, with five years of monetary easing failing to lift inflation.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Masayoshi Amamiya said the central bank had no fixed timeframe for how long it would keep interest rates low but signalled the chance of taking more steps to address the rising cost of easing on parts of the economy.

site_title: China's property outbound investment in H1 hits lowest since 2015: property consultancy
summary: China's real estate outbound investment fell to its lowest level since 2015, dropping 37% to $9.9 billion in the first half of 2018, according to Cushman & Wakefield. This decline was mainly due to tighter controls on lending and geopolitical issues, particularly in the US market. The consultancy downgraded its forecast for the full year, predicting a 40-50% drop in investment volume, compared to a 30-40% decline originally forecast. Investments in office space increased, but are expected to be limited for the rest of the year.

site_title: Hot stock: Hi-P pares losses from morning trade; down 10% on day
summary: Hi-P International's stock fell 10.24% on Thursday, despite regaining some losses, to trade at S$1.14. The company announced a 19% drop in net profit for its second quarter due to escalating cost of sales. Hi-P attributed the decline to the challenging market conditions in the smartphone, Internet of Things, and consumer electronics sectors. The company plans to focus on developing new customers and products to boost revenue and manage costs.

site_title: Siemens chief tech officer Busch to become chief operating officer
summary: Siemens appoints Roland Busch, its 53-year-old chief technology officer, as its new chief operating officer, effective October 1. Busch will oversee an overhaul of the company, potentially paving the way for him to replace CEO Joe Kaeser. The company also plans to extend Lisa Davis' contract as head of its struggling power and gas division until October 1, when she will take over the new Gas and Power operating company.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 1.05 points to 1,787.26, with 241 losers outweighing 210 gainers. The index closed at RM230.94 million in volume.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia stock indices hit by temporary FTSE disruption
summary: Singapore and Malaysia's stock indices were temporarily disrupted due to technical glitches at index provider FTSE Russell. The issue affected the Straits Times Index and FTSE China A50 indices, causing real-time values to be temporarily inaccurate. The disruptions were resolved after 10am local time. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index was also impacted due to a technical issue at FTSE's end. The cause of the disruption is under investigation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on US-China trade worries
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, August 2, 2018, due to US-China trade worries. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.36% to 22,664.28, while the Topix index dropped 0.11% to 1,767.77. The US threatened to raise tariffs on Chinese goods, causing selling in companies with close ties to China, such as Komatsu and Fanuc. However, some investors saw buying opportunities in companies with good earnings but low prices, like Sony.

site_title: Rap brawl delays flights at Paris airport
summary: Flights at Paris's Orly Airport were delayed due to a brawl between French rappers Booba and Kaaris and their entourages. The fight occurred in a duty-free shop and waiting lounge, forcing officials to temporarily shut down a departures hall. 13 people were detained, and a small number of flights were delayed by 15-30 minutes. The incident is part of a long-running feud between the two rappers, who have known each other since 2011.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend losses on fears of escalating trade war
summary: Asian markets sank on August 2, 2018, due to fears of an escalating US-China trade war. The US threatened to double tariffs on Chinese imports, prompting China to warn it would not back down. The US had already imposed tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods, and additional tariffs of $16 billion are set to be imposed. Markets in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Seoul fell, while Tokyo and Sydney lost ground. Investors are concerned about the potential for further trade tensions to impact global growth.

site_title: Scoot to raise fares by 5% on average from Sept 1 on rising fuel prices
summary: Scoot, the low-cost arm of Singapore Airlines, will raise fares by 5% on average starting September 1, due to rising fuel prices, which have surged by 40% year-on-year. Fuel costs account for 32% of Scoot's operating costs, leading to a 31% increase in fuel expenditure. The airline aims to contain costs by exploring ways to reduce fuel burn, reviewing contracts, and improving productivity. This fare increase follows the removal of fuel surcharges in 2016 when fuel prices reached six-year lows.

site_title: Pacific Radiance sets Aug 24 date for vote to restructure S$100m of 4.3% notes due Aug 29
summary: Pacific Radiance has scheduled a vote on August 24 for its S$100 million 4.3% notes due August 29. The vote will determine whether to restructure the bonds by swapping them for warrants and either cash and equity or convertible bonds. Under the cash-and-equity option, holders will receive cash and shares, while the convertible bond option offers new bonds with a conversion price of S$0.112 per share. The company is also seeking to waive principal payments and postpone the maturity date to September 30, 2019.

site_title: UnUsUaL lands North American live entertainment gig with show on Apollo
summary: UnUsUaL Ltd has entered into a binding agreement with Nick Grace Management to develop and produce the live entertainment show "Apollo," marking its first foray into the North American market. The $13.5 million production will commemorate the 50th anniversary of man's first steps on the moon. A joint venture company will be formed to lead the investment and production of the show.

site_title: Singapore's Big Data HR startup Pulsifi snags US$1.1m through angel investors
summary: Singapore's HR startup Pulsifi secured US$1.1 million in angel funding, led by Chi Sieng Tiong and Chieh Suang Khor. The platform uses Big Data and organisational psychology to help companies identify and retain employees. The funding will be used to improve the platform, which is currently used by multinationals such as Nestlé and Deutsche Telekom T-Systems. Pulsifi believes innovation in HR technology has reached an inflexion point, with 66% of CEOs expecting AI to transform the industry.

site_title: Grab raises another US$1b to finance ride-hailing battle
summary: Grab, South-east Asia's leading ride-hailing service, has raised US$1 billion from investors including OppenheimerFunds and Ping An Capital to finance its battle against Jakarta-based rival Go-Jek. This brings Grab's total funding to US$2 billion, with a significant portion to be invested in Indonesia. Grab is expanding its services, including payments and grocery delivery, to create a mobile platform for everyday requests. The company handles over 7 million drivers and merchants across 225 cities in eight countries, and its app has been downloaded on over 100 million mobile devices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened in negative territory on August 2, 2018, extending recent losses due to fears of an escalation in the China-US trade row. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.54% to 28,188.36, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.33% and 0.41%, respectively.

site_title: WhatsApp out to make money from business messages
summary: Facebook is introducing a "WhatsApp Business" tool to connect businesses with customers via the smartphone messaging service. The tool has been tested with over 90 companies, including Uber and Singapore Airlines. The feature allows businesses to chat on WhatsApp and enables users to quickly start a conversation from a Facebook ad. This move aims to generate revenue for Facebook from business messages, marking a shift in the company's approach to monetizing its messaging services.

site_title: Google said to be planning China search app, ending long boycott
summary: Google is reportedly planning a censored search engine for China, dubbed Dragonfly, which would block sensitive search results deemed unacceptable by the Chinese government. The move marks a significant shift for the company, which withdrew from China in 2010 after refusing to self-censor search content. The decision has sparked outrage among some Google employees, who argue it would enable mass censorship of search results. A final version of the app could be launched within six to nine months, with China's second-largest economy and growing population of internet users potentially driving Google's decision.

site_title: Australia to 'vehemently' oppose Japan push to ease whaling ban
summary: Australia vows to "vehemently" oppose Japan's push to ease the global whaling ban, citing concerns over Tokyo's "scientific research" program. Australia's Foreign Minister Julie Bishop stated that the 30-year moratorium on commercial whaling should be maintained, and the country will work with like-minded nations to reject Japan's proposal. Japan plans to propose setting catch quotas for whale species deemed healthy by the IWC scientific committee and change the body's decision-making process. The proposal aims to justify commercial whaling, despite international criticism and the fact that whale meat is often served in Japan.

site_title: Starbucks ties up with Alibaba for China coffee delivery to revive sales
summary: Starbucks partners with Alibaba to deliver its coffee in Chinese cities, aiming to revive sales growth in the second-largest market. The tie-up comes after the company reported a slowdown in China sales growth due to a government crackdown on third-party delivery firms. Starbucks CEO Kevin Johnson praised Alibaba's technology and retail expertise, and the partnership is expected to help the company compete with local coffee startups.

site_title: EU keen on closer Asean ties
summary: EU High Representative Federica Mogherini emphasizes the EU's commitment to Asia, calling it a "reliable and constructive partner" for regional and international issues. She highlights the EU's focus on increasing its role as a security provider, pushing for open and fair trade, and supporting the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. Mogherini also emphasizes the importance of developing a strategic partnership between the EU and ASEAN, with a focus on multilateralism and cooperation on security, trade, and sustainable connectivity. She notes that the EU has recently strengthened its relations with Asian partners, including China and Japan, and is prepared to support international efforts for peace and security in the region.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday, with STI at 3,329.05
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.04 point to 3,329.05. Losers outnumbered gainers 129 to 79, with 226.4 million shares changing hands. Key stocks like Ezion, DBS, and UOB fell, while the market remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Wells Fargo to pay US$2.1b fine to settle US mortgage probe: DOJ
summary: Wells Fargo agreed to pay a US$2.1 billion fine to settle US charges that it misrepresented the quality of home loans used in securities, contributing to the 2008 financial crisis. The Justice Department announced the settlement without Wells Fargo admitting liability. The bank originated and sold mortgage loans with incorrect income information, warranting a civil penalty.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo will pay US$2.1 billion to settle US charges it misrepresented the quality of home loans used in securities that led to 2008 financial crisis, the Justice Department announced Wednesday.

site_title: Oil tanker owners are scrapping the most ships for decades
summary: Oil tanker owners are scrapping the most ships in decades due to a 19-month Opec cargo curtailment and environmental regulations. Global Marketing Systems Inc reports a surge in ship demolitions, with owners giving up the supertanker fleet at the fastest pace since the 1980s. Morgan Stanley estimates the global fleet could lack 100 million barrels of transportation capacity by late 2020, as scrapping sets the stage for market recoveries.

site_title: US Fed highlights strong economy, leaves rate untouched
summary: The US Federal Reserve highlighted the strength of the US economy and labor markets, confirming interest rate increases are ahead, despite holding rates unchanged. The Fed described the economy as growing at a "strong rate" and noted household spending had "grown strongly." Financial markets expect a benchmark lending rate increase in September and possibly four more hikes this year, solidifying expectations for a fourth hike in December. The decision is unlikely to please President Donald Trump, who has publicly criticized the Fed's policy.

site_title: New Zealand PM returns to work from maternity leave
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern returned to work from maternity leave on Thursday, ending a six-week break. The 38-year-old opted to work from home in Auckland until the weekend, when she will relocate to Wellington. Ardern, who gave birth while in office, stated in a Facebook message that her family was doing well despite lacking a routine. She is the second world leader to give birth while in office, following Angela Merkel.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall on renewed Sino-US trade friction; won steady
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 16.66 points or 0.72% to 2,290.41 due to renewed Sino-US trade friction. The US administration proposed a higher 25% tariff on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports, increasing pressure on China for trade concessions. The Korean won remained steady, while bond yields slipped, as investors brushed off the uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as mixed earnings fail to dispel trade fears
summary: European shares fell 0.5% on Wednesday due to mixed corporate earnings, with concerns about the US-China trade conflict and subdued euro zone manufacturing growth. Autos stocks declined 2.4%, and basic materials fell 1.6% due to copper price drops. However, some sectors, such as Air France-KLM and Lloyds Banking, rose after reporting positive results. The US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates is expected to be announced later, with investors awaiting a potential rate hike.

site_title: US may raise tariffs on US$200b in Chinese goods to 25%: officials
summary: The US may increase tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports to 25% from 10%, according to US officials. This move is part of President Trump's pressure on China to reform its trade practices. The proposed tariffs, which were previously set at 10%, would make Chinese goods significantly more expensive for US consumers. The US has already imposed 25% tariffs on $34 billion in Chinese goods, and another $16 billion is set to be targeted in coming weeks. The comment period on the proposal will be extended into September.

site_title: Lawsuit claims Walmart stole technology to keep produce fresh
summary: Walmart was sued by Zest Labs for allegedly stealing its technology to preserve produce freshness, known as Zest Fresh. Zest claims Walmart's "Eden" technology looks and functions similarly to its own. The lawsuit seeks $2 billion in damages, alleging Walmart misappropriated trade secrets and know-how. Walmart has estimated $2 billion in savings over five years from Eden, but denies wrongdoing, stating it will respond to the complaint in court.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, OUE Lippo Healthcare, FLT, BreadTalk, Moya Holdings
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported an 18% gain in net profit for the second quarter, driven by higher net interest income and fee income, but flagged heightened macroeconomic uncertainty. OUE Lippo Healthcare narrowed its loss year-on-year to S$2.9 million, while Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust posted a 2.9% rise in distribution per unit. BreadTalk's net profit rose 10.5% to S$2.4 million, and Moya Holdings Asia's net profit more than doubled to S$7.2 million.

site_title: DBS flags spillover concern with US-China tensions; 18% gain in Q2 profit misses estimates
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest bank, flags heightened macroeconomic uncertainty due to US-China trade tensions, citing spillover effects on the region and property loan growth. The bank reported an 18% gain in net profit for Q2, beating estimates, but missed on non-interest income due to weaker trading income. DBS has cut its loan growth outlook to 6-7% and expects a stronger net interest margin, but shares fell 2.56% amid broader market weakness.

site_title: India's Central Bank ups interest rate to fight inflation
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) raised its benchmark interest rate to 6.5% to combat inflation, the highest in two years. The decision, made by a 5-1 vote, aims to reach the 4% medium-term inflation goal. The move follows emerging-market counterparts and comes amid currency woes, with the rupee down nearly 7% against the dollar this year. The RBI also kept its policy stance neutral, citing the need to prevent drifting away from the inflation target.

site_title: Italy July budget surplus shrinks slightly vs July 2017: Treasury
summary: Italy's July state sector budget surplus decreased to 10.6 billion euros, slightly lower than the 11.3 billion euros recorded in the same month last year. The cumulative budget deficit for the first seven months of the year was 30.7 billion euros, a 9.4 billion euros reduction from the same period in 2017. This improvement is in line with Italy's goal to cut its general government deficit to 1.6% of GDP from 2.3% last year, well within the EU's 3% ceiling.

site_title: Elon Musk's apology to analysts he scorned sends Tesla stock soaring
summary: Elon Musk apologized to analysts he previously scorned during Tesla's second-quarter earnings call, offering personal apologies to Sanford C Bernstein's Toni Sacconaghi and RBC Capital Markets' Joseph Spak. Musk had previously criticized their questions as "boring" and "dry." The apology led to a 12% surge in Tesla shares in after-hours trading, as investors responded positively to Musk's contrition. This comes after major shareholders urged Musk to focus on execution and improve his public image.

site_title: JPMorgan says it is a subject of SEC probe of ADR abuses
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. has revealed it is under investigation by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for its handling of "pre-released" American Depositary Receipts (ADR) between 2011 and 2015. The bank is among several institutions being probed for mishandling of these securities, which represent foreign shares held in custody at a depositary bank. JPMorgan has cooperated with the investigation, while Deutsche Bank previously agreed to pay $75 million to settle its part of the investigation. The SEC has warned that improper handling of ADRs can lead to potential abuse at the expense of investors.

site_title: Bank of England poised to raise rates in the face of Brexit risk
summary: The Bank of England is set to raise interest rates to their highest level since the 2008 financial crisis, defying warnings of a gamble ahead of Brexit uncertainty. The decision comes as the UK economy slows and the terms of its future trading relationship with the EU remain unclear.

site_title: US mulls cutting passenger screening at small airports: report
summary: US authorities are considering eliminating passenger screening at small and mid-size airports, a proposal that has sparked concern among terrorism experts. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) is looking at cutting screening at over 150 airports with 60 seats or fewer, where travelers would instead be screened when their flights connect to higher-volume airports. The move could save $115 million annually but would increase the risk of security breaches. TSA officials have expressed serious concern, citing militant groups' continued regard for aviation as a priority target.

site_title: More scope for Singapore and Argentina to collaborate on food, technology: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore and Argentina are exploring potential collaboration in the areas of food and technology, according to Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing. The potential partnership was discussed at the Argentina-Singapore business forum in Singapore. This collaboration could lead to increased trade and investment opportunities between the two countries.

site_title: GE sees stronger Q2 sales growth; profits up 3%
summary: Great Eastern, a Singaporean insurer, reported a 3% increase in net profit to S$241.1 million in the second quarter, driven by stronger topline sales. Earnings per share rose 4% to S$0.51, and gross premiums rose 33% to S$3.26 billion. The group attributed the growth to improved productivity and new product introductions, but also reported a S$903.5 million loss from the sale of investments and changes in fair value.

site_title: Global factory growth slowing; China-US trade war biting
summary: Global factory growth has slowed, with factory activity in the euro zone, Asia, and the US all showing signs of a loss of momentum. The US-China trade war is attributed to the slowdown, with tariffs imposed on billions of dollars' worth of goods. Despite this, major central banks are expected to maintain their ultra-loose monetary policies, citing resilient economic growth, low unemployment, and rising wages. The global economic outlook remains healthy, but the trade war is expected to have a significant impact, with economists estimating an 81-basis-point impact on global growth.

site_title: STI edges up, with banks gaining
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.27% to 3,328.95, driven by gains from DBS Group Holdings (0.71%), OCBC Bank (0.26%), and Venture (6.84%). The top-performing stocks on Wednesday's trading session were DBS, Singtel, and Venture, with the local bourse recovering from an early dip. The STI's 5-day rally continues ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: SunMoon Q1 profit down 77%
summary: SunMoon Food Company's first-quarter net profit plummeted 77% to S$603,000, due to a sharply lower gross margin and wider loss. The company's disposal gain from subsidiaries nearly halved to S$1.54 million. Earnings per share decreased to 0.0838 Singapore cents, down from 0.8128 cents last year. The decline in profit is attributed to a decline in gross margin and operating loss.

site_title: US: Apple lifts Nasdaq as trade war fears hit Dow
summary: US stocks finished mixed on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq lifted by strong Apple results, while the Dow fell 0.3% due to trade-war fears. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.6% to close at 7,707.29, despite President Trump's plans to increase tariffs on Chinese goods. Apple jumped 5.9% after reporting a 30% profit increase. The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged but signaled more rate hikes are in the works.

site_title: EU an avid supporter of rules-based global system
summary: The European Union's High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, will attend the Asean Regional Forum Ministerial Meeting in Singapore, reaffirming the EU's commitment to Asia as a reliable and constructive partner. Mogherini stated that the EU's commitment will not waiver, emphasizing its support for a rules-based global system. This visit underscores the EU's ongoing engagement with the region and its desire to maintain a strong partnership with Asia.

site_title: Bird Rides takes its electric scooters to Paris, Tel Aviv
summary: Bird Rides Inc, an electric scooter-rental startup, has launched pilot programs in Paris and Tel Aviv, marking its first forays outside the US. The move comes as rival Lime has also expanded globally, with scooters in over 70 cities in the US and Europe. Both companies, valued at $1 billion and $2 billion respectively, have significant funding and ambitions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Bird's CEO Travis VanderZanden expressed plans to expand to more cities, following Uber's investment in Lime.

site_title: Tesla shares rise despite bigger Q2 loss
summary: Tesla reported a Q2 loss of $717.5 million, more than double the previous year's loss, but its share price rose 4.4% to $313.99 after the company confirmed it's on track to become profitable this year. The company's Model 3 production ramp-up has hit its stride, with output meeting a 5,000 per week benchmark in June and exceeding it in July. Tesla expects to reach 6,000 vehicles per week by late August and 10,000 per week "sometime next year."

images.alt_text: Electric automaker Tesla on Wednesday reported a huge second-quarter loss of US$717.5 million - worse than analysts expected - but its share price rose on news the company was on track to become profitable this year.

site_title: Kuroda's move: Easing to continue or stealth taper?
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) made policy tweaks, allowing the 10-year yield to rise to 0.2% and cutting the amount of bank reserves facing a negative rate, sparking debate over whether it's easing or normalizing policy. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's forward guidance pledged to keep rates low for an extended period, supporting easing. Analysts such as Masamichi Adachi and Hiromichi Shirakawa interpret the moves as easing, while others, like Takahide Kiuchi, see a "stealth rate hike" and a step away from negative rates.

site_title: Ezion announces changes in senior management
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine company, has announced changes in senior management to sharpen focus on business priorities and operational efficiency. Goon Fook Wye Paul has been appointed as chief group business officer, while Chong Chee Wei Alan will take over as acting chief financial officer. Chan Kong Meng Lawrence has been seconded to the associated company's renewable energy and strategic assets portfolio. These changes will take effect from August 1, 2018.

site_title: Oil falls 2% on rising supply, concern about trade tensions
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Wednesday due to a surprise increase in US crude stockpiles and concerns about global oversupply. Brent crude futures dropped $1.82 to $72.39 a barrel, a 2.5% loss, and US WTI crude futures fell $1.10 to $67.66 a barrel, a 1.6% loss. Rising trade tensions between the US and other countries also contributed to the decline, with investors worried about reduced energy demand.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell about 2 per cent on Wednesday as a surprise increase in US crude stockpiles fed concerns about global oversupply, while investors worried that trade tensions could hit energy demand.

site_title: Women achieve a milestone in the boardroom, but the struggle isn't over
summary: Women have achieved a milestone in Singapore's boardroom, with a majority of listed companies now having a woman director for the first time. The proportion of board seats held by women has been growing steadily, reaching 11.2% as of June. New revisions to the Code of Corporate Governance aim to improve board gender diversity, including setting targets and reporting progress, and introducing a nine-year term limit for independent directors. However, progress is expected to be slow, and efforts must focus on ensuring genuine efforts to increase diversity, rather than just meeting numerical targets.

site_title: Windy Heights owners cutting reserve price in fresh en-bloc bid
summary: Windy Heights, a 192-unit freehold residential development in Singapore's Kembangan area, is set to launch a fresh collective sale after a failed bid in April. The reserve price has been reduced by 6.97% to S$750 million, down from S$806.2 million, in a bid to attract more sellers. The revised price works out to S$1,089 per sq ft, excluding a bonus balcony area, and is subject to authorities' approval. The sale is seen as an opportunity for developers to capitalize on the area's limited supply, with Knight Frank predicting strong demand for new launches in the Kembangan and Bedok area.

site_title: Silicon Valley's invasion of banking just got key US nod
summary: The US Office of the Comptroller of the Currency has invited fintech companies to apply for special national charters, allowing them to operate in banking without traditional bank oversight. This move aims to spur innovation and is seen as a key nod for Silicon Valley upstarts to enter the banking sector. The OCC's decision has been opposed by the financial industry and state regulators, but the Treasury Department has advocated for the step to promote competition and financial inclusion. The new charters could enable online lenders, payments firms, and cryptocurrency ventures to operate without relying on a bank.

site_title: Global factory growth slowing
summary: Global factory growth slowed in July, with many countries experiencing stagnant expansion rates. Economists expect protectionist trade policies to continue, with US tariffs on Chinese imports expected to increase. Despite this, major central banks are unlikely to adjust their monetary policies, citing low unemployment and rising wages. The European Central Bank and Bank of England are expected to raise interest rates, while the Bank of Japan will maintain its stimulus package. China's economy is also expected to slow, with the country cutting bank reserve requirements to ease financial pressures.

site_title: China to probe online bazaar PDD as fake goods complaints rise
summary: Chinese regulators have ordered an investigation into Pinduoduo Inc, a popular online bazaar, amid reports of widespread counterfeit goods sold on the platform. The investigation comes after a week of high-profile complaints about trademark infringements and fake products, including knock-offs of Samsung TVs and Xiaomi phones. The State Administration for Market Regulation vows "serious" punishment if it uncovers violations, and the investigation is seen as a significant blow to the e-commerce operator's valuation.

site_title: Kuwait says oil market approaching stability
summary: Kuwait's oil minister Bakhit al-Rashidi stated that the global oil market is approaching stability based on current production levels, following the recent Opec and non-Opec agreement to boost output. Kuwait has raised its oil output to 2.8 million barrels per day, and an upcoming meeting will review producers' oil supply levels. The agreement aims to increase output by 1 million barrels per day, helping to cool the market after recent price declines.

site_title: Do 'Quiet Skies' equal safe skies?
summary: The "Quiet Skies" program, which assigns air marshals to monitor passengers deemed suspicious, has raised concerns about surveillance and waste. The program, initiated by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA), aims to allocate air marshals' time more effectively. Air marshals watch passengers for up to 90 days if they exhibit alarming patterns of international travel or suspicious behavior. The program has led to calls for Congress to review its effectiveness and ensure it does not infringe on Americans' rights. Some argue the program could be adjusted to focus on high-risk flights and passengers.

site_title: Enterprising charities can contribute more to society
summary: Singapore's demographic is rapidly ageing, with growing inequalities in wealth, income, and opportunity. To address these issues, the government may need to step in to guarantee employment and income. Instead of expanding the public sector, a smarter approach could be to expand the non-profit sector, where soft skills and empathy are valued. Non-profits can deliver significant value to society, but are constrained by a lack of investment and sustainable funding. To overcome this, the government and private investors can work together to create a more entrepreneurial mindset among charities, using innovative funding models such as social impact bonds and impact investing.

site_title: India's monsoon rains this year likely to miss forecast for normal showers
summary: India's monsoon season is likely to be below the forecast for normal showers, with precipitation forecast to be 92% of the long-term average, according to Skymet Weather Services Pvt. The South Asian nation, which accounts for over 70% of its annual showers, may experience lower crop output and spur imports of commodities due to deficient rain. Warming of the Pacific Ocean surface and neutral Indian Ocean Dipole are contributing factors, with a 60% chance of below-normal monsoon showers and a 25% chance of drought this year.

site_title: Pushing boundaries in medical technology
summary: Medical technology firms are developing innovative products to address the growing demand for healthcare services in Asia. Four exhibitors at Medical Manufacturing Asia 2018 showcase their products, including a safer method for injecting life-saving drugs, a fully hydraulic injection-moulding machine for producing small components, and 3D-printed human anatomy models for pre-surgical planning. These products aim to improve patient health outcomes, increase productivity, and reduce costs in the medical sector, which is expected to become the world's second-largest market by 2020.

site_title: Oil falls below US$74 on US inventories, Opec supply
summary: Oil prices fell below US$74 a barrel on Wednesday due to a report showing US crude inventories rose unexpectedly and higher production from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec). Brent crude dropped 40 cents to US$73.81 a barrel, while US crude fell 44 cents to $68.32. Opec's supply cuts were eased in June, and production rose, led by Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. Concerns over a supply disruption in the Bab al-Mandeb Strait and US-China trade tensions also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Pacific Radiance was granted a moratorium on creditor actions while restructuring discussions are underway. BreadTalk Group reported a 10.5% increase in Q2 net profit to S$2.4 million, with revenue flat at S$148.8 million. Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings saw a 50.4% rise in Q2 net profit to HK$6.6 million. Moya Holdings Asia's net profit rose 6 times to S$7.2 million, driven by the contribution from its Acuatico Group acquisition. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust posted a 2.9% rise in Q3 distribution per unit to 1.8 Singapore cents.

site_title: E-commerce propels Singapore SMEs to lead APAC exporters
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) led Asia-Pacific exporters in 2017, generating an average annual exporting revenue of US$1.75 million. 78% of SMEs used e-commerce, 65% social commerce, and over half tapped into mobile commerce to boost exports. Digital economy growth and access to international markets made it easier for SMEs to venture into e-commerce. Despite challenges, SMEs remain bullish about export growth, thanks to government support and Singapore's pro-trade stance.

site_title: Temasek's ST Telemedia backs GDS against shortseller's attack
summary: GDS Holdings, a unit of Temasek Holdings' ST Telemedia, has responded to a short-seller report alleging chicanery, saying the report's claims are false and its conclusions are incorrect. The company's market value was hit by 37.2% on Tuesday, but the rebuttal aims to address the report's "fundamental misunderstanding" of its business. GDS Holdings maintains its rebuttal, implying a strong defense against the short-seller's attack.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages SIA Engineering and Cache Logistics Trust have issued buy recommendations, citing undervaluation and potential for long-term growth. SIA Engineering, which has declined 22% in the past year due to structural challenges, is seen as an event-driven stock awaiting privatization by parent SIA. Cache Logistics Trust's Q2 results showed a 7.7% increase in gross revenue, but a 17.6% decline in distribution per unit. Analysts expect the industrial sector to bottom out in the end of 2018/early-2019, making Cache a buy opportunity.

site_title: 97 hurt as Mexican plane crashes at airport in hail storm
summary: A plane operated by Aeromexico, an Embraer 190 aircraft, crashed during a hail storm on takeoff in Durango, Mexico, injuring 97 people. The aircraft, carrying 88 adults, nine minors, and two pilots, made an emergency landing but caught fire, engulfing the plane in flames. Two serious injuries were reported, with a pilot undergoing a spinal operation and a young girl suffering burns on 25% of her body. No fatalities were confirmed, and the plane was found immobilized in a field.

site_title: Social change through technology
summary: Dell emphasizes its commitment to driving human progress through technology, focusing on environmental sustainability, transparent supply chains, inclusive workforce development, and advancing underserved communities. The company's key tenets involve investing in innovation that benefits people in need, reflecting its dedication to corporate purpose.

site_title: P2B lender Validus raises over S$100m in funding for SMEs
summary: Singapore-based peer-to-business lender Validus Capital has raised over S$100 million in funding for local SMEs through its financing platform, exceeding an average loan amount of S$70,000 across over 1,400 loans. Established in 2015, Validus focuses on helping SMEs secure short- and medium-term financing from accredited investors and institutions, offering faster approval times and lower costs of capital. The platform has received capital markets licensing from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and has partnered with Temasek-backed Vertex Ventures to support SME growth.

site_title: Leading lights in corporate governance
summary: The 13th annual Singapore Corporate Awards honored the best in corporate governance and shareholder communication, with 34 companies and six individuals receiving recognition. DBS Group received the Special Recognition Award for its "all-round excellence in corporate governance," while CapitaLand swept four awards and Tuan Sing Holdings bagged three. The awards ceremony also featured notable speakers, including Minister Ng Chee Meng and DBS CEO Kelvin Tan, who joked about DBS's "royal flush" of winning awards in five categories from 2013 to 2017.

site_title: 8-storey Mohd Sultan Rd project put up for sale for S$30m
summary: A 8-storey residential block and adjoining commercial building in Singapore's District 9 has been put up for sale by tender for S$30 million. The property, located near Robertson Walk and Fort Canning MRT Station, features 11 residential units and a commercial space. The site has a 999-year lease and is zoned for residential and commercial use. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity for family offices, funds, and high net worth individuals to diversify their portfolios. The tender closes on August 30.

site_title: Deloitte sets up foreign law practice in Singapore
summary: Deloitte has launched Deloitte Legal International, a licensed foreign law practice in Singapore, offering full international legal services to clients in South-east Asia. The new practice aims to become a one-stop shop for clients, building on Deloitte's existing accounting and advisory services. As part of its regional hub, Deloitte Legal International will serve clients in the region, expanding the Big Four accounting firm's offerings.

site_title: China's central bank steps up drive to boost lending
summary: China's central bank is encouraging banks to boost lending as the country's economy cools. The People's Bank of China has provided window guidance to banks, indicating a willingness to be more flexible on government-imposed lending caps. This move aims to bolster small-business lending and offset a contraction in China's shadow-finance sector. The central bank's efforts come as the US economy slows and US President Donald Trump threatens to impose more tariffs on Chinese goods. Increased lending could improve sentiment in the country's equity and credit markets, easing financial conditions and supporting growth.

site_title: Sony jumps to decade high as PlayStation drives higher forecast
summary: Sony Corp jumped to its highest in over a decade after raising its fiscal year outlook, driven by robust PlayStation 4 sales and profits from its Spotify stake. The company lifted full-year net income and revenue forecasts, beating operating profit estimates for the June quarter. Shares rose 5.4% in early Tokyo trading, their highest close since 2008.

site_title: Koalas starve as residents destroy trees to stop bush fires
summary: Koalas are starving to death on an Australian island due to residents cutting down trees to prevent bush fires. Rescue workers on Raymond Island report admitting at least one starving koala per week, affecting the entire state. Koalas rely on eucalyptus leaves for food, but the destruction of their habitat is threatening their survival. With fewer than 90,000 koalas left in the wild, conservation efforts are needed to protect the vulnerable species.

site_title: China's exports fall for fourth straight month: Caixin index
summary: China's manufacturing sector experienced its slowest growth rate in 18 months, with the Purchasing Managers' index (PMI) falling to 50.8 in July, down from 51.0 in June. This decline is attributed to a grim export market, leading to slower output and new orders growth. For the fourth consecutive month, exports fell, and companies reduced workers faster than in June. The slowdown is partly due to China's trade war with the US, which has imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, and tighter credit conditions at home.

site_title: Huawei passes Apple in smartphone share for the first time
summary: Huawei surpassed Apple to claim the No 2 position in smartphone shipments in the second quarter, with 54.2 million phones shipped, 41% more than the previous year. This marks the first time Huawei has passed Apple, with 16% of the market share. Chinese smartphone makers, including Xiaomi and Oppo, also rose in the rankings. The overall smartphone market slowed, with shipments down 1.8% to 342 million units, and Samsung's earnings were impacted by the decline.

site_title: Apple quarterly profit leaps, nears market value of US$1 trillion
summary: Apple's quarterly profit jumped 30% to $11.5 billion, beating market expectations, driven by 17% revenue growth to $53.3 billion on sales of pricier iPhones, online services, and wearable devices. The company sold 41.3 million iPhones, slightly shy of analyst projections. Apple's market value is nearing $1 trillion, with shares rising 2.85% to $195.79 in after-hours trading. The company is expected to unveil new iPhone models in the fall and is diversifying its revenue with services, which are seen as a key growth area.

site_title: New airline to join Vietnam's congested skies
summary: A new airline, Bamboo Airways, plans to join Vietnam's congested skies with 37 routes after its October inaugural flight. The airline, backed by property developer FLC Group JSC, aims to capitalize on the country's growing middle class and tourism industry. Despite forecasts of Vietnam becoming one of the world's top five fastest-growing air travel markets, analysts warn that the market is becoming saturated, making it challenging for new entrants to succeed. Bamboo Airways has secured 20 leased aircraft and plans 50 international routes in 2019.

site_title: AEM Holdings dives 25%; analyst downgrades stock, slashes target
summary: AEM Holdings' stock plummeted 25% on Wednesday, losing almost 40% of its value in two days, following a downgrade by analyst Willian Tng at CGS-CIMB, who slashed his target price to S$0.69 from S$1.78. The company warned of "significant volatility" ahead due to a potential replacement of legacy equipment by Intel Corp, its major customer. Analyst Ling Lee Keng at DBS Group Research noted that tech stocks may be stuck in range-bound trading due to a lack of catalysts, despite their cheap valuation.

site_title: Is this the sound of a residential property market dying?
summary: Singapore's residential property market experienced a sudden downturn on July 6, 2018, after the government announced increased Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) and Loan-to-Value (LTV) limits on housing loans. The measures, which included a five percent additional tax, prompted developers to reassess their strategies and caused a surge in en bloc sales in the preceding months. The government's cooling measures were seen as a response to the market's "euphoria" and were effective immediately, sparking concerns about the market's stability.

site_title: Google opens third data centre in Singapore's Jurong West
summary: Google has announced the construction of its third data centre in Singapore's Jurong West, marking a US$850 million long-term investment in the country. The new centre, expected to come online in 2020, will be built on a plot of land the size of the first two centres combined. This addition is driven by rapid user growth in the region, with over 70 million people getting online for the first time in the past three years. Google currently employs over 1,000 people in Singapore and is actively hiring for new roles.

site_title: Democrats steal a march on Trump's playbook
summary: The article discusses the upcoming US midterm elections, which are being heavily influenced by President Donald Trump's populist policies. Despite polls suggesting a Democratic victory, history shows that incumbent presidents can still win re-election. Democrats are confident they can win key districts in states Trump carried in 2016, but Trump's base remains solid, and he has a chance to benefit from a Democratic takeover of the House. Trump's advisers debate whether to focus on economic issues or energize his base to ensure a strong showing in November.

site_title: Baidu's Q2 results exceed expectations, powered by ad sales growth
summary: Chinese internet search giant Baidu reported Q2 results exceeding expectations, driven by 25% growth in online ad revenue to 21.1 billion yuan. Total revenue rose nearly a quarter to 26 billion yuan, and net income rose 45% to 6.4 billion yuan. Baidu navigated regulatory challenges, with CEO Robin Li citing a "close dialogue" with regulators. The company continues to invest heavily in AI and auto businesses, but analysts note margin growth will be constrained in the near term.

site_title: How healthy is your office?
summary: Developers and architects are shifting focus from environmentally friendly buildings to creating offices with measurable wellness benefits. The Well Building Standard, introduced by Delos in 2014, aims to promote health through seven categories, including air quality, comfort, and nutrition. Several companies, such as the American Society of Interior Designers, have reported significant productivity gains and cost savings after implementing the standard. Certification programs like Fitwel, developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, are also gaining traction, offering a more affordable alternative to the Well standard.

images.alt_text: From standing desks and an organic foods cafe to triple-filtered air and plants galore, Delos' new headquarters is a showcase for the trend of commercial real estate designed with wellness in mind.

site_title: Euro pressured by dollar strength
summary: The euro fell 0.1% to $1.1684 due to a stronger US dollar and subdued euro zone manufacturing growth. Fears of an escalation in the US-China trade dispute boosted the dollar, with the US planning to propose 25% tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports. The offshore Chinese yuan also slid 0.5% on reports of the new tariffs. Despite initial market concerns, currency markets quickly regained poise, with the yuan remaining virtually flat.

site_title: Boustead inks deal to develop integrated production and warehouse facility for long-term lease to Amcor
summary: Boustead Development Partnership (BDP) has secured a development contract for an integrated production and warehouse facility in Singapore. BDP, a co-investment partnership between Boustead Projects and the Abu Dhabi Investment Council, will lease the facility to Amcor for the long term. This marks a significant development for Boustead, with the contract valued at an undisclosed amount. The project is expected to enhance Amcor's logistics capabilities and contribute to Boustead's growth strategy.

site_title: The Hour Glass Q1 profit more than doubles
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported a net profit of S$14.3 million for its first quarter of 2019, more than doubling from S$7 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 10% to S$180.7 million, driven by improved consumer sentiment in the region. Gross margin improved to 24.4%, boosting profit after tax. The company expects to be profitable for the financial year, barring unforeseen circumstances. Its shares closed up 1.55% at 65.5 cents after the announcement.

site_title: Hi-P Q2 earnings down 19% at S$12.29m
summary: Hi-P International reported a 19% drop in net profit to S$12.29 million for the second quarter, despite an 8% increase in revenue to S$302 million. The decline in gross profit margin to 9.8% was attributed to a change in product mix and increased competition. The company expects similar revenue but lower profit for FY18, and plans to focus on developing new customers, products, and exploring inorganic growth opportunities.

site_title: US factory activity slows
summary: US factory activity slowed in July, with the Institute for Supply Management index falling to 58.1 from 60.2 in June, indicating an expansion in manufacturing. Despite robust demand, supply chains and employment resources continue to struggle, with tariff-related concerns cited by respondents. The slowdown may draw attention from the Federal Reserve, which is wrapping up a policy meeting and is expected to leave interest rates unchanged. The labor market remains robust, with the jobless rate at 4.0%, but the economy's growth pace may be put at risk by supply chain disruptions.

site_title: EZ-Link still a leading player in Singapore's e-payment drive
summary: EZ-Link, a leading player in Singapore's e-payment drive, has been quietly trialing and rolling out services to promote e-payment adoption and reduce cash handling. The company has introduced EZ-Reload, a free service that automatically tops up ez-link cards, and a loose-change top-up service at Cheers outlets. EZ-Link aims to boost its 12% market share of ez-link card holders to 30% and is developing an e-wallet for launch in 2019. The company is also creating a senior-friendly app to increase activity among seniors and is working to overcome cultural transformation challenges within the organization.

site_title: Tesla plans to raise funds for its China factory
summary: Tesla plans to raise a portion of the $5 billion needed to build its Shanghai factory in China from local Chinese partners, according to a Bloomberg report. The company's CEO, Elon Musk, previously stated that Tesla would not need to raise funds from investors, but analysts now question the company's ability to secure the necessary capital. China is a key market for Tesla, accounting for 17% of its revenue last year, and a plant in Shanghai will help avoid high tariffs.

site_title: Singapore talent in the spotlight
summary: Singaporean talent is highlighted in a special issue of Weekend magazine, featuring established jewellery designers such as Choo Yilin and Vinod More, who create bespoke designs to hand down to future generations. Additionally, the magazine profiles Han Keen Juan, founder of Old Chang Kee, which has expanded into a multi-million dollar empire, and four home-grown eateries that have gained international recognition for their unique identities. The issue showcases Singapore's thriving food scene, creative industry, and entrepreneurial spirit.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare Q2 loss narrows to S$2.9m
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare reported a narrower loss of S$2.9 million in the second quarter, compared to a year-on-year loss of S$20.6 million, due to the absence of an impairment loss. Revenue fell 12.2% to S$9.5 million, mainly due to lower revenue from the Wuxi New District Phoenix Hospital and China pharmaceutical distribution business. The company has undertaken various initiatives to rebuild its financial health and expand its business network in Asia.

site_title: US hiring surges in July: survey
summary: US private firms hired at a faster-than-expected pace in July, adding 219,000 new jobs, the most since February, according to ADP's survey. The strong labor market suggests a possible dip in the unemployment rate and could lead to accelerated wages, fueling inflation. The Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates twice more this year, closely watching wages and inflation. The services sector led the way, adding 177,000 jobs, with the goods-producing sector hiring 42,000, including 23,000 in manufacturing.

site_title: Eiffel Tower shut in dispute over 'monstrous' queues
summary: Staff at the Eiffel Tower in Paris shut down the landmark on August 1, 2018, in protest over a new access policy that generates "monstrous" queues for tourists. The policy, implemented last month, sets aside half of daily tickets for online pre-bookings, causing long waits for walk-ins. Staff, represented by the CGT union, demand equal access to all elevators, regardless of ticket type. The shutdown, which affected tourists already inside, was a response to failed talks with management, which claimed waiting times are short for online ticket holders.

site_title: US construction spending posts biggest drop in more than a year
summary: US construction spending plummeted 1.1% in June, its largest decline in over a year, due to a sharp drop in private and public projects. The revision of May's spending showed a 1.3% increase, not a 0.4% gain as initially reported. Private residential projects fell 0.5% and public construction projects tumbled 3.5%, the largest decline since March 2013. The decline was attributed to rising material costs and labor shortages in the homebuilding sector.

site_title: China Aviation Oil Q2 net profit up 14.4%
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 14.4% increase in Q2 net profit to US$29.3 million, driven by higher gross profit and stable profit contributions from associates. Revenue jumped 57.9% to US$5.8 billion, mainly due to higher oil prices and increased supply and trading volume. The company's six-month net profit rose 14.2% to US$56.2 million, with revenue growing 41.8% to US$9.9 billion. Despite uncertainties in the oil markets, CAO's CEO expressed confidence in the company's progress and growth prospects.

site_title: China's central bank steps up effort to boost lending
summary: China's central bank has taken a softer stance on loan quotas, encouraging banks to extend more credit and boost lending to small businesses, amid efforts to bolster a cooling economy. The move aims to offset an unprecedented contraction in China's shadow-finance sector and improve sentiment in the country's equity and credit markets. The People's Bank of China has relaxed lending rules, allowing banks to exceed their year-to-date quotas, and has raised small-business lending quotas by more than 50% for some banks.

site_title: Brookvale Park en bloc bid latest to be headed to court
summary: The collective sale of Brookvale Park in Singapore has been issued a "stop" order by the Strata Titles Board (STB) after mediation failed to resolve objections from seven owners. The sale, valued at S$530 million, is now likely headed to court within two weeks. The dissenting owners disagree with the independent valuation report, believing it undervalued the 999-year leasehold condo by comparing it to sites with 99-year leases. A separate valuation report valued the property 10% higher.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Apple lifts tech stocks
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by Apple's strong earnings and easing concerns over tech sector growth. The Dow Jones rose 46.44 points, or 0.18%, to 25,461.63, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The tech-heavy Nasdaq led the gains, rising 30.03 points, or 0.39%, to 7,701.82. The strong performance came despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Japanese sake maker may buy US firms to set sales records
summary: Takara Holdings Inc., Japan's largest sake supplier to overseas markets, plans to expand its US operations under new president Mutsumi Kimura. The company aims to increase revenue from overseas sales to about half of total sales, up from 33% in 2018. This could involve acquiring local distributors and increasing production at its Berkeley sake plant. Kimura also targets a 5-6% annual increase in output, using locally-grown rice, to make sake as popular as wine.

site_title: July's share buyback value slips 37%
summary: Singapore-listed companies bought back 52.5 million shares in July, a 37% decrease from the previous month. Despite the drop, the share buyback value was still up sharply compared to the same month last year. 37 companies participated in the share buyback, with no specific details provided on the companies or the value of the shares bought back.

site_title: Berkshire loans US$2b to Buffet-backed real estate firm
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, backed by Warren Buffett, has loaned US$2 billion to Seritage Growth Properties, a real estate investment trust that owns Sears stores and vacant properties. The loan will be used to refinance debt and increase capital. This move marks Berkshire's involvement in the real estate empire spun out of Sears Holdings, which Buffett bet on more than two years ago. The loan demonstrates Berkshire's confidence in Seritage's business prospects.

site_title: Yorkshine applies for extension to submit resumption proposal
summary: Yorkshine Holdings has applied to the Singapore Exchange for a five-month extension to submit a resumption proposal, pushing the deadline from August 3, 2018 to January 2, 2019. Trading in the company's shares has been suspended since August 3, 2017. The SGX-ST is reviewing the application, with no certainty of approval. If approved, the company will submit a resumption proposal, allowing trading to resume.

site_title: Hi-P Intl posts 18.6% drop in Q2 net profit
summary: Hi-P Intl recorded a 18.6% year-on-year drop in Q2 net profit to S$12.29 million, despite an 8% increase in revenue to S$302 million. Net profit for the six-month period declined 4.8% to S$22.38 million. The company expects similar revenue and profit for 3Q2018, but lower profit for FY18 compared to FY17.

site_title: Volkswagen profit jumps, but 'great challenges' ahead
summary: Volkswagen reported a 6.8% year-on-year increase in second-quarter net profit to 3.3 billion euros, beating analyst expectations. Despite this, the company warned of "great challenges" ahead due to strict new emissions tests and global trade tensions. The company's new CEO, Herbert Diess, cautioned that VW cannot rest on its laurels as it adapts to the new WLTP test procedure and navigates EU-US trade tensions. VW confirmed its full-year outlook, expecting revenues up to 5% higher and an operating profit margin of 6.5-7.5%.

site_title: BreadTalk Q2 net profit up 10.5% to S$2.4m
summary: BreadTalk Group reported a 10.5% increase in Q2 net profit to S$2.4 million, driven by growth in its Food Atrium, restaurant, and 4orth Food Concepts divisions. Revenue remained flat at S$148.8 million. The company recommended a special dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share for FY2018. Despite a 72.2% decrease in first-half net profit to S$3.6 million, BreadTalk plans to leverage technology to improve efficiency and expand its brands.

site_title: Ascott adds 2 Citadines Viet properties
summary: The Ascott Ltd, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has opened two new properties in Vietnam: the 548-unit Citadines Blue Cove Danang in Danang and the 229-unit Citadines Regency Saigon in Ho Chi Minh City. These properties are part of Ascott's 21 properties across seven cities in Vietnam, with plans to open over 2,000 units in the next three years. The company cites high demand for serviced residences in Vietnam, with Lew Yen Ping, country general manager, stating that Vietnam is Ascott's largest market in South-east Asia.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's SMEs are top exporters in the Asia-Pacific, generating an average annual exporting revenue of US$1.75 million. Google is investing US$350 million to build its third data centre in Singapore, bringing its total investment to US$850 million. Meanwhile, a residential and commercial project at Mohamed Sultan Road has been put up for sale for S$30 million, and a rare strata office portfolio in Tanjong Pagar's GB Building is up for sale. Singapore's financial sector will undergo the IMF's comprehensive assessment for the third time.

site_title: Temasek-backed GDS Holdings hits back against short-seller
summary: GDS Holdings, a Nasdaq-listed datacentre developer and operator in China, has hit back against a short-seller report alleging chicanery and overstating its performance. The report, from Texas-based Blue Orca Capital, accused the company of inflating its profits and overpaying for acquisitions. GDS denies the allegations, stating its SEC filings accurately reflect the amounts paid for acquisitions. The company also disputes claims about its flagship datacentre's occupancy rate and accounts receivables. Despite the allegations, one broker has defended GDS, citing its strong track record and large shareholder Temasek Holdings.

site_title: Pacific Radiance granted moratorium on creditors' actions
summary: Pacific Radiance has been granted a moratorium on creditors' actions until it completes restructuring discussions with stakeholders. The court allowed the moratorium to protect the company from creditor attempts to enforce claims while restructuring talks are ongoing. Pacific Radiance must submit a report on asset valuation and provide forecasts of profitability and cash flow to creditors. Trading of its shares has been voluntarily suspended since February 28.

site_title: Hong Kong June retail sales see double digit growth for 5th month
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales experienced double-digit growth for the fifth consecutive month in June, with a 12% increase in value terms to HK$37.8 billion. The growth was driven by strong consumer sentiment, a tight labor market, and an increase in mainland visitors. This marks the 16th month of expansion for Hong Kong's retail sector, with total sales rising 13.4% in value terms and 11.8% in volume terms for the first six months of 2018.

site_title: US hiring surges in July: ADP survey
summary: US private firms hired 219,000 new jobs in July, surpassing economists' expectations and fueling concerns about inflation. The strong labor market, led by the services sector, suggests wages may accelerate, while tariffs have yet to have a major impact on jobs. The ADP survey comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, which is expected to hike rates twice more this year. The robust job growth could lead to a dip in the unemployment rate and increased inflation, prompting the Fed to be more aggressive about controlling the economy.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC are expanding cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Trump's ex-lawyer Cohen sells stakes in NY apartment buildings
summary: Michael Cohen, former US President Donald Trump's personal attorney, has sold his stakes in two Manhattan apartment buildings, 330 East 63rd St and 133 Avenue D, for a combined US$13 million. Cohen cleared approximately US$7 million after purchasing his shares in 2015. The sale was made through trusts connected to Eric Nelson, a co-investor in the buildings. This comes as Cohen's finances have deteriorated due to the decline in value of his taxi medallions, and he recently pleaded guilty to eight criminal counts.

site_title: RBI hikes key rate for 2nd straight meet; 'neutral' stance kept
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) raised its key interest rate by 25 basis points to 6.50% for the second consecutive meeting, maintaining its "neutral" stance to contain inflation without stifling growth. The decision aligns with a Reuters poll and follows global central banks' tightening paths. RBI Governor Urjit Patel warned of rising trade protectionism posing a risk to global growth, while trimming inflation projections for the current quarter.

site_title: Dubai tourism growth slows in first half of 2018
summary: Dubai's tourism growth slowed in the first half of 2018, with a 0.5% increase in foreign visitors compared to the 10.6% growth in the same period last year. The city hosted 8.1 million international overnight tourists, a decrease from the 8.06 million reported in the first half of 2017. India remained Dubai's top overseas market, with a 3% increase in visitors, while Chinese and Russian tourists grew by 9% and 74%, respectively. The slowdown in tourism growth is attributed to a decline in passenger traffic through Dubai's international airport and a slowdown in the real estate sector.

site_title: Trump says attorney general should stop Mueller probe 'right now'
summary: US President Donald Trump called on Attorney General Jeff Sessions to end the Mueller probe into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, labeling it a "TOTAL HOAX." Trump tweeted that Sessions should "stop this Rigged Witch Hunt right now" and claimed Special Counsel Robert Mueller is "totally conflicted." The Mueller probe is ongoing, with Manafort's trial beginning in Alexandria, Virginia, and the investigation examining potential obstruction of justice by Trump or his campaign.

site_title: No Nafta deal, talks to resume next week
summary: US-Canada trade negotiations ended without a deal on Friday, with talks set to resume next week. Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland left the US trade representative's offices in Washington, indicating a resumption of negotiations. The Canadian official stated that talks will continue, but no details on a potential deal were disclosed. The development marks a setback in the bid to reach a continental trade pact, leaving the outcome uncertain.

site_title: EZ-Link promotes e-payment adoption with free auto top-up, loose-change top-up
summary: EZ-Link, a Singaporean company, has announced the removal of a S$0.25 convenience fee for its EZ-Reload service, which automatically tops up registered ez-link cards when insufficient value is present. This move aims to promote e-payment adoption and discourage cash use. EZ-Link also simplified the application process for EZ-Reload and partnered with convenience stores and fintech companies to facilitate cash-to-card transactions. The company hopes to contribute to Singapore's goal of reducing cash handling and promoting e-payment adoption, with 3.4 million ez-link cardholders and 400,000 EZ-Reload users in Singapore.

site_title: Kingboard Copper Q2 net profit up 50.4% to HK$6.6m
summary: Kingboard Copper Holdings reported a 50.4% increase in Q2 net profit to HK$6.6 million, driven by a 15.13% year-on-year rise in revenue to HK$158.2 million. Revenue from polyvinyl butyral (PVB) resin sales rose, but was impacted by restrictions on residential units in China affecting the construction industry. The company aims to improve production efficiency, reduce costs, and shorten lead time to deliver greater returns to shareholders. Earnings per share increased to 0.92 HK cent from 0.61 HK cent in the same period.

site_title: Deloitte to offer legal services through new foreign law practice
summary: Deloitte has launched Deloitte Legal International, a licensed foreign law practice providing full international legal services from Singapore. The new practice is part of the global Deloitte Legal network of over 2,000 professionals in 80 countries. Led by managing director Rashed Idrees, it will serve clients across various sectors, offering services in commercial law, mergers and acquisitions, and infrastructure projects. This move follows similar announcements by PwC and EY to boost their legal service offerings, positioning Deloitte as a one-stop shop for clients.

site_title: Moya Holdings net profit up more than five-fold to S$7.2m
summary: Moya Holdings Asia reported a net profit of S$7.2 million for the second quarter, a six-fold increase from S$1.2 million in the same period last year, driven by contributions from a new acquisition. Revenue rose 130% year-over-year to S$48.6 million. The company's first-half net profit reached S$16 million, with revenue increasing to S$93.6 million. Moya Holdings plans to consolidate private water treatment players in Indonesia through mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Fitch ratings agency says Italian debt outlook now 'negative'
summary: Fitch ratings agency has downgraded Italy's long-term debt outlook to 'negative' due to the risks of a new, untested coalition government. The agency expects fiscal loosening, potentially exposing Italy's high public debt to potential shocks. This revision comes after the coalition, formed by the Five Star Movement and Lega Nord, took power in May. The move is seen as a concern for investors, with Italy's high debt levels and potential for fiscal expansion.

site_title: Mars dust storm clears, raising hope for stalled Nasa rover
summary: NASA's 15-year-old Mars rover Opportunity is nearing a possible revival after a nearly three-month dust storm clears on the Red Planet. The rover went silent in June, and if no contact is made after 45 days, NASA will give up efforts. However, team members remain cautiously optimistic, citing Opportunity's past resilience. Passive listening efforts will continue, and a former rover driver, Mike Siebert, criticized the 45-day timeframe, calling it "woefully insufficient."

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust Q3 DPU up 2.9%
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) reported a 2.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.8 Singapore cents for the fiscal third quarter ended June 30. The reit's gross revenue rose 22.6% to A$49.3 million, with adjusted net property income increasing 27.4% to A$39.3 million. FLT's portfolio remained near full occupancy at 99.3% and aggregate leverage was 36.3%, providing adequate available debt headroom for growth.

site_title: China Tower raises US$6.9b in IPO priced at low end
summary: China Tower Corp raised US$6.9 billion in its Hong Kong IPO priced at HK$1.26 apiece, at the low end of a marketed range. The company sold 43.1 billion shares, making it the world's largest first-time stock sale since 2016. The IPO comes amid global trade war concerns, with the Hang Seng Index down 15% from its January high. China Tower plans to use 60% of the proceeds for capital expenditure and 30% to repay bank loans.

site_title: Indonesia-Australia push economic ties, trade deal soon
summary: Indonesia and Australia concluded talks on an economic partnership, aiming to boost trade in areas like cars and cattle, as well as relax controls on investing in services in Indonesia. Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison visited Indonesia, marking his first overseas trip since taking office. The talks led to a commitment to strengthen economic ties, with Indonesian President Joko Widodo describing it as a strong commitment to build relations. A trade deal is expected to be signed soon.

site_title: Vodafone seals merger to become India's biggest telecoms group
summary: Vodafone completed a merger with Idea Cellular to become India's largest telecom group, surpassing Bharti Airtel with 400 million customers. The $23 billion merger was approved by the National Company Law Tribunal and generated $11.34 billion in revenues in 2018. The deal is expected to further disrupt India's telecom industry, which is projected to reach $50 billion in revenue by 2020. The merger follows the launch of Jio, a market-defying telecom operator launched by Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries in 2016, sparking a wave of consolidation in the sector.

site_title: Malaysia shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.06 points to 1,788.31 on Wednesday, driven by a higher volume of 23.29 million lots worth RM20.05 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 449 to 443. The rally comes as global markets continue to push forward despite US trade tensions, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.27% up on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 0.27% higher at 3,328.95, with 1.51 billion shares worth S$1.10 billion changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 235 to 177, and active stocks including DBS Bank and Singtel rose 0.71% and 0.31% respectively.

site_title: Hour Glass Q1 net profit more than doubles to S$14.3m
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 100% increase in Q1 net profit to S$14.3 million, driven by improved gross margins to 24.4%. Revenue rose 10% to S$180.7 million, with earnings per share increasing to 2.03 Singapore cents. The company's inventory stood at S$277.8 million and cash reserves at S$188.0 million. The Hour Glass expects to be profitable for the financial year, citing improved consumer sentiment in the watch sector.

site_title: BlackRock voted to replace Tesla's Musk with independent board chair
summary: BlackRock-managed funds voted in favor of a shareholder proposal to replace Tesla's CEO Elon Musk with an independent board chairman, despite Musk's role as both chairman and CEO. The proposal was initially defeated in June, but BlackRock's vote was not previously reported. The proposal aims to improve oversight and address concerns about Musk's pay and board independence. BlackRock's approach to investment stewardship is driven by its fiduciary duties to clients, aiming to drive long-term shareholder value.

site_title: Europe: Shares flat as earnings optimism overtakes trade war fears
summary: European shares were flat on Wednesday as corporate earnings, particularly from France's BNP Paribas, offset concerns over the US-China trade conflict. The pan-European STOXX 600 remained unchanged, while Germany's DAX gained 0.1% and France's CAC 40 rose 0.3%. Earnings optimism from sectors like mining and healthcare supported shares.

site_title: Pussy Riot members freed over World Cup protest
summary: Russian police unexpectedly released four Pussy Riot members, Pyotr Verzilov, Veronika Nikulshina, Olga Kuracheva, and Olga Pakhtusova, after a judge refused to hear their case over technicalities. The activists had been charged for invading the pitch at the World Cup final in Moscow, where they briefly protested as police. They had already served a 15-day sentence and a fine for violating event rules and wearing police uniforms. The group may face up to 25 more days in jail, but they were released after a night in police custody and a day awaiting a hearing.

site_title: Ezion announces changes in senior management
summary: Ezion Holdings has announced changes in senior management to sharpen focus on business priorities and operational efficiency. Goon Fook Wye Paul will be appointed as chief group business officer, relinquishing his group CFO position, while Chong Chee Wei Alan will become acting CFO. Paul will also retain his role as joint company secretary. These changes aim to drive strategic and commercial plans, as well as improve financial functions and investor relations.

site_title: Singapore SMEs top exporters in Asia-Pacific: FedEx survey
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) were the top exporters in the Asia-Pacific region in 2018, generating an average annual exporting revenue of US$1.75 million, ahead of the regional average. The digital economy drove business growth, with 78% of SMEs using e-commerce, social commerce, and mobile commerce. However, SMEs face challenges in exports, including customs procedures, logistics, and foreign currency exchange issues. To overcome these obstacles, SMEs must remain agile and seek new innovations to ensure a strong supply chain.

site_title: Windy Heights launches second tender for collective sale; unit owners seek to slash reserve price
summary: Windy Heights, a four-block development in Kembangan, is launching its second collective sale tender. Owners aim to lower the reserve price to S$750 million from S$806.2 million, with the goal of garnering enough fresh signatures. This would result in a land rate of S$1,089 psf ppr. The tender closes on September 7. The move is seen as a response to the limited supply of new launches in the Kembangan and Bedok area, with Knight Frank expecting strong demand for the property.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won gain ahead of FOMC decision
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.51% to 2,307.07 ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) decision, while the won edged up 0.17% to 1,120.6 per dollar. Shares of cosmetics makers gained ahead of South Korea-China high-level talks. Despite fears of an escalation in the US-China tariff war, foreigners were net buyers of 174,379 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai stocks end sharply lower
